summary: Singapore's business prospects are expected to improve, with more companies anticipating growth over worsening prospects, a U-turn from last year's coronavirus blues. However, economists say this optimism won't translate into a job market rebound, citing unchanged economic forecasts. Despite this, the government remains committed to supporting businesses, including offering grants and training programs to help workers future-proof their careers.

site_title: Oil pares gains on worries about Coronavirus vaccine rollout
summary: Oil prices edged up slightly on Friday, but traded in a tight range, due to concerns over coronavirus vaccine rollout and slow vaccine distribution. Despite a bullish sentiment from a cut in Saudi Arabian oil supply and falling US oil inventories, prices were offset by worries about the vaccine rollout and potential delays in a US economic stimulus package. Global benchmark Brent crude futures rose 0.8% to $55.97 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.1% to $52.36.

site_title: KL urged to lift quarantine rules for vaccinated Singaporeans
summary: Malaysian tourism and trade groups urge the Malaysian government to discuss with Singapore the possibility of allowing vaccinated Singaporeans to enter Malaysia without quarantine. This move is crucial for the recovery of the local economy and the tourism sector, which has suffered greatly due to the pandemic. Industry players, including hotel associations and the Chinese Chamber of Commerce, hope that starting discussions will give them a chance to recover and adapt to changes in the post-pandemic landscape.

site_title: Russia to launch 'Sputnik-Light' Covid vaccine in Feb
summary: Russia plans to launch the one-dose "Sputnik-Light" version of its Covid vaccine in February, which could be used for export to help countries with high infection rates make their vaccine supplies last longer. The vaccine is a possible temporary solution to address global vaccine shortages.

site_title: Metro-led fund to acquire student accommodation property in Bristol, UK for £30.1 million
summary: Metro Holdings' student accommodation fund Paideia Capital UK Trust has acquired a property in Bristol, UK, for £30.1 million. The £4 million equity commitment is funded by internal cash and borrowings. The six-storey property, Dean Street Works, has 44 studios and 181 ensuite units, with a 100% occupancy rate. The acquisition is part of Metro's ordinary course of business and is not expected to impact its financials.

site_title: Are cheaper funds really better bets?
summary: Investors often prioritize lower fees when selecting investment funds, but a study reveals that the relationship between fees and performance is not as straightforward. In fact, many actively managed funds with high fees can outperform their peers, while cheaper funds may underperform. This is because highly skilled managers can capture more value in fees, making it unlikely that the best managers are clustered in low-cost funds. Instead, investors should focus on a fund's value added net of costs, and avoid relying solely on fees when making investment decisions.

site_title: Reddit ignites mall stock, letting fund cash out US$500m
summary: The largest shareholder of Macerich, a high-end mall owner, sold its entire 24.56 million shares, generating nearly US$500 million after the stock surged 68% following a Reddit mention. The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, which owned 16.4% of the company, sold the shares at an average price of US$20.25 a share. The sale comes after the company's shares were touted on Reddit, sparking a significant increase in value.

site_title: Europe: Stocks post worst week since October on vaccine woes
summary: Europe's stocks recorded their worst weekly performance since October, closing 1.9% lower, amid concerns over the slow rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and a new strain of the coronavirus. The US also saw a decline, with stocks falling more than 1% after underwhelming vaccine data from Johnson & Johnson. Europe's medicines regulator approved the AstraZeneca and Oxford University vaccine for people over 18, but the bloc still urgently needs more shots to speed up its inoculation program.

images.alt_text: European stocks slid on Friday, recording their worst weekly performance since October as concerns around the slow rollout of Covid-19 vaccines mount, while a retail trading frenzy led to volatility on Wall Street.

site_title: No hongbao for red packet makers this year
summary: Hongbao printers in Singapore are feeling the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, economic downturn, and climate consciousness on their business. Many companies have reduced their volume of physical hongbao printing, with some seeing a 20-30% fall in demand. Caston, Craftwerkz, and Switts, three design and production companies, have reported lower orders due to the pandemic and economic instability. To adapt, they are adopting eco-friendly practices, such as printing on FSC paper and offering reusable alternatives to plastic packaging. Despite the decline in the industry, hongbao printers remain confident in their place in Singapore's culture.

site_title: US: Dow ends ugly session 2% lower; GameStop surges
summary: US stocks ended a volatile session on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2% to 29,982.62, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declining 1.9% and 2% respectively. The decline was partly due to concerns over lofty equity valuations and potential delays in US fiscal stimulus. Meanwhile, GameStop surged 70% after trading restrictions were lifted, as hedge funds face billions of dollars in losses from short-selling. Other companies, such as Johnson & Johnson and Chevron, also fell due to various reasons, including vaccine efficacy and quarterly losses.

site_title: China won't recognise British passport for HK residents from Jan 31
summary: China announced it will no longer recognize the British National (Overseas) passport for Hong Kong residents starting January 31, in response to Britain's plan to offer a visa and potential citizenship to Hong Kong people fleeing Beijing's crackdown on dissent. The move could lead to further confrontation with London and potential restrictions for holders of the passport. About 70% of Hong Kong's population, or 5.25 million, may be eligible for the passport, with Britain predicting up to 322,000 could arrive over five years.

site_title: Most analysts positive on Keppel's rig-building exit but trim targets; shares sink 8.2%
summary: Keppel Corp announced its intention to exit the rig-building business and focus on green energy, drawing mixed reactions from analysts. Most believe the decision could be a catalyst for growth, but some see risks from a prolonged O&M restructuring. Shares sank 8.2% to a two-month low, closing at S$5.01. Analysts UOBKH, CGS-CIMB, and DBS maintained "buy" or "hold" calls, but lowered target prices, citing the need for better positive indicators.

site_title: Pump and dump finds a new home - on social media and chat forums
summary: A penny-stock craze has emerged on social media and chat forums, with a small, obscure company called Blue Sphere Corp suddenly soaring 451% in just one day. The stock's price rise was fueled by a group of traders, including a prominent figure on the Stocktwits platform, who promoted the stock as a "clean-energy" opportunity. The phenomenon is similar to past "pump-and-dump" schemes, where a group of people buy up a stock to artificially inflate its price before selling it at a profit. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has not taken action, but some experts warn of the risks of speculative investing.

images.alt_text: On any given day, there are a dozen or more stories of tiny, profitless companies that mysteriously go from obscurity to viral sensation. Lately the frenzied pace of boom and bust in these penny stocks has started to drown out all the other forms of speculative mania in the pandemic-era market.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps above US$38,000 as Musk adds it to Twitter profile
summary: Bitcoin surged above US$38,000 after Tesla founder Elon Musk mentioned the cryptocurrency on his Twitter profile, sparking a 15% intraday price spike. Musk's tweet, accompanied by a #bitcoin hashtag, fueled speculation about his potential investment in the cryptocurrency. Bitcoin pared gains later in the day, but remained up 11% to US$37,088. The move also led to a surge in Dogecoin prices, jumping 300% in the last 24 hours, and cryptocurrency stocks such as Marathon Patent Group and Bit Digital.

site_title: No new Fed monetary stimulus measures: gold prices slide, silver up
summary: Gold prices ended the week with a lacklustre performance due to the Federal Reserve's mildly dovish stance and lack of new monetary stimulus measures. Despite this, silver prices rose as retail traders, including those on WallStreetBets, showed interest in the precious metal. The World Gold Council expects global gold demand to recover this year, driven by the economic recovery in China. Gold prices are expected to close the week at $1,830, with support at $1,800 and resistance at $1,874.

site_title: US household spending falls, while stimulus boosts incomes
summary: US household spending fell 0.2% in December, marking a second consecutive decline, as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact consumers. In contrast, personal incomes rose 0.6%, boosted by pandemic relief payments and supplemental jobless benefits. The increase in income partly reflected an increase in pandemic unemployment compensation, and personal saving rates rose to 13.7%, the first increase since April. Inflation-adjusted personal spending fell 0.6% in December, with the core price index increasing 1.5% year-over-year.

site_title: GameStop phenomenon spreads to Malaysian glove stocks
summary: Malaysian retail investors joined forces on social media to push up stocks of under-pressure rubber glove makers, inspired by the GameStop trading phenomenon in the US. The BursaBets group, set up on Reddit, urged people to buy and hold shares, targeting glove stocks as they fell after vaccines became available and were targeted by short sellers. Top Glove's stock soared over 8% the day after the group was set up, while rival companies Hartalega and Supermax also saw strong gains, with shares rising over 5% and 3.6% respectively.

site_title: To resume travel, develop system to verify Covid-19 tests, vaccines: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for international cooperation to tackle the global pandemic and its long-term challenges, including climate change. He called for a robust system to verify Covid-19 tests and vaccinations to resume international travel. Lee also highlighted the importance of stable great power relations and multilateral institutions, citing the need for regular constructive dialogue to build a stable international order.

site_title: Housing loans lift bank lending in December amid rising home prices
summary: Singapore's bank lending rose 0.3% to S$678.72 billion in December, driven by a 0.4% increase in housing loans to S$201.36 billion, lifting total consumer loans by 0.5% to S$259.62 billion. This growth was partly fueled by rising private home prices, which rose 2.1% in Q4 2020. Other consumer lending segments also saw upticks, while loans to businesses and general commerce contracted. Year-over-year, total bank lending fell 2%, with consumer loans down 1.2% and business loans down 2.4%.

site_title: Volvo XC90 T8 Recharge: Large and in charge
summary: The Volvo XC90 T8 Recharge is a large and heavy plug-in hybrid SUV with a solid and safe design, weighing 2,311kg. It offers 402 horsepower and 640 Newton meters of torque, but its performance is somewhat subdued due to its size and weight. The car is efficient, with a real-world test achieving 40km on pure electric power, but its electric range is limited by its battery size and charging time. The XC90 Recharge is a practical and comfortable family vehicle with a spacious interior, but its high price tag makes it less justifiable compared to other SUV options.

images.alt_text: The XC90, which exudes a sense of solidity and all-round practicality, has seven seats, and all seven are habitable.
The car can haul a huge amount of cargo if you fold its seats.

site_title: Singapore-Johor RTS Link: Second civil contract for viaduct and tunnels awarded
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore awarded a S$180 million contract to China Communications Construction Company (Singapore Branch) for the construction of a 25-metre-tall viaduct and rail tunnels for the Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link. This is the second civil contract for the project, following the ground-breaking ceremony last week. The RTS Link is a cross-border rail shuttle service connecting Singapore with Malaysia, and its construction is expected to improve connectivity and travel times between the two countries.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In other markets, European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. The US imposed fresh tariffs on Canada. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: The best time of day to exercise
summary: A new study suggests that exercising in the afternoon may be more beneficial for people with disrupted metabolisms than exercising in the morning. Researchers found that men with Type 2 diabetes who completed afternoon workouts had significantly better insulin sensitivity and lost more fat around their middles compared to those who exercised in the morning. The study's findings suggest that moderate afternoon exercise may help regulate blood sugar levels and improve overall metabolic health.

site_title: Reits (Jan 30-31, 2021)
summary: Reits saw significant price movements in the Jan 30-31, 2021 period. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World sold China property assets after securing a loan deal. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases expected. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its post-bankruptcy.

site_title: For Lampard and Chelsea, an encore without the cheers
summary: Frank Lampard was fired as Chelsea manager after a banner supporting him was unveiled by fans, reading "In Frank We Trust, Then. Now. Forever." The gesture demonstrated the fans' loyalty, but Lampard was let go the next morning. This marks the latest in a pattern of Chelsea's owner Roman Abramovich's ruthless impatience, with Lampard joining a list of previous managers who have been unceremoniously dismissed, including Carlo Ancelotti, Antonio Conte, and Jose Mourinho. The fans' display highlights the limited power they have in influencing Abramovich's decisions, despite their demonstrated loyalty.

site_title: US household spending falls, while stimulus boosts incomes
summary: US household spending fell 0.2% in December for the second-straight time, following a revised 0.7% decline in November. Despite this, personal incomes rose 0.6% due to the pandemic relief package and increased unemployment compensation. The US$900 billion stimulus package, which included stimulus payments and supplemental jobless benefits, contributed to the income boost. The decline in spending is attributed to state and city restrictions on businesses and activity, resulting in nearly half a million job losses in the leisure and hospitality sector.

site_title: Parliament to debate Bill on TraceTogether data use on Monday
summary: Singapore's Parliament will debate the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) (Amendment) Bill on February 1, which aims to formalize assurances that data from the TraceTogether contact tracing programme can be used for serious offences like murder and terrorism if needed for criminal investigations. The law, introduced by the Minister for Law, specifies that personal data collected through digital contact tracing solutions can be used only for contact tracing, with an exception for "clear and pressing" criminal investigations.

site_title: UN voices alarm about Myanmar after military threats, coup fears
summary: The United Nations and Western governments, including Australia, Britain, Canada, the European Union, and the US, have voiced alarm over threats by Myanmar's military that could lead to a coup following the country's disputed election. The military has demanded a resolution to its complaints about alleged voter fraud, while the civilian government has refused to back down. The UN Secretary-General has expressed great concern over the situation, and a ruling party spokesman has warned of the need for caution ahead of parliament's opening on Monday.

site_title: Is small really beautiful? The mixed case for art tokenisation
summary: Art tokenisation, a process combining fractionalisation and securitisation, allows ownership of artworks to be transferred to token holders via blockchains. However, its benefits are unclear, with concerns over the selection of artworks, valuation, and scalability. The concept promises transparency and liquidity but faces challenges in making art investment accessible to all investors. Investing in art aggregates, such as portfolios, funds, or indices, may be a more sustainable option for opening up art investment to small investors, with the art market expected to reach $2.215 trillion in 2023.

site_title: Dot-com era stock valuations bring bubble fears to ESG funds
summary: ESG funds, which invest in companies with responsible environmental, social, and corporate governance practices, saw a record $85 billion in US and European investments in 2020. However, rising stock valuations are sparking concerns about a bubble. Stocks are trading at price-to-earnings multiples that are increasingly difficult to justify, casting doubt on the sustainability of ESG fund growth. This raises questions about the long-term viability of these investments.

site_title: From values to value: The risk of not investing sustainably
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for sustainable business practices, with governments, companies, and investors recognizing the importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations. The US and Asian countries, such as Japan, South Korea, and Singapore, have stepped up their sustainability efforts, with China aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The investment community is also playing a crucial role in channeling funds to support sustainable enterprises and business models. As technology advances, FinTech companies are enabling sustainable investing, and a shift in mindset is required to overcome skepticism and inertia, with sustainable investing seen as complementary to traditional investment concepts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 14.22 points to 1,566.40, following a losing streak. Losers outnumbered gainers 869 to 367, with a total volume of 6.535 billion lots worth RM6.373 billion.

site_title: Emerging Towns and Cities, Hong Lai Huat warn of FY20 losses
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) and Hong Lai Huat Group have issued profit warnings for FY 2020, citing losses due to fair value losses on investment properties and lower sales revenue. ETC attributed the loss to Golden City project, while Hong Lai Huat blamed the Covid-19 pandemic. Both companies are still finalizing FY 2020 results and have seen shares trade relatively unchanged.

site_title: Ezion to sell liftboat for US$13m; gain on disposal is US$650k
summary: Ezion Holdings will sell its liftboat, Teras Conquest 7, for US$13 million, resulting in a gain of US$650,000. The vessel's net book value was US$12.3 million. The sale will help Ezion reduce its outstanding liabilities by partially repaying secured bank loans. The disposal will not affect the company's issued and paid-up share capital. Trading in Ezion shares has been suspended since March 2019.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. Stocks in Europe and the US edged down, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging, as US-EU tariffs remained a focus. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and an Indonesian employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: LSE looks at 'blank cheque' deals to keep London ahead after Brexit
summary: London Stock Exchange (LSE) CEO David Schwimmer suggests replicating New York's "blank cheque" listings to boost London's appeal as a global financial centre after Brexit. The LSE is set to play a central role in keeping Britain's huge financial services sector competitive. Schwimmer also notes that SPACs, or Special Purpose Acquisition Companies, have become popular in the US markets and may be of interest to London. A government-backed review of Britain's listing rules is underway to make recommendations to help London compete better with New York.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit divests industrial property in Japan for 2.9b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit divested its non-core industrial property in Japan, P-Life Matsudo, for 2.9 billion yen (S$37.1 million), recognizing an estimated gain of S$5.1 million. The divestment aligns with its asset recycling strategy to rebalance its Japan portfolio, bolstering its balance sheet and providing financial flexibility for future investments. The property was Parkway Life Reit's maiden industrial investment in Japan, and the sale yield was 4.3%.

site_title: China stresses party leadership in corporate governance of banks and insurers
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator has issued draft rules emphasizing stronger Communist Party leadership in corporate governance of state-owned and private banks and insurers to contain risks. The rules prioritize key business decisions made by the Communist Party committee over board and top leadership consultations. The regulations also limit individual appointments to multiple independent directorships and urge lenders and insurers to take responsibility for environmental, social, and corporate governance. This move aims to strengthen financial institutions' governance and mitigate potential weaknesses in the country's financial system.

images.alt_text: Malaysian retail investors joined forces on social media and pushed up stocks of under-pressure rubber glove makers on Friday, taking inspiration from the recent GameStop trading phenomenon in the US.

site_title: Better business sentiment - but no big boost to Singapore economy or jobs yet: Analysts
summary: Singapore's business sentiment has improved, with 32% of manufacturers expecting business conditions to beat last quarter's, and 7% of services companies expecting improvement. However, this optimism is not expected to translate into a significant boost to the economy or jobs. Economists predict a gradual recovery in 2021, but manufacturing output is expected to expand at a modest pace, and the wider economy is likely to remain negative year-on-year. The job market is also expected to remain tepid, with few employers planning to hire more workers.

site_title: Former China Huarong chairman executed after bribery conviction
summary: Former China Huarong chairman Lai Xiaomin was executed after being convicted of bribery charges, totaling US$278 million, by a Tianjin court. He was also found guilty of corruption and bigamy charges. Lai's "significant meritorious service" was deemed insufficient given the harm caused by his crimes. This follows President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has led to hundreds of officials being prosecuted. Lai was expelled from the Communist Party in 2018.

images.alt_text: The former chairman of China Huarong Asset Management, Lai Xiaomin, was executed on Friday following his conviction on bribery charges by a court in Tianjin, the official People's Daily reported.

site_title: The GameStop reckoning was a long time coming
summary: A group of online investors in Reddit's r/WallStreetBets forum orchestrated a "short squeeze" that pushed up GameStop's stock price, entrapping hedge funds that had bet against it. This move was seen as a populist revolt against Wall Street establishment, with the online community gleefully participating in the drama. The incident has been described as an "absurdist" and "righteous" act, with the online community potentially profiting from the chaos. The event has sparked a significant reaction in the financial markets.

site_title: US data centre contribution boosts MIT's Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's (MIT) Q3 DPU increased to 3.28 Singapore cents due to a 20.5% rise in gross revenue to S$123.7 million, mainly from US data centres. Rental reliefs extended to tenants and redevelopment losses offset the gains. MIT's average occupancy rate rose to 93.1% and rental rates increased to S$2.11 psf/month. The manager expects strong demand for high-quality data centre space in 2021 but growth will plateau as the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore businesses have turned positive again, with more companies expecting business prospects to improve than worsen, according to surveys. Home loan growth lifted Singapore bank lending, reaching S$678.72 billion in December. Meanwhile, corporate earnings reported mixed results, with CapitaLand China Trust and CDL Hospitality Trusts experiencing declines in distributions per unit, while Micro-Mechanics Q2 net profit rose 24.6%. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Friday, ending the week in the red.

site_title: Hong Kong economy shrank a record 6.1% in 2020
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted a record 6.1% in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, which followed widespread political unrest in 2019. The city's GDP declined 3% in the last quarter of 2020, leading to the record decline. Social distancing measures, imposed to control the pandemic, had a significant impact on the economy. Private consumption expenditure fell 10.2% and exports and imports of services decreased by 36.8% and 35.2% respectively. Unemployment reached 6.6%, its highest in 16 years. The economy is expected to see positive growth in 2021, but the first half of the year will remain challenging.

site_title: Europe: Markets sink in opening deals
summary: European stock markets plummeted in early trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index losing 1.6% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices shedding 1.8% and 1.7%, respectively. Investors remained cautious amid concerns over the pandemic's impact and US-EU trade tensions. The declines were attributed to a drag from banks and healthcare sectors.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts' H2 DPS falls 29.2% to 3.44 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 29.2% decline in second-half 2020 distribution per stapled security to 3.44 Singapore cents, from 4.86 cents a year ago. Gross revenue fell 36.5% to S$65.5 million and net property income dropped 46.2% to S$39.6 million. The managers attributed the decline to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 crisis on the hospitality and conference businesses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end in the red again
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined for the second consecutive day, falling 0.94% to 28,283.71, amidst investor concerns over rising infections, vaccine rollouts, and high valuations. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped 0.63% and 0.75%, respectively. The losses followed a painful week for global markets, with investors cautious about the impact of surging infections, stuttering vaccine rollouts, and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Shopper360 CEO Matthew Ho Weiern has resigned effective March 1, 2020, to focus on family commitments. Chew Sue Ann will take over as group CEO. Parkway Life Reit is divesting its Japanese industrial property for $36.8 million, expected to result in a gain of $5.1 million. EZION Holdings sold a liftboat for $13 million, reducing outstanding liabilities. Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore and Hong Lai Huat Group are expected to report losses for FY2020 due to fair value losses and revenue decline from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SGX, Temasek JV partners Covalent Capital for end-to-end digital infrastructure
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Temasek have partnered with Covalent Capital to build the Asia-Pacific's first end-to-end digital infrastructure in the fixed income space. Marketnode, the joint venture between SGX and Temasek, will acquire a minority stake in Covalent and collaborate to streamline the listing, processing, and settlement of bonds. The partnership aims to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance price transparency in the capital markets, with a focus on post-trade and asset servicing.

site_title: Metro unit acquires 30% stake in UK student accommodation property for £4m
summary: Metro Holdings' student accommodation fund, Paideia Capital UK Trust, has acquired a £30.1 million property in Bristol, UK, for 30% stake, with Metro's wholly-owned subsidiary Sun Capital Assets holding 30% and other parties holding the remaining 70%. The property, Dean Street Works, has 44 studios and 181 ensuite units, with a 100% occupancy rate. Metro's equity commitment to the acquisition is £4 million, funded by internal cash and external borrowings, with no expected impact on the company's financials.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post weekly loss as foreigners lead profit taking
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 3.03% to 2,976.21 on Friday, marking a fourth consecutive session of losses, due to heavy profit taking by foreign investors. Net foreign selling of 1,432.8 billion won (S$1.7 billion) occurred, with shares of Samsung Biologics and Hyundai Motor dropping 5.37% and 3.98%, respectively. The Kospi has risen 3.58% so far this year, but volatility from US market fluctuations, including GameStop losses, may have contributed to the losses.

site_title: Philippines set sights on hydrogen to diversify energy sources
summary: The Philippines has signed a memorandum of understanding with Australia-based Star Scientific Ltd to explore the potential of hydrogen as a fuel source. The country aims to diversify its energy mix and reduce CO2 emissions. A hydrogen manufacturing facility is being constructed in the Philippines, and the government and Australian partner will investigate hydrogen production to make the country energy independent. The use of hydrogen worldwide is expected to grow, particularly in the transport, building, and power generation sectors.

site_title: UK says upholding 'freedom and autonomy' with new Hong Kong visas
summary: The UK has launched a new visa scheme for Hong Kong residents holding British National (Overseas) status, allowing them to live and work in the UK for up to five years and potentially seek citizenship. The move comes in response to China's National Security Law, which has devastated Hong Kong's democracy movement. Approximately 322,400 Hong Kong residents may benefit from the scheme, with estimated economic benefits of up to £2.9 billion. The UK has defended its actions as standing up for freedom and autonomy, while China has accused London of flouting the handover agreement.

site_title: SIA Engineering posts net profit of S$7.7m in Q3, propped up by government grants
summary: SIA Engineering reported a net profit of S$7.7 million in Q3 2020, down 85.7% from the previous year, due to low flight activities and reduced aircraft numbers. The group's revenue decreased by 58.5% year-on-year. Government grants, particularly the Jobs Support Scheme, partially cushioned the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Without these grants, the group would have recorded a loss of S$44.7 million.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel slides 7% after rigbuilding exit, pivot to clean energy
summary: Keppel Corporation's shares dropped 7.3% to a two-month low after the conglomerate announced a radical reboot to exit the rig business and pivot to clean energy. The move comes amid record losses of S$1.19 billion in 2020 for Keppel Offshore & Marine, the conglomerate's offshore and marine unit. The restructuring is expected to free up stranded rig assets and provide a healthy balance sheet, with a robust net order book of S$3.3 billion in renewables and gas solutions.

site_title: Why the Grab-Gojek ride was not meant to be
summary: Grab and Gojek's potential merger talks collapsed due to a lack of compromise, complexity of the deal, and market sentiment. Key reasons for the failure included valuation disputes, with neither company willing to concede being the smaller party, and disagreements over corporate structure, including control of the combined entity. Anti-competition concerns also arose, with Grab's previous merger with Uber's South-east Asian operations drawing attention from regulators. Additionally, public backlash from Indonesian motorbike operators and riders who feared job losses and uncertainty over their rights also contributed to the talks' demise.

images.alt_text: Grab and Gojek's potential union had the market abuzz for almost a year.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on mining losses
summary: Australian shares closed 0.6% lower on Friday, posting a 2.8% weekly loss, due to mining stocks' decline following Chinese iron ore futures' drop. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,607.4. Miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP, closed 1.8% lower, their worst week since March 2020. The decline was attributed to concerns over demand and US hedge-funds' short positions.

site_title: Hong Kong Monetary Authority's quota for intra-day yuan funding nearly used up
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) 10 billion yuan quota for intra-day yuan funding was nearly used up by Friday, indicating tighter yuan liquidity conditions. China's short-term money rates rose for a fifth consecutive day, exceeding the central bank's interest rate corridor ceiling. This suggests the central bank may be shifting towards a tighter monetary policy. The developments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: RTS Link: Second civil contract for viaduct and tunnels awarded
summary: The second civil contract for the Johor Baru-Singapore RTS Link was awarded to China Communications Construction Company Limited (Singapore Branch) for S$180 million. The contract covers the construction of a 25m-tall viaduct and connecting rail tunnels spanning the Strait of Johor. Work is expected to start in the next quarter, with the 4-km RTS Link expected to be operational by end-2026, carrying up to 10,000 passengers per hour. The project will ease congestion on the Causeway and features a terminus station and immigration complex in Woodlands North.

site_title: Biden talks the talk in first 10 days - but can he deliver?
summary: US President Joe Biden has signed multiple executive orders in his first 10 days, overturning rules from his predecessor Donald Trump. Despite this, Biden's presidency is not marked by dramatic or divisive actions, instead focusing on unity and fact-based briefings. The country faces major challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic and economic contraction, which could impact Biden's success. With vaccinations and economic revival expected to be key factors, Biden's presidency hinges on his ability to deliver on these fronts, with bipartisan Senate support for his economic relief package being a crucial test.

images.alt_text: Normal is the new extraordinary under President Joe Biden.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Friday to end week in the red; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks closed lower on Friday, ending a second week in the red, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.6% to 2,902.52. The decline follows a broader Asia-Pacific market downturn. Despite gloomy vaccination news, market strategist Stephen Innes sees a positive outlook due to unprecedented monetary and fiscal stimulus, a potential economic rebound, and a chance of inflation.

site_title: Singapore businesses turn positive again on six-month outlook: surveys
summary: Singapore businesses have turned positive again on their six-month outlook, according to official quarterly surveys. A net weighted balance of 32% of manufacturers expect the business situation to be better than the last quarter of 2020, while a 7% positive net weighted balance in the services sector marks a turnaround from four straight quarters of negativity. The optimism is driven by a rosier global economic climate and the roll-out of Covid-19 vaccines, with biomedical manufacturers being the most optimistic, followed by precision engineering and electronics clusters.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises iFast TP to S$6.40 on strong earnings projections
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price for iFast to S$6.40, citing strong earnings projections and growth potential in the wealth management platform's total assets under administration (AUA). The firm attributes iFast's 72% share price surge to a potential contract win for Hong Kong's pension fund project, which could contribute over S$10 million to the firm's bottomline. DBS expects iFast to grow its AUA by 30% in FY2021 and 20% in FY2022, driven by its scalable business model and digitalization efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Friday's session with a rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.96% gain, rising 275.41 points to 28,826.18, following a volatile week amid concerns about high valuations and virus infections. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, rising 0.47% and 0.98% respectively. The rally comes after a week of global market fluctuations.

site_title: ANA posts Q3 operating loss of US$779m on virus-related travel curbs
summary: ANA Holdings reported a Q3 operating loss of US$779.10 million due to virus-related travel curbs, beating an estimated average loss of 83.8 billion yen. This is slightly better than the year-ago loss of 40.7 billion yen. ANA maintains its full-year forecast for a record operating loss of 505 billion yen. The airline's result is attributed to reduced demand for flights amidst fresh coronavirus restrictions.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q2 net profit rises 24.6% to S$4.5m
summary: Micro-Mechanics Holdings, a semiconductor industry manufacturer, reported a 24.6% increase in Q2 net profit to S$4.5 million, driven by revenue growth of 15.2% to S$18.7 million. The company attributed the growth to the semiconductor industry's buoyant growth. For the half year, net profit rose 33% to S$9.1 million, with revenue up 16.7% to S$36.9 million. Micro-Mechanics declared an interim dividend of six Singapore cents per share for FY2021, with plans to accelerate key investments in new machining technology.

site_title: 24 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 24 new Covid-19 cases on January 29, all of which were imported. The cases include two individuals who have tested preliminarily positive for the B117 strain of the virus, which is circulating in Britain. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 59,449, with 59,133 patients fully recovered and 40 patients remaining in hospital.

images.alt_text: There were 24 new coronavirus cases confirmed as at Friday noon (Jan 29), all of them imported.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.45 points to 1,582.07. Volume reached 985.47 million lots worth RM1.05 billion, with losers beating gainers 439 to 272.

site_title: Home loans lift Singapore bank lending to end higher in December: MAS
summary: Singapore's bank lending rose 0.3% in December, driven by steady growth in housing loans, reaching S$678.72 billion. Consumer loans increased 0.5% to S$259.62 billion, while business loans rose 0.2% to S$419.12 billion. Despite a 2% year-on-year decline, December's lending marks the second consecutive month of growth. This follows a 2.1% quarterly increase in private home prices in Q4 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending rallies on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.35% and the Topix index gaining 0.16%. The gains were driven by investors focusing on corporate earnings.

site_title: China boosts cadres in Hong Kong by 100, as Beijing tightens supervision of city
summary: China has deployed an additional 100 cadres to its top Hong Kong office to reinforce Beijing's supervision of the city. This move follows the imposition of new security laws and the arrest of political opponents in the past year. The new cadres will oversee policy implementation, contain the coronavirus, and build bridges with young people who have expressed anger towards Beijing. They will also be tasked with identifying long-term governance challenges and promoting a "down-to-earth working style" that adheres to Communist Party discipline. The move aims to ensure Hong Kong is ruled by patriots.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to profit-taking, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 1.89% and the Topix index falling 1.64%. Investors focused on corporate earnings in Japan. The benchmark indices closed at 27,663.39 and 1,808.78 respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 0.7% to 2,939.74. The gains were driven by Wall Street's partial rebound from its previous decline, with local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rising. Index stock Keppel Corp slipped 1.1% after announcing plans to exit the offshore rig-building business, while ThaiBev rose 1.2% after market chatter about a possible listing of its brewery unit.

site_title: WeWork is said to explore SPAC merger or private fundraising
summary: WeWork is exploring a potential merger with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) or private fundraising, 16 months after its initial public offering attempt failed. The company's executive chairman, Marcelo Claure, said WeWork has received offers from SPACs and is considering a private funding round, which could value the company at around $10 billion. WeWork's bonds surged on the news, and the company has maintained focus on achieving profitability despite a decline in membership and revenue.

site_title: Daimler beats forecasts in preliminary 2020 results
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, released preliminary 2020 earnings showing an operating profit of 6.6 billion euros, exceeding forecasts by around half. Adjusted for one-off costs, profits were down 16% year-on-year. The company attributed the results to successful cost discipline and expected demand, but warned of ongoing challenges including a semiconductor shortage and potential coronavirus disruptions. Daimler plans to publish full 2020 financial data on February 18.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as traders lick wounds after tough week
summary: Asia markets struggled on Friday, rebounding from a tough week, as investors sought to kickstart a recovery amid fears over surging infections and a stuttering vaccine rollout. Despite a positive lead from Wall Street and Europe, Hong Kong and Shanghai rose, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Manila fell. A David-and-Goliath battle between retail traders and Wall Street investors over GameStop also contributed to the volatility. Analysts remain optimistic for the long-term prospects of Asian markets, citing unprecedented monetary and fiscal stimulus and a potential economic rebound.

site_title: Trump flexes political muscle, meets top House Republican
summary: US House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy met with former President Donald Trump at Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida, amid a tug of war over the Republican Party's future. McCarthy appeared to distance himself from Trump after the January 6 Capitol assault, but later re-aligned with the outgoing president, committing to help elect Republicans in 2022. The meeting comes as Trump faces impeachment and a potential trial in the Senate, with some Republicans signaling their loyalty to him despite the controversy.

site_title: SK Hynix's Q4 operating profit surges 298%
summary: SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chip maker, reported a 298% surge in fourth-quarter operating profits to 966 billion won (S$1.15 billion) due to strong mobile chip demand offsetting lower prices. The company's net profit for the period reached 1.77 trillion won, reversing a loss of 126 billion won a year earlier. Revenue rose 15% to 7.97 trillion won, with demand for server and mobile DRAM products expected to remain high in 2021 due to investments in new data centers and 5G phones.

images.alt_text: The world's second-largest memory chip maker, South Korea's SK Hynix, saw fourth-quarter operating profits quadruple as strong mobile chip demand offset lower prices, it said Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump over 1% as miners, banks rebound
summary: Australia's shares jumped 1.1% on Friday, led by a recovery in banks and miners, following overnight US stock gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for a 1.7% gain for the month, its fourth straight monthly increase. Key drivers of the rally included Aussie miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto, as well as the country's largest producer of rare earths, Lynas Rare Earths. The Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting next week is expected to keep its cash rate at a record low.

site_title: Google bombards Australian search users as PR campaign intensifies
summary: Google intensified its PR campaign against Australian regulation, presenting all search users with a pop-up opposing the proposed laws that would require them to pay news companies for content. The new rules aim to rebalance the relationship between news companies and tech giants. Google has threatened to pull its search service from Australia if the laws pass, and has been backed by World Wide Web inventor Tim Berners-Lee, who argues the laws are "unworkable". Critics see Google's actions as an attempt to undermine regulation and protect its market dominance.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated merits of bigger yield moves ahead of March review
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers discussed allowing long-term yields to move more flexibly, a key element of its policy review in March. This move aims to make its tools more sustainable amid a prolonged pandemic. One member noted that allowing 10-year yields to deviate from the 0% target will contribute to financial system stability. Another opinion suggested tweaks to its huge ETF purchases, indicating the review will result in some changes to its stimulus programme. The BOJ plans to announce the outcome in March, with analysts expecting a mix of measures to ensure flexibility in response to future economic shocks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher on Wall Street, airlines bounce
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Thursday, reversing early losses, driven by gains in airlines and upbeat earnings reports. US stocks surged on technology gains, with American Airlines jumping 20% after being mentioned on a Reddit forum. European travel names like Lufthansa and British Airways-owner IAG rose 4.7-7.2%. Despite strong earnings from Apple and Facebook, investors were cautious due to concerns over Covid-19 vaccine rollout and economic recovery.

site_title: Facebook shuts popular stock trading group amid GameStop frenzy
summary: Facebook has shut down the popular Robinhood Stock Traders group, which had 157,000 members, amid a market frenzy surrounding GameStop, AMC Entertainment, and BlackBerry. The group's founder, Allen Tran, claims Facebook disabled the group for violating policies, despite Tran saying no adult content existed. This move comes as individual investors, using social media and trading apps, coordinated to buy shares and squeeze hedge funds. Tran fears his new group may also be targeted, as Facebook suspends groups deemed "dangerous organizations."

site_title: Brokers' take: Exit from rig business to benefit Keppel, say analysts
summary: Keppel Corp announced plans to exit the rig business and restructure its Keppel Offshore & Marine unit, a move analysts see as a catalyst for growth. Despite this, analysts lowered their target prices for the stock, with UOB Kay Hian and CGS-CIMB maintaining "buy" calls but reducing their prices to S$6.10 and S$6.40, respectively. Analysts expect the rig-building sector to remain bearish, but believe Keppel's focus on floating infrastructure and renewable projects can deliver predictable cash flow.

site_title: Ride to nowhere? The Grab-Gojek story thus far
summary: The proposed merger between Grab and Gojek, two South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing companies, has been called off after a year of negotiations. The deal was initially sparked by reports of SoftBank's Masayoshi Son urging the companies to merge, but was hindered by antitrust concerns, e-wallet wars, and public backlash from motorbike operators and riders in Indonesia. Despite efforts to address these concerns, Grab and Gojek were unable to reach a deal, with Grab opting to pursue an IPO in the US instead. The collapse of the merger marks a significant setback for the two companies and raises questions about the future of the ride-hailing industry in the region.

images.alt_text: Grab and Gojek's potential union had the market abuzz for almost a year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, ThaiBev, MNACT, ComfortDelGro, ST Engineering
summary:

Keppel Corporation will restructure its offshore rig building business and posted a net profit of S$31.3 million for its second half. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust saw its net property income jump 49% to S$75.7 million. site_title: US airlines eye slow, gradual comeback after 2020 battering
summary: US airlines expect a gradual recovery from the 2020 pandemic-induced losses, with demand expected to pick up in the second half of 2021 and beyond. Despite the arrival of vaccines, leisure travel is expected to return before business travel, and domestic travel will outpace international. The industry faces another year of low demand, with airlines trimming capital budgets, retiring aircraft, and taking on debt to ride out the downturn. A full recovery is expected to take two years, with some carriers predicting a return to pre-pandemic levels by 2023.

site_title: Master of Chronographs
summary: Zenith unveiled two premium watches, the Chronomaster Sport and Chronomaster Revival A385, at LVMH Watch Week. The Chronomaster Sport boasts the El Primero 3600 automatic movement, measuring 1/10th of a second precision, while the Chronomaster Revival A385 is a faithful reproduction of a 1969 Zenith chronograph, featuring a vintage-inspired design. Other notable novelties include the Defy 21 Urban Jungle and Pilot Type 20 Chronograph Silver, priced between S$11,600 and S$21,200.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust reports 30.2% lower H2 DPU of 3.33 S cents
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) reported a 30.2% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.33 cents due to lower gross revenue, net property income (NPI), and distributable income from its 51% interest in Guangzhou's Rock Square mall. The trust's H2 DPU was impacted by the resurgence of Covid-19 cases in northern China, which affects its portfolio. Despite this, CLCT's manager remains cautious, citing the trust's debt maturity and gearing as positives. The trust plans to pursue accretive growth opportunities through space reconfiguration and redevelopment of its portfolio.

site_title: General Motors sets 2035 goal for eliminating emissions from most cars
summary: General Motors (GM) has set a goal to eliminate emissions-producing vehicles from its light-duty fleet by 2035, marking a significant shift in the company's strategy. The move is part of GM's broader plan to make all operations carbon-neutral by 2040. Industry analysts believe the goal indicates GM's intention to go "all in" on electric vehicles, driven by the Biden administration's environmental goals and competition from other automakers. The company aims to offer 30 electric models by 2025 across its four main brands.

site_title: First cases of South African coronavirus variant detected in US
summary: The US has detected its first cases of the highly transmissible B.1.351 coronavirus variant from South Africa, with two adults in South Carolina having no travel history. The variant, which has been identified in over 30 countries, is more likely to evade the blocking action of current vaccines and could lead to increased hospitalizations and deaths. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is working to expand its detection system and scientists are more concerned about this mutation than the B.1.1.7 variant from Britain, which has been seen in dozens of US states.

site_title: Japan's Dec factory output extends declines as recovery stalls
summary: Japan's factory output declined 1.6% in December, extending a slowdown in the country's economic recovery due to global Covid-19 lockdown measures. The decline was larger than the previous month's 0.5% fall, but in line with economists' forecasts. The average number of available jobs per applicant for 2020 saw its biggest decline in 45 years, while the jobless rate held steady. Manufacturers expect output to surge 8.9% in January and decline 0.3% in February, suggesting the economic recovery may continue. The government maintains its assessment of industrial production picking up.

site_title: Oil eases as demand worries offset weaker dollar, big storage draw
summary: Oil prices eased on Thursday as concerns about vaccine rollout delays and travel curbs outweighed the impact of a weaker dollar and a big US crude inventory drawdown. Brent futures fell 0.5% to $55.53 a barrel and US WTI crude ended 1.0% lower at $52.34. Analysts attributed the drop to increased demand concerns related to the coronavirus, despite Saudi Arabia's pledge to cut 1 million barrels per day in February and March.

site_title: Novavax Covid vaccine highly effective, but not against South Africa variant
summary: US biotech firm Novavax's Covid-19 vaccine candidate showed 89.3% efficacy in a Phase 3 clinical trial in Britain, but was less effective against a South Africa variant, with 49.4% efficacy. The company will develop a new vaccine targeting this variant, which has critical mutations. The vaccine's efficacy against the original Covid strain was 95.6%, but against the B.1.1.7 variant, it was 85.6%.

site_title: US judge allows extradition of two men accused of aiding Ghosn escape
summary: A US federal judge has allowed the extradition of two men, Michael Taylor and his son Peter Taylor, who are accused of aiding former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn's escape from Japan. The judge rejected their last-ditch effort to avoid extradition, citing the US State Department's approval and stating that the Taylors' actions amount to an extraditable offense. The Taylors, who received $1.3 million for their services, will be handed over to Japan to face charges of aiding Ghosn's escape. The extradition is seen as a significant step in Ghosn's trial, which he denies.

images.alt_text: A federal judge in Boston on Thursday rejected a last-ditch effort by two men to avoid being extradited to Japan to face charges they helped former Nissan Motor Chairman Carlos Ghosn flee the country.

site_title: France welcomes 'active' US in multinational tax talks
summary: France welcomed the Biden administration's active participation in multinational tax talks, following years of transatlantic trade battles. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen committed to re-engaging in OECD discussions on international taxation to forge a timely global accord. The talks aim to address the threat of climate change and reduce trade tensions between the US and Europe, which have had a negative impact on growth. France hopes for an international deal by the end of the first half of the year, following a phone call between Le Maire and Yellen.

site_title: US: Stocks stage partial rebound from rout
summary: US stocks staged a partial rebound from the prior session's rout, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.0% to 30,603.36 and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 1.0% and 0.5% respectively. The rebound followed new restrictions on trades in GameStop and other heavily traded stocks, which helped calm the market. The US economy shrank by 3.5% last year, with the growth of 4.0% annualized in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Short-sellers: Beware kamikaze stock buyers
summary: A growing wave of investors is taking on short-sellers, who bet against rising stocks, at almost any cost. Short-sellers, including Andrew Left of Citron Research, have been criticized for their methods and are facing backlash from online trolls. This "gamestop mania" has made it challenging for short-sellers to make a profit, as markets continue to rise. The trend has raised concerns about the potential for investors to take extreme measures, including threatening their lives, to achieve their goals.

site_title: Facebook out to loosen Apple's grip on App Store: report
summary: Facebook is reportedly preparing an anti-trust lawsuit against Apple, accusing the tech giant of abusing its control of the App Store by imposing rules on outside developers that are not applied to its own software. Facebook claims this gives Apple an unfair advantage, benefiting the company's bottom line at the expense of app developers and small businesses.

site_title: US, EU diplomacy chiefs discuss 'ways to repair' ties
summary: US and EU diplomacy chiefs, Josep Borrell and Antony Blinken, discussed ways to "repair" and "revitalise" their ties amid the Biden administration's shift in policy. They emphasized strengthening multilateralism and cooperation on issues like COVID-19, climate change, and data flows. The two also touched on shared foreign policy and security priorities, including countering China's expansion. The US and EU are preparing to work together on a range of issues, with potential cooperation on China, Turkey, and other global challenges.

images.alt_text: The top EU and US diplomats discussed on Thursday on how to "repair" their ties under President Joe Biden as Brussels and Washington prepare to work in concert on a range of issues.

site_title: New opportunities for Singapore, Indonesia firms to collaborate
summary: Singapore and Indonesia have expressed their commitment to strengthening bilateral ties and emerging stronger from the pandemic. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing and Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto discussed opportunities for collaboration, including Industry 4.0 adoption and digital upskilling of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises. The two countries have complementary strengths in manufacturing, innovation, and global connectivity, and are working together to boost investment and economic growth. A webinar co-hosted by the Singapore Economic Development Board and the Indonesian embassy facilitated discussions between entrepreneurs and officials from both countries.

site_title: Singapore ranked third-least corrupt in world: Transparency International
summary: Singapore ranked third-least corrupt in the world, according to Transparency International's Corruptions Perceptions Index 2020, with a score of 85. The city-state has maintained its score since 2018 and climbed from 4th in 2019. However, TI warns that high levels of secrecy in corporate and financial sectors make Singapore an attractive place for dirty money. Despite this, Singapore's success in combating corruption is attributed to the public's vigilance and resolve.

site_title: Property SMEs can get instant collateral-free loans under proptech, Validus tie-up
summary: Singapore property SMEs can access instant, collateral-free financing through a partnership between proptech startup Really Singapore and peer-to-peer financing platform Validus. Really eZFunds offers pre-approved working capital for up to S$50,000, with higher amounts available within 48 hours of due diligence assessment. Property owners also receive a 0.3% discount on invoices from approved vendors, and vendors can access flexible, pay-per-use financing with a 90-day tenor. This partnership aims to bridge the SME financing gap and support the growth of businesses in the property industry.

site_title: Tackling the tech talent crunch for mid-careers
summary: Singapore's tech talent crunch is real, with strong hiring demand for tech sector jobs. However, many mid-career professionals, particularly PMETs (Professional, Managerial, Executive, and Technicians), lack the necessary skills to compete for these roles. To address this, companies like Google and IBM are offering training programs. Meanwhile, vaccines continue to be a major focus, and experts like Robert Langer are looking ahead to innovative medical solutions.

site_title: The business case for boardroom diversity
summary: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are expanding their board advisory services to promote diversity among corporate boards. Goldman Sachs has built a business to help recruit diverse directors, while JPMorgan Chase has placed 30 women and five people of color in board positions since 2016. The move is seen as a way to increase shareholder value and attract clients seeking to improve their diversity and inclusion. Both banks believe that diverse boards are essential for companies to succeed in today's business environment.

images.alt_text: Only 5 per cent of the 3,000 largest listed companies in the United States have a board with an equal gender balance, per the group Women on Boards. Progress on these measures has been gradual, despite some research that shows more diverse boards are linked with better financial performance.

site_title: Remaking of an icon
summary: PARKROYAL COLLECTION Marina Bay, a Singapore hotel, has been revamped to champion sustainability and responsible living. The 583-room hotel features lush greenery, an onsite urban farm, and a garden-in-a-hotel concept. It eliminates single-use plastics, such as plastic water bottles, and provides biodegradable bath amenities. The hotel also offers digital concierge services, recycling bins, and energy-saving technology. The hotel's design, inspired by neo-futurist architect John Portman, seamlessly blends nature and architecture. The hotel's commitment to sustainability reflects the parent company Pan Pacific Hotels Group's goal to reduce environmental impact and promote responsible living.

site_title: Singapore leads region in personalised health innovation
summary: Singapore has become the most advanced country in the Asia-Pacific region in preparing for personalized healthcare, according to the Personalized Healthcare Index for Asia-Pacific. The country's strong digital infrastructure, comprehensive strategies, and significant adoption of technologies such as artificial intelligence enable personalized healthcare. Singapore leads in health information and personalized technologies, and ranked first in two Vital Signs, with areas for improvement in policy context. The country's readiness for personalized healthcare offers potential to improve health outcomes and address regional challenges, but requires further development of an overarching policy.

site_title: Gojek-Tokopedia merger: other startups eye fresh valuations
summary: Indonesia's tech giants Gojek and Tokopedia are reportedly in talks for a possible merger, valued at over $18 billion. The deal could set new valuation benchmarks for startups and create greater awareness of the digital economy. If successful, the merger would allow the combined entity to retain its individual brands and offer a range of services from transportation to e-commerce. The deal is expected to have significant implications for the sector, potentially driving scale and innovation, and attracting more investments from Chinese tech giants.

site_title: CPO prices expected to remain at elevated levels in Q1 2021
summary: Crude palm oil (CPO) prices have hit a 11-year high of RM3,050 per tonne, driven by wet weather and a low stockpile. Analysts expect prices to remain elevated in Q1 2021, but warn of a correction after the wet weather season ends. Stockpiles are expected to recover, and production is likely to increase due to heavier rainfall. Demand has held firm, with importing countries prioritizing food security amid the Covid-19 pandemic and weather conditions.

site_title: Lightweight fare at Moonbow
summary: Moonbow, a whimsical restaurant in Singapore's Dempsey Hill, boasts a beautiful and airy atmosphere, but its menu falls short in terms of substance. The restaurant's eclectic menu, inspired by various cuisines, lacks cohesion, resulting in a "seen this, eaten that" feel. Despite some standout dishes, such as the escargot and black chicken consommé, the overall experience is marred by erratic service and a sense of indecision about the food. With a better story to tell, Moonbow has a promising framework, but needs refinement to live up to its potential.

site_title: UK high streets emptying at the fastest pace on record
summary: The UK high streets are emptying at the fastest pace on record due to the pandemic's economic fallout, with office, mall, and store vacancies surging. Retail landlords face falling rents and values, while office landlords struggle with dwindling demand and questioning the need for in-person work. Warehouses, however, are a bright spot, with growing demand and forecasted rent increases. Experts predict a dim outlook for these sectors, with expectations for rents and capital values remaining negative.

site_title: Apple logs record quarterly smartphone shipments in Q4, Huawei in freefall
summary: Apple recorded a 22% increase in smartphone shipments to 90.1 million in Q4, surpassing Samsung and taking the global market share lead with 23.4%. This surge is attributed to the launch of new 5G-enabled iPhone models and a strong demand for upgrades in China. In contrast, Huawei's shipments plummeted 42.4% to 32.3 million due to US sanctions and a lack of supply, resulting in a market share drop to 5th place. This marks a significant shift in the global smartphone market.

site_title: Singapore moves to guide companies through green transition
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a proposed taxonomy to help Singapore-based financial institutions identify green activities, guiding companies through the green transition. The taxonomy proposes a "traffic-light" system to classify activities as green, yellow (transition), or red, and identifies environmental objectives and focus sectors to encourage greener practices. The Green Finance Industry Taskforce (GFIT) has invited comments on the taxonomy by March 11, and will also conduct workshops to strengthen financial institutions' environmental risk management capabilities.

site_title: Fed's Powell more worried by cool economy than hot markets
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concern over the state of the US economy, citing a long way to full recovery and nine million Americans without jobs due to the pandemic. He pledged to keep monetary spigots open to aid the pandemic-hit economy, downplaying concerns of a stock market bubble and inflation. Despite stock prices slumping, Powell emphasized the Fed's focus on full employment and financial stability, ruling out interest rate hikes to curb inflation, and indicating it may continue asset purchases for an extended period.

site_title: Toyota races ahead of Volkswagen to be world's top car seller
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has overtaken Volkswagen AG as the world's top-selling automaker in 2020, with 9.53 million units sold, compared to VW's 9.31 million units. This marks the first time Toyota has held the position in five years. Toyota's sales include those of its subsidiaries Daihatsu Motor and Hino Motors.

site_title: ST Engg's mask filters strengthen Singapore's supply chain resilience
summary: Singapore is strengthening its domestic mask production capabilities, with ST Engineering starting to produce high-quality melt blown polypropylene filters suitable for medical use. These filters, which can be inserted into reusable masks, have a filtration efficiency of over 98% and exceed ASTM-II standards. The government plans to stockpile the filters, providing every person in Singapore with at least two per week, and distribute them to the population in case of a worsening pandemic. This move aims to enhance the country's supply chain resilience and provide adequate protection against COVID-19.

site_title: Souring risk sentiment lifts US dollar
summary: US dollar rises as riskier currencies, such as the Australian and Canadian dollars, fall to multi-week lows. This shift in sentiment is attributed to souring risk appetite in global markets, driven by falling stock markets in the US, Asia, and Europe. The US dollar edged 0.05% higher against a basket of currencies by 11:38am GMT, as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Why Ericsson took on its government to defend Huawei
summary: Ericsson's CEO, Borje Ekholm, publicly defied Sweden's government by criticizing the country's decision to ban Huawei from its 5G networks, citing concerns over free trade and competition. Ekholm's text messages to a government minister revealed that he felt pressure from Chinese authorities to support Huawei, and warned that Sweden would be a "bad country" for Ericsson if it didn't reconsider. The move highlights the intense geopolitical tensions facing businesses and the need for Western governments to better support their companies from potential threats.

site_title: Merger talks between Grab and Gojek off the table
summary: Merger talks between Grab and Gojek, two of South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing firms, have ended, according to sources in Jakarta. The proposed merger, which aimed to create a regional giant, has been off the table due to unresolved negotiations. The move comes as both companies continue to compete fiercely in the region's ride-hailing market. The news may impact Gojek shares, which have seen a sell-off of US$2.2 billion recently.

images.alt_text: After lengthy negotiations, the proposed merger between two of South-east Asia's decacorns is said to be off the table, sources in Jakarta told The Business Times.

site_title: Lim Kay Tong, siblings sell bungalow for S$43m
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market is off to a strong start in 2021, with at least seven caveats lodged for transactions totaling S$218 million. The market saw a 35% increase in transaction value to S$1.05 billion in 2020. Several high-profile deals, including a S$43.35 million villa in King Albert Park, have been brokered by top real estate firms. Experts predict "very strong demand" in the GCB market this year, with prices expected to appreciate 5-7% by end of the year.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows after jump in exports
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit narrowed to $82.5 billion in December, a decrease from $85.5 billion in November, driven by a 4.6% increase in exports to pre-pandemic levels. Imports rose 1.4% to $215.9 billion, the highest since October 2018. This signals a recovery in global demand for American products, with overall trade value reaching $349.3 billion, the highest since May 2019. The narrow deficit follows a trade agreement signed between the US and China in January, which aims to increase Chinese purchases of American goods.

site_title: Amazon, Enterprise Singapore unite to help sellers
summary: Amazon and Enterprise Singapore have teamed up to help local retailers scale businesses globally through the Market Readiness Assistance scheme. The scheme will partially offset costs for expanding into new countries, up to 70% of eligible costs, capped at S$100,000 per company. Additionally, Amazon will waive professional selling account subscription fees for new and existing sellers until June. This is part of Singapore's five-pronged approach to build up the country as a global e-commerce hub, including strengthening digital infrastructure, encouraging digital solutions, and developing a robust supply chain.

site_title: Keppel says goodbye to rig business, pivots to clean energy
summary: Keppel Corp, the world's largest offshore rig builder, is rebranding itself as a "green" entity after posting a record full-year loss of S$1.19 billion in 2020. The company will exit the depressed rig business and pivot to clean energy, with a leaner and more asset-light entity. Keppel O&M's headcount will be significantly reduced, and it will focus on higher-value work. The company has a robust net order book of S$3.3 billion, mostly in renewables and gas solutions.

images.alt_text: Keppel O&M will exit the offshore rig-building business and pivot towards green energy.

site_title: Reunion feasts at Mandarin Orchard
summary: Mandarin Orchard offers various reunion feasts at its two Michelin-starred restaurants, Shisen Hanten and Triple Three, to celebrate the Year of the Ox. Shisen Hanten features bespoke set menus with luxurious dishes like Braised Bird's Nest and Barbecued Boneless Suckling Pig, while Triple Three offers Japanese-inspired specials such as Braised Mini Abalone and Wok-fried Slipper Lobster. Takeaway options are also available, and reservations can be made by calling the respective restaurants or visiting their websites.

site_title: Spanish cement sales slump to 50-year low with no pick-up in 2021
summary: Spanish cement sales plummeted to a 50-year low in 2020, with sales dropping 1.4 million tonnes from 2019 to 13.3 million tonnes. The decline was largely due to the coronavirus pandemic, which halted construction work for several months. Cement sales are expected to remain flat in 2021, with exports also down 3.4% from 2019. Industry leaders are calling for measures to address the sector's decline, including a system of carbon adjustment at the borders to balance competition.

site_title: Insolvency support for small firms from Jan 29
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law will offer a Simplified Insolvency Programme (SIP) starting January 29 for micro and small companies severely impacted by Covid-19. The six-month programme, which may extend, includes two separate schemes: Simplified Debt Restructuring Programme (SDRP) for viable businesses and Simplified Winding Up Programme (SWUP) for non-viable businesses. To qualify, firms must have annual sales turnover not exceeding S$10 million, 50 creditors or fewer employees, and liabilities not exceeding S$2 million. Application fees range from S$450 to S$18,750.

site_title: DoctorxDentist on its software and advertising
summary: DoctorxDentist, a Singapore-based doctor referral platform, responds to allegations that it favors paying doctors. The platform's software uses filters to recommend doctors based on patient preferences, and there is no gatekeeper function to discriminate against non-paying doctors. Statistics show that non-paying doctors accounted for 60.2% of all appointments booked through the platform, and patients' preferences determine the doctor recommendations generated by the system. The platform has upheld the Singapore Medical Council's and Ministry of Health's advertising guidelines, which prohibit doctors from paying for reviews. DoctorxDentist's CEO and GM argue that the platform is patient-centric and aims to provide a fair and comprehensive directory of doctor listings.

site_title: Sands' new CEO outlines plans for life after Adelson
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp's new CEO, Robert Goldstein, has outlined plans to capitalize on growth opportunities in Macau, Singapore, and online gambling. Goldstein, who succeeded company founder Sheldon Adelson, aims to continue investing in resort projects and potentially renewing the company's Macau concession. He also expressed interest in building a casino in Texas and pursuing online betting, a goal previously opposed by Adelson. The company reported a steep drop in sales and ongoing losses for the fourth quarter, but Goldstein plans to explore new revenue streams to drive growth.

site_title: US economy's growth moderates to 4% in final quarter
summary: The US economy experienced a moderation in growth, expanding at a 4% annualized rate in the fourth quarter of 2020, down from the record 33.4% rate in the previous quarter. Consumer spending slowed to a 2.5% rate, while non-residential investment and residential outlays continued to grow. The economy contracted 2.5% in 2020, but the pandemic relief package and expected additional aid may help sustain the recovery. The Federal Reserve characterized the economy as having "moderated" growth, with policymakers monitoring the pace of recovery and employment.

site_title: Number of condos up for rental in Toronto surges 132%
summary: Toronto's condominium rental market saw a 132% surge in the fourth quarter, with the number of condos put up for rent more than doubling compared to the previous year. This led to a significant decrease in average rents, with a one-bedroom condo falling 17% and a two-bedroom unit dropping 15%. The surge in supply was driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has prompted people to move from urban centers to more spacious accommodations in the suburbs. This trend is particularly pronounced among the younger demographic.

site_title: American Airlines reports US$8.9b 2020 loss on pandemic hit
summary: American Airlines reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.2 billion, bringing its 2020 loss to $8.9 billion due to the pandemic. The airline expects a rebound to begin later in 2021. In contrast, Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting its shares.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's H1 distribution drops 16.8%
summary: Starhill Global Reit's first-half distribution per unit (DPU) fell 16.8% to 1.88 Singapore cents, with net property income (NPI) and gross revenue dropping 12.3% and 8.6% respectively due to rental assistance during the Covid-19 pandemic. Income distributable to unitholders also decreased 16.1%. The Reit activated its maiden Distribution Reinvestment Plan (DRP) and expects to pay out its DPU on March 25, 2021. Despite a challenging period, the Reit's retail portfolio remains resilient, with occupancy rates at 96% in Singapore and 94.6% in Australia.

summary:
