summary: Singapore is preparing for a quiet Chinese New Year (CNY) festive season amidst a delicate Covid-19 situation and economic recovery. The government has tightened measures, limiting households to eight visitors per day and restricting visitors to two households per day. Experts warn that a second wave of infections could undo progress, but experiences in the US and UK suggest that a quiet CNY with responsible behavior could prevent new cases and support economic recovery.

site_title: Olam prices S$100m reopening of its 4% fixed-rate notes due Feb 2026
summary: Olam International priced a S$100 million reopening of its 4% fixed-rate senior unsecured notes due Feb 2026, increasing the total bond size to S$600 million. The offering will be issued at par, plus accrued interest, and used for debt refinancing and general corporate purposes. HSBC Singapore acted as the sole dealer. The reopening is part of a consolidation with existing fixed-rate senior unsecured notes.

site_title: MCT's revenue and net property income down in its nine-months year-to-date results
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1.9% decline in year-to-date gross revenue and a 1.2% decrease in net property income for FY20/21 due to Covid-19 rental rebates. However, office and business park assets saw a 21.8% and 22.6% increase, respectively. The trust has sufficient facilities to refinance its borrowings, with over S$500 million of cash and undrawn committed facilities. Despite a stabilizing economy, MCT expects the retail sector to remain under pressure, with office demand expected to remain subdued in H1 2021, but potential for rents to turn upwards by the second half of 2021.

site_title: Boeing takes US$6.5b charge on new delay to 777X jet
summary: Boeing pushed back the debut of its 777X jetliner to late 2023, citing the coronavirus pandemic and regulatory scrutiny, and absorbed a US$6.5 billion pretax charge. The company also wrote down additional charges to US$8.3 billion, affecting its services division and 787 Dreamliner program. This marks one of Boeing's worst years in its century-long history, amid a grinding slump caused by the 737 MAX grounding and the pandemic's impact on global travel.

site_title: Xi says 'patriots' should govern Hong Kong
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged Hong Kong to be governed by "patriots" in a video conference with Chief Executive Carrie Lam, following the arrest of over 50 opposition politicians and activists under the city's national security law. Xi emphasized the need for "patriots" to ensure Hong Kong's long-term prosperity and stability, echoing Beijing's message that Hong Kong's lawmakers and civil servants must be patriotic. The comments come amid China's efforts to purge pro-democracy activists and impose stricter control over the territory.

site_title: Take precautions during CNY, says PM who will celebrate 'with eight visitors, not more, from the family'
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged citizens to take precautions during the upcoming Chinese New Year celebrations due to the ongoing pandemic. He will celebrate with a small gathering of eight visitors from his family, and will also visit frontline workers. The government has introduced new measures, including limiting household visitors to eight per day, to prevent the risk of new clusters forming. PM Lee emphasized the importance of taking precautions to keep Singapore safe and avoid a repeat of the circuit breaker lockdown in March and April last year.

site_title: HBO Max gains traction after 'Wonder Woman' premiere
summary: HBO Max saw a significant increase in subscribers after reaching a distribution deal with Roku and the premiere of "Wonder Woman 1984" in December 2020. The streaming service now has 17.2 million active accounts, up from 4.1 million after its initial launch. AT&T's WarnerMedia aims to accelerate subscriber growth, with plans to premiere more films on HBO Max and expand globally. The company sets a goal of 50 million US subscribers by 2025 and 75-90 million globally by the same year, with a lower-cost ad-supported version expected to be launched later this year.

site_title: Tesla's report could trigger US$7 billion payout to CEO Musk
summary: Tesla's upcoming quarterly report could trigger a US$7 billion payout to CEO Elon Musk due to the vesting of options in his 2018 pay package. The company's shares have surged nearly 700% in the past year, making it the fifth-most-valuable US company. Analysts expect Tesla to report revenue of US$10.3 billion and net income of US$752.5 million, with deliveries expected to reach around 900,000 in 2021. This could lead to a significant payout to Musk, who is also the majority owner of SpaceX.

site_title: Police dismantle world's 'most dangerous' criminal hacking network
summary: International law enforcement agencies successfully dismantled the "Emotet" malware network, considered the most dangerous globally, used to steal billions of dollars from businesses and private citizens worldwide. The operation, involving six European countries and the US, took control of Internet servers used to run and control the malware. German police reported at least $17.56 million in damages, while global damages were estimated at $2.5 billion. Authorities seized computers and equipment, but no arrests were made, dealing a significant blow to international organized internet crime.

site_title: DBS wins bankruptcy bid on Nelson Loh in relation to S$14m loan
summary: DBS Bank has won a bankruptcy bid against Nelson Loh, a failed businessman, in relation to S$14.2 million in outstanding debts. Loh, the co-founder of Bellagraph Nova, had stood as guarantor for two facilities with DBS, which he was unable to pay. The court also granted an order for Leow Quek Shiong to be appointed as the private trustee of Loh's estate. Loh's cousin, Terence Loh, is also facing bankruptcy proceedings with DBS and Citibank.

site_title: China's Ant Group plans revamp amid regulator pressure: WSJ
summary: China's Ant Group is planning to restructure itself as a financial holding company under the supervision of China's central bank amid regulatory pressure. The fintech affiliate of Alibaba Group has submitted an outline of a restructuring plan, which could be finalized before the Lunar New Year holiday in mid-February. Chinese regulators had asked Ant to fold most of its financial businesses into a holding company subject to stricter capital requirements. This comes after regulators halted Ant's $37 billion initial public offering in November. The move aims to comply with Chinese law and address regulatory concerns.

images.alt_text: China's Ant Group is planning to refashion itself as a financial holding company under the supervision of China's central bank in the face of regulatory pressure, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares break three-day losing streak; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, breaking a three-day losing streak, to close at 2,958.63 points. The top gainer was Venture Corporation, which rose 2.3%, while Sheng Siong rose 1.3% after announcing increased bonuses for staff. DBS Group Research suggested that Covid-19 beneficiaries such as Sheng Siong and semiconductor stocks may outperform casualties ahead of results season. Asian markets were mixed, with the Nikkei 225 and Shanghai Composite Index rising, while the Hang Seng Index and Kospi fell.

site_title: HSBC Singapore appoints new commercial banking head
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Regina Lee as its new Singapore head of commercial banking, effective March 1. Lee, who has over 20 years of experience, takes over from Alan Turner, who will move to Canada. She brings expertise in corporate and commercial banking, having previously led the coverage team for TMT and consumer sectors at HSBC Hong Kong. The appointment aims to accelerate HSBC's push into South-east Asia, a strategic growth market for the bank.

site_title: Sheng Siong issues profit guidance for Q4, says it has computed bonuses the same way since 2007
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, has issued a profit guidance for its fourth quarter, stating revenue and net profit are expected to vary by less than 5% from the previous quarter. The company's employee bonus payments, unchanged since 2007, were calculated based on the group's financial performance in FY2020, resulting in bonuses ranging from 4.68 to 15.72 months for eligible staff. Sheng Siong will announce its fourth-quarter and full-year results on Feb 24.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit to acquire Sime Darby Business Centre for S$106.6m
summary: AIMS Apac Reit has agreed to acquire Sime Darby Business Centre for S$106.6 million, its first acquisition in a "city-fringe location". The property, a premium showroom and business-space precinct, will be acquired on a partial leaseback arrangement. The acquisition is expected to add 0.48 Singapore cents to the FY 2020 DPU, bringing it to 9.98 Singapore cents, and increase the Reit's light industrial exposure to 15.8% and portfolio occupancy to 95%.

site_title: Colin Low resigns as CEO of FHT's managers after less than two years
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's (FHT) managers announced Colin Low's resignation as CEO, effective April 10, 2021, after less than two years in the role. Low cited a desire to pursue other professional interests outside the real estate industry. His departure marks a change for the company, with managers now recruiting a replacement.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange Fund's investment income tumbled in 2020
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund reported a 24.6% decline in investment income to HK$197.80 billion (S$33.8 billion) in 2020, down from HK$262.2 billion in 2019. The fund's investment income rebounded in the fourth quarter, increasing by 31.7% to HK$107.0 billion. The decline was attributed to the coronavirus crisis, but asset markets recovered quickly due to ultra-loose monetary policies. The fund's bond holdings fell 19.2% to HK$92.5 billion, while income from Hong Kong and equities declined. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority expects a gradual recovery in 2021, but warns of geopolitical risks.

site_title: Genting Singapore among seven new Asean firms on gender-equality index; DBS leads Asean region
summary: Genting Singapore is among seven new Asean companies included in Bloomberg's 2021 Gender-Equality Index (GEI), recognizing publicly-listed companies that promote transparency on gender-related practices and policies. DBS leads the Asean region, with a combined market capitalization of US$14 trillion, and is recognized as best-in-class for gender equality. The index comprises 380 companies across 44 countries and regions, with an average disclosure score of 94% and an average data-excellence score of 55%. The inclusion of Genting marks the first time an Indonesian-headquartered firm has participated in the list.

site_title: Contactless payments are here to stay: Visa
summary: Visa's study found that only 6% of Singapore's consumers would revert to pre-Covid payment methods after a vaccine is available, with nearly 7 in 10 using contactless payments whenever possible. The preference for contactless payments grew during the pandemic as cash payments became less popular. This shift is expected to persist, with contactless payments becoming a permanent fixture in the market.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX safe to return to service in Europe, regulator says
summary: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has cleared Boeing's 737 MAX to return to service in Europe, lifting a 22-month flight ban following two crashes that resulted in 346 deaths. EASA executive director Patrick Ky expressed confidence in the aircraft's safety, but emphasized continued monitoring. Boeing also committed to further enhancing the aircraft's safety in the medium term. The decision marks a significant step forward for Boeing, allowing the 737 MAX to resume operations in Europe.

site_title: Singapore waste-management company 800 Super expands into Cambodia
summary: Singapore waste-management company 800 Super has successfully expanded into Cambodia's solid-waste management sector through a 10-year contract with the Phnom Penh Capital Administration. The joint venture, 800 Super-GAEA, will collect and transport waste from five sub-zones to a transfer station and regional landfill. The company plans to introduce GPS fleet-management systems and other technologies to support Cambodia's growing urban centers, aiming to enhance waste management efficiency and safety.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.31 points to 1,580.62. The index saw 614 gainers versus 525 losers, with a total trading volume of 5.641 billion lots worth RM4.984 billion.

site_title: Moody's restores Singtel's 'stable' ratings outlook
summary: Moody's Investors Service has restored Singtel's credit ratings outlook to "stable" from "negative", citing expectations that lower shareholder returns and a scrip dividend scheme will reduce leverage. The upgrade comes after nearly two years of a negative outlook, with Moody's predicting a stable business and financial profile for Singtel in the next two to three years. Despite this, the agency expects underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) to remain unchanged in the next 12 to 18 months due to intense competition and the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: LG Chem swings to Q4 profit on car battery demand but misses forecast
summary: LG Chem reported a profitable Q4 on demand for car batteries, but missed expectations due to costs from splitting its battery unit and recall charges. The company posted an operating profit of 674 billion won, up from a loss of 33 billion won last year. Revenue rose 20% to 8.9 trillion won, driven by strong demand for electric car batteries from Tesla. However, the petrochemical business suffered after a naphtha cracker shut down in November, and future profits may be impacted by recall costs.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit H2 DPU up 4% to 3.13 US cents
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) reported a 4% increase in its second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.13 US cents, driven by contributions from its Dallas property, One Twenty Five, and proactive leasing efforts. Distributable income rose 13.4% year-over-year to US$29.5 million, while gross revenue increased 7.7% to US$69.1 million. The Reit's net property income rose 6.6% to US$41.1 million. KORE's tenant concentration risk remains low, with a weighted average lease expiry of 3.8 years.

site_title: UK mobile networks Vodafone, O2 and Three tackle rural coverage
summary: UK mobile networks Vodafone, O2, and Three are collaborating to build and share 222 mobile masts to improve 4G coverage in rural areas. The project, worth £1 billion, will increase coverage in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland, and England, with construction starting this year and completion by 2024. The first stage targets areas with only one network coverage, while a second stage will focus on areas with no signal at all, funded by the government. The initiative aims to address rural coverage gaps and provide better connectivity for residents.

site_title: Singapore to continue prioritising development of human capital for financial sector: Minister Teo
summary: Singapore plans to prioritize the development of human capital in the financial sector, aiming to deepen local workers' expertise and expand businesses alongside a growing talent pool. Minister of Manpower Josephine Teo announced a three-pronged approach to enhance the country's position as a trusted location for financial institutions, including digitalizing financial services, strengthening connectivity with overseas players, and helping businesses seize emerging opportunities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also pushing for green finance, pandemic risk financing, and restructuring and insolvency.

site_title: Europe: Stocks narrowly mixed at open
summary: European stock markets started trading narrowly mixed, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.2% at 6,640.18 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 declined 0.3% to 13,827.31, while the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.2% to 5,534.74. Market sentiment was influenced by bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade tensions also a focus. Despite these factors, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower with eye on US
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.32% to 29,297.53 on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day, amid US stimulus developments and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.11% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.28%. Investors track US developments while considering potential tariffs between the US and EU.

site_title: 16-year-old detained under ISA for plans to attack two mosques in Singapore
summary: A 16-year-old Singaporean student has been detained under the Internal Security Act for planning to attack two mosques in Singapore on March 15, the second anniversary of the Christchurch terror attacks. The student, a Protestant Christian of Indian ethnicity, made detailed plans to use a machete against Muslims at two mosques in Woodlands. He is the first detainee to be inspired by far-right extremist ideology and the youngest person detained under the ISA for terrorism-related activities to date.

images.alt_text: A 16-year old Singaporean student has been detained under the Internal Security Act (ISA) for planning to attack two mosques and kill worshippers in Singapore on March 15 this year - the second anniversary of the Christchurch terror attacks.

site_title: Four Singapore PRs among 25 new Covid-19 imported cases
summary: Singapore reported 25 new COVID-19 cases, all imported, with 22 asymptomatic. Four PRs from India and the UAE, one dependent's pass holder, and two work pass holders from India and the UAE were among the new cases. The total cases in Singapore now stand at 59,391, with 59,089 recovered and 38 in hospital. The number of new community cases decreased to five, and unlinked cases in the community dropped to one.

site_title: Singapore faces talent crunch as tech giants scale up
summary: Singapore is facing a severe talent crunch as tech giants, including Bytedance, Tencent, and Zoom, scale up operations in the city-state. The demand for tech talent has soared, with up to 500 new tech vacancies posted weekly, but the supply is relatively weak, slowing down expansion plans. The government has re-trained thousands of people with tech skills and introduced a new work visa for top-tier tech executives, but border curbs and tighter foreign worker policies are exacerbating the shortage. Experts warn that the labour crunch may not be sustainable once borders reopen and the talent pool develops.

site_title: South-east Asia still the top choice for business expansion: SBF poll
summary: Singapore Business Federation's (SBF) annual National Business Survey 2020/21 found that 76% of businesses in South-east Asia are keen to expand within the region. Vietnam, Indonesia, and China topped the list, with 30% of businesses interested in venturing into these countries. Overseas business expansion contracted by 7% in 2020, with 84% of businesses active in South-east Asia, citing Covid-19 as the main challenge, followed by demand uncertainty and manpower costs. Only 27% of respondents plan to expand overseas in the next six to 12 months.

site_title: Brokers' take: Higher office space demand from TMT to benefit Suntec Reit, say analysts
summary: Analysts from four research houses, including UOB Kay Hian, CGS-CIMB, OCBC Investment Research, and Maybank Kim Eng, expect rising demand for office space from the technology, media, and telecommunications (TMT) sector to benefit Suntec Reit. Positive rental reversions in the office sector are expected to continue in 2021, with some analysts raising their target prices for the Reit, while others maintain a "hold" or "sell" call due to concerns over gearing and weak operational metrics.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust posts H2 DPU of 1.86 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.86 Singapore cents for the second half of 2020, unchanged from the previous year. The trust's free cash flow to equity rose 18.9% to S$112.4 million, driven by growth in its distribution and network, and energy sectors. Revenue fell 8.4% to S$760.6 million, while total expenses decreased 4.6%. KIT posted a loss of S$79.5 million for the half-year, compared to a profit of S$38.8 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher as IMF forecast boosts hopes of higher earnings
summary: Japanese stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of better corporate results after the International Monetary Fund (IMF) raised its forecast for global growth. The Nikkei share average ended 0.31% higher at 28,635.21, while the Topix gained 0.65%. Shares of Nitto Denko jumped 7.91% to a three-year high after raising its annual operating profit forecast. Other top gainers included Canon and Sharp.

site_title: Goldman sees US$200b opening from European tech unicorns
summary: Goldman Sachs expects European tech unicorns to unlock a $200 billion base of fast-growing clients, driven by the sector's booming growth during the pandemic. The bank is targeting these companies for private fundraising mandates and initial public offerings (IPOs), citing the importance of spotting them early. Goldman Sachs has already worked with multibillion-dollar technology groups like Spotify and Just Eat Takeaway.com, and expects a strong year for IPOs across Europe, driven predominantly by technology and technology-related issuances.

site_title: Taiwan says chipmakers to prioritise auto chips
summary: Taiwan's Economics Minister Wang Mei-hua announced that major Taiwanese chipmakers have agreed to prioritize supplies for the automotive industry amid a global chip shortage. The chipmakers, including senior executives, expressed willingness to increase capacity and negotiate with other clients to put auto chip supplies first. However, the shortage is expected to take time to resolve, with no specific timeline provided.

site_title: HSBC CEO defends China policy under fire from UK lawmakers
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn defended the bank's decision to close an exiled Hong Kong lawmaker's account, stating it was driven by the need to comply with local laws. Quinn told UK lawmakers that he couldn't judge the motives or validity of the law enforcement authority's instruction. The move comes amid accusations that HSBC has become a tool of Chinese authorities. Quinn emphasized that the bank's actions were purely driven by compliance, not politics.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide; Fed meeting, US stimulus in focus
summary: South Korean stocks slid 0.4% on Wednesday, led by selling from foreigners, amid uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's meeting and US stimulus package. The benchmark Kospi fell 10.84 points to 3,129.47, while the Korean won edged up and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 320.4 billion won worth of shares, while major heavyweights traded mixed. Investors await the outcome of the US Federal Reserve's meeting and the US Senate's coronavirus relief plan.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares slid on Wednesday, led lower by selling from foreigners, as investors eye the outcome of the US central bank's meeting amid uncertainty around the country's stimulus package.

site_title: TikTok owner Bytedance's sales doubled to US$35b despite US ban
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, reported a 100% increase in sales to $35 billion in 2020, defying US competition and a potential ban by Donald Trump. The company's operating profit also doubled to $7 billion. Despite US efforts to ban TikTok, ByteDance is moving forward with a potential listing in Hong Kong for part of its social media empire. The company's growth is attributed to the global success of TikTok and its Chinese twin Douyin, which pioneered a new form of social video.

site_title: Hong Kong turns to 'ambush lockdowns' to fight virus
summary: Hong Kong has started using "ambush lockdowns" to combat the coronavirus, suddenly closing off and testing entire neighborhoods where cases have spiked. The tactic involves no warning, with authorities citing the need to prevent residents from fleeing before testing begins. A recent two-day lockdown in a low-income neighborhood was leaked to the media, prompting the sudden action. The move aims to address the city's rampant inequality and clusters of infections in densely packed housing. Authorities plan further ambush lockdowns in the coming days.

site_title: Google revives Australia news platform launch amid content payment fight
summary: Google is reviving plans to launch its News Showcase platform in Australia, potentially in February, as part of its campaign against proposed laws requiring content payments to local news providers. The platform was initially announced in June 2020, but delayed due to regulatory conditions. Google's move is seen as a show of willingness to run its own content deals, negating the need for government-mandated legislation. The company's Australian chief executive Mel Silva threatened to pull its flagship search tool from the country if the laws went ahead, citing the unworkability of the legislation.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat from 11-month high as resource firms fall
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to a 11-month low on Wednesday, led by losses in the resources sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,780.6. Underlying inflation in the December quarter remained at 1.2%, indicating the Reserve Bank of Australia may keep interest rates accommodative. This data signals a possible retention of the central bank's easy policy stance.

site_title: Upcoming Budget to stay 'expansionary but calibrated': UOB
summary: UOB expects Singapore's upcoming Budget 2021 to be "expansionary but calibrated" to target specific industries and sectors affected by the pandemic. The research team projects an overall deficit of 2.5% of nominal GDP, with operating revenue growing to S$70 billion and total expenditure falling to S$80 billion. The budget may introduce measures to develop advanced manufacturing capabilities, digital connectivity, and accelerate industry transformation, including job creation, business liquidity, social safety nets, and promoting Singapore as a Global-Asia node for technology and innovation.

site_title: Hong Kong's first Covid-19 lockdown exposes deep-rooted inequality
summary: Hong Kong's first Covid-19 lockdown highlighted the city's deep-rooted inequality, with the poorest residents facing cramped and unsanitary living conditions in subdivided flats. The lockdown, which affected 10,000 residents, was imposed after a neighborhood in Jordan reported over 160 confirmed cases. Experts say the government failed to address underlying issues, such as inadequate plumbing and poor communication with low-income communities. The lockdown was criticized for disproportionately affecting South Asian residents, who make up about 1% of the city's population, and for failing to provide culturally sensitive aid.

site_title: 7-Eleven kicks off mega bond sale to help finance Speedway purchase
summary: 7-Eleven is marketing a potential $10.95 billion bond offering to finance its US$21 billion acquisition of Speedway gas stations from Marathon Petroleum Corp. This would be the largest corporate dollar debt sale globally so far this year. The bond sale will help Seven & i Holdings, the Tokyo-based parent company, pay for the acquisition. Moody's has downgraded 7-Eleven's issuer rating to Baa2 due to the increased debt, while S&P Global Ratings is likely to lower 7-Eleven's credit rating by two notches.

images.alt_text: 7-Eleven is marketing a potential US$10.95 billion bond offering, according to people familiar with the matter, in what would be the largest corporate dollar debt sale globally so far this year.

site_title: Certis to hire 100 locals while offering skills training to non-staff for the first time
summary: Certis, a security firm, has launched the Certis Accelerator programme to hire 100 locals and provide skills training to existing staff and non-employees in Singapore. The programme offers market-competitive remuneration packages and aims to support the community, particularly those affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. Interested jobseekers can visit the company's website for more information. The initiative is part of Certis' workforce transformation efforts and aims to accelerate its business transformation plans.

site_title: Philippine province cancels award for China Communications' US$10b airport project
summary: The Cavite province in the Philippines has cancelled the award of a $10 billion airport project to China Communications Construction Co (CCCC) and MacroAsia Corp. The decision was made due to "deficiencies" in the consortium's documentation, with Governor Juanito Victor Remulla stating that the partners were "not fully committed" to the project. The cancellation comes despite China's CCCC being blacklisted by the US for its roles in constructing artificial South China Sea islands. MacroAsia's shares plummeted as a result of the cancellation.

images.alt_text: A Philippine province has cancelled its award of a US$10 billion airport deal south of the capital, among the biggest projects involving a Chinese firm under President Rodrigo Duterte who has pursued warmer ties with Beijing since taking office in 2016.

site_title: Swiber's headquarters in Jurong put on market for S$40m
summary: Swiber Holdings' headquarters in Jurong is up for sale via private treaty with a guide price of S$40 million. The 60-year leasehold building, used by the troubled offshore and marine group, was acquired in 2011 for S$37 million. The sale follows a series of proposed rescue packages that have been rejected, and a new investment agreement with Saudi Arabian conglomerate Rawabi Holding that excludes the transfer of the building. The property offers redevelopment opportunities, with a remaining lease of 35 years and a dual-feed power supply, and is located in the International Business Park.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, increasing 16.4 points or 1% to 1,591.7. Volume was 550.7 million lots worth RM423.9 million. Gainers outpaced losers 361 to 211.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars probe resistance, inflation tops forecasts
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged against the US dollar, with the Aussie reaching US$0.7740 and the kiwi dollar reaching US$0.723, defying recent chart resistance. This comes as the US dollar weakened. The currencies face resistance at US$0.7785 for the Aussie and US$0.7240/50 for the kiwi dollar. The recent surge in domestic data in both countries is also attributed to the upward momentum.

site_title: Vietnam to see fast-and-furious rally: report
summary: Vietnam's stock index, VNIndex, is predicted to reach 1,350 points by end-2021, a 22% increase from 2020, according to Maybank Kim Eng analyst Hoang Huy. This target is based on 28% year-on-year earnings growth and an earnings multiple of 17.4 times. Huy cites similarities with the 2017-2018 period, when corporate earnings grew 20-30% and the market experienced a strong rerating. However, he notes that a high valuation can be unsustainable and warns of potential volatility. Key sectors predicted to perform in 2021 include energy, financial, and real estate.

site_title: Shophouse investment sales in Singapore a bright spot in virus-ravaged 2020: Colliers
summary: Singapore's shophouse investment sales saw a 16.1% increase in 2020, with 18 transactions worth S$288 million, making it the only segment to improve from 2019. This marked the best quarterly showing since 2018, with shophouse sales for the year reaching S$467 million. Commercial assets led the market, with a 52% share, while residential and industrial sales volumes fell 23.6% and 43.3% respectively. Colliers expects private land sales to recover in 2021 and anticipates a 20% growth in overall investment sales to S$29.7 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% at the open on Wednesday, driven by bargain-buying following the previous day's losses. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,556.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. Investors are monitoring US stimulus developments and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq slip from record levels as earnings season gains speed
summary: US stocks slipped from record levels on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq falling 0.2% and 0.1% respectively, as investors digested corporate earnings results. Despite strong performances from companies like 3M and Johnson & Johnson, American Express fell 4.13% after posting a 15% drop in quarterly profit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 22.96 points, with Microsoft shares rising 5.2% after beating revenue growth estimates. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce a policy statement on Wednesday, with few changes expected.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, ART, Sheng Siong, Bonvests
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 27.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.795 Singapore cents for the second half of 2020. In contrast, Ascott Residence Trust's DPU fell 52% to 1.99 Singapore cents. Sheng Siong Group is giving eligible staff up to 16 months of bonuses, while Bonvests Holdings expects to record a loss for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Australian consumer prices lifted by taxes, Covid stimulus in Q4
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 0.9% in the December quarter, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher tobacco taxes and the unwinding of Covid-19 subsidies. Core inflation remained subdued at 1.2%, a record low, and the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is likely to keep interest rates low. The RBA aims to hold inflation in a 2-3% band, but it has been below the floor for five years. The central bank has pledged to maintain interest rates at 0.1% for three years and buy bonds to hold yields down.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by bargain-hunters ahead of Japan's corporate earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.4% to 28,670.41, while the Topix index advanced 0.5% to 1,856.41. This follows modest declines on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tokyo Stocks opened higher on Wednesday following modest declines on Wall Street as bargain-hunters moved in ahead of Japan's corporate earnings season.

site_title: Australia set for 10th day of no local Covid-19 cases
summary: Australia is on track for its 10th consecutive day without local Covid-19 cases, allowing New South Wales to relax coronavirus restrictions. The state had previously controlled a fast-spreading cluster, and other states and territories are also expected to report zero local infections. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced restrictions would be eased from Friday, including rules around mask wearing and gatherings. If no further cases are reported, restrictions may be eased further in two weeks. Australia's success in controlling outbreaks comes as global coronavirus cases approach 100 million and the death toll surpasses two million.

images.alt_text: Australia is on track for a 10th day of no new local Covid-19 cases on Wednesday, allowing its most populous state of New South Wales (NSW) to relax coronavirus restrictions after controlling a fast-spreading cluster.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust H2 DPU falls 52% to 1.99 S cents; buys US student housing
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 52% decline in half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.99 Singapore cents, due to lower revenue from its existing portfolio and divestments. Despite this, the trust's cash reserves are sufficient to cover three years' fixed costs under a worst-case scenario. ART also acquired its first US student accommodation asset, Signature West Midtown, for $95 million, and plans to refurbish Hotel Central Times Square. The trust's DPS for the full year is expected to be 3.03 cents.

site_title: IMDA, ESG unveil new digital solutions for businesses
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) unveiled new digital solutions for businesses, including digital collaboration tools and enhanced social media advertisement templates. These solutions aim to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in their digital marketing and transactions. The initiatives include integrated invoice management and e-payment systems, enabling smoother digital transactions and remote work capabilities. The goal is to help businesses adapt to the evolving business environment and stay competitive.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 11.04 points to 2,956.56. The gains were driven by local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while China Star Food rose 22% after announcing a first-half FY2020 net loss. The market followed modest declines on Wall Street overnight, where the Dow Jones fell 0.1% and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%.

site_title: Goldman Sachs CEO gets US$10m pay cut in light of 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon's annual pay fell by 36% to US$17.5 million in 2020, following a US$10 million pay cut in light of the bank's role in the 1MDB scandal. The scandal, which began in 2009, involved Goldman paying over US$1.6 billion in bribes to foreign officials. The bank has agreed to pay US$2.9 billion to settle probes into the scandal and has clawed back US$174 million from executives, including Solomon. Solomon's reduced pay is compared to a 22% pay increase for Morgan Stanley's CEO James Gorman.

site_title: India's unusual vaccine problem: Plenty of shots, but few takers
summary: India faces a unique challenge in its COVID-19 vaccination program, with a surplus of vaccine shots but a low inoculation rate. As of Monday, only 56% of eligible people have received the vaccine, hindering the government's goal of inoculating 300 million people by July. Safety concerns over the Bharat Biotech vaccine, which has not completed Phase III trials, are contributing to the hesitation. The government and vaccine manufacturer have defended the shot, but critics argue for more transparency and data on its efficacy.

site_title: Microsoft profit soars as pandemic speeds shift to cloud
summary: Microsoft reported a 33% increase in net income to $15.5 billion in its fiscal second quarter, driven by a 17% rise in overall revenue to $43.1 billion. The company's commercial cloud offerings saw a 34% increase in revenue to $16.7 billion. Microsoft's Xbox division reported a 40% surge in revenue, with overall gaming sales reaching a record high in the US. CEO Satya Nadella expects the shift to cloud services and remote work to continue even after the pandemic, with a focus on "hybrid" work styles.

site_title: Hong Kong lifts second lockdown in Kowloon for Covid-19 tests
summary: Hong Kong lifted a second neighborhood lockdown in the densely-populated Kowloon area after completing a round of virus testing, finding one confirmed coronavirus case among 330 tested individuals. The lockdown was part of efforts to combat the city's fourth surge of coronavirus cases, with 64 new cases reported earlier Tuesday. The move follows a targeted two-day lockdown that tested 7,000 people and comes as the city faces growing frustration over its sometimes erratic virus measures.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed; US tech rises after hours
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Wednesday, with Japan's Topix index rising 0.6% and South Korea's Kospi index climbing 0.3%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index fell 0.4%. US tech stocks rose after hours, driven by Microsoft's strong earnings report, with Nasdaq futures jumping. Investors are concerned about new coronavirus variants and the US stimulus plan, with the global stock market near record highs.

images.alt_text: Japan's Topix index rose 0.6 per cent. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index fell 0.4 per cent.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall from 11-month high as big miners, energy stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,801.60, dropping from an 11-month high, due to big miners and energy stocks. Aussie miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto declined 3% and 3.7%, respectively, on declining iron ore prices. Energy stocks also dropped nearly 3%, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos easing. Investors await inflation data and the US Federal Reserve meeting, expecting a dovish statement.

images.alt_text: Australian shares slipped on Wednesday from an 11-month peak scaled in the previous trading session, dragged down by big miners and energy stocks, while investors awaited inflation data and outcome of the US Federal Reserve meeting.

site_title: Italy's PM quits in tactical bid to build new parliamentary majority
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte resigned on Tuesday, amid a deepening political crisis, to try to build a new parliamentary majority. Conte lost his absolute majority in the Senate after a junior partner quit over the government's handling of the coronavirus crisis and economic recession. President Sergio Mattarella will consult with party leaders to test the political waters, potentially giving Conte time to form a new administration. If Conte fails, the president may call an election, two years ahead of schedule, or appoint a new candidate.

site_title: US dollar retreats as riskier currencies recover
summary: The US dollar retreated 0.2% against a basket of currencies, following a day of riskier currencies recovering after vaccine rollout and fiscal stimulus concerns boosted demand for safe havens. The US Dollar Currency Index fell to 90.143, with the euro and Australian dollar gaining against the US dollar. Emerging-market currencies also saw easing selling pressure. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting on Wednesday, expecting few changes. Speculators remain bearish on the US currency, citing weak technicals and uncertainty over fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Yellen makes history again as US Treasury Secretary
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has made history as the first woman to lead the department, following her confirmation by the Senate on Monday. She was sworn in by Vice President Kamala Harris at the White House, taking on the role amidst a record slowdown in US economic growth and a large coronavirus outbreak. Yellen will focus on winning Congressional support for President Biden's $1.9 trillion economic rescue plan and increasing the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. Her appointment comes after a long career in economics and public service, including her previous role as head of the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: In selecting Janet Yellen to be the first woman to lead the US Treasury Department, President Joe Biden chose a progressive economist focused on unemployment who supports fiscal stimulus and tackling climate change.

site_title: EU vaccine roll-out in disarray as Germany pushes for export limits
summary: Germany urged the EU to limit vaccine exports as a worsening standoff with AstraZeneca and underwhelming inoculation campaigns threaten to prolong lockdowns across the bloc. German Health Minister Jens Spahn proposed export limits to ensure fair distribution of vaccines, amid a production disruption at a Pfizer factory and planned delays in AstraZeneca deliveries. The EU's executive arm proposed a transparency mechanism for vaccine exports, which could disrupt deliveries of the Pfizer shot. The move threatens to derail the EU's vaccination campaign, which lags behind the US and UK.

images.alt_text: Germany urged the European Union to limit vaccine exports as a worsening standoff with AstraZeneca Plc and underwhelming inoculation campaigns threaten to prolong recession-inducing lockdowns across the bloc.

site_title: Starbucks profits dip on continued drag from Covid-19
summary: Starbucks reported a drop in quarterly profits, despite a partial recovery from Covid-19 restrictions. The company returned to comparable sales growth in China and saw a smaller decline in the US, but revenues lagged analyst estimates. CEO Kevin Johnson attributed the results to the brand's continued strength and relevance.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands hands reins to Robert Goldstein after Sheldon Adelson's death
summary: Las Vegas Sands has named Robert Goldstein as its permanent CEO and chairman after the death of founder Sheldon Adelson. Goldstein, 65, previously acted as CEO and will assume the role of chairman. The company also promoted Patrick Dumont to president and chief operating officer, and Randy Hyzak to CFO. The appointments come as the company faces a 63% drop in revenue due to the global coronavirus pandemic. The company remains under the control of Adelson's widow, Miriam, with a 57% stake, and is exploring a role for Sands in sports betting.

site_title: EQT agrees to buy Exeter Property Group for US$1.9 billion
summary: EQT, a European private equity firm, has agreed to buy Exeter Property Group for $1.9 billion. The deal gives EQT access to real estate assets across the US and Europe, with more than $10 billion under management. EQT will pay $800 million in new shares and $1.1 billion in cash for Exeter, majority-owned by Ward Fitzgerald and management. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to EQT's earnings this year, following a 34% increase in annual revenue.

site_title: Gold edges down on US stimulus worries, softer dollar limits losses
summary: Gold prices edged lower on Tuesday, down 0.2% to $1,851.26 per ounce, amid concerns over a fresh US coronavirus aid package and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. A weaker US dollar also limited losses. Investors are uncertain about the direction of fiscal spending and the central bank's reaction, weighing on gold prices. The US dollar slipped from a near one-week high, raising gold's appeal for other currency holders. Investors await the US central bank's policy statement on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged lower on Tuesday on concerns over a fresh US coronavirus aid package, while a slightly weaker US dollar and subdued treasury yields limited losses and investors kept a close eye on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: US says US$35b more in pandemic loans approved, trying to fix programme snags
summary: The US Small Business Administration (SBA) has approved an additional $35 billion in pandemic relief loans, bringing the total to $70 billion, as part of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP). However, lenders are experiencing technical issues and receiving incorrect error messages, causing delays in approvals. A review of first-time loans found anomalies in 4.7% of the lender-submitted data, requiring follow-up between lenders and borrowers to access a second round of loans. The SBA is working to address the operational snags and provide guidance to lenders to resolve the issues.

images.alt_text: The US Small Business Administration (SBA) on Tuesday said it had approved 400,000 more pandemic relief loans worth US$35 billion and was trying to fix issues operational snags with the programme raised by lenders.

site_title: Oil prices steady as virus deaths rise, demand worries persist
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday, with Brent crude ending the session up three cents at $55.91 and US crude settling at $52.61, despite rising coronavirus deaths and worries about global demand. A blast in Saudi Arabia and geopolitical tensions in Indonesia also supported prices. However, losses were capped by data showing a decline in US crude inventories and positive news on vaccine roll-outs in the European Union.

site_title: Patrick Grove's Catcha files to raise US$250m for blank-cheque firm
summary: Singapore-based Catcha Group has filed a US$250 million special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) to target tech companies in South-east Asia and Australia, with a focus on those worth over US$1 billion. The SPAC, called Catcha Investment, will be run by co-founders Patrick Grove and Luke Elliot. The company expects to start trading in mid-February and aims to differentiate itself from other SPACs by having entrepreneurs as sponsors, who can better understand the needs of tech founders.

site_title: Europe: Earnings lifts shares, German DAX outperforms
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Tuesday, with the German DAX outperforming, as strong earnings from UBS and Autoliv added to a string of upbeat corporate updates. The International Monetary Fund raised its forecast for global growth in 2021. Despite a gloomy picture of Europe's economy, investors are optimistic about the second half of the year, citing better-than-expected earnings and a recovery in car production.

site_title: UBS plans to buy back 4b francs of shares after wealth management surge
summary: UBS plans to repurchase up to 4 billion francs (S$5.98 billion) of shares over the next three years to bolster shareholder returns. The bank finished 2020 on a strong note with a fourth-quarter net income of US$1.7 billion, beating analyst estimates. CEO Ralph Hamers' start has been overshadowed by a Dutch probe, but the results give him a boost. UBS's focus on wealthy clients and conservative lending helped it navigate the pandemic, with total returns for shareholders at US$3.7 billion in 2020.

site_title: More carats and sparkle: How LVMH plans to change Tiffany
summary: LVMH plans to overhaul Tiffany & Co's merchandise line-up, focusing on gold and precious gems, and upmarket silver bangles. The French luxury group aims to revamp the brand's stores, boosting presence in Europe and Asia. Tiffany's US$15.8 billion takeover is expected to give LVMH the resources to invest in product range and stores worldwide. The company is also considering expanding Tiffany's line-up in watches. Under LVMH, Tiffany's will aim to create an aura of exclusivity, with a focus on high-end products and a more sophisticated brand image.

site_title: US dollar at one-week high ahead of Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-week high against its rivals, reaching 90.65, as investors anticipate the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week. The dollar's strength is attributed to rising US Treasury yields and concerns over the speed and size of US stimulus. The euro slipped 0.2% to US$1.2126, while the Chinese yuan strengthened due to tight liquidity. Emerging market currencies, including the Brazilian real and Mexican peso, remain under pressure. Few changes are expected to the Fed's policy statement, with no new economic forecasts scheduled.

site_title: Biden faces balancing act in dealing with China
summary: US President Joe Biden is navigating a complex balancing act in dealing with China, shifting from a bipartisan consensus of engagement to a more critical stance. Biden's administration views China as America's most dangerous global rival, but seeks to maintain a competitive relationship without escalating tensions. The new policy aims to contain China's rise, promote Western trading norms, and counter Beijing's alleged human rights abuses. However, the approach faces obstacles, including a hostile Congress and a bureaucracy less supportive of engagement with China, and may lead to economic decoupling and confrontation.

site_title: Kim Jones wants to rule the fashion world
summary: Kim Jones, a renowned menswear designer, makes his debut in womenswear at Fendi, taking over as artistic director after Karl Lagerfeld's 54-year tenure. Despite never creating a full women's collection, Jones is confident in his abilities, citing his experience in menswear and collaborations with brands like Supreme and Air Jordan. His Fendi debut, inspired by Virginia Woolf's novel Orlando, features eclectic androgynous designs, including capes, and is seen as a bold move to shake up the luxury fashion industry.

site_title: UK passes 100,000 Covid deaths as European states eye tighter borders
summary: Britain surpassed 100,000 Covid-19 deaths, with a global death toll of 2.1 million and over 100 million infections. Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed his condolences, saying it's "hard to compute" the loss felt by British families. Meanwhile, European nations are considering tighter border controls to combat the spread of new, more transmissible virus strains.

site_title: Vaccine divide between rich and poor worsening, WHO warns
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that the Covid-19 vaccine divide between rich and poor nations is worsening, with the global economy potentially losing up to $9.2 trillion if vaccine nationalism continues. The WHO needs $26 billion to distribute vaccines fairly and curb the pandemic on an equitable basis. Director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urges nations to prioritize vaccine equity, citing the financial damage of the pandemic in wealthy countries and the inter-connectivity of global economies.

images.alt_text: WHO director-general Dr Tedros said that "vaccine nationalism" could cost the global economy up to US$9.2 trillion - almost half of which would be incurred in the wealthiest economies.

site_title: Europe's top football clubs face 2b euros revenue hit from pandemic
summary: Europe's top football clubs are expected to miss out on over 2 billion euros in revenue by the end of the 2020-21 season due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This represents a 12% drop in combined revenue from the 2019/20 season, primarily caused by the deferral of broadcast revenue into the financial year ending in 2021. The major leagues were brought to a standstill in March 2020, resulting in a 1.1 billion euro income loss. This figure is based on Deloitte's Football Money League report.

site_title: Art Basel Switzerland postponed till September
summary: Art Basel Switzerland has postponed its flagship fair initially scheduled for June due to the "ongoing impact of the pandemic and travel restrictions worldwide." The fair is now rescheduled for September 23-26, marking a setback for the international art trade's hopes of returning to in-person normality.

site_title: CapitaLand's pursuit of heft and diversity is not working; it's time to separate growth from value
summary: CapitaLand's shares tumbled after announcing negative earnings guidance for FY2020, with operating profit after tax and minority interests (Patmi) expected to be 30% below FY2019 levels. The company expects a loss for FY2020, with fair value losses ranging from S$1.55 billion to S$1.65 billion and impairment losses between S$800 million and S$900 million. Despite efforts to diversify and reposition itself, CapitaLand's shares have underperformed, trading at a 31.5% discount to NAV, and investors are questioning the company's ability to sustain growth in a post-Covid-19 world.

site_title: Apple plans thinner MacBook Air in Mac line-up reboot
summary: Apple is developing a thinner, lighter version of the MacBook Air, expected to be released in 2022, featuring Apple's MagSafe charging technology and next-generation processors. The new laptop will have a 13-inch screen, weigh 2.8 pounds, and include USB 4 ports. It will be a higher-end version of the current MacBook Air, with the current model remaining in the lineup as an entry-level offering. This update follows Apple's recent product refreshes, including the M1 Mac chip and redesigns of the iMac and MacBook Pro.

site_title: Tokyo's apartment prices rise to near bubble-era high in 2020
summary: Tokyo's newly-built apartment prices rose 1.7% in 2020, reaching a near-record high of 60.84 million yen (S$777,307) due to construction costs linked to the Olympics and high-rise condominiums in waterfront areas. This is the highest price since 1990, when it reached 61.23 million yen during Japan's asset-inflated bubble era.

site_title: EU sustainable investment rules need better corporate data, says banking report
summary: EU sustainable investment rules are aimed at reducing "greenwashing" by businesses, but better corporate data is needed to ensure their effectiveness. A banking report found that 26 major lenders tested the EU framework, welcoming the regulations as they seek to align with the low-carbon economy. However, the report raised concerns over data quality, detail, and standardization, particularly for smaller and mid-sized clients. Regulators are urged to seek global alignment of regulations and develop better data management tools, such as a centralized EU database.

site_title: Emerging markets are investment favourites again, but watch the risks
summary: Emerging markets (EMs) are experiencing a resurgence in popularity among investors, driven by strong outperformance against global equities in 2020. Despite COVID-19 and economic concerns, EM equities returned 18% in 2020, outperforming the MSCI All Country World Index. Fund inflows also increased, reaching $313 billion in 2020, with Oxford Economics forecasting 5% aggregate GDP growth among EMs this year, led by China. However, investors should be cautious, as vaccines may be rolled out more slowly in EMs, and risk appetite can quickly reverse.

site_title: Rolls-Royce cuts 2021 forecasts on travel slump
summary: Rolls-Royce has cut its 2021 forecasts due to the travel slump caused by extra Covid-19 travel restrictions. The company now expects a cash outflow of £2 billion, higher than analyst estimates, which range from £900 million to £1.55 billion. The downgrade is attributed to the restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of new Covid-19 variants.

images.alt_text: To ride out the pandemic, Rolls-Royce plans to sell assets worth £2 billion.

site_title: Stop the inequality virus
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated economic inequality globally, particularly in Asia, where 711 billionaires have seen their fortunes increase by $1.5 trillion since March 2020. In contrast, the world's poorest are struggling to recover, with some estimates suggesting it could take over 10 years for them to return to pre-pandemic levels. Oxfam urges Asian governments to take bold policy measures to address inequality, including investing in essential care services, taxing the rich, and providing universal social protection. The pandemic has also disproportionately affected women and marginalized groups, highlighting the need for a fair and just economic recovery.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's DPU up 27.5%; data centre market likely to get 'very tight' in H2 2021
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 27.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second half of 2020, driven by strong demand for data centre space. The company's occupancy rate stands at 97.8%, with limited space available for expansion. The Singapore government's moratorium on building new data centres is expected to keep the market "very tight" in the second half of 2021, despite efforts to encourage greener data centres and renewable energy. Keppel DC Reit's pipeline of assets is strong, with attractive yields and DPU-accretive potential.

site_title: Balance frequency of property valuation reviews with a longer-term outlook
summary: Singapore's property companies may need to reassess their valuation review frequency amid the ongoing pandemic, but a more balanced approach is required. Analysts suggest a more robust quarterly assessment on the impact of the crisis on individual assets rather than full valuations. Industry experts, such as CBRE and Colliers, recommend reviewing valuations more frequently, but caution against short-term swings and the potential volatility to stock prices. A long-term outlook is also essential to accurately report a company's financial position.

site_title: Blackrock urges firms to prep for net-zero transition
summary: BlackRock CEO Laurence Fink urged companies to prepare for a net-zero transition, calling it a "historic investment opportunity" and distinguishing those with a plan from those that won't. The firm, managing over $7.8 trillion in assets, plans to intensify its engagement with companies to hold directors accountable and disclose a plan for net-zero emissions by 2050. Companies with a well-articulated strategy will distinguish themselves, while those that fail to prepare will see their businesses suffer.

site_title: Japan's Lower House passes extra budget featuring travel campaign
summary: Japan's Lower House approved a third extra budget of 19 trillion yen, despite criticism over its focus on a government tourism campaign. The budget allocates 60% for promoting a green and digitalized economy and 16% for infrastructure spending, leaving 23% for vaccine roll-outs and medical aid. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga defended the budget, citing its potential to create 460,000 jobs, but opposition parties called for redirecting funds to more urgent medical needs. The budget's enactment is now secured, with the Upper House lacking the power to override it.

site_title: More meaningful to get boards to set diversity goals, report progress
summary: Singapore's companies need to improve board diversity, with only 11% of board seats held by women, according to a study by Willis Towers Watson. Experts suggest that setting self-declared targets and reporting progress could be more meaningful than introducing official requirements. Having quotas could drive change, but it may also lead to tokenism. Some argue that board diversity is not a determinant of good corporate governance, and that a more nuanced approach is needed to measure and select board members. Companies like Mewah International and Yeo Hiap Seng have shown success in achieving diversity on their boards, but more needs to be done to address the issue.

site_title: No cash flow? S$42.6m still awaiting claims from corporate owners
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Finance has a website where S$42.6 million, mostly unclaimed by businesses, is waiting to be claimed by companies and individuals. This amount includes corporate tax refunds, levy bonds, and security deposits, with the largest single sum being a corporate tax refund of S$190,000. The unclaimed money, totaling S$274 million, is held by various ministries and statutory boards. Claimants can search for their refunds on the website and make the necessary request, with refunds made without interest and transfers to the government's consolidated fund after six years.

site_title: What Biden's Asia pivot signals
summary: US President Joe Biden's appointment of Kurt Campbell as coordinator of his approach to the Indo-Pacific region signals a coherent and realistic China strategy. Campbell, a key architect of the "Pivot to Asia" under the Obama administration, emphasizes the need for the US to address domestic imbalances, engage diplomatically with allies, and re-engage in trade initiatives. He also proposes investing in Asia-oriented human capital to build capacity. This marks a significant shift in the US' approach to Asia, potentially making it the first among equals in the region, and may lead to a more active trade policy and improved relations with China.

site_title: Hillman strikes US$2.64b merger with blank-cheque firm Landcadia
summary: Construction hardware supplier Hillman Group has agreed to a US$2.64 billion merger with Landcadia Holdings III, a blank-cheque company led by Tilman Fertitta. Hillman will retain its operations and relationships with over 38,000 companies, including Lowe's and Home Depot. Private equity firm CCMP will remain the largest shareholder. CEO Doug Cahill cited a shift in how people think of their residences and the trend towards home renovations as key drivers for the merger. Investors led by Wells Capital Management and Columbia Threadneedle Investments will contribute US$375 million in equity to support the transaction.

site_title: Beware the GOP's fake budget hawks
summary: US President Joe Biden has announced a $1.9 trillion "American Rescue Plan" to address the COVID-19 pandemic, education, infrastructure, and state/local finances. However, this move is met with skepticism from Republicans, who are rediscovering their long-standing opposition to budget deficits. This is the third cycle of Republicans reversing their stance on deficits since the 1980s, following similar patterns during the 1990s and 2000s under Presidents Reagan and Bush. Experts warn that the US is now starting a fourth cycle, with large-scale federal borrowing needed to finance spending on worthy causes, but Republicans are likely to oppose Biden's spending proposals.

site_title: Malaysia's opposition leader challenges PM over Parliament suspension
summary: Malaysia's opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has launched a lawsuit against Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin over the suspension of Parliament during a state of emergency aimed at fighting the COVID-19 pandemic. Anwar's lawyer claims the suspension was "unlawful and unconstitutional" and seeks a judicial review of the advice given to the king. The move comes as the country struggles with over 190,000 infections and 700 deaths, with strict curbs in place across the country. Anwar's lawsuit challenges the prime minister's use of the emergency to cling to power amid government instability.

site_title: Making a case for alternative fuels
summary: A recent webinar by the International Bunker Industry Association and the UK Chamber of Shipping discussed alternative fuels for the shipping industry, focusing on Shell's Gas To Liquid (GTL) technology. GTL converts liquefied natural gas into liquid products, offering a "drop-in" fuel that can be used interchangeably with traditional marine fuels, reducing local emissions. However, GTL is significantly more expensive than current fuels, limiting its adoption. Despite its potential, the shipping industry has not widely adopted GTL, mainly due to the extra costs involved, and it is currently mainly used in European waters and ports.

site_title: Ant IPO could resume once issues are resolved: PBOC
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang said Ant Group Co can resume its IPO plans once issues related to monopolies are resolved. Regulators are investigating monopolies at Ant, a fintech giant owned by billionaire Jack Ma, and need a clear legal framework to resolve problems. Yi Gang stated that Ant needs to overhaul its business and come up with a timetable to address issues, avoiding a worst-case scenario of shutting down businesses. Ant's valuation may be cut further under new measures proposed by China to curb market concentration.

site_title: Leon Black cedes Apollo's reins after Epstein sex scandal
summary: Leon Black, co-founder and former CEO of Apollo Global Management, steps down as CEO amid ongoing damage control over the company's ties to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The move comes after over a year of negative headlines. Black's departure is seen as a strategic decision to distance Apollo from the scandal and maintain its reputation. The company's board will now oversee its operations, allowing Black to maintain a role as executive chairman.

site_title: Consumer confidence in US improves on outlook for economy
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 89.3 in January, surpassing economists' median forecast of 89. Optimism about the economy and job market increased due to further fiscal aid and the distribution of coronavirus vaccines. The gauge of expectations reached a three-month high of 92.5, while a measure of sentiment about current conditions decreased to 84.4, the worst reading since May. The improvement in consumer confidence is a positive sign for the US economy, but concerns about inflation and the ongoing pandemic remain.

site_title: WHO experts issue recommendations on Moderna Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has recommended the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine be given in two doses with an interval of 28 days, which can be extended to 42 days under exceptional circumstances. The vaccine should not be used on pregnant women unless they are health workers exposed to the virus or have medical conditions putting them at high risk. WHO experts are currently reviewing data on the vaccine's use in pregnant women and are liaising with Moderna to make a decision on WHO emergency use listing.

site_title: 3M profits jump amid heavy demand for face masks
summary: 3M reported a 43.3% increase in fourth-quarter earnings to $1.4 billion, driven by strong demand for personal safety and cleaning products amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenues rose 5.8% to $8.6 billion. The company projects 5-8% sales growth in 2021. Despite dented revenues in elective health procedures and hospitality, 3M's health care business remains a key area of strength. The company's production capacity for N95 masks has been raised to 2.5 billion units.

site_title: As rebates end, restaurants and retailers reel from rent, deposit hikes
summary: Singapore's retail and food and beverage (F&B) businesses are struggling with unexpected rent hikes and hefty security deposits as they recover from the pandemic. Tenants reported rent increments of up to 20% and landlords are asking for four to six months' deposits for a one-year renewal. Industry sources say this is exacerbating tensions between tenants and landlords, with some landlords prioritizing shorter renewals and higher gross turnover rents. Experts warn that unsustainable rents could harm retailers' ability to invest in digital transformation and marketing campaigns, and tenants should carefully consider their options before renewing leases.

site_title: Twitter acquires newsletter startup Revue to expand business
summary: Twitter acquired newsletter startup Revue to expand its business, giving writers on the platform more features. Revue's service will continue operating as a standalone service, with Twitter eliminating some fees to encourage more people to create newsletters. Twitter aims to expand its business outside of advertising, where it generates 85% of its annual revenue, and explore audience-based monetization options. The acquisition also marks Twitter's latest effort to grow its team, following recent purchases of social video app Squad, podcast company Breaker, and a design firm.

site_title: Tesla, BMW approved for slice of US$3.5b EU battery aid
summary: The European Union has approved US$3.5 billion in state aid for battery projects, including companies like Tesla and BMW, to strengthen the bloc's electric vehicle production capabilities. The aid is expected to trigger over three times as much private investment, totaling 12 billion euros. The goal is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport and meet the EU's climate neutrality target by 2050. The projects will cover the entire battery value chain and aim to develop new technologies, including synthetic materials, to reduce reliance on Asian battery producers.

site_title: Conte quits as Italy's PM in tactical bid to build new majority
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte resigned on Tuesday amid a deepening political crisis, aiming to build a new majority. Conte lost his absolute majority in the Senate after a junior partner quit, and efforts to lure centrist and independent senators into the coalition have been unsuccessful. President Sergio Mattarella will start consultations to find a new administration, and Conte will have a few days to finalize a deal. Conte's popularity remains high, with an approval rating of 56%, and he may try to form his own party or take charge of the 5-Star Movement if ousted from office.

site_title: Closing the funding gap for green urban infrastructure
summary: Standard Chartered highlights the need to close the funding gap for green urban infrastructure to mitigate climate change risks. A $2.5 trillion annual financing gap is forecasted for emerging markets by 2030, and a $10 trillion gap is estimated for 15 high-growth markets in Asia and Africa. Innovative financing forms, such as blended deals, can unlock progress with NGOs, governments, and insurers working together. Standard Chartered is committing $40 billion in project financing services by 2024 and withdrawing services from clients reliant on coal. Collaboration and multilateralism are key to addressing the sustainable financing gap and creating a more resilient and sustainable world.

site_title: Malaysia secures 18.4m doses of Russian, Chinese Covid-19 vaccines
summary: Malaysia has secured 18.4 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines from Russian and Chinese producers, with pharmaceutical firm Duopharma supplying 6.4 million doses of Sputnik V and Malaysia Pharmaniaga providing 12 million doses of Sinovac's vaccine. The deals will cover 28.75% of the population, subject to regulatory approval. This addition to the country's vaccine procurement comes as Malaysia reports 3,585 new coronavirus cases, bringing its cumulative total to 190,434 and 700 deaths.

site_title: Jane Fonda to get lifetime award at Golden Globes
summary: Jane Fonda will receive the Cecil B deMille lifetime achievement award at the Golden Globes ceremony on February 28. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) recognized Fonda for her 60-year career in film, television, and her commitment to social issues. HFPA president Ali Sar praised Fonda's "undeniable talent" and "unwavering commitment to evoking change."

site_title: China's Covid-19 vaccines can be upgraded for variants in 2 months, says expert
summary: China's Covid-19 vaccines can be upgraded to combat new variants in approximately 2 months, according to an expert with the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. The vaccines, which are based on the inactivated virus, have shown weaker neutralizing abilities against recently discovered variants in the UK and South Africa. This upgrade could be completed faster than for mRNA-based vaccines, which require less time and effort. The move aims to address concerns that existing vaccines may be less effective against new variants.

site_title: Singapore's FDI flows were down 37% in 2020
summary: Singapore's foreign direct investment (FDI) flows declined 37% to US$58 billion in 2020, a gentler contraction than the global 42% drop. This left FDI flows 30% below the post-2009 trough. In contrast, Malaysia's FDI fell 68%, while Indonesia's declined 24%. The region, however, remains a strong FDI engine, with over US$70 billion in new greenfield investments. A recovery in FDI is anticipated, driven by the signing of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

site_title: Ant IPO could resume once issues resolved: PBOC
summary: China's central bank chief, Yi Gang, says Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) could resume once issues related to monopolies are resolved. The People's Bank of China is investigating issues and needs a clear legal framework to resolve the problems. Regulators are asking Ant to overhaul its business and come up with a timetable, avoiding a worst-case scenario of shuttering businesses completely. The news offers relief to global investors, who had been seeking signs on Ant's future after its US$35 billion IPO was halted in November.

site_title: US: Stocks steady amid earnings deluge
summary: US stocks remained steady on Tuesday as investors digested a deluge of earnings reports and looked forward to key consumer confidence data and a Federal Reserve policy announcement. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 rose 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.1%. Big companies, including General Electric and 3M, projected higher 2021 sales amid an expected economic improvement with the spread of coronavirus vaccines. The IMF projects 5.5% global growth in 2021, but cautions of "extraordinary uncertainty" amid Covid-19.

site_title: IMF boosts world growth outlook as vaccines outweigh uncertainty
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its global growth forecast to 5.5% for 2021, citing the rollout of coronavirus vaccines and fiscal stimulus as key factors. The upgrade is driven by improvements in the US economy, but cuts are made to forecasts for the euro area and UK. This would be the best growth in four decades, matching the 2007 expansion, and follows an upwardly revised 3% contraction last year. The IMF projects a 4.2% global expansion for 2022, with major central banks maintaining policy-rate settings and financial conditions remaining stable.

site_title: China asset-bubble warning threatens stock frenzy in HK
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), withdrew $12 billion from the banking system through open-market operations, sparking a chill in financial markets. An official warned about asset bubbles, which threatens a stock frenzy in Hong Kong. The move is unusual, as liquidity is typically maintained before the Chinese New Year holiday. The warning and cash drain raise concerns about China's economic growth and pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Asia has many faces; businesses will have to adapt
summary: By 2030, Asia's middle class is expected to reach 5.4 billion consumers, with close to two-thirds coming from the region. This demographic shift will significantly influence demand for products and services, making it crucial for businesses to adapt. Asia's internet usage is predominantly mobile, with mobile devices accounting for over two-thirds of internet traffic. The 5G wave is expected to bring new technologies and applications, creating opportunities for investors. Major tech firms, such as Tencent, Bytedance, and Alibaba, are setting up operations in Singapore, which is becoming a hub for engineering and research and development. The greying population in Asia will drive healthcare spending, benefiting healthcare providers and adjacent services. Investors must be selective in choosing companies that can serve the needs of these new growth paths.

images.alt_text: Shopee tweaked its focus to flash sales in Malaysia where big discount events are better received.

site_title: Biden stimulus plan could boost US output by 5 per cent over three years: IMF
summary: US President Joe Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion economic stimulus package could boost US economic output by 5% over the next three years, according to the IMF's chief economist Gita Gopinath. Preliminary estimates suggest the package could add 1.5% to US growth in 2021, when the IMF projects a 5.1% expansion after a 3.4% contraction in 2020. The stimulus plan aims to stimulate economic growth and support recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong enacts second lockdown in Kowloon for Covid tests
summary: Hong Kong has implemented a second neighborhood lockdown in the densely-populated Kowloon area to combat a fourth surge of coronavirus cases. The lockdown, which began on Tuesday, involves mandatory virus testing for residents in a dozen buildings, and aims to end by Wednesday. The measure follows a targeted, two-day lockdown over the weekend that tested 7,000 people.
