The city has seen over 10,000 total cases and 172 deaths since the pandemic began, with the government warning of the possibility of future lockdowns if needed to battle the outbreak.

site_title: Harvard applications surge as students flock to biggest names
summary: Harvard University received a record 57,000 undergraduate applications for the 2021-22 academic year, a 42% surge from the previous year. The pandemic led to a shift away from standardized test scores, with Harvard no longer requiring them. The increased applications come as students adapt to the changing college application process.

site_title: Thai health minister urges understanding over vaccine plan
summary: Thailand's health minister, Anutin Charnvirakul, has sought to explain the country's coronavirus vaccine procurement plan amid criticism of the government's lack of transparency. The plan involves a deal with AstraZeneca to produce locally 26 million doses of its vaccine, with an additional 35 million doses reserved. The minister assured that the plan does not have a political aim and is focused on public health and safety. The country aims to vaccinate 31.5 million of its 70 million people with 63 million doses, reaching herd immunity.

site_title: SGX RegCo to review Rich Capital's potential listing-rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has launched an independent review into potential listing-rule breaches by property developer Rich Capital. The review, led by Provenance Capital, was initiated in August 2019 after several announcements regarding a project in Batam, Indonesia. The review's findings will be reported to the relevant authorities and may lead to further investigations. Rich Capital has appointed Provenance Capital as an independent reviewer to examine the circumstances surrounding the contract.

site_title: Anwar challenges PM over Parliament suspension
summary: Malaysia's opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has launched a lawsuit against Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin over the suspension of Parliament during a national emergency declared to combat the coronavirus. Anwar's lawyer, Ramkarpal Singh, stated that the opposition is challenging the prime minister's advice to the king to suspend parliament, claiming it is "unlawful and unconstitutional." The lawsuit seeks a judicial review of the advice, which allowed Muhyiddin to cling to power as his government was on the brink of collapse. Anwar's action comes amid the country's record-breaking COVID-19 cases and strict curbs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore factory output rose 14.3% in December, driven by a semiconductor surge, while pharmaceuticals declined. The full-year growth was 7.3%. A survey found three in 10 firms lack confidence in sustaining business this year, but seven in 10 remain hopeful for recovery. FDI flows in Singapore declined 37% in 2020, but were gentler than the global contraction. Stocks fell for the third consecutive day, with the STI down 0.9%, while corporate earnings showed mixed results.

site_title: Three previous Covid-19 cases test positive for UK strain in Singapore
summary: Three previously reported Covid-19 cases in Singapore have tested positive for the B117 UK strain, linked to Jewel Changi Airport and Changi Airport Terminal 3 on December 31. The Ministry of Health will offer testing for staff and public areas affected. Meanwhile, 14 new imported cases were announced, with two Singaporeans and one permanent resident returning from Russia, the UK, and the US. The total number of cases in Singapore is now 59,366, with 59,071 fully recovered and 50 patients in hospital.

site_title: UBS reaps rich rewards from pandemic with strongest performance since 2006
summary: UBS reported its highest annual pre-tax profit since 2006, with a 54% increase to $6.6 billion, driven by strong lending to the ultra-rich, bumper trading volumes, and investment gains. The bank's wealth management division saw record invested assets of $4 trillion, while its investment banking pre-tax profits jumped to $529 million. UBS announced a new three-year share buyback program of up to $4.5 billion and plans to adjust shareholder returns to favor buybacks. The bank's results beat forecasts, with CEO Ralph Hamers attributing the success to the bank's stability and confidence in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Didi close to raising US$1.5b for trucking unit
summary: Didi Chuxing Technology is close to securing a US$1.5 billion funding round for its on-demand trucking unit, Didi Freight, surpassing its initial target of US$400 million. The funding, led by Temasek Holdings, Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital, and IDG Capital, aims to capitalize on China's economic recovery and strain on the domestic logistics network. This move is part of Didi's diversification efforts, following the launch of its on-demand logistics service in June, which handles over 100,000 orders daily.

site_title: Bonvests, Zhongxin Fruit and Juice issue profit warnings
summary: Property group Bonvests Holdings and Zhongxin Fruit and Juice issued profit warnings for their full and half fiscal years ended Dec 31, 2020. Bonvests expects a loss due to Covid-19's impact on revenue, while Zhongxin is expected to report a net loss due to impairment of property and equipment. Zhongxin's share price surged 106.5% on Tuesday after the profit warning, prompting a trading query from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline for third consecutive day; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks declined for a third consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.9% or 28.13 points to 2,945.52. The losses were attributed to market uncertainty over US fiscal stimulus and European lockdowns. 25 out of 30 STI counters declined, with only four managing gains. The top gainer was Keppel DC Reit, while Biolidics rose 4.8% after launching a Covid-19 antigen test kit.

site_title: CDL ranked world's top real estate company on Global 100 index
summary: CDL ranked world's top real estate company on the Global 100 most sustainable corporations index, taking the 40th place globally and third consecutive year as Singapore's top-ranked most sustainable company. CDL has been included in the index for 12 years in a row, making it the first and only Singapore company to achieve this milestone.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit H2 DPU up 27.5% to 4.795 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 27.5% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.795 Singapore cents, driven by 39.1% year-on-year growth in distributable income to S$81.9 million. The Reit's gross revenue grew 42.6% to S$141.6 million, while property expenses increased 36.7%. The company's portfolio occupancy rate reached 97.8% and it has "comfortable debt headroom" for future acquisitions. The Reit's assets under management increased to approximately S$3.0 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 1.31 points to 1,575.31. The index saw a volume of 5.930 billion lots worth RM4.735 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 601 to 537.

site_title: Sheng Siong staff to get up to 16 months' bonus for FY2020
summary: Sheng Siong, a supermarket operator, will give staff bonuses of up to 16 months, with the highest bonus being 15.72 months for assistant managers. The bonus, which includes an annual wage supplement, is due to the company's strong performance in FY2020, driven by elevated demand during the Covid-19 pandemic. Eligible staff will receive total bonuses ranging from 4.68 to 16 months, depending on their rank and employment status. The company recognized its "extremely well-performed" results in 2020.

site_title: Singapore factory growth tipped to carry over into 2021 - but capped by high base
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a strong rebound in 2020, with industrial production rising 7.3% year-on-year, driven by growth in the electronics and biomedical clusters. Economists expect the economy to outperform in 2021, but caution that a high base effect may cap factory growth, potentially moderating to 3-4% year-on-year. Risks include potential escalation of US-China tensions and a slowdown in the global electronics supply chain.

site_title: All 24 towns to have community vaccination centre each by end-March: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore plans to establish 24 community vaccination centres by end-March, with each town having its own facility, to quickly distribute COVID-19 vaccines, particularly to the elderly. This move is part of the nationwide vaccination drive, with the first two centres already operational in Tanjong Pagar and Ang Mo Kio. The centres aim to ensure a smooth and efficient distribution of vaccines, allowing the population to receive the necessary protection.

images.alt_text: Each of the 24 towns here will have one community vaccination centre by end-March, as the nation ramps up its Covid-19 vaccination drive.

site_title: United Global to form JV with Latitude Shipping
summary: United Global's subsidiary, United Supply Chain, has formed a 45-55% joint venture with Latitude Shipping to acquire a 49% stake in Indonesia-based maritime-transport service provider PT LIMA for approximately US$3.8 million. The JV aims to expand into other businesses and seize new growth opportunities in industries outside of lubricants. United Global's shares closed flat at S$0.41 following the announcement. The joint venture is expected to increase the issued and paid-up share capital to US$4.5 million.

site_title: Top global traders work to ease seafarer crisis due to coronavirus
summary: Top global traders have formed a joint effort to address the seafarer crisis caused by the coronavirus, affecting hundreds of thousands of merchant sailors stranded on ships for months. The initiative, known as the "Neptune Declaration," brings together over 300 companies, including major shipping groups and trading companies, to boost information sharing and speed up crew changes. The aim is to provide a collaborative response to the humanitarian crisis and recognize seafarers as key workers, essential to safe and efficient operations.

site_title: 14 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 14 new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore as of Jan 26, all of which were imported. The cases were placed on stay-home notice upon arrival. This brings Singapore's total cases to 59,366. The Ministry of Health reported no new cases in the community for the fourth consecutive day and no cases from workers' dormitories.

site_title: Nepal's star K2 climber does it his way
summary: Nepali mountaineer Nirmal Purja, known as "Nims," has led an all-Nepali team to conquer K2, the world's second-highest mountain, in winter conditions. The team, united by their goal of claiming the record for Nepal, successfully summited the mountain without oxygen. Purja, a former elite soldier and mountaineer, has set numerous records, including climbing all 8,000-meter peaks in six months. This achievement is seen as a historic milestone for Nepal, and Purja credits his team's unity and determination for the success.

site_title: Singapore factory output up by 14.3% in December, taking full-year growth to 7.3%
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 14.3% in December, exceeding expectations, driven by a semiconductor surge in the electronics segment. The full-year manufacturing growth reached 7.3%, with electronics expanding by 41.8% and biomedical cluster declining 13.2%. The government aims to grow manufacturing value by 50% over the next decade.

site_title: Wheels Up in talks with SPAC to go public
summary: Wheels Up Partners, a private jet charter company, is in talks with blank-cheque acquisition company Aspirational Consumer Lifestyle to go public through a merger valued at over $2 billion. Aspirational Consumer Lifestyle has raised $225 million in an initial public offering and has engaged potential investors for a private investment in public equity transaction. Wheels Up, valued at $1.1 billion in 2019, would be the latest aviation company to merge with a SPAC to list its shares on the stock market.

site_title: China's peak Lunar New Year air travel season fizzles as Covid cases rise
summary: China's Lunar New Year air travel season has seen a significant decline in bookings, with a 73.7% drop in bookings made as of Jan 19 compared to 2019. The COVID-19 outbreak and resulting travel restrictions have led to this decrease, with the government discouraging travel and requiring negative nucleic acid test results for those who do travel. As a result, airline bookings have plummeted, and ticket prices have dropped to their lowest level in five years. Experts predict a reduction of 6 million trips and a delayed full recovery of airline revenue to pre-crisis levels.

site_title: Spotify tests audiobooks of classics including 'Persuasion,' 'Frankenstein'
summary: Spotify is testing audiobooks of nine classic novels, including "Persuasion" and "Frankenstein," narrated by celebrities such as Hilary Swank and Forest Whitaker. The audiobooks are available for free globally due to the public domain status of the works. This expansion follows Spotify's recent foray into podcasts and its recruitment of a head of audiobooks. The test aims to improve user experience, with the results potentially paving the way for a broader audiobook selection.

images.alt_text: Streaming giant Spotify is extending its foray into audiobooks, dropping nine new public-domain classics narrated by celebrities including Hilary Swank and Forest Whitaker.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the start of trading on Tuesday, following a previous session's decline due to increasing virus lockdown measures. The FTSE 100 index opened flat at 6,639.07 points, while the eurozone's Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 indices also remained stable. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Singapore listcos' AGM attendance slid in 2020; hybrid meetings a 'next step': report
summary: Singapore-listed companies' Annual General Meetings (AGMs) saw a 70% decline in shareholder attendance in 2020 due to COVID-19 safe-distancing measures. The majority postponed meetings to later months, with June being the most popular month for virtual meetings. Attendees observed proceedings via audio and video, with meetings lasting an average of 54 minutes shorter than physical meetings. Despite technical issues, more than half of respondents plan to consider electronic meetings in the future, with a potential shift towards hybrid models.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drop on liquidity fears in China, US stimulus worries
summary: South Korean stocks fell 2.14% on Tuesday, with the Kospi benchmark dropping 68.68 points to 3,140.31, amid liquidity fears in China and uncertainty over a US stimulus package. Foreign investors turned net sellers, while retail investors net purchased shares. Heavyweight chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix dropped 3.02% and 4.44%, respectively. The decline overshadowed data showing South Korea's faster-than-expected fourth-quarter growth.

site_title: India likely to double health spending next fiscal year: sources
summary: India is likely to double its health spending to 1.2-1.3 trillion rupees in the next fiscal year, aiming to raise expenditure to 4% of GDP over the next four years. This move comes after the COVID-19 pandemic exposed the country's underfunded healthcare system, with states forced to set up makeshift care centers and hospitals struggling to meet demand. The plan, set to be unveiled by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, will be funded by a dedicated health fund and increased health taxes.

images.alt_text: India is likely to double health spending in the next fiscal year with the aim of raising expenditure in the sector to 4 per cent of gross domestic output in the coming four years.

site_title: Netherlands has worst riots in four decades over Covid curbs
summary: The Netherlands experienced its worst civil unrest in four decades due to a government-imposed curfew aimed at curbing the pandemic. Rioting occurred in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, and smaller cities, with 184 people arrested on the third night of protests. The disturbances were described as "criminal violence" by caretaker Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who is likely to remain in office despite the unrest, as his party consolidates its position ahead of the national election on March 17. The curfew has been in place since Saturday amidst concern over new coronavirus variants.

images.alt_text: The Netherlands faced its worst civil unrest in four decades after a third night of rioting against a government curfew aimed at curbing the pandemic, just weeks before a national election.

site_title: Indonesia set to pass 1 million coronavirus cases as vaccinations roll out
summary: Indonesia is set to surpass 1 million coronavirus cases, with 999,256 infections reported as of Monday, according to official data. The country has struggled to control the pandemic, with 28,132 deaths. Health experts believe the true spread of the virus is likely to be far worse due to low testing and contact-tracing rates. The government has started its vaccination program and tightened movement restrictions, but has been criticized for prioritizing vaccine distribution over enforcing health protocols.

site_title: Britain to help other countries track down coronavirus variants
summary: Britain will share its genomic sequencing capabilities with other countries to help track down new coronavirus variants. The country has carried out over half of the SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences globally and will launch a New Variant Assessment Platform to better understand the virus. The platform will aid global capacity to understand coronavirus, including future pandemics. Britain's health minister has warned of a "vaccine-busting" variant, prompting concerns over vaccine effectiveness against variants discovered in South Africa and Brazil. The move aims to bolster global preparedness for the virus.

site_title: Tokyo revises contact tracing strategy, narrows to higher-risk cases
summary: Tokyo has revised its contact-tracing strategy to prioritize outreach to higher-risk individuals affected by the coronavirus, such as the elderly and those with pre-existing conditions. The move comes as the city faces a third wave of the pandemic, overwhelming its public health centers. The revised strategy aims to help public health workers cope with the rising number of cases, despite concerns over scaling back efforts to trace the contacts of every person. Neighboring prefectures have also revised their policies to focus on high-risk individuals.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises China Aviation Oil target price as air traffic recovers
summary: DBS Group Research raised its target price for China Aviation Oil (CAO) to S$1.38 from S$1.20, maintaining its "buy" call, due to a strong recovery in China's domestic air travel and improvements in international air travel as vaccination efforts continue. Analysts estimate an ex-cash price-to-earnings ratio at less than three times for FY2021, benefiting CAO from higher departing frequencies at Shanghai Pudong International Airport.

site_title: Swedish private equity firm EQT buys investment manager Exeter
summary: EQT, a Swedish private equity firm, has acquired Exeter Property Group, a global real estate investment manager, for $1.87 billion. Exeter, with over $10 billion in assets under management, will accelerate EQT's strategy of building a globally-scaled real estate platform. The deal marks growth for EQT, with the firm reporting increased net income for 2020. Exeter's management team, led by Ward Fitzgerald, will remain in place. The acquisition is expected to diversify EQT's presence in private markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.96% on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 28,546.18, amid concerns over fresh lockdowns in Europe and potential US stimulus delays. Investors remained cautious ahead of corporate earnings, with some brokers citing a "worsening situation in Europe" and "tariff threats" as reasons for the decline. Despite this, the US stimulus package is expected to remain a positive factor in the long run. Trading was sluggish due to investor caution, with the Topix index also losing 0.75%.

site_title: Luxury cars fuel Hyundai Q4 profit
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported a 57% surge in quarterly profit due to strong demand for high-margin SUVs and premium Genesis cars, despite a stronger won eroding overseas sales. The company forecast a 12% increase in sales in North America and 5% revenue growth. Analysts attributed the boost to higher average-selling-price cars, holiday deals, and solid demand in emerging markets. Hyundai expects to sell 562,000 vehicles in China and 909,000 in North America this year, with electric vehicle sales expected to boost despite a global recall.

site_title: South Korea probes adequacy of Hyundai's Kona EV recall after new fire: ministry official
summary: A Hyundai Kona EV in South Korea has caught fire for the first time after undergoing a recall, prompting an investigation into the adequacy of the recall process. The incident, which occurred in the city of Daegu, is among 11 reported fires involving the Kona EV, which were recalled due to a risk of short circuit from faulty battery cells. The vehicle had only received a software update, not a battery replacement, and is the first of the recalled model to catch fire. Authorities are now examining whether the recall process was sufficient to prevent such incidents.

site_title: Bukit Timah, Duke's Road sites up for en bloc sale with S$62.5m guide price
summary: A collective sale of three adjoining mixed-use redevelopment sites in Singapore's Bukit Timah and Duke's Road areas has been put up for sale with a guide price of S$62.5 million. The 16,479 sq ft site, zoned for residential and commercial use, features 40 residential units averaging 85 sq meters and has a gross plot ratio of 3.0. The tender exercise closes on March 4, with JLL expecting good responses from small to mid-sized developers due to the current market sentiments.

images.alt_text: The freehold 16,479 square foot site is zoned for residential and commercial use.

site_title: More carats and sparkle: How LVMH plans to change Tiffany
summary: LVMH, the parent company of Louis Vuitton, plans to overhaul Tiffany & Co's merchandise lineup to focus on gold and precious gems, with a greater emphasis on high-end jewelry. The company aims to boost its presence in Europe and Asia, revamp store appearances, and expand into watches. Tiffany's current products range from affordable silver jewelry to diamond necklaces, but LVMH plans to shift focus to the higher-end market. The new leadership team, led by Bernard Arnault, aims to elevate Tiffany's standing and create an aura of exclusivity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.55% on Tuesday, led by investor concerns over the timing of a new US stimulus and a Chinese central bank's decision to absorb excess liquidity. The Hang Seng Index dropped 767.75 points to 29,391.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 54.81 points to 3,569.43. The decline was also attributed to cross-border investment flows being put on hold.

site_title: Bitcoin seen topping US$50,000 long term as it vies with gold
summary: Bitcoin's price may reach over US$50,000 in the long term as it competes with gold for investment flows, according to Luno and OSL. The digital asset has quadrupled in value this year, with increasing interest from long-term investors and hedge against inflation. Predictions are challenging, but experts believe it will rise as funds allocate 0.5-1% of their portfolios to Bitcoin. The asset currently trades at around US$31,500, up 9% this year.

site_title: Union lauds Biden action on slaughter speeds industry calls safe
summary: The US Department of Agriculture withdrew a proposed rule allowing poultry producers to kill more chickens per minute, a move praised by the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union as prioritizing worker safety. The rule, which would have increased speeds to 175 birds per minute, was opposed by critics citing increased injury rates and potential Covid-19 infection rates. Industry groups, however, said elevated line speeds were safe and effective, citing a 86% decline in injury and illness rates over the past 25 years.

site_title: EV charging firm FreeWire closes funding round from Riverstone
summary: FreeWire Technologies Inc, an electric vehicle charging startup, has raised US$50 million in a series C funding round led by Riverstone Holdings. Existing shareholders, including BP's venture arm and Alumni Ventures Group, also participated. This brings FreeWire's total funding to US$100 million. The company's valuation in the new round is not immediately available. The funding round follows FreeWire's previous funding rounds and solidifies its position in the electric vehicle charging market.

site_title: Indonesia raises economic recovery budget to nearly 553.09t rupiah
summary: Indonesia's government has raised its economic recovery budget to 553.09 trillion rupiah (S$52.3 billion), a 49% increase from the previously approved 372.3 trillion rupiah. The increased budget aims to support economic recovery in 2021, similar to the support provided in 2020. The move is a response to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the country's economy.

site_title: Asia: Stocks weaken on stimulus worries, dollar holds firm
summary: Asian stocks weakened on Tuesday, retreating from record highs due to lingering concerns about potential roadblocks to the US stimulus package. The dollar held firm, while oil prices edged down. South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan, and Chinese stocks all fell, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index dipping 0.7% to near a record high. US lawmakers agreed on prioritizing Covid-19 vaccine distribution, but disagreements over the stimulus package remain, with fourth-quarter GDP data set to release this week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped at Tuesday's open, following a 2% rally the previous day due to concerns over a potential US stimulus delay. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.88% to 29,892.85, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes eased 0.37% and 0.40% respectively. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Thai banks' resilience to be tested as moratoriums expire: S&P Global Ratings
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns that Thai banks' resilience will be tested as moratoriums expire, with the non-performing loan ratio expected to increase to 6% in the next 12-24 months. The agency attributes this to the high household debt and tough environment for export-oriented SMEs. Credit losses are forecast to remain elevated at 1.9% of outstanding loans this year, and a U-shaped recovery in 2021 is expected, with GDP growth of 5%. A prolonged economic delay could deepen the downside scenario for domestic banks.

images.alt_text: Credit risk is already heightened in Thailand given the very high household debt and tough environment for export-oriented SMEs, some of which are getting priced out by more cost-efficient manufacturers in Vietnam and Cambodia.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,961.92 at Tuesday's open, following mixed global markets amid corporate earnings and concerns over vaccine rollouts. Tech shares surged on Wall Street, while European shares hit two-week lows due to German business morale concerns. Asian markets, including Tokyo, also opened lower.

site_title: Listen-in social network Clubhouse readies for the masses
summary: Clubhouse, a private invite-only audio social network, is expanding to the masses with a fresh funding round valued at nearly $1 billion. The platform, which allows users to listen in on conversations and participate through comments, has grown to nearly 2 million weekly users. With the influx of funding, Clubhouse plans to introduce features such as tipping, tickets, and subscriptions to support creators. The company aims to build a trusted, safe space for users to engage in discussions, contrasting with the typical ad-based business model of social networks.

images.alt_text: Invite-only audio social network Clubhouse is readying to let in the masses with the help of a fresh funding round reported to value it at nearly a billion dollars.

site_title: China, New Zealand agree to expand trade deal: Xinhua
summary: China and New Zealand have signed a protocol to upgrade their bilateral free trade agreement, expanding sectors such as aviation, education, and finance for China, and increasing visa quotas for Chinese language teachers and tour guides in New Zealand. The agreement aims to further boost trade and economic cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: India's green energy goals boosted by return of foreign backers
summary: Foreign investors, including Total SA, BP Plc, and Malaysia's Petroliam Nasional Bhd, are investing in India's renewable energy sector, boosting the country's goal of doubling renewable power by 2022. The investments, worth US$2.5 billion, come as international investors see India's massive market potential outweighing risks. This influx of foreign capital is crucial to meeting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's target of raising renewable energy capacity to 450 gigawatts by 2030, offering investment opportunities of US$20 billion annually.

site_title: Las Vegas plans to reopen schools as suicide fears grow
summary: Las Vegas schools plan to reopen within weeks amid growing concerns over US student mental health and a possible surge in suicides since school closures due to Covid-19. Nevada's Clark County has recorded 19 student suicides since closures, more than double the previous year. The district has set up an alert program to identify at-risk students and introduced 24-hour monitoring. No specific reopening date has been set, but the district is allowed to proceed subject to health regulation compliance. Experts warn that complex factors contribute to suicides, and the pandemic has impacted vulnerable populations, including out-of-school youths.

images.alt_text: Las Vegas schools are planning to reopen within weeks as anger and concerns grow over US student mental health and a possible surge in suicides since they closed due to Covid-19 last March.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 3.7% fall in DPU to 2.261 S cents for Q4
summary: Suntec Reit posted a 3.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.261 Singapore cents for Q4, down from 2.347 cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue fell 12% to S$165.9 million, mainly due to a 65.9% drop in rental income from office and retail properties. The Reit expects a stable office sector recovery in 2021 but a slow retail sector recovery supported by domestic consumption.

site_title: Property auction success rates rise in 2020 despite fewer listings: Knight Frank
summary: Despite a 51.7% decline in mortgagee sale listings, property auction success rates rose 3.6% in 2020, driven by demand for landed homes and industrial properties. Only 495 auction listings were held in 2020, down from 1,387 in 2019. Five landed properties sold at auction, with most located outside traditional prime districts. Industrial properties also contributed to a significant proportion of auctions, with seven sold in Q4. Owner sale listings plummeted 73.8% to 180 in 2020, while Knight Frank expects an increase in mortgagee listings and owner sales in 2021.

site_title: China should stop setting annual GDP targets, central bank adviser says
summary: A central bank adviser in China recommends abandoning annual GDP targets, focusing instead on stabilizing employment and controlling inflation. Ma Jun suggests relaxing foreign exchange measures to alleviate currency pressure and promote the yuan's internationalization. China's economy grew 2.3% in 2020, but is expected to accelerate to 8.4% this year, its fastest rate in a decade. This shift in policy comes as the country faces pressure to slow its growth rate and address economic concerns.

site_title: Disney's Jungle Cruise ride to remove 'negative depictions'
summary: Disney's Jungle Cruise ride is undergoing changes to remove "negative depictions" of some cultures, including non-Western characters portrayed as savages and cannibals. The updated ride will feature new scenes and a new storyline, reflecting the diversity of the world. The changes, announced after a cultural reckoning in the US over systemic racism, are not connected to the upcoming movie. This overhaul follows similar changes to Splash Mountain and classic animated movies, such as "Peter Pan" and "The Aristocrats," which contain outdated or stereotyped depictions of people of color.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares fall most in a week; Australia closed
summary: New Zealand shares fell 0.5% on Tuesday, the largest decline in a week, due to the closure of equity markets in Australia for a public holiday and the suspension of a travel bubble with Australia. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index slipped to 13,328.89. Financials and industrials led the declines, with Westpac Banking Corp and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group losing 1% each. Synlait Milk rose 3% after hiking its milk price forecast. The decline was partly attributed to the confirmation of New Zealand's first case of Covid-19 in the community in months.

site_title: Top executives quit Brazil's Petrobras, Eletrobras as privatisation doubts grow
summary: Brazil's top executives overseeing privatization efforts at state-run oil and electricity companies Petrobras and Eletrobras have quit, raising questions about President Jair Bolsonaro's asset sale program. Wilson Ferreira Jr, CEO of Eletrobras, stepped down due to lack of political support, while Anelise Lara, Petrobras' refining unit chief, announced plans to retire. The departures come amid doubts about the government's commitment to selling off billions of dollars worth of assets at fair prices, following years of political interference and corruption.

site_title: Biden doesn't believe Trump will be convicted at his impeachment trial: CNN
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that he does not believe there will be enough votes to convict former President Donald Trump at his impeachment trial, citing that 17 Republican senators will not vote to convict. This is necessary for a conviction, with all 50 Democrats voting in favor. Biden's comments were based on a brief interview with CNN.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, ARA Logos, Keppel Reit, MLT, Parkway Life Reit
summary:
Stocks to watch: 

- Suntec Reit reported a 3.7% decline in DPU for Q4, while ARA Logos Logistics Trust (ARA Logos) announced an 8.9% increase in DPU. Keppel Reit's DPU rose 4.6% year-over-year, while Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) saw a 1% increase in DPU. Parkway Life Reit posted a 6.7% increase in DPU.

site_title: US 'well on' way to Covid-19 herd immunity by summer: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that the country is on track to achieve Covid-19 herd immunity by summer, with mass vaccinations set to become available in the spring. He aims to administer 100 million vaccinations within his first 100 days in office and expects the country to surpass this goal within the next 100 days. This milestone could mark the beginning of herd immunity, a key goal in controlling the pandemic.

site_title: Klook raises US$200m more to boost merchant SaaS solutions
summary: Klook, a travel booking platform, has raised an additional US$200 million in funding, bringing its total to over US$720 million since its founding in 2014. The funding will be used to accelerate the development and roll-out of its merchant software as a service (SaaS) solutions, which power millions of bookings for over 2,500 merchants worldwide. With the new capital, Klook aims to expand its offerings and grow demand domestically, partnering with tourism boards in Asia to boost domestic tourism. The company's CEO, Ethan Lin, sees the funding as a strategic move to strengthen its position in the market.

images.alt_text: From left: Klook's co-founders Eric Gnock Fah, Ethan Lin and Bernie Xiong.

site_title: Three in 10 firms lack confidence in sustaining business this year: SBF poll
summary: Three in 10 Singapore firms lack confidence in sustaining their business over the next 12 months due to the ongoing pandemic, according to the Singapore Business Federation's annual National Business Survey 2020/21. Despite this, seven in 10 firms are somewhat or very confident of making it through the year. The survey found that the top challenges facing businesses include demand uncertainty, manpower costs, and travel restrictions due to Covid-19. However, firms that underwent high levels of digital transformation reported higher confidence in sustaining their business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 18.30 points, or 1.16%, to 1,594.92. The index saw a higher volume of 888.04 million lots worth RM557.59 million. Gainers outpaced losers 495 to 173.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, January 26, 2021, due to cautious trade ahead of corporate earnings reports. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% to 28,674.33, while the Topix index dropped 0.50% to 1,852.72.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday in cautious trade ahead of corporate earnings reports at home and abroad.

site_title: Crafting Covid-19 recovery plans to recycle more could slash emissions
summary: Researchers say Covid-19 recovery plans that focus on recycling and reusing materials could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 39%, or 22.8 billion gigatonnes annually. The Amsterdam-based social enterprise Circle Economy found that 70% of emissions come from resource extraction and manufacturing, while only 8.6% of materials are reused. Strategies to become "circular" include reusing and recycling products, reducing waste, and adopting low-carbon building materials, transportation, and nutrition practices. Governments are encouraged to adopt these strategies to meet their climate commitments and limit climate change impacts.

site_title: UK supermarkets caught in plastic packaging: study
summary: UK supermarkets continue to use significant amounts of plastic packaging, producing almost 900,000 tonnes in 2019, a 1.6% decrease from 2018. Despite efforts to reduce plastic use, the sector remains stagnant. Many supermarkets are reducing plastic packaging in their own branded products, but third-party companies' packaging remains a major issue. The Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) urges supermarkets to take action against manufacturers and implement reuse and refill systems to achieve a 50% reduction in plastic packaging by 2025.

site_title: ANA says domestic routes to be main earnings source in FY2021
summary: Top Japanese airline ANA Holdings announced that domestic routes will be the main source of income for fiscal year 2021 due to the impact of Covid-19 on travel demand. The airline plans to reorganize its routes and temporarily downsize operations by using smaller aircraft to reduce costs. ANA's interim flight schedule for fiscal 2021 has been announced, marking a shift in strategy amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: US Senate confirms Yellen as first female Treasury secretary
summary: The US Senate confirmed Janet Yellen as the first female Treasury Secretary, playing a key role in crafting President Joe Biden's economic policy amidst the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Yellen, a seasoned economist, previously led the Federal Reserve and the White House Council of Economic Advisers. This historic appointment marks a significant milestone in US politics.

site_title: Current cryptocurrencies unlikely to last: Bank of England governor
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey stated that no existing cryptocurrency has a structure suitable for long-term use as a means of payment. He expressed doubts about the original formulation of cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, which experienced extreme volatility. Bailey's comments suggest that current cryptocurrencies are unlikely to last, highlighting the need for further development in their design, governance, and arrangements.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah backs Chinese lab firm Adicon in US$88m funding round
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional Berhad has backed Chinese diagnostic lab firm Adicon Holdings in a US$88 million funding round. Adicon, which operates 24 diagnostic laboratories in China, plans an initial public offering after the fundraising. Other investors include Carlyle Group, Lake Bleu Capital, Cenova Capital, OrbiMed, and Mirae Asset. This deal marks Carlyle's second investment in Adicon, following a 2018 investment. Adicon's valuation after the round was not disclosed.

site_title: 'This is not normal': Wall Street grows wary of stock bubbles
summary: Wall Street is growing increasingly wary of stock bubbles, with concerns fueled by a surge in retail participation and high share prices for loss-making firms. The S&P 500 has gained over 70% since March, with some stocks experiencing wild price swings, such as GameStop's 250% gain this year. Analysts warn of a potential pullback, citing elevated retail participation and a "buy everything" rally fueled by low interest rates and Covid-19 vaccine rollouts.

images.alt_text: Growing concerns about stock bubbles on Wall Street are sparking fears of a pullback, highlighted by the wild ride for shares such as GameStop Corp.

site_title: Rich and poor vaccine divide worsening, warns WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned that the Covid-19 vaccine divide between rich and poor nations is worsening, with rich countries rolling out vaccines while the world's least-developed countries wait. The WHO needs $26 billion to distribute vaccines and treatments equitably, citing a study that predicts vaccine nationalism could cost the global economy up to $9.2 trillion. Director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized that investing in vaccine equity is "economic common sense" to address the pandemic's impact on developing nations.

site_title: South Korea posts worst growth in two decades
summary: South Korea recorded its worst economic growth in over two decades in 2020, with a 1.0% contraction from the previous year. The country's economy was impacted by weak private spending and exports, but is expected to be one of the best-performing OECD economies due to its swift response to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a 5.1% contraction in 1998, South Korea's economy is expected to grow 3% in 2021, according to the central bank's forecast.

images.alt_text: South Korea recorded its worst growth in more than two decades in 2020, the central bank said Tuesday, but it is expected to be among the best-performing OECD economies in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Moderna says Covid-19 vaccine effective against UK, South Africa variants
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine remains effective against UK and South Africa variants, according to lab studies. However, the vaccine showed a sixfold reduction in neutralizing antibodies against the South African variant. To address this, Moderna is testing a second booster shot and has begun preclinical studies on a booster specifically for the South African variant, B.1.351. The company's CEO, Stephane Bancel, expressed confidence in the vaccine's protective effects, but independent experts have mixed reactions, with some expressing concern about potential impact on vaccine efficacy and duration of protection.

site_title: Facebook News in UK to help 'sustain' local journalism
summary: Facebook has launched its news service in the UK, aiming to help sustain local journalism by paying publishers for their content. The service, called Facebook News, will feature curated news from major UK publishers, including Channel 4 News, The Guardian, and The Telegraph. Facebook will pay publishers for their content and provide additional advertising and subscription opportunities. The move is seen as a response to the financial struggles faced by many UK media companies, which have seen dwindling advertising revenue and print sales. Facebook's director of news partnerships in Europe, Jesper Doub, says the product is a multi-year investment in original journalism.

site_title: Italy PM to quit on Tuesday, seeking new government
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte announced his resignation on Tuesday, aiming to form a new government amidst the country's ongoing battle with the coronavirus pandemic. The move comes after weeks of turmoil, with the ruling coalition on the verge of collapse. Conte's resignation follows a parliamentary vote of confidence last week, where he failed to secure a majority in the Senate, severely weakening his government. A key vote on judicial reforms is set for later this week, which commentators suggest the government was on course to lose.

site_title: WEF focuses on trust in post-pandemic world
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is focusing on rebuilding trust in a post-pandemic world, recognizing the need for greater cohesion and cooperation among institutions and elites to address challenges such as populist surges, economic inequality, and the 'post-truth' phenomenon. Keynote speakers include world leaders, UN officials, and business leaders, who will discuss strategies for rebuilding trust and creating sustainable solutions for a post-pandemic world. The forum aims to leverage the power of business, governments, and civil society to drive growth and address global challenges.

site_title: Makers of social robots plan mass roll-out amid pandemic
summary: Hong Kong-based Hanson Robotics plans to mass-produce social robots, including Sophia, by the end of 2021. The company aims to sell "thousands" of robots, targeting industries such as healthcare, retail, and airlines. The pandemic is expected to accelerate the use of robots, with some experts predicting a closer relationship between humans and robots. Hanson Robotics is launching a new robot, Grace, for the healthcare sector, and other companies, such as SoftBank Robotics, are also deploying robots to combat the pandemic.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 end at records led by tech shares
summary: US stocks ended at records on Monday, led by tech shares. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.7% to close at a record 13,635.99, while the S&P 500 gained 0.4% to end at 3,855.36, also reaching a fresh record. Tech shares, including Apple, Microsoft, and Facebook, drove the gains ahead of earnings releases later in the week. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% to 30,960.00.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on US stimulus hopes, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday as US stimulus hopes and some supply concerns boosted futures. Brent crude futures rose 47 cents to $55.88 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 50 cents to $52.77 a barrel. US President Biden's administration discussed its $1.9 trillion pandemic relief proposal, which is seen as a sign of an economic recovery. Supply concerns, including OPEC's 85% compliance with output curbs, also contributed to the price increase. However, demand worries due to coronavirus lockdowns limited gains.

site_title: ARA Logos posts 8.9% rise in H2 DPU to 2.927 S cents
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust posted an 8.9% rise in half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.927 Singapore cents, driven by a 10.7% increase in net property income to S$46.1 million. The trust's DPU has grown 16.3% on an adjusted basis, driven by new leases and revenue from DHL Supply Chain ARC. DBS analysts maintain a "buy" call with a higher target price of S$0.80, citing high and growing yields and a resilient logistics portfolio.

site_title: Twitter unveils 'community-driven' effort to fight misinformation
summary: Twitter has launched Birdwatch, a community-driven effort to combat misinformation on its platform. Users can flag tweets they believe are false or misleading, providing context through notes. The project, separate from Twitter, aims to broaden voices tackling misinformation and eventually make notes visible on tweets with consensus from diverse contributors. This crowdsourced approach is similar to Wikipedia, with the goal of letting the Twitter community decide when and what context is added to tweets. The initiative comes amid criticism of social networks for failing to stem manipulation and misinformation.

site_title: Pacific island nations turn to AIIB as Covid-19 sinks economies
summary: Pacific island nations, struggling to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, are turning to China-led agencies for funding, raising concerns about economic dependence on Beijing. The Cook Islands and Fiji have secured loans from the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) and China's Exim Bank, while Vanuatu has accepted a Chinese grant. This development unsettles the US and its allies, who have historically dominated the Pacific region, and could potentially lead to exploitation of these economies.

site_title: This season, it's not all smooth skiing
summary: New York ski resorts are operating during the pandemic, with challenges including reduced capacity, reduced workforce, and financial losses. Many resorts have implemented innovations such as UV lights and automation to minimize the risk of transmission. Lift tickets have become a sought-after prize, with some resorts reducing capacity to 3,000 skiers from 7,000. Some visitors are taking advantage of cheaper lift passes during the week and outdoor dining options in the parking lot. Staffing shortages are also a concern, with many resorts relying on seasonal employees who cannot travel due to pandemic restrictions.

site_title: Europe: Weak German business morale, vaccine delays push stocks to two-week low
summary: European stocks fell to a two-week low on Monday, driven by weak German business morale and vaccine delays. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined 0.8%, while the German DAX, France CAC 40, and UK's FTSE 100 also fell. The Ifo economic institute's business climate index dropped to 90.1 in January, and economists forecast a slow economic recovery. The German economy is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels in mid-2022, according to a draft document. Vaccine delays and tighter Covid-19 restrictions also weighed on markets.

site_title: California ends wide lockdown as Covid hospital strain eases
summary: California has lifted its "stay-at-home" orders across the state, allowing for outdoor dining and other activities to resume in worst-hit regions as the pandemic's strain on hospitals eases. The decision comes after a seven-week lockdown for 20 million people in southern and central California, which was driven by a homegrown Covid strain. ICU capacity is expected to improve, with projections showing over 33% capacity available within four weeks. However, pre-existing restrictions based on individual counties will remain in place, including bans on bars and live sport crowds.

site_title: Deutsche Bank conducting internal investigation on sales of investment banking products
summary: Deutsche Bank is conducting an internal investigation into sales of investment banking products after a Financial Times report alleged employees sold clients risky investments they didn't understand. The probe, code-named Project Teal, found the bank wrongly categorized clients and may have knowingly sold unsuited products. The investigation is examining potential breaches of EU rules and collusion with clients to split profits. This is the latest in a string of misconduct by the German lender, which has paid billions in fines and settlements for various wrongdoings. The bank's spokesman declined to comment on details.

site_title: Top hedge funds earned US$63.5b in 2020, highest in decade: LCH data
summary: The world's 20 top-performing hedge funds earned a record US$63.5 billion for clients in 2020, according to LCH Investments data. This represents half of the total US$127 billion earned by all hedge funds last year, driven by a rebound in technology-oriented stocks. The record performance came during a chaotic year caused by the pandemic, marking the highest earnings for hedge funds in the last decade.

site_title: Budgeting to grow the new green economy
summary: Singapore's upcoming 2021 Budget will focus on green economy growth, targeting sectors such as sustainable finance and green-collar jobs. The government aims to decarbonize the domestic economy, supported by private sector investments and innovation. Partnerships with neighboring countries, including Asean nations, will be crucial in mitigating climate change. Singapore can leverage its position as a hub for business and trade to drive regional green growth, with opportunities in technological innovation and finance. The budget will reinforce incentives for research and development, employment support, and sustainable finance products.

site_title: Under pressure US oil refiners seen posting painful Q4 earnings
summary: US oil refiners are expected to post a painful fourth-quarter earnings loss due to rising crude prices, weak demand, and higher costs associated with blending renewable fuels. Seven independent refiners are projected to lose an average of $1.51 per share, down from a loss of $1.06 in the third quarter. Crude oil benchmarks rallied 20% in the quarter, squeezing US refining margins to less than $10 a barrel, and lockdowns in Europe suppressed international flights and jet fuel demand.

site_title: Biolidics gets confirmation to market, sell Covid-19 antigen test kit in the EU
summary: Biolidics, a medtech firm, has received confirmation to market and sell its Covid-19 antigen test kit, ClearEpi SARS-CoV-2 Antigen Rapid Test Kit, in the European Union. The test kit, which detects viral proteins via nasal swabbing, received a CE marking, indicating compliance with EU safety and health requirements. Biolidics expects the launch to contribute positively to revenue for the financial year ending December 31, 2021, with shares trading 7.9% higher following the announcement.

site_title: Sundance enters uncharted waters in unique Oscar season
summary: The Sundance Film Festival, typically held in late January, has entered an uncharted season due to the pandemic. Unlike normal years, the festival now takes place in January 2021, coinciding with the start of Hollywood's award season. This unusual timing allows producers, stars, and journalists to share Oscar tips and catch a glimpse of contenders for the next year's Oscars. The festival's unique timing marks a departure from its typical schedule and creates an exciting opportunity for industry professionals to network and discover new talent.

site_title: Fed set to look beyond possible post-pandemic inflation shock
summary: The US Federal Reserve is preparing for potential inflation spikes as Americans receive stimulus checks, with some estimating up to $2 trillion in extra cash. Fed officials argue that the increases are part of a normal recovery and unlikely to lead to persistent inflation, citing a 2% inflation target. Policymakers will address inflation in their post-meeting news conference, with a focus on sustained improvements in inflation before concluding the economy has met its goal. The Fed's policy remains in rescue mode, with interest rates near zero, and no changes expected for three years.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. Stocks in Europe and the US fell, with banks and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets. Meanwhile, Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: In search of bright spots in 2021
summary: A panel of experts predicts a bright outlook for 2021, driven by a global economic recovery from the pandemic. They expect equities to perform well, particularly in cyclical industries, emerging markets, and the UK. Fixed income investments are also expected to benefit from low interest rates and government stimulus. Experts recommend diversifying portfolios with a mix of growth and income investments, and consider hedging strategies to mitigate risks. The region of Asia is expected to benefit from a strong economic recovery, with China equities poised to outperform.

site_title: Learning when to take a step back
summary: Spark Systems founder Wong Joo Seng, CEO of M-DAQ, made a strategic decision to exit as founding chairman after a successful Series C funding round, which raised the company's value to S$250 million. He retained a significant share in the company and transitioned into a venture partner role at Vickers Venture Partners, citing the need to adapt to a company's growth and avoid becoming obsolete. Wong emphasizes the importance of discerning when to call it quits, highlighting that even with a solid business model, entrepreneurs must be willing to pivot and learn from failures.

site_title: Robo-advisers diverge on regulatory risk in China tech exposure
summary: Robo-advisers are adjusting their tech exposure amid China's antitrust clampdown on big tech companies and lofty US stock valuations. StashAway shifted allocation from US tech stocks to Chinese innovations, while OCBC divested from Alibaba due to regulatory risks. DBS and UOBAM Invest also rebalanced their portfolios, with DBS focusing on long-term structural trends and UOBAM Invest allocating to global or Asia ex-Japan equities. Syfe trimmed its tech exposure, opting for global market cap-weighted ETFs. Despite regulatory pressures, most firms are bullish on Asian equities, with a focus on recovery in the region.

images.alt_text: Last December, the Chinese government launched an antitrust probe against e-commerce giant Alibaba for allegations of monopolistic practices, and ordered its parent company, Ant Group, to scale back operations.

site_title: Asian ambitions
summary: Amundi, a Paris-based fund management group, aims to expand assets under management in the Asia-Pacific by 60% to 500 billion euros by 2025, with a focus on organic growth, partnerships, and joint ventures. The group has partnerships in South Korea and India and recently launched a joint venture with BOC Wealth Management in China. Amundi's CEO, Eric Bramoullé, believes sustainability is crucial in the region, with the group aiming to deepen its commitment to ESG investments, covering over 10,000 securities by 2025.

site_title: Mobilising communities to action
summary: Rebekah Lin, founder of the Jia Foundation, aims to mobilize communities to support causes with limited funding. The foundation, run by Lin and her family, focuses on elderly and mental health issues, often overlooked but needing attention. Jia Foundation prefers to catalyze community action rather than making grants, and utilizes arts, music, and film to generate awareness and spark action. Lin's personal experiences, including a family background of privilege and a close relationship with her elderly grandfather, drive her motivation to support these causes.

site_title: Workspace Property Trust exploring raising fresh capital
summary: Workspace Property Trust, a US office and industrial landlord, is exploring raising fresh capital through the sale of preferred equity. The company, led by Tom Rizk and Roger Thomas, aims to bolster its balance sheet for future growth, including acquisitions. With 90% occupancy and 98% rental collection, Workspace has a strong financial foundation. The new capital will be used to return capital to existing investors and strengthen its balance sheet. The move comes as the US office sector faces uncertainty, with a 17.1% vacancy rate. Workspace previously filed to go public in 2017 but withdrew its paperwork.

site_title: European banks set to trail Wall Street as provisions swell
summary: European banks are likely to underperform US peers in Q4 due to setting aside more money for doubtful credit, with estimated provisions totaling US$15 billion. This marks the highest since 2012, with total provisions for the year reaching US$61.5 billion. Weakened by negative interest rates, European lenders had initially taken a more optimistic view of the pandemic, but a shift to stocks in the final months of the year may hurt companies like Deutsche Bank. Analysts expect European banks to post smaller gains or declines in stock trading while delivering better performance in fixed income.

site_title: US dollar index resumes decline amid rising hopes
summary: The US dollar index declined 0.2% to 90.094, resuming its downward trend, as global market sentiment turned more optimistic over US President Joe Biden's stimulus plans. Analysts expect a broad dollar decline in 2021, citing a large speculative short position and the Fed's plan to taper stimulus. The euro was flat against the dollar, despite a 9% surge last year, and traders remain bullish on the euro, expecting a high bar for a rate cut. The US Federal Reserve meets on Wednesday, with Chair Jerome Powell expected to signal no plans to wind back stimulus.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend last week's decline, STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.6% on Monday, extending last week's decline, finishing at 2,973.65. The decline was largely driven by CapitaLand's 3.8% drop after the property giant reported a full-year loss due to revaluations and impairments. Wilmar International rose 1.8% to S$5.53, while The Place Holdings surged 25.5%. China overtook the US as the largest recipient of foreign direct investment in 2020, lifting markets in North Asia.

site_title: Idle supertankers about to be junked on Asian beaches
summary: A surge in supertanker scrapping is expected in Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to disrupt the global oil market, leading to a significant surplus of vessels. With scrap values soaring, many older tankers are being sold for demolition, with Clarkson Research Services forecasting a 2% demolition rate in 2021. The industry's earnings are also suffering, with daily earnings for supertankers on the Middle East to China route reaching negative rates. Owners are bracing for a challenging market, with some reporting that ships are being offered to pick up cargoes at a loss.

site_title: Don't be too fast to dismiss Singapore tech manufacturing stocks
summary: Singapore's tech manufacturing stocks are expected to continue growing despite recent rotation into cyclical counters. Analysts point to sustained demand for digitalization, increased semiconductor equipment spending, and the rollout of 5G as key drivers. Companies such as AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings, and Micro-Mechanics are expected to benefit from these trends, with some analysts predicting further mergers and acquisitions in the sector. The sector's growth is also expected to be driven by the recovery in semiconductor sales and the increasing need for data storage and analytics.

site_title: Cathay Pacific warns of capacity cuts, higher cash burn
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways warns of a 60% reduction in passenger capacity and a potential increase in monthly cash burn by HK$300-400 million if Hong Kong implements a two-week quarantine measure for flight crew. The airline expects to reduce its cargo capacity by 2% due to the curbs. Cathay has requested volunteers among its crew for temporary duty, and the airline will continue to engage with the Hong Kong government on the matter.

site_title: Contactless payments the new normal post-Covid, says Adyen
summary: Global payments company Adyen predicts contactless payments will be the new normal post-Covid, driven by consumers' increasing preference for technological retail experiences. 58% of Asia-Pacific respondents and 72% of Singaporeans prefer contactless payment methods. The use of e-wallet payments has risen, and businesses can leverage subscription models to collect customer data and cultivate brand loyalty. Adyen also recommends a unified commerce approach, integrating technology in stores to blur the distinction between offline and online stores.

site_title: Pandemic preparedness vital to building back better process
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for improved pandemic preparedness and response. Despite warnings from health experts and institutions, governments weakened their countries' ability to respond to outbreaks through budget cuts. The pandemic has demonstrated the importance of reducing disease spread through measures such as lockdowns and quarantines. An international inquiry into the global response to COVID-19 is recommended to ensure collective learning and cooperation. Implementing protocols for effective response to future pandemics, including protecting vital workers and auxiliary staff, is crucial for minimizing the impact of future outbreaks.

site_title: Embracing technological innovations to stay ahead
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a Singapore-based company, has won the prestigious Enterprise 50 (E50) award for 10 consecutive years. The company, which has been creating high-performance building facades since 1978, attributes its success to its pursuit of excellence, leadership development, and adoption of new technologies. Seiko Wall has expanded globally, taking on large-scale projects in cities such as Vancouver and Seattle, and is now investing in research and development to stay competitive. The company's managing director, Rodney Cheong, emphasizes the importance of good leadership, talent management, and embracing new technologies to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: Global life insurers impose curbs as worries rise over long-term pandemic risks
summary: Global life insurers are imposing curbs on payouts due to long-term pandemic risks, including waiting periods and limited coverage for certain age groups. Reinsurers are demanding new safeguards from life insurers, citing the uncertainty of long-term consequences of Covid-19. Insurers are also concerned about the mental-health crisis and substance-abuse issues caused by the pandemic. Despite minimal claims so far, insurers are taking precautionary steps to mitigate potential long-term financial impacts.

site_title: Much to gain from rebalance of power between labour and capital
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is pushing for a rebalance of power between labor and capital, aiming to increase the national minimum wage, raise taxes on corporations, and promote unionization. Despite challenges, including stagnant pay and growing inequality, several factors could favor a shift in the labor-capital divide. These include the creation of more jobs in the "caring economy" due to an aging population, increased unionization in high-growth industries, and the potential for individuals to recapture the value of their personal data through "data unions".

site_title: New year, new optimism
summary: Market optimism has risen following global vaccine rollouts and positive economic growth in China in 2020. Investors are expected to favor equities due to a global economic rebound, monetary policy support, and low bond yields. Popular themes for 2021 include exposures to China and Asian equities, an ESG wave in bond issuance, and weakness in the US dollar. Investors are advised to be diversified and focus on quality assets, as timing the market can be challenging, according to Credit Suisse's John Woods.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing value targeted to grow 50% over 10 years
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector aims to grow 50% in value by 2030, with a focus on increasing local talent and investing in research and development. The goal, set by Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing, seeks to maintain the sector's economic contributions at one-fifth of the gross domestic product. The sector is expected to shift from labor-intensive to capital-intensive segments, with a target of employing 10-15% of the workforce. Efforts to develop the talent pipeline and attract frontier investments are also part of the Manufacturing 2030 vision.

site_title: Bitcoin's return to US$40,000 in doubt as flows to key fund slow
summary: Bitcoin's return to the $40,000 level is uncertain due to faltering demand for the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust, a $20 billion fund tracking the digital asset. The fund's four-week rolling averages appear to have peaked, with a 22% drop over the past two weeks, outpacing Bitcoin's 17% decline. JPMorgan strategists believe institutional flow into the fund is not strong enough to support a break above $40,000, citing a risk of momentum traders unwinding Bitcoin futures positions.

site_title: Trends that will outlast the pandemic
summary: UBP, a wealth management firm, reported a 5% increase in total assets under management to 147.4 billion Swiss francs in 2020, driven by net new money from private clients. The firm's head of South Asia and Singapore, Ranjit Khanna, is optimistic about the future, citing the growing affluence in the region and the trend towards digitization. Key areas of focus include active risk management, transformation-led strategies, and China's economic growth. UBP is also strengthening its foreign exchange and private market offerings, including flow products and discretionary portfolios.

site_title: Office market in San Francisco set to see biggest drop in US
summary: San Francisco's office market is expected to see the largest drop in the US, with a 22% decline in rent and occupancy in 2021, according to a Green Street report. This is attributed to technology companies embracing remote work. New York will follow with a 17% drop. Analysts predict a permanent resetting of rents, with tenants reevaluating space needs and looking for cheaper states to expand. The US office market is expected to fall by 15% through 2025 due to growing work-from-home trends.

site_title: Fosun Pharma-BioNTech vaccine gets HK official nod
summary: Hong Kong has approved the use of the Fosun Pharma-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine, with the first batch of around 1 million doses expected to arrive in the second half of February. This approval comes after Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam secured 22.5 million doses of the vaccine from various manufacturers. The move aims to address the city's lag in vaccine rollout, with Hong Kong having recorded nearly 10,000 COVID-19 cases and 166 deaths since January 2020. China's state media has also criticized Western vaccines while promoting its own vaccines as safer and more accessible.

images.alt_text: A woman pushing a cart past civil servants in protective gear in the Jordan district in Hong Kong on Monday. The government lifted the lockdown restrictions on several blocks in districts where old and dilapidated buildings had been at the centre of a Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: China's Xi uses Davos speech to warn world against new Cold War
summary: China's President Xi Jinping used his Davos speech to warn the world against a new Cold War, urging mutual respect and cooperation to recover from the pandemic. He called for a return to international law and rules, rejecting a "supremacy" mentality and criticizing those who would impose decoupling, supply disruptions, or sanctions. Xi signaled China's determination to forge its own path, despite Western criticism, and repeated calls for multilateralism and "win-win" outcomes. The speech sets the tone for relations among the world's biggest economies over the next four years.

site_title: Themes expected to play out in 2021
summary: Investors expect 2021 to see a shift towards equities, driven by low interest rates and signs of global economic growth. The ESG (environmental, social and governance) wave is also expected to continue, with green and social bond issuance on the rise. Key sectors to watch include e-commerce, 5G telecoms, and sustainable investments. Fixed income investors anticipate a rotation into equities due to low yields and expect Asian fixed income to become a more prominent part of global portfolios.

site_title: Tencent's US$251b jump in value triggers frenzy in shares, options
summary: Tencent Holdings' US$251 billion valuation surge has triggered a frenzy in Hong Kong shares, with traders buying thousands of January call options and selling bearish puts. The stock rallied 11% on Monday to HK$766.50, its largest gain since 2011, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 2.4%. Tencent's market value has increased by about US$251 billion this year, making it the largest gainer worldwide, according to Bloomberg. The company's shares now trade at nearly 40 times analysts' estimated earnings, with some analysts predicting a target price of HK$876.

site_title: ByteDance rival Kuaishou seeks US$5.4b in biggest tech IPO since Uber
summary: Kuaishou, a Chinese short video startup backed by Tencent Holdings, is seeking a $5.4 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, the largest tech IPO since Uber's $8.1 billion IPO in 2019. The company, which operates China's second-largest video service after Douyin (TikTok), aims to raise 365 million shares at HK$105 to HK$115 each. Kuaishou's valuation could more than double to $60.9 billion, surpassing its $28.6 billion valuation in a funding round last year.

site_title: To revive New York's economy, Wall Street firms offer help with vaccinations
summary: Wall Street firms are offering to help distribute COVID-19 vaccines in New York to revive the city's economy, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. Financial industry leaders, including Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon and JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, have expressed concerns about the city's ability to recover without broader access to vaccines. They are offering logistical and distribution expertise, as well as real estate resources, to help address the city's dwindling vaccine supply and improve the rollout. The efforts aim to get more people vaccinated and confident to return to the city, with some firms predicting it may take until September for workers to feel safe returning to offices.

site_title: Indonesia seizes tankers over alleged illegal oil transfer
summary: Indonesia's coast guard seized two tankers, MT Horse and MT Freya, over suspected illegal oil transfer in its waters. The tankers, flying Iranian and Panamanian flags, concealed their identities and turned off automatic identification systems. 61 crew members were detained. The vessels were found transferring oil, resulting in an oil spill, and were escorted to Batam island for further investigation.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian Coast Guard said the vessels concealed their identities by not showing their national flags, turning off their transponders and failing to respond to a radio call.

site_title: Will US political backdrop be supportive of risk assets in 2021?
summary: US President Joe Biden's Democratic Party, with a slim majority in Congress, is expected to provide a supportive backdrop for risk assets in 2021. A large Covid-19 relief package and President Biden's plan to accelerate vaccine distribution could boost consumer spending and aggregate demand. This, combined with the potential for new economic expansion, could encourage the beginnings of a new economic expansion, historically great for risk assets such as small-cap and value equities.

site_title: Renewables the dominant EU power source for 1st time
summary: For the first time, renewables have become the dominant power source in the European Union's electric grid, accounting for 38% of electricity production in 2020, surpassing fossil fuels. This milestone comes despite the COVID-19 pandemic, which reduced energy demand. The EU aims to double renewable energy production by 2030 to meet its 55% emissions reduction target. Wind and solar generation increased 10% in 2020, while coal production fell 20%. The shift away from coal has reduced the EU's carbon intensity by 29% in the last five years.

site_title: Shanghai tightens rules to further cool property market
summary: Shanghai has tightened its rules to cool the property market, expanding purchase restrictions and limiting loans for transactions. The city now includes homes from court auctions in purchase restrictions, aiming to curb buying by individuals seeking to bypass ownership limits. Industrial and Commercial Bank of China has also suspended loans used in property transactions, slowing down the pace of housing deals and controlling market sentiment. These measures follow a recent surge in property sales, with sales by volume hitting a nearly four-year high.

site_title: Blackstone adds warehouses, boosting industrial bet
summary: Blackstone Group Inc is acquiring a majority stake in 71 warehouses valued at $1.6 billion, boosting its industrial property bet. The non-traded real estate investment trust, BREIT, will take a 60% stake in the warehouses, primarily located in California and Seattle, which are in "last mile" locations close to consumers. This acquisition comes as investors increasingly target industrial properties, driven by the rise of online shopping during the pandemic, resulting in higher prices and a 6.1% return for BREIT last year.

site_title: In Los Angeles, virus ravages overcrowded homes
summary: A virus is spreading rapidly in overcrowded neighborhoods in Los Angeles, highlighting the city's economic inequality and housing affordability issues. The virus has disproportionately affected immigrant households, with many living in crowded homes and lacking access to healthcare. The city's hospitals are overwhelmed, and the death toll is rising. The Los Angeles County Public Health Director recommends that people in overcrowded homes wear masks indoors, especially those with vulnerable family members. The virus has underscored the crisis in economic inequality and housing affordability, with wealthy neighborhoods experiencing fewer cases and deaths.

site_title: Isetan could pay dearly for dragging its heels on sale of Wisma Atria space
summary: Isetan Singapore, a Japanese department store chain, has announced plans to sell its investment property at Wisma Atria, a prime asset in Singapore's busiest shopping belt. The move comes after the company's financial struggles due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenue and earnings declining over the past five years. Isetan's shares surged 35% on the news, driven by hopes of a sale that could unlock the asset's value. The sale could provide a much-needed boost to the company, which faces other challenges including finding a replacement tenant for a vacant floor and navigating uncertain market conditions.
