site_title: HSBC's CEO faces UK questions over freezing of HK accounts
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn is set to face UK Parliament questions over the lender's account freezes of Hong Kong activists. Exiled lawmaker Ted Hui, whose account was frozen, has provided the committee with detailed information on the cases. The bank's move comes amid China's tightening control over Hong Kong, following criticism over its endorsement of a security law. HSBC has declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: DBS offers SME customers quicker audit confirmation via digital platform
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has launched DBS Audit Confirmation, the banking industry's first digital audit confirmation solution. The platform allows corporate and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) customers to verify their financial positions digitally, reducing processing time for audit confirmation requests to under 24 hours. This digital solution is expected to save 30,000 clients time and expedite the closure of their annual financial statements, with customers able to track the status of their requests in real-time.

site_title: China's Xi uses Davos speech to warn against new cold war
summary: China's President Xi Jinping used his Davos speech to warn against a new Cold War, urging the world to abandon ideological prejudice and shun an outdated mentality. He called for mutual respect and commitment to international law to aid in pandemic recovery, warning that confrontation would lead to division and confrontation. Xi signaled China will continue to forge its own path, rejecting US pressure, and put aside political issues to improve ties with Western countries. The speech marked a more defensive tone than his 2017 address, setting the tone for relations between China and the world's biggest economies over the next four years.

site_title: Boohoo, Asos seek to rescue failed UK clothing chains
summary: Online fashion retailers Boohoo Group and Asos are seeking to rescue ailing UK retail brands Debenhams and Topshop. Boohoo is buying the Debenhams brand for £55 million, while Asos is in exclusive talks with administrators to buy Topshop and other labels. The deals aim to rescue thousands of jobs and expand the retailers' online offerings beyond their main customer base. The moves come after Debenhams entered administration and Asos' rival Frasers Group failed to secure a deal.

site_title: Biden hits ground running, but will a new day dawn in America?
summary: US President Joe Biden has outlined his goals for his first 100 days in office, focusing on unity, democratic principles, and controlling the COVID-19 pandemic. He aims to marshal federal resources to support states in a national vaccination program, which could aid economic recovery efforts. With the pandemic expected to pass 500,000 US deaths and millions out of work, Biden must demonstrate leadership and competence to address the nation's challenges, including a tarnished global image under his predecessor. His success will depend on his ability to deliver on these goals amidst significant economic and health crises.

site_title: The Marksman captures top spot at US box office
summary: Liam Neeson's thriller "The Marksman" holds onto first place at the US box office for the second weekend in a row, grossing over $2 million. The film has grossed $61 million after 10 days of release. Despite this, the box office distinction is not as significant as it was pre-pandemic due to ongoing closures of major markets. The performance suggests a slow recovery for the economy.

site_title: US: Nasdaq rises again ahead of tech earnings, Dow drops
summary: The Nasdaq jumped 1.2% ahead of tech earnings, while the Dow fell 0.6% due to uncertainty over the US stimulus package and mixed Covid-19 vaccine news. The S&P 500 added 0.2% as tech giants Apple and Microsoft prepare to report earnings. Markets are watching the developments in Washington, where centrist lawmakers have responded skeptically to President Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion economic relief package.

site_title: ECB can price climate risk better than the market, Panetta says
summary: ECB board member Fabio Panetta suggests the European Central Bank can better price climate risk than the market and should conduct its own environmental analysis for monetary policy. Panetta aims to protect the ECB's balance sheet from climate-related financial risks not accurately priced by markets. By analyzing climate risks using rigorous methodologies, the ECB can contribute to accurate valuation of these risks, ultimately influencing its economic analysis and policy implementation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings, a Malaysian property developer, will transfer its listing from the Catalist board to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Jan 28. The move aims to boost visibility and facilitate future fundraising efforts. Meanwhile, The Place Holdings is engaged in discussions on potential investment opportunities and projects, while Anchor Resources won a court case against a contractor's progress claim dispute. The court decisions cleared GGTM of liabilities and pending suits.

site_title: Enhancing Singapore's ecosystem for FX
summary: Entrepreneur Wong Joo Seng's latest venture, Spark Systems, aims to reduce costs and time for FX trading in Singapore, enhancing the country's ecosystem for foreign exchange. Wong, a veteran trader, identified the need for a faster and more cost-effective platform, and with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's grants, Spark Systems successfully lured major institutions such as UBS, Citi, and Goldman Sachs to establish data centers in Singapore. The platform reduces FX platform costs from $6-8 to $2 per $1 million worth of trades, making Singapore a major FX matching center.

site_title: Countries must deal with setbacks, protect weakest as they recover from Covid-19, says Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for governments to prepare for a range of possibilities as the world recovers from Covid-19. Until widespread vaccine distribution and herd immunity are achieved, global economic recovery will be uncertain. Governments must be ready to deal with setbacks and ensure policies protect the weakest citizens. Tharman noted the uncertainty surrounding vaccine distribution in the developing world and the impact on global growth, citing the need for preparedness and flexibility in economic recovery efforts.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q4 DPU up 6.7% to 3.57 Singapore cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 6.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.57 Singapore cents for Q4 2020, driven by revenue growth from property acquisitions in Japan and higher rent from Singapore properties. Gross revenue rose 9% to S$30.6 million, while property expenses increased 200%. The Reit's portfolio valuation gained S$7.4 million, and distributable income to unitholders rose 6.7% to S$21.6 million. The company's CEO attributed the growth to the resilient healthcare industry in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Foley-backed SPAC agrees to US$7.3b deal with Blackstone's Alight
summary: Foley-backed SPAC Foley Trasimene Acquisition Corp has agreed to a $7.3 billion deal to take Alight Solutions, a US benefits services provider owned by Blackstone Group, public. Alight will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "ALIT". The deal includes a $1.55 billion private investment in public equity (PIPE). Alight offers cloud-based benefits administration and human resources services to 70% of Fortune 100 companies in 188 countries. The deal aims to help the company expand its services to more clients and boost its business outside the US.

site_title: Dr Martens owners to raise US$1.78b in London IPO
summary: The owners of Dr. Martens are planning to raise approximately US$1.78 billion in a London initial public offering (IPO), with shares priced between 330 and 370 pence ($6.70) per share. The company, valued at around £3.3-£3.7 billion, will sell 350 million existing shares. This is part of a growing trend of European IPOs, following a quiet 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: CNMC to stop all production activities, operations in Malaysia during extended lockdown
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings in Malaysia will halt all production activities and operations until Feb 4 due to the second round of movement control order (MCO) restrictions. The company's ore material transfer, quarrying, and mineral mining activities will remain shut until the end of MCO 2.0 or approval from Malaysia's National Security Council. This move affects the company's earnings per share and net asset value per share for the financial year ending December 2021, with the board of directors monitoring the evolving situation.

site_title: Sabah keeps palm oil estates open, orders mass Covid -19 testing
summary: Sabah, Malaysia's largest palm oil-producing state, has decided not to impose a shutdown on plantations despite rising coronavirus infections. The state government ordered widespread testing on all workers within 30 days, and those with positive cases will be closed immediately. Plantations were also encouraged to voluntarily impose a 30-day restriction on movement to prevent a work stoppage. Sabah accounts for nearly 25% of global crude palm oil production, and the state aims to encourage compliance with Covid-19 prevention measures.

site_title: Anchor Resources in the clear after KL court decides in favour of its JV
summary: Anchor Resources' joint venture company GGTMECOJV has had a contractor's progress claim dispute against it successfully set aside by the Kuala Lumpur High Court, with the court dismissing an application to enforce the decision. As a result, there are no pending suits against GGTMECOJV and no liabilities against it. The company's shares ended trading at 1.5 Singapore cents, up 0.4 Singapore cents.

site_title: PBOC will balance stabilising growth and curbing risks
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, aims to balance economic growth and risk control, Governor Yi Gang said. The country's economy grew 2.3% last year, despite the coronavirus slump, and authorities want to curb debt levels. The debt-to-output ratio rose to 280% and is expected to stabilize in 2021. The PBOC will maintain monetary policy stability and support areas with fragile recoveries, with no plans for sharp policy changes. The central bank also prioritizes green finance development and aims to reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: Tory MPs back parents in call to reopen UK schools
summary: A dozen UK Conservative MPs have called for schools to reopen sooner, citing concerns about pupils becoming the "forgotten victims" of the pandemic. The MPs, including Esther McVey and Graham Brady, have backed a parents' pressure group campaign, urging Education Secretary Gavin Williamson to provide clarity on reopening plans. Despite a failed bid to force a government statement in Parliament, Williamson is expected to address the issue later this week. Schools in England are currently closed to all but key workers, with no guarantee of reopening by Easter.

site_title: Google workers to form global union alliance
summary: Google employees worldwide are forming a global union alliance called Alpha Global, in collaboration with the UNI Global Union, representing 20 million workers globally. This follows the formation of Alphabet Workers Union in the US and Canada. Alpha Global will fight for the rights of full-time Alphabet employees, as well as temporary and contract workers. The union aims to address global issues affecting Alphabet, citing problems with working conditions and business practices. The move comes after years of protests and comes as Alphabet has yet to respond to a request for comment.

site_title: US 'proud to be back' in climate fight, Kerry tells leaders
summary: US special climate envoy John Kerry stated that the US is "proud to be back" in international efforts to tackle global warming, following the country's re-entry into the 2015 Paris climate agreement. Kerry emphasized President Joe Biden's commitment to fighting climate change and pledged to make up for the US' previous global climate finance commitments by investing in climate action domestically and abroad. The US aims to invest $3 billion in the global Green Climate Fund to help vulnerable countries combat climate change.

site_title: Fitch revises Deutsche Bank rating outlook to positive from negative
summary: Fitch has revised its outlook for Deutsche Bank to positive from negative, citing progress in its multi-billion euro restructuring process. The German lender's credit rating remains BBB, two notches above junk. Fitch predicts the ratings could be upgraded within 18 months, but the bank still faces a challenging path to cost cuts and revenue growth. This move contrasts with Moody's, which lifted its negative outlook in November, and Standard & Poor's, which maintains a negative outlook.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 20.12 points to 1,576.62. The decline was driven by a larger number of losers (1,119) compared to gainers (231). Volume reached 7.485 billion lots worth RM5.166 billion.

site_title: Gallant Venture proposes to acquire 66.25% stake in Singapore-Bintan Resort Holdings for S$4.94m
summary: Gallant Venture proposes to acquire 66.25% stake in Singapore-Bintan Resort Holdings (SBRH) for S$4.94 million from shareholders including Keppel Land and OCBC. The acquisition will give Gallant Venture full control over PT BRC, a master planner and manager for Bintan Resort in Indonesia. SBRH has been loss-making since inception, with a deficit of S$10.9 million as of 2019. The proposed acquisition is expected to have no material impact on Gallant Venture's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific warns of capacity cuts, higher cash burn
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has warned of a 60% cut in passenger capacity and a rise in monthly cash burn due to potential quarantine measures in Hong Kong. The airline expects a HK$300-400 million increase in cash burn per month, on top of their current HK$1-1.5 billion levels. The airline's cash burn would be significantly higher if the new measures are implemented, posing a financial challenge to the airline.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd on Monday warned of a cut in its passenger capacity by about 60 per cent and a rise in monthly cash burn if the Asian financial hub puts into effect new measures requiring flight crew to quarantine for two weeks.

site_title: Shopee scales up Brazil operations, eyes Latam potential: sources
summary: Shopee, an e-commerce arm of Sea Ltd, is expanding its operations in Brazil, a pilot initiative launched in late 2019, with the company now growing its presence and hiring executives. Shopee Brazil has seen significant growth, with its app having more monthly active users than Amazon's unit in the country, according to analytics firm App Annie. The company is assessing the potential of other Latin American markets, with Mexico being a notable interest, amid a projected 36.7% rise in e-commerce sales in Latin America this year to US$84.9 billion.

images.alt_text: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of South-east Asia's Sea Ltd, is scaling up its operations in Brazil and evaluating the long-term potential of Latin American markets, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Giuliani faces Dominion lawsuit for 'big lie' election fraud claims
summary: Rudy Giuliani, former President Donald Trump's lawyer, is being sued by Dominion Voting Systems for defamation over his claims of widespread election fraud. The company is seeking $1.3 billion in damages, alleging Giuliani's "big lie" campaign deceived millions. This comes after Giuliani's allies stormed the US Capitol on January 6, following two months of denying Trump's election defeat. Giuliani's lawyer has not commented on the lawsuit, which also accuses his former client, Trump, of spreading false conspiracy theories.

images.alt_text: A US voting machine company sued former President Donald Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani, accusing him of defamation in what it called his "big lie" campaign about widespread fraud in the presidential election.

site_title: SGX queries Hosen as shares rise 55.7% to 52-week high
summary: Hosen Group, a packaged-food distributor listed on the Catalist, saw its shares surge 55.7% to a 52-week high on Monday, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about "unusual price movements". The company responded, stating it was not aware of any new information that could explain the trading activity. This is the second SGX query issued to Hosen in five months, following a similar query in September 2020.

site_title: China's steel champion nods to Xi with 2050 carbon-zero vow
summary: China Baowu Steel Group, the world's top steel producer, has pledged to go carbon neutral by 2050, aligning with President Xi Jinping's push to shift the economy away from fossil fuels. The company expects emissions to peak by 2023 and reduce its carbon footprint to zero by 2035, aiming to achieve a 30% reduction by 2025. This vow echoes a global trend of companies moving towards low-carbon production, with steelmakers exploring hydrogen alternatives to coal in the steelmaking process.

site_title: Hong Kong formally approves Fosun Pharma-BioNTech vaccine
summary: Hong Kong has formally approved the use of the Fosun Pharma-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, becoming the first Asian financial hub to do so. The first batch of around one million doses is expected to arrive in February. This move comes after mainland China started its vaccine program in July last year, and Hong Kong has been lagging in vaccine distribution.

images.alt_text: The first batch of around one million doses is expected to arrive in the second half of February.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core consumer prices fell further in December, but headline inflation remained flat at -0.1%. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing set a target of 50% growth in manufacturing value over the next decade. The COVID-19 pandemic has increased the need for stronger social safety nets, according to Education Minister Lawrence Wong. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) rolled out a suite of ESG derivatives and DBS launched a digital audit confirmation solution. Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.6% on Monday, extending last week's decline.

site_title: Keppel Reit H2 DPU rises 4.6% to 2.93 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 4.6% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.93 Singapore cents, up from 2.80 cents in the same period last year. Full-year DPU rose 2.7% to 5.73 cents. The Reit's distributable income for FY 2020 increased 2.8% to S$194.6 million, driven by contributions from T Tower and Victoria Police Centre. However, the absence of income from Bugis Junction Towers and the impact of Covid-19 measures partially offset the growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.3% to 6,713.14 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 advancing 0.5% to 13,943.98 points, and Paris's CAC 40 adding 0.3% to 5,575.33 points. The gains followed positive trends across Asia.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's DPU up 1% in Q3
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 1% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.065 Singapore cents in Q3 2020, driven by higher revenue from existing properties and accretive acquisitions. Gross revenue rose 15.5% to S$139.9 million, while net property income increased 14.9% to S$124.7 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy remained at 97.1% and its weighted average lease expiry was about 3.7 years. Despite increased debt, MLT's aggregate leverage declined to 36.8% and its debt duration was 3.8 years.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip on Monday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.6% to 2,973.65 on Monday, extending last week's decline. CapitaLand was the worst performer, falling 3.8% after reporting a full-year loss due to revaluations and impairments. Wilmar International rose 1.8% to S$5.53, while FJ Benjamin Holdings gained 25% to two Singapore cents after receiving in-principle approval to transfer to the Catalist board.

site_title: Shopee ramps up initiatives to adapt platform to changing consumer base
summary: Shopee, a South-east Asian e-commerce player, is adapting its platform to engage a diverse customer base, driven by a surge in digitalisation during the pandemic. The company has created a platform for high-end brands, expanded its grocery delivery service, and plans to increase logistics network coverage. To cater to a broader customer base, Shopee is also building up its fulfilment capability and expanding its in-house last-mile delivery service to reach more cities. The company has seen significant growth, with e-commerce revenue up 173.3% to US$618.7 million and gross merchandise value increasing 102.7% to US$9.3 billion in the third quarter of 2020.

site_title: Covid-19 has increased impetus for stronger social safety nets: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a "permanent shift" towards stronger social safety nets in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The government aims to provide more assurance and support for Singaporeans, particularly the lower-income group, and address issues such as meritocracy and income inequality. Wong also highlighted the importance of a greener Singapore, with plans to phase out internal combustion engines and invest in sustainable energy. Additionally, he noted that the pandemic has brought a renewed sense of social solidarity, and the government is creating opportunities for involvement in decision-making to foster this sense of unity.

site_title: Electric vehicles to dominate in India by 2030, Mahindra says
summary: India's electric vehicle market is expected to overtake gas guzzlers by 2030, according to Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. The company's Deputy Managing Director Anish Shah attributes this shift to improved infrastructure and technology, with the government playing a significant role in developing charging networks. Mahindra is currently focusing on larger SUVs and pickup trucks, which are proving popular, and sees opportunities for growth in the farm implements business. The company reported its first quarterly loss in nearly two decades due to economic slowdown in India, but rural areas remain a growth area.

site_title: Grab picks Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan for US IPO: sources
summary: Grab Holdings, a South-east Asian ride-hailing giant, has selected Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co to work on a potential US initial public offering (IPO) that could raise at least $2 billion. The IPO comes after talks to combine with Indonesian rival Gojek stalled, and could create a regional powerhouse with a valuation of $18 billion. Grab's IPO consideration may threaten its expansion plans in Indonesia, where it has seen 70% net revenue growth in 2020. The listing could happen as soon as the second half of this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by investor focus on Japan's corporate earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67%, while the broader Topix index advanced 0.29%. The moves come after a mixed close on Wall Street last week, with investors shifting their attention to Japan's earnings season.

site_title: Philips Q4 core profit rises as robust pandemic-led demand continues
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips reported a 7% increase in fourth-quarter core earnings, reaching 1.14 billion euros, driven by robust demand for hospital equipment to treat Covid-19 patients. Comparable sales rose 7% to 6 billion euros, with a 24% jump in sales of its Connected Care division. Philips confirmed its outlook for low-single-digit comparable sales growth in 2021, citing a strong order book, but expects demand for Covid-19 equipment to cool down.

site_title: Samsung's Jay Y Lee will not appeal jail term to Supreme Court: Yonhap
summary: Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y. Lee will not appeal his 2.5-year jail term to the Supreme Court after receiving the sentence on charges including bribery, according to his lawyer. The decision was made following the receipt of the sentence, and neither Lee's lawyer nor Samsung made an immediate comment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week on strong note
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 2% on Monday, rebounding from a two-day sell-off, following news that leaders lifted a lockdown in a part of the city. The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.41% to 30,159.01, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.48% to 3,624.24. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.27% to 2,462.85, indicating a strong start to the week for Hong Kong's stock market.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: Opportunities and risks for stock investors in 2021 (Ep 3)
summary: Ben Paul, a senior correspondent at The Business Times, discusses market trends and corporate issues in Singapore's podcast series, "Mark To Market." In 2021, tech-oriented growth stocks led the recovery, driven by synchronous global growth. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) outpaced the S&P 500 due to this trend. Paul also highlights the need to tolerate inflation and cautions against structurally weak profitability in certain STI stocks. Furthermore, he notes that the recovery tailwind may not be enough to unlock value in certain companies, emphasizing the importance of board-level focus on unlocking value.

site_title: New Zealand confirms first coronavirus case in months
summary: New Zealand confirmed its first coronavirus case in months, with a 56-year-old woman testing positive for the South African variant after returning on December 30. Authorities believe the source of the infection was a fellow returnee at a quarantine facility. No other community cases were reported, and the country is investigating the case.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post record closing high on chip boost, US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares reached a record high on Monday, driven by chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, which surged 3% and 5.1% respectively. The Kospi index rose 2.18% to 3,208.99, rebounding from a 0.6% decline on Friday. Investors are hopeful for a US stimulus package, which is expected to boost the market. Other heavyweights such as LG Chem and Naver also added 1.5%. This marks the fourth gain in five sessions for the Kospi index.

site_title: Indonesia seizes Iran, Panama-flagged tankers over alleged illegal oil transfer
summary: Indonesia's coast guard seized two tankers, the Iranian-flagged MT Horse and the Panamanian-flagged MT Freya, over suspected illegal oil transfer in its waters. The vessels, which concealed their identities and turned off automatic identification systems, were detected on January 23 and seized on January 25. They will be escorted to Batam island for further investigation. The incident highlights concerns over oil smuggling in the region.

site_title: Worst over for Asean economies but challenges remain: BNP Paribas
summary: Asean economies have largely overcome the worst of the pandemic, but challenges remain, according to BNP Paribas' Asean Outlook 2021 report. Rising Covid-19 cases and movement restrictions may scarring balance sheets, limiting household and corporate spending. The report predicts a "tepid recovery" with domestic demand constrained by rebuilding household savings. Central banks are expected to implement stimulus measures, including rate cuts and quantitative easing, to support growth. The region is expected to experience a flat recovery, with limited fiscal space, shifting the onus to monetary policy.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise SGX target price; see potential upside of 1.3-15.3%
summary: Analysts have raised their target prices for Singapore Exchange (SGX) after adjusting their forecasts higher for the bourse operator's FY2021-22 earnings. The stock closed at S$10.05 on Monday, with a 1.5% upside to the highest target price of S$11.61. Analysts cited revenue increases across SGX's businesses, lower operating expenses, and strong trading volumes, supporting their positive outlook.

site_title: South Africa's Woolworths expects first-half profit to soar as retail demand improves
summary: South Africa's Woolworths Holdings Ltd expects a 50-60% increase in first-half headline earnings per share, driven by improved retail demand. The company forecasts group sales to rise 5.3% and online sales to contribute 2-4% to overall sales. Despite a 4% drop in retail sales in November, Woolworths' focus on online sales and inventory management has resulted in positive cash flows. The company will release its results on February 25.

site_title: Chinese and Indian troops in fresh clashes along disputed border
summary: Indian and Chinese troops clashed along their disputed Himalayan border in the first outbreak of violence in seven months, with several soldiers injured. The clashes occurred in the Nakula area of North Sikkim, where violence broke out in May. China's Foreign Ministry spokesman denied reports of clashes, calling them "fake news." The incident comes after clashes in the Galwan valley last June left at least 20 Indian soldiers dead. Both sides are holding talks to resolve the standoff, which has seen thousands of soldiers and troops deployed to the border.

site_title: China's Xi to address Davos in first remarks during Biden era
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to deliver his first speech since Joe Biden entered the White House at the Davos Agenda event, marking a significant moment in relations between the world's biggest economies. Xi's earlier remarks highlighted China's openness and warned against protectionism, a tone that may contrast with the Biden administration's tough line on China. With China expected to report an 8.3% economic expansion this year, Xi is speaking from a position of strength, and his "dual circulation" policy prioritizes self-sufficiency amid US sanctions and tariffs.

site_title: Consumer prices fell more for Singapore households at the bottom in H2 2020
summary: Consumer prices in Singapore fell more for the bottom 20% of households in the second half of 2020, with a 0.2% year-on-year decrease in the all-items consumer price index (CPI). Excluding imputed rentals, the difference was greater, with a 0.4% fall for the lowest 20%, 0.3% for the middle 60%, and 0.2% for the top 20%. This suggests that households at the lower end of the income spectrum were disproportionately affected by the economic downturn.

site_title: Borders tightened as coronavirus curfew fury spills over
summary: Global borders are tightening in response to the unrelenting coronavirus threat, with the US joining France, Israel, and Sweden in imposing restrictions on certain arrivals. New strains of the virus originating in Britain and South Africa have sparked increased concern. Protests against coronavirus curfews in the Netherlands turned violent, with clashes and looting reported. The US also announced a ban on non-US citizens who have been in Britain, Brazil, Ireland, and parts of Europe, with South Africa added to the list.

site_title: Indonesia foreign direct investment up 5.5% y-o-y in Q4
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) rose 5.5% in Q4 2020 to 111.1 trillion rupiah, despite a 2.4% decline in 2020 compared to 2019. The slowdown was attributed to the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Foreign direct investment (FDI) into Indonesia in the fourth quarter last year rose 5.5 per cent to 111.1 trillion rupiah (S$10.5 billion), despite a slowdown earlier in the year, data from the country's investment board showed on Monday.

site_title: A new green frontier for businesses
summary: Businesses are embracing the "Great Reset" as a chance to transform their practices for a more sustainable future. With the global pandemic's impact, e-commerce and doorstep deliveries have surged, making logistics a key aspect of commerce. Consumers are increasingly demanding sustainable practices, with 61% making environmentally friendly purchases. To meet this demand, companies can adopt green packaging, such as reusable and biodegradable materials, and leverage emerging technologies like AI, IoT, and 5G for smart and efficient deliveries. Partnering with responsible ecosystem partners is crucial to amplify the eco-impact.

site_title: Japan likely to hit Covid-19 herd immunity in Oct, months after Olympics - researcher
summary: Japan is likely to achieve Covid-19 herd immunity in October, months after the planned Tokyo Olympics, according to a London-based forecaster. This prediction contradicts Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's pledge to have enough shots for the populace by the middle of 2021. Japan's vaccine supply is dependent on imports from the US, and it's unlikely to receive large quantities of the Pfizer vaccine. The country will not reach a 75% inoculation rate until around October, about two months after the Summer Games close.

site_title: 1-year-old boy among 44 new Covid-19 imported cases in Singapore
summary: A 1-year-old boy was among 44 new Covid-19 imported cases in Singapore, confirmed on Monday. The cases include four Singaporeans and two permanent residents who returned from Indonesia, Malaysia, and the US. No new community cases were reported for the third day in a row. With 25 cases discharged, 59,051 patients have fully recovered, and 59,352 total cases have been reported, with 29 deaths and 198 recuperating in community facilities.

images.alt_text: There were 44 new coronavirus cases confirmed as at Monday noon (Jan 25), all of which were imported.

site_title: US leading race in artificial intelligence, China rising: survey
summary: The US leads in artificial intelligence development and use, according to a research report by the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation. The US scored 44.6 points out of 100, followed by China with 32 and the European Union with 23.3. The assessment used 30 separate metrics, including human talent, research activity, and commercial development. The report is based on 2020 data.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 11-month high as country approves Pfizer vaccine
summary: Australian shares closed at an 11-month high on Monday after the country's drug regulator approved the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, lifting broader market sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4%, its highest since February 2020, driven by gains in miners and technology stocks. Vaccination of priority groups is expected to begin by February-end, with 80,000 doses per week. Markets will be closed on Tuesday for Australia Day.

site_title: DBS launches digital audit confirmation solution on corporate banking platform
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has launched the world's first digital audit confirmation solution on its corporate banking platform, DBS IDEAL. The solution allows customers to verify financial positions and balances digitally, reducing processing time for audit confirmation requests to under 24 hours, compared to the industry's norm of at least seven days. This digital process is expected to save 30,000 corporate and SME clients from manual submissions and expedite the closure of annual financial statements. The solution also provides real-time tracking of requests, reducing the need for phone inquiries.

site_title: Japan still has mountain to climb before it can lift emergency
summary: Japan's second state of emergency, declared on January 7, is halfway through and officials will examine its effectiveness in the coming week. The measure, which restricts residents from going out after 8 pm and closes bars and restaurants, has shown some success in slowing new infections, but experts are uncertain if it will be enough to lift the emergency. The government may extend the measure for another month, but public health experts question its impact, citing lighter restrictions and a decline in footfall.

site_title: Singapore core consumer prices fall further in December, but headline inflation flat
summary: Singapore's core consumer prices fell further in December, reaching -0.3% year-on-year, while headline inflation remained flat at 0%. This follows a similar trend in November, with core inflation also falling. Economists expect prices to pick up in 2021 as the economy recovers from the pandemic recession. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their 2021 inflation forecasts, with some economists predicting an average inflation rate of 0.5% for both headline and core inflation.

site_title: Covid condemns billions to poverty for a decade: Oxfam
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is exacerbating global inequality, with the richest 1,000 people recouping their losses within 9 months, while the world's poorest may take over a decade to recover. Anti-poverty group Oxfam warns that the pandemic is the first time since records began that inequality is rising in virtually every country simultaneously. The organization calls for fairer economies and a tax system where the richest individuals and corporations pay their fair share to drive a rapid economic recovery from Covid-19.

site_title: South Korean left-wing party chief sacked for sexual harassment
summary: South Korea's left-wing Justice Party has sacked its chairman, Kim Jong-Cheol, for sexually harassing an MP, Jang Hye-yeong, who is a prominent human rights campaigner. Kim admitted to making unwanted physical contacts and committing clear sexual harassment. The incident occurred after a dinner meeting last month, and Jang reported it three days later. The Justice Party's deputy leader called the incident "blatant sexual harassment" and Kim acknowledged all allegations, offering Jang a "deepest apology."

site_title: Hot stock: The Place Holdings shares surge 15.7%; receives SGX query
summary: The Place Holdings shares surged 15.7% to 11.8 Singapore cents after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the company over unexplained trading activity. The counter was actively pursuing potential investment opportunities and had no definitive agreements. Despite an SGX query, the company's shares continued to rise, reaching an intraday high of 12.1 cents. The company will make announcements if any agreements materialize, and shares have grown 120% in the past week.

site_title: China overtook US in foreign direct investment, UN agency says
summary: China surpassed the US as the largest recipient of foreign direct investment in 2020, with $163 billion in flows, according to the UNCTAD Investment Trends Monitor. Global FDI fell 42% to $859 billion due to the COVID-19 pandemic. China's high-tech industries saw an 11% increase in FDI, while North America's flows dropped 46% to $166 billion. Europe, particularly the UK, saw significant declines in FDI. The UN agency expects weak FDI in 2021 due to pandemic uncertainty, with investors remaining cautious about committing capital to new overseas assets.

images.alt_text: China overtook the US as the largest recipient of foreign direct investment in 2020, a year in which overall global flows cratered by 42 per cent as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, a United Nations trade agency said.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise with eyes on US stimulus push
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, rebounding from last week's sell-off as investors await the US stimulus package. Hong Kong led gains, while Taipei, Manila, and Wellington fell. The rollout of COVID-19 vaccinations continues to support equities, but concerns over surging infections and new variants weigh sentiment. Lawmakers in Washington are working on the $1.9 trillion stimulus proposal, which faces headwinds from Republicans. The Federal Reserve is set to hold its first meeting under the Biden administration, with investors seeking clues on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led the gains, rallying 1.8 per cent, after the government lifted a strict weekend lockdown in one part of the city, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, Sydney and Singapore also posted healthy gains. Taipei, Manila and Wellington all fell.

site_title: SGX rolls out pioneering suite of ESG derivatives
summary: SGX has launched a suite of four ESG derivatives, marking a key thrust of its sustainability agenda. The derivatives, developed in partnership with FTSE Russell, are designed to enable seamless adoption of ESG factors into investment portfolios. The indices are backed by major global pension funds and certified by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, allowing for direct trading from the US. The launch aims to drive sustainable risk-management solutions in Asia, with SGX positioning itself as a leader in this area.

images.alt_text: SGX has launched its pioneering suite of environment, social and governance derivatives under the SGX First (Future in Reshaping Sustainability Together) sustainability agenda, which was announced in December 2020.

site_title: HSBC's CEO faces UK questions over Hong Kong account
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn is set to answer UK Parliament questions over the bank's account freezes of Hong Kong activists. Former Hong Kong lawmaker Ted Hui claims the bank's actions were unjustified, citing a lack of legal basis. The move comes amid growing tension in Hong Kong as China tightens control. HSBC froze accounts of activists, including Hui, after a police request. Quinn's explanation that the bank was forced to freeze accounts has been rejected by Hui, who is now in exile. The UK Foreign Affairs Committee's hearing is scheduled for Tuesday.

site_title: Unemployed supertankers are about to get junked on Asia's beaches
summary: Unemployment is expected to rise among supertankers as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact the global oil market. With a surplus of ships, vessel owners are forced to subsidize cargo delivery, leading to a surge in beach scrapping in Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan. The Baltic Exchange reports daily earnings for supertankers to be -$1,190, with ship speeds expected to decrease by 25%. Clarkson Research Services estimates 2% of the fleet will be scrapped in 2021, and owners expect a recovery in earnings only in the second half of the year.

site_title: Oil prices fall for second session as Covid-19 lockdown concerns cast pall over demand prospects
summary: Oil prices fell for the second consecutive session as renewed Covid-19 lockdowns raised concerns about global fuel demand. Brent crude futures dropped 0.3% to $55.26 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.2% to $52.19 a barrel. Lockdowns in Hong Kong, China, and possible France are restricting business activity and fuel consumption, weighing on the market. China's new Covid-19 cases rose, casting a pall over demand prospects, the world's largest energy consumer. Oil production cuts from Saudi Arabia and US sanctions on Iran are also being watched.

site_title: Renewables overtook fossil fuels in EU electricity mix in 2020
summary: Renewables surpassed fossil fuels as the EU's main source of electricity in 2020, with renewables accounting for 38% and fossil fuels at 37%. Denmark generated 61% of its electricity from wind and solar, while Ireland and Germany followed with 35% and 33%, respectively. Coal-fired power generation fell 20% in 2020, with many countries phasing out polluting plants to meet emission targets. The COVID-19 pandemic led to a 4% drop in electricity demand, but renewables are expected to continue rising, with fossil fuels potentially rebounding but not expected to regain their previous dominance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by investors shifting focus to corporate earnings season in Japan. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.21% to 28,691.49, while the Topix index gained 0.26% to 1,861.56. The gains come after a mixed close on Wall Street last week, with investors awaiting corporate earnings reports in Japan.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing value must grow by 50% over next decade: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing has set a target of 50% growth in manufacturing value over the next decade, aiming to maintain a strong manufacturing base and increase the sector's share of the economy to 20%. The government plans to focus on a more productive sector with a higher-skilled workforce, and to reposition manufacturing beyond just quantitative growth, with a focus on advanced manufacturing, innovation, and intellectual property. Growing the sector's Singaporean workforce will be a key strategy, with a focus on attracting high-quality talent and complementing it with advanced machines and technology.

site_title: Shanghai financiers say China exchanges must rectify flaws, propose changes: The Paper
summary: Shanghai's top financiers have proposed changes to improve China's exchanges, citing management shortcomings as a major hindrance to development. The proposal includes integrating exchanges under a group holding entity, improving corporate governance, and listing on both the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE). The goal is to increase transparency, commercialize the exchanges, and boost the city's status as a global financial center. The 22 signatories, including the chairman of the Shanghai Gold Exchange and bank executives, aim to address these issues to enhance the capital markets' competitiveness.

site_title: Australia regulator approves Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for use
summary: Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has conditionally approved the Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for use in people aged over 16. The vaccine's safety, quality, and efficacy met strict standards. Prime Minister Scott Morrison welcomed the approval, stating it is safe, effective, and of high standard. The first doses will be prioritized for Australians over 16, with a second dose to follow.

site_title: Kuaishou seeks US$5.4b in biggest tech IPO since Uber
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a Chinese short video startup, is seeking a record-breaking US$5.4 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, surpassing Uber's 2019 IPO. The company, backed by Tencent Holdings, will sell 365 million shares at HK$105 to HK$115 each. The IPO, slated for February 5, would be the world's largest internet IPO since Uber's US$8.1 billion sale in May 2019, and could become Asia's largest since Budweiser's US$5.8 billion float in 2023.

images.alt_text: Kuaishou Technology, the main rival to ByteDance Ltd in China, is seeking to raise as much as US$5.4 billion in Hong Kong in what would be the world's biggest internet initial public offering since Uber Technologies Inc.

site_title: Greece eyes former royal estate for tourism makeover
summary: Greece's conservative government plans to reopen the former royal estate, Tatoi, for eco-friendly visits and sustainable agriculture. The 4.2-hectare estate, abandoned since 1967, will be restored and revived with a "historic brand" of agricultural products. The government expects to conclude studies next year and seek private investment. The estate, once home to European royalty, was seized by a military junta and has been in disrepair since. The move aims to create a year-round destination for all ages through sustainable infrastructure and activities, closely linked to Greece's modern history.

site_title: Biden to reinstate Covid-19 travel bans: White House official
summary: President Joe Biden will reinstate a Covid-19 travel ban on most non-US citizens who have been in Britain, Brazil, Ireland, and much of Europe, as well as recently visited South Africa, due to new, more transmissible coronavirus variants. The ban aims to tackle the US's worsening coronavirus crisis, with the death toll projected to rise to half a million next month. The move reverses a ban lifted by former President Donald Trump in his last days in office.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.74 points to 1,597.48. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 890.15 million lots worth RM579.04 million. The number of losers outweighed gainers 610 to 184.

site_title: Hong Kong lifts lockdown in Kowloon district after testing 7,000 people
summary: Hong Kong lifted a lockdown in a Kowloon district after testing 7,000 people for coronavirus, citing a reduced risk of transmission. The lockdown, which affected 13 confirmed cases, was the first since the outbreak began. The government aims to ease residents' worries and fear, allowing businesses to resume normal activities. The decision comes as Hong Kong reported 76 new cases, bringing the total to 10,086, with 169 deaths. Authorities have taken aggressive measures to curb the spread, including a ban on in-house dining and closures of public facilities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.78% to 29,677.30, following two days of losses. Investors monitored the US stimulus package progress. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were flat and down 0.17% respectively.

site_title: StashAway crosses US$1b in assets under management
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based fintech, has reached a milestone of over US$1 billion in assets under management in just three-and-a-half years. The platform has consistently outperformed its benchmarks, with annualized returns ranging from 16.5% to 4.3% since its inception. StashAway's ability to generate strong returns, even in market volatility, has attracted assets from clients in South-east Asia and the Middle East. The firm's focus on financial education and customer experience has contributed to its fast growth, with a total paid-up capital of US$36.6 million.

site_title: Biden to impose South Africa travel ban to combat new Covid-19 variant: CDC
summary: US President Joe Biden will impose a travel ban on most non-US citizens entering the country who have recently been in South Africa due to the new Covid-19 variant, starting Saturday. This ban, combined with existing restrictions on Brazil, the UK, Ireland, and 26 European countries, will restrict non-US citizens who have been in one of these countries within the last 14 days from entering the US. The ban aims to contain the spread of the variant, which is 50% more infectious and has been detected in at least 20 countries.

site_title: Top hedge funds earn US$63.5b in 2020, highest in a decade: LCH data
summary: The world's 20 top-performing hedge funds earned US$63.5 billion for clients in 2020, setting a record for the last decade amidst a chaotic year marked by a pandemic-induced sell-off. The average hedge fund returned 11.6% in 2020, lagging behind the S&P 500 index's 16% gain. Top performers included Tiger Global, Millennium, Lone Pine, Viking Global Investors, and Citadel, with Bridgewater Associates holding the No. 1 spot despite a terrible 2020.

site_title: Russian Nord Stream 2 pipe-laying ship begins work in Danish waters
summary: A Russian pipe-laying ship, Fortuna, began work on the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Danish waters on January 24, 2021. The ship started laying pipes in the Danish Exclusive Economic Zone, ahead of the pipeline's resumption. Despite US sanctions threats, the ship arrived in Danish waters. The work is being performed in line with relevant permits.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, CapitaLand, Jumbo, USP Group, FJ Benjamin, Fu Yu
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Singapore Exchange (SGX) posted a 12.4% net profit for the half-year ended Dec 31, 2020, and announced a joint venture with Temasek to advance digital asset infrastructure. CapitaLand expects a loss for FY2020 due to revaluations and impairments. Jumbo Group's indirect subsidiary entered a joint venture with The Art of Mee Pok to sell Teochew fishball and minced meat noodles. USP Group is seeking $11 million in damages from five parties, including two former board members. FJ Benjamin Holdings obtained in-principle approval to transfer to the Catalist board, while Fu Yu Corp sold a 29.8% stake to a buyer.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.72 points or 0.1% to 2,993.25. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 47, driven by gains in CapitaLand and Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust. Local lenders DBS and UOB also saw gains, while OCBC slipped. The STI's gain comes after a mixed close on Wall Street, where US equities finished mostly lower due to concerns over new coronavirus strains.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares began trading on Monday morning in slightly positive territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.72 points or 0.1 per cent to 2,993.25 as at 9am.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher as miners, banks lead gains
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.2% to 6,814.40, driven by gains in miners and financials, while energy stocks declined. Heavyweight miners BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group advanced 1.4%, 1.1%, and 3.5% respectively. Big Four banks also traded positively, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank adding 0.8% each. The markets will be closed on Tuesday for Australia Day, with investors watching domestic inflation data and US Federal Reserve meeting.

site_title: France imposes border controls in scramble to avoid lockdown
summary: France has implemented border controls, requiring arrivals from European Union countries by air or sea to produce a negative PCR test result within 72 hours, amid concerns of a potential third nationwide lockdown due to high Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations. One million people in France have received at least one Covid-19 jab, but health authorities warn that the current measures, including a daily curfew, may not be enough to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Hot stock: CapitaLand shares sink 4.7% after profit warning; analysts remain positive
summary: CapitaLand shares fell 4.7% on Monday after the property group warned of a full-year loss due to revaluations and impairments. Despite this, analysts remain positive, with RHB analyst Vijay Natarajan saying the loss is driven by non-cash fair value and impairment losses. Core operating profit is expected to remain resilient, and analysts have maintained their "buy" calls with unchanged target prices.

images.alt_text: Shares in CapitaLand took a beating at the start of the week, after the property behemoth on Friday issued a profit warning expecting a full-year loss for the year ended Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Online fashion retailer Boohoo to buy Debenhams brand: FT
summary: Online fashion retailer Boohoo Group is set to acquire the Debenhams brand in a £50 million deal, resulting in the closure of the group's remaining department stores. The acquisition is a cut-price deal and a deal could be announced in the next few days. Debenhams had previously been wound down, closing its shops and putting 12,000 jobs at risk due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The purchase price is expected to be about £50 million (S$90.7 million).

site_title: Israel 'closes skies' to air travel to prevent virus spread
summary: Israel has announced a week-long ban on most incoming and outgoing flights to slow the spread of new coronavirus variants. The ban, starting Monday, will allow for exceptions for cargo, firefighting, medical treatments, funerals, and legal procedures. The measure comes as the country is in its third national lockdown due to a surge in Covid-19 deaths, with over 2.5 million of its 9-million-strong population vaccinated since January. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cited the need to prevent the entry of virus mutations and ensure progress with the vaccination campaign.

site_title: China-Taiwan tensions rise days into Biden presidency
summary: China has dispatched 27 aircraft, including 12 fighter jets, into Taiwan's air defense identification zone for the second consecutive day, escalating tensions near the island. This move comes days into US President Joe Biden's administration, with China viewing Taiwan as its own territory. The US has reaffirmed its commitment to Taiwan, while China claims its actions are aimed at defending sovereignty and warning against "collusion" between the US and Taiwan.

site_title: Kuaishou draws BlackRock, Abu Dhabi to US$6b IPO
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a Chinese short-video startup, has attracted BlackRock, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, and several other investors to its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) valued at up to US$6 billion. The company plans to allocate around US$2.5 billion of IPO stock to 10 cornerstone investors, including Capital Group Cos, Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, and Morgan Stanley Investment Management. This is the largest internet IPO since Uber's US$8.1 billion share sale in 2019, and Kuaishou aims to expand its presence beyond smaller cities and into metropolitan areas.

site_title: Lian Beng and PropNex directors continue accumulating shares
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% over the five trading sessions from Jan 15 to 21, bringing its total return for the 2021 year to 6.5%. DBS Group Holdings, OCBC, and Wilmar International saw the highest net institutional inflows, while technology trio Fu Yu Corporation, AEM Holdings, and UMS Holdings logged the highest net institutional inflows outside the STI. Ten primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with OUE purchasing 2.1% of its issued shares and Global Investments buying back 3.73% of its issued shares. Directors and substantial shareholders accumulated shares in companies like Lian Beng Group and PropNex.

site_title: Staff get perk immunity at some firms
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines staff and their dependents continue to enjoy a free flight perk despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline allowed staff to roll over unused privilege tickets into 2021, a standard practice. This perk was not taken away, unlike some other firms that have granted immunity to staff due to the pandemic.

site_title: Deutsche Bank starts probe in relation to engagement with some clients
summary: Deutsche Bank has initiated an investigation into its engagement with some clients after the Financial Times reported on alleged mis-selling of investment banking products. The German lender declined to comment on the details of the probe until it is complete. This move comes amid a broader trend of financial institutions being scrutinized for their business practices. The investigation's outcome and any potential consequences for Deutsche Bank remain unclear at this time.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG said on Sunday it began a probe in relation to engagement with some clients after the Financial Times reported earlier that the German lender was investigating the alleged mis-selling of investment banking products.

site_title: KLM to keep long haul flights as Covid testing demands are softened
summary: Dutch airline KLM will continue to operate long-haul flights, including those for vaccine distribution, after agreeing to softer Covid-19 testing demands with the government. The airline had initially planned to cancel flights due to the requirement for passengers and crew to show a negative rapid Covid-19 test taken before departure. Instead, flight crew will take a rapid antigen test before and after departure, and follow strict quarantine rules during their stay abroad.

site_title: Solskjaer hails Fernandes as Man United star downs Liverpool
summary: Manchester United defeated Liverpool 3-2 in the FA Cup fourth round, with Bruno Fernandes scoring a late winning free-kick. Fernandes' goal capped a thrilling tie, as United recovered from Mohamed Salah's early opener to also score through Mason Greenwood and Marcus Rashford. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer praised Fernandes' work ethic, saying he stayed after training to practice free-kicks. The win marks United's renaissance after a poor start to the season, with the team now six points clear of Liverpool in the league.

site_title: Oil industry reels as Biden targets fossil fuels in his first days
summary: President Joe Biden has taken swift action in his first days in office, canceling the Keystone XL oil pipeline and mandating that only top agency leaders can approve new drilling permits on federal land. The Interior Department has also announced plans to suspend the sale of oil and gas leases on federal land, where the US gets 10% of its supplies. The actions have sent oil producers' stocks tumbling and raised concerns about the impact on the economy and jobs, with industry officials warning of a "broader ban" on leasing.

site_title: Paris says Biden, Macron in agreement on Covid-19, climate change
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and US President Joe Biden have agreed on climate change and cooperation in fighting the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a phone call between the two leaders. Macron had previously praised Biden's decision to re-enter the Paris climate accord, which Trump had withdrawn from. The two leaders also discussed their willingness to work together on global issues, including the Iranian nuclear issue and the Middle East. Biden has vowed to rebuild the US's relationships with European allies and has made close coordination with Paris a priority.

site_title: Billionaire seeks Moneta stake to revive Czech bank merger
summary: Billionaire Petr Kellner's PPF Group is proposing to buy up to 29% of Moneta Money Bank at a 19% premium to its market value, aiming to revive a failed Czech banking merger. The move would give PPF significant control and support a proposed deal to acquire Air Bank and other assets through a share swap. Moneta has agreed to start talks with PPF and is open to a mandatory takeover bid if the deal goes through, potentially creating the fifth-largest bank in the Czech Republic.

site_title: Cutting Budget deficit while sustaining positive fiscal impulse a knotty endeavour
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 aims to balance a smaller deficit while maintaining a positive fiscal impulse, following a downturn that curtailed tax revenue. A planned Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike will not occur in 2021. The government will focus on supporting the nascent recovery, avoiding measures that could hurt the economy. With a more modest budget, the government will prioritize expenditure on key areas, including healthcare and education, while managing public finances.

site_title: Is property development in Singapore becoming an unsustainable business?
summary: Singapore's property development sector is under scrutiny due to its unsustainable business model, which creates negative externalities for society. The government may introduce further cooling measures, including increasing the minimum average home size and raising stamp duties. This could impact major property developers such as CapitaLand, City Developments, and UOL Group. The sector's profitability relies on pushing prices higher, but this comes at the cost of crushing mortgage debt for the public. As the sector faces growing sustainability risks, developers must adapt their business model to eliminate negative externalities without destroying shareholder returns.

site_title: Charity offers money back guarantee for youth intervention programme
summary: YMCA of Singapore has launched a unique "money back guarantee" for its Project Bridge Vocational and Soft Skills Programme, promising to return donated funds if outcome targets are not met. The Social Impact Guarantee model aims to boost accountability and rigorous outcome-focused practices, and has been adopted by the YMCA in partnership with Tri-Sector Associates. The programme aims to place 75% of enrolled youth into employment or education, with a guaranteed success rate of 75% if the target is not met.

site_title: Taiwan says it's asking chip firms to help ease vehicle chip shortage
summary: Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs has asked local tech firms, particularly Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), to provide full assistance in easing a global shortage of automotive chips. The shortage has affected major carmakers, including Ford, Subaru, Toyota, and Volkswagen, due to a shortage of semiconductors exacerbated by the former Trump administration's actions against Chinese chip factories. Taiwanese officials have received requests from foreign governments, including Germany, and are working to address the issue, which is a priority for TSMC.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's Gorman is top-paid US bank CEO
summary: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman surpassed JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon as the top-paid US bank CEO, with a total compensation of $33 million for 2020, up 22% from the previous year. Gorman's pay includes $23.6 million in long-term awards, while Dimon's compensation remained unchanged at $31.5 million. The boost in Gorman's pay comes after Morgan Stanley posted its third consecutive year of record earnings and carried out two of the largest deals by a top Wall Street bank.

site_title: Maersk loses 750 containers as seas hit LA-bound ship
summary: A Maersk container ship, Maersk Essen, lost around 750 containers overboard while sailing from China to Los Angeles during bad weather on January 16. All crew members are safe, and the ship continues its journey to Mexico for cargo surveys and repairs. This incident comes after another Maersk ship, ONE Apus, lost 1,816 containers at sea due to severe weather in November. The loss is part of a surge in container ship travel with record-high freight rates and restocking of US inventories.

site_title: No Europe deaths seen directly tied to Covid jabs
summary: Despite dozens of reported deaths of people shortly after receiving COVID-19 vaccinations, scientists say the evidence does not incriminate the vaccines. Most post-vaccination fatalities were elderly, vulnerable, and already sick. Health agencies stress that normal side effects like fever or nausea could have contributed to the deaths. No cause-and-effect relationship has been identified, and European health officials say the deaths do not call into question the safety of the vaccines.

site_title: Forced digitalisation of firms opens 'tech-lite' window for non-tech grads
summary: Singapore businesses have seen a surge in demand for tech talent due to the global pandemic, forcing them to digitalize and upgrade their technology set-ups. This has opened up opportunities for non-tech graduates, particularly in "tech-lite" roles such as technical customer service and IT sales, with salaries ranging from S$2,800 to S$3,500. With restrictions on foreign hiring, companies are now more open to hiring and training local fresh graduates, with some offering grants under the SGUnited Traineeships Programme.

site_title: SpaceX rocket deploys record-setting cargo
summary: SpaceX successfully launched its Falcon 9 rocket, carrying a record 143 satellites, including 133 commercial and government spacecraft and 10 SpaceX satellites, on January 24, 2021. The rocket, launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida, successfully deployed all satellites, with the main booster landing on an unmanned drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean. This marks the fifth successful deployment and recapture of the booster. The launch is part of SpaceX's "rideshare" program, aiming to send thousands of small satellites into space to form a global broadband system called Starlink.

images.alt_text: SpaceX on Sunday launched its Falcon 9 rocket carrying a record number of satellites on board, the private space company said.

site_title: Getting the US back in shape
summary: US President Joe Biden faces significant challenges in his first term, including unity, stability, and alliances. The nation is deeply divided, with issues such as racial disharmony, demographic changes, and economic inequality. Biden's biggest challenge is to heal the nation's divisions, rebuild the economy, and regain the trust of the American people. He must also navigate the complexities of global politics, address climate change, and rebalance US-China relations. With unrealistic expectations and a divided Congress, Biden's success hinges on his ability to bring people together and make decisive action on key issues.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden speaks about his administration's plans to fight the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic as Vice President Kamala Harris listens  during a COVID-19 response event at the White House in Washington, U.S., January 21, 2021. site_title: Larry King, TV host who interviewed presidents, dies at 87
summary: Larry King, a renowned TV host who interviewed numerous U.S. presidents, passed away at 87. He died on January 23, 2021, at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, after recently undergoing treatment for COVID-19. King hosted a popular nighttime radio call-in show and later a TV interview program, "Larry King Live," which featured interviews with world leaders, celebrities, and athletes. He won an Emmy award for lifetime achievement and was inducted into the Radio, Cable, and Broadcasters Halls of Fame.

site_title: Diamond trade roaring back, thanks to stuck-at-home shoppers buying online
summary: The global diamond trade has experienced a significant resurgence, driven by online shopping and bumper holiday sales, particularly in the US and Chinese markets. Factories in Surat, India, are struggling to keep up with demand, with some offering 50% pay hikes to skilled cutters and polishers. De Beers is poised for its largest rough-diamond sale in three years, while Alrosa expects the recovery to continue. However, some industry participants worry that the rebound may be short-lived, and prices could drop later in the year if sales slow.

site_title: US housing boomed in 2020 even as pandemic slammed economy
summary: The US housing market experienced a surge in 2020 despite the pandemic, with existing home sales reaching a 14-year high and new home sales increasing 20.8% from the previous year. Americans took advantage of low borrowing rates to buy homes, with the median sale price rising 12.9% to $309,800. The market's resilience contrasts with the 2008 global financial crisis, where mortgages played a central role in the downturn. Experts predict the momentum will continue, with more buyers expected to enter the market in the new year.

site_title: Leading through a modern-day crisis
summary: A study by Nanyang Technological University revealed that the pandemic has shifted emotions from fear to anger, with 61% of remote workers reporting stress. To alleviate stress and maintain trust, CEOs must adopt key leadership traits: empathy, decisiveness, humility, vulnerability, and inclusiveness. Empathy involves checking in with staff, developing policies to address common challenges, and demonstrating genuine care for the workforce. Decisiveness requires making quick, informed decisions, even with limited information. Humility involves acknowledging uncertainty and transparency. Vulnerability showcases authenticity and inspires trust. Inclusiveness fosters a culture of solidarity and consideration for diverse perspectives, essential for navigating a hybrid work model and driving business recovery.

images.alt_text: Randstad's Jaya Dass: "Instead of trying to put up a brave front all the time, being real in these uncertain times can in fact be more reassuring to your people and make you seem more relatable."

site_title: Home-baking frenzy sweetens sugar demand
summary: Global sugar demand surged last season, defying expectations as a home-baking frenzy, stimulus cheques, and stockpiling boosted consumption. The rebound is set to reach a record in 2021, with Asia and Africa driving the increase. In contrast, the US and Europe are expected to see little change in demand. Production in key sugar-producing countries, such as Brazil, the European Union, and Thailand, is under stress, sending sugar futures up 70% since pandemic lows. Analysts predict a 2-1% increase in global sugar consumption this year.

site_title: Australian Open tweaks lead-in events for players in virus lockdown
summary: Australian Open organisers have revised the lead-in events schedule to give 72 players more time to prepare after a 14-day quarantine lockdown due to coronavirus cases on charter flights. A third WTA 500 event will run from Feb 3-7, while the two original events will go ahead with reduced draw sizes. The ATP 250 events will start on Feb 1 with increased singles main draw sizes, and the ATP Cup will be delayed to Feb 2. The revised schedule aims to help players prepare after a challenging quarantine period.

site_title: 2020 property investment up even as retail consumption slides
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 40-52% year-on-year in April and May 2020, but recovered slightly due to "revenge spending" as the economy reopened. New private home sales, however, surged 58% to 256 units in April, and sales continued to grow in subsequent months. Despite a 2.1% quarterly jump in new private home prices, the retail sector remains weak due to a severe decline in tourist arrivals, with visitor numbers plummeting 84.4% year-on-year.

site_title: EUR/USD nears narrowing end of rising wedge
summary: EUR/USD is nearing the end of a rising wedge pattern, a bearish reversal signal. The currency pair has been trading within an ascending channel since December 2020, but broke out of it on January 8, 2021. The pair is currently above the support level around 1.2075. A potential reversal is expected, with the pair testing the support line around 1.2025 and potentially breaking down to 1.1624, where it tested twice in 2020 before resuming a bullish trend.

site_title: Indonesia sees downside risks to Q1 growth on virus curbs, natural disasters
summary: Indonesia faces downside risks to Q1 growth due to the COVID-19 outbreak and natural disasters, with Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati warning that January will be "very tough" despite efforts to contain the virus and implement stimulus packages. The country aims to achieve 5% full-year growth, with a mass vaccination program offering "hope and optimism". Despite a recession in 2020, President Joko Widodo expects a turnaround in 2021, but the government must contend with surging cases and deaths, as well as natural disasters.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati: "We hope in February and March we can still catch up despite January which is going to be very tough because of Covid and natural disasters".

site_title: Long-term bonds a 'senseless' speculative trade: hedge fund manager
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager Paul Singer warns that the combination of COVID-19 relief spending, wage pressures, and low interest rates could lead to a significant and abrupt price readjustment in bond markets, potentially causing inflation to spike higher. Bond-market indicators have risen sharply, with 10-year breakeven rates climbing above 2% for the first time since 2018. Singer considers holding long-term bonds "senseless" at current yields, calling it a form of speculation.

site_title: Chinese brand spun out of Huawei unveils devices with US chips
summary: Chinese smartphone brand Honor, spun off from Huawei, has unveiled new devices featuring US-made chips from Intel, MediaTek, and Nvidia. The move comes after suppliers resumed business following US sanctions on Huawei. Honor's CEO, George Zhao, stated the company has the flexibility to choose its suppliers, confirming partnerships with AMD, Intel, MediaTek, and others. This marks a significant development for the brand, which was once larger than Samsung's smartphone business, and aims to restore its global supply chain.

site_title: Seven banks escape with minor fines in Mexico antitrust case
summary: Mexico's antitrust body fined seven banks, including Deutsche Bank and Barclays, a total of 29.4 million pesos (S$1.96 million) for alleged price-rigging in the peso bond market. The fines, totaling 4% of the potential 680 million pesos, were announced after a four-year investigation. Eleven traders were also fined 5.7 million pesos. The fines are smaller than those paid by the banks in 2015 to settle charges with US, UK, and European regulators.

site_title: Parc Central Residences executive condominium about 60% sold
summary: The Parc Central Residences executive condominium in Tampines has sold about 60% of its 700 units, with 414 units sold at an average price of S$1,177 per square foot. Second-timer applicants can book units starting February 23, and a selection of three- to five-bedroom units remain available. Viewing is by appointment only through appointed agents. The development is jointly developed by Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Development.

site_title: New-home sales in London slump as lockdowns hurt demand
summary: New-home sales in London plummeted 27% in the fourth quarter to 4,190, largely due to lockdowns hurting demand and investors holding back on building apartments. This marks the lowest number of construction starts in a decade and the fewest home sales since 2011. Central London, heavily reliant on international travel, has been particularly affected, with a 2.9-year backlog of unsold homes if no new development begins. In contrast, suburban areas like Zone 3 experienced the second-highest sales rate on record last year.

site_title: Oil falls on China's Covid-19 cases, high crude build
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday due to a build in US crude inventories and concerns over new pandemic restrictions in China, the world's largest oil importer. Brent crude futures declined 1.1% to $55.50 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.3% to $52.45. China's rising Covid-19 cases and new restrictions have curbed fuel demand, while US crude inventory data showed signs of strength in domestic product demand, with refineries operating at high capacity and petrol and diesel demand increasing.

site_title: Orange sells half of 2.7b euro fibre unit to fund rural rollout
summary: Orange sells half of its €2.7 billion fibre unit to a consortium of investors, including Caisse des Dépôts and EDF Invest, to fund rural fibre rollout. The deal, expected to close by the end of the year, will allow Orange to ease the cost of deploying fibre connections to less-populated regions. Orange CEO Stephane Richard said the accord will enable the company to win new contracts and participate in market consolidation. The partnership will become France's leading fibre-to-the-home operator with over 4.5 million planned or built plug-ins.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower on grim Covid-19 news
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Friday due to concerns over new coronavirus strains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 retreating 0.6% and 0.3% respectively.
