site_title: Sales of HDB resale flats hit eight-year high in 2020 as prices climb 5%
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market ended 2020 on a strong note, with flat prices rising 5% for the year, the highest increase since 2012. Sales of HDB resale flats reached an eight-year high, with 24,748 units sold in 2020, a 4.4% increase from 2019. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, buyer demand remained buoyant, driven by government stimulus measures and a growing supply of HDB flats. Experts attribute the market's stability to strict measures in place, preventing over-leveraging and excessive speculative buying.

images.alt_text: The Housing Board resale market ended 2020 on a strong note with flat prices edging up in many locations and buyer demand remaining buoyant despite the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Japan Cabinet approves bill for tougher virus measures
summary: Japan's Cabinet approved draft laws to tighten coronavirus restrictions, which could include fines and prison sentences for rule-breakers for the first time since the outbreak began. The move aims to curb a record spike in Covid-19 infections in the capital and other regions ahead of the Tokyo Olympics. The new laws would allow authorities to punish those who test positive but refuse hospitalization, and penalize businesses that ignore closure requests. The bills are expected to pass Parliament next week, despite opposition concerns over civil liberties.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.6% or 162.47 points at 28,594.39. The broader Topix index also declined 0.6% or 10.78 points at 1,849.86. There were no fresh market-moving factors, following a rally in the previous session.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with a dearth of fresh market-moving factors following a rally in the previous session.

site_title: Shiseido in talks to sell personal-care business to CVC
summary: Shiseido Co, a Japanese cosmetics maker, is in advanced talks to sell its shampoo and affordable skincare business to CVC Capital Partners for 150-200 billion yen ($1.92-$2.55 billion). The deal, if agreed, would include operations in Japan, China, and other parts of Asia, and is part of Shiseido's efforts to shift focus to premium beauty products. The company, founded over 140 years ago, is revamping its portfolio due to the pandemic's impact on the beauty industry, with annual sales of the targeted business around 100 billion yen.

site_title: Singapore's new private home sales down 26% in Oct-Dec from previous quarter
summary: Singapore's new private home sales decreased 26% in October-December compared to the previous quarter, but still saw a 6.5% year-on-year increase. Prices rose 2.1% during the period, with non-landed properties in the rest of central region and core central region seeing significant growth. The market is expected to swing back in favor of sellers as housing stock depletes amid robust demand. Total new home sales for 2020 reached 9,982 units, and the government will continue to monitor the market and adjust supply accordingly.

site_title: Liverpool's 68-game unbeaten home run ended by Burnley
summary: Liverpool's 68-game unbeaten home run in the Premier League ended with a 1-0 loss to Burnley on Thursday. Ashley Barnes scored a late penalty after being tripped by Alisson Becker to give Burnley a first win at Anfield since 1974. The defeat marks Liverpool's fifth consecutive league game without a win, and their title defense is collapsing as they remain six points behind Manchester United in fourth.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend gains on tech boost
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth consecutive session, driven by gains in technology heavyweights Naver and Kakao. The Kospi index increased 17.64 points, or 0.6%, to 3,178.48, marking its record close. Other major companies, such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, traded mixed. The South Korean economy is expected to grow at a slower pace in the fourth quarter due to sluggish domestic demand. Foreign investors were net sellers of 44.3 billion won worth of shares, and the won weakened to 1,101.2 per US dollar.

site_title: Yellen leaves door open to tax increase on wealthy Americans
summary: Treasury Secretary-designate Janet Yellen has hinted that the Biden administration may increase taxes on corporations and wealthy Americans to fund infrastructure and social safety net programs. Yellen promised to "work with members of Congress" on protecting households earning less than $400,000 from a reversal of President Trump's 2017 tax cuts. She also suggested that the wealthy could be audited at higher rates and that the Treasury would review its debt-issuance strategy. Yellen's comments come as the Senate Finance panel is set to advance her nomination on Friday.

site_title: Retail rents fall at faster clip of 5.2% in Q4 but vacancy eases to 8.8%
summary: Singapore retail rentals declined 5.2% in Q4 2020, faster than the 4.5% drop in the previous quarter. For the year, rentals fell 14.7% and prices dropped 4.5%. The islandwide vacancy rate decreased to 8.8% from 9.6% in Q3 2020. Despite a decrease in occupied retail space, the total supply remained relatively stable, with 426,000 sq m of retail space available as of Q4 2020.

site_title: Google says it will shut search engine in Australia if forced to pay for news
summary: Google threatens to disable its search function in Australia if the government forces it to pay local media companies for sharing their content. The proposed law, which has broad support, would require Google and Facebook to negotiate payments with local publishers and broadcasters. If no deal is reached, a government-appointed arbitrator will set the price. Google's managing director, Mel Silva, said the code's arbitration model poses unmanageable financial and operational risk, while Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison rejected the threat, saying the country makes its own rules.

images.alt_text: Google said on Friday it will disable its search function in Australia if the government proceeds with a media code that would force it and Facebook to pay local media companies for sharing their content.

site_title: Japan doubles down on Tokyo Olympics, denies report of cancellation
summary: Japan reaffirmed its commitment to hosting the Tokyo Olympics this year, despite a recent surge in Covid-19 cases and public fears of holding the event during the pandemic. The country's government and Olympic committee denied reports of a potential cancellation, with the International Olympic Committee also confirming its commitment to holding the Games as scheduled. Organizers are preparing for the event, which is set to open on July 23, despite concerns from athletes and some countries, including Australia, that the Games may not go ahead as planned.

images.alt_text: Organisers of the Tokyo Olympics said all event partners, including the Japanese government and the International Olympic Committee, were "fully focused" on hosting the Games this summer in response to a report by the Times newspaper.

site_title: US Congress moves toward approving Biden's defence secretary pick
summary: US Congress approved a waiver allowing President Joe Biden's nominee, Lloyd Austin, to lead the Pentagon despite not meeting the required 7-year waiting period since leaving the military. The House voted 326-78 and the Senate followed with a 69-27 tally, paving the way for Austin's confirmation. This marks the first time a Black US Secretary of Defence will lead the Pentagon. The swift approval is seen as a priority for Biden's national security team to address ongoing challenges.

site_title: In Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, the gifts of simplicity
summary: A recent article highlights the appeal of simple, everyday wines, such as Montepulciano d'Abruzzo from Italy, over complex and expensive ones. These wines, often made by small, serious producers, offer direct and immediate pleasures, with a connection to their place of origin and the people who made them. The article reviews three Montepulciano d'Abruzzo wines, Cirelli, Tiberio, and De Fermo, praising their simplicity, freshness, and aging potential. The author concludes that everyday wines are essential for shaping a relationship with wine and setting a baseline for personal preferences.

site_title: United Airlines pledges more cost cuts after pandemic-driven quarterly loss
summary: United Airlines Holdings Inc announced a plan to cut US$2 billion in annual costs through 2023 to recover from the pandemic-driven fourth consecutive quarterly loss. The airline aims to reduce daily costs and expects to offer employees voluntary leave options to reduce furloughs. United's adjusted net loss was US$2.1 billion, with total operating revenue falling 69% in the fourth quarter. The airline expects revenue to fall by 65-70% in the current quarter and flight capacity to shrink by at least 51%.

site_title: Oil steadies after unexpected build in US crude stockpiles
summary: Oil prices steadied on Thursday after a surprise increase in US crude inventories, reviving concerns about pandemic-related fuel demand. US crude inventories rose 2.6 million barrels, contrary to forecasts. Brent crude futures rose 2 cents to $56.10 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 18 cents to $53.13 a barrel. The market awaits Friday's official inventory report and potential US stimulus. Rising coronavirus cases in China and the Biden administration's climate change policies may have long-term implications for oil prices.

site_title: Biden inauguration draws bigger television audience than Trump's
summary: Joe Biden's inauguration drew a larger television audience than Donald Trump's four years ago, with 39.9 million viewers tuning in to the six major broadcast and cable networks. This surpasses the 38.4 million who watched Trump's inauguration in 2017. The viewership numbers suggest that news channels may keep viewers engaged during a new administration, following a year of heavy news. CNN led among cable and broadcast news channels with 10 million viewers, while ABC led among broadcast networks for the first time in 28 years with 7.7 million viewers.

site_title: France tells its citizens: Fabric masks not enough to protect from Covid
summary: The French government is now recommending the use of surgical masks in public due to concerns over new, more contagious variants of Covid-19. Health Minister Olivier Veran stated that fabric masks are not sufficient protection and advised citizens to switch to surgical masks. This move may impact the country's ski resorts, which were initially expected to reopen in February, and could lead to a tightening of coronavirus restrictions if transmission rates worsen. France has reported over 71,000 coronavirus-related deaths, but is currently at 35% of its peak infection rate.

images.alt_text: The French government is now recommending that people wear surgical masks in public because they offer better protection from Covid-19 transmission than fabric face coverings, Health Minister Olivier Veran said on Thursday.

site_title: iSTOX raises US$50m as new Tokyo-backed investors come aboard
summary: iSTOX, a Singapore Exchange-backed digital securities platform, has raised US$50 million in Series A funding. New investors include the Japan Investment Corporation, Development Bank of Japan, and Juroku Bank, alongside existing backers like SGX, Tokai Tokyo Financial Holdings, and Hanwha Asset Management. The funds will be used to expand investment offerings and geographical footprint, including the launch of blue-chip issuers and deals in Europe and Australia.

site_title: Biden administration pauses federal drilling programme in climate push
summary: The Biden administration has temporarily suspended oil and gas permitting on federal lands and waters for 60 days, a move aimed at fighting climate change and tamping down the US fossil fuel industry. The suspension affects federal leases, which account for 25% of the nation's crude oil output, and is seen as a step towards permanently banning new drilling on federal acreage. Environmentalists welcome the move, while the oil and gas industry criticizes it as a threat to jobs and the economy, with shares of US shale producers falling following the news.

site_title: Sabana's manager wants to leave failed merger behind to look forward for growth
summary: Sabana Reit's CEO Donald Han wants to focus on improving the real estate investment trust's portfolio and performance after a failed merger with ESR-Reit. He aims to incorporate feedback from the merger process into the strategy, which includes rejuvenating select assets and proactively leasing and managing properties. Despite a 47.7% rise in distribution per unit, the Reit's gross revenue and net property income fell due to lower contributions from a terminated master lease. Han is open to disposing of assets or leasing them to tenants, and the Reit has seen increased take-up at its new mall.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: REX International's 90% owned subsidiary Lime Petroleum secured participating interests in four new offshore licenses, including one with a discovery for development, in the 2020 APA 2020 round in Norway. Kimly Makan Place entered a joint venture agreement to run a coffeeshop in Hougang. SOILBUILD Business Space Reit posted a 29.1% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit to 1.194 Singapore cents.

site_title: Japan privately concludes Tokyo Olympics should be cancelled due to coronavirus
summary: Japan's government has privately concluded the Tokyo Olympics should be cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to a report by The Times. The decision focuses on securing the Games for Tokyo in 2032. Japan has closed its borders to non-resident foreigners and declared a state of emergency in Tokyo and major cities amid a recent surge in cases.

site_title: IBM revenue disappoints as software sales mark rare decline
summary: IBM missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue, falling 6.5% to $20.37 billion, due to a rare decline in software sales. The company's cloud-computing business saw a 10% increase to a record $7.5 billion, but sales from its cloud and cognitive unit declined 4.5%. IBM expects revenue to grow in mid-single digits after its separation into two companies, focusing on hybrid cloud and cloud-computing. The company's shares dropped 6.7% in extended trading after its fourth consecutive quarter of sales decline.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq close at record highs on optimism about Biden stimulus plan
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Thursday, driven by optimism over the Biden administration's stimulus plan and a labor market recovery. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq gained 1.22 and 0.55% respectively, while the Dow fell 0.04%. Despite a high unemployment rate, the housing and manufacturing sectors showed strength. Investors are also optimistic about the technology sector, particularly megacap stocks, ahead of earnings reports.

site_title: Gold slips on profit taking; stimulus bets limit losses
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,867.56 per ounce, following a two-week high, as investors took profits after a rally fueled by US stimulus expectations. Despite this, gold remains supported by prospects of further stimulus and a weaker US dollar. US gold futures settled little changed, and spot silver edged 0.1% higher. Platinum rose 1%, while palladium eased 0.2%. The Biden administration's proposed $1.9 trillion stimulus package is expected to be a key factor in gold's performance.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices fall at decade-fast pace, add to deflation fears
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 1% in December from a year ago, the largest annual drop in a decade, amid intensifying deflationary pressures. The decline, driven by slumping oil prices, raises concerns about Japan's economy sliding back into recession and deflation. The data contradicts former premier Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus policies, which aimed to boost economic growth. A renewed state of emergency due to the coronavirus pandemic may further strain the economy, potentially hampering a sustained recovery.

site_title: CDL expecting 'material impairment loss' from investment in Sincere Property
summary: CDL expects to make provisions for a material impairment loss on its Sincere Property investment due to ongoing unprecedented challenges in China's real estate market. A review by Deloitte, CDL's external financial adviser, has taken into account the challenges, including China's "three red-lines" rule restricting bank borrowing for real estate firms. CDL has not provided further liquidity support or guarantees to Sincere Property since Dec 31, 2020, and has ring-fenced its current financial exposure to the investment.

site_title: US dollar slides for third day on economic data, stimulus expectations
summary: The US dollar slid for a third consecutive day, losing 0.3% to 90.103, as investors sought higher-yielding currencies amid optimism about a US economic recovery and a massive stimulus package. Better-than-expected US data and European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde's comments on a potential surge in Covid-19 infections also contributed to the decline. The euro gained 0.5% against the dollar, while the eurozone's vaccination delays are expected to impact growth trends. Analysts predict the US dollar will continue its downtrend, which saw it lose nearly 7% in 2020.

site_title: Biden unveils coronavirus plan, but says 100,000 may die over next month
summary: President Joe Biden unveiled a national coronavirus plan, emphasizing the need for a coordinated federal response. He warned that the pandemic will claim an additional 100,000 lives in the US over the next month and that the crisis will worsen before it improves. Biden announced executive actions to bolster vaccine distribution, stabilize medical supply chains, and provide resources for schools and childcare centers. He also encouraged Americans to wear masks, citing them as the single best way to save lives. The administration acknowledges the need for congressional approval for additional spending to support the plan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks run out of steam after ECB; energy shares weigh
summary: European stocks ended flat, weighed down by energy and real estate shares, after the European Central Bank kept monetary policy unchanged. Energy majors BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Total fell 2% or more, while oil prices slipped after US crude inventories rose. The ECB warned of a risk to the euro zone's recovery due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. Despite a rally to near 11-month highs earlier, shares in the euro zone closed 0.1% lower, with the euro strengthening against the dollar.

site_title: Biden to order masks, traveller quarantines in Covid fight
summary: US President Joe Biden will issue an executive order requiring masks in airports and on planes, as well as enforcing quarantines for travelers arriving from other countries. This action is expected to codify a policy implemented by former President Donald Trump on January 12, which required a negative COVID-19 test before flying to the US. The order aims to increase travel safety during the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore office rents fall at slower clip of 3.5% q-o-q in Q4, vacancies ease
summary: Singapore office rents fell 3.5% in Q4 2020, a slower decline than the 4.5% drop in Q3. For the year, rents dropped 8.5% and prices decreased 10.7%. Vacancies eased to 11.8% at the end of Q4, up from 12% in the previous quarter. The supply of office space remained steady, with 770,000 sq m of space in the pipeline. Occupied space increased by 2,000 sq m, while the stock of office space decreased by 13,000 sq m.

site_title: Deal-making in a pandemic
summary: In 2020, deal-making in Southeast Asia's region, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, showed resilience despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Transaction values declined 17% in the region and 24% globally, but a total of 1,000 deals valued at US$84 billion occurred. The pandemic led to deal-completion delays, indeterminable valuations, and renegotiation or cancellation of deals. However, some sectors, such as technology and real estate, saw growth, and the region's transaction landscape is expected to be positively impacted by the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and improved global conditions.

site_title: Euro gains before ECB meeting, US dollar declines
summary: The euro rose 0.2% before the European Central Bank meeting, while the US dollar declined against major peers amid hopes for a US stimulus package. The US dollar index slipped 0.2% to 90.240, and the euro traded at US$1.2134. Analysts expect the US dollar to continue its downtrend, driven by loose US monetary policy and a post-pandemic global recovery. The ECB meeting is forecast to be "fairly uneventful," with no significant policy changes expected.

site_title: US dollar may continue fall, but impact on Singapore stocks unlikely to be major
summary: The US dollar is expected to continue its downward trend due to positive risk sentiment in markets, which may benefit Asian assets. However, analysts believe the impact on Singapore stocks with US exposure will be minimal, as USD-priced contracts are usually hedged. The weaker dollar also supports commodity prices and lifts sentiment. Despite this, Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, indicating a cautious optimism.

site_title: EU to ease customs delays on goods if UK sticks to Brexit rules
summary: The EU is considering easing customs delays on British goods if the UK adheres to the Brexit agreement's regulations. The current customs hold-ups have caused problems for hauliers, the fishing and meat industries, resulting in considerable wastage and price rises impacting UK inflation. To ease border friction, the EU is open to talks, but this would depend on the UK government sticking to the agreed-upon regulatory accord, which includes maintaining customs controls and paperwork.

site_title: Penguin chairman, MD tie up with Dymon Asia fund to take firm private
summary: Penguin International, a Singapore-based aluminium high-speed craft builder and operator, has agreed to be taken private by a consortium led by its executive chairman and managing director, with a takeover price of S$0.65 per share. The offer represents a 30% premium over the last traded price and is conditional on the consortium acquiring at least 50% of the company's shares. The deal is intended to provide shareholders with an exit opportunity and allow the company's management to focus on business operations.

site_title: Oceanus Group shares rise, then fall following SGX query on unusual trading activity
summary: Oceanus Group shares surged 8.2% to 5.3 Singapore cents after market opening, but fell to 4.7 cents by close, still the top traded share by volume. The company attributed the unusual trading activity to a stockbroking firm's internal report, highlighting its strong turnaround since 2014. Oceanus confirmed it is in compliance with mainboard listing rules and did not provide any other explanation for the trading activity.

site_title: STI regains 3,000 level as equity markets cheer Biden's swearing-in
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) breached the 3,000 mark, closing at 3,017.15 points, up 18.38 points or 0.61% following US President Joe Biden's swearing-in. Regional markets, including Japan, Australia, South Korea, and Hong Kong, also rose, while Singapore's Wilmar International and Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust were among the top performers. The decline in Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust was attributed to negative rental reversions of 6.6%.

site_title: Biden's message of unity may not change the minds of ardent Trumpists
summary: President Joe Biden's inaugural address emphasized unity and appealed to Americans' "better natures" in the face of division and crisis. Despite lacking a masterful oratory style, Biden's message was inspiring, particularly in contrast to his predecessor's divisive rhetoric. The new president urged Americans to reject misinformation and toxic politics, instead focusing on unity and civility. However, it remains to be seen whether his message will resonate with ardent Trump supporters, who continue to question the legitimacy of his presidency.

site_title: CICT's malls post negative 6.6% rent reversions in FY20; DPU falls 15.4% for Q4
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 6.6% decline in rental reversions for FY20, with distribution per unit (DPU) falling 15.4% in Q4 to 2.63 cents. CICT's manager, Tony Tan, attributes the decline to tactical rent reductions to retain tenants and improve mall traffic. Despite this, the Reit's office portfolio achieved positive rental reversions, and its strategy to help tenants ease cash flow problems is seen as a positive move.

site_title: Turning back time with Cartier Vintage
summary: Cartier has introduced its Cartier Vintage collection in Singapore, offering restored classic timepieces at its ION Orchard flagship boutique. The collection features six rare pieces from the 1970s to the 2010s, including the Square Incurvée, Pasha de Cartier Golf, and Tortue. Each watch is sourced by experts, authenticated, and undergoes a rigorous restoration process before being offered with an eight-year warranty and authenticity certificate. This marks Cartier's first timepiece offering in Singapore, joining London and Paris in showcasing its vintage collection.

site_title: Amanda Gorman makes history as she captures key moment in verse
summary: Poet Amanda Gorman made history by becoming the youngest inaugural poet in US history, reciting her poem "The Hill We Climb" at President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. Gorman, 22, struggled to finish the poem due to the Capitol riot on January 6, but persevered, incorporating themes of national unity, hope, and collective purpose. Her performance was a significant moment in a year marked by the pandemic and partisan division. Gorman's debut poetry collection, also titled "The Hill We Climb," is set to be released in September, and she has gained widespread recognition for her powerful words.

site_title: F&B sector has evolved over the course of 2020
summary: The Singapore food and beverage (F&B) sector experienced a significant downturn in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a year-on-year loss of nearly 30%. However, the sector has evolved, with digitalization playing a crucial role in its survival. The government's support through subsidies and grants, such as the Digital Resilience Bonus and Productivity Solutions Grant, drove digitalization among F&B SMEs. Despite the challenges, 1,132 new entrants joined the industry in 2020, and the younger generation has taken a smarter approach to the industry, embracing digitalization and social media.

site_title: No changes to ECB monetary policy as virus jitters grow
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its ultra-loose monetary policy, with no changes to its pandemic stimulus, amid growing concerns about new virus variants and slow vaccination drives. ECB President Christine Lagarde predicted a double-dip recession in the eurozone, citing a probable contraction in 2020 and a possible shrinkage in output this quarter. The ECB's measures, including a pandemic emergency bond-buying scheme, aim to keep borrowing costs low and encourage spending and investment.

site_title: After a billion-dollar year, Australia eyes even more tech IPOs
summary: Australia is poised for a significant increase in technology initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2021, driven by investor demand for tech companies. Last year, technology businesses accounted for 24% of Australia's A$5.4 billion in IPOs, the largest share in at least a decade. Tech companies have seen average stock price rises of 79% since their IPOs, outperforming other sectors. The shift is attributed to the growing demand for digital platforms and companies with sustainable growth prospects, making them more attractive to investors.

site_title: Frasers Property sets net-zero carbon goal
summary: Frasers Property, a Singapore-listed real estate company, has set a net-zero carbon goal, aiming to reach it by 2050. This commitment aligns with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's recommendations. By achieving this goal, Frasers Property will become the first Singapore-listed real estate company to do so, demonstrating its commitment to sustainability.

site_title: Nestle to up sustainability spending at Nescafe brand
summary: Nestle is boosting its sustainability spending at its Nescafe brand, investing over $1.04 billion in the next decade. The program aims to responsibly source all coffee, trace supplies back to farmer groups by 2025, and reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. This investment doubles Nestle's past 10-year sustainability spending and responds to growing consumer demand for transparency. The program includes improving farmer incomes, cutting carbon emissions, and moving to recyclable or reusable packaging, with a focus on deforestation and human rights standards.

site_title: Taking hawkers up the food chain
summary: Singapore's hawker culture is at risk of being lost as many famous hawkers become part of big businesses or chains. This has raised concerns about the preservation of the trade and its independence. The government and the community must work together to ensure that hawkers can continue to thrive and provide everyday comfort to Singaporeans.

site_title: Asean IPO proceeds triple in Q4 on bigger deals: EY report
summary: Asean's IPO proceeds tripled in Q4 2020, reaching US$3.3 billion, despite a steady number of listings, according to an EY report. The rise in proceeds was driven by larger deals in Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore. This signals a potential return of medium-cap IPOs in 2021, with Asean's full-year IPO activity declining 13% from 2019. In contrast, the Asia-Pacific region saw a 20% increase in IPO volume and 45% in proceeds, with Greater China exchanges leading the way.

site_title: IG buys Tastytrade as retail investors embrace derivatives
summary: IG Group Holdings Plc acquired online brokerage Tastytrade Inc for $1 billion, predicting a shift towards retail investors embracing derivatives. The deal includes $300 million in cash and 61 million IG shares, adding 105,000 active accounts to IG's platform. IG CEO June Felix sees this as a step towards retail traders taking control of their financial outcomes, with derivatives allowing for risk management in a "more holistic way." The acquisition aims to educate and serve more active, informed, and wealthier traders, with the average age of options traders being around 50.

site_title: Bank of Japan leaves interest rates unchanged amid gloomy outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its interest rates and asset buying policies unchanged amid a gloomy economic outlook due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The BOJ forecast a stronger economic rebound in the year starting April, driven by government stimulus and weaker growth at the end of the current fiscal year. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that while the outlook is uncertain, the bank is prepared to be more agile in its policy decisions. The decision was largely in line with market expectations and had little impact on markets, with stocks and the yen remaining relatively unchanged.

site_title: FedEx gears up to distribute Covid-19 vaccines regionally
summary: FedEx is gearing up to distribute Covid-19 vaccines regionally, leveraging its Life Sciences Express Hub in Singapore and other facilities worldwide. The logistics company has showcased its capabilities to keep vaccines at various temperature ranges, from 25°C to -150°C. FedEx joins other major logistics firms like UPS and DHL in supporting the taskforce formed by the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore and Changi Airport Group to ensure the logistical demands of vaccine distribution can be met.

site_title: Biden calls for unity to heal divided nation
summary: US President Joe Biden called for unity to heal a divided nation, vowing to restore American democracy after the Capitol riot. In his inauguration speech, he condemned anti-democratic forces and appealed to Americans to reject a culture of manipulated facts. Biden's determination to appeal to all persuasions was reflected in his Cabinet choices and inauguration performers. He addressed four intertwined crises, including the Covid-19 pandemic, economic hardship, climate change, and racial injustice. The new president acknowledged Kamala Harris as the first female vice-president and vowed to hold accountable those who stormed the Capitol.

site_title: Strapped developers eye New York City as next big target for gambling
summary: Real estate developers and gambling interests are reviving interest in a long-shelved proposal for a casino in New York City, driven by the state's need for new revenue sources. This push comes as the city's dense, tourist-rich sections of Manhattan are considered the holy grail of gambling in the US. The proposal has been met with support from key stakeholders, increasing its potential to move forward. The timing of this push is also significant, as it comes at a time when New York state is seeking new sources of revenue.

site_title: Biden signs 17 executive orders, memorandums and proclamations on his first day at work
summary: US President Joe Biden signed 17 executive orders, memorandums, and proclamations on his first day in office, aimed at reversing former President Donald Trump's policies on climate change, immigration, and the pandemic. The actions include rejoining the Paris climate accord, ending Trump's travel ban, and halting construction of the border wall. Biden also signed orders to bolster the economic recovery, promote diversity, and restore federal efforts on global health security and biodefense. The move was seen as a significant down payment on Biden's goal to "reverse the gravest damages" done to the country by Trump.

site_title: Lazada/Alibaba and TikTok figure in latest office-leasing deals
summary: E-commerce and tech players Lazada and Alibaba, along with TikTok, have signed significant office-leasing deals in Singapore. Lazada and Alibaba leased 140,000 sq ft at 5One Central, while TikTok took 58,000 sq ft at Guoco Tower. These deals come despite challenges to office leasing demand amid the recession and work-from-home trend. The monthly rental rate is expected to be around S$11 per square foot, and market observers believe the gross effective monthly rental rates for these spaces will be in the low-S$10 psf range.

site_title: Teams in evolution - and revolution
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for teams to adapt to constant changes, prompting a reevaluation of evolutionary and revolutionary changes. Teams were already shifting towards dynamic membership, fuzzy boundaries, and increased machine-human interaction before the pandemic. However, the pandemic's impact has amplified these changes, making sensemaking a crucial capability for teams to cope with the new landscape. By focusing on sensemaking, teams can create a cohesive framework that adapts to evolving circumstances and prepares for revolutionary changes, ensuring they remain relevant in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: FCT reports 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy for Q1 FY21
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy for Q1 FY21, with total tenants' sales stable near pre-pandemic levels. Shopper traffic is at 60-70% of pre-Covid-19 levels. FCT renewed nearly a quarter of expiring leases and extended its debt maturity to three years. The trust's gearing level was 37.7% and borrowing costs decreased to 2.2%. Despite challenging leasing environment, FCT's manager expects dominant suburban malls to remain resilient, driven by omni-channel retailing trends.

site_title: Business makes the case for a post-Trump reset
summary: A memo from a group of influential global leaders, including Tony Blair and former US officials, calls for a "reset" in US policy to address the country's growing inequality and lack of international cooperation. The document, written by JPMorgan Chase's private advisory committee, argues that engaging with other countries is not a sign of weakness but rather "America First" and advocates for a return to multilateral engagement. The group urges policymakers to prioritize global health, climate issues, and cooperation with China, and places responsibility on the business community to advocate for policies that benefit the public interest.

site_title: Frankfurt icon's tenant loss shows European office market risks
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Germany's largest airline, quietly moved 840 staff out of Frankfurt's iconic Squaire complex, highlighting the office market's risks. The move follows Europe's largest economy shrinking 5% last year, and economists warn of a potential downturn in the office market as more companies adopt home working. The Squaire, once valued at 643 million euros, now faces the challenge of finding a new tenant, with the airline's departure until May 2022.

site_title: ADDA doesn't add up
summary: A review of ADDA, a Neo-Indian restaurant in Singapore, found the dining experience to be marred by loud interiors and overwhelming food presentation. The restaurant's psychedelic decor and vibrant colors may be off-putting, and the food, while creative, can be overwhelming. Standout dishes include the butter chicken pot pie and chicken dum biryani, but the overall experience is inconsistent and could benefit from toning down its attention-getting atmosphere. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: China's monopoly rules threaten super-app model
summary: China's central bank has defined unhealthy dominance in specific market-share terms for financial super-apps, threatening the business models of Ant and Tencent. The People's Bank of China will scrutinize non-bank operators controlling over half the market or two or three companies dominating. This could limit Ant's Alipay and Tencent's Tenpay's ability to cross-sell financial services, potentially harming their profitability. The guidelines aim to regulate the integration of mobile payments and financial services, a move seen as a reasonable approach given the higher liquidity risk.

site_title: Lotus looks to Renault's Alpine for help on electric sports car
summary: LOTUS Cars, a UK-based automaker, is partnering with Renault's Alpine to develop a battery-powered sports car, marking the company's first collaboration outside of its Chinese owner Zhejiang Geely Holding Group. The partnership aims to accelerate delivery of an all-new architecture, saving costs and improving economies of scale. Lotus plans to market its first electric vehicle based on this platform by mid-decade, targeting modest price tags, and will consider licensing the platform to other manufacturers. This collaboration follows Geely's hands-off approach with Volvo, which has seen a resurgence under its ownership.

site_title: New year, new ventures
summary: A group of entrepreneurs in Singapore are making a fresh start in 2021 by changing careers or launching new businesses. Jenny Ang, managing director of Ecole hôtelière de Lausanne's Singapore campus, left her role at a music school to launch a hospitality school. Sean Low, 25, started a digital health clinic for men, Noah, after leaving an end-of-life tech startup. Kelvin Chan launched Furniche Plus, an online shop selling utilitarian-designed furniture and homewares. Gidania Wong, founder of SOVA, a boutique selling mulberry silk products, created the brand during the Circuit Breaker. Soukaina, Boutaina, and Amira Faruq started Rawbought, a sleepwear brand made from sustainable materials. Veronica Chau and Alvin Tan launched Emery & Co, a creative agency that also developed nail wraps. These entrepreneurs are taking advantage of the pandemic's accelerated adoption of telemedicine and e-commerce, and are seeking to create new opportunities in the market.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG GLB 35 review: On terror firma
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GLB 35 is a high-performance SUV that defies its practical design, boasting 306 horsepower and accelerating from 0-100km/h in just 5.2 seconds. Its tall center of gravity and height can make it unstable, but the wide Michelin tires help to mitigate this. Despite its sporty capabilities, the GLB 35 is a family-friendly vehicle with ample space for passengers and cargo. Its price of S$246,888 makes it a compelling value, especially considering its sportscar-like performance for its size and price.

site_title: Electric car maker BYD raises HK$30b in upsized sale
summary: Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer BYD Co raised HK$29.9 billion from an upsized sale of its Hong Kong-listed shares, capitalizing on rising demand for new-energy vehicles. The company agreed to sell 133 million shares at HK$225 each, representing a 7.8% discount to its closing price. BYD plans to use the funds to replenish working capital, repay debt, and invest in research and development. This is the largest primary share placement in Hong Kong since 2014, following a broader rally in EV maker stocks buoyed by strong investor expectations for industry growth.

site_title: DBS says Wilmar deserves higher valuation than peers in palm-oil plays
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price for Wilmar International to S$6.67, maintaining its "buy" call on the agribusiness group. The research house believes Wilmar deserves a higher valuation multiple than its crude palm oil plantation peers due to its well-established brand, distribution channels, and supply chain system. DBS expects Wilmar to benefit from strong food demand and raise its FY2021 earnings forecast to US$1.48 billion. The company's shares closed at S$5.47, up 2.4% on the day.

site_title: London's poshest homes are sitting empty
summary: London's luxury housing market is experiencing a prolonged period of vacancy, with homes in poshest areas sitting empty for over two months before finding tenants. Despite a 75% surge in luxury rentals, rents have plummeted 14% annually, and landlords are forced to slash prices. The pandemic's impact on office workers and global visitors has led to a decrease in demand, with wealthy tenants opting to live further afield. The market is expected to remain stagnant until restrictions are lifted, with landlords facing a potentially long winter of lower rents.

site_title: Thai regulator approves AstraZenca vaccine for emergency use
summary: Thailand's Food and Drug Administration has approved the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine for emergency use, allowing the country to import 200,000 doses. The first 50,000 doses are expected to arrive next month, and the approval is valid for a period of one year. This move comes as Thailand seeks to combat the spread of the virus, with the health minister announcing plans to distribute the vaccine nationwide.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency use approval for the Covid-19 vaccine of AstraZeneca, three health ministry sources said on Thursday.

site_title: GL has deeper value than just 70¢ a share: analysts
summary: Singaporean tycoon Quek Leng Chan is attempting to take GL Limited private at a discounted price, sparking concerns among analysts that shareholders may be getting a better deal. Based on a 30% discount to estimated fair value, analysts value GL at at least S$1.16 per share, citing the "highly undervalued" 18 hotel assets. The offer price of S$0.70 per share is already above the current market price, and analysts warn that shareholders should hold out for a better offer, given the potential for hotel and oil prices to rise.

site_title: Up close and personal with art
summary: Singapore Art Week begins on January 22, 2021, featuring notable works by local artists. Jo Ho and WY Huang's "Re(rooting)" at National Gallery Singapore uses projection mapping to recreate fragmented memories of Singapore. Guo-Liang Tan's installation, "Arrive, Arrive," features delicate, translucent paintings suspended from the ceiling. Reza Hasni's augmented-reality environments at Blk 22, Gillman Barracks, offer trippy, fantastical experiences. The week also includes video works by Ho Tzu Nyen and Ian Tee, addressing regional history and social issues.

site_title: Ant Group 'could be worth below 700b yuan' on crackdown
summary: China's draft proposals to curb market concentration in its online payments market may slash Ant Group's valuation by half, potentially reducing its Alipay service's value to 300 billion yuan (S$143 billion). Senior analyst Francis Chan estimates this could bring the company's value below 700 billion yuan, a significant drop from its previous valuation of 1.44 trillion yuan. The measures could also force Ant to break up its payment unit, further reducing its value. This could impact Ant Group's ability to relaunch its IPO this year.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said that any non-bank payment company with half the market share for online transactions, or two entities with combined two-thirds share could be subject to antitrust probes.

site_title: China's New Year travel slump likely to slow consumer spending recovery
summary: China is expected to experience a travel slump during the Chinese New Year period due to new COVID curbs, resulting in a 40% decline in travel compared to 2019. Despite this, 1.7 billion trips are still anticipated, a 10% increase from 2020. This downturn threatens China's consumer spending recovery, as hundreds of millions of people typically travel during this seven-day holiday to see family and spend in shops and restaurants.

site_title: Missing the Singapore Motorshow? These could be the next best thing
summary: German car brands Audi and BMW are hosting mini-motorshows in Singapore to showcase new cars and kickstart sales after the Singapore Motorshow was cancelled due to COVID-19. Audi is launching new battery-powered crossover cars at its e-tron Hub, while BMW is showcasing the 530e plug-in hybrid electric sedan and other models. The events aim to drum up interest in electric mobility in Singapore, which has seen new tax rebates for EVs and an expanding charging network. Both brands are hoping to maintain their sales momentum and lead over rival Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 task force mulls new measures ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 task force is considering new measures ahead of the Chinese New Year due to a new cluster forming for the first time in months. Lawrence Wong, co-chair, warned that the pandemic may not be over by next year, despite Singapore having enough vaccines for its population by Q3. Vaccination efforts are underway, but concerns about vaccine safety remain. The task force is weighing the risks of additional restrictions, echoing concerns about the next pandemic. Both co-chairs emphasized the need for continuous monitoring and adjustments to measures, citing past experiences with H1N1 and SARS.

site_title: Sick of working from home? Dread daily commute? Go hybrid, says office provider
summary: IWG, an office-space provider, is betting on a permanent shift to hybrid working, where employees split time between home and office. The company aims to offer its facilities to more firms looking to reduce their reliance on their own properties. This move is seen as a response to the growing fatigue with working from home and the desire to return to office environments. By providing a mix-and-match solution, IWG hopes to capitalize on the trend and provide companies with a flexible and cost-effective alternative to traditional office space.

images.alt_text: Hybrid working patterns will be a large part of the future of real estate, IWG CEO Mark Dixon says.

site_title: AirAsia Group to raise up to US$113m via private placement
summary: AirAsia Group plans to raise up to US$113 million through a private placement to address immediate cash flow requirements. The airline, which reported a fifth straight quarterly loss, will issue up to 20% of its shares to investors. The funds will be used for fuel hedging, aircraft lease payments, and technology development. Although the placement will enhance the group's financial position, it may not fully address long-term cash flow concerns. AirAsia will continue to explore other fundraising options to improve its financial performance.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 cases in BS Industrial Construction & Supply cluster
summary: Three new Covid-19 cases have been linked to the BS Industrial Construction & Supply cluster in Singapore, bringing the total cluster cases to seven. The cases include a salesperson, a sales employee, and a permanent resident who works as a diver. The cluster's cases have increased significantly, with 21 community cases reported in the past seven days, and six unlinked cases detected. Singapore's total Covid-19 cases now stand at 59,235, with 43 patients discharged and 204 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Indonesia to improve credibility of Jakarta interbank dollar rate
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, plans to widen the observation period for its Jakarta Interbank Spot Dollar Rate (Jisdor) from 8 am-9.45 am to 8 am-4 pm, starting April 5, to increase the credibility of the domestic foreign exchange market and promote exchange rate stability. The move aims to better reflect day-to-day transactions and improve the reference for foreign exchange rates. The change is expected to help stabilize the Indonesian rupiah, which has been vulnerable to volatility in recent months.

site_title: Mercedes expects big things from the EQA, its compact electric car
summary: Mercedes-EQ is launching its first battery-powered car, the EQA, a compact electric crossover, as the first of four electric vehicles this year. The EQA is expected to cost around S$200,000 in Singapore, with a range of over 400km on a single charge. The company aims to nearly double its plug-in and full electric car production to 13% this year. Mercedes-EQ plans to launch the EQB, EQS, and EQE, with the EQC SUV to follow in the second quarter. The company is seeing high interest in small electric cars, with every tenth Mercedes sold being a GLA or GLB, which will be electric versions.

site_title: KLM to cut 1,000 more jobs, says mandatory Covid-19 testing will ground planes
summary: KLM to cut 1,000 more jobs in 2021 due to government plans to require mandatory Covid-19 testing for all passengers and crew before flying to the Netherlands. The rule, proposed by the Dutch government, would force KLM to ground its long-haul flights and halt freight-only flights from Asia, threatening the Netherlands' global connectivity and aviation sector employment. KLM joins other airlines in criticizing the measure, with support from the International Aviation and Transport Association.

site_title: Britain's IG to buy tastytrade for US$1b in US foray
summary: Britain's IG Group is set to acquire US trading platform tastytrade for $1 billion, its largest deal to date. The acquisition, part of IG's diversification strategy, aims to fuel its expansion into North America. IG shares fell 2.3% following the announcement, but the company expects the deal to be low single-digit accretive to its adjusted earnings per share in the first full year after closing. This move comes as the US financial sector awaits potential regulatory changes under President Joe Biden's administration.

site_title: Daiso is latest household brand to go online
summary: Daiso, a Japanese discount store, launched its Singapore website on January 18, offering 393 items in 25 categories, including cleaning supplies and personal care. The online store requires a minimum purchase of five items and has a $5 delivery charge. While some items have sold out, customers can track sales online and offline to ensure accurate stock availability. The move comes as other brands, such as Popular and Muji, have also transitioned to e-commerce platforms.

site_title: Jobless claim data underscores employment crisis awaiting Biden
summary: US jobless claims surged to 900,000 last week, exceeding the single worst week of the 2008-2010 global financial crisis. The unemployment rate remains at 6.7% as the Covid-19 pandemic continues to impact the economy. New filings under the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance programme nearly doubled, and nearly 16 million people received some form of government aid. Economists expect the situation to worsen until the pandemic is curbed, with President Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion spending measure aimed at revitalizing the economy and improving vaccine rollout.

site_title: Biden's swearing-in lifts regional indexes; STI breaches 3,000-mark
summary: US President Joe Biden's swearing-in lifted global equity markets, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) breaching the 3,000-mark, closing at 3,017.15 points. The STI saw a 0.61% gain, with Oceanus Group's shares experiencing a 4.08% drop after a brief surge. The market gains were largely driven by Biden's swearing-in, which has boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: US: Stocks flat following mixed economic data
summary: US stocks remained flat early Thursday, following mixed economic data, after reaching all-time highs the previous day on optimism over the US presidential transition. The housing market showed strength in December, while new jobless claims remained high. Analysts expressed skepticism about the passage of President Biden's $1.9 trillion fiscal package, citing congressional skepticism. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 remained unchanged, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1%.

site_title: Bitcoin losses gather pace, with prices nearing three-week low
summary: Bitcoin prices dropped 8.3% to near a three-week low, closing below US$33,000. The cryptocurrency's rally has slowed due to concerns that prices are too high, prompting professional investors to be cautious. Despite this, some analysts predict a retracement to US$30,000, while others believe a sharp move higher could push prices above US$50,000. This decline comes as Wall Street shows interest in Bitcoin, with BlackRock filing paperwork to add Bitcoin futures as an eligible investment in two funds.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 task force is considering new restrictions ahead of Chinese New Year. Headline inflation expectations rose to 2.2% in December's poll. Penguin International is taking the company private at S$0.65 per share. REX International's subsidiary obtained four offshore licences in Norway, including one with discovery. Cromwell E-Reit priced 200m euro notes at 2.125%. A Kimly unit entered into a joint venture to run a coffeeshop at Hougang. CICT's malls posted a rental reversion of negative 6.6% in FY20.

site_title: Ant's Malaysian e-wallet venture with CIMB in talks to raise US$150m
summary: Malaysian e-wallet operator TNG Digital, owned by CIMB Group and China's Ant Group, is in talks to raise at least US$150 million to fund expansion plans. The venture, which operates the country's largest e-wallet, Touch 'n Go, with over 15 million registered users, is seeking global banks and asset managers as investors. The fundraising is expected to give TNG Digital a valuation of over US$700 million, with CIMB and Ant Group paring their stakes but remaining the biggest investors. The move aims to step up TNG Digital's presence in financial services and capitalize on market growth.

site_title: 38 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including four in the community
summary: There were 38 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, bringing the total to 59,195. The cases included 34 imported cases and four community cases, with no cases from worker's dormitories. The Ministry of Health reported this update as of noon on January 21, 2021.

site_title: Union Gas unit subscribes for convertible bonds in data handling services provider
summary: Union Gas Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary U-Global has subscribed for S$1 million of convertible bonds with data handling services provider Adera AI, representing a 10% annual internal rate of return. The investment is seen as a positive for the group, which provides electronic solutions through e-invoicing and related services. The bonds will be redeemed at their principal amount, and if Adera AI lists on a stock exchange, they will be converted into shares at a 20% discount. The subscription is expected to have a minimal impact on Union Gas' financials.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.74 points lower on Thursday at 1,594.80, with a trading volume of 6.718 billion lots worth RM 4.285 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 812 to 347, marking a lower market day.

site_title: Biden's Keystone 'insult' sees Alberta leader urging retaliation
summary: Alberta Premier Jason Kenney called US President Joe Biden's decision to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline project an "insult" to the Canadian economy. Kenney urged Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to consider retaliation, suggesting punitive measures against the US. The pipeline's cancellation will cost over 2,000 jobs and is seen as a significant blow to Alberta's oil sands producers. Kenney has prepared to seek compensation through the courts if the decision is not reversed.

site_title: ISOTeam announces contract wins worth S$20.8m
summary: BUILDING maintenance company ISOTeam announced S$20.84 million in contract wins, bringing total project value for the financial year to S$63.10 million. The projects, expected to be completed by February 2024, include interior design, mechanical and electrical, and coating and painting projects. CEO Anthony Koh expressed optimism about securing new business, citing the company's multi-disciplinary capabilities and long-standing customer relationships as key differentiators.

site_title: Kimly unit enters into joint venture to run coffeeshop at Hougang
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop consolidator, has entered into a joint venture to run a coffeeshop at Hougang with private company Jin Xin Yuan. Kimly will pay S$735,000 for a 49% stake in the JV, including a lease assignment fee. The joint venture aims to diversify Kimly's revenue streams and expand its presence in the market. The company plans to open more food stalls and explore opportunities to acquire and operate coffee shops in mature estates.

site_title: ECB sits tight as virus jitters grow
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governors held steady on pandemic stimulus, maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy despite growing concerns over new virus variants and slow vaccination drives. The ECB's pandemic emergency bond-buying scheme remains in place, with a total envelope of 1.85 trillion euros, and no changes were made to interest rates or loan amounts. The decision aims to keep borrowing costs low, encouraging spending and investment in the eurozone, but clouds of uncertainty gather as countries struggle to control outbreaks and vaccination drives lag behind forecasts.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reports 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy in Q1 FY21
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 96.4% retail portfolio occupancy in Q1 FY21, with total tenants' sales stable near pre-pandemic levels. Shopper traffic is at 60-70% of pre-Covid-19 levels due to safe-distancing measures. The trust renewed nearly a quarter of expiring leases and extended its debt maturity to three years. FCT's gearing level was 37.7% at end-December, and it reduced the cost of borrowing from 2.4% to 2.2%. The trust expects dominant suburban malls to remain resilient, driven by omni-channel retailing trends.

site_title: CDL expects 'material impairment loss' on investment in Sincere Property
summary: CDL expects to make provisions for a material impairment loss on its 51-per-cent joint venture investment in Sincere Property due to ongoing challenges in China's real estate market. The review by Deloitte suggests the investment may not be recoverable, but the final quantum of impairment cannot be determined yet as the situation remains fluid. CDL has not provided further liquidity support to Sincere Property since Dec 31, 2020, and has ring-fenced its current financial exposure to the investment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly lower on Thursday, ending a five-day gain streak. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.12% to 29,927.76, its first drop above 30,000 since April 2019. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.53%. This follows a 20-month high for the Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Nissan to close Philippines car assembly operations
summary: Nissan Motor will close its car assembly operations in the Philippines, affecting the Almera model and 133 workers. The move is part of Nissan's plan to optimize production and business operations in South-east Asia. The closure will have a significant impact on the local automotive industry and workers.

site_title: Frasers Property first SGX-listed property firm to commit to net-zero carbon by 2050
summary: Frasers Property, the first Singapore-listed real estate firm, has committed to achieving net-zero carbon by 2050, aligning with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change recommendations. The company has outlined five new sustainability goals, including carbon neutrality, climate resilience, and green financing, and aims to train all employees on sustainability by 2021. By 2022, it will develop net-zero carbon roadmaps and implement strategies to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend gains on Biden bounce
summary: European stock markets rose, extending gains from the previous day, as US President Joe Biden took office. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index advanced 0.7%, and the Paris CAC 40 added 0.7%. Asian markets also made gains ahead of President Biden's plans to unveil coronavirus crisis measures and a $1.9 trillion US relief package. Analysts attributed the optimism to investors' backing of the stimulus plans, with the European Central Bank set to review its monetary stimulus efforts later.

site_title: Bank of Japan leaves interest rates unchanged amid gloomy outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its main policy unchanged, despite a gloomy economic outlook due to the ongoing state of emergency. The central bank predicted a stronger rebound in the economy, driven by weaker growth at the end of the current fiscal year and a government stimulus package. All 44 economists surveyed by Bloomberg predicted no change in the bank's main policy levers ahead of a policy review in March. The BOJ forecast the economy will regain more lost growth than previously thought once it starts to recover.

site_title: Frasers Property unit to sell entire stake in China property
summary: Frasers Property's subsidiary Excellent Esteem is selling its entire stake in Beijing Fraser Suites Real Estate Management for 1.6 billion yuan (S$327.5 million). The sale, in the ordinary course of business, is expected to increase net tangible assets per share to S$2.37 and earnings per share to 6.19 Singapore cents. The transaction, concluded after arm's length negotiations, marks a strategic move by the company. Shares of Frasers Property ended at S$1.28, up 0.8% following the announcement.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend gains on strong export data, Wall St boost
summary: South Korean shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by strong export data and a boost from Wall Street's record close. The Kospi index closed up 1.49% at 3,160.84, following a 0.7% gain in the previous session. Exports expanded at a faster pace in January, driven by demand for chips, cars, and mobile devices. Foreigners were net buyers of $203.45 million worth of shares on the main board, while major heavyweights like Naver, Kakao, and Samsung Electronics also saw gains.

site_title: Penguin chairman, MD in tie up with Dymon Asia fund to take firm private
summary: Penguin International, a Singapore-based aluminium high-speed craft builder, agreed to be taken private by a consortium led by its chairman and managing director at S$0.65 per share, a 30% premium over the last traded price. The offeror, Emet Grace, is backed by a US$450 million fund managed by Dymon Asia Private Equity. If successful, Penguin will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Emet Grace and be delisted from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard, allowing for increased management flexibility and cost savings.

site_title: Australia: Shares open higher as Biden inauguration boosts sentiment
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,770.4 points, driven by gains in technology and gold stocks, following the swearing in of US President Joe Biden. Tech stocks soared 2.5%, while gold stocks rose 1.5% as investors bet on further US stimulus. Financials also advanced, with the "big four" banks rising between 0.4% and 1.9%. Energy stocks declined, with Woodside Petroleum and Worley falling 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes at 30-year high as Biden inauguration sparks optimism
summary: Japanese shares hit a 30-year high on investor optimism over US President Joe Biden's massive stimulus package, boosting growth expectations. The Nikkei share average gained 0.82% to 28,756.86, while the Topix inched up 0.6% to 1,860.64. Companies benefiting from a recovery in the Chinese economy are expected to revise up their earnings forecasts. The US stimulus plan is seen as a positive factor, despite some opposition from Republicans. Asian stocks reached all-time highs as investors await more economic stimulus from the Biden administration.

site_title: Oceanus Group responds to SGX query on unusual trading activity
summary: Oceanus Group's shares surged 8.2% to a record high of 5.3 Singapore cents after opening, but fell to 4.7 Singapore cents at close, a 4.1% decline from the previous day. The unusual trading activity prompted queries from the Singapore Exchange, with the company stating it is unaware of any information explaining the surge.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit Q4 DPU up 29.1% to 1.194 Singapore cent
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 29.1% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.194 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from its Australia portfolio. Distributions rose 30.2% to S$15.2 million, and gross revenue increased 5.4% to S$24.1 million. However, the Reit's net property income climbed only 10.1% due to lower contributions from some properties. The Reit's net asset value (NAV) per unit decreased to S$0.55, and portfolio occupancy remained stable at 94.3%.

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus shares surge 8.2%, prompting SGX query
summary: Oceanus Group shares surged 8.2% to a record high of 5.3 Singapore cents, prompting the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to issue a query on the "unusual price and volume movements". The company's shares changed hands for 343.8 million shares worth S$17.9 million, making it the top traded share by volume. The SGX asked Oceanus Group if it was aware of any explanation for the trading activity and if it was compliant with mainboard listing rules. This is the company's first query by SGX this year.

site_title: Chinese monopoly rules threaten super-app model
summary: China's central bank has outlined guidelines defining unhealthy dominance in digital payments, threatening the business models of super-apps like Ant and Tencent. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will scrutinize non-bank operators with over 50% market share or two companies with a combined 67% share. The rules aim to separate digital payments from interest-bearing accounts and regulate cross-selling of financial services. This move complicates the super-app model, where users pay for items directly from interest-yielding accounts, and could lead to regulatory action against Ant and Tencent.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Wilmar deserves a higher valuation multiple than CPO peers
summary: DBS Group Research maintained its "buy" call on Wilmar International, raising its target price to S$6.67 from S$5.28. The research house attributes Wilmar's potential for exceeding expectations in the fourth quarter of 2020 to its successful brand, investment in distribution channels and production facilities, and steady profit performance. This move follows the group's decade-long focus on delivering consistent results.

site_title: Asean IPO proceeds treble in Q4 2020 on larger deals: EY
summary: Asean's IPO proceeds trebled in Q4 2020 to $3.3 billion, driven by larger deals, despite steady numbers of listings. The region saw 34 IPOs, with Thailand's exchanges being the most active, raising $1.9 billion. This signals a potential return of medium-cap IPOs in 2021, contrary to the previous year's trend. The full-year Asean IPO activity declined 13% to 111 listings, raising $7.7 billion.

site_title: Man over Machine: Recognising the human value of digitalisation in SMEs
summary: A recent survey by Employment Hero found that 24% of entry-level employees in Singapore feel unsure or unprepared for digital changes in their organisations. Research by Boston Consulting Group shows that only 30% of organisations meet their target value and experience sustainable change after digital transformation. To achieve successful digital transformation, SMEs must integrate people, processes, and technology together, focusing on empathy, autonomy, and meaningful relationships. Leaders should adopt a relationship-oriented approach, listening to employees' concerns and providing support. Building a strong culture and enforcing communication are also crucial, and SMEs should upskill current employees to stay competitive.

site_title: BlackRock to add bitcoin as eligible investment to two funds
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to add bitcoin futures as an eligible investment to two funds, the BlackRock Strategic Income Opportunities and BlackRock Global Allocation Fund Inc. The funds will invest in cash-settled bitcoin futures traded on commodity exchanges registered with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. This move follows CEO Larry Fink's statement that bitcoin could evolve into a global market, and comes amid a record high of US$40,000 for the cryptocurrency. The decision allows BlackRock clients to invest in bitcoin derivatives.

site_title: Rescuers scramble to free Chinese miners trapped underground
summary: Chinese rescuers are drilling deep into the ground to save 21 miners trapped underground for almost two weeks. One miner has been confirmed dead, and contact has been established with a group of 11 miners, but 10 others remain uncontacted. Rescuers have drilled "lifeline" channels to deliver food and medicine and installed a telephone line to try to locate the missing miners. The rescue efforts have been slow due to drilling through granite and the water-logged state of the mine, with plans to broaden a shaft to extract the miners once drilling is finished.

site_title: President Halimah and PM Lee congratulate US President Biden on his inauguration
summary: President Halimah Yacob and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore sent congratulatory letters to US President Joe Biden on his inauguration, wishing him success as he assumes office. The letters highlighted the strong bilateral relationship between Singapore and the US, spanning defence, security, economics, and people-to-people ties. Both leaders expressed their commitment to strengthening ties and cooperation in various areas, including digital trade and infrastructure development, and looked forward to meeting again in Singapore or Washington.

site_title: Asia: Stocks see healthy gains with Biden presidency
summary: Asian markets experienced significant gains on Joe Biden's first day as US president, driven by optimism over his economic and Covid recovery plans. Biden signed executive orders rejoining the World Health Organization and re-entering the Paris climate accord, as well as extending a mortgage foreclosure moratorium and student debt repayments. The new administration's $1.9 trillion relief package has investors hopeful for growth, despite concerns about higher taxes and market regulation. All three major US indexes reached record highs, with Asian markets also rising, driven by expectations of stimulus and Covid vaccinations.

site_title: Singaporeans expect headline inflation to rise to 2.2% for year ahead: poll
summary: Singaporeans expect headline inflation to rise to 2.2% for the year ahead, according to a poll of 500 individuals that represent a cross-section of Singaporean households. This is slightly higher than the 1.9% in September and lower than the Q4 average of 3.2% from 2012-2019. The survey attributed the increase in inflation expectations to a sense of normalisation and global cues of recovery, including the advent of vaccines and the signing of the Brexit deal.

site_title: Chinese telecom firms seek review of NYSE delisting decision
summary: Chinese telecom firms China Unicom Hong Kong, China Mobile, and China Telecom Corp have requested a review of the New York Stock Exchange's decision to delist their American depositary shares. The NYSE delisted the companies in January 2021 following an executive order by former US President Donald Trump, which barred Americans from investing in companies deemed linked to the Chinese military. The companies seek to maintain trading suspension pending the review, which is expected to be finalized within 25 days.

site_title: 'No evidence of decline' in Covid-19 rates in England's third lockdown
summary: A third pandemic lockdown in England appears to have little impact on COVID-19 rates, with prevalence rates remaining "very high" and showing no decline. Researchers warn that health services will remain under extreme pressure and deaths will continue to rise rapidly unless rates are reduced substantially. The number of in-patients in hospital is extremely high, and the lockdown's effectiveness is being questioned, with experts attributing the stubborn levels of infection to a more transmissible variant of the virus.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 11-month high as jobs data fans optimism
summary: Australian shares ended at an 11-month high on Thursday, rising 0.8% to 6,823.7, driven by strong employment data and optimistic investor sentiment. The unemployment rate fell to 6.6% in December, supporting economic recovery. Tech stocks rose 2.7% to record highs, while brokerages increased price targets, citing earnings strength and a bounce back in economic growth. This optimism has also boosted investor appetite, with New Zealand's benchmark index rising 0.7%.

site_title: ECB meets as virus woes weigh on eurozone
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) meets on Thursday to assess its monetary stimulus efforts amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Despite a recent surge in the euro against the dollar, policymakers are unlikely to take fresh action, instead focusing on maintaining the current stimulus package. The ECB's chief Christine Lagarde will be scrutinized for hints of concern about the virus resurgence and the eurozone's economic outlook, which is expected to be influenced by vaccination drives, lockdowns, and fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the opening of Thursday, marking a breather after a five-day rally that reached a 20-month high. The Hang Seng Index decreased 10.69 points to 29,951.78. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains. The market is closely watching the US presidential transition, particularly with Joe Biden's inauguration, and potential trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday as Biden takes office; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday as US President Joe Biden took office, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.2% to 3,003.52. Gainers outnumbered losers 114 to 24, with Ascendas Reit, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and Rex International advancing. On Wall Street, all three major indices ended at record highs, with the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2% amid promises of big economic stimulus.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit prices 200m euro notes due in 2025 at 2.125%
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has priced a 200 million euro note issue due 2025 at a coupon rate of 2.125% and a reoffer yield of 1.6%. The notes will be issued under a recently established 1.5 billion euro medium-term note programme, primarily used for refinancing existing debt and general working capital. The issue is expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on January 27, 2021, and will be rated BBB- by Fitch Ratings Singapore.

site_title: Biden to roll back Trump policies, remake US role in climate crisis
summary: President Joe Biden signed executive orders to rejoin the Paris climate accord, block an oil pipeline project, and freeze Arctic drilling, marking the start of his environmental efforts. The US aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 45-50% by 2030 and has pledged $2 trillion for a climate plan, with a focus on green action and economic recovery. Biden also plans to convene a climate summit with major economies and has scrapped the Keystone XL pipeline, despite potential strain on relations with Canada.

site_title: Taiwan-Biden ties off to strong start with invite for top diplomat
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration has strengthened ties with Taiwan, with the island's de facto ambassador attending his inauguration. This move, seen as a significant gesture of support, comes after the Trump administration increased arms sales and engagement with Taiwan, angering China. The US commitment to Taiwan is described as "rock-solid" by the White House, and Taiwan's Foreign Ministry praises the attendance of Hsiao Bi-khim at the inauguration. The two sides have expressed a desire to maintain regional democracy, freedom, peace, and stability.

site_title: Biden's inauguration a restoration of American democracy
summary: US President Joe Biden has inaugurated, vowing to restore American democracy after the January 6 Capitol riot. He emphasized unity and appealed to both Republicans and Democrats to reject a culture of manipulated facts. Biden's Cabinet choices, including the first female vice-president Kamala Harris, reflect his commitment to addressing racial injustice and the pandemic. He has issued executive orders addressing four intertwined crises, including the pandemic, economic hardship, climate change, and racial injustice. Biden's appeal to unity was seen as effective for most liberals and moderates, but may not have resonated with Trump's loyal supporters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, SIAEC, GK Goh, SIIC Environment, GHY Culture & Media
summary: Several companies experienced new developments affecting trading on Thursday.
