CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) announced a Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.63 Singapore cents, while SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) commenced phase two of its transformation program and showcased new digital tools. SIAEC's CEO noted the company now handles about 20% of pre-Covid-19 flight levels. No specific impact on market trends was mentioned for the other listed companies.

site_title: Biden set to rejoin Paris climate accord, impose curbs on US oil industry
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to rejoin the Paris climate accord and impose curbs on the US oil industry, marking a significant policy reversal after four years of rolling back environmental regulations. Biden aims to put the US on a track to net-zero emissions by 2050, using curbs on fossil fuels and massive investments in clean energy. The move is seen as a major step forward in global efforts to combat climate change, but faces opposition from domestic and international stakeholders.

site_title: Biden says Trump wrote him 'very generous letter'
summary: President Joe Biden stated that outgoing President Donald Trump had left him a "very generous" letter in the Oval Office, following tradition. The letter's contents remain private until Biden speaks with Trump. This marks a departure from Trump's decision to skip Biden's inauguration and never formally congratulate him on his election win.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending US rallies, driven by hopes of new stimulus following President Joe Biden's office. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.86% to 28,769.39, while the Topix index advanced 0.68% to 1,862.15. Traders await the Bank of Japan's policy decision.

site_title: Bank of Japan lifts next year's growth forecast, saves ammunition as virus risks linger
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, while revising up its economic forecast for next fiscal year to 3.9% growth, citing hopes for the government's spending package to cushion the pandemic's impact. However, it warned of escalating risks to the economic outlook due to new state of emergency measures. The central bank maintained its yield curve control targets, but hinted at potential changes to its stimulus measures in the coming months.

images.alt_text: he Bank of Japan kept monetary policy steady on Thursday and revised up its economic forecast for next fiscal year, signalling that it has delivered sufficient stimulus for now to cushion the blow from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.85 points, or 0.55%, to 1,610.39 on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume was 742.49 million lots worth RM417.29 million. Gainers outpaced losers 404 to 231.

site_title: Rex unit obtains four offshore licences in Norway, including one with discovery
summary: REX International's subsidiary Lime Petroleum has obtained participating interests in four new offshore licences in Norway, including one with a gas discovery. Lime holds 20% interests in PL263F Apollonia, PL1111 Kings Canyon, and PL1125 Falk/Linerle, with potential for commercial field development. The new licences bring Lime's portfolio to 13 licences, including three discoveries, with the potential to unlock more value as contingent resources are added.

site_title: 'Going home': Biden's surreal walk to the White House
summary: US President Joe Biden walked to the White House hand-in-hand with his wife Jill, surrounded by a surreal security lockdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic, after a swearing-in ceremony and visit to Arlington National Cemetery. The inauguration was marked by a massive security presence, with 25,000 National Guard troops and thousands of masked security forces, compared to the usual 200,000 spectators. Biden joked that it felt like he was "going home," as he made his way to the White House with Vice-President Kamala Harris and her family.

site_title: Digital securities platform iSTOX raises US$50m in Series A round
summary: iSTOX, a Singapore fintech backed by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), has raised US$50 million in Series A funding. New investors include the Japan Investment Corporation and the Development Bank of Japan, along with existing backers such as SGX, Japan's Tokai Tokyo Financial Holdings, and Korea's Hanwha Asset Management. The platform aims to allow accredited investors to access private markets and alternative assets through digital securities, and plans to expand its investment offerings and geographical footprint with the new funds.

site_title: Amazon offers to help with Covid-19 vaccine effort
summary: Amazon has offered to help the Biden administration with its 100 million vaccine goal within the next 100 days by putting its vast resources to work. The company, the second-largest US employer, has seen a surge in online shopping during the pandemic and has agreements in place to administer vaccines on-site at its facilities. Amazon CEO Dave Clark sent a letter to President Biden urging his employees to get vaccinated and expressing the company's commitment to assisting the vaccination effort. Uber has also offered logistical assistance.

site_title: WHO plans slew of Covid-19 vaccine approvals for global rollout
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) plans to approve several Covid-19 vaccines from Western and Chinese manufacturers in coming weeks and months, aiming for rapid rollouts in poorer countries. The WHO plans to deliver at least 2 billion doses globally this year, with 1.3 billion going to poorer countries. Vaccines from AstraZeneca, Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson are expected to receive WHO approval in January, February, and May or June, respectively. The WHO is also considering possible quick approvals for two Chinese vaccines, Sinopharm and Sinovac, and Russia's Sputnik V vaccine.

site_title: Oil rises on US stimulus hopes, tighter market under Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is expected to deliver pandemic-related economic stimulus, lifting fuel demand and tightening crude supply. Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude settling at US$56.08 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settling at US$53.24 a barrel. The administration's plans to curb the US oil industry, including re-entering the Paris climate accord and pausing drilling in the Arctic, are also expected to boost prices. Analysts predict higher prices due to the administration's pro-green energy policies.

site_title: Bank of England's Bailey expects 'pronounced recovery' for economy
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey expects a pronounced recovery in Britain's economy as the country vaccinates its population against Covid-19. The economy shrank by the most among industrial powerhouses in the first half of 2020, but vaccination efforts have raised hopes for a recovery. Bailey also downplayed expectations of swift interest rate cuts, citing unclear effectiveness of negative rates. Most economists expect the BoE to keep rates steady at 0.1% until 2024, with a big impact expected in the first quarter due to the current lockdown.

site_title: CICT's malls post rental reversion of negative 6.6% in FY20
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a negative 6.6% rental reversion in FY20, with its CEO Tony Tan expressing hopes that this is the bottom for the Reit. Despite this, the Reit maintained an "uplifting" environment in its malls by minimising hoarding and vacancies. The Reit's office portfolio achieved positive rental reversions, while its retail portfolio struggled. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 15.4% to 2.63 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, with gross revenue and net property income growing 36% and 36.4% year-over-year, respectively.

images.alt_text: CAPITALAND Integrated Commercial Trust on Thursday posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.63 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, down 15.4 per cent from 3.11 cents a year ago.

site_title: HSBC, Maybank venture among bidders for AXA Singapore
summary: HSBC Holdings and Malayan Banking's insurance venture, along with Etiqa, have advanced to the next round of bidding for AXA's Singapore business, which could generate approximately $700 million in revenue. The sale comes as AXA seeks to divest smaller operations, including its Middle Eastern business, to raise funds for its recent $15.3 billion purchase of XL Group. HSBC aims to accelerate its Asian expansion, while Etiqa seeks opportunities for growth in the region. Bidders have a few weeks to submit binding offers before the deadline.

site_title: Australian jobless rate falls as employment nears pre-pandemic highs
summary: Australia's jobless rate fell to 6.6% in December, recovering most of the job losses suffered during the pandemic lockdown of 2020. The country added 50,000 net new jobs, with employment now rebounding by 784,500 since May, leaving it 87,600 short of pre-pandemic levels. This marks another solid rise in employment, driven by strength in consumer spending and housing.

site_title: Australian economy forecast to rebound in 2021 as pandemic subsides: poll
summary: Australia's economy is forecast to rebound in 2021, growing 3.5% this year, driven by the successful domestic suppression of the pandemic and supportive policies. The economy contracted 3.0% in 2020, its first recession since the 1990s. While unemployment is expected to rise, it is forecast to be less than initially feared. However, tensions with China and weak population growth could constrain the recovery, with goods exports to China declining 10% in November. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates low to support growth.

images.alt_text: Australia's economy, which entered 2021 in better shape than most of its peers, will gain further momentum from the successful domestic suppression of the coronavirus pandemic and supportive policies, according to a Reuters poll of economists.

site_title: China sanctions Pompeo, Trump officials for violating 'sovereignty'
summary: China has sanctioned over 28 US officials, including former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, for violating China's sovereignty with "crazy" policy moves. The sanctions include Trump trade advisor Peter Navarro, national security advisor Robert O'Brien, and UN envoy Kelly Craft, among others. Beijing also sanctioned former Trump national security advisor John Bolton and former senior advisor Steve Bannon. The officials are prohibited from entering mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau, and their companies are restricted from doing business with China.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes at record high after Biden takes office
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on President Joe Biden's inauguration day, driven by promises of economic stimulus and relief. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 2.0% to an all-time high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also reached new highs. Investors were relieved that the transition of power was peaceful, and tech companies like Netflix, Apple, and Alphabet surged after strong earnings reports. The market expects Biden's economic relief package to boost the economy and lead to earnings growth.

site_title: Twitter shifts US presidential accounts to Biden team
summary: US President Joe Biden took office on Wednesday, with Twitter handing over control of the official @POTUS account to his team. The platform also activated a new @SecondGentleman handle for the Vice President's husband, Douglas Emhoff. Accounts for the White House, President, Vice-President, First Lady, and Press Secretary have been updated with new institutional usernames. Outgoing President Donald Trump's tweets will be archived, and his followers will not automatically retain their accounts. Biden's team has inherited official @WhiteHouse, @PressSec, and @FLOTUS accounts.

site_title: Europe: Wall Street bounce, upbeat earnings lift stocks
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Wednesday after ASML and Richemont gave encouraging earnings updates, with investors hoping for a large US stimulus plan under the Biden administration. Tech stocks reached a two-decade peak, while luxury goods makers like Burberry and LVMH gained. The European Central Bank is set to meet on Thursday, but no policy changes are expected. Italy's FTSE MIB and lenders rose after Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte won a confidence vote, while Daimler AG jumped 4.2% after unveiling a new electric compact SUV.

site_title: HK bank staff arrested in HK$6.3b laundering probe
summary: Hong Kong police arrested seven bank employees, including former and current staff, in a HK$6.3 billion international money-laundering syndicate probe. The arrests mark the largest case in recent years and the first time local bank staff have been arrested for involvement in money laundering. The employees allegedly helped a Hong Kong-based syndicate apply for business accounts, falsifying documents and coaching applicants, and opened 14 accounts using names from mainland China and Belgium. At least HK$6.3 billion in illicit funds were laundered through these accounts, with some funds traced to Italy, Germany, and Vietnam.

site_title: Fundamentals for Malaysia equities still solid; KLCI to hit 1,830: Maybank KE
summary: Malaysia's equity market fundamentals remain solid despite a second round of movement control order restrictions, according to Maybank Kim Eng analysts. The market is supported by domestic interest and can still move higher. Analysts predict the KLCI will hit 1,830. Despite falling out of favour with foreign investors, domestic interest keeps the market afloat, suggesting a potential recovery.

site_title: China outbound M&A seen driving loans rebound
summary: China's outbound mergers and acquisitions are expected to drive a rebound in loans this year, after falling to a five-year low in 2020 due to the pandemic. Greater China offshore club and syndicated loans are expected to increase, with China offshore loans projected to rise 40% to $45.2 billion. The outlook is driven by China's strong economic growth, robust exports, and infrastructure spending, as well as increased M&A activity, with $26 billion of deals announced or proposed since last year.

site_title: S$30m fund launched to speed up 5G adoption and commercialisation
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched a S$30 million fund to accelerate 5G adoption and commercialization in Singapore. The fund aims to support enterprises, solutions-providers, and technology-developers to adopt 5G solutions, driving down latency and improving efficiency in industries such as logistics and transportation. IMDA plans to nurture a 5G ecosystem that includes industry partnerships, talent development, and solutions services, with the goal of establishing Singapore as a global innovation hub for connected mobility.

site_title: From 'see you soon' to call for 'unity': How America's transfer of power played out on TV
summary: US President Joe Biden's inauguration sparked controversy on cable TV, with conservative networks dismissing his call for unity as "dark" and "divisive." Newsmax and One America News Network (OAN) skipped covering the event, instead airing pre-recorded segments praising Donald Trump's legacy. Fox News commentators focused on Biden's speech, with some acknowledging its positive tone but others questioning its feasibility given deep policy disagreements. The networks' differing reactions highlighted the deep divisions in American politics, with Trump's departure marked by criticism and Trump himself teasing a potential return.

site_title: Canada extends international traveller ban
summary: Canada has extended its one-month ban on non-essential international travel until February 21, requiring travellers to quarantine for 14 days and test negative for Covid-19 before entry.

site_title: EHT confirms Chapter 11 filing, to start marketing process to sell some hotels
summary: EHT confirms Chapter 11 bankruptcy filings for 27 US-based entities to protect stakeholders, and will start marketing process to sell some hotels. The filings allow for debtor-in-possession financing to pay critical expenses and execute value-maximizing strategies. EHT has limited resources to operate as a going concern, with a list of defaults, legal proceedings, and employment-related claims. A new manager has not been appointed, and the company's stapled securities remain suspended.

site_title: Employees should also take charge of their own reskilling and upgrading
summary: Employees in Singapore feel that employers are not providing sufficient training opportunities to help them upskill and advance their careers. Only 32% of employees believe their company provides the right training, while 71% wish for more support. The survey suggests that employees should take personal responsibility for their own continuous learning, as companies can only do so much. With the rise of digitalization, employees must equip themselves with relevant skills to stay employable, and the government has provided infrastructure to support this, including training programs and subsidies.

site_title: Thai government files royal insult complaint after criticism of vaccine strategy
summary: The Thai government has filed a complaint under Article 112 of the criminal code, accusing a banned opposition politician, Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, of defaming the monarchy for criticizing the country's Covid-19 vaccine strategy. The complaint comes after Thanathorn linked the vaccine strategy to the Crown Property Bureau, under the king's personal control. The move could mark the highest-profile lese majeste case since anti-government protests emerged last year, with critics calling it a "political tool" to stifle criticism.

site_title: United Airlines posts fourth straight quarterly loss and pledges more cost cuts
summary: United Airlines reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss of $2.1 billion, or $7 per share, in the fourth quarter ended December 31, down 69% from the previous year. The company aims to cut $2 billion in annual costs through 2023 as it charts a recovery plan. Analysts had estimated a loss of $6.60 per share. United expects revenue to fall 65-70% and flight capacity to shrink 51% in the current quarter. The company has $19.7 billion in liquidity and plans to maintain cost control as the industry awaits a recovery.

images.alt_text: United Airlines Holdings Inc on Wednesday reported a fourth straight quarterly loss as the coronavirus pandemic continued to upend the travel industry and said it aims to cut about US$2 billion of annual costs through 2023 as it charts a recovery plan.

site_title: Singapore top Asean pick for Asia-Pacific investors: survey
summary: Singapore has emerged as the top Asean pick for Asia-Pacific investors, according to CBRE's 2021 survey, with Ho Chi Minh City entering the top 10 for the first time. The city-state remains a key hub for foreign corporations seeking to access South-east Asia, with office demand fueled by Chinese tech firms and non-bank financial services. Central business district rents in Singapore are forecast to grow over the next three years, driven by low vacancy and strong demand.

site_title: Biden sworn in amid historic challenges: 'This is America's day'
summary: US President Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president, taking control of a nation facing a deadly pandemic, unemployment, and social unrest. In his inaugural address, Biden emphasized democracy's fragility and the need for unity, calling on Americans to put aside division and work together. He also highlighted historic challenges, including the pandemic and rising infection rates, and vowed to take swift action to address them. Biden's inauguration marked a reversal for the American electorate, following four years of governance by Donald Trump.

site_title: Israel and UAE agree renewable energy deal
summary: Israel and the UAE have signed a renewable energy deal, with Abu Dhabi-based Masdar and EDF Renewables Israel partnering to develop clean energy projects. This agreement is part of the Abraham accords, which normalized ties between the two nations in September 2020. Israel's Energy Minister Yuval Steinitz predicts his country can become a global leader in solar energy within six years, while Masdar's head Muhammad Jamil al-Ramhi hails the collaboration as a new era of cooperation in clean energy ventures.

site_title: Building - and sustaining - trust in Singapore's CPF system
summary: A new study in Singapore found that trust in the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system significantly influences pension behaviors among older Singaporeans. Those who trust CPF representatives have larger CPF balances and are more likely to invest through the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS). The study also discovered that trust in CPF representatives averaged 3.67 out of 5, with the highest levels of trust reported for CPF officials and civil servants. In contrast, trust in civil servants averaged 3.29. The study highlights the importance of effective communication in maintaining trust in the CPF system, as a recent incident involving a misinterpreted CPF payout eligibility age change led to a significant decline in trust scores.

site_title: Restaurants defy Japan's virus curbs to stay open late
summary: In Japan, restaurants are defying government requests to close early due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing financial struggles and concerns over the effectiveness of voluntary curbs. Authorities have called on bars and restaurants to shut by 8pm, but many are pushing back, citing the need to protect jobs and the lack of support for larger corporations. Experts say tackling infections during meals is crucial to containing the virus, but the current system is failing to quell winter surges, with some cities considering stricter measures.

site_title: Stores close in Tokyo's high-end mall amid travel bans
summary: Tokyo's high-end Ginza Six mall has seen over a dozen stores close due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on luxury tourism. The mall, which opened in 2017, relied heavily on foreign visitors, but travel bans have kept numbers at 1-2% of pre-pandemic levels. Stores including Moschino, Shiseido, and Salon des Parfums have shut down, with department stores like Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings also feeling the effects, with same-store sales falling over 30% in 2020. The pandemic has dealt a significant blow to the mall and the Ginza district's luxury shopping scene.

site_title: Tencent seeks breakthrough in video to counter its nemesis ByteDance
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, the Chinese tech giant behind WeChat, is seeking a breakthrough in video content to counter its rival ByteDance Ltd, owner of TikTok. In a speech to developers, WeChat creator Allen Zhang announced plans to expand WeChat's short-form video feature, Channels, which has garnered 200 million daily active users. The move aims to help WeChat regain its industry lead in user time-spent, now dominated by Douyin. Tencent has nearly 200 people working on the product, and executives are exploring ways to open up access to its mini programs, signaling a shift towards a more open ecosystem.

site_title: Asian markets upbeat on stimulus hopes ahead of Biden's inauguration
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday ahead of US President Joe Biden's inauguration, boosted by hopes of US stimulus. The US$1.9 trillion stimulus package proposal and Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen's urging lawmakers to "act big" on coronavirus relief spending lifted regional indices. The Kospi in South Korea and Australia's ASX 200 index rose 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. However, shares in Japan fell 0.4% due to profit taking. Analysts expect the stimulus to benefit Asian exporters, particularly the semiconductor and electronics sectors, and potentially lead to increased consumer spending.

site_title: Maybank KE sees further upside for Singtel as recovery is underway
summary: Maybank KE sees further upside for Singtel as the telco's recovery gains momentum, driven by its associate Bharti Airtel's strong performance in India. Bharti Airtel's surge in data usage has led to a structural shift in the Indian telecommunications sector, benefiting Singtel. The research house maintains its "buy" call on Singtel, with a sum-of-the-parts-based target price of S$2.88, citing "deep value" in the stock. A breakout above S$2.60 could validate a reversal and start a new uptrend towards S$2.90 to S$3.

site_title: New year, new challenges? Some say: 'Bring it on'
summary: The new year brings opportunities for individuals to take on new challenges and pursue fresh starts. Various people have successfully transitioned into new careers, started businesses, or launched ventures addressing pandemic-related issues. Notable examples include a music conservatory director transitioning to hospitality, a digital clinic for men with erectile dysfunction, a logistics expert in furniture rental, and a mumpreneur in silk bedding products. Meanwhile, luxury watch and jewelry brand Cartier launches a vintage exhibition, and local Indian restaurant ADDA, founded by a former chef, offers a spicy addition to the dining scene.

site_title: Euro sinks amid broader risk rally against dollar
summary: The euro dropped 0.1% against the US dollar to US$1.2117, as concerns over extended lockdowns in Europe and the continent's lag in vaccine rollout weighed on the currency. The risk-sensitive Australian and New Zealand dollars gained 0.4% and 0.25% respectively, while the pound hit a 2.5-year high against the euro. Analysts expect the US dollar to weaken, citing market expectations of a broadening economic recovery and dovish Fed policies.

site_title: Firms must prime for growth as 2021 offers opportunities and risks
summary: Businesses must prepare for growth in 2021 despite ongoing pandemic risks and geopolitical tensions. The year's mix of challenges and opportunities will require companies to remain adaptable and resilient. As the world grapples with the aftermath of the pandemic, businesses must balance the need to manage risks with the imperative to seize growth opportunities. With the global economy recovering unevenly, companies must be prepared to navigate shifting national interests and contested political and economic spaces. By doing so, businesses can capitalize on the year's potential for creativity and innovation.

site_title: ESG investing beyond boom and bust
summary: The ESG investing market is maturing, with research showing that ESG approaches that integrate financially relevant considerations can provide a financial edge. A study comparing companies with top MSCI ESG ratings to their bottom-rated peers found that the top third of companies outperformed the bottom third by 2.56% per year, driven by higher earnings growth and reinvestment returns. New analytical tools can isolate the contribution of specific ESG factors to explain performance, and ESG ratings from different providers are not always correlated. The market is moving towards greater discipline in distinguishing between ESG strategies, and investors can now build their own strategies based on a track record, paving the way for a more sustainable growth of inflows.

site_title: UOBKH starts coverage on GHY Culture & Media with 'buy' call, S$1.08 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on GHY Culture & Media Holding with a "buy" recommendation and a target price of S$1.08. The brokerage expects a three-year projected revenue CAGR of 56% driven by growth from completed drama productions and potential expansion into the high-growth Web series market. GHY has a strong production pipeline and has been granted rights to produce concerts from Taiwanese singer-songwriter Jay Chou in several countries, providing a significant revenue growth opportunity.

site_title: Markets upbeat on Yellen's push for large fiscal stimulus
summary: US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen's push for a large fiscal stimulus package boosted Asian markets, with Singapore shares inching up 0.1% to 2,998.77. The benchmark Kospi and Hang Seng Index also rose, driven by investor optimism following Yellen's comments that stimulus would provide the "biggest bang for the buck". Asian equities followed Wall Street's overnight rally, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding emerging as the top performer.

site_title: GK Goh Holdings evaluates shareholding in Boardroom
summary: GK Goh Holdings is evaluating its 92% stake in Boardroom, a corporate-services provider, with the goal of maximizing shareholder value. The firm is considering a potential divestment, which could fetch about US$300 million, and has appointed Credit Suisse as its financial adviser. No definitive transaction has been entered into, and the evaluation is in its preliminary stages. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution and refrain from taking any action on their shares until further developments are announced.

site_title: Google sidelines second Al researcher
summary: Google researcher Margaret Mitchell has been locked out of corporate systems, following colleague Timnit Gebru's departure in acrimonious circumstances. Mitchell led Google's Ethical AI team and had been critical of the company's handling of AI projects and diversity issues. The move comes after Gebru tweeted that Mitchell's account was locked due to a security issue, and Google has launched an investigation. The incident is the latest in a series of controversies surrounding Google's AI projects and workplace diversity.

site_title: SIAEC says flights handled now at 20% of pre-covid-19 level
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has handled approximately 20% of its pre-Covid-19 flight volumes, up from 14% in the previous quarter. The company is investing $40 million in digitalisation and automation efforts, including an engine lifter that will automate engine changes and lean methodology to reduce maintenance check times. Staff reskilling and upskilling are also part of the transformation program, aiming to boost productivity and financial performance.

site_title: Cold storage a long-term play in alternative property investment: M&G
summary: M&G Real Estate expects cold storage facilities to gain prominence in the long run due to increasing demand for life sciences and data centers amid climate change and global warming. The investment manager notes that such properties are capex-intensive, especially in hot and humid climates like Singapore. Demand for cold storage is expected to be overwhelming, particularly with the rise of online shopping for groceries. M&G Real Estate also sees potential in data centers and life sciences, but advises caution and discipline before investing.

site_title: Why medical tourism is drawing patients, even in a pandemic
summary: During the US pandemic, millions of Americans, like Melissa Jackson, are seeking medical treatment abroad due to high costs and limited insurance options. The US has seen a significant increase in medical tourism, with destinations like Mexico and Costa Rica drawing patients for dental care, cosmetic surgery, and prescription medicines. The COVID-19 crisis has exacerbated the issue, with over 177,000 surgeries postponed in the US, and many patients opting for cheaper, foreign care. Experts say the "working poor" are disproportionately affected, with limited access to affordable healthcare.

site_title: Semi-detached unit sees fierce bidding in year's first property auction
summary: A semi-detached house in Singapore's Siglap area sold for S$3.89 million at the country's first public property auction of the year, surpassing its guide price of S$3.4 million by S$490,000. The auction saw 33 bids, with 14 properties being sold, including 14 mortgagee sales, a higher number than usual. The high demand may be attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the market, with buyers seeking bargains and banks repossessing properties.

site_title: MNCs eye local market hires, instead of expat pool, to drive strategic growth in S-E Asia
summary: Multinational corporations (MNCs) in South-east Asia are shifting their focus from hiring expatriates to local talent to drive strategic growth in the region. With the six leading economies facing diverging fiscal paths, companies are prioritizing top talent in the rapidly growing region. MNCs are adopting a more localized approach, hiring local market talent in industries such as finance, consumer markets, and technology. This trend is expected to continue, with top local talent commanding a premium, driven by the importance of relationships and limited supply at the top end of executive talent.

site_title: New Covid-19 cluster in Singapore
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster has been reported in Singapore, with 18 community cases and six unlinked cases reported in the past week. The cluster is linked to a 39-year-old permanent resident who tested positive earlier this week, and investigations are ongoing to assess if safe management measures were breached at his workplace. This brings Singapore's total cases to 59,197, with 45 patients in hospital and 197 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Ma video helps add US$63b to Alibaba's value
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd saw its stock surge 11% in Hong Kong, adding about US$63 billion to its market value, following a video of Jack Ma addressing teachers. The video, which marked Ma's public reappearance, sparked a significant rally and boosted investor sentiment. Analysts believe the event may signal a deal between Ma's companies and the government to settle antitrust issues, which could help Alibaba's stock reach its previous high of HK$275. However, concerns about regulation targeting Ant Group remain, and some analysts expect resistance near HK$300.

site_title: Singapore bags S$17.2b in fixed asset investment commitments in 2020
summary: Singapore secured S$17.2 billion in fixed asset investment (FAI) in 2020, exceeding the Economic Development Board's (EDB) medium to long-term goal of S$8 billion to S$10 billion. Electronics and chemicals were the top sources of commitments, accounting for 37.7% and 24% respectively. The EDB aims to maintain its current investment commitment goals and is cautiously optimistic about the semiconductor sector in 2021, with many significant investment decisions expected in the next two to three years that will determine global supply chains.

site_title: SP acquires Engie's 40% stake in Sino-French Energy Services in China for undisclosed sum
summary: SP Group has acquired Engie's 40% stake in Sino-French Energy Services (SFES) in Chongqing, China for an undisclosed sum. This marks SP's first acquisition of energy assets in China, expanding its district cooling and heating presence. The deal will support hospitals in becoming more energy efficient and growing market share. Additionally, SP has new partnerships in Shanghai and Guangzhou, including a district cooling project and a memorandum of understanding with State Grid Shanghai Energy Services.

images.alt_text: CEO Stanley Huang: "The acquisition of Engie's stake in SFES strengthens SP Group's district cooling and heating presence in Chongqing."

site_title: Wall Street's top banks widen gulf with rivals amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Wall Street's top investment banks, JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs, have widened the gap with their rivals amid the COVID-19 pandemic. JPMorgan posted record profits, with a 20% increase in revenue from trading, while Goldman's quarterly profit soared 135%. This trend is expected to continue, with JPMorgan's dealmakers and underwriters increasing their market share to the highest in a decade. However, critics, such as Ohio Democrat Sherrod Brown, are scrutinizing how companies use their profits, and the industry's success may lead to problems in the future.

site_title: Indonesia to cut foreign ownership curbs to add jobs, woo funds
summary: Indonesia plans to remove foreign ownership curbs in energy, communications, tourism, and creative economy sectors to boost investments and create jobs. The government aims to simplify business regulations and support small businesses, which are the biggest source of jobs. The move is part of a long-awaited overhaul of the negative investment list, which restricts foreign ownership in hundreds of business fields. The new list will prioritize sectors that are export-oriented or key to national strategic projects, and will limit foreign ownership in sectors like transportation and news publishing.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU falls 16% to 0.84 Singapore cent for Q4
summary: ESR-Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 16% to 0.84 Singapore cents for Q4 2020, despite operational stability and steady growth throughout FY2020. Gross revenue and net property income decreased 9.1% and 12.6% respectively, due to higher property expenses and lower rental income from non-renewals and downsizing by tenants. The company plans to reduce debt and focus on asset enhancements and acquisitions, with a potential first overseas acquisition this year.

site_title: Gaming revenue at Genting Singapore bouncing back on domestic market demand
summary: Genting Singapore's gaming revenue has shown resilience in the domestic market, with local gamers supporting table games at its Resorts World Singapore. Despite a 50% decline in revenue to S$301 million, gaming revenue fell 41% to S$212.9 million, with the mass-gaming segment contributing to the recovery. The company's share price may not fully reflect its resilience, with analysts expecting substantial upside if investors assume a full post-pandemic earnings recovery in 2022. UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price on Genting Singapore to S$1.08, while Maybank Kim Eng analyst Samuel Yin expects the company to expand margins due to a tilt towards mass market.

site_title: Passenger traffic at Changi Airport falls 82.8% last year
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore experienced an 82.8% drop in passenger traffic last year, from 68.3 million to 11.8 million, with the hardest hit months being April and May. Freight volume and commercial aircraft traffic also declined, with 23.3% and 67.2% drops, respectively. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, which affected the airline industry worldwide, with Singapore Airlines posting its largest quarterly loss of S$2.3 billion in the July to September period.

site_title: Tesla faces bumpier ride breaking into India after China success
summary: Tesla is set to enter India's electric vehicle (EV) market, but the company faces significant challenges. Despite India's growing EV market, which could reach $206 billion by 2030, the country's stringent regulations and high costs may limit Tesla's initial success. The company's foray into India comes after China's success, where Tesla dominates EV sales due to generous government subsidies and a strong charging network. India's FAME programs, which offer subsidies for EVs, may not be enough to make Tesla's vehicles affordable for most drivers, with the upper limit for subsidies set at 1.5 million rupees.

site_title: Italy's political instability brings new unease into the EU
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte lost his absolute majority in the Senate following the withdrawal of the Italia Viva party, leading to a period of political instability. The country is struggling with the COVID-19 pandemic and economic damage, with a massive debt load and high unemployment. The uncertainty in Rome has raised concerns in the EU, particularly given Italy's key role in the single market area and its second-largest debt load in the euro zone. The country's chronic political instability and inability to secure structural reforms pose a threat to the euro zone and the EU's stability.

site_title: Biden's huge economic relief plan aims to tackle poverty, inequality head-on
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has proposed a $1.9 trillion economic relief package, aiming to tackle poverty and inequality. The 9% of GDP plan includes increased stimulus checks, supplemental unemployment support, and funding for Covid-19 response, education, and childcare. A $15 minimum wage and infrastructure support are also proposed, with plans to finance them through progressive taxes. Experts expect the final package to be less than $1 trillion, and Republicans are likely to oppose direct state and local government support. The proposal's impact on the economy and markets is expected to be significant, with forecasters predicting 8% growth and strengthened financial markets.

site_title: 'Act big' on Covid relief spending, Yellen tells US lawmakers
summary: US Treasury nominee Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to "act big" on coronavirus relief spending, prioritizing economic benefits over debt burden concerns. Yellen emphasized the need for a muscular Treasury to reduce economic inequality, fight climate change, and counter China's unfair trade practices. She proposed a stimulus package, with spending on public health and vaccinations as the first step, followed by extended unemployment and nutrition aid. Yellen also signaled a focus on taxing corporations and the wealthy to finance Mr. Biden's infrastructure and research plans.

site_title: A newly-imagined world under the sea
summary: A 9-year-old Singaporean artist, Mea Maryam-Mirza, has created a unique underwater world in a large acrylic painting. As part of the "World Of Colours" project, 26 artworks by socially-disadvantaged youths and those with muscular dystrophy are up for silent auction, with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, Muscular Dystrophy Association, and SOTA Endowment Fund. Bids can be submitted online until February 8, 2021, with artworks priced from S$300.

images.alt_text: World Of Colours by (60cm x 90cm, acrylic on canvas) by Mea Maryam-Mirza.

site_title: Chinese media criticise Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine, tout local shots
summary: Chinese state media outlets have criticized Western Covid-19 vaccines, including Pfizer's, in recent weeks, while promoting China-made vaccines as safer and more accessible. The criticism comes amid concerns over insufficient data disclosure in China's vaccines being rolled out to countries such as Brazil, Indonesia, and Turkey. Reports have highlighted deaths of frail patients in Norway after receiving the Pfizer vaccine, with some Chinese media outlets accusing Western media of "propaganda power" and downplaying the deaths.

site_title: When puppets meet Baroque opera
summary: Puppeteer Basil Twist is directing a virtual premiere of 18th-century Baroque opera Titon et l'Aurore at the Opéra Comique in Paris. The opera, conducted by American-born William Christie, features imaginative puppet designs and a three-act pastoral fantasy about a shepherd and his love for the goddess of light. Twist's first appearance as a director in France was a long time coming, and he is dedicating the production to the late director Lee Breuer, a major influence and mentor. The virtual premiere will be streamed on Medici TV for three months.

site_title: On-the-ground intel gave Trafigura a banner year in 2020 amid Covid-19
summary: Trafigura, a Singapore-based commodities trader, had a successful 2020 despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's on-the-ground presence in China provided crucial insights into the impact of the pandemic on oil and metal demand, enabling it to make profitable trading decisions. Trafigura's net profit of US$1.6 billion in 2020 was an 84% increase from the previous year, making it the company's record profit. The trader expects 2021 to be another strong year, driven by a recovery in global growth and stimulus measures.

site_title: US-China dialogue under Biden may be more reasoned: top economist
summary: Top economist Raghuram Rajan says US-China relations under President Joe Biden may be more reasoned, focusing on a multilateral discussion rather than a bilateral one. The former IMF chief economist notes that China's rise as a military and economic power has shifted the dynamic, and the Biden administration will involve alliance partners in Europe and Japan. Rajan foresees a more pragmatic dialogue with clear views of each other, but with a focus on a "modus vivendi" between the US and China, potentially involving other major powers like Europe, India, and Brazil.

images.alt_text: Where US-China relations are concerned, there is no going back to the era of goodwill that preceded former US president Donald Trump's administration, according to top economist Raghuram Rajan.

site_title: US: Stocks gain ahead of Biden inauguration
summary: US stocks rose ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, with the Nasdaq leading the gains. The S&P 500 gained 0.7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index reached a record close. Individual companies like Netflix and Morgan Stanley also saw gains, with Netflix adding 12.7% and Morgan Stanley rising 1.9%. The early gains were driven by hopes for more stimulus spending and an improved rollout of coronavirus vaccines.

site_title: SP acquires Engie's 40% stake in Sino-French Energy Services in China
summary: SP Group acquired Engie's 40% stake in Sino-French Energy Services (SFES) in Chongqing, China, for an undisclosed sum. This marks SP's first acquisition of energy assets in China, expanding its district cooling and heating presence in Chongqing. The acquisition will support hospitals in becoming more energy-efficient and growing SP's market share. Additionally, SP has new partnerships in Shanghai and Guangzhou, including a district cooling and heating solution for Knowledge Tower in Shanghai and a study on integrated-energy projects in Shanghai.

site_title: Japan plans mass virus jabs before Olympics: reports
summary: Japan plans to start mass vaccinating the general public against the coronavirus in May, two months before the postponed Olympics, with the goal of vaccinating most adults by July. The country has agreed to receive enough doses for all 126 million residents and is working to approve the Pfizer jab. Around 10,000 medical workers and 50 million at-risk individuals, including over-65s, will be prioritized for vaccination. Despite concerns over vaccine hesitancy, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has said he will be among the first to be vaccinated, and officials are "unwavering" on holding the Olympics this year with virus countermeasures.

site_title: Vogue to release new Kamala Harris cover after controversy
summary: Vogue will release a limited edition of its February issue featuring a new photo of Vice-President-elect Kamala Harris after the original cover sparked controversy. The original image was criticized for its poor composition and lighting, which some claimed diminished Ms. Harris's achievements as the first Black woman to be elected vice-president. A more formal portrait of Ms. Harris wearing a light blue pantsuit will be included in some copies, which was used for the digital cover. The move comes after fashion critic Robin Givhan called the print cover "overly familiar" and lacking due respect.

images.alt_text: Vogue will release some copies with a more formal portrait of Ms Harris wearing a light blue Michael Kors pantsuit.

site_title: Thai police summon activist for false abduction report
summary: Thai police summoned 25-year-old activist Mongkol Santimetakul for falsifying a statement claiming he was abducted, sparking social media anger and allegations of state harassment of critics. Police found evidence, including camera footage and witnesses, contradicting his claim. Regional police commissioner Ampon Buarubpon said allegations of abductions were designed to create mistrust of state officials, and an arrest warrant would be issued if Mongkol failed to respond. This incident follows accusations of intimidation against critics, with many facing sedition and insulting the monarchy charges.

site_title: On Day One, Biden moves swiftly to undo Trump's legacy
summary: President-elect Joe Biden signed 17 executive orders, memorandums, and proclamations on his first day in office, aimed at reversing the "gravest damages" done to the country by his predecessor, Donald Trump. The actions include reversing Trump's pandemic response, environmental agenda, anti-immigration policies, and bolstering the economic recovery. Biden plans to unilaterally reverse policies, direct others to act, and begin shifting the federal government in a new direction. The actions focus on four broad categories: the pandemic, economic struggles, immigration and diversity issues, and the environment and climate change.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence fell to a four-month low in January
summary: US homebuilder confidence fell to a four-month low in January, dropping to 83 from 86 in December, according to the National Association of Home Builders. Higher house prices and construction costs, exacerbated by pandemic-related supply-chain challenges, are slowing momentum. Builders face a shortage of buildable lots and rising material prices outpacing home price increases, harming affordability. Confidence measures decreased across all four US regions, with gauges of current sales, sales expectations, and prospective homebuyer traffic all declining to their lowest levels since August.

site_title: ASML beats estimates, grapples with chip supply shortage
summary: ASML Holding NV, a leading semiconductor supplier, reported strong first-quarter earnings, beating analyst expectations. The company expects revenue of 3.9-4.1 billion euros and a gross margin of up to 51%. CEO Peter Wennink emphasized the need to address the global chip supply shortage, stating, "This engine needs to start running again." ASML shares hit a record high, driven by strong demand for its machines and a positive outlook for future growth. The company is insulated from the pandemic-induced economic downturn due to demand from major customers like Intel, Samsung, and TSMC.

site_title: Singapore boutique hotels tap on buoyant market to offload
summary: Boutique hotel owners in Singapore are putting their properties on the market as the COVID-19 pandemic boosts demand from funds and family offices for assets expected to recover in two years. A few properties have been listed in the last six months, with owners seeking attention from buyers. This trend is seen as a sign of optimism in the tourism sector, despite the pandemic's initial impact. The sale of these properties is expected to provide a boost to the market, as buyers are eager to capitalize on the projected recovery.

images.alt_text: The Porcelain Hotel at 48, 49 and 50 Mosque Street was relaunched for sale last November with an indicative price of S$68.8 million.
Fortuna Hotel, near Mustafa Centre, was launched for sale by tender with a guide price of S$98.8 million last October.

site_title: Trump leaves White House, skipping Biden inauguration
summary: President Donald Trump departed the White House on January 20, 2021, skipping Joe Biden's inauguration as the 46th US president. Trump, 74, and First Lady Melania Trump boarded a Marine One helicopter, heading to Florida. Trump called his time in office "the honour of a lifetime" and expressed a desire to bid farewell. The inauguration is taking place in an unprecedented and heavily secured environment, with 25,000 National Guard troops present and the general public barred from attending due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Bhutan to await 'auspicious' time for Covid-19 jab roll-out
summary: Bhutan has received 150,000 Covid-19 vaccine shots, but plans to vaccinate the entire population of 750,000 once the "inauspicious month" ends on March 13. The Himalayan kingdom will not begin vaccination until after this period, despite having the required doses. The decision is based on astrological consultations and is not expected to attract criticism in the deeply-Buddhist nation. A total of 533,000 people will be vaccinated, excluding those under 18 and pregnant/breastfeeding women.

images.alt_text: Bhutan received 150,000 coronavirus vaccine shots on Wednesday, but the Himalayan kingdom has insisted that no one will get the jab until the current "inauspicious month" ends on March 13.

site_title: China's appetite for Cartier boosts Richemont sales
summary: Richemont, the world's second-largest luxury group, reported a 5% sales increase in the final quarter of 2020, driven by strong demand for its Cartier jewellery brand in China, where sales rose 80%. This growth was attributed to the brand's popularity and the fact that much of the world's jewellery is unbranded. In contrast, sales of luxury watches, which account for about a third of Richemont's sales, contracted sharply during the pandemic. The company's jewellery brands delivered 14% constant currency sales growth, while its watch labels saw sales fall 4%.

site_title: SIIC Environment bags wastewater-treatment plant project
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings, a Mainboard-listed company, has won a concessionary arrangement to expand a wastewater-treatment plant in Zaozhuang City, Shandong province, with a daily capacity of 60,000 tonnes. The project, called Yicheng Expansion Project, will be implemented in two phases with a 30,000-tonne-a-day capacity each. The concession period is 30 years, with water tariffs priced at RMB1.92 (S$0.39) per tonne. The company has also completed upgrades and approval for seven wastewater-treatment plants in Henan and Guangdong provinces.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.34 points to 1,601.54. Volume was 5.859 billion lots worth RM4.382 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 619 to 528.

site_title: Passenger traffic in Changi Airport fell 82.8% last year from 68.3m in 2019 to 11.8m
summary: Changi Airport saw a 82.8% drop in passenger traffic last year, from 68.3m in 2019 to 11.8m in 2020, with the airport hit hardest during the circuit breaker months of April and May. Freight volume and commercial aircraft traffic also declined, with 23.3% and 67.2% drops, respectively. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has severely impacted the airline industry worldwide, with Singapore Airlines posting its largest quarterly loss of S$2.3 billion.

site_title: G.H.Y Culture & Media's associate company incorporates JV company
summary: G.H.Y Culture & Media's associate company, Tianjin Changxin Film & Media Co, has incorporated a joint venture (JV) limited partnership in China, Xiamen Kaimen Jianjun Film & Television Industry Investment, with a 48.9% stake. The JV has a registered capital of RMB10.22 million and will focus on literary and artistic creation, including script development. The incorporation is not expected to impact GHY's earnings per share or net tangible assets. GHY's shares rose 6 cents or 7.6% to 84.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: ICP ditches purchase of 5% stake in Osaka hotel
summary: CATALIST-LISTED ICP has terminated its plan to acquire a 5% stake in the Osaka Midosuji Hotel in Japan due to unfulfilled conditions. The company had initially agreed to pay 532.5 million yen (S$6.9 million) for its share of the purchase price, but the deal will not go through. ICP will refund the deposit in full, and shares of the company ended the day at 0.8 cents, down 0.1 cents or 11.1%. The company will continue to engage with the vendor to revise the acquisition terms.

site_title: The Place Holdings appoints new chief strategy officer
summary: THE Place Holdings appointed 39-year-old Zhang Wei as its new chief strategy officer, replacing Leow Soon Guan. Zhang holds an MBA from the China University of Political Science and Law and previously served as vice-general manager of Beijing Quandaxingye Investment Management Co. His appointment follows a 7.7% increase in shares to 7 Singapore cents. Zhang's role will assist the executive chairman with strategic planning and growth strategy.

site_title: Morgan Stanley traders drive earnings surge for best year
summary: Morgan Stanley's traders drove the firm's best year on record, with equity revenue surging 30% to $2.5 billion, beating analyst estimates. The bank's fixed-income, currencies, and commodities trading revenue also increased 31% to $1.66 billion. Investment banking revenue rose 39% to $2.3 billion, driven by equity underwriting and corporate matchmaking. Wealth management revenue increased 24% to $5.68 billion, with assets under management reaching $781 billion. The firm's record earnings cement its position as the top stock-trading shop on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore, Ho Chi Minh City are top Asean picks for Asia-Pacific property investors: survey
summary: Singapore and Ho Chi Minh City are the top Asean cities for Asia-Pacific property investors, according to CBRE's 2021 survey. Singapore ranks second, while Ho Chi Minh City enters the top 10 for the first time, driven by potential for property value appreciation and higher yields. Tokyo retains the top spot, with investors seeking value-add assets and industrial/logistics sectors, and willing to pay up to 10% higher for real estate purchases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore invested a decade-high S$17.2 billion in fixed assets in 2020, with electronics and chemicals being the top sources. KPMG suggests green finance, agritech, and supply chain resilience as key areas for Budget 2021. US and China must renegotiate their relationship under the Biden administration, according to Dr Raghuram Rajan. A S$30m fund has been launched to accelerate 5G adoption, while Singapore boutique hotels are tapping into a buoyant market. The STI inched up 0.1% to 2,998.77, following a push for large fiscal stimulus by US Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen.

site_title: Cold storage facilities a long-term play in alternative property investment: M&G
summary: M&G Real Estate expects cold storage facilities to gain prominence in the long run due to increasing demand for life sciences and data centers. The asset manager attributes this growth to climate change and the need for redundant medical or food supplies in the face of global warming. Cold storage facilities, being capex-intensive, are initially a "long-term play" with potential for "overwhelming" demand. Meanwhile, data centers are seen as having "very high risk" and require extra caution, while retail and hospitality sectors offer opportunities for distressed asset investors.

site_title: Markets upbeat on Yellen's push for large fiscal stimulus
summary: US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to "act big" on a $1.9 trillion US relief package, boosting investor optimism in Asia. Markets responded positively, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1%, Kospi up 0.71%, and Hang Seng Index up 1.08%. Analysts attributed the rally to Yellen's comments, citing Wall Street's overnight rally and dovishly unchanged central bank decisions.

site_title: Tencent's WeChat doubled commerce on mini programs in 2020
summary: Tencent's WeChat reported a significant surge in online transactions on its mini programs in 2020, reaching over $240 billion, with a 67% increase in transaction value per user. The platform's daily average users surpassed 400 million, with 300 million buying fresh produce and 500 million playing mini-program games. WeChat aims to break away from its traditionally walled-off ecosystem by making its mini programs accessible through links sent via email and text messages. The platform's growth is driven by the pandemic, with users turning to social interactions for online commerce.

site_title: Japan's Dentsu considering sale of HQ building, said to be worth US$2.9b
summary: Japanese advertising giant Dentsu Group is considering the sale of its Tokyo headquarters, reportedly worth around US$2.9 billion. The 48-story building, currently used by about 70% of Dentsu, may be sold and then rented back with the remaining space. This move is part of a comprehensive business review announced in August, with no decision yet made. The sale comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, where companies are rethinking their real estate holdings due to increased remote work.

site_title: Fundamentals for Malaysia equities still solid, KLCI to hit 1,830: Maybank
summary: Maybank predicts Malaysia's equity market will reach 1,830 points for the benchmark KLCI in 2021, driven by domestic interest, government bond yield increases, and a weaker US dollar. Despite MCO 2.0 restrictions, Maybank estimates 78% of the Malaysian economy will remain operational, with daily losses estimated between RM 0.7 billion and RM 1 billion. The bank advises a balance of value and growth stocks, including glove stocks, which may offer good earnings growth and dividend yields.

site_title: Bank Negara holds key rate steady, warns of 'downside risks' from Covid-19
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, held its key benchmark interest rate steady at 1.75% amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Despite fresh lockdowns and surging cases, the bank deemed its current monetary stance "appropriate and accommodative". However, it warned of potential downside risks from further coronavirus surges or delayed vaccination roll-outs, leaving room for future policy adjustments to aid a sustainable recovery.

site_title: Singapore Airlines trials pre-departure Covid-19 tests to revive travel
summary: Singapore Airlines has launched a trial service for pre-departure COVID-19 tests for passengers traveling to and from Singapore, with the goal of reviving travel demand. The test, available at clinics, provides results within 36 hours, and negative results can be used for travel. The trial service began on January 20 and will run until mid-March. This move aims to restore confidence in travel and is part of efforts to revive the airline's passenger numbers, which slumped 82% in 2020.

site_title: Electric car maker BYD seeks up to US$3.6b from sale of its Hong Kong-listed shares
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer backed by Warren Buffett, is seeking up to US$3.6 billion from a sale of its Hong Kong-listed shares. The company is selling 121.1 million shares at HK$222-HK$228 each, representing a 6.6-9% discount. This offering comes as BYD's shares have surged 400% in the last 12 months, capitalizing on rising demand for new-energy vehicles. The funds will be used to replenish working capital, repay debt, and invest in research and development.

site_title: More stores shutter in Tokyo's high-end Ginza Six mall amid travel bans
summary: More than a dozen high-end stores in Tokyo's Ginza Six mall have closed due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on foreign tourists and luxury shoppers. The mall, which opened in 2017, was a symbol of the Ginza district's revival as a popular destination for Asian tourists. However, global travel bans have kept foreign visitor numbers at 1-2% of year-ago levels since last April, resulting in significant store closures. This marks a significant blow to the mall's luxury retailers, including Moschino and Shiseido.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open, following Asia's record highs and Wall Street futures. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices added 0.3% each. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally, Ma appearance boosts Alibaba
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied on Wednesday, driven by Alibaba's 1.08% surge after founder Jack Ma's first public appearance in over two months. The Hang Seng Index rose 320.19 points to 29,962.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Ma's appearance is seen as a boost to Alibaba's shares, contributing to the overall market advance.

site_title: GK Goh Holdings evaluating options regarding its shareholding in Boardroom
summary: MAINBOARD-listed investment company G. K. Goh Holdings is evaluating options for its shareholding in corporate-services provider Boardroom, aiming to maximize shareholder value. The company has appointed Credit Suisse as its financial adviser and is considering a potential divestment, with a sale valued at around US$300 million. The evaluation is in its preliminary stages, and no definitive transaction has been entered into. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution and refrain from taking any action regarding their shares.

site_title: SGX queries on New Silkroutes' liquidation of oil-trading unit
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried New Silkroutes Group's liquidation of its oil-trading subsidiary, International Energy Group (IEG), due to the buyer's failure to disburse loans. The group's management and board believe the energy business is unsustainable, leading to a creditors' voluntary liquidation. New Silkroutes has sufficient working capital and financial resources to meet its obligations, and the group can continue as a going concern despite the liquidation. Shares of New Silkroutes ended 4.3% down after the announcement.

site_title: Thai government to file royal defamation complaint against Thanathorn
summary: Thailand's ministry of digital economy and society plans to file a lese majeste complaint against Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, a banned opposition politician, over comments made about the government's vaccine strategy. The complaint, under Article 112 of the Thai criminal code, could result in up to 15 years in prison. The move comes amid criticism of King Maha Vajiralongkorn and a wave of anti-government protests. Thanathorn's Progressive Movement denies any insult in his comments, calling the complaint a "political tool."

site_title: S$30m fund launched to accelerate 5G adoption, commercialisation
summary: IMDA launches a S$30 million fund to accelerate 5G adoption and commercialization in Singapore. The fund will support enterprises adopting 5G solutions, as well as solutions-providers and technology-developers. This initiative aims to make 5G benefits more accessible to companies, including small and medium-sized enterprises. The fund is part of IMDA's 5G Innovation Programme, which also includes industry partnerships to develop 5G talent and solutions to drive adoption.

site_title: Hong Kong and Singapore's Changi lose status as Asia's busiest airports
summary: Hong Kong International Airport and Changi Airport in Singapore have lost their status as Asia's busiest airports due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020, South Korea's Incheon International Airport handled 11.96 million passengers, surpassing Changi's 11.8 million and Hong Kong's 8.84 million. The pandemic significantly reduced travel demand, with passenger numbers plummeting 88% in Hong Kong. The two airports will likely regain their top spot once travel demand recovers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares track global gains as Yellen calls for more stimulus
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.71% to 3,114.55 on Wednesday, tracking global gains, after US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to pass a coronavirus relief package. The benchmark KospI index soared 2.6% on Tuesday. Major heavyweights Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics rose, while Hyundai Motor fell. Foreigners sold $216.06 million worth of shares. Yellen's comments boosted risk appetite, but concerns about short-term overheating remain.

site_title: US, China must renegotiate relationship under Biden administration: ex-IMF chief economist
summary: US-China relations will likely require renegotiation under the Biden administration, according to Dr. Raghuram Rajan, former IMF chief economist. The Trump administration's views on China are seen as a unique stance, but many in Washington would support a similar approach. The Biden administration is expected to adopt a more multilateral dialogue, involving alliance partners and other big powers, rather than a bilateral one. This shift is driven by China's rise as a military and economic power, and the US will need to involve other nations in discussions on a "modus vivendi" between the two superpowers.

site_title: GK Goh weighs US$300m Boardroom sale
summary: Singaporean investment firm GK Goh Holdings is exploring the sale of corporate services provider Boardroom for approximately US$300 million, according to people familiar with the matter. Boardroom, founded in 1968, offers corporate and advisory services in multiple countries. The potential sale is ongoing, with the owner potentially deciding to keep the business. GK Goh owns a 92% stake in Boardroom, which went public in 2000 and was later taken private by the firm in 2019.

site_title: World's rich fled Alibaba after monopoly probe: Citi
summary: Wealthy investors, including those from Citigroup's ultra-rich clients, rapidly sold their Alibaba shares following China's investigation into alleged monopolistic practices. The probe, targeting Alibaba's influence over daily life in China, led to a significant outflow of funds from the company. This move comes after the US$35 billion IPO halt of Ant Group, Alibaba's affiliate payments firm, and increased pressure on regulators to rein in the company's business. As a result, Alibaba shares rose 1.2% despite the negative market sentiment.

site_title: Eight chicken suppliers in Singapore get reduced penalties after successful appeal
summary: Eight chicken suppliers in Singapore had their penalties reduced after successful appeals. The original penalties, totaling S$26.9 million, were reduced by up to 70% after the Competition Appeal Board reviewed the cases. The reduced penalties ranged from S$513,992 to S$9.1 million, with four distributors receiving lower penalties than the original S$1.8 million to S$2.3 million. The reduced penalties were payable within 14 days and carried interest at 4% per annum until full payment was made.

site_title: 40 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including four in the community
summary: Singapore reported 40 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,197, including 36 imported cases and four community cases. A new local cluster emerged after the wife and housemate of a previously confirmed case tested positive, while another case linked to the para-vet cluster was identified. The multi-ministry task force warned of additional measures if community cases continue to rise, following the discovery of the second local cluster in recent weeks.

site_title: Hong Kong bank staff arrested in US$810m laundering probe
summary: Seven former and current Hong Kong bank employees have been arrested in a US$810 million international money laundering probe. The operation, the largest in recent years, involved the opening of 14 business accounts using names from mainland China and Belgium, handling HK$6.3 billion in illicit funds. The detained staff allegedly falsified documents and coached applicants for interviews to help a key Hong Kong-based syndicate member. The arrests bring attention to Hong Kong's lax regulations, which allow for money laundering and shell companies, and carry sentences of up to 14 years in jail and a fine of HK$5 million.

site_title: Australian consumer confidence clouded by Covid-19 in January: survey
summary: Australian consumer confidence dropped 4.5% in January due to new Covid-19 outbreaks in Sydney and Brisbane, despite the spread being contained. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment remains 41% above its 2020 nadir, with optimists outnumbering pessimists. The survey showed a decline in measures of family finances and the outlook for the economy over the next 12 months and five years. A measure of whether it's a good time to buy a major household item also decreased.

images.alt_text: A measure of Australian consumer sentiment slipped from a decade high in January as new outbreaks of Covid-19 in Sydney and Brisbane spooked people, though the spread has now been contained with relatively few cases and no deaths.

site_title: Tower Capital hits US$250m first close of South-east Asian PE fund
summary: Tower Capital Asia has hit the first close of its South-east Asian private equity fund, Tower Capital PE Fund I, at US$250 million. The fund, which focuses on mid-market investments in consumer, education, healthcare, manufacturing, and business services, will invest in Singapore and opportunistically in the rest of South-east Asia. Founded in 2016, Tower Capital is grateful for investors' support despite a challenging fundraising year. The fund's first deal is expected to close this quarter, allowing the firm to capture buyout opportunities in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.81 points, or 0.36%, to 1,607.69. Volume was 735.84 million lots worth RM457.82 million. Gainers outpaced losers 315 to 253.

site_title: COE prices shoot up ahead of smaller supply in February
summary: COE prices in Singapore rose ahead of a smaller supply in February, with prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increasing to S$43,501, and premium for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp rising to S$50,100. Commercial vehicle COE prices also surged, finishing at S$40,999. The increases are attributed to dealers seeking to secure COEs before the smaller quota kicks in, as car manufacturers push for more sales to counter sharp market contractions.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up on hope for Biden recovery agenda
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for a recovery agenda under President Joe Biden and positive comments from Treasury nominee Janet Yellen. Yellen's calls for a $1.9 trillion stimulus package and her emphasis on cooperation between the Fed and Treasury boosted risk sentiment. Markets were also lifted by Yellen's experience as a former Federal Reserve head. However, the ongoing pandemic cast a shadow, with several governments maintaining lockdowns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at Wednesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.51% at Wednesday's open, extending a healthy rally on recovery hopes. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,794.41, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.06%. Investors await the US presidential inauguration later in the day.

site_title: Hedge fund Elliott Management to shutter Hong Kong office
summary: US hedge fund Elliott Management is closing its 20-strong Hong Kong office, relocating Asian investment decisions to London and Tokyo. The move, made for efficiency reasons, coincides with rising political tension in the Asian financial hub. The Hong Kong workforce will be transferred to London and Tokyo, with no shift in investment priorities. The decision follows Elliott's investments in Hong Kong companies, including Bank of East Asia, and comes as Japan seeks to attract banks and asset managers after new security legislation. Elliott will retain offices in the US, London, and Tokyo.

site_title: Australian dollar edges ahead, upside risk seen for jobs report
summary: The Australian dollar edged higher against the US dollar, reaching US$0.7712, amid expectations of aggressive US fiscal stimulus. The kiwi dollar also rose, reaching US$0.7126. A positive jobs report in Australia, with a possible 100,000 new jobs, could lead to speculation that the Reserve Bank of Australia might not extend its bond-buying campaign. This could lead to higher interest rates and a stronger Australian dollar.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH starts coverage on GHY Culture & Media with 'buy', S$1.08 TP
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on GHY Culture & Media Holding with a "buy" recommendation and a target price of S$1.08. The brokerage expects a three-year projected revenue compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 56% driven by growth from drama productions and a strong production pipeline of 23 projects. GHY aims to expand its regional reach and diversify into web series and online video platforms, with potential earnings growth of 72% CAGR and a valuation of 18.5 times 2021F price-to-earnings.

site_title: EHT announces Chapter 11 filing; to start marketing process to sell some hotels
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US, with 27 entities seeking protection to stay claims against its US-based entities. The trust aims to sell some hotels through a marketing process, but will explore other restructuring alternatives. EHT obtained a debtor-in-possession financing facility of up to $125 million from Monarch Alternative Capital to protect its assets and execute value-maximizing strategies. The filings follow a list of defaults, legal proceedings, and employment-related claims, and come after EHT lost its manager last year.

site_title: SIAEC launches phase 2 transformation; flights handled at 20% of pre-Covid level
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has launched phase 2 of its transformation program, aiming to boost productivity and financial performance. Currently, the company handles about 20% of pre-Covid-19 flight levels, with plans to invest $40 million over three years in digitalization and automation initiatives. New technologies include an engine lifter to automate engine changes and lean methodology to reduce maintenance check times by 25%. The company also plans to reskill staff, with 126 employees already vaccinated.

site_title: HSBC, Maybank's insurance venture among bidders for AXA Singapore: sources
summary: HSBC and Etiqa, a joint venture between Maybank and Ageas, are among shortlisted bidders for AXA's Singapore insurance business, which could raise approximately $700 million. The sale comes as AXA seeks to divest peripheral operations and focus on property and casualty insurance. The Singapore unit generated $990.2 million in revenue in 2019 and provides services in life and property and casualty insurance, savings, and investments. Bidders have until a few weeks before a deadline to submit binding offers, with at least one Chinese firm also in the running.

site_title: Singapore boutique hotels tap buoyant market to offload
summary: Singapore's boutique hotel market is experiencing a resurgence, with several high-end properties being put up for sale. The Aqueen Heritage Hotel at 51 Joo Chiat Road has been listed with an indicative price of S$55 million, while Fortuna Hotel at 2 Owen Road and The Porcelain Hotel at 48-50 Mosque Street are also up for sale. Buyers are attracted to the hotels' prime locations and potential for long-term recovery in the tourism sector. Experts expect interest from boutique real estate funds, family offices, and high net worth individuals, driven by low interest rates and optimism about future economic conditions.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU falls 16% to 0.84 Singapore cent for Q4
summary: ESR-REIT's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 16% to 0.84 Singapore cents in Q4 2020, due to higher property expenses and lower revenue. Gross revenue declined 9.1% to $229.9 million, while net property income (NPI) dropped 12.6% to $164.2 million. Despite this, the Reit's core DPU showed operational stability and steady growth throughout FY2020. The company plans to refinance debt and explore growth opportunities to capitalize on the post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on profit-taking
