summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.38% on Wednesday, wiping out earlier gains, as investors took a wait-and-see stance ahead of US President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. The Nikkei 225 index fell 110.20 points to 28,523.26, and the Topix index declined 6.26 points to 1,849.58. The decline was attributed to profit-taking, with investors focusing on the upcoming US-EU trade talks and potential tariff threats.

site_title: Year's first public property auction in Singapore includes remnant land
summary: Singapore is holding its first public property auction of the year, featuring a 6,042 sq ft freehold remnant land with a guide price of S$3 million. The land, surrounded by state land, is up for sale as a mortgagee or bank sale and has attracted over 100 enquiries from developers and residents. The sale will be conducted under social distancing measures, with only 50 attendees allowed. The auction includes 16 properties worth close to S$25 million, with most being mortgagee sales.

site_title: Wall Street's top banks widen gulf with rivals amid pandemic
summary: Wall Street's top banks, led by JPMorgan Chase & Co and Goldman Sachs, have widened their leads over rivals amid the pandemic. JPMorgan reported record profits in the fourth quarter, driven by a 20% increase in trading revenue. Goldman Sachs' quarterly profit soared 135% due to a flurry of transactions. The strong performance of these banks has raised concerns about their ability to sustain growth in an uncertain economic environment, with regulators and lawmakers scrutinizing their business practices.

site_title: Green finance, agritech, supply chain resilience can be key areas for Budget 2021: KPMG
summary: KPMG has proposed key areas for Singapore's Budget 2021, including green finance, agritech, and supply chain resilience. The audit firm suggests grants and subsidies to support sustainable finance deals, agritech, and food security, as well as tax incentives for businesses operating in these areas. KPMG also recommends measures to help cash-strapped businesses, such as property tax remission and longer instalment plans for income tax payments. The proposals aim to help Singapore emerge from the COVID-19 crisis stronger and more resilient.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma makes first live appearance in three months in online meet
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma made his first live appearance in three months via a live video meeting with 100 rural teachers in China, sparking a 6% jump in the Hong Kong-listed shares of the e-commerce giant. Ma's reappearance comes amid a regulatory clampdown by Beijing on his business empire, which led to the suspension of a US$37-billion IPO of Alibaba's financial affiliate Ant Group. Ma's public appearance also coincides with Alibaba's planned US$5 billion bond sale and an antitrust investigation launched by Chinese authorities.

site_title: BBC must make tough decisions on spending: watchdog
summary: The BBC needs to make tough decisions to ensure its future as it faces declining audiences and revenue from the licence fee. The National Audit Office found the BBC made substantial savings but its costs outstripped income for three of the past five years. The government is considering decriminalizing licence fee evasion, which could reduce the BBC's income by over £1 billion by 2027. The BBC's director general and new chairman will lead negotiations with the government on future funding and the licence fee.

site_title: Biden arrives at air base near Washington on eve of inauguration
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden arrived at Joint Base Andrews near Washington on January 19, 2021, on the eve of his inauguration as the 46th president. Biden returns to a transformed Washington, dealing with economic and pandemic crises, as well as an extraordinary security challenge following the January 6 US Capitol siege. President Donald Trump will break protocol by not attending Biden's swearing-in ceremony on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks slipped 0.1% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 3.68 points to 2,992.24. Gainers outnumbered losers 121 to 42, despite a positive lead from Wall Street overnight. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC were down, while Nanofilm rose 2.6% on its debut, and First Reit advanced 2% after unitholders voted in favor of a proposed restructuring.

site_title: In farewell address, Trump wishes luck to next administration without mentioning Biden
summary: US President Donald Trump released a farewell address, wishing luck to President-elect Joe Biden without mentioning him by name. Trump's remarks highlighted his legacy, including his economic policies and foreign deals, but also acknowledged the Capitol riots and the COVID-19 pandemic. He refused to concede the election and instead plans to fly to Florida after the inauguration. Trump's speech was seen as a final attempt to shape the narrative of his presidency and the transition of power.

site_title: Australia: Shares up as Yellen backs more US stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to their highest level since February 25, 2020, following overnight gains in the US and expectations of a US$1.9 trillion stimulus package. US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to "act big" on the package, boosting optimism. Domestic corporate earnings also supported the market.

site_title: World Wide Web inventor opposes Australia's news payment plan
summary: World Wide Web inventor Tim Berners-Lee opposes Australia's plan to force digital giants to pay media outlets for news content, calling it "unworkable" and undermining the fundamental principle of the Internet. Berners-Lee submitted a statement to an Australian Senate inquiry, stating that constraints on hypertext links are not the correct way to reward publishers. The US Trade Representative has also urged Australia to abandon the plan, citing potential negative consequences for consumers and companies.

site_title: Netflix tops 200 million paid subscribers globally
summary: Netflix reported topping 200 million paid subscribers globally in the recently ended quarter, exceeding expectations. Annual revenues reached $25 billion, driven by a record 37 million paid memberships added for the full year. The company's shares jumped over 10% in after-market trades. Despite rate increases, Netflix attributed its success to providing a source of escape and connection for its members worldwide.

site_title: Decade-high S$17.2b in fixed asset investments for Singapore in 2020: EDB
summary: Singapore secured a decade-high S$17.2 billion in fixed asset investments (FAI) in 2020, exceeding its annual investment commitment goals of S$8 billion to S$10 billion. The top two sources of investment commitments were electronics and chemicals, accounting for 37.7% and 24% respectively. Despite a challenging business environment, the EDB aims to maintain its current investment commitment goals for the medium to long term, with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing expressing cautious optimism for the rest of the year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, First Reit, Keppel Infra Trust, Sunningdale, ARA Logos, Oxley
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday include ESR-Reit, which reported a Q4 FY2020 distribution per unit of 0.84 Singapore cents, down 16% from the same period last year. First Reit's unitholders voted in favor of a proposed restructuring of Lippo Karawaci's master lease agreements. Keppel Infrastructure Trust entered into an unsecured S$300 million facility agreement to finance its proposed acquisition of Philippine Tank Storage International.

site_title: Italian PM wins confidence vote but loses overall majority
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte survived a vote of confidence in the Senate, winning 156-140 but failing to secure an overall majority. The result leaves his ruling coalition severely weakened, battling the coronavirus pandemic. Conte will likely seek to win over opposition lawmakers to bolster his position, but analysts question the government's ability to lead Italy out of the crisis.

site_title: Disney cuts bonuses for top executives in pandemic fallout
summary: Walt Disney Co. has eliminated performance-based bonuses for top executives, including CEO Bob Chapek and executive chairman Bob Iger, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Iger's total compensation for fiscal year 2020 was $21 million, significantly lower than $47.5 million in the prior year. Chapek's compensation package was $14.2 million, with a 50% pay cut implemented during the crisis. The move aims to soften the impact of the pandemic on Disney's theme parks and movie studio business.

site_title: Beijing steps up Covid-19 curbs amid new outbreak
summary: Beijing has stepped up COVID-19 curbs amid a new outbreak, investigating individuals who entered the city from abroad from December 10 and shutting down a subway station after a record 7 new cases were reported. The measures come ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday season, which could see hundreds of millions travel, raising fears of another major COVID-19 wave. The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China stands at 88,557, with the death toll remaining unchanged at 4,635.

images.alt_text: China's capital Beijing said on Wednesday it will investigate all individuals who entered the city from abroad from Dec 10 and shut down a subway station after reporting the biggest daily jump in new Covid-19 cases in more than three weeks.

site_title: UK finance sector revives, cuts staff, reviews office space: survey
summary: The UK finance sector has seen business volumes grow for the first time in two years during the final quarter of 2020, despite staff cuts and reviews of office space amid the pandemic. A survey by CBI and PwC found firms expect business volumes to grow slightly quicker in the first three months of 2021, but plan to cut headcount further. Remote working has prompted a review of office space, with many firms opening hubs in the EU to maintain access. The sector faces ongoing challenges, including the UK's post-Brexit relationship with the EU.

site_title: Blinken says US plans full review of approach to North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State nominee Antony Blinken announced that President-elect Joe Biden's administration plans a full review of the US approach to North Korea to increase pressure on the country to come to the negotiating table over its nuclear weapons. Blinken emphasized the need to consider the humanitarian side of the equation, in addition to the security side, during any future negotiations. This approach aims to resolve the long-standing issue without worsening the situation, as it has in previous administrations.

site_title: Vogue to release new Kamala Harris cover after controversy
summary: Vogue will release a limited edition of its February issue featuring a different photo of Vice-President-elect Kamala Harris after the original cover sparked controversy. Critics criticized the photo, citing poor composition and lighting that diminished Ms. Harris's achievements as the first Black woman to be elected vice-president. Vogue will publish special edition inaugural issues with a more formal portrait of Ms. Harris wearing a light blue pantsuit, which was used for the digital cover. The move comes after Editor Anna Wintour defended the original image and faced backlash for its perceived lack of respect.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by solid gains on Wall Street ahead of US President Joe Biden's inauguration and expected stimulus spending. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.50% or 142.64 points to 28,776.10, while the Topix index gained 0.09% or 1.66 points to 1,857.50. The gains come as investors await Biden's government's aggressive stimulus measures.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE sees further upside for Singtel as recovery is underway
summary: Maybank KE's research team expects Singtel to see further upside as the Indian telecommunications sector undergoes a structural shift and benefits from increased data usage. Bharti Airtel's outperformance is driving this recovery, with the research house maintaining a "buy" call on Singtel. The stock offers a 5.1% yield and a sum-of-the-parts-based target price of S$2.88, indicating "deep value" in the stock.

site_title: Biden to keep Jerusalem embassy but seek Palestinian state, nominee says
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden will maintain the US embassy in Jerusalem, but his nominee for secretary of state, Antony Blinken, says the US will seek a Palestinian state, contrary to Donald Trump's stance. Blinken stated that the two-state solution is the only way to ensure Israel's future as a Jewish, democratic state and to give Palestinians a state. However, he acknowledged the difficulties in pursuing this goal, citing the need for neither side to take steps that make the process more challenging.

site_title: Global chip crunch unlikely to impact car deliveries here
summary: A worldwide microchip shortage is unlikely to affect car deliveries in Singapore, despite supply chain disruptions globally. Major carmakers such as Ford, Nissan, and Volkswagen have slowed or shut production due to the shortage, but importers in Singapore say their current inventory will see them through until supply returns to normal. Audi and BMW also reported no impact on their deliveries in Singapore, citing adjustments to production and preventive risk management measures.

site_title: Eyeing a recovery, some US airlines resume pilot hiring
summary: US airlines American Airlines and Frontier Airlines plan to resume pilot hiring this year, a positive sign for the industry after a year of COVID-19-related disruptions. American Airlines' regional subsidiary PSA Airlines will begin hiring First Officers, while Frontier Airlines aims to hire around 100 pilots if passenger demand recovers. The moves come as airlines hope for a significant improvement in domestic air travel by summer, driven by the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines. Major airlines are also preparing for pilot retirements in coming years, with American Airlines expecting over 11,000 pilots to reach retirement age between 2021 and 2041.

site_title: Biden to unveil sweeping immigration reforms
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to unveil sweeping immigration reforms on his first day in office, including a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants and increased asylum opportunities for those fleeing abuse and violence. Homeland Security Department nominee Alejandro Mayorkas said the reforms will include an eight-year track to gain citizenship and increased admissions, reversing Trump's drastic measures to seal the southern border. The reforms aim to fix the "broken" immigration system and provide a permanent solution.

site_title: 'Act big' now to save economy, worry about debt later, Yellen says in Treasury testimony
summary: US Treasury nominee Janet Yellen urged lawmakers to "act big" on coronavirus relief spending, prioritizing economic benefits over higher debt burdens. She emphasized the need for bold investment to jump-start the economy and accelerate vaccine distribution. Yellen proposed a stimulus package, focusing on public health, unemployment, and nutrition aid, while acknowledging the country's debt burden. She also called climate change an "existential threat" and vowed to appoint a senior official to oversee the issue. Yellen's confirmation hearing marked a shift towards a more muscular Treasury, with a focus on reducing economic inequality and countering China's unfair trade practices.

site_title: YouTube bans Trump for another week over inauguration violence concerns
summary: YouTube has extended its one-week ban on former US President Donald Trump for another week due to concerns about the ongoing potential for violence. The ban, initially imposed on January 12, is now set to last for at least 7 more days. Trump is scheduled to leave office on Wednesday as President-elect Joe Biden takes office. The extension comes after Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol on January 6, and he had violated YouTube's policy against inciting violence. The platform will review the ban after 90 days unless Trump violates its policies again.

site_title: UK's Johnson congratulates Biden ahead of inauguration
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson congratulated US President-elect Joe Biden ahead of his inauguration, expressing a desire to work closely on policy areas including COVID-19, climate change, and defense. Johnson cited shared goals with Biden, including defeating COVID and promoting democracy. The UK will host the G-7 summit in June and COP26 in November, with Johnson hoping to bolster his international image. Despite criticism of his relationship with Trump, Johnson and Biden have had a constructive conversation, with Johnson describing Biden as a "warm and friendly" leader.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said late on Tuesday he was looking forward to "working closely" with incoming US president Joe Biden, on the eve of his inauguration in Washington.

site_title: US declares China committing 'genocide' against Uighurs
summary: The US has declared that China is committing "genocide" against the Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim minority, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's statement on his last full day in office. At least 1 million Uighurs are believed to be incarcerated in camps in Xinjiang, with China denying wrongdoing and claiming its camps are vocational training centers. The US declaration aligns with the views of President-elect Joe Biden and other Biden nominees, who have promised firm action against China. Rights groups and witnesses say China is seeking to forcibly integrate Uighurs into the majority Han culture, eradicating Islamic customs.

site_title: Oil gains on stimulus optimism ahead of Biden inauguration
summary: Oil prices rose 2.1% ahead of US President Joe Biden's inauguration, driven by optimism over potential government stimulus and economic growth. Brent futures climbed to $55.90 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose to $52.98 a barrel. Wall Street indexes rose after positive earnings from big US banks and comments from US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen. Investors also welcomed demand in China, which saw its refinery output reach a record high in 2020.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on Inaugration-eve, Yellen call for stimulus
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by anticipation of President Joe Biden's inauguration and a call for aggressive stimulus spending from his Treasury secretary nominee, Janet Yellen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4%, the S&P 500 rose 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.5%. Individual stocks also saw gains, including General Motors and Boeing, while Stellantis surged 10.8% following its merger with Fiat Chrysler. The market's optimism reflects early approval for Biden's policy agenda.

site_title: US orders Ford to recall 3 million vehicles with Takata airbags
summary: US regulators ordered Ford to recall 3 million vehicles with Takata airbags due to "potential future rupture risk." The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) rejected an appeal, citing inadequate evidence from Ford. This decision follows a similar finding against General Motors, which required the recall of 5.9 million autos. The recall affects vehicles in model years 2007-2012, including the Ford Ranger and Ford Fusion, and owners will be notified within 30 days. The NHTSA has confirmed 18 US fatalities and hundreds of injuries due to Takata airbag explosions.

site_title: OUE C-Reit divests 50% of OUE Bayfront to Allianz entity
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) is divesting 50% of its OUE Bayfront property to an Allianz entity for S$1.27 billion, or S$3,170 per square foot. The sale, valued at S$1.18 billion, is expected to net OUE C-Reit S$262.6 million, improving its aggregate leverage from 40.3% to 33.6%. The divestment is seen as a strategic move to pare down debt and undertake accretive acquisitions, with OUE C-Reit's manager affirming the office segment's resilience.

site_title: Frankfurt Airport's traffic nosedives to lowest since 1984
summary: Frankfurt Airport's passenger numbers plummeted to 18.8 million in 2020, the lowest since 1984, with a 73% decline from the previous year. The COVID-19 pandemic devastated the travel sector, with global air travel falling 60% to 1.8 billion passengers. Germany's Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports also reported significant drops. Fraport CEO Stefan Schulte expects passenger traffic to rebound in the second half of 2021, but predicts 2021 traffic will reach only 35-45% of 2019 levels, still a "difficult year".

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as lockdown worries resurface
summary: European stocks slipped 0.2% on Tuesday, weighed down by retailers, travel, and banking stocks, amid concerns over a possible extension of Germany's coronavirus lockdown. Despite a positive ZEW economic survey, the Stoxx 600 index closed lower. The DAX also fell 0.2% despite a rise in investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: European stocks slipped on Tuesday, dragged down by retailers, travel and banking stocks, as the possible extension of Germany's coronavirus lockdown raised concerns about the damage to earnings and economic growth.

site_title: Asset-heavy property groups may take the privatisation route
summary: A Singapore-listed hotel group, GL Limited, is facing a difficult operating environment due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the loss, its largest shareholder, Guoco Group, has made a voluntary conditional offer to take the company private at a 25% premium to the last traded price. This move may be a bet on a return to normalcy within a few years, with business travel potentially recovering but leisure travel resuming. The trend of asset-heavy groups being taken private could continue, with many property and hotel groups trading at substantial discounts to book value, offering opportunities for investors.

site_title: Thai woman gets record 43-year jail term for lese majeste
summary: A Thai woman, Anchan, was sentenced to 43 years in prison for lese majeste, a record punishment under the country's strict laws. She was convicted of 29 counts of insulting the royal family and had previously been released on bail after three years in pre-trial detention. The harsh sentence has raised concerns about the use of the law to silence critics, with activists demanding reforms to the monarchy. The verdict comes as Thailand ramps up its use of lese majeste laws against democracy protesters.

images.alt_text: Ms Anchan was convicted on 29 counts of lese majeste and given a total of 87 years in prison, but the court halved her sentence because she confessed.

site_title: Zoom says issues affecting some European users resolved
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc has resolved an issue affecting some European users' access to its desktop and mobile apps, but not through a web browser. The issue, which started affecting users, was resolved Tuesday. The surge in popularity of video conferencing platforms, such as Zoom, has continued during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Zoom Video Communications Inc said on Tuesday it had resolved an issue that was preventing some users in Europe from accessing its desktop and mobile apps.

site_title: As deadline of tax break looms, UK housing boom faces reality check
summary: The UK housing market's boom is set to face a reality check as the £15,000 tax break deadline approaches on March 31. With nearly one-in-six transactions currently underway likely to miss the deadline, vendors are dropping asking prices and concerns are rising about transactions collapsing. Loan providers predict a 5% price slump this year, and authorities are keeping the stamp duty under review. The government will announce the future of the policy at its March 3 budget, amid pressure from Conservative lawmakers to postpone the deadline.

site_title: Qatar sovereign wealth fund plans Asia push
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), plans to diversify its $300 billion investment portfolio by focusing on Asia. Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani stated that Asia has been on their radar, citing a need for growth and diversification, particularly after substantial investments in Europe. QIA has already invested in China and is considering stakes in India, Malaysia, Singapore, and China, while maintaining a priority on North American deals. The fund holds stakes in top companies like Volkswagen and London Stock Exchange.

site_title: LMIRT raises S$281m in rights issue
summary: LIPPO Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) raised S$281 million through a 53.84% subscribed rights issue, exceeding the gross proceeds target. The issue received valid acceptances and excess applications totaling S$352 million, representing 125.4% of available units. The funds will be used to acquire strata title units in Lippo Mall Puri, as well as for working capital and debt financing. The trust's units will be listed on the mainboard on January 22, closing at 6.8 Singapore cents on the day.

site_title: Malaysia imposes nationwide lockdown following surge in Covid-19 cases
summary: Malaysia has imposed a nationwide lockdown, excluding Sarawak, following a surge in Covid-19 cases. The Movement Control Order (MCO) will be enforced from January 22 to February 4 in six states, with restricted hours for various businesses and essential services. People are allowed to leave their homes for daily essentials and emergencies, but must obtain police consent for travel. The lockdown will be enforced nationwide, with the exception of Sarawak, to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: US asks Australia to scrap plan to make Facebook, Google pay for news
summary: The US government has asked Australia to scrap its plan to make Facebook and Google pay for news sourced from local media outlets, citing concerns over market manipulation and potential harm to competition. US trade representatives suggested instead that Australia further study the markets and develop a voluntary code. This move comes as Australia is set to become the first country to implement such a policy, which would require tech giants to pay for news content.

site_title: Of TraceTogether and trust together
summary: Singapore's contact tracing app, TraceTogether, has been marred by revelations that its data is available to law enforcement for criminal investigations, sparking concerns about trust and potential misuse. This raises moral questions about the long history of contact tracing efforts, which have often perpetuated discrimination and exploitation. To repair trust, the government must communicate its intentions and competence, offer solutions and explanations, and act consistently. A lack of trust can harm the efficient use of the app and contact tracing efforts, making it essential for the government to address citizens' concerns and rebuild trust.

site_title: Michelin awards first star to vegan restaurant in France
summary: A vegan restaurant in Ares, near Bordeaux, France, ONA, has been awarded its first Michelin star, making it the first establishment serving only animal-free products in France to receive the honor. The restaurant, founded by Claire Vallee in 2016, also received a green star for its strong record on ethical practices. Vallee secured financing through crowdfunding and a green bank, overcoming initial rejections from traditional French banks. The award recognizes her innovative and pioneering work in vegan cuisine.

site_title: BT's regional newsletter will track trends, offer insights
summary: The Business Times' (BT) Asean Lookout regional newsletter will now be published on Fridays, starting immediately, to provide timely updates on the region's key happenings. The newsletter, which costs $3.90 a month, will feature curated content from BT articles, including insights, trends, and exclusive access to profiles of influential players. The change aims to cater to time-starved readers and provide in-depth analysis on regional trends, with new editor Gayle Goh joining the editorial team.

site_title: US lawmakers aim to curtail face recognition even as tech identifies Capitol attackers
summary: US lawmakers are moving to ban federal agencies from using facial recognition software, despite its use helping identify Capitol attackers. Senator Ed Markey says the technology poses risks and may not be worth the benefits. The technology, which can identify similar faces in databases, has been used to aid in the investigation into the January 6 Capitol riot. Critics argue it can perpetuate discriminatory policing and raise concerns about constant tracking. Markey's bill, which was previously introduced, may be reintroduced this year.

site_title: First Reit unitholders vote in favour of proposed restructuring
summary: First Reit unitholders voted in favor of a proposed restructuring of Lippo Karawaci (LK) master lease agreements and a whitewash resolution waiving the right to receive a takeover offer from substantial shareholder OUE. The restructuring aims to address the risk of LK defaulting on its obligations due to its negative cash flow since 2015. The move also paves the way for a proposed 98-for-100 renounceable rights issue to raise S$158.2 million in gross proceeds.

site_title: Shipping industry should stay on zero-carbon course
summary: A new study suggests that human interference in key weather systems, rather than carbon emissions, is central to climate issues. Research by Conor McMenemie found that controlling the River Nile flood in Egypt has increased Atlantic Ocean temperatures and hurricanes. The study's findings contradict the current focus on reducing carbon emissions. The shipping industry, however, remains committed to moving towards a zero-carbon future, with the International Chamber of Shipping hosting a webinar on achieving zero carbon. The industry acknowledges that reducing CO2 emissions is a sensible policy, despite the research's implications.

site_title: Prestige Biopharma eyes at least 1.8t won valuation in Korean IPO
summary: Prestige Biopharma, a Singapore-based biotech firm, plans to list on the Korea Exchange (KRX) with an implied market capitalization of 1.8-1.93 trillion won (S$2.2-2.3 billion) in its upcoming initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to expand its headcount to 300 staff in the next five years, with a focus on developing biosimilars and antibody therapeutics. Founded by CEO Lisa Park and co-founder Michael Kim in 2015, Prestige has a pipeline of projects, including biosimilars for cancer drugs and innovative antibody drugs.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

Prestige Biopharma co-founder Lisa Park says that drug development has always been her "dream and goal". She reckons that the timing is now optimal to pursue an IPO as investor appetite for a biotech play on the Korea Exchange appears buoyant.

site_title: High Court revises ruling on creditors' claim on joint bank accounts
summary: The High Court in Singapore has revised its ruling on creditors' claims to joint bank accounts, overturning provisional garnishee orders granted to two bank accounts. The court found that the plaintiff, Timing Limited, had failed to prove that the beneficial ownership of the entire sums in the joint accounts belonged to one of the account holders, Mr Tay. The court emphasized that the ownership of funds in a joint account cannot be determined solely by the actions of one account holder, and that a strong prima facie case must be weighed against the evidence provided by the joint account holder.

site_title: STI flirts near 3,000 mark, with 0.18% gain to 2,995.92
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,995.92, gaining 0.18% or 5.52 points on Tuesday, narrowly missing the 3,000 mark. Fu Yu declined 8.07% after founders sold S$58.3 million worth of shares. Mainboard-listed Sunningdale Tech rose 3.85% after a sweetened corporate action proposal. Key regional indexes performed well, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 2.70% and South Korea's Kospi up 2.61%.

site_title: Did UOL underprice its Clavon launch?
summary: UOL Group's Clavon condo launched with a record-breaking 442 units sold at an average price of S$1,640 psf, accounting for nearly 70% of the 640 units. Analysts estimate the breakeven cost at S$1,340 psf, suggesting a comfortable gross profit margin of nearly 20%. This strategy may have priced the project sensibly, capturing buyers for most units and ensuring cashflow. UOL's strong track record, with a total return to shareholders exceeding 100% over the last decade, contrasts with peers City Developments and CapitaLand.

site_title: Fu Yu founders retire, sell 29.8% stake in company for S$58.3m
summary: Fu Yu Corp's co-founders, Ching Heng Yang, Ho Nee Kit, and Tam Wai, have sold 29.8% of the company, valued at S$58.3m, to local fund management firm Pilgrim Partners Asia. The trio have retired from their board positions, effective January 18. New appointments include Choo Boon Tiong as vice-chairman and executive director, and David Seow Jun Hao and Haytham T KH S Al Essa as executive director and independent director, respectively. The divestment and board changes followed unusual price and volume movements in Fu Yu's shares.

site_title: Trial reopening of nightclubs and karaoke joints put off amid rise in community cases
summary: Singapore's trial reopening of nightclubs and karaoke joints has been postponed amid a spike in community Covid-19 cases. The Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of Home Affairs cited the risk of community transmission and cluster formation in enclosed spaces. Trials for bars and pubs continue, but operators of shortlisted nightclubs and karaoke joints will be helped to pivot or exit the industry, with some receiving government support. The pilot was initially set to run for three months.

site_title: Investing in the new normal for Asian banks
summary: Asian banks are expected to benefit from increased digitalisation, which will reduce operating costs and lead to higher net revenue growth. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital adoption, with changes in retail customer habits, regulatory changes, and increased demand for digital services among SMEs and large corporates. As a result, banks can expect cost savings of 0.7% to return on equity (RoE) and additional revenue growth of 0.1-0.7% to RoE. Investors can benefit from this theme by investing in Indonesian and Indian banks, such as BCA and BRI, which are well-positioned for digitalisation.

site_title: Europe car sales drop most on record last year
summary: Europe's car sales dropped 24% in 2021, the largest annual decline on record since 1990. Despite a strong finish in December, the industry suffered from a collapse in sales from March to May. However, electric vehicles were a rare bright spot, with BloombergNEF estimating that Europe's plug-in hybrid and battery-only vehicle sales exceeded China's for the first time, reaching 1.9 million in 2021. Europe's top two carmakers, Volkswagen and PSA, saw a limited decline in December, while others, including Daimler and Renault, saw significant drops.

site_title: EU's bond spree threatens future demand for debt
summary: The European Union's (EU) massive bond issuance, set to reach €750 billion, threatens to cannibalize future demand for its member countries' debt. Record-breaking social debt sales in 2020 drew record bidding, and the EU's joint issuance will dwarf that of most euro area sovereigns. Investors are expected to rebalance into sovereign, supranational, and agencies bonds, potentially reducing demand for national debt, and pushing up borrowing costs for individual governments. Despite this, EU debt may continue to attract investors due to its attractive yields and ESG factors.

site_title: Gig workers are employees; start treating them as such
summary: US grocery chain Albertsons plans to replace staff delivery drivers with independent contractors working for DoorDash, denying them essential labor protections. This decision follows a California ballot proposition and a Trump administration rule that allow companies to classify gig workers as independent contractors. The Biden administration can undo these measures and provide basic protections for gig workers, including minimum wage and unemployment insurance, to address the growing inequality and vulnerability of service workers.

site_title: Germany mulls tighter shutdown on virus variants
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel and state leaders are expected to extend and tighten a partial lockdown beyond January to combat the spread of more contagious virus variants. Draft measures include prolonging restrictions until mid-February, requiring medical masks on public transport and in shops, and encouraging remote work. The lockdown has brought about a "flattening of the infections curve," but experts warn that the trend may not be sustainable without stricter measures. Germany has seen a surge in new infections and daily deaths, with over 11,000 new cases recorded last week.

images.alt_text: Germany shuttered restaurants, leisure and sporting facilities in November.

site_title: Why are some mutual funds changing into ETFs?
summary: At least three mutual fund issuers, including Dimensional Fund Advisors and Guinness Atkinson Asset Management, plan to convert some of their mutual funds to exchange-traded funds (ETFs) due to their lower costs and flexibility. ETFs can be traded throughout the day, offering investors more transparency and lower tax bills. The conversion process, which began in 2018, aims to provide investors with more choices and potentially cut management fees by up to 0.15%. This move follows a trend where investors have been favoring ETFs over mutual funds, with ETFs posting total inflows of over $509 billion in 2020.

site_title: Can anyone beat Chadwick Boseman for the best-actor Oscar?
summary: The 2021 Oscar best-actor category is expected to be highly competitive, with Chadwick Boseman's posthumous nomination for his role in "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom" giving him an edge. However, up-and-comers Riz Ahmed, Kingsley Ben-Adir, and Delroy Lindo are also in the running, with Ahmed and Ben-Adir being considered potential breakouts. Other contenders include Sacha Baron Cohen, Tom Hanks, Anthony Hopkins, and Gary Oldman, with some voters potentially defaulting to big-name actors like Hanks. The category is expected to be one of the most competitive in Oscar history.

site_title: Brexit leaves some meat shipments rotting at European border
summary: British meat shipments are facing delays and potential losses due to new customs checks and health certificates required after the UK's departure from the European Union. Delays of up to five days are reported, with some shipments being returned or thrown away. The British Meat Processors Association blames the new post-Brexit customs system for the issues, estimating a 5-8% rise in costs for livestock trade. EU customers are also considering alternative suppliers, such as Spain or Ireland, amid the border chaos.

site_title: Crescent Cove Advisors launching special purpose acquisition company to target S-E Asian tech firms
summary: Singaporean tech investment firm Crescent Cove Advisors, founded by Heng Jun Hong, plans to launch a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) targeting South-east Asia's technology sector. The SPAC aims to raise around US$200 million and list on Nasdaq. Crescent Cove, which manages up to US$500 million in assets, has previously invested in US-based startups such as Luminar. The firm's SPAC will be led by Pandu Sjahrir and may attract investors including Yeh V-Nee, a co-founder of Value Partners. This move is part of the growing trend of SPACs in South-east Asia, with companies like Grab and Gojek reportedly eyeing public markets.

site_title: Sector-specific help, focus on jobs expected in Budget 2021
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 is expected to be a more modest one, shifting focus from firefighting measures to supporting recovery and preparing for the future. Jobs will remain a priority, with targeted support for sectors like travel and hospitality. The government may extend support measures for select sectors, such as catering services and tourism, but will taper off broader support. The Budget is also expected to retain a focus on employment, tackling skill mismatches, and investing in growth sectors like technology and human capital.

site_title: Entities of EHT file for bankruptcy protection
summary: Entities of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the US Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, with 27 entities listed. Estimated liabilities range from $500 million to $1 billion, and assets are valued at $500 million to $1 billion. The move comes after securityholders voted against a change of manager in December. Current troubles include defaults, legal proceedings, and employment-related claims, prompting the need for restructuring under Chapter 11.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Riverstone Resources, a subsidiary of Riverstone Holdings, has acquired industrial land in Malaysia for RM5 million to expand production capacity for cleanroom gloves. Oxley Holdings' Malaysian arm is partnering Pavilion Project Management to develop Oxley Towers in Kuala Lumpur. ARA Logos Logistics Trust has received valid acceptances for its preferential offering, with 225.4% oversubscription. Keppel Infrastructure Trust has secured a S$300 million facility agreement to finance its acquisition of Philippine Tank Storage International. Tee International has assured it can meet its debt obligations despite repayments falling due in a year or less.

site_title: China signals easing of deleveraging stance on big state firms
summary: China is shifting its focus from deleveraging state-run firms to maintaining debt levels, a move aimed at reassuring investors amid a wave of defaults at smaller firms. State-owned enterprises' credit ratings remain good, and their bond sizes are reasonable, according to a spokesperson. This stance suggests Beijing will avoid a significant reduction in debt, which could help contain default risks. The move is seen as a cautious approach to managing leverage risks, with regulators opting for a gradual reduction in debt levels through quality economic growth.

site_title: Takeover price for Sunningdale Tech raised to S$1.65 per share in final offer
summary: Sunningdale Tech's chairman and Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 have raised their offer price for the precision plastic components manufacturer to S$1.65 per share, up 6.5% from S$1.55. This comes after activist investor Quarz Capital Management criticized the proposed takeover price as "too low" and "significantly undervalues" the company. The new price is part of the final offer.

site_title: America should set sights high for post-Trump reconstruction
summary: The US inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden presents a unique opportunity to bolster liberal democracy globally, following the recent rise of illiberal populist governments. The Capitol storming, which undermined America's capacity to lead by example, has led to a shift in public opinion. Biden's administration should prioritize a comprehensive domestic agenda, advocate liberal democracy, and establish alliances with democratic countries. The US should respect national sovereignty, engage in multilateralism, and develop standards for cyberspace, artificial intelligence, and biotechnology. A credible strategy for backing liberal democracy is long overdue, and Biden's administration has the right mindset to provide global leadership.

site_title: Fintechs' moves to acquire Indonesian banks will rev up competition: Fitch
summary: Tech firms' acquisition of Indonesian banks is expected to boost competition in the region, but may not pose a significant challenge to incumbent lenders in the near term. Fintechs are likely to target underserved segments, and established banks have invested heavily in IT infrastructure. Smaller banks with sub-par digital offerings are at risk of losing out. However, fintechs backed by deep-pocketed corporates or with established platforms are more likely to sustain long-term competition, prompting closer regulatory scrutiny in markets with digital bank licensing frameworks.

site_title: BOJ seen buying fewer bonds if it widens yield-trading band
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may reduce its bond purchases if it allows the 10-year yield to fluctuate in a wider band, potentially leading to a steeper yield curve. Analysts say this move could boost market speculation and improve the pricing mechanism in Japan's moribund bond market. However, the BOJ is expected to keep its negative-rate policy on hold, and a review of its policy framework is possible in March. The decision could be influenced by the Japanese government's record debt sales and global market trends.

site_title: US dollar drops; Euro gains 0.5% to US$1.21
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.3% to 90.472 on the dollar index, following a 2% rise in 2021, as investors await US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen's testimony on fiscal stimulus and a market-determined exchange rate. The euro rose 0.5% to $1.2132, while commodity-linked currencies like the Australian dollar and sterling also gained. Analysts expect the dollar to remain weak, citing the need for fiscal stimulus and a commitment to market-set currency rates.

site_title: Employers should lead by example to boost Covid-19 vaccine take-up rate
summary: Singapore is in the fourth week of its Covid-19 vaccination programme, aiming for an 80% vaccination rate to build herd immunity. Employers are encouraged to lead by example by encouraging staff to get vaccinated, with some companies offering incentives such as paid time off and reimbursement of medical consultation fees. The government has also established a vaccine fund for customers and is providing clear information on the vaccines. By promoting vaccination among employees and setting an example from leadership, Singapore can boost the take-up rate and reduce the risk of future outbreaks.

site_title: Okinawa declares coronavirus emergency as cases spike
summary: Okinawa, Japan's southernmost prefecture, declared a state of emergency due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with 113 confirmed cases on Tuesday, its third-highest daily tally. The emergency measures include closing restaurants and bars by 8 pm and restricting non-urgent outings after 8 pm. This declaration comes six months before the Summer Olympics in Japan, which the national government has vowed to hold despite growing public opposition.

site_title: SPACs can benefit Singapore, but implementation will determine success: participants
summary: Singapore is considering allowing Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to list on its exchange, which could benefit the market and provide exit opportunities for tech companies in the region. Market participants see the structure as a way to bring companies to the public market quickly and efficiently, with more certainty for pricing compared to traditional IPOs. However, concerns about the quality of companies being acquired and the potential for overvaluation need to be addressed. Successful implementation will depend on how the listing rules are drawn up, with proper disclosures and protecting shareholders' interests remaining critical.

site_title: Reliable conglomerates in an unreliable world
summary: Conglomerates, made up of unrelated businesses with significant stakes, can operate independently while maintaining parent company influence. Despite the potential for synergy, many conglomerates have resisted breaking up, citing benefits such as capital access and diversified economic exposure. Conglomerates typically retain 60% of profits for internal use, with median free cash flow yields of 9.4%. Companies with high retention ratios and return on equity, like Berkshire Hathaway, have delivered high total returns for shareholders. Investors may consider conglomerates with high retention ratios and return on equity for diversification and dividend growth opportunities.

site_title: Bonds in hardest-hit sectors poised to recover
summary: Bonds in hardest-hit sectors, such as healthcare and travel, are poised to recover as the US economy recovers and the COVID-19 pandemic slows. A new administration under President Joe Biden is expected to focus on rebuilding the US economy, including a $1.9 trillion stimulus package. Accommodative monetary policy and a new fiscal package will support corporate bonds, particularly those in travel-related sectors. Investors may consider bonds from companies like Shangri-La Hotel and Ascott Residence Trust, which have strong brand values and balance sheets. The pace of coronavirus infections is expected to stage a meaningful turnaround this year, leading to a significant demand recovery for travel.

site_title: SBF, trade bodies lead way on fair employment
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and 29 trade associations and chambers have pledged to support fair hiring and employment practices, aligning with the Ministry of Manpower's Fair Consideration Framework and Tripartite Guidelines. The pledge aims to promote positive workplace relations, fair hiring, and development opportunities, with a focus on merit-based hiring. The move is seen as a commitment to attracting and retaining top talent, both locally and internationally, to drive growth and recovery in Singapore's economy.

site_title: The Biden bulldozer is ready to roll on
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden will face significant challenges upon taking office, including a deadly pandemic and economic crisis. Unlike previous inaugurations, Biden's ceremony will be attended by a smaller crowd due to security concerns, with over 20,000 military and police personnel surrounding the Capitol. Biden plans to push forward with a "blitz of grand policy and legislative ideas," including a $1.9 trillion fiscal rescue package to combat the pandemic and revive the economy. However, he may face opposition from Republicans, who have vowed to sabotage his plans, and a polarized electorate, with 7 in 10 Republicans doubting Biden's legitimacy and only 12% confident in his decision-making.

site_title: American democratic experiment still works despite Trumpian assault
summary: US President Joe Biden will be inaugurated on Wednesday, marking a shift away from the tumultuous Trump presidency. Despite Trump's attempts to undermine democracy, Biden aims to rekindle the "shining city on the hill" of American democracy. With a focus on unity and healing, Biden's agenda includes pandemic relief, economic aid, and climate change initiatives. His speech will attempt to change the channel to more positive public-service programming, and his administration may convene a court to cancel Trump from future offices.

images.alt_text: Thousands of flags creating a "field of flags" are seen on the National Mall in Washington, DC on Jan 18 ahead of Joe Biden's swearing-in as the 46th US president.

site_title: Yellen says aid to jobless, small firms 'biggest bang' for buck
summary: Janet Yellen, President-elect Joe Biden's Treasury secretary pick, told lawmakers that aid to the unemployed and small businesses would provide the "biggest bang for the buck" in the US$1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief plan. Yellen emphasized the need for "act big" to rescue an economy battered by the coronavirus. Republicans have expressed concerns over the plan's size and components, citing a need for targeted relief efforts and avoiding liberal economic reforms. Yellen's confirmation hearing is ongoing, with Democrats prioritizing swift approval given the state of the economy.

site_title: WHO must be reformed to give it necessary powers, says pandemic panel
summary: An independent panel reviewing the WHO and the global response to the Covid-19 pandemic has concluded that the organization is underpowered and underfunded, requiring reform to be more effective. The panel's co-chair, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, stated that WHO is reformable, aiming to provide concrete recommendations for the world to respond faster and better in the future. The report's release comes amid the global response to the pandemic, emphasizing the need for WHO reform to address its current limitations.

site_title: On minimum wage, America does have a radical party - but it is not the Democrats
summary: A growing divide exists in US politics over minimum wage, with Democrats advocating for a $15-an-hour increase and Republicans opposing it. However, a significant majority of Americans, including Republicans, support raising the minimum wage. In fact, a referendum in Florida last year resulted in a landslide victory for a $15 minimum wage. Economists now widely agree that raising the minimum wage to this level would have minimal negative effects on employment, but significant benefits for workers. The opposition to the minimum wage increase can be seen as a radical stance, with Republicans out of step with public opinion and at odds with mainstream economics.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust expects properties in countries with domestic travel market to recover faster
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) expects its properties in countries with domestic travel markets, such as Australia, Japan, and the UK, to recover faster than others due to pent-up demand in the leisure segment. Corporate travel demand is expected to recover next, while large-scale events will take longer. FHT has secured quarantine businesses in Singapore, Sydney, and Melbourne, and its other properties are seeking revenue through domestic travel or staycation business. The company's investment portfolio valued at S$2.25 billion as of Sept 30, 2020, declined 3.5% year-over-year due to the pandemic's impact on cash flow. FHT maintains an active capital management strategy and has sufficient debt headroom.

site_title: India plans foreign investment rule changes that could hit Amazon
summary: India is considering changes to its foreign investment rules for e-commerce, which could force Amazon and other foreign companies to restructure their ties with sellers. The government is looking to prevent foreign e-commerce firms from holding indirect stakes in sellers and may ban online sales by sellers who purchase goods from these firms. The changes could hurt Amazon, which has indirect equity stakes in two of its biggest online sellers in India. The move comes amid growing complaints from brick-and-mortar retailers and an antitrust investigation.

site_title: Evergrande's rejig offers measure of Xi
summary: China's struggling property developer Evergrande, with $25 billion in debt, is undergoing a restructuring under President Xi Jinping's efforts to clean up the sector. The company, founded by 62-year-old Hui Ka Yan, is selling off projects, reducing debt, and exploring new sectors like electric vehicles. Evergrande's high leverage ratio poses liquidity risks, and its stock has lost nearly a third of its value since August. The company's assets total $2.3 trillion, and it holds China's largest land bank, making it "too big to fail" and a key measure of Xi's commitment to reform.

site_title: CapitaLand's building in CBD struggles to find tenants
summary: CapitaLand's 51-floor integrated development, CapitaSpring, in Singapore's central business district is struggling to find tenants, securing only 38% of its 647,000 square feet of net lettable area despite being 75% completed. Typically, at this stage, buildings would have leased out more than half of their space. The pandemic has upended the office market, with work-from-home arrangements becoming long-term for some companies, contributing to lower demand. Despite this, CapitaSpring has attracted interest from tenants and prospective clients due to the limited office supply in the area.

site_title: Sustainable (or ESG) investing: Are we on the same page?
summary: Investors are increasingly seeking sustainable investing options, but the terms "sustainable investing," "responsible investing," "socially responsible investing," and "impact investing" are often used interchangeably, leading to confusion. A framework is needed to distinguish between these approaches, which include sustainable investing, socially responsible investing, best-in-class investing, and impact investing. Each approach incorporates ESG considerations in different ways, such as exclusions, ESG integration, and voting, and investors should look beyond product names to understand what an ESG-labelled product entails. Industry efforts, including a global industry disclosure standard, aim to provide greater transparency and comparability for investors, helping to achieve consistency and alignment.

site_title: China's sovereign fund revamps overseas investment committees
summary: China's sovereign fund, China Investment Corp (CIC), has revamped its overseas investment committees to boost efficiency and achieve its goal of increasing private assets to half of its global portfolio by the end of 2022. The fund has formed two new committees to approve investments in public and non-public assets, replacing previous bodies with overlapping responsibilities. The change aims to implement asset allocation strategies and limit exposure to volatile public markets, which have been complicated by market rallies and protectionism. CIC's long-term goal is to expand non-public investments for stable returns.

site_title: Malaysia expands lockdown measures to most states as virus spreads
summary: Malaysia has expanded lockdown measures to most states as the coronavirus spreads, with a two-week lockdown in effect across 12 states, including the capital Kuala Lumpur. The lockdown will also be imposed on six other states starting Friday. The move aims to alleviate the strain on the healthcare system, which is at a breaking point. The country has reported 165,371 coronavirus infections and 619 deaths. The lockdown restrictions will allow essential sectors to operate, but a nationwide travel ban remains in place. The move has been criticized by the opposition as an attempt to consolidate power.

site_title: New local Covid-19 cluster; 8-year-old boy added to para-vet cluster
summary: A new local COVID-19 cluster has been identified in Singapore, with 8-year-old boy added to the para-vet cluster. The cluster includes 33-year-old Chinese man, his wife, and housemate, who tested positive for the infection, as well as a 48-year-old woman who works at a food processing factory. The boy, who is a student, developed a fever while in quarantine and tested positive for the virus. The cluster brings Singapore's total number of cases to 59,157, with 45 patients remaining in hospital and 189 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: HSBC to axe 82 branches in UK, cut services in others
summary: HSBC plans to close 82 branches in the UK, leaving 511, due to a drop in footfall and a surge in digital banking. Many remaining branches will be remodelled with reduced counter services. The bank aims to redeploy staff to nearby branches, where possible.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust announces results of preferential offering
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust announced the results of its preferential offering, receiving valid acceptances and excess applications for 205.4 million units, representing about 225.4% of the available units. The trust will issue 91.1 million units at S$0.5525, raising S$50 million. After the listing, Logos Units No. 1 will collectively own 136.4 million units, or 10.7% of the total units issued.

site_title: Milan Men's Fashion Week longs for a bright winter
summary: Milan Men's Fashion Week showcased autumn-winter 2021 collections with a focus on comforting fabrics, bright colors, and uninhibited movement, reflecting the new normal of interactions at a distance due to COVID-19. Designs featured cozy indoor-wear elements, such as long-johns, dressing-gowns, and reversible coats, blended with outdoor styles like shorts and windbreakers. Bright colors and whimsical touches, like doodles from artist Noel Fielding, added a playful touch to the collections, with designers prioritizing flexibility and movement in their designs.

images.alt_text: There were signs everywhere of cosy, comfortable indoor-wear leaving its mark on outdoor styles. Even windbreaker brand K-Way blurred the lines between indoor and outdoor wear.

site_title: Hong Kong unemployment climbs to highest level since 2004
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate soared to 6.6% in the October-to-December period, the highest level in 16 years, as the city struggled under social distancing measures. The number of unemployed rose by about 1,500 to 245,800, mainly due to the fourth wave of local Covid-19 cases. Local businesses, particularly in the consumption and tourism-related sectors, are severely affected, with restrictions weighing on consumer spending. The economy is expected to struggle through the first half of the year before a recovery emerges in the second half, depending on vaccine roll-out.

site_title: GM, Microsoft lead US$2b round for self-driving startup
summary: General Motors and Microsoft have led a $2 billion investment round in self-driving car startup Cruise, raising its post-investment valuation to an estimated $30 billion. The partnership gives Cruise access to Microsoft's cloud and edge-computing capabilities, competing with Waymo, which has Alphabet Inc.'s software capabilities. Cruise, majority owned by GM, also has Honda Motor and other institutional investors participating in the new round, expanding its software capabilities and valuation.

site_title: Entities of Eagle Hospitality Trust file for bankruptcy protection in Delaware court
summary: Entities of Eagle Hospitality Trust filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in Delaware court on Monday, with 27 entities within the trust stable filing for protection. Estimated liabilities range from $500 million to $1 billion, and assets valued at $500 million to $1 billion at end-September 2020. The court will help restructure debts and obligations, with creditors ranging from 1,000 to 5,000. The bankruptcy filing allows for a reorganization of the business affairs, debts, and assets.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher ahead of Yellen speech, spotlight on earnings
summary: Wall Street's main indexes rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.74% to 31,041.45, the S&P 500 gaining 0.79% to 3,798.12, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 1.03% to 13,132.46. Strong earnings from US banks and Halliburton drove the gains, with shares of Goldman Sachs and Bank of America also rising after beating profit estimates. US Treasury Secretary nominee Janet Yellen is set to testify to the Senate Finance Committee, advocating for a hefty fiscal spending package to boost the economy.

site_title: Economists still expect more monetary support, despite Malaysia's latest fiscal package
summary: Malaysia's latest fiscal package, totaling RM15 billion, aims to offset the effects of Covid-19 curbs and the reimposition of the Movement Control Order. Despite this, economists still expect a 25 basis points cut to the overnight policy rate, citing growth jitters and the threat of tariffs. The package is seen as insufficient to address economic concerns, and a rate cut is expected to provide further monetary support.

site_title: Thai woman handed record four-decade jail term for lese majeste
summary: A Thai woman, Anchan, has been jailed for 43 years under the country's strict lese majeste laws for insulting the royal family. She was convicted of 29 counts and initially sentenced to 87 years, but the sentence was halved due to her confession. The verdict has sparked concerns about the use of the law to silence democracy protesters, who demand reforms to the monarchy. This is the harshest punishment ever handed out under the law, and critics warn it could backfire and damage the monarchy's reputation domestically and internationally.

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit more than doubles on underwriting, trading boost
summary: Goldman Sachs' fourth-quarter profit more than doubled to $4.36 billion, driven by a 23% surge in global markets revenue and a 195% increase in equity underwriting fees from blockbuster IPOs. The bank's net earnings per share rose to $12.08, beating analyst estimates. Despite a $3-billion hit from a settlement with US regulators, Goldman's performance was in line with broader gains for trading units across Wall Street banks. The bank reiterated its three-year targets for profitability and expense savings.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs dwarfed Wall Street estimates as its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, powered by another blowout performance at its trading business and a surge in fees from underwriting a string of blockbuster IPOs.

site_title: Digital work platform Citrix to buy Vista's Wrike for US$2.25b
summary: Citrix Systems has agreed to acquire Wrike, a project management platform, for $2.25 billion from Vista Equity Partners. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2021. Wrike counts Google, Airbnb, Dell, and Siemens among its customers, and its CEO, Andrew Filev, will continue to lead the company after the merger. Citrix plans to finance the deal with a combination of new debt and existing cash and investments. The acquisition is in line with the growing demand for virtual collaboration technologies amid the remote work trend.

site_title: ByteDance launches Douyin Pay, its mobile payment service for China
summary: ByteDance, the owner of the popular short video app Douyin, has launched Douyin Pay, its third-party mobile payment service for China. The move aims to expand the company's e-commerce business and enhance user experience. Douyin Pay will supplement existing payment options, such as Alipay and WeChat Pay, and is seen as a step towards Douyin becoming a major e-commerce platform. The launch comes as China's financial regulators tighten oversight, and ByteDance seeks to capitalize on the growing demand for mobile payments.

site_title: Tinder co-founder leads US$2.1m seed funding in Singapore fintech Volopay
summary: Singapore-based fintech Volopay has raised US$2.1 million in seed funding led by Justin Mateen, co-founder of Tinder. The funding round also includes investors such as Soma Capital, Y Combinator, and angel investors from Razorpay. Volopay, founded in 2019, offers financial solutions to businesses in the Asia-Pacific, including corporate cards and money transfers. The startup plans to use the funds for hiring, product development, and international expansion, including a launch in Australia this month.

site_title: Bank of America profit falls as consumer banking business falters
summary: Bank of America reported a 13% drop in consumer banking revenue to $8.2 billion in the fourth quarter, citing lower interest rates and a decline in credit card activity. Net income fell to $5.21 billion, or 59 cents per share, from $6.75 billion, or 74 cents per share, a year earlier. The bank relies on higher interest rates to drive profit growth, which has been impacted by the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts. Bank of America's board approved a $3.2 billion share repurchase program in the first quarter.

site_title: Oxley Holdings teams up with Pavilion to develop Oxley Towers in Kuala Lumpur
summary: Oxley Holdings' Malaysian arm, Oxley Rising, has partnered with Pavilion Project Management to develop Oxley Towers, a mixed-use complex in Kuala Lumpur. The freehold property spans 12,554 sqm and has a gross development value of S$1.1 billion. The project includes two hotel towers, residences, an office tower, and retail space, near the Maxis Tower and Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre. Oxley Holdings' CEO, Ching Chiat Kwong, expressed excitement for the partnership, citing Pavilion's expertise and networks to elevate the project's excellence.

site_title: FedEx to cut up to 6,300 jobs in Europe on TNT integration
summary: FedEx plans to cut up to 6,300 jobs in Europe as part of its integration with TNT Express, citing duplication in delivery networks. The move is expected to generate a pretax cost of $300-575 million from severance benefits. The integration aims to offer "greater coverage, speed of delivery, and enhanced service levels" as a single company. FedEx President Karen Reddington stated that the process will allow for a unified operation, enabling the company to better serve its customers.

site_title: STI shy of 3,000 points as it inches up 0.18%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.18% or 5.52 points to 2,995.92 points, narrowly missing the 3,000 mark. Jefferies' global equity strategist Sean Darby is bullish on Singapore shares, citing a strong dividend story and ample liquidity. Gainers outnumbered decliners 287 to 195, with S$1.40 billion in transactions over 2.93 billion securities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A US-based tech investment firm, Crescent Cove Advisors, has filed to launch a special purpose acquisition company (Spac) targeting South-east Asian tech firms. This comes after Singaporean Heng Jun Hong founded the firm. Meanwhile, nightclubs and karaoke joints in Singapore are delayed in reopening due to a spike in community cases. The High Court also overturned an earlier ruling allowing creditors to seize money from joint bank accounts. Additionally, the takeover price for Sunningdale Tech has been raised to S$1.65 per share, and First Reit unit-holders voted in favour of proposed restructuring.

site_title: Tee International tells bourse it is able to fulfil borrowing obligations
summary: Tee International, a Singapore-listed company, has assured the Singapore Exchange that it can fulfill its S$44 million loan obligations due in a year or less. The company has a cash balance of S$21.2 million and plans to repay the loans using cash generated from trade receivables and contract assets. Tee International swung into profitability in the second quarter, recording a profit after tax of S$1.8 million, despite lower revenue and higher borrowing costs. The company's outstanding order book stands at S$251.2 million.

site_title: HDB issues S$800m notes due in 2026
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has issued S$800 million worth of five-year notes with a fixed coupon rate of 0.635% per annum, rated AAA by Fitch Ratings. The notes will mature on January 19, 2026, and were launched under HDB's S$32 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme. The Singapore Exchange has approved the listing of the new notes on the bourse, with joint lead managers and book-runners including Bank of China (Singapore), Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Singapore), and OCBC.

site_title: Kids sign up for vaccine trials in next step to conquer Covid
summary: Children in the US are participating in vaccine trials for COVID-19, with over 2,000 adolescents aged 12-15 enrolled in Pfizer's trial. The trials aim to ensure the vaccines are safe for young people, who are crucial in breaking the transmission chain. Experts believe vaccinating children could help achieve herd immunity and reduce the spread of the virus. Trials are ongoing for Moderna and Oxford University, with initial data expected by summer. The goal is to return to normalcy for students and their families, with many parents hoping a vaccine will allow them to send their children back to school.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust enters into S$300m facility agreement
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has entered into a S$300 million facility agreement with various lenders to partially finance its acquisition of Philippine Tank Storage International (PTSI), a petroleum products import storage facility in the Philippines. KIT had previously announced a conditional agreement with its Philippine partner Metro Pacific Investments Corporation (MPIC) to fully acquire PTSI. The facility agreement is part of KIT's efforts to secure funding for the acquisition, which is expected to be completed once the conditional agreement is fulfilled.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.64 points to 1,601.88. The index saw a volume of 6.806 billion lots worth RM4.829 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 625 to 496, indicating a bearish trend in the market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished with a 2.70% gain, driven by interest from mainland Chinese investors, lifting the Hang Seng Index to 29,642.28. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.83% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.96%.

site_title: UK's Hammerson gets less than half of Q1 rent as Covid-19 curbs tighten
summary: London-based shopping centre operator Hammerson Plc received less than half of the rents due for the first quarter due to stricter Covid-19 restrictions in the UK and Europe. The company reported 41% of first-quarter rent received, with UK destinations collecting similar levels. Hammerson cited lockdowns, reduced footfall, and evening curfews as factors. The company waived 21 million pounds of rent for fiscal 2020 and shares were 1% higher in early trade. This is the latest in a series of rent collections below expectations for mall operators.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on rebound in miners, financials
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.2% to 6,742.60, rebounding from a 0.8% drop on Monday, driven by gains in mining and financial stocks. Bingo Industries, the top gainer, surged 20.4% after a private equity firm made a US$1.76 billion buyout offer. Positive GDP figures from China and stabilizing domestic Covid-19 cases also contributed to the recovery.

site_title: Europe car sales drop most on record in year bedevilled by virus
summary: European car sales plummeted 24% in 2021, the largest annual drop since records began in 1990, due to the initial Covid-19 outbreak. Despite a strong finish to the year, the industry's collapse in March, April, and May proved difficult to recover from. However, the industry managed a single month of growth in December, driven by Volkswagen AG and PSA Group. In contrast, China's auto market expanded throughout the second half of the year.

site_title: Taiwan cancels major festival as domestic Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Taiwan has cancelled the Taiwan Lantern Festival due to a surge in locally transmitted COVID-19 cases, the largest daily rise in nearly 11 months. The festival, which attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors, will not take place in mid-February. The decision was made after four new cases were reported, all related to a hospital outbreak in the northern city of Taoyuan. The festival's cancellation is a priority for pandemic prevention, according to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

site_title: High Court decision reshapes earlier ruling on creditors' claim on joint bank accounts
summary: The High Court overturned provisional garnishee orders for joint bank accounts, setting a high bar for creditors to prove ownership of funds in joint accounts. A recent case, Timing Limited vs Pacific Star Holdings, saw the court reject the claim that all money in joint accounts belonged solely to the debtor, Tay Toh Hin. The judge ruled that the debtor's frequent transfers to a joint account, as well as jointly incurred expenses, did not conclusively determine ownership of funds. The decision echoes the court's earlier ruling, stating that a "strong prima facie case" is not watertight and must be weighed against evidence provided by the garnishee and joint account holder.

site_title: Hong Kong unemployment rises to highest level since 2004
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate surged to 6.6% in the October-to-December period, the highest level in 16 years, amid strict social distancing measures to control Covid-19 cases. The number of unemployed rose by 1,500 to 245,800, with the underemployment rate remaining at 3.4%. Local businesses struggle due to restrictions on group gatherings, early restaurant closures, and a lack of tourism. The economy is expected to continue struggling through the first half of the year before a recovery emerges in the second half, depending on the global rollout of vaccines.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose in December to the highest level in 16 years as the city struggled under stiff social distancing measures to control new waves of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS sees 'pre-emptive' policy response to curb higher property prices
summary: DBS Group Research warns that a 5% or higher annual increase in the Singapore property price index (PPI) could lead to "bubble territory" and pressure household affordability ratios. The analysts suggest a pre-emptive policy response, such as tweaking the additional buyer's stamp duty or shortening mortgage tenures, to curb price increases. The government is monitoring the market closely, and listed developers like CapitaLand and City Developments Limited have been prudent in their land-banking strategy, which may mitigate the impact of policy changes.

site_title: Sequoia investing in Auto1 at six billion euro value before IPO: sources
summary: Sequoia Capital has agreed to invest in Auto1 Group at a valuation of about six billion euros ahead of the German online car-trading platform's initial public offering (IPO). The US venture capital firm and rival fund Lone Pine Capital will each buy about 50 million euros of Auto1 stock from early investor DN Capital. Sequoia and Lone Pine plan to invest at least 50 million euros apiece in Auto1's IPO. This investment marks a vote of confidence in Auto1 and its online car-buying and selling business.

site_title: Trial reopening of nightclubs and karaoke joints put off amid spike in community cases
summary: Singapore's trial reopening of nightclubs and karaoke joints, initially set for January, has been postponed due to a spike in community Covid-19 cases. The Ministry of Trade and Industry and Ministry of Home Affairs cited the risk of further community transmission and cluster formation in enclosed spaces. The trials will now be reassessed, with authorities working with shortlisted operators to tighten safe-management measures. The decision affects 12 businesses, including two nightclubs and 10 karaoke outlets, which were set to participate in the three-month pilot programme.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.39% to 28,633.46, while the broader Topix index gained 0.56% to 1,855.84, driven by bargain-hunting following two days of profit-taking. Investors sought to buy on dips amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on upbeat earnings reports
summary: European shares rose on Tuesday, driven by upbeat earnings reports from Rio Tinto and Logitech, with the STOXX 600 index gaining 0.4% and the DAX and CAC 40 indices also rising 0.4%. Rio Tinto's iron ore shipments increased 2.4% and Logitech raised its sales growth and profit outlook.
