Asian markets rallied on optimism about China's economy, with stocks closing near all-time highs as investors expect China's economic strength to support regional growth.

site_title: 30 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including four in the community
summary: Singapore reported 30 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,157, as of January 19. The cases included 26 imported cases and four community cases, with no new cases from worker's dormitories. Two community cases were linked to the police para-veterinarian cluster, bringing the cluster's total to six. Both cases, a 43-year-old Singaporean and a 66-year-old Malaysian, did not seek medical treatment despite symptoms.

site_title: Ex-regional MD of WeWork launches fintech firm with buy-now-pay-later solution
summary: Former WeWork executive Turochas "T" Fuad has launched Pace Enterprise, a fintech firm offering a buy-now-pay-later solution. The Singapore-based startup raised a "high seven-figure" amount in seed funding from Temasek's Vertex Ventures and Alpha JWC. Pace aims to expand to 5,000 merchant partners by 2021, with a focus on underserved populations. The platform matches customers with spending limits for interest-free instalments, and has already partnered with over 200 merchants in South-east Asia.

site_title: Japan business lobby says blanket pay rises 'unrealistic' amid pandemic pain
summary: Japan's largest business lobby, Keidanren, has expressed concerns over blanket pay rises amid the COVID-19 pandemic, calling them "unrealistic." The group's priority is job protection, not wage hikes, as companies face economic and health challenges. This stance may lead to tough negotiations with labour unions, which have called for 2% uniform base pay hikes. Japan's labour market has shifted towards merit-based wages, and unions now prioritize job security and income gap reduction over aggressive pay hikes. Negotiations will conclude by mid-March.

site_title: China seen keeping lending benchmark unchanged
summary: China's benchmark lending rate is likely to remain unchanged at 3.85% for the ninth straight month, according to a Reuters poll of 26 traders and analysts. The one-year Loan Prime Rate and five-year tenor are expected to remain steady, with only four respondents forecasting a rise in the LPR. China's economy has recovered from the coronavirus shock, with growth beating expectations in the fourth quarter, and policymakers are expected to maintain a slightly dovish bias near term, driven by uncertainty and uneven economic recovery.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound on Samsung Elec, Hyundai Motor boost
summary: South Korean shares surged 2.61% on Tuesday, marking the sharpest gain since January 8, driven by a 11.2% boost in auto stocks led by Hyundai Motor's 8.5% surge. The KospI index closed at 3,092.66, its highest level since January 8.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars buoyed by risk-on mood
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar, with the Aussie increasing 0.3% to US$0.7705 and the kiwi dollar reaching US$0.7134. This was driven by renewed optimism that China will continue to support growth in the region, with China's economy showing signs of picking up speed in the fourth quarter. However, analysts expect the dollar to weaken in the coming days due to expectations of US President-elect Joe Biden's focus on economic stimulus and coronavirus inoculations.

site_title: China rescuers drill new 'lifelines' to trapped gold miners
summary: Chinese rescuers drilled new channels to reach 12 gold miners trapped underground for nine days, with dwindling food supplies and rising waters threatening their survival. The miners, 22 workers who were injured, were 540 meters underground after an explosion damaged the entrance. Rescuers have sent food, medicine, and paper down thin shafts, but progress is slow due to hard rock and water flow. A telephone connection has been set up, and footage shows dozens of rescuers clearing the main return shaft.

site_title: Philippines now free of H5N6 bird flu, but monitoring another strain
summary: The Philippines is now free of the highly pathogenic H5N6 bird flu virus, according to the Department of Agriculture. The World Organization for Animal Health declared the country virus-free on January 8, after resolving outbreaks in Pampanga and Rizal provinces. However, the Philippines is still monitoring another strain, H5N8, detected in France, South Korea, the Netherlands, and Poland, and has imposed a temporary ban on importing domestic and wild birds and their products from these countries.

site_title: First Reit unit-holders vote in favour of proposed restructuring
summary: First Reit unit-holders voted overwhelmingly in favour of proposed restructuring of Lippo Karawaci master lease agreements and a whitewash resolution waiving the right to receive a takeover offer from OUE. The resolutions were approved by 91.25% and 90.5% of unit-holders, respectively. The restructuring aims to address First Reit's financial difficulties, which include a negative cash flow position since 2015. The company plans to use S$158.2 million in gross proceeds to repay debt and set aside funds for fees and working capital.

site_title: Macquarie Consortium bids S$2.35b for waste firm Bingo
summary: Macquarie Consortium bids S$2.35b for Bingo Industries Ltd., offering A$3.50 in cash for each share, 28% higher than Monday's close. The bid is part of a consortium with CPE Capital, and discussions and due diligence are ongoing. Bingo is considering the offer but has not ruled out a deal. The acquisition would give the consortium a network of recycling and waste-management facilities in Australia.

site_title: LMIRT raises S$281m in rights issue
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) raised S$281 million in a rights issue, with 125.4% of preferential offering units subscribed. The issue was oversubscribed, with excess applications totaling S$352 million. The funds will be used for the acquisition of strata title units in Lippo Mall Puri and as working capital. The trust's units traded 1.4% lower at 7 cents following the announcement.

site_title: In farewell video, Melania Trump says be passionate, but not violent
summary: Melania Trump released a farewell video message as she prepares to leave the White House, focusing on the importance of kindness, integrity, and non-violent behavior. She made a fleeting reference to her husband, Donald Trump, and his supporters' storming of the US Capitol. Melania emphasized the value of passion and encouraged people to build good habits into their daily lives, while condemning violence as "never the answer." The Trumps' departure from the White House has been marked by controversy, including their refusal to congratulate President Joe Biden and attend his inauguration.

site_title: Asia: Investors eye recovery as most markets rise, Yellen in focus
summary: Most Asian markets rose on optimism about the global economic recovery and vaccine rollouts, with Hong Kong and Tokyo gaining over 2% and Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Taipei gaining more than 1%. Investors await the Senate confirmation hearing for Treasury secretary pick Janet Yellen, which may impact US President Joe Biden's stimulus proposal. World virus cases broke 95 million, with economists warning of a risk of a longer, more painful recession if aid is not approved.

images.alt_text: Optimism about the global economic recovery and vaccine rollouts trumped ongoing concerns about soaring virus infections Tuesday with most Asian markets clocking up big gains.

site_title: Crescent Cove Advisors launching Spac to target South-east Asian tech firms
summary: San Francisco-based tech investment firm Crescent Cove Advisors, founded by Singaporean Heng Jun Hong, is launching a special purpose acquisition company (Spac) targeting South-east Asian tech firms. The firm aims to raise around $200 million and list its shares on Nasdaq, with Pandu Sjahrir, an investor based in Indonesia, joining the Spac's board. Crescent Cove has previously invested in US-based startups and has managed over $500 million in assets, with its biggest bet being in Luminar, a self-driving vehicle sensor startup.

site_title: Vietnam top coffee shipper Intimex plans to offer 49% stake
summary: Vietnam's largest coffee bean exporter, Intimex Group, plans to offer up to a 49% stake to foreign investors to expand its instant coffee factory. The company aims to surpass Nestle SA as Vietnam's biggest instant coffee supplier by 2025, with a planned annual capacity of 20,000 tons. Talks with foreign investors are expected to begin after the factory reaches its designed capacity of 4,000 tons this quarter. The company plans to list shares on one of Vietnam's stock exchanges.

site_title: Fintechs' plans to buy Indonesian banks will raise competition: Fitch
summary: Fintech firms' plans to acquire Indonesian banks will add color to the region's financing landscape, but are unlikely to pose a material challenge to incumbent lenders in the near term. Tech firms will initially target underserved or niche segments, while established banks have invested in digital infrastructure. Fitch believes the impact will be manageable in the near term, but fintechs backed by deep-pocketed corporates or with established platforms are more likely to provide formidable competition over the longer term.

site_title: Qatar wealth fund plans Asia push to diversify from Europe, US
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, the Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), plans to diversify its $300 billion investment portfolio by focusing on Asia, following substantial investments in Europe over the past decade. Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani stated that Asia has been on the fund's radar and will receive priority investments, with locations such as India, Malaysia, and China targeted. The fund will continue to prioritize North American deals, but aims to rebalance its portfolio through Asian investments.

site_title: Germany mulls tighter shutdown as virus variants fuel fears
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel and state leaders are expected to extend and tighten a partial lockdown beyond January, amid fears over virus variant strains believed to be more contagious. The current measures, which include shutting down restaurants and most shops, have brought a "flattening of the infections curve" but experts warn that more drastic measures are needed to control the spread of the virus. Virus variants first seen in Britain and South Africa pose a significant risk to sustaining the current trend, and the government is considering measures such as working from home and reducing public transport usage.

site_title: Chinese city rushes to build massive Covid-19 quarantine centre
summary: China is rapidly constructing a massive Covid-19 quarantine centre in Shijiazhuang city to curb the growing outbreak. The facility, expected to hold over 4,000 people, is equipped with amenities and will house close contacts of confirmed patients. Construction began on January 13 as northern Chinese cities placed millions under lockdown. The move comes as China prepares for the Lunar New Year holiday, which poses challenges to virus prevention. The quarantine centre is part of China's efforts to contain the virus, despite the rest of the world struggling with mounting deaths and overburdened hospitals.

images.alt_text: Thousands of prefabricated rooms fill a vast field on the outskirts of China's Shijiazhuang city as construction crews work around the clock to erect a large quarantine facility to curb the city's growing Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Carmakers redesign cars for millions of ageing drivers in Japan
summary: Carmakers in Japan are redesigning cars to make them more user-friendly for elderly drivers, following a series of accidents involving elderly drivers. Automatic brakes and advanced safety features, such as lane departure correction and pedestrian detection, are being standardised. Toyota and Subaru are employing smart technology, including stereo cameras and artificial intelligence, to detect potential hazards and prevent accidents. The goal is to make cars safer for elderly drivers, who are increasingly confined to their homes due to public transport shortages in rural areas. Industry leaders aim to eliminate fatal accidents by 2030.

images.alt_text: Carmakers in Japan, where almost 30 per cent of the population is 65 or older, are taking the lead on adapting cars so the nation's legions of elderly drivers can feel more confident - and be safer - behind the wheel.

site_title: France backs non-GMO regulation for crop gene-editing in EU
summary: France's agriculture minister, Julien Denormandie, opposes the European Union's decision to regulate gene-editing techniques for crops under strict genetically modified organism (GMO) rules. Denormandie claims that gene-editing techniques, known as New Breeding Techniques (NBT), are distinct from GMOs and should not be subject to the same regulations. France, the EU's largest agricultural producer, has banned the cultivation of GMO crops and is considering how to respond to a ruling requiring it to change its mutagenesis regulations in line with the EU court's decision.

site_title: Disneyland Paris postpones re-opening to April
summary: Disneyland Paris has postponed its re-opening to April 2, seven weeks later than planned due to the ongoing Covid-19 crisis. The park, which employs 17,000 people, initially targeted a February 13 re-opening but cited health conditions as a factor. The Disney group has also announced 32,000 job cuts at its theme park activities worldwide. Management expects a return to pre-pandemic levels of activity only in 2022.

site_title: Plaid plans to double Europe staff after Visa deal falls through
summary: Plaid Inc plans to nearly double its European staff to around 80 employees by the end of 2021, after a US$5.3 billion acquisition deal with Visa Inc fell through. The company will focus on growth in the European market, particularly in payments, and expand product features. With 600 employees globally, Plaid aims to aggressively scale its customers and payments volume, targeting financial-technology firms and technology companies. Despite the cancelled deal, the company's strategy remains unchanged, focusing on its own growth and destiny.

site_title: Ivanhoe Mines taking 'hard look' at US projects
summary: Canadian exploration company Ivanhoe Mines is reviewing US projects amid a surge in green metal demand. Executive Co-Chairman Robert Friedland stated that the company is taking a "hard look" at projects in states where they can obtain a "social license to mine." This move follows US President-elect Joe Biden's plans to boost domestic metal production, crucial for electric vehicles and climate goals. Specific projects and states were not mentioned.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1% on reports Queensland to lift lockdown curbs
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by reports that Queensland state was set to lift coronavirus-led restrictions and improved industrial activity in top consumer China. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,729.6, with financials and healthcare stocks climbing 1.3% and 1%, respectively. Local media reported Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's plan to lift restrictions on Friday. The gains were partly attributed to better-than-expected data on China's economy and production results from local miners.

site_title: China top financial watchdog blasts 'state monopoly' accusation
summary: China's top financial regulator, Guo Shuqing, denied accusations of "state monopoly capitalism" and distortion of the economy, stating that private companies contribute 60% to the economy but have only half the tax burden of state-owned enterprises. He argued that it's impossible for banks to subsidize state-backed companies due to intense competition in the credit market. This comes amid international pressure to reduce industrial subsidies and align with global trade rules, following the US, Europe, and Japan's push for stronger World Trade Organization rules.

site_title: Intel Chairman planning up to US$1b health-tech SPAC IPO
summary: Intel Chairman Omar Ishrak is planning a health-tech SPAC IPO, aiming to raise $750 million to $1 billion. Goldman Sachs is leading the initial public offering, with hedge fund manager Joshua Fink and Medtronic executive Jean Nehme holding senior roles. Ishrak, who previously ran Medtronic, will be chairman of the blank-check company. This follows a surge in SPAC listings, with 53 companies raising $15 billion in January and 47 more planning to raise $11.7 billion. The move is part of the growing trend of health-tech investments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at start of trade on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.82% on Tuesday, extending the previous day's rally, ahead of congressional testimony from Janet Yellen. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 29,100.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index saw minimal gains. The market reaction appears to be driven by investor anticipation of Yellen's testimony, rather than specific economic data.

site_title: Milan Men's Fashion Week longs for a bright winter
summary: Milan Men's Fashion Week showcased autumn-winter 2021 collections with a focus on comfort, bright colors, and uninhibited movement. Due to the pandemic, designers incorporated elements of indoor wear into outdoor styles, such as cozy chic, layering, and reversible coats. Bright colors, including golden, fuchsia, and emerald green, were also prominent. The collections featured flexible and moveable clothing, with designers aiming to liberate bodies from the constraints of the pandemic era.

site_title: Carrefour suitor has few regrets about a 'good deal' that failed
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. CEO Brian Hannasch expressed regret over the timing of a proposed $20 billion acquisition of Carrefour SA, but not the deal itself, after the French government blocked the takeover. The company had researched the target, visiting 500 stores, and believed it would bring scale to navigate changing consumer preferences. Couche-Tard shares dropped 13% before rebounding on Friday as investors acknowledged the deal's demise. The company's focus on food and fuel remains unchanged, with acquisitions still in its DNA.

images.alt_text: After a tumultuous week that saw the French government shut down an attempt to take over Carrefour SA, executives at Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. lamented the timing of events, but not the move.

site_title: Top India cinema operator predicts return of big bang releases
summary: India's top cinema operator, PVR Ltd, is in talks with Bollywood producers to release movies in cinemas before streaming platforms. Following the easing of COVID-19 restrictions, PVR sees benefits in the traditional "big bang release" strategy. The company's CEO, Kamal Gianchandani, stated that movies yield the highest revenue per eyeball in theaters compared to other platforms. This strategy is expected to help filmmakers generate better returns despite increased production costs. PVR's shares have risen 14% this year, with analysts predicting a favorable release calendar for Bollywood films.

site_title: Michelin awards first star to vegan restaurant in France
summary: A vegan restaurant in Ares, France, ONA, run by Claire Vallee, has become the first establishment in France to receive a Michelin star. Vallee launched the restaurant in 2016 with crowdfunding and a loan from an ethical bank, despite facing initial rejections from traditional French banks. ONA, meaning "Animal-free origin," has received a classic star and a green star for its strong record of ethical practices. Vallee attributes her success to perseverance and innovation in vegan cuisine.

site_title: Biden team says US will not lift travel bans, despite Trump statement
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's team has dismissed Donald Trump's statement to lift travel bans on Europe and Brazil, citing worsening pandemic conditions and the need to strengthen public health measures. Biden's press secretary, Jen Psaki, stated that the administration does not intend to lift the restrictions on January 26, and plans to further mitigate the spread of Covid-19. The travel ban, which was previously in place due to the pandemic, was announced by Trump just days before Biden's inauguration.

site_title: Hong Kong to extend outbreak-control measures as cases surge
summary: Hong Kong extends outbreak-control measures as coronavirus cases surge, with 107 daily infections reported on Monday, the highest in a month. The Asian financial hub will expand mandatory testing, introduce new restrictions in certain neighborhoods, and maintain social-distancing measures to curb transmission. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam emphasized the need to "join hands and curb transmission as much as possible" to combat the extended wave of cases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.43 points, or 0.52%, to 1,617.95. Trading volume reached 864.16 million lots worth RM437.88 million. Gainers outpaced losers 417 to 228.

site_title: Mexican energy regulator freezes key operations due to pandemic
summary: Mexican energy regulator CRE has suspended its activities due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing health risks. The suspension affects retail fuel stations, natural gas transport, and electricity generation permits. Companies with pending or future approvals will not be penalized, and some "extremely urgent" matters will be exempt. The move comes amid speculation about the regulator's future, with some suggesting it could be folded into the energy ministry to cut costs, while others argue it's a power consolidation move.

site_title: Biden's rejection of pipeline throws 'wrench' in Canada, US ties
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to immediately rescind a permit for the Keystone XL pipeline via executive order, blocking its completion and potentially straining Canada-US ties. The $8 billion pipeline, which would transport oil from Alberta's oil sands to refineries in Texas, has been a contentious issue due to environmental concerns. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government had committed to the project, and its rejection could have significant economic implications for Canada, including job losses and a decrease in oil exports.

site_title: Fu Yu founders retire, sell 29.8% stake in company for S$58.3m
summary: Fu Yu Corp's co-founders, Ching Heng Yang, Ho Nee Kit, and Tam Wai, have retired from their board positions after selling a 29.8% stake in the company for S$58.3 million to Pilgrim Partners Asia. The trio, who established the precision plastic components maker in 1978, have stepped down as executive directors and vice-chairman of the board, effective January 18. The company has appointed new board members, including Choo Boon Tiong and David Seow Jun Hao, following the divestment and board changes announced after an unusual price and volume movement in the company's shares.

site_title: New York governor asks Pfizer to directly sell Covid-19 vaccine doses
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo asked Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla if the state could directly purchase Covid-19 vaccine doses from the US drugmaker. Pfizer replied that such a proposal would require US Department of Health and Human Services approval. Cuomo emphasized the need to increase vaccine doses to combat the rising number of hospitalizations and deaths in the state. The proposal comes as the US is in a "footrace with the virus."

site_title: UK business lobby urges more help for virus-hit firms
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) is urging the UK government to extend its furlough jobs support scheme and taxation holidays to help coronavirus-plagued firms. The scheme is set to expire at the end of April, but the CBI wants it to continue until the end of June. The lobby group is also seeking deferred payments of value added taxation (VAT) and an extension to a pause in business rates. The move comes as the UK economy slumped 2.6% in November, stoking fears of a double-dip recession.

images.alt_text: Britain's main business lobby on Tuesday urged the government to extend its furlough jobs support scheme and taxation holidays to help coronavirus-plagued firms.

site_title: Bargain hunting by hoarders, jewellers could send gold price up again
summary: Gold prices may surge again due to bargain hunting by hoarders and jewellers, driven by declining investor and speculative holdings. Investors took profits after the 2020 surge, but sentiment has changed despite remaining concerns about a weak dollar and fiat currencies. Investment banks forecast a gold price surge to US$3,000 and US$2,300 an ounce, while analysts expect the market to stabilize if Chinese and Asian buyers increase demand. If investors continue to sell gold, it could lead to a rally, with some predicting a high of US$2,285 an ounce this year.

site_title: Birkenstock in talks for S$6.4b sale to CVC Capital
summary: Birkenstock, the German company behind iconic sandals, is in talks for a S$6.38 billion sale to private equity firm CVC Capital Partners. The deal could value the nearly 250-year-old brand at over 4 billion euros, including debt. Birkenstock's heritage, dating back to 1774, appeals to shoppers seeking products with a back story. The company has sold 23.8 million pairs of shoes in the past year, with sales rising 11% to 721.5 million euros. A final decision has not been made, and there's no certainty the discussions will lead to an agreement.

site_title: US lawmakers aim to curtail face recognition even as the technology IDs Capitol attackers
summary: US lawmakers are moving to ban facial recognition software despite its use in identifying Capitol attackers. The technology has helped identify several individuals, including Larry Brock, who was charged with violent entry and other counts. Researchers, including Michael Sheldon, have praised facial recognition for its potential to help in investigations, but lawmakers like Senator Ed Markey have raised concerns about its accuracy and bias issues, potentially leading to increased problematic surveillance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.68% or 191.95 points to 28,434.16. This follows two days of profit-taking, with few market-moving headlines. The US market was closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE C-Reit, SIA, SPH, BRC Asia, InnoTek, Silkroad Nickel
summary:

site_title: Scion of City Developments strives to salvage China deal
summary: Pressure mounts on Sherman Kwek, CEO of City Developments, as he seeks to salvage the troubled China property investment. Since October, three board members have resigned, and a special team has been formed to decide on asset sales and restructuring. The firm's father, CDL's executive chairman, has defended the investment, amid a rift with Chinese developer Sincere Property Group. The situation highlights the challenges faced by Singapore's largest family fortune in navigating the complex Chinese market.

site_title: Takeover price for Sunningdale Tech raised to S$1.65 per share in final offer
summary: Sunningdale Tech's chairman Koh Boon Hwee and Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 have raised their takeover offer price to S$1.65 per share, a 6.5% increase from S$1.55, in response to activist investor Quarz Capital Management's criticism that the initial price was "too low" and undervalued the company. The new price is a 22% discount to Sunningdale's book value of S$2 per share.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,001.44 at Tuesday's open, driven by gains in banking stocks and active index counters. Notable movers included DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which advanced 0.8%, 0.5%, and 0.6% respectively. European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, bolstered by carmaker Stellantis and luxury stocks, while Asian markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei 225, also gained ground.

site_title: US asks Australia to scrap proposed laws to make Facebook, Google pay for news
summary: The US government has asked Australia to scrap proposed laws requiring Facebook and Google to pay for news sourced from local media outlets. US trade representatives suggested suspending the plans and developing a voluntary code instead. The law, which has broad support, would make Google and Facebook subject to mandatory price arbitration if a commercial agreement on payments cannot be reached.

site_title: UK's Johnson criticised over lack of Covid-19 welfare commitment
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was criticized in parliament for refusing to commit to renewing a temporary £20 weekly welfare payment increase to help people through the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a 278-0 vote in favor, Johnson abstained, citing no decision has been made yet. The opposition Labour Party called for the increase to be extended beyond April, when it is due to expire, and some Conservative Party members defied Johnson's instruction to abstain, expressing dissatisfaction over ministers' handling of support for society's most vulnerable.

site_title: China 'already decided' to sanction US officials over Taiwan
summary: China has stated it has already decided to sanction US officials over involvement in Taiwan issues, following the Trump administration's recent move to lift decades-old restrictions on US diplomats' interactions with Taiwan. This comes amid worsening relations between Washington and Beijing, with China considering democratic Taiwan part of its territory. China also plans to sanction US officials, congress people, and NGO personnel, as well as direct family members, for their involvement in recent US moves in Hong Kong.

site_title: Parler partially reappears with support from Russian technology firm
summary: Parler, a social media platform popular with the American far right, has partially returned online after being dropped by Amazon for poor moderation. The website is now reachable again, though only with a limited message from its CEO. Parler's users can see but not post comments, and the app remains banned from Apple and Google stores. The platform's restoration is attributed to support from Russian technology firm DDoS-Guard, which provides services including protection from denial of service attacks. Critics have raised concerns about the potential security risks and odd choice of a Russian company for a site popular with self-described patriots.

site_title: Japan firms see capex rebound in FY2021 despite Covid-19 hit
summary: Japan firms expect to maintain or increase capital spending in the coming year, despite the COVID-19 resurgence and recent state of emergency declarations. Almost three quarters of firms surveyed expect steady or increased spending, particularly in areas like digital transformation and green technology. Companies are focusing on repairing/refurbishing, digitalisation, and capacity enhancement, with some economists predicting business investment will return to pre-pandemic levels by 2022.

site_title: Pandemic reveals hidden poverty in wealthy Japan
summary: Japan's strong economy and social safety net have masked a growing number of people pushed into poverty by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite an unemployment rate below 3%, around 40% of workers are in vulnerable "non-regular" jobs with lower wages and easily terminated contracts. Many struggle to access welfare, and campaigners say the pandemic has hit the working poor, including women who face economic hardship due to temporary contracts. Experts warn that the economic pain may contribute to a rise in suicides and that the stigma of receiving welfare assistance prevents many from seeking help.

site_title: OUE C-Reit seals S$1.27b deal with Allianz entity to divest 50% of OUE Bayfront
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) has agreed to sell 50% of its OUE Bayfront property to a special purpose vehicle (SPV) managed by Allianz Real Estate for S$1.27 billion, exceeding the property's valuation of S$1.18 billion. The deal, valued at S$3,170 per square foot, provides OUE C-Reit with S$262.6 million in net proceeds to reduce debt and enhance returns. The sale is expected to improve the Reit's aggregate leverage from 40.3% to 33.6% and is seen as a strategic move to add a high-quality office asset to Allianz's portfolio.

site_title: Leaving office, Trump has lowest approval rating of his presidency
summary: President Donald Trump is set to leave office with the lowest approval rating of his presidency, at 34% according to a Gallup poll. This marks a significant decline from his average approval rating of 41%, which is four points lower than his predecessors. Trump's approval rating had previously dipped to 35% after the Charlottesville incident and the storming of the US Capitol building. His all-time high rating was in early 2020, during the pandemic.

site_title: Trump lifting Covid-19 travel restrictions on Europe, UK, Brazil: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump will lift COVID-19 travel restrictions on most non-US citizens who recently visited Europe and Brazil, starting January 26. The restrictions, imposed in mid-March and May, were set to end under a new proclamation. The move comes after airlines and public health officials pushed for the lifting, citing the new COVID-19 test requirements for international visitors. The restrictions bar nearly all non-US citizens who have been in Brazil, the UK, Ireland, and 26 European countries with open borders within the last 14 days.

site_title: WHO, China could have acted faster on pandemic: experts
summary: A panel of independent experts has concluded that China and the World Health Organization (WHO) could have acted faster to prevent the COVID-19 pandemic. The report suggests that containment measures should have been implemented immediately in countries where transmission was likely, and that the WHO should have declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) earlier. Experts agree that the official death toll and infection numbers are undercounts, and that the virus was spreading more widely than reported, with a "largely hidden epidemic" contributing to the global spread.

site_title: Apple sets terms to let Parler back into App Store
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook said Parler, a social network popular among conservatives, could return to the App Store if it changes its moderation policies. Apple suspended Parler after the US Capitol attack citing incitement to violence on the platform. Parler sued Amazon, alleging antitrust violations, after it was cut off from Internet servers. Cook stated that if Parler improves moderation, it would be reinstated in the App Store. Parler was previously the top-downloaded app in the US before its suspension.

site_title: Biden pushes unity two days before taking over crisis-laden White House
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is pushing for unity ahead of his inauguration, despite multiple crises including the COVID-19 pandemic, economic recovery, and division among Americans. Biden marked the Martin Luther King Jr holiday with a charity event, calling for Americans to come together. In contrast, President Donald Trump has remained secluded, with a Gallup poll showing him at a record low of 34% approval. Trump is expected to announce pardons for convicted criminals, including himself and his family members, potentially sparking controversy. Biden will face a heavily secured inauguration ceremony on Wednesday, with over 20,000 National Guard soldiers present.

site_title: FBI says Capitol rioter allegedly hoped to sell Pelosi laptop to Russia
summary: The FBI has filed a criminal complaint against Riley June Williams, a Pennsylvania woman who allegedly took part in the January 6 US Capitol riot, accusing her of stealing a laptop belonging to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and planning to sell it to a Russian spy agency. Williams, who was seen near Pelosi's office, had taken a sudden interest in President Trump's politics and was seen directing fellow rioters. Her whereabouts are currently unknown, and it is unclear if the laptop was actually stolen. The FBI continues to investigate.

site_title: Singapore government keeping close watch on property market
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the government's close watch on Singapore's property market to ensure stability, amid rising global asset prices and renewed positive sentiments in the local market. The government will adjust policies as needed to maintain a stable and sustainable market for Singaporeans, with Minister Desmond Lee highlighting the need for vigilance due to uncertain economic outlooks. The uptrend in private housing prices has picked up pace since Q2 2020, with developers expected to continue new project launches this year.

site_title: Oil slips on coronavirus fears, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday due to a stronger US dollar, concerns over the spread of coronavirus, and slower-than-expected vaccination rates. Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate US crude declined 0.4% to $54.87 and $52.17 per barrel, respectively. The slower vaccine rollout and economic fears outweighed a better-than-expected quarterly rebound for China's economy, which boosted oil prices in recent weeks. The US dollar reached a four-week high, making crude more expensive for buyers with other currencies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher as Stellantis, luxury stocks jump
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by a 4.8% jump in Adidas and luxury stocks, including Richemont and LVMH. The Stoxx 600 index saw-sawed through the session, reversing early losses due to concerns about an economic recovery and Carrefour's 6.9% slide. Investors await European earnings season, which is expected to see a 26.3% drop in fourth-quarter profit. Meanwhile, Italian stocks outperformed after Stellantis' 7.6% jump on the completion of its US$52 billion merger with PSA.

site_title: Yellen says US must 'act big' on next coronavirus relief package
summary: US Treasury nominee Janet Yellen says the government must "act big" with its next coronavirus relief package, citing the need for bold investment to jump-start the economy and accelerate vaccine distribution. The proposed $1.9 trillion package includes $415 billion for virus response and vaccines, $1 trillion in direct relief to households, and $440 billion for small businesses and communities. Many Americans would receive stimulus payments of $1,400, and supplemental unemployment insurance would increase to $400 a week.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen, US President-elect Joe Biden's nominee to run the Treasury Department, will tell the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday that the government must "act big" with its next coronavirus relief package.

site_title: Turning agony into relief for those living with chronic pain
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings, a healthcare group specializing in pain care treatments, aims to provide accessible and affordable relief to those suffering from chronic pain. The company treats up to five needy patients annually for free, and offers free consultations to patients referred by partner organizations. Its approach focuses on eradicating pain generators, rather than just providing temporary relief, and utilizes minimally invasive procedures and specialized injections to achieve sustained pain reduction.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence improves further in Q4: NZIER survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence improved in the fourth quarter, with a net 6% of firms expecting general business conditions to deteriorate, down from 40% in the previous quarter. This represents a significant shift from the 68% feeling pessimistic in March 2020. Capacity utilisation reached 95.1%, up from 92.6% in the previous quarter. The improvement suggests businesses are holding onto the recovery in sales seen in September.

images.alt_text: New Zealand business confidence showed further improvement in the fourth quarter as businesses held onto the recovery in sales seen in September, a private think tank said on Tuesday.

site_title: Cybersecurity breach at InnoTek's China unit; Singapore networks unscathed
summary: A cybersecurity breach occurred at InnoTek's China unit, Mansfield Manufacturing Company Hong Kong, where its IT network was unlawfully accessed and encrypted by cyber criminals. The incident has been contained, and most data was recovered, with business activities now operational. The breach is not expected to have a material financial impact on the company's financial year ended Dec 31, 2020. InnoTek's Singapore networks remain unscathed, and the company is conducting a rigorous review of the incident to ensure data security. Law enforcement authorities and security bureaus have been notified.

site_title: South Korea's president pledges 'extraordinary' steps to supply homes
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has pledged "extraordinary" measures to increase housing supply, aiming to curb soaring home prices that have negatively impacted his public approval. The government plans to develop new land and encourage public sector participation to exceed market expectations. Low interest rates, abundant liquidity, and an increase in households have driven demand, outstripping supply. The government will release a new plan before the Lunar New Year holiday, with approximately 83,000 homes to be provided in Seoul this year, including 24,000 public rental homes.

site_title: A self-governing market: brokers have a role to play too
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) chief executive Tan Boon Gin envisions a self-governing market where the regulator's presence is minimal. To achieve this, brokers must step up their game and minimize instances that lead to Trade with Caution warnings, which have been issued for several companies. RegCo is using AI enhancements to monitor the market, and brokers should also perform basic surveillance to prevent problems. By working together, the market can become more mature and self-regulating, benefiting investors and brokers alike.

site_title: Property developers facing better year ahead in 2021
summary: Singapore's private property market is expected to have a better year in 2021, following a 2.2% rise in 2020 despite the pandemic. Measures to combat the pandemic, such as mortgage deferment and wage subsidies, helped support the market. Higher-income earners and those with robust household balance sheets are expected to drive demand, while low interest rates and an eventual lifting of border control measures are also expected to boost sales. Analysts, including OCBC and RHB, are optimistic about the outlook for developers, with some predicting a 3% rise in private property prices this year.

site_title: 2021 construction demand forecast to recover
summary: Singapore's construction industry is expected to recover to $23-28 billion in demand this year, driven by public sector projects, including public housing and infrastructure developments. However, the industry faces challenges due to the ongoing labor shortage and uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic. Industry players are concerned about meeting demand and rising labor costs, which may lead to delays and increased costs for projects. The government has acknowledged the industry's headwinds and will continue to monitor the situation to support the sector.

site_title: US dollar at 1-month high, euro slips to 6-week low
summary: The US dollar strengthened to a four-week high, reaching a one-month high of 90.94 on the US dollar index, driven by risk aversion and anticipation of a US stimulus package. The euro slid to a six-week low, while the Australian and British pounds also fell. Hedge funds have taken a massive net short US dollar position, and derivative markets indicate short-term US dollar strength. Despite this, analysts remain cautious about the short-term outlook.

site_title: Singapore's December trade rebound set to continue into 2021
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 6.8% year-over-year in December, ending a two-month losing streak, according to preliminary data from Enterprise Singapore. Analysts predict a solid economic recovery for Singapore and the region, with exports expected to continue growing in 2021. The rebound is attributed to strong demand for electronics and biomedical goods, particularly for 5G infrastructure and Covid-19 vaccine requirements. However, economists caution that the pace of growth may be influenced by consumer sentiment and the uncertain external environment.

site_title: Trump goes, but global populism may still grow
summary: Global populism, fueled by economic crises and social media, may continue to grow despite the departure of Donald Trump, who was a prominent symbol of the phenomenon. Two billion people, or nearly 30% of the world's population, are currently governed by populist leaders, with a significant increase in populist leaders since the 2007-08 financial crisis. The COVID-19 pandemic has triggered a deeper global recession, exacerbating economic inequality and fueling discontent among younger generations, which may drive further growth of populism. Social media has played a key role in mobilizing discontent and enabling populist movements.

images.alt_text: While Mr Trump lost the election in November, he won more votes than in 2016, and was most likely to be re-elected before the pandemic struck.

site_title: He is on a drive to change the way we sell our cars
summary: Damian Sia, founder of Motorist, aims to revolutionize the automotive industry by providing a platform for buying and selling cars, as well as managing vehicle ownership matters. His company has already gained traction, transacting over 400 vehicles per month in Singapore. Motorist has also developed an app with over 90,000 users, and introduced social initiatives such as Co-Driver, which sends real-time alerts to drivers approaching speed and red-light cameras. Sia's goal is to make the industry more transparent and create a positive impact on society.

site_title: Paris theatres carry on - behind closed doors
summary: In defiance of France's ongoing coronavirus restrictions, Parisian theatres have continued to hold clandestine performances, with some productions being held behind closed doors for professionals. The shows, which have been criticized for breaking rules, aim to maintain the spirit of theatre and provide an outlet for artists. Meanwhile, the government's decision to delay reopening theatres has led to last-minute cancellations, with some theatres opting for private daytime performances instead. The industry awaits the government's next move, with some productions adapting to the new reality, such as a closed premiere of a monologue by German author Rainald Goetz.

site_title: ECB to hold course as virus clouds outlook
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy at its meeting on Thursday, despite the resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic and concerns over vaccination drives. The ECB has already injected more stimulus into the eurozone economy and prolonged its pandemic emergency bond-buying programme until March 2022. Policymakers are focusing on the impact of the pandemic on economic growth, with many European governments reimposing restrictions to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Trump halts shipments to Huawei from Intel, other suppliers
summary: The US government, under President Donald Trump, has notified Huawei suppliers, including Intel, that they are revoking certain licenses to sell to the Chinese company and rejecting dozens of other applications. This move is part of a long-running effort to weaken Huawei, seen as a national security threat. The action was likely the last against Huawei under Trump's administration, as Democrat Joe Biden is set to take office. The Commerce Department said it will continue to apply licensing policies to protect US national security interests.

site_title: Tycoons Ambani, Adani caught in crossfire over India's farming laws
summary: Indian tycoons Mukesh Ambani and Gautam Adani are caught in a controversy over the country's new farming laws, with protesters alleging they have benefited from their ties to Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The laws, passed in September, allow private companies to buy produce directly from farmers, sparking fears of market-driven price fluctuations. The protests, led by tens of thousands of farmers, have revived debate on a perceived nexus between the tycoons and the PM, with some accusing crony capitalism. The Indian top court has barred the implementation of the law until it decides on the matter.

site_title: Eurostar survival concern grows as UK firms lobby for govt rescue
summary: UK business leaders are urging the government to rescue Eurostar International Ltd due to concerns the Channel Tunnel rail operator may collapse due to border closures and pandemic-related traffic decline. The company seeks access to Bank of England-backed loans, similar to those provided to airlines. Over 25 executives and academics signed a letter to Chancellor Rishi Sunak, warning of "swift action" needed to safeguard Eurostar's future amidst a 95% traffic plunge during the pandemic.

site_title: An artwork for the festive season
summary: A silent online auction is underway, featuring 26 artworks created by socially-disadvantaged youths and individuals with muscular dystrophy. Bidders can purchase artworks, with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, Muscular Dystrophy Association, and SOTA Endowment Fund. Starting bids range from S$300 to S$480, with the auction closing on Feb 8, 2021. The artworks, including acrylic paintings and fine art prints, aim to promote hope and positivity, while supporting financially-disadvantaged individuals and those with muscular dystrophy.

site_title: Mask-eteers on a mission to ensure everyone has access to affordable, quality masks
summary: A Singaporean company, The Wellness Fellows, has made affordable, quality masks available to the public amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Founded by Daniel Chui, a 54-year-old entrepreneur with a 25-year experience in the tourism industry, the company has manufactured three million masks with ISO 13485 certification. The masks are sold online and in stores, with a portion of the sales donated to a non-profit organization supporting individuals with special needs. The company aims to educate the public on choosing the right mask and plans to open its factory for educational tours.

site_title: Singapore office rents may dip by 5% this year as WFH continues: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank expects Singapore office rents to fall by 5% in 2021, bottoming out before recovering in 2022, unless new Covid-19 strains and lockdowns occur. A projected 5.3m sq ft of new supply will hit the market from Q4 2020 to 2023, with CBD occupancy estimated at 94.1% and prime office rents averaging S$10.16/sq ft/month.

site_title: Intra-, inter-party rifts open up ahead of Merkel's leaving
summary: Germany's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) is facing internal divisions ahead of Chancellor Angela Merkel's retirement. Armin Laschet's narrow victory as party chairman has exposed deep differences on policies, and Markus Söder, the Bavarian prime minister, is seen as a strong contender to be the CDU's September chancellor candidate. Söder is wooing Laschet and the Green party, preparing a campaign opposing the CDU's industrial and energy policies. The party's leadership is set to face fresh challenges, including a potential pandemic flare-up and the European Union's response to US President Joe Biden's administration.

site_title: Grooming socially responsible leaders
summary: Field Experience, a social impact training firm founded by Mr. Theodore Teo in 2016, aims to equip leaders with sustainable decision-making skills to make a positive impact in their communities. The firm's training methods focus on equipping leaders to lead and facilitate reflections for their team members, and its approach prioritizes people, planet, and profits. With a commitment to creating a ripple effect in the community, Field Experience has been recognized as an Honoree in the Brands For Good 2020 awards under the Leadership For Good category.

site_title: UOBAM completes acquisition of Vietnam fund manager
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has completed the acquisition of VAM Vietnam Fund Management Joint Stock Company, a Vietnam-based fund manager, for a cash consideration of S$6.7 million. The acquisition will boost UOBAM's presence in ASEAN and expand its regional network to nine markets. The entity will be renamed UOB Asset Management (Vietnam) Fund Management Joint Stock Company, subject to regulatory approval. UOBAM aims to become a leading asset management firm in Vietnam within the next five years, with Thieu Thi Nhat Le, CEO of the new Vietnam subsidiary, stating that the goal is to achieve this within the next five years.

site_title: Sembcorp names ex-CEO of CapitaLand as new independent director
summary: Sembcorp Industries appointed Lim Ming Yan, a former CEO of CapitaLand, as a non-executive and independent director, effective Monday. Lim, 58, led CapitaLand's growth in China for over a decade before retiring in 2018. He currently holds 11 directorships, including one as chairman of Workforce Singapore. This appointment comes after Sembcorp's CFO Graham Cockroft quit to return to New Zealand, with the company's shares rising 0.55% to S$1.83.

site_title: Mount Emily residential block relaunched for sale with lower S$18m guide price
summary: A freehold residential block at 2, 4, and 6 Mount Emily Road in Singapore has been relaunched for collective sale by tender with a new guide price of S$18 million, a 25% decrease from its initial launch in June 2020. The new price translates to S$1,115 per square foot. The property, which comprises three-storey buildings with basement and attic, is zoned for residential use and is near Mount Emily Park and the central business district. The tender opens on Tuesday and closes on February 25, 2021.

site_title: Samsung's Lee sent back to prison in bribery case
summary: South Korea's Seoul High Court sentenced Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee to 2.5 years in prison for bribery, embezzlement, and concealment of criminal proceeds. This ruling marks a shift in South Korea's view on wrongdoings by powerful conglomerates, or chaebol, and may delay Samsung's ownership restructuring following the death of Lee's father. Lee will serve the remaining 18 months of his original sentence, which he had already completed in 2017-2018.

site_title: Her company treats wastewater to make it drinkable
summary: Watch Water, a Singapore-based company, treats wastewater to make it drinkable, aiming to address the global issue of 1 in 3 people lacking access to clean drinking water. Founded by Ivy Heng in 2015, the company uses German water treatment technology to enhance drinking water and treat industrial, commercial, and residential wastewater. Watch Water's mission is to make water clean, safe, and healthy, while also promoting employee mental happiness and contributing to social change. The company has been recognized as an Honouree in the Brands For Good 2020 awards for its leadership in meeting impact goals and social change.

site_title: World facing 'catastrophic moral failure' on vaccines: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of a "catastrophic moral failure" if rich countries continue to hoard COVID-19 vaccine doses, while the poorest suffer. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus criticized wealthy nations for prioritizing their own deals with manufacturers and driving up prices, while leaving the world's poorest countries without access to vaccines. As of January 2021, 39 million doses had been administered in 49 higher-income countries, while only 25 doses had been given in one lowest-income country.

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie sets sights on 30% revenue growth in digital, data push
summary: OrangeTee & Tie (OTT) has restructured its organisational structure to accelerate its digital transformation and aims to increase its 2021 revenue by at least 30% from 2019 levels. The real estate firm is developing its agents into trusted investment advisers and launching data-driven products, such as a market analytics suite, to enhance its agency activities. OTT also plans to roll out a tool to generate instant viewing reports and is increasing its headcount by 5% this year to bolster its tech and digital capabilities.

site_title: A historic opportunity to rebuild economies and tackle climate change
summary: Investors in the Asia-Pacific are optimistic about 2021 as the global economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic, with steady progress in vaccine development and distribution expected to fuel a strong economic recovery. The transition to a lower-carbon economy is also gaining momentum, with countries pledging to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by mid-century. Governments and businesses are expected to deliver carbon pricing frameworks, support renewable energy sources, and invest in sustainable infrastructure, creating opportunities for investors seeking impact. A diversified approach to investment in companies involved in the net-zero transition is expected to reward investors.

site_title: Singapore Environment Council honours 12 companies for their efforts to go green
summary: The Singapore Environment Council (SEC) has awarded the GreenDNA Certification to 12 companies for their efforts to adopt green practices, aiming to reduce carbon intensity by 36% by 2030. Recipients include ComfortDelGro, DBS Bank, and companies from various sectors, who have implemented environmentally friendly practices, set measurable goals, and trained employees. The certification is part of the SEC's plan to encourage sustainable practices among Singaporean businesses.

site_title: PrimePartners launches digital whisky-based security
summary: PrimePartners has launched a digital asset-backed security (ABS) linked to exclusive casks of single malt Scotch whisky, "Casks of Distinction" (COD), selected by Diageo. The digital ABS is the first of its kind in South-east Asia, open to accredited investors. Each token represents a bottle from the offering, comprising five CODs, including rare vintages, and is expected to mature between 2022 and 2025. The ABS aims to mitigate risks associated with investing in whisky by securing casks stored onsite at Diageo's distilleries and warehouses.

site_title: Upholding honour in everyday life
summary: Singapore-based non-profit Honour (Singapore) aims to promote a culture of honour, integrity, and trust through various outreach strategies. Founded by Professor Lim Siong Guan, the organization has reached over 250 organizational leaders, hosted international symposiums, and connected with 5,000 students and 150 educators through Honour Learning Journeys. Honour (Singapore) also supports young local film producers and has contributed to the arts, with over 30 films garnering over 10 million views on social media. The organization was named a Champion in last year's Brands For Good 2020 awards under the Leadership For Good category.

site_title: Canada to lift Boeing 737 MAX flight ban on Jan 20
summary: Canada to lift Boeing 737 MAX flight ban on January 20, joining the US in bringing the aircraft back after two fatal crashes. Transport Canada approved design changes to the aircraft in December, paving the way for the ban lift. The regulator also issued an airworthiness directive and interim order requiring airlines to provide additional crew training. The move comes after a nearly two-year flight ban on the 737 MAX.

site_title: Helping others care for their loved ones
summary: A social enterprise called 1.Care Employment Agency, founded by hospital nurse Janice Kerena Tan in 2013, aims to provide affordable caregiver training and services for seniors in Singapore. The agency trains caregivers in basic nursing skills and assesses their capabilities to care for seniors with physical and medical needs. With a growing elderly population, 1.Care hopes to recruit more middle-aged retirees to be caregivers, addressing the shortage in the industry. The organization also prioritizes helping lower-income families and donates medical supplies to the needy.

site_title: SIA can be world's first vaccinated international airline: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore Airlines may become the world's first vaccinated international airline as the country inoculates 37,000 aviation and maritime frontline workers against the novel coronavirus. The exercise aims to revive Singapore's air hub, which has been frozen since March 2020. Minister for Transport Ong Ye Kung said vaccinations will provide greater protection for staff and assurance to families, while SIA chief Goh Choon Phong urged staff to take up the option early to ensure the company's recovery. The vaccination centres can accommodate up to 8,000 people per day, with priority given to frontline workers who may come into contact with travellers from high-risk countries.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty. US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Malaysia gives economy RM15b shot in arm to fight pandemic
summary: Malaysia has unveiled a new RM15 billion stimulus package, dubbed Permai, to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The package, worth about 1.1% of the country's GDP, includes 22 initiatives aimed at combating Covid-19, protecting people's welfare, and supporting business continuity. The measures include bank moratorium assistance, loan repayment reduction, and a one-off monetary assistance for taxi and bus drivers. The package is the first stimulus package for the year and aims to prevent a relapse in economic health.

site_title: Laid off during crisis, she went on to found a company worth S$8m
summary: Shi Ru Xin, a former managing director at Glovia International Asia Pacific, was retrenched in 2008 due to the global financial crisis. She then founded Xintesys, a cloud-based business solutions provider, developing enterprise resource planning (ERP) software for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The company has a paid-up capital of S$7.7 million and has attracted private investors. Xintesys has weathered the COVID-19 pandemic, with the company continuing to pay employees on time and securing new projects. Shi credits her flexible working hours and trust in employees for the company's success, and plans to develop an internal platform to facilitate work opportunities and resources.

site_title: Inspiring kids to step up in the fight against climate change
summary: Kidz Treehouse, a student care and enrichment centre, aims to inspire a future generation of eco-conscious leaders through its nature-based education. Founded in 2007, the centre hopes to educate children on the importance of sustainability and taking care of the environment. Co-director Muhammad Taufiq Yahya emphasizes the need for proactive steps to address climate change, citing it as an existential crisis of our time. By focusing on environmental education, Kidz Treehouse seeks to empower children to become leaders in the fight against climate change.

images.alt_text: Kidz Treehouse founders Muhammad Taufiq Yahya and his wife Nur Suliani believe that instilling a love for the environment in children is key in cultivating an interest in sustainability for the future.
Kidz Treehouse's Eco Camp 2019 was themed 'Be a Hero, Go Zero' and focused on teaching its young participants about zero waste and how to apply environmentally sustainable practices.

site_title: UK house prices drop amid rush to beat deadline for tax break
summary: UK house prices dropped 0.9% in January as sellers offered discounts to meet a tax deadline, with many deals set to miss the March 31 cut-off. The average asking price fell, with about 100,000 transactions expected to close after the deadline, resulting in £15,000 (S$27,000) higher tax bills. Despite Covid-related market closures, the housing market has seen increased activity, driven by the desire for more space and upsize to the suburbs.

site_title: Private home buyers undaunted by rise in unemployment rate last year
summary: Despite a rise in unemployment rate to 3.6% in Q3 2020, private home purchases in Singapore increased by 27% year-over-year to 6,949 homes. The uneven impact of COVID-19 on different sectors, particularly the electronics and manufacturing industries, contributed to the surge in home sales. Experts attribute the trend to the low interest rate environment and government schemes that enabled residents to keep their jobs, leading them to invest in assets deemed safe, such as private property. Home sales are expected to remain firm in Q1 2021, driven by improving sentiment and the re-opening of the economy.

site_title: US$40,000 key test for Bitcoin boom: JPMorgan strategists
summary: JPMorgan strategists warn Bitcoin is at risk of a further drop unless it climbs back above US$40,000. The digital coin's price has been volatile, with a 11% slide from a record high of almost US$42,000 on January 8. Trend-following investors are expected to exit the market if Bitcoin fails to break above US$40,000, potentially leading to a correction. The strategists will monitor demand for Bitcoin futures and the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust to gauge investor appetite for risk.

site_title: SPH media hit by lower ad revenue in Q1 but digital circulation continues to grow
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 36% decline in Q1 print advertisement revenue due to Covid-19 disruptions. However, its digital circulation revenue saw a 45.6% year-on-year growth, mitigating the decline. The company's purpose-built student accommodation and aged care segments remained resilient. Print advertising remains crucial for core advertisers, and SPH will continue to provide innovative solutions. The company's overall circulation was up 1.8% year-over-year, with digital circulation growing 26.5%.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: HYPHENS Pharma International appoints JSPharma as exclusive distributor of its pigment lightening cream in South Korea. iX Biopharma appoints Eva Tan as new chief commercial officer to develop global commercial strategies. LET enters into a S$10 million joint venture with a Singapore-based company to set up membrane manufacturing facilities in Singapore and China. New Silkroutes Group signs a Memorandum of Understanding with Huawei International to develop an AI platform for genomics-driven healthcare.

site_title: Brazil, Russia, India and China economies after two decades
summary: The BRIC grouping, formed in 2001 to capture the economic potential of Brazil, Russia, India, and China, has seen its economies grow significantly over the past two decades. Despite initial projections of modest growth, the BRICs have outperformed expectations, with China's economy growing to over $15 trillion in nominal terms. India has emerged as the world's fifth-largest economy, while Brazil and Russia's shares of global GDP have largely returned to their 2001 levels. However, the BRICs' second decade has been marked by strained relations with Western democracies, and the need for stronger global economic governance remains unaddressed.

site_title: MAS revises technology risk management guidelines
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) revised its technology risk management guidelines, citing a worsening cyberthreat environment. The guidelines focus on addressing technology and cyber risks in financial institutions using cloud technologies and third-party service providers. Enhanced risk mitigation strategies include timely analysis of cyberthreat intelligence and conducting cyber exercises to test defenses. MAS also emphasizes the importance of strong oversight of third-party service providers to maintain system resilience and data confidentiality. The revised guidelines incorporate feedback from a 2019 public consultation and MAS's cybersecurity advisory panel.

site_title: Billionaire to take over bankrupt Indian shadow bank
summary: Billionaire Ajay Piramal's conglomerate, Piramal Enterprises, won the bidding for bankrupt Indian shadow lender Dewan Housing Finance Corp, securing nearly 94% of the votes. The resolution plan, approved by Dewan's committee of creditors, will help Piramal double down on its real estate-focused shadow banking business. The deal brings resolution to a key case in India's insolvency system, which had lingered for years, and highlights interest in the country's soured bank loans, valued at approximately $140 billion.

site_title: Ideas for Jurong Lake District include bigger plots, signature events
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is seeking views from developers, investors, and businesses on plans for the Jurong Lake District, which aims to create over 100,000 new jobs and 20,000 new homes. Stakeholders suggest selling larger sites with flexible development options, hosting signature events, and activating public spaces through placemaking. They also recommend creating landmark developments and attractions, and promoting a car-lite environment with a mix of office, residential, and retail uses. The URA is also exploring strategies to support last-mile business-to-consumer logistics and improve the liveability of the built environment.

site_title: Covid-19 shows businesses it is possible to do well while doing good
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has shown businesses that success and corporate philanthropy can go hand-in-hand. Brands For Good, a non-profit organization, advocates for socially responsible business practices. According to co-chair Alan Ng, the pandemic has exposed the fragility of the global economic system, emphasizing the need for inter-related businesses to work together towards a sustainable future. By prioritizing giving back, companies can naturally achieve success, aligning with Brands For Good's philosophy that doing good is a powerful business model.

site_title: How this business owner personifies the 'Tin Man' with a heart of gold
summary: A Singaporean business owner, Kabir Hossain, stepped up to help migrant workers during the 2020 circuit breaker period. He and his wife, Nuriya Begum, spent over $24,000 delivering food, essentials, and personal care items to over 9,000 migrant workers, often going above and beyond to personalize the packages. In response to the growing demand, Hossain launched the Brooklynz Community Support (BCS) website and mobile app, which now offers passport renewal services and fund transfers to migrant workers' home countries.

site_title: This cross-border remittance firm banks on technology to give SMEs a boost
summary: TranSwap, a cross-border payment platform, aims to simplify global finance for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Founded in 2015, the platform offers cost-effective and efficient overseas transactions, allowing businesses to make payments to over 180 countries and hold up to 34 currencies. TranSwap's CEO, Benjamin Wong, seeks to empower individuals and businesses worldwide by expanding its reach and launching initiatives to support under-served communities, including an e-remittance service and outreach programs. The firm plans to establish a Global Innovation Lab to develop new solutions and accelerate growth.

site_title: Take a leaf from this home-grown gourmet tea brand
summary: Tea Ideas, a Singapore-based gourmet tea brand, prioritizes sustainability and senior-friendly practices. The company uses eco-friendly packaging, sources Gyokuro green tea from a Japanese farm powered by solar energy, and recycles tea leaves as compost. Tea Ideas also employs a senior staff of over 60-year-olds, who are valued for their contributions. The company's flexible work model and inclusive culture have earned it a Distinction in the Brands For Good 2020 awards. By prioritizing staff well-being and embracing digitalization, Tea Ideas has achieved success without sacrificing its core values.

site_title: This animal lover wants to give all pets a healthier life - one loving meal at a time
summary: Animal Human Alliance, a business social enterprise, was founded in 2013 by Mr. Chan Chow Wah to improve the lives of pets, particularly community cats and dogs. The organization offers nutritious pet food and products, such as Gold-D and AHA, which are free from harmful ingredients. AHA also provides palliative care for ill animals, promotes animal-centric products, and supports rescue work, highlighting the plight of community animals through various outreach efforts. The organization aims to treat animals as fellow beings and create a global network of animal lovers.

images.alt_text: Through his range of pet food and supplies, animal lover and activist Chan Chow Wah hopes to help pet owners provide a healthier lifestyle for their four-legged friends.

site_title: US and China clash at WHO over scientific mission in Wuhan
summary: The US and China are clashing at the World Health Organization (WHO) over a scientific mission in Wuhan, China, aimed at determining the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic. The US has called for China to allow WHO-led experts to interview caregivers, patients, and lab workers, as well as access medical data and samples. China has rejected the request, citing the need for coordination and cooperation. The US has also criticized the terms of the visit, under which Chinese experts have done the first phase of research.

site_title: Philippine banks 'likely to recover faster from pandemic than 1997 Asian crisis'
summary: Philippine banks are expected to recover faster from the pandemic than they did from the 1997 Asian crisis due to record-low interest rates, higher capital, and a stable economy. The country's bad loan ratio may peak at 6-7% this year, with banks holding approximately $20.6 billion in bad debt. This is a significant improvement from the 20% levels seen during the Asian crisis. Philippine banks are expected to recover in 3-4 years, half the time it took after the 1997 crisis, with the economy projected to grow 6.5-7.5% this year.

site_title: Lower valuation for ThaiBev's Sabeco expected: UOB Kay Hian
summary: Thai Beverage Company's beer assets are expected to have a lower valuation, according to UOB Kay Hian. The valuation is impacted by drink-driving regulations and Covid-19 restrictions in Vietnam. The company plans to list its regional beer assets through an initial public offering in Singapore, which could raise US$2 billion. Analysts expect beer volumes in Vietnam to be 15-20% below pre-Covid-19 levels. UOB Kay Hian maintains its "buy" call on the stock with a sum-of-the-parts-based target price of S$0.85.

site_title: Education is more than just textbooks for this teacher
summary: Ms Christina Koh, founder of Arts Kidz International, aims to raise "global citizens who are ready to take on the challenges of modern life" through holistic learning. The pre-school's Science Math Arts Research Technology (S.M.A.R.T.) approach teaches pupils not just basic skills, but also environmental sustainability, science, technology, and the arts. Arts Kidz has partnered with organizations like the World Wildlife Fund and Wildlife Reserves Singapore to promote environmental awareness and sustainability. The pre-school's curriculum is designed to empower students for a limitless future, igniting a passion for learning and fostering a well-rounded education.

site_title: De Beers raises diamond prices
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, has raised diamond prices by about 5% in its first sale of the year, marking the industry's fastest recovery since the pandemic. The price increase, mostly for stones over 1 carat, is attributed to strong demand from US and Chinese holiday sales and a shortage of stock held by industry middlemen. This is a significant price hike, likely one of the steepest increases since the early part of the last decade.

site_title: Thai protesters accuse authorities of abduction, intimidation
summary: Thai protesters are accusing authorities of abduction and intimidation after a volunteer guard claimed he was abducted and questioned for 12 hours over an anti-monarchy sign. Mongkol Santimetakul, 25, filed a police complaint after being dumped on the street. Authorities have denied involvement, with the Internal Security Operations Command releasing a statement denying any involvement. Protest leaders say these tactics will only increase anger among protesters, while a legal monitoring group has called for those arrested to have access to a lawyer or relative before being charged.

site_title: Escaping coronavirus lockdowns, tourists flock to Dubai
summary: Dubai, a major tourist destination, has reopened its doors to visitors despite a sharp rise in coronavirus cases, with daily detected cases hovering in the mid-3,000s. The emirate has implemented strict mask-wearing and social distancing measures, but life appears largely normal, with restaurants, hotels, and mega-malls open for business. Tourists from countries like Britain and Russia have flocked to the city, with many citing limited options elsewhere. However, economists warn that the risks of a renewed outbreak could set back the recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 17.49 points to 1,609.52. The decline was attributed to a lack of significant news, with 716 losers outnumbering 458 gainers. Volume was 7.168 billion lots worth RM4.307 billion.

site_title: Leader Environmental Tech enters S$10m JV with Nanosun to set up membrane-making facilities
summary: Leader Environmental Tech (LET) has entered a S$10 million joint venture with Nanosun to establish membrane-making facilities in Singapore and China. LET will own 40% of the JV, while Nanosun will own 60%. The total investment is funded using proceeds from a rights issue and bank borrowings.

site_title: BRC Asia to place up to 10m shares to raise S$13.7m
summary: BRC Asia plans to issue up to 10 million shares at S$1.42 apiece to raise S$13.7 million, a 9.4% discount to its previous trading price. The placement aims to increase the company's financial resources and repay outstanding bank borrowings. The shares represent 4.29% of the existing issued share capital and will be sold through an exempt offering in Singapore.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel teams up with Ganfeng Lithium to tap growing electric vehicle industry
