summary: Silkroad Nickel, a CATALIST-listed nickel-ore producer, has partnered with Ganfeng Lithium to tap the growing electric vehicle (EV) industry. The exclusive term sheet aims to ensure the availability of raw materials, particularly nickel and cobalt, essential for lithium-ion battery production. Silkroad Nickel's mine will supply laterite ore, and Ganfeng Lithium will expand its business in the EV industry, leveraging Silkroad Nickel's presence in the South East Asian market. The partnership is expected to strengthen both companies' positions in the EV industry.

site_title: Shangri-La Dialogue to resume this year: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen announced that the Shangri-La Dialogue will resume this year, with more effective safety measures in place and increased vaccination rates. The annual event was cancelled in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic and will take place from June 5-7. Over 200 defence officials and experts from 26 countries will attend, with stringent precautionary measures, including pre-entry testing and safe distancing, in place. This marks the return of the dialogue, which has taken place every year since 2002.

site_title: Nutryfarm to sell S$24m worth of fresh durians to China firm
summary: A wholly-owned subsidiary of Nutryfarm International, Global Agricapital Holdings, has entered into a binding import-purchase agreement with Shanghai Yuqu Trading Co to sell 180 containers of fresh durians for RMB117 million (S$24 million). The agreement involves 30% advance payment and 70% payment upon inspection and receipt of goods. This deal highlights growing demand for durian exports from Singapore to China.

site_title: Biden taps veteran regulators to lead key Wall Street watchdogs
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has nominated former Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) chairman Gary Gensler to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) member Rohit Chopra to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). The selections aim to implement tougher oversight and enforcement of financial regulations, a departure from the Trump administration's light-touch policies. Gensler's nomination is seen as a challenge for the banking industry, while Chopra's selection is expected to reinvigorate the CFPB and crack down on private lenders misguiding student borrowers.

site_title: HSBC chairman gives hints of looming strategy revamp
summary: HSBC chairman Mark Tucker hinted at a looming strategy revamp, accelerating the bank's expansion across Asia to capitalize on opportunities in the region's growing wealth business and South Asia. Tucker stated that "economic realities" have forced the bank to make its plans more radical and urgent, confirming areas of focus, particularly in Asia. This move is seen as a response to changing global economic conditions and the need for HSBC to adapt its strategy.

site_title: Covid-19: Additional measures may be needed as community cases inch up
summary: Singapore may need additional measures to control Covid-19 as community cases increase. The country has seen 10 new cases in the past week, with two community cases linked to a police para-vet cluster. The two cases are a 43-year-old housewife and a 66-year-old Malaysian woman who did not seek medical treatment despite showing flu-like symptoms. Contact tracers are working to identify contacts and prevent further spread. With 22 cases discharged, 58,853 patients have recovered, and 44 remain in hospital.

site_title: iX Biopharma appoints new chief commercial officer
summary: iX Biopharma has appointed Eva Tan, a 36-year-old former corporate lawyer, as its new chief commercial officer. Tan, who joined the company in 2017, led the commercialization of its pharmaceutical and nutraceutical business segments, including the market launch of the Entity line of nutraceuticals in 2019. The appointment comes as the company transitions from research and development to commercialization, with Chairman and CEO Eddy Lee stating that Tan's execution capabilities make her a strong addition to the executive management team, and primes the group for growth.

site_title: 2021 construction demand forecast to recover, but shadow of manpower crunch remains
summary: Construction demand in Singapore is expected to recover to between S$23 billion and S$28 billion this year, driven by public-sector projects such as public housing and infrastructure developments. However, industry players are concerned about the labor crunch and potential delays, with some estimating it may take three to four months for the situation to improve. The government has acknowledged the challenges and is monitoring the situation to adjust measures as necessary to support the sector. Despite the recovery in demand, costs are expected to remain volatile due to material costs, technology adoption, and labor market fluctuations.

site_title: Suburban retail S-Reits have smoothest recovery path: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse predicts suburban retail S-Reits will have the smoothest recovery path in 2021, driven by domestic mobility and slow international travel improvement. Analysts recommend Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), and Keppel DC Reit (KDC Reit) for their domestic recovery potential. The analysts also expect industrial or data centre Reits to be a focus for acquisitions, citing relatively higher cap rates and low dividend yields.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'high degree of uncertainty' in global outlook
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva expressed uncertainty over the global economic outlook due to the coronavirus pandemic and divergence between rich and poor countries. She proposed allocating Special Drawing Rights to give countries more fiscal space to address the crisis and shift to a digital and green economy. Swedish Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson emphasized the need for liquidity and plans to consult with member countries on expanding liquidity options. The IMF aims to address the growing uncertainty and support countries in navigating the challenging economic landscape.

site_title: New Silkroutes explores working with Huawei on genomic medicine
summary: New Silkroutes Group has signed a memorandum of understanding with Huawei International to develop an AI platform for genomics-driven healthcare, aiming to use AI for breakthrough analyses and predictive models in oncology and genomics. The collaboration will focus on using big data to speed up genomic sequence analysis, enabling early condition identification and management. The agreement does not involve funding commitment, with both parties to sign a binding agreement if the collaboration advances.

site_title: World facing 'catastrophic moral failure' on vaccines: WHO chief
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, warned that the world is on the brink of a "catastrophic moral failure" if rich countries hoard Covid-19 vaccine doses while the poorest suffer. As of January 2021, 39 million doses were administered in 49 higher-income countries, while only 25 doses were given in the lowest-income country. The WHO has criticized vaccine manufacturers for prioritizing regulatory approval in rich countries and urging them to submit data for global approval. The organization aims to secure vaccines for 20% of the population in each participating country by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the opening on Monday, with the FTSE 100 down 0.1%, the DAX 30 down 0.2%, and the CAC 40 down 0.4%. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Protecting your digital financial assets (Ep 88)
summary: BT Money Hacks discusses protecting digital financial assets. Digital editor Chris Lim hosts Michael Shaulov, CEO of Fireblocks, to discuss advantages and disadvantages of dealing with digital assets, common mistakes, and steps to take before and during digital transactions. The conversation highlights the importance of consulting with a qualified financial adviser before making investment decisions. The episode provides general information for Singaporean listeners and emphasizes the need for caution when handling digital financial assets.

site_title: Cyber security breach at InnoTek's China subsidiary; networks in Singapore unscathed
summary: A Chinese subsidiary of precision metal part maker InnoTek, Mansfield Manufacturing Company Hong Kong, has suffered a cyber security breach where its IT network was unlawfully accessed by cyber criminals and its system encrypted by a virus. The incident has been contained, and most data has been recovered. The company has notified law enforcement authorities and security bureaus in Hong Kong and mainland China. InnoTek's shares closed flat, and the incident is not expected to have a material financial impact on the company's financial year ended Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Swiss ski resort St Moritz quarantines hotels, shuts schools to contain Covid variant
summary: Swiss ski resort St Moritz has quarantined two hotels and shut schools to contain an outbreak of the highly infectious Covid-19 variant. Health authorities have ordered everyone to wear masks in the town and mass testing of residents will take place on Tuesday. The move comes after about a dozen cases were reported in the two hotels, with employees and guests to undergo corona tests. The eastern canton of Grisons aims to protect the health of the population and guests.

site_title: Singapore's 2020 trade growth expected to carry through this year, say analysts
summary: Analysts expect Singapore's 2020 trade growth to continue into 2021, driven by a rebound in non-oil domestic exports (NODX) that rose 6.8% year-on-year in December, ending a two-month losing streak. The Asian economy is expected to shake off the Covid-19 malaise, with Singapore poised to benefit from the recovery. This growth is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, with analysts predicting a solid economic recovery for Singapore and the region in 2021.

site_title: Broker's take: Credit Suisse says S-Reits positioned for retail recovery
summary: Credit Suisse has upgraded its outlook for Singapore-listed retail and hospitality real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), predicting a recovery in 2021. The bank recommends "outperform" ratings for Frasers Centrepoint Trust, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and Keppel DC Reit, citing domestic recovery and a slow improvement in international travel. Credit Suisse also expects industrial or data centre Reits to be a focus for acquisitions, with Keppel DC Reit seen as a top performer for DPU accretion.

site_title: STI slips back under 3,000 points, in line with most key regional indexes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped back to under 3,000 points, closing at 2,990.40, 0.48% lower. Despite a 6.8% year-on-year gain in non-oil domestic exports, uncertainties surrounding new virus strains and vaccine acceptance rates hindered the market. Singapore Airlines fell 2.51% to S$4.28, while AEM Holdings rose 3.3% to S$4.04. Regional markets were mixed, with China's Shanghai Composite Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi declined.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of a stable property market for young Singaporeans to own homes, despite rising asset prices globally. Analysts predict a solid economic recovery for Singapore in 2021, driven by non-oil domestic exports. Singapore Airlines is set to become the world's first vaccinated international airline, while MAS revised tech risk management guidelines to address growing cyberthreats. Grab is preparing for an IPO, and office rents may dip 5% this year due to WFH trends. The STI slipped to 2,990.40 points, 0.48% lower.

site_title: SIA can be the world's first vaccinated international airline
summary: Singapore Airlines may become the world's first vaccinated international airline as the country inoculates 37,000 aviation and maritime front-line workers against COVID-19. The vaccination centers have a daily capacity of 2,000 and 1,000 people, which can be increased to 8,000. The move aims to revive Singapore's air hub and demonstrate the city-state's safety. If successful, it will boost international branding and pave the way for quarantine-free travel arrangements with other countries, including Hong Kong.

site_title: Malaysia unveils additional RM15b stimulus plan as Covid cases surge
summary: Malaysia has unveiled an additional RM15 billion stimulus package to combat the economic impact of a surge in coronavirus cases. The plan, announced by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, follows the country's declaration of a state of emergency last week. The measures aim to support the economy and contain the pandemic, despite concerns about market stability and investment climate. The government's move comes as the country navigates a challenging economic landscape.

site_title: UK is vaccinating 140 people per minute on average, minister says
summary: The UK is vaccinating 140 people per minute on average, with 3,857,266 people receiving a first dose and 449,736 a second dose, according to Vaccine Deployment Minister Nadhim Zahawi. The country is racing to vaccinate its population to exit the pandemic, with plans to expand vaccination centers and offer vaccines to key workers once those over 50 have been offered a shot. The UK aims to be among the first major countries to vaccinate its population, with 17 large vaccination centers set to open by the end of the month.

site_title: Grab joins five other regional startups gunning for IPO
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing firm, is reportedly considering an initial public offering (IPO) in the US this year, potentially raising at least $2 billion. The move joins a growing list of regional startups aiming for the public markets, including Tokopedia and Traveloka. Grab's plans depend on market conditions, but the company's valuation of $14 billion and presence in eight South-east Asian markets make it an attractive candidate. The IPO ambitions come as merger talks with archrival Gojek hit an impasse, with Gojek reportedly in talks with Tokopedia to pursue a $18 billion merger.

site_title: UOB completes acquisition of Vietnam fund manager
summary: UOB Asset Management has completed the acquisition of VAM Vietnam Fund Management Joint Stock Company for a cash consideration of S$6.7 million, revving up its presence in ASEAN. The entity will be renamed UOB Asset Management (Vietnam) Fund Management Joint Stock Company, subject to regulatory approval. UOBAM aims to become a leading asset management firm in Vietnam within the next five years, complementing its broader strategies in Asean equity and fixed income funds.

site_title: Shift to renewable energy eases key environmental burdens, EU says
summary: The European Union reports that its shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy has significantly reduced environmental burdens and greenhouse gas emissions. Renewable power generation has nearly doubled since 2005, producing 34% of EU electricity in 2019. The EU's switch has decreased emissions and improved key environmental problems, including soil acidification, eutrophication, and air pollution. To meet emissions-cutting goals, the EU aims for a 70% renewable power sector by 2030, requiring better reuse of materials to mitigate environmental impacts.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma to expand presence in South Korea through distribution agreement with JSPharma
summary: HYPHENS Pharma International has signed a distribution agreement with JSPharma for its pigment lightening cream, Fairence T-Complex, in South Korea. JSPharma, which represents international brands in medical clinics and hospitals, will distribute the cream to dermatologists, plastic surgeons, and aesthetic doctors. The cream is expected to reduce dark spots and pigmented skin issues. This expansion marks Hyphens Pharma's regional presence in South Korea, cementing its position in the dermo-cosmetic market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.01% to 28,862.77. This followed data showing China's economy expanded at a quicker pace than expected last year. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, rising 0.84% and 1.48%, respectively. The positive momentum was attributed to China's economic growth data.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as fresh Covid-19 cluster emerges in Sydney
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index slipping 0.8% to 6,663, amid worries over rising global coronavirus cases and concerns about the country's potential reopening of international borders this year. A fresh Covid-19 cluster in Sydney and reports of adverse effects from the Pfizer vaccine also contributed to the risk-off sentiment. Mining stocks fell despite rising copper and iron ore prices, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto shedding 3% and 1.5%, respectively.

site_title: Property market must remain stable so young Singaporeans can own homes: DPM
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a stable property market to enable young Singaporeans to own homes. Despite rising asset prices worldwide, the government is monitoring the local market closely to ensure it aligns with economic fundamentals. The government will adjust policies if necessary to maintain a stable and sustainable property market. The built environment sector is also expected to focus on sustainability and climate resilience, with initiatives like the Cooling Singapore project aiming to develop innovative solutions to mitigate urban heat challenges.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng said: "We do not want to see the property market run ahead of the underlying economic fundamentals."

site_title: Digital gold startup Bullion Asset Management raises US$1.3m led by ASX-listed Theta
summary: Bullion Asset Management (BAM), a digital gold startup, has raised US$1.3 million in a Series A round led by Theta Gold Mines, an ASX-listed company. Existing investors, including DigitalX and Decentralised Capital, also participated. The funds will be used for expansion and educating investors about digital gold. BAM's digital gold token, "GOLD", has seen 50% month-over-month growth in issuance since its launch. Theta has entered into a strategic agreement with BAM, allowing it to acquire up to 15% of the company and tokenise its gold production.

site_title: Grab mulling US IPO this year: sources
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing and food delivery giant, is exploring a US IPO this year, with sources indicating a potential raise of at least $2 billion. This would be the largest overseas share offering by a South-east Asian company. The move is encouraged by robust investor appetite for IPOs and comes as the company's business is reportedly doing better than before.

site_title: Singapore office rents may dip by 5% this year as WFH trends continue: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore office rents are expected to decline by around 5% in 2021 due to the permanent adoption of rotational remote working by corporates, according to Knight Frank. This trend is driven by lower net new demand for office space and a projected 5.3 million square feet of new supply from 2020 to 2023. However, ICT companies are expected to remain active in the office market, with tech giants such as ByteDance and Tencent expanding in Singapore. The Singapore government's effective handling of the Covid-19 outbreak and commitment to developing key sectors are also expected to boost the city-state as an office destination.

site_title: MAS revises tech risk management guidelines amid growing cyberthreats
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised technology risk management guidelines to address growing cyber threats in the financial sector. The guidelines, issued amid a recent spate of cyberattacks on supply chains, focus on enhancing risk mitigation strategies for financial institutions, including the timely analysis and sharing of cyber threat intelligence and conducting cyber exercises. The revised guidelines also emphasize the importance of strong oversight of third-party service providers and the appointment of a chief information officer and chief information security officer.

site_title: SPH media segment hit by low print ad revenue in Q1; accommodation, aged care businesses stable
summary: SPH media segment reported a 36% decline in print ad revenue for Q1 due to Covid-19 disruptions, but digital circulation revenue grew 26.5%. The company's purpose-built student accommodation and aged care segments remain stable. Print advertising remains crucial for core advertisers, and SPH will continue to offer innovative solutions. Circulation revenue increased 1.8% year-over-year, while digital ad revenue declined 8.1%. The company's aged care business in Singapore and Japan saw stable performance, with high bed occupancy rates.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.97% to 28,242.21, and the Topix index slipping 0.60% to 1,845.49. The decline followed profit-taking after US President-elect Joe Biden's $1.9-trillion stimulus plan was largely priced in.

site_title: Seoul: Shares down after Samsung group leader's prison sentence
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 2.33% to their sharpest decline in nearly three months, with the Kospi index ending at 3,013.93, after a court sentenced Samsung group leader Jay Lee to 2.5 years in prison. Samsung Electronics led losses with a 3.4% drop, while other heavyweights like LG Chem and Samsung BioLogics also declined. The decline was exacerbated by concerns over surging global coronavirus cases and their economic impact. Foreign investors were net sellers of $198.48 million worth of shares.

site_title: China's Sinovac steps up defence of vaccine after confusing data
summary: China's Sinovac Biotech defended its Covid-19 vaccine, CoronaVac, citing higher efficacy rates in a two-dose regime administered over a longer time frame. The vaccine showed a nearly 20 percentage point higher protection rate when doses were given three weeks apart, compared to the standard two-week interval. Despite inconsistent data readouts in clinical trials, Sinovac believes the vaccine could be more than borderline effective in preventing symptomatic Covid-19, particularly in medical workers exposed to the highly infectious pathogen.

site_title: Singapore government to ensure property market is in line with economic fundamentals
summary: The Singapore government is closely monitoring the property market to ensure it remains stable and sustainable. National Development Minister Desmond Lee said the government will adjust policies if necessary to prevent economic downturns, property bubbles, and external shocks. Despite the pandemic, the number of private housing units launched in 2020 was only 4.1% fewer than in 2019, and developers are poised to continue their new project launch momentum this year. Lee advised Singaporeans to remain vigilant and exercise caution in property purchase decisions, given uncertain economic outlook and possible rises in interest rates.

site_title: Japan's ministers see economy picking up, stick to FY2025 budget-balance target
summary: Japan's main economic ministers expressed optimism about the economy's recovery, projecting a 4% real-term growth and 4.4% nominal growth in the coming fiscal year. The projections exceed private-sector analysts' estimates, but a recent state of emergency declaration raises concerns about a double-dip recession. The ministers aim to revive the economy while restoring public finances, with a focus on achieving a primary budget surplus by fiscal 2025, despite Japan's massive public debt burden of over twice its economy.

site_title: IEA says oil, gas methane emissions down 10% in 2020 as output fell
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported that global methane emissions from oil and gas production decreased by 10% in 2020, primarily due to lower output rather than climate action. Oil and gas operations emitted around 70 million tonnes of methane, or 10% less than in 2019. The IEA warns that this trend may reverse if production increases to fuel economic growth. To curb methane emissions, the agency aims for energy sector emissions to fall below 50 million tonnes by 2025 and 25 million tonnes by 2030.

site_title: Tokyo to cut back on athletes at Olympics opening ceremony
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers plan to reduce the number of athletes attending the opening and closing ceremonies due to anti-virus measures limiting athlete time in the Olympic Village. The number of attendees is expected to be significantly lower than the original 11,000 athletes. Organisers also plan to "reconsider" athlete participation in ceremonies and ensure safe entry into the stadium.

site_title: Tesla says starts delivering Shanghai-made Model Y in China
summary: Tesla has started delivering its Shanghai-made Model Y sports utility vehicles to customers in China, marking a significant milestone for the US automaker. The company obtained permission to sell the cars from the Chinese government in November and has set a starting price of 339,900 yuan (S$69,840). This move is part of Tesla's efforts to expand its presence in the Chinese market and further diversify its production capabilities.

site_title: Japan PM vows to tackle virus as public support plunges
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga vowed to tackle the surging coronavirus cases and restore normal life "as soon as possible" amidst plunging public support for his government. His approval ratings have dropped six percentage points to 39% due to the government's handling of the third wave of infections. Suga committed to holding the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as a "proof of mankind's victory over the virus," despite a virus state of emergency in the greater Tokyo region until February 7.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH says lower valuation for ThaiBev's Vietnam beer assets expected
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) expects a lower valuation for ThaiBev's Vietnam beer assets due to the impact of drink-driving regulations and Covid-19 restrictions. The analyst estimates beer volumes in Vietnam to be 15-20% below pre-Covid-19 levels. However, the market remains a compelling prospect for growth due to its young population. UOBKH maintains its "buy" call on ThaiBev's stock with a sum-of-the-parts target price of S$0.85.

site_title: Chinese e-cigarette maker seeks up to US$1.2 billion in US IPO
summary: Chinese e-cigarette maker RLX Technology Inc. is seeking up to $1.17 billion in a US initial public offering (IPO), despite tensions between the US and China. The company, backed by Sequoia Capital China, plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite concerns over Chinese companies' audit papers, the US remains an attractive fund-raising avenue for mainland firms, with $15 billion raised by Chinese IPOs on US exchanges in 2020. RLX, China's largest e-cigarette maker, has seen its revenues increase to $2.2 billion in the first nine months of 2020.

site_title: 14 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 12 imported, two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 14 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,127. 12 cases were imported, with two community cases linked to a Singapore Police Force para-veterinarian. The community cases, a 44-year-old man and his wife, had symptoms but did not seek medical attention, and their test results returned positive. The MOH urged everyone to reduce transmission risk and seek medical attention immediately if showing early/mild symptoms.

site_title: Total inks US$2.5b deal to add 20% stake in Adani Green
summary: Total has agreed to a $2.5 billion deal to acquire a 20% stake in India's Adani Green Energy, taking a board seat and a 50% stake in operating solar assets with 2.35 GW capacity. This move diversifies Total's efforts beyond oil as it implements its energy transition strategy based on renewables and natural gas.

site_title: China pork output recovers sharply in 2020, down 3.3% y-o-y: stats bureau
summary: China's pork output fell 3.3% in 2020 to 41.13 million tonnes, but recovered sharply from the 21% drop in 2019 due to government support and investment. The sector was ravaged by African swine fever in 2019, but a 200 billion yuan investment in new farms helped rebuild the herd. China slaughtered 527.04 million hogs in 2020, with output in the final quarter jumping 21% from the same period a year ago.

site_title: Heritas leads US$16m round in Indian digital health startup MFine
summary: Heritas Capital led a US$16 million funding round for Indian digital health startup MFine, joined by Singapore-based family office Y'S Investment and existing investors. MFine plans to triple investments in AI, mobile engineering, and device integration, expand its hospital network, and initiate Series C fundraising. The platform, which has over 4,000 doctors from 600 hospitals, aims to optimize healthcare resources and address unmet needs in India and beyond.

site_title: Mount Emily residential block relaunched for sale with lower S$18m guide price
summary: A freehold residential block at Mount Emily Road has been relaunched for sale by tender with a reduced guide price of S$18 million, down 25% from its initial launch in June 2020. The new price translates to S$1,115 per square foot. This compares favorably to recently transacted collective sales, with prices ranging from S$1,158 to S$1,120 per square foot per plot ratio. The relaunch aims to test demand for Singapore prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Billionaire Piramal to take over key Indian shadow bank Dewan
summary: Billionaire Ajay Piramal's conglomerate, Piramal Enterprises Ltd, has won a bid to take over Dewan Housing Finance Corp, a bankrupt Indian shadow lender. The resolution plan was approved by Dewan's committee of creditors with Piramal receiving 94% of the votes. The takeover will help Piramal double down on its real estate-focused shadow banking business, bringing resolution to a key case in India's insolvency system. The deal marks a test of the country's bankruptcy system, which has seen high-profile cases linger for years.

site_title: A high-end Croatian wine finds its way to US presidential inauguration
summary: A Croatian red wine, produced by the Benmosche Family Winery, will be served at events on US presidential Inauguration Day. The wine, a Zinfandel and Dingac blend, sells for $60-70 per bottle in the US. This is a significant opportunity for Croatia's small wine industry, which has limited global competitiveness. The winery, which produces 4,000-5,000 bottles annually, hopes the exposure will promote Croatian wines. The winery's director, Boris Mrgudic, sees this as a valuable promotion for the country's wine industry.

site_title: Philippine bank virus rebound to be faster than post-Asian crisis
summary: Philippine banks are expected to recover faster from the coronavirus pandemic than from the 1997 Asian financial crisis due to low interest rates, higher capital, and a stable economy. The nation's bad loan ratio may peak at 6-7% this year, compared to 4% in 2020. Banks are aggressively provisioning for losses and have ample provisions, with most lenders having over 100% coverage. The economy is expected to grow 6.5-7.5% this year, and lenders predict a recovery in 3-4 years, half the time it took after the 1997 crisis.

site_title: UK firms urge government to help struggling Eurostar
summary: British business leaders have urged the UK government to rescue struggling Eurostar, citing the firm's critical state due to the coronavirus crisis and tightened travel restrictions. Eurostar, majority owned by French firm SNCF, has seen its services down 85% from last year, with only one daily service between Paris and London. The London First lobby group has warned the Treasury and Department for Transport not to let the firm "fall between the cracks of support," calling for swift action to safeguard its future.

site_title: Escaping coronavirus lockdowns, tourists flock to Dubai
summary: Dubai has become a popular destination for tourists seeking to escape coronavirus lockdowns, with the emirate flinging open its doors despite a sharp rise in cases. Life in Dubai looks much like normal, with restaurants, hotels, and mega-malls open for business, while mask-wearing and social distancing are strictly enforced. Despite concerns from economists, tourists are flocking to Dubai, with many citing a desire to experience winter in a sunny destination. The city's government is seeking to capitalize on the trend, with a focus on attracting visitors ahead of the Dubai Expo 2020.

site_title: More than 760,000 pounds of Hot Pockets recalled
summary: Nestle Prepared Foods has recalled over 760,000 pounds of frozen pepperoni Hot Pockets due to possible contamination with pieces of glass and hard plastic, posing a choking or laceration risk. The recall was issued after four consumer complaints were received, with one minor oral injury reported. No other reports of injury or illness have been documented.

site_title: Twitter suspends QAnon-linked Republican lawmaker's account
summary: US Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's Twitter account was temporarily suspended for 12 hours after promoting election fraud claims in her home state of Georgia. The suspension was due to "multiple violations of Twitter's civic integrity policy." Greene, a strong supporter of former President Donald Trump, has echoed his baseless election claims and promoted QAnon conspiracy theories. This move follows a series of social media bans targeting Trump and QAnon followers in the wake of the January 6 US Capitol riot.

site_title: China's 2020 property investment rises 7% y-o-y
summary: China's property investment rose 7.0% in 2020 from the previous year, with a slower growth rate compared to 2019. Property sales by floor area increased 2.6% year-over-year, faster than the first 11 months' 1.3% rise. The growth rate was also up from a 6.8% gain in the first 11 months of 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates 'add' on Jiutian Chemical with S$0.145 TP
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Jiutian Chemical Group with an "add" recommendation, targeting the stock at S$0.145. The analysts forecast a record net profit of S$40.9 million in FY2020 and S$40.9 million in FY2021, driven by favorable industry dynamics, including rising demand for dimethylformamide (DMF) and lower raw material costs. The company's cost advantages and higher average selling prices are expected to drive growth, with the analysts pegging the target price at 5.7 times forward price-to-earnings.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks down after gains, China growth beats expectations
summary: Asia stocks fell on Monday after a recent rally, with Hong Kong and Shanghai enjoying gains after China's economy grew 2.3% last year, beating expectations. Investors took a breather ahead of US President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus proposal, which may be watered down, and concerns about new virus cases and lockdowns. Despite this, analysts remain upbeat for the long-term outlook, with some noting that markets needed a breather to justify reflationary expectations.

site_title: Biden to cancel Keystone XL pipeline permit on first day in office: CBC
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden plans to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline permit via executive action on his first day in office, according to a briefing note from the Biden transition team. The decision would reverse the permit issued by the Trump administration in 2019. This move is seen as a significant step towards addressing environmental concerns and aligning with the Biden administration's climate change policies. The exact details of the plan are still being finalized.

site_title: Miners trapped underground in China send note up to rescuers
summary: Miners trapped underground in eastern China's Shandong province after a gold mine blast sent a note to rescuers, stating 12 of the 22 trapped miners are still alive. The note, sent via a metal wire with food parcels attached, requested medical supplies and warned of underground water. Four miners are injured, while the state of the remaining 10 workers is unknown. Rescuers have been drilling through the mine since Sunday, and two officials have been sacked over the accident. The note's writer expressed urgency and hope for rescue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Monday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Monday with losses, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.42% to 28,454.59. Investors await Chinese economic growth data release later in the day. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.32% to 3,554.80, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.30% to 2,359.65.

site_title: Ideas for Jurong Lake District include bigger plots, signature events
summary: Singapore's Jurong Lake District, set to create 100,000 new jobs and 20,000 homes, is being developed with suggestions from industry stakeholders. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) plans to sell larger sites with attractive option schemes, and hold signature events to make the area more attractive. The district will also feature landmark developments, placemaking, and a mix of office, residential, and retail uses. The URA is reviewing policies to support the growth of last-mile business-to-consumer logistics and is partnering with the industry to develop pilots for innovative delivery systems.

images.alt_text: Developers, investors and businesses like Jurong Lake District's improved rail connectivity, car-lite environment; and sustainable district infrastructure.

site_title: Meet the Bidens: America's new 'first family'
summary: President-elect Joe Biden and his wife Jill will become the new White House residents on January 20. Jill Biden, an educator and future first lady, plans to continue her full-time job as an English professor while working on education issues and relaunching Joining Forces, a mission to support military families. The Bidens have three children: Hunter, 50, who has struggled with addiction; Beau, who passed away in 2015; and Ashley, who is not in the public eye. The couple is also bringing two German shepherds, Champ and Major, and a cat to the White House.

site_title: Audi delays output, idles 10,000 staff on chip shortage
summary: Audi, a Volkswagen AG brand, is delaying the production of high-end cars due to a global semiconductor shortage. The company has put over 10,000 workers on furlough, but expects to make up for lost time in the second half of 2021. Audi's CEO, Markus Duesmann, stated that the company will produce fewer models than usual in the first quarter to cope with the shortage, which is affecting other carmakers as well. The shortage is attributed to an unexpected rise in demand for cars, particularly in China, and the US Commerce Department is urging Asian semiconductor makers to reallocate output.

images.alt_text: A global semiconductor shortage is forcing Audi to delay the production of some high-end cars and furlough workers, its chief executive officer told the Financial Times.

site_title: Californians face unprecedented fire blackouts in January
summary: California utilities warn of possible power blackouts affecting over 280,000 homes and businesses due to high winds and drought conditions. Edison International and PG&E Corp. plan to cut power to prevent live wires from sparking wildfires. This is an unprecedented move in January, with the potential to affect over 800,000 people. Climate change is exacerbating California's extreme weather, with record temperatures and drought conditions contributing to the risk of wildfires.

site_title: India's fuel demand makes shaky start to 2021
summary: India's fuel demand began 2021 with a decline in sales of transport and cooking fuels, with diesel sales dropping 6.6% from December and 3.5% from the same period last year. However, motor fuel sales remained 8.5% higher from the previous year due to increased use of personal vehicles to avoid public transport amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Liquefied petroleum gas sales also increased year-over-year due to plunging temperatures.

images.alt_text: Indian energy demand got off to a shaky start in the new year with sales of transport and cooking fuels over the first two weeks of 2021 declining from a month earlier.

site_title: China's Q4 GDP grows 6.5% y-o-y, beats expectations as recovery gains momentum
summary: China's GDP grew 6.5% in the fourth quarter of 2020, surpassing forecasts of 6.1%, as the country's economic recovery gained momentum. This marked the second quarter of growth in 2020, following a 4.9% expansion in the third quarter. China's GDP grew 2.3% in 2020, avoiding a contraction as the world's second-largest economy rebounded from the COVID-19 pandemic. The strong data has led the central bank to scale back policy support, but policymakers have signaled no abrupt shift in direction.

site_title: Quick takes: What is driving property buying in Singapore?
summary: Singapore's property market has seen a surge in buying activity over the past few months, driven by low-interest rates, pent-up demand following the "circuit-breaker" period, and a projected rise in HDB upgraders. Developers sold 10,024 private housing units in 2020, surpassing 2019's figure by 1.1%. The government is monitoring the market closely, with some analysts projecting private home prices to rise by 0-5% in 2021. A new en bloc cycle is also anticipated, with unsold residential units falling to 26,600 in Q3 2020, signaling undersupply in the primary market.

site_title: UK vacancies for remote workers triple in a year: consultancy
summary: The UK saw a significant increase in remote work opportunities, with 80,700 remote jobs advertised in November 2020, tripling from 26,600 in 2019. This trend is expected to continue, with New Street Consulting Group predicting a hybrid workforce that incorporates working from home as an option. However, it remains unclear how many remote roles will revert to office-based work once the pandemic subsides.

site_title: England expands Covid-19 vaccination programme to more groups
summary: England expands its Covid-19 vaccination programme to include people aged 70 and above and those considered clinically extremely vulnerable. The programme, the largest in Europe, aims to vaccinate 14 million people by mid-February. Over half of those aged 80 and older have already received a vaccination. The rollout is expected to ease lockdown restrictions in March, with the government hoping to meet its target of vaccinating all adults by September.

site_title: Civmec awaits bonanza from commodity rush, defence spending, infrastructure
summary: Australian engineering firm Civmec has seen a surge in revenue and profits in 2021, driven by a commodity rush and defence spending. The company clinched several fresh jobs, insulated from pandemic-led problems, and is now poised to benefit from a massive government investment in naval shipbuilding in Australia. Civmec's waterfront facility in Henderson, South Perth, has doubled its capacity and capacity to double revenue, and the company is also building a rescue facility for submarines. Despite a slow stock performance, Civmec's CEO Patrick Tallon is optimistic about the company's future growth prospects.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports grow 6.8% in December as gold regains its lustre
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports grew 6.8% in December, beating a two-month losing streak, driven by non-electronics such as machinery, non-monetary gold, and measuring instruments. Shipments to South Korea, the US, and Taiwan contributed to the growth, while electronic exports rose 13.7% due to strong demand for integrated circuits. Total trade dipped 0.3% due to a continued contraction in the oil trade, with imports outweighing exports' return to growth.

site_title: Measuring the impact of Covid-19 on economic growth in ASEAN
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted economic growth in ASEAN countries, with the average growth rate reduced by 7.8 percentage points in 2020. The worst-affected economies are the Philippines (-14.4 percentage points), Malaysia (-10.4 percentage points), and Thailand (-10.2 percentage points). In contrast, Brunei, Laos, and Vietnam recorded positive growth in 2020. The economic slowdown is attributed to shrinking private consumption and investment, as well as a decline in outputs in services and industry. Real GDP growth in ASEAN is expected to hit the bottom in the second quarter of 2020 and improve in the rest of 2020 and 2021.

images.alt_text: At present, real GDP growth in ASEAN is expected to hit the bottom in the second quarter of 2020 and would improve in the rest of 2020 and 2021. However, the revival of economic activities in 2021 can be interrupted by the on-going spread of COVID-19 in Indonesia and the Philippines, and most recently in Myanmar, Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Australia: Shares open lower after new coronavirus cluster emerges in Sydney
summary: Australian shares fell 0.79% to 6,662.5 points on Monday, driven by losses in mining and energy sectors amid a new coronavirus cluster in Sydney. The cluster, linked to a man in Berala suburb, led to a decline in mining stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, and oil prices due to Chinese lockdown concerns. Financials also fell, with the "big four" banks experiencing losses between 0.4% and 1%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to profit-taking following US President-elect Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.06% and the Topix index declined 0.63%. The moves were seen as a result of the plan being largely priced in by investors.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday's open tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.3% on Monday, tracking a Wall Street retreat, despite a surprise 6.8% increase in non-electronics exports in December, which broke a two-month losing streak. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 2,996.18. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 72, with Jiutian Chemical rising 3% and Wilmar International gaining 1.2%. Banking stocks declined, with DBS down 1.3% and UOB losing 0.5%. The US market also fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% and the S&P 500 losing 0.7%.

site_title: Australia unlikely to fully reopen borders in 2021 as virus cases slide
summary: Australia is unlikely to fully reopen its international borders in 2021 despite a decline in local COVID-19 cases, according to the country's health department head Brendan Murphy. Even with widespread vaccination, it's unclear whether it will prevent virus transmission. Australia reported zero local cases on Monday, but overseas travelers at the Australian Open were placed in hard quarantine. The country has reported over 22,000 local cases and 909 deaths since the pandemic began. Australia will begin its immunization program next month, with some states considering venue rules for unvaccinated individuals.

site_title: UK house prices dip as sellers seek deals before tax break ends: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices dropped 0.9% in December and early January, slowing annual growth to 3.3% due to sellers seeking deals before a tax cut for buyers expires on March 31. Despite this, the number of buyers contacting agents increased by 12% and sales agreements rose by 9% in January compared to the same period last year. The housing market remains busy, but other measures suggest the boom may be fading, with a gauge of new buyer enquiries falling to a seven-month low in December.

site_title: Canadian dollar drops, posts weekly decline on greenback short-covering
summary: The Canadian dollar declined 0.8% against the US dollar, posting a weekly loss of 0.4%, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid declining risk appetite. The decline is attributed to greenback gains due to higher US Treasury yields and concerns over US fiscal spending and vaccine rollout. Despite record home sales in Canada, the Canadian dollar weakened against the greenback, with Canadian government bond yields falling in sympathy with US Treasuries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Boustead, Sembcorp, OUE Lippo Healthcare, ART, Q&M
summary: Stocks to watch on Monday include Boustead Projects, which secured a S$130 million green loan to refinance ALICE@Mediapolis, and Sembcorp Industries, which appointed former CEO Lim Ming Yan as a new independent director. OUE Lippo Healthcare warned of a significant loss in its half-year and full-year results, while Ascott Residence Trust (ART) expects to cut distribution per stapled security by 60-70% in FY2020. Q&M Dental Group sold its stake in a Chinese dental equipment maker for S$25.1 million, and GL Limited hit a 10-month high after a proposed privatisation plan.

site_title: Biden team lays out plans as inauguration, impeachment loom
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's team outlined plans to tackle the nation's crises, including the pandemic, economy, climate change, and racial tensions, as he prepares to take power amid an impeachment trial of Donald Trump. Biden aims to pass a $1.9-trillion stimulus package and accelerate the vaccine rollout, with a goal of 100 million doses within his first 100 days. The Senate impeachment trial casts a shadow over his path forward, but Biden hopes Congress can handle both the trial and his agenda.

site_title: Trump administration slams China's Huawei, halting shipments from Intel, others: sources
summary: The Trump administration has notified Huawei suppliers, including Intel, that it is revoking certain licenses to sell to the Chinese company, and intends to reject dozens of other applications. This action is the latest in a long-running effort to weaken Huawei, citing national security and foreign policy concerns. Eight licenses were revoked from four companies, and at least one license was revoked from Japanese chip maker Kioxia Corp. The move comes as the administration is set to leave office and is part of a broader effort to restrict Huawei's access to US technology.

site_title: Boustead Projects bags S$130m green loan from UOB
summary: Boustead Projects secured a S$130 million green loan from UOB to refinance its smart eco-sustainable business park development, Alice@Mediapolis. The loan, extended to a joint venture, features energy-saving implementations and greener building methodologies. This marks Boustead Projects' first green loan, with 80% of the building's floor area using sustainable methods. The company's managing director, Thomas Chu, highlighted the commercial advantages of investing in eco-sustainable projects, while UOB's head of group wholesale banking, Frederick Chin, praised the collaboration as contributing to a sustainable future.

site_title: Russia detains Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny, faces clash with Western nations
summary: Russia detained opposition politician Alexei Navalny upon his return from Germany, where he was recovering from a poisoning with Novichok nerve agent. Navalny faces a 3.5-year prison sentence for allegedly violating his suspended sentence, and his detention has triggered international condemnation, with Western nations calling for his immediate release. The move may lead to increased pressure on the West to tighten sanctions on Russia, particularly on the $11.6 billion Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project.

site_title: Branson's Virgin Orbit reaches space for first time
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit successfully launched its rocket, LauncherOne, into space from the wing of a 747 plane, marking the company's first successful flight. The rocket, weighing 21m, reached orbit after being released from the plane over the Pacific Ocean. This achievement paves the way for a new method of launching low-cost satellites, a booming market. Virgin Orbit aims to offer a quick and flexible service for operators of small satellites, weighing between 300kg and 500kg, with a goal to disrupt the traditional space launch industry.

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie CEO thinks cooling measures unlikely; weighs in on HDB 'lottery' effect
summary: Singapore residential property prices are expected to trend steadily upwards due to a K-shaped economic recovery, where different sectors recover at varying paces. OrangeTee & Tie CEO Steven Tan believes the government will not introduce cooling measures in the near future. He attributes the stable trend to factors such as low interest rates, a surge in upgraders, and a shift towards work-from-home lifestyles. Tan suggests introducing shorter leasehold tenures for higher-end HDB flats to prevent speculative buying, but this has not been ruled out by the government.

site_title: 2021 construction demand forecast at S$23-28b; public sector to drive bulk of demand: BCA
summary: Singapore's construction demand is forecasted to recover to S$23-28 billion in 2021, up from S$21.3 billion in 2020, driven mainly by public sector projects. The public sector is expected to account for 65% of the demand, with S$15 billion to S$18 billion allocated for public housing and infrastructure projects. Private sector demand is projected to be between S$8 billion and S$10 billion. The total nominal construction output is expected to increase to S$24-27 billion, up from S$19.5 billion in 2020.

site_title: Samsung's Lee faces sentencing for bribery charge after four years of trials
summary: A South Korean court will sentence Samsung Electronics heir Jay Y. Lee on a bribery charge, likely impacting his leadership and the company's control. Lee, 52, was convicted of bribing an associate of former President Park Geun Hye and jailed for five years. He was released after serving a year, and the case was sent back to the Seoul High Court for a ruling on the sentencing. Prosecutors have called for a nine-year jail term, while Lee's lawyers argue that a suspended sentence is possible. The outcome may influence South Korea's views on big business and family-run conglomerates.

site_title: The lottery effect - fair or foul?
summary: The sale of higher-end HDB flats in prime locations, such as the Greater Southern Waterfront, may create a two-tier public housing market. Lawrence Loh, Director of the Centre for Governance and Sustainability, suggests making explicit the high subsidies to buyers, allowing non-tax strengths to prevail. This approach could address issues of affordability and fairness in the housing market.

site_title: Sembcorp names ex-CEO of CapitaLand as new independent director
summary: Sembcorp Industries has appointed Lim Ming Yan, former president and CEO of CapitaLand, as a non-executive and independent director, effective immediately. This appointment comes after the company's CFO Graham Cockroft's resignation. Lim previously held directorships at multiple companies, including chairman of Workforce Singapore. The move follows a week of market volatility, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks down in Europe and the US due to market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions concerns.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries has appointed Lim Ming Yan as a non-executive and independent director, with effect from Monday.

site_title: Oil drops 1% as rising coronavirus cases end supply-led rally
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday, extending losses that ended a supply-led rally, as rising coronavirus cases cast doubt on market recovery. Brent crude dropped 45 cents to $54.65 a barrel, and US oil declined 43 cents to $51.93 a barrel. The rally, driven by production cuts and strong Chinese demand, was fueled by the start of Covid-19 vaccine rollouts and Saudi Arabia's surprise output cut. The recent price gains are now being questioned as the market grapples with the impact of rising coronavirus cases.

site_title: Buying frenzy caps record year for Canadian housing market
summary: The Canadian housing market ended 2020 on a record high, with national home sales rising 7.2% in December and reaching a record 551,392 units. Benchmark home prices increased 1.5% to $607,280, a 13.1% gain from year-ago levels. Experts attribute the surge to low mortgage rates, a pandemic-induced desire for bigger homes, and a historic lack of housing supply. With little prospect for the market to cool off in 2021, economists predict property values will continue to rise.

site_title: Treasury nominee Janet Yellen to say US does not seek weaker dollar: WSJ
summary: Janet Yellen, President-elect Joe Biden's Treasury nominee, will testify before the Senate on Tuesday, affirming the US commitment to market-determined foreign exchange rates. She is expected to state that the US does not seek a weaker dollar, opposing attempts by other countries to devalue their currency. This stance aligns with a traditional US policy, reversing the approach of outgoing President Donald Trump, who had sought a stronger dollar to gain a competitive advantage. Yellen's testimony is seen as a return to a traditional US posture on the dollar.

site_title: Apple's Cook says Parler could return to App Store with reforms
summary: Apple's CEO Tim Cook said Parler, a social network popular among conservatives, could return to the App Store if it changes its moderation policies. Apple suspended Parler downloads after the US Capitol attack on January 6, citing incitement to violence on the platform. Cook stated that if Parler improves moderation, it would be allowed back on the App Store. Parler sued Amazon after being cut off from internet servers, alleging Amazon was violating antitrust laws to help rival Twitter. Cook also expressed concerns over the attack on the Capitol, calling it an "attack on our democracy."

site_title: After long journey, Fiat Chrysler, PSA merge to become Stellantis
summary: Fiat Chrysler and PSA Group merged to form Stellantis, the world's fourth-largest automotive group, in a $52 billion deal. The merger, finalized after over a year, aims to fund the shift to electric driving and take on rivals Toyota and Volkswagen. Stellantis will be led by Carlos Tavares, with plans to cut annual costs by over $8 billion without plant closures. The new group faces challenges, including excess production capacity and a poor performance in China, which Tavares will address in his first press conference on Tuesday.

site_title: Europcar credit insurance debacle sends warning to speculators
summary: A failed attempt to settle debt insurance on struggling French car rental company Europcar Mobility Group resulted in protection buyers being left with nothing, highlighting flaws in the US$9 trillion credit derivatives market. The auction process, designed to avoid shortages, was overwhelmed by bids exceeding available securities, driven by speculators. The incident undermines confidence in the market, with dealers warning that speculators can lose money. The Europcar debacle is a reminder that the market doesn't always function as expected, and market participants must pay attention to the situation they're trying to cover.

site_title: Phil Spector, pop producer convicted of murder, dead at 81
summary: Phil Spector, the 81-year-old pop producer convicted of murder, has died. Spector, known as the "Tycoon of Teen" and creator of the "Wall of Sound" production technique, was imprisoned in 2009 for the 2003 shooting death of actress Lana Clarkson. Born in 1939, Spector's music career spanned the 1960s, producing hits for The Crystals, The Ronettes, and The Righteous Brothers. He later became reclusive and was accused of abusive behavior, including threatening his ex-wife and artists he worked with. Spector's cause of death will be determined by the medical examiner.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's latest report reveals a surge in the Capesize market to a three-month high, with rates peaking at $26,489. Charterers regained some influence, but fixture activity was weaker at the end of the week. The Panamax market remained in flux, with FFA values tumbling and physical sentiment becoming cautious. Ultramax and Supramax rates improved, while Handysize activity levels were slightly low. VLCC rates weakened, and Suezmax rates remained steady. Aframax rates were steady, and Clean rates were largely unchanged. The market is now calibrating itself before the next move, with rates potentially adjusting up or down.

site_title: A 'very young' bull market in stocks is still minting believers
summary: US stocks continue to rally despite warnings of a potential crash, with the S&P 500's price-earnings ratio reaching levels not seen since the dot-com era. A 10-month, 70% rally has pushed investor holdings of stocks to 43.8%, trailing the peak of 50% before the 2007-2009 global financial crisis. Analysts predict the bull market is still young and has room for a 26% appreciation, citing factors such as growing profits, income forecasts, and low bond allocations. Young investors are flocking to stocks, despite concerns about valuations and the coronavirus.

site_title: Global investors poised to buy US Treasuries if 10-year gets into 1.25-1.3% range
summary: Global investors are poised to buy US Treasuries if the 10-year yield reaches 1.25-1.3% range, limiting upside in yields. A unified Democratic government has sparked inflation expectations, driving long-term Treasury yields back to pre-pandemic levels. Overseas buyers, particularly in Asia, are watching the market, with Japan and China expected to increase their Treasury holdings if yields breach the key levels. This could limit the cost to US taxpayers of financing the nation's swelling debt load and reduce the risk of Treasury yields rising further, potentially affecting other asset classes.

site_title: Not-so-festive season for food manufacturers with supply crunch, missed opportunities, higher costs
summary: Singapore's food manufacturers and suppliers are facing a challenging festive season due to ongoing supply chain issues and unpredictable demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Missed opportunities and higher costs are affecting businesses, with some forced to close Christmas orders early and seek alternative storage spaces. To mitigate these challenges, companies are diversifying their supply sources and providing suppliers with longer lead times, while others are investing in warehouse space to hold more stocks. The situation highlights the need for more flexible and resilient supply chains in the food industry.

site_title: Rescue deals lift 2020 equity fundraising to 10-year high
summary: Singapore's secondary equity fundraising reached a decade high of S$12 billion in 2020, driven by jumbo rights issues and mega asset acquisitions. This momentum is expected to continue as the economy recovers, despite fewer rescue deals. The surge in fundraising was largely attributed to the Singapore Airlines and Sembcorp Marine rights issues, as well as S-Reits seeking funds for asset acquisitions.

site_title: Petronas taps changing demand trends to grow downstream business
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil firm, is capitalizing on changing demand trends and new markets to grow its downstream business. The company identified areas with high demand, such as energy transition, petrochemicals, and nitrile gloves, to counter the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Petronas' downstream segment will focus on improving non-fuel income, capturing opportunities in energy transition, and expanding into new markets like the electric vehicle market and the oxyalkylates market. The company aims to reshape its portfolio mix to ensure high-value returns while prioritizing sustainability and efficiency.

site_title: Britain invites G-7 leaders to Cornish resort for June summit
summary: Britain plans to host the first in-person G-7 meeting in June, inviting leaders of major developed economies to discuss post-pandemic recovery and climate change. Prime Minister Boris Johnson aims to forge a consensus on pro-free trade and sustainable economic growth. The meeting will take place in a picturesque Cornish resort, marking the first in-person G-7 gathering in nearly two years.

site_title: Electronics companies in the region still lag China: report
summary: ASEAN electronics companies remain lagging behind China in terms of revenue, with the Asean Quad accounting for just 1% of Asian electronics revenues, while China dominates with 23% and Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan contributing 74%. Challenges include an uncompetitive business environment in the Philippines, reliance on low-wage workers in Malaysia, and underdeveloped infrastructure in Vietnam. Despite this, the Asean Quad has a strong presence in niche segments, and China's rise into high-value-added technology could create opportunities for other Asian economies to expand.

site_title: Top Glove screens more workers after some test positive
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest rubber glove maker, is screening more workers at four of its Malaysian factories after some tested positive for the coronavirus. The company is closely monitoring the situation and is in discussion with management to develop and update affected employees. Following a previous lockdown due to over 4,000 infected workers, Top Glove aims to avoid a repeat. The company has already begun mass screening and contract tracing at affected facilities, amid a record surge in Malaysia's daily cases and fatalities.

site_title: Normanton Park sells about one third of 1,862 units on first day
summary: Normanton Park, a Singapore residential project, sold about one-third of its 1,862 units on the first day, with 600 units sold at an average price of S$1,750 per square foot. The majority of buyers were Singapore citizens and permanent residents, mostly seeking owner-occupiers or property investors. The project's sales gallery drew a large turnout of 12,000 visitors despite heavy rain. Kingsford Huray Development had previously faced a no-sale licence for nearly two years before receiving a sales licence on November 30.

site_title: Normanton Park sells nearly a third of 1,862 units on first day at S$1,750 psf
summary: Normanton Park, a 1,862-unit residential project, sold about 1/3 of its units on the first day at an average price of S$1,750 psf. 600 units were sold, with 80% being one- and two-bedroom units. Three commercial units were also taken up. The majority of buyers are Singapore citizens and permanent residents, mostly "owner-occupiers or property investors". The development, expected to obtain a Temporary Occupation Permit in 2023, saw a heavy turnout of 12,000 visitors during its preview.

site_title: Emirates stops flights to major Australian cities
summary: Emirates has suspended flights to Sydney, Brisbane, and Melbourne due to Australia's restrictions on international arrivals amid fears of new virus strains. The airline will continue to operate flights to Perth. The decision comes as Australia's borders remain closed and the government limits citizens' return. Prime Minister Scott Morrison cited concerns over a new strain of Covid-19, which has led to a snap lockdown in Brisbane. The move affects tens of thousands of stranded Australians attempting to return home.

site_title: Europe vaccine rollout shifts up a gear as supply worries linger
summary: Europe is shifting its COVID-19 vaccination rollout, with France and Russia preparing to increase inoculations next week. Despite supply concerns, France will begin vaccinating people over 75 and Russia will start mass vaccinations. The vaccination campaigns come amid criticism of the slow rollout in Europe, with some countries tightening restrictions. Meanwhile, India's vaccination drive has started successfully, with over 224,000 people receiving their first doses, and Israel has begun vaccinating prison inmates.

site_title: Australian Open to go ahead despite 72 players in quarantine
summary: The Australian Open tennis tournament will proceed as scheduled despite 72 players in a 14-day hotel quarantine, following a third positive Covid-19 test on a flight from Doha. The additional 25 players will join 47 others already in quarantine, with all players and officials restricted to hotel rooms for training and treatment. Tournament director Craig Tiley stated that measures will be taken to make the situation as fair as possible for those in lockdown, including providing fitness equipment for hotel rooms.

site_title: Bets on 2021 economic recovery largely priced in
summary: The ongoing economic recovery rally has stalled due to the worsening pandemic, rising US dollar, and 10-year bond yields, resulting in massive sell-offs in riskier assets. The S&P 500 Index has rallied 200 points since the 2020 US presidential elections, but Bitcoin plummeted 20% from its all-time highs, with the US dollar and bond yields contributing to the decline. Investors' optimism for a more stable economic climate has been tempered by the ongoing pandemic and trade tensions.

site_title: Arctic cold blast will prop up European energy prices into spring
summary: A prolonged Arctic cold blast in Europe is expected to impact energy prices through spring, with analysts predicting a tighter global gas market and volatility in prices. The cold weather has already pushed European power and gas prices to their highest levels in years, with forecasts indicating that the situation may not improve until late January. As people turn up their heating, gas stores are expected to be depleted, leading to higher summer prices. Experts predict a 75% increase in average gas prices compared to last year, with some regions experiencing price gains of up to 10%.

site_title: Secondary fundraisings portfolio acquisitions continue into 2021
summary: Singaporean secondary fundraisings raised S$4.5 billion in 2020, with S$3.0 billion from placements and S$1.5 billion from rights issues, primarily to fund portfolio acquisitions. Three major Reits, Ascendas Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, and Mapletree Logistics Trust, raised over S$3.0 billion. These acquisitions expanded the Reits' exposure to US technology cities and European data centre hubs. The sector saw a healthy balance sheet and low interest rates, enabling non-secondary market acquisitions, and averaged S$300 million in daily turnover.

site_title: Fermented food craze prompts buyers hunting down the right bacteria
summary: Fermented food sales surge amid pandemic, with consumers seeking "perfect bacteria" in products like kombucha and kimchi. Companies like Chr. Hansen Holding A/S and Kerry Group are branding bacteria to capitalize on growing demand, with some labeling products as having "real presence" and supporting health claims. The trend is driven by the pandemic's impact on consumer behavior, with a shift towards healthy foods and exotic flavors. Europe lags behind other regions in bacteria brand recognition, presenting opportunities for growth in the probiotics industry.

site_title: Super fast 5G in the US still a work in progress
summary: US 5G networks remain a work in progress despite marketing promises of innovation and widespread adoption. While some cities have seen deployments, nationwide coverage is hindered by local regulations and agencies. Telecom companies invest in different frequency bands, but speeds vary. Early adopters, such as Verizon, have begun offering 5G connections, but smartphones can still use slower networks for full benefits. Experts say 5G's true potential lies in quality of service, not flashy features, and its impact on rural communities and remote services is uncertain.

site_title: US banks growing more optimistic with vaccines, stimulus on the way
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo, are becoming more optimistic due to the rollout of vaccines and a new round of economic stimulus. They are releasing reserves they had set aside in case of an economic disaster, with JPMorgan releasing $2.9 billion and Citigroup releasing $1.5 billion. The banks' improved outlook is driven by favorable indicators such as low unemployment rates and rising consumer spending. While some of these changes may be temporary, the banks' brighter outlook suggests a potential recovery in the economy, with some expecting a possible stimulus package in the near future.

site_title: After long journey, Fiat Chrysler and PSA to seal merger to become Stellantis
summary: Fiat Chrysler and PSA Group are merging to form Stellantis, the world's fourth-largest auto group, after a year-long deal worth $52 billion. The new entity, led by PSA CEO Carlos Tavares, aims to cut annual costs by over $8 billion and transform its vehicle range for the electric era. Analysts expect Tavares to outline his action plan, focusing on rationalizing the group's empire, addressing massive overcapacity, and reviving lagging fortunes in China. The company's shares will start trading on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia takes WTO legal action against EU over palm biofuel curbs
summary: Malaysia is taking legal action at the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the European Union and member states France and Lithuania for restricting palm oil-based biofuels. The action comes after the EU implemented a directive without considering Malaysia's views and commitment. The directive restricts the use of palm oil as biofuel in the EU, creating undue trade restrictions for Malaysia's palm oil industry. Malaysia is seeking consultations under the WTO's Dispute Settlement Mechanism, showing solidarity with neighboring Indonesia, the world's biggest palm oil producer.

site_title: UK to give airports aid after Covid-19 rules tightened
summary: The UK government will provide financial aid to airports before the end of March to support the industry amid tightened Covid-19 rules for international travellers. The Aviation Minister Robert Courts announced a new support programme, the Airport and Ground Operations Support Scheme, which will help airports reduce costs. The move comes as airlines face significant debt and the withdrawal of quarantine-free travel will further impact the industry. The government's support is seen as a relief, with London's Gatwick airport and industry body Airlines UK welcoming the aid, but airlines are also calling for plans to relax travel rules by Easter.

site_title: Quake death toll at 78 as Indonesia struggles with string of disasters
summary: Indonesia is struggling with a string of disasters, including a 6.2 magnitude earthquake in West Sulawesi province that has killed 78 people, injured over 740, and left 27,800 homeless. The quake, part of a series of natural disasters in the country, has also raised concerns of a potential tsunami. The country is battling multiple crises, including floods in North Sulawesi and South Kalimantan province, landslides in West Java province, and the recent crash of a Sriwijaya Air jet.

site_title: EU sets out plans to limit US dollar reliance, boost euro
summary: The European Union has proposed plans to limit its reliance on the US dollar and boost the euro's international role. The measures include countermeasures against currency shocks and greater scrutiny of foreign takeovers. The EU aims to protect its foreign policy and strategic interests, particularly amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has disrupted global markets and economic growth. The proposals, set to be adopted by the European Commission on January 19, come amid tensions with the US over sanctions and trade. The goal is to foster "openness, strength, and resilience" in the EU's economic and foreign policy.

site_title: Maersk urges action in Gulf of Guinea after record kidnappings
summary: The world's largest shipping company, Maersk, has urged a more effective military response to record kidnappings and pirate attacks in the Gulf of Guinea. The region accounted for 95% of hostages taken in 2020, with 135 crew members kidnapped globally. Maersk demands decisive action to address the issue, citing the need for a more robust military presence. African governments, including Nigeria, have pledged to tackle piracy, but progress has been slow, and the problem persists. International cooperation, including naval support, is seen as essential to mitigating the risk of piracy in the region.

site_title: US CDC warns new virus variant could fuel huge spikes in Covid cases
summary: US health officials warn that a highly contagious COVID-19 variant identified in Britain could lead to a surge in cases and deaths in the US by March, potentially overwhelming hospitals. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) urges Americans to maintain protective measures such as mask-wearing, social distancing, and frequent handwashing. Vaccination efforts are being accelerated to prevent the variant from spreading across the country.

site_title: KKR looks to Singapore as key investment market for new US$1.7b Asia real estate fund
summary: KKR, a US investment firm, has set its sights on Singapore as a key market for its US$1.7 billion Asia real estate fund. The firm expects to gain exposure to the Singapore market within the next two years, focusing on retail and office sectors. A significant portion of the fund, potentially 10-15%, could be deployed in Singapore, although this amount is not set in stone. With Singapore on the path to recovery, KKR sees opportunities for investment in the city-state.

site_title: Hong Kong government slams US for 'insane' sanctions
summary: The Hong Kong government strongly criticized the US for imposing sanctions on six pro-China officials, labeling the move as "insane, shameless and despicable". The sanctions, announced by the US on Friday, target officials involved in the arrests of over 50 pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong. The Hong Kong government expressed "utmost anger" and denounced the US's attempt to intervene in China's internal affairs, amid China's imposition of a draconian security law in Hong Kong last year. The sanctions mark the latest escalation in tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong's autonomy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong on Saturday hit back at the United States over its latest sanctions on six pro-China officials, slamming the move as "insane, shameless and despicable".

site_title: StanChart employees volunteer to make a difference to the community
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) has embedded volunteering into its corporate culture, providing employees with three days of volunteering leave annually. Staff members have participated in various activities, such as mangrove clean-up, kitchen preparation at soup kitchens, and food packing sessions. The bank's CEO, Patrick Lee, believes that community well-being is crucial to the stability and prosperity of society, and that volunteering helps forge deep relationships in the community. The bank has also introduced virtual volunteering activities, including a crowdsourcing project to transcribe historical records, to meet the needs of the community during the pandemic.

site_title: Trump to leave town early Wednesday before Biden inauguration
