summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is set to be sworn in on Wednesday, with outgoing President Donald Trump having flown out of the White House early that morning to his Mar-a-Lago golf club in Florida. This will be the first time a president has snubbed the inauguration of their successor in over a century and a half. Trump's departure comes after a tumultuous period, including the January 6 storming of Congress and his refusal to invite Biden to the White House for a traditional tea. Biden faces multiple crises on day one, including the national Covid vaccination project and Trump's looming impeachment trial.

site_title: Wealth gap widens for Britain's young with surge in house prices
summary: The UK's wealth gap has widened for younger generations due to a surge in house prices, driven by cheap borrowing and government tax cuts. The average house price in the UK reached a record high of £253,374 in December, making it difficult for young people to afford homes, particularly in London. The gap between "generation rent" and older generations has grown, with implications for the economy's productivity and social mobility. Experts warn that the situation may worsen unless the government takes action, such as levying a wealth tax or increasing affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Affordability is particularly stretched in the UK capital of London, where first-time buyers paid £420,618 on average at the end of 2020 - the equivalent of more than nine times their earnings.

site_title: Trump brand tarnished after bruising presidency and Capitol attack
summary: US President Donald Trump's brand is severely tarnished following his presidency and the violent Capitol attack. Experts warn that his businesses will suffer long-term damage, with companies like Signature Bank and the PGA of America cutting ties with him. Trump's business empire, built on his name, is now at risk due to the chaos and violence associated with him. This development is likely to have a lasting impact on his business ventures.

site_title: Pandemic drives Spain's real estate companies online
summary: Spain's real estate companies are shifting online to adapt to the pandemic's impact on footfall and commercial space. Merlin Properties launched an online platform allowing clients to view, reserve, and rent space in its shopping centers, cutting red tape for prospective tenants. Similar initiatives, such as Hogaria's automated valuation tool, are also being rolled out to aid the sector's digitalization and mitigate the effects of the pandemic.

site_title: India begins mega-rollout of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: India launches its massive Covid-19 vaccination program, aiming to inoculate 300 million people by July. The program prioritizes health workers, people over 50, and those at high risk, with 300,000 receiving their first dose on day one. Despite concerns about safety, infrastructure, and public scepticism, authorities are drawing on experience with elections and child immunization programs. The rollout is complicated by issues such as refrigeration and digital management, and experts warn of potential shortages and hoaxes.

site_title: Global Covid-19 death toll passes two million
summary: The global Covid-19 death toll surpassed 2 million on Friday, with the World Health Organization urging mass vaccinations to combat the pandemic's record-breaking spread. The WHO called for a worldwide acceleration in vaccine rollouts, while the US pharmaceutical giant Pfizer announced delayed shipments of its vaccines. The surge in cases has been most marked in Latin America and the Caribbean, with many countries imposing new restrictions, including lockdowns and curfews.

site_title: EU states warn of risks to vaccination credibility as Pfizer slows supplies
summary: The European Union is facing risks to its Covid-19 vaccination credibility after US pharmaceutical firm Pfizer announced a temporary slowdown of deliveries of its vaccines, citing changes to manufacturing processes to boost output. Nine EU governments expressed concerns over insufficient doses, with Pfizer and its German partner BioNTech assuring that deliveries planned for the first quarter would not be delayed. However, EU officials warn that the situation may impact the credibility of vaccination programs, and some countries, like Germany, have already seen significant delays in receiving doses.

site_title: Sunningdale latest to face activist investor Quarz
summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital Management is targeting Sunningdale Tech, a precision plastic components maker, after its chairman and major shareholder Koh Boon Hwee partnered with a private equity fund to offer minority shareholders S$1.55 per share. Quarz claims the deal is opportunistically timed, coming after a period of heavy capital expenditure that weighed on profitability. Quarz suggests securing improved terms for minorities would be a better outcome than voting down the entire deal.

site_title: Retired doctors and more syringes: Biden lays out plan to get America vaccinated
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has outlined a plan to increase production of syringes and other supplies to ramp up vaccinations against Covid-19. He will invoke the Defense Production Act to boost equipment production and set up thousands of vaccination centers, staffed by retired doctors. Biden aims to get 100 million vaccine shots into Americans' arms during his first 100 days in office and has promised to release the majority of vaccine doses when they become available, rather than holding them back for a second dose.

site_title: US: Big Biden stimulus no balm for US stocks, Dow loses 0.6%
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial average down 0.6% and the S&P 500 losing 0.7% to 3,768.25. Despite President-elect Joe Biden's proposed $1.9 trillion stimulus package, market sentiment remains downbeat due to concerns over higher taxes and the decline in retail sales in December. The Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 12,998.50 after losing 0.9%. The week's losses were the largest for the Dow and Nasdaq since January 8.

site_title: WhatsApp to delay launch of update business features after privacy backlash
summary: WhatsApp is delaying the launch of its update aimed at increasing business transactions on the platform, initially set for February, to May after a global backlash over concerns that the messaging platform was watering down its privacy policy. The update was focused on allowing users to message with businesses, but WhatsApp stated that personal conversations will continue to have end-to-end encryption. The delay comes after users expressed concern over sharing data with Facebook, leading to a surge in users switching to competitor private messaging apps.

site_title: Canada's Couche-Tard drops 16.2b euros Carrefour takeover plan: sources
summary: Canada's Alimentation Couche-Tard has dropped its 16.2 billion euro bid to acquire European retailer Carrefour SA after the French government expressed opposition to the deal on food security grounds. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire ruled out the sale, citing strategic importance for the country's food sovereignty. Couche-Tard's founder and chairman, Alain Bouchard, met with Le Maire to discuss the deal, but ultimately decided to end merger talks to avoid a political storm.

site_title: Credit card firm Capital One fined for violating US anti-money laundering law
summary: Capital One Financial Corp has been fined $390 million by the US government for violating the Bank Secrecy Act's anti-money laundering law. The company admitted to willfully failing to implement an effective program to guard against money laundering, resulting in thousands of suspicious transactions going unreported. The violations occurred from 2008 to 2014, causing millions of dollars in suspicious transactions to go unreported. The Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) deemed the failures "egregious" and willful and negligent.

site_title: Oil drops over 2% on China lockdowns, US stimulus concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped over 2% on Friday, with Brent falling to $55.10 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $52.36 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over Chinese cities in lockdown due to coronavirus outbreaks, tempering a rally fueled by strong import data from China. The market also weighed on US stimulus concerns and bearish Trump tariff outlook.

site_title: Private equity firms seize on IPO boom with consumer assets
summary: Private equity firms are seizing on the recent IPO boom by listing their consumer assets on US exchanges. Two private equity-backed companies went public last week, with two more filings announced for listings. This trend is driven by the success of technology IPOs, which have seen shares double on day one. Private equity firms are hoping to capture some of the market's attention for their slower-growing, higher-leverage assets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end four weeks of gains on lockdown, vaccine worries
summary: European stocks ended a four-week gain streak on Friday, falling 1% as concerns over tighter lockdowns, slow vaccine shipments, and resurgent coronavirus cases in China dampened hopes of a speedy economic recovery. The Stoxx 600 index logged a 0.8% weekly decline, its first weekly decline since mid-December. German Chancellor Angela Merkel called for "very fast action" to counter the spread of coronavirus, while France strengthened its border controls.

site_title: Tencent-backed Yidu Tech surges 148% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Yidu Tech, a Tencent-backed company offering artificial intelligence and big data products to the healthcare industry, made its Hong Kong debut with a 148% surge in shares after a HK$4.12 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company's shares closed at HK$65.2, surpassing the IPO price of HK$26.30. The strong performance is the third-best for a Hong Kong IPO raising over US$500 million, with overwhelming demand from retail investors. This trend reflects the ongoing appetite for tech and healthcare IPOs amid the pandemic.

site_title: Five Hong Kong democracy protesters seek asylum in the US
summary: Five Hong Kong democracy protesters, all under 30, have arrived in the US seeking asylum after fleeing to Taiwan last July. The activists took part in pro-democracy protests, faced arrest and charges, and fled by boat due to China's national security law crackdown. The Hong Kong Democracy Council welcomed them to the US, citing their "arduous and perilous" journey. This move comes after Beijing's imposition of a national security law in 2019, resulting in the arrest of over 11,000 people and the jailing of 10 Hong Kong activists for up to three years for attempting to flee to Taiwan.

site_title: US dollar finishes week stronger as US data hurts risk appetite
summary: The US dollar rose to a four-week high against a basket of currencies as US retail sales fell for a third straight month in December, indicating a slowdown in the economy amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This data boosted demand for the safe-haven currency, driving US Treasury yields lower and US stocks down. The weak data also turned investors more risk-averse, contributing to the dollar's strength.

site_title: China new home prices up moderately in December
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.1% month on month in December, according to official data, as government measures aimed at cooling the property market took effect. This represents a 3.8% year-over-year increase, slowing from a 4.0% increase in November. The moderation in growth is attributed to tightening government measures, including borrowing caps and property loans. New home prices in Tier 1 cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou, rose 0.3% month on month, while second-hand home prices gained 0.6%.

site_title: Brazil airlifts emergency oxygen into pandemic-struck state, vaccine drive lags
summary: Brazil's Air Force flew emergency oxygen supplies to the pandemic-stricken state of Amazonas, where oxygen supplies had run out at hospitals and intensive care wards were full. President Jair Bolsonaro's handling of the health crisis has been criticized, with Brazilians protesting against him and his government. A nationwide vaccine drive is in disarray, with the government scrambling to organize immunizations and a plan to start inoculating Brazilians early next week is in disarray. The country is now dealing with a snowballing second wave and a new, potentially more contagious, coronavirus variant.

site_title: US imposes fresh sanctions on Iran in final days of Trump presidency
summary: The US imposed sanctions on seven companies, including Chinese-based Jiangyin Mascot Special Steel Co and UAE-based Accenture Building Materials, for doing business with Iran. The sanctions also targeted three Iranian entities over conventional arms proliferation. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated these measures are part of the administration's efforts to step up pressure on Tehran in the final days of President Donald Trump's presidency, set to end on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: The United States on Friday imposed sanctions on companies in Iran, China and the United Arab Emirates for doing business with the Islamic Republic of Iran Shipping Lines and on three Iranian entities over conventional arms proliferation.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains; STI up 0.16%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.16% to close at 3,004.87 points, marking its third straight session of gains. The benchmark STI index outperformed Asian markets, with US President-elect Joe Biden's economic rescue plan having little impact. Key transport-related Covid-19 recovery plays, such as Singapore Airlines and Sats, also fared well. However, Singapore Exchange and Singtel shed 0.8% each, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding closed flat. Analysts attributed the gains to optimism over the stimulus package, tempered by concerns over its passage through Congress and new sanctions on Chinese companies.

site_title: Gold falls 1% as US dollar accelerates rally
summary: Gold prices fell 1% to $1,827.90 per ounce, marking a second straight weekly drop, as the US dollar accelerated its rally and overshadowed bullion's appeal as an inflation hedge. The US dollar index is on track for its biggest weekly gain since October 2020, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. Analysts attribute the decline to bouts of dollar strength and rising US yields, despite rising inflation expectations from a new US$1.9 trillion stimulus package.

site_title: Two Covid-19 cases on Australian Open flight, arrivals to quarantine
summary: Two Covid-19 cases were reported on a charter flight from Los Angeles to the Australian Open, prompting a two-week hotel quarantine for the tennis players and entourage on board. The cases, an aircrew member and an Australian Open participant, were confirmed after testing positive for the new coronavirus. The affected individuals will undergo 14-day quarantine, restricting outdoor training to indoors. This development comes as Australia continues to manage the spread of the virus, with 28,700 infections and 909 deaths reported.

images.alt_text: Two coronavirus infections were reported on Saturday on a flight to the Australian Open, forcing two weeks of strict hotel quarantine for all the tennis players and entourage on board.

site_title: The death of alpha
summary: Investors are struggling to find alpha in a highly efficient market where information is easily accessible. The disappearance of excess returns above the market's return has led to a shift towards embracing beta by investing in exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Even successful investors like Warren Buffett have underperformed the S&P 500 ETF over the past 17 years. The Internet's increased availability of information has converged asset values and prices, making it difficult to find undervalued assets. As a result, investors are being forced to adapt to a world where alpha generation is becoming increasingly challenging.

site_title: WEF targets Marina Bay Sands to host Singapore summit: sources
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is planning to host its Singapore summit at the Marina Bay Sands complex in late May, with around 1,000 delegates expected to attend. The event, initially moved from Davos due to the Covid-19 pandemic, will feature a "bubble" system to minimize interactions with locals. Negotiations are ongoing, and the venue's suitability is being assessed, despite Singapore's strict border controls and travel restrictions. The WEF aims to make the event the first in-person global conference since the pandemic began, but the plans are fluid due to the ongoing pandemic uncertainty.

site_title: iFast cites contract bids, news and industry reports in response to SGX queries on share price surge
summary: iFast Corp's share price surged 8.2% to S$4.63 on Friday, reaching an intraday high of S$4.68, after the company cited contract bids, industry reports, and its growing assets under administration (S$14.45 billion) as possible explanations for the trading activity. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had queried the company for the fourth time in six months, asking about possible explanations for the unusual price movements and compliance with mainboard listing rules. iFast also mentioned an initiation research report from Jefferies Singapore and a research update from CGS-CIMB, but did not provide further comments due to confidentiality requirements.

site_title: Tech workers can't leave the Bay Area fast enough
summary: Tech workers are fleeing the Bay Area due to high costs of living, taxes, and crime. With the pandemic allowing remote work, many are opting for more affordable towns like Austin, Texas, and Savannah, Georgia, with lower costs of living and no state income taxes. The migration is evident, with San Francisco seeing a 27% drop in residential rents and a 16.7% office vacancy rate. Companies like Apple, Google, and Facebook are still present, but the talent and money of newly remote tech workers are up for grabs, with cities like Miami, Topeka, Kansas, and Tulsa, Oklahoma, trying to lure them in with incentives and benefits.

site_title: Biden's giant aid plan to be opening salvo in legislative battle
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion economic relief proposal, known as the American Rescue Plan, is set to face a legislative battle in the Senate. The plan includes measures to combat the coronavirus, speed the economy's reopening, and provide direct stimulus payments. While it has elements that could appeal to moderate Republicans, the proposal also includes proposals opposed by many Republicans, such as doubling the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. Negotiations may produce a smaller bipartisan package, followed by a larger budget bill with Democratic priorities later in the year.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic lops US$2.5b in NYC property tax revenue
summary: New York City is facing a projected $2.5 billion decline in property tax revenue due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the largest drop in at least three decades. The decline is largely driven by a 15.8% decrease in the value of office buildings and hotel properties, which have emptied out since the pandemic began. To offset the loss, the city will partially reduce spending and cut 5,000 jobs. Despite optimism from officials that President-elect Joe Biden will provide substantial assistance, the federal government's ability to fully meet the city's budgetary needs remains uncertain.

site_title: Goldman eyes deals to boost consumer banking unit: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is considering acquisitions to boost its consumer banking unit, Marcus, amid slowed loan and deposit growth since the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank has set a high bar for any deal to be large and transformative. Digital banking is an area of interest, with Goldman's M&A bankers crunching numbers on various ideas. The goal is to increase growth and improve the unit's performance.

site_title: First Reit FY2020 DPU falls 51.7% to 4.15 Singapore cents
summary: Singapore's First Reit reported a 51.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for FY2020 to 4.15 Singapore cents, down from 8.6 cents in FY2019. The decline was largely due to rental reliefs extended during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Reit's distributable income fell 51.2% to S$33.4 million, and net property and other income decreased to S$77.5 million. The Reit is seeking to raise S$158.2 million through a proposed rights issue to repay debt and deleverage its balance sheet.

site_title: Developers expected to continue milking positive market conditions to push new projects this year
summary: Singapore's private housing market showed a remarkable performance in 2020, with developers launching 10,883 units for sale, only 4.1% fewer than in 2019. Despite the pandemic-induced recession, developers sold 10,024 units, surpassing the 9,912 units in 2019 by 1.1%. Experts expect developers to continue launching new projects this year, with forecasted sales ranging from 9,500 to 10,500 units. The COVID-19 vaccination program and economic recovery are seen as positive factors, with local buyers, including HDB upgraders, driving demand.

site_title: The hot alternative investments to watch in 2021
summary: Alternative investments to watch in 2021 include cask whisky, music rights, rewilding, insect farming, and landscaping. Cask whisky has seen a 564% surge in value over the last decade, with rare bottles selling for $1 million to $2 million. Music rights have also become more valuable, with songwriters selling rights for millions. Rewilding, which involves restoring land to its original wilderness state, has become a trend, with investors such as billionaire Anders Povlsen purchasing large tracts of land. Insect farming is another emerging trend, with companies like Astanor Ventures investing in sustainable agri-food startups. Landscaping, particularly in well-designed gardens, has also seen a surge in value, with homes selling for 2.7% more than expected.

site_title: Court rejects bid by Ocean Tankers JMs to strike out PetroChina's writs against four ships
summary: The Singapore High Court has rejected Ocean Tankers' bid to strike out PetroChina's four admiralty writs against four vessels chartered by Ocean Tankers. The writs claim the vessels failed to deliver cargo or misdelivered it, and the court ruled that the writs were valid and only against the vessels, not Ocean Tankers. If PetroChina wins, Ocean Tankers could be liable for any judgment entered against it, not limited to the value of the vessels.

site_title: Confessions of a virtual reality gym rat
summary: A fitness enthusiast discovered a virtual reality (VR) fitness app called Supernatural, which provides immersive workouts with stunning scenery and Top 40 hits. The app, available for $19/month, uses hand-tracking technology to guide users through exercises, offering a real workout experience despite the virtual environment. With no live classes and a focus on individual progress, Supernatural has become the primary form of exercise for the author, helping them stay active and sane during the pandemic. While it has its drawbacks, including compatibility issues and a high price point, Supernatural offers a unique and engaging alternative to traditional gym workouts.

site_title: Spike in US Treasury yields inhibits gold's appeal
summary: US Treasury yields surged, deterring gold's appeal, causing prices to slump over 4% on Friday. However, the market rebounded after buying on dips at $1,820 an ounce. A proposed $1.9 trillion US stimulus package by President-elect Joe Biden boosted gold, but gains were limited by the spike in Treasury yields.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swiber Holdings' judicial management was extended to June 30. KrisEnergy applied to extend its debt moratorium for a hearing on February 1. Sembcorp Industries CFO Graham Cockroft is quitting after two years to return to New Zealand. Ascott Residence Trust expects a 60-70% cut in distribution per stapled security for FY2020. SIIC Environment Holdings changed CEOs due to work re-designation. Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings plans to sell two crane barges to a Taiwanese company for $5.6 million.

site_title: No need to introduce TraceTogether-only check-ins yet, retailers told
summary: Singapore authorities have told retailers to halt TraceTogether-only check-ins, after many businesses prematurely implemented the function and put up posters displaying the new requirements. The Smart Nation and Digital Government Office (SNDGO) said the function will only be implemented after everyone has collected a token and a reasonable period of national distribution is achieved. Over 40 retailers were found to have mistakenly implemented TT-only SafeEntry, with some allowing alternative methods of check-in. The government has announced that TT-only SafeEntry will be rolled out nationwide, but the rollout has been pushed back to early this year.

site_title: Vallianz tells bourse sale disclosure held up by talks with sponsor
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore support vessel company, took more than a week to disclose the sale of its subsidiary due to talks with its listing sponsor, Provenance Capital. The company sold a wholly-owned unit for US$1 on December 31, 2020, but filed the announcement on January 11, 2021, after seeking its board's clearance and amendments to the sale and purchase agreement. The buyer is identified as an entity owned by Singaporean businessman Tan Yam Seng, and Vallianz cited confidentiality clauses and non-core business reasons for not disclosing the details earlier.

site_title: Malaysian medical glove exports face more delays amid shipping container shortage
summary: Malaysia's medical glove exports face further delays due to a global shortage of shipping containers. The shortage, which has eased after year-end festivities, still causes delays of two to five weeks for glove makers. The situation is expected to return to normal by the end of February, but industry officials warn that the lead time to deliver gloves to customers has increased by over six months. The shortage, affecting countries like China, has driven up freight rates by 300-400% and led to cancellations of container bookings.

site_title: Life extension - health, rejuvenation and longevity
summary: Researchers are exploring ways to achieve life extension through cutting risk factors, healthy lifestyle, and supplements like resveratrol and NAD-boosting compounds. Sirtuins, enzymes powered by NAD, play a crucial role in preventing diseases and reversing aging. Studies show that increased sirtuin activity is linked to delayed age-related diseases and increased longevity. Resveratrol, a natural compound found in red grapes, has been shown to have life-extending properties, but its effects can be contradictory at high doses. NMN supplementation has also been found to increase NAD levels, improve cardiovascular response, and prevent age-related cognitive decline. A healthy lifestyle, including caloric restriction, exercise, and regular check-ups, is recommended to control risk factors and potentially achieve life extension.

site_title: Four rules that should guide Bidenomics
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to inherit an economy in distress, inheriting a similar situation to 12 years ago. A newly unveiled rescue package indicates Biden's willingness to take bold steps. However, a narrow Democratic margin in Congress means ambitious progressive goals will be put on hold. Four key rules for Biden's economic policies are proposed, including taking decisive action, avoiding excessive caution, focusing on the lives of Americans, and being willing to make tough decisions. Biden's success will depend on his ability to deliver effective policies amidst economic challenges.

site_title: Reits (Jan 16-17, 2020)
summary: Real estate investors and developers face challenges in the market. US mortgage rates rise after five weeks of decline, affecting the demand for Singapore's prime projects. In the US, Manhattan rents hit a record, and UK homebuyer demand rebounds to a six-month high. In Asia, Goldman Sachs acquires a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. New World Group sells China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secures new tenants and fills more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow drop as big banks fall after results
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 dropping as major banks fell after reporting better-than-expected fourth-quarter profits. The S&P 500 banks index fell 1.9% and JPMorgan Chase fell 0.6% despite a seven-day winning streak. Investors worried that President Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, which includes tax hikes, could slow economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 115.05 points, and the S&P 500 lost 9.71 points.

site_title: Chinese investors can soothe Xiaomi's US pains
summary: Chinese investors are helping to ease the pain of Xiaomi's US listing ban, which resulted in a $10 billion market value loss. Following a similar experience by China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom, mainland investors are buying up Xiaomi shares, offsetting selling. This has led to a significant recovery of lost equity value, with Xiaomi's market capitalization falling to $96 billion. Local support is limiting the impact of the US blacklist, and Xiaomi's shares have recovered nearly half the total lost equity value in just four days.

site_title: Dutch PM Rutte confirms government resignation
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced the resignation of his government due to a scandal involving the false accusation of thousands of parents of benefit fraud, resulting in financial ruin for many. Rutte admitted the system had "gone terribly wrong" and took joint responsibility. The government will remain in a caretaker role until the elections on March 17, amid the ongoing coronavirus battle.

site_title: Rethinking mental health: wellness startups and apps on the upswing
summary: Mental health and wellness apps have seen a surge in demand and funding, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on stress and stigma. US mental health startups raised $1.37 billion in venture capital funding in the third quarter of last year, with Singapore-based companies Holmusk and Safe Space securing significant funding rounds. Digital solutions offer accessibility and privacy, particularly in Asian communities where stigma around mental healthcare is prevalent. Corporate demand for mental health services has increased, with companies like Google and foodpanda partnering with mental health apps to support employee well-being. Insurers are also starting to roll out coverage for mental health conditions, and a blended model of online and in-person care is expected to become the future of mental healthcare.

site_title: Amazon will let companies build voice assistants on Alexa
summary: Amazon is allowing other companies to build voice assistants on top of its Alexa platform, offering a more complete set of tools, including speech recognition and unique capabilities. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) will be the first to use Alexa Custom Assistant, integrating in-car functions with Alexa's web of data. This move aims to expand Alexa's reach and fend off rivals like Apple and Google, while also providing a more seamless user experience.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com is offering other companies the ability to use the building blocks of the Alexa digital assistant for their own automated versions, the latest effort to embed the company's voice software into other devices.

site_title: Singapore's GIC invests in software consultancy ThoughtWorks
summary: Singapore's sovereign investor GIC and Abu Dhabi's Mubadala have invested $720 million in global software consultancy ThoughtWorks, alongside Siemens and Fidelity. The investment will be used to buy out other shareholders, pegging ThoughtWorks' enterprise value at $4.6 billion. ThoughtWorks, set up in 1993, aims to expand internationally with the capital injection, according to the company.

site_title: Banks, MAS urge switch to e-hongbao
summary: Banks and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are urging a switch to e-hongbao, or digital red envelopes, to encourage safe distancing during the Chinese New Year. This year's celebrations will be limited due to Phase 3 restrictions, which cap social gatherings at eight people. The move aims to promote digital transactions and reduce the risk of in-person gatherings.

site_title: Rejuvenated Red Devils ready to rumble in Liverpool
summary: Manchester United and Liverpool, two of the most decorated teams in English football, will face off in a crucial Premier League match at Anfield on Sunday. Manchester United, currently top of the table, aims to maintain or extend their three-point lead over Liverpool, who are struggling with injuries to key players, particularly Virgil van Dijk. Despite Liverpool's erratic form, they have a lethal attack that can tear opponents apart when in top gear. The match could go a long way in determining the season's Premier League trophy winner, with Manchester United looking to make a statement and Liverpool seeking to bounce back from their recent setbacks.

site_title: Lian Beng Group to buy BreadTalk IHQ building in S$118m sale-and-leaseback deal
summary: Lian Beng Group is set to buy the BreadTalk IHQ Building in Tai Seng, Singapore, in an S$118 million sale-and-leaseback deal. BreadTalk Group will rent the property as an anchor tenant for 10 years, with the option to extend or buy back the building at a mutually agreed price. The deal is expected to yield positive rental returns and diversify Lian Beng's property portfolio. The transaction requires approval from the government landlord JTC and is slated to go through on April 1.

site_title: GL shares soar to 10-month high after proposed privatisation of firm
summary: GL Limited shares surged to a 10-month high after the hotel operator announced a proposed privatisation, reaching an intra-day high of S$0.71 and closing at S$0.70. The offer price matches Guoco Group's proposal, providing greater management flexibility to navigate the challenging operating environment. GL posted a net loss of US$19.8 million for the six months to Dec 31, 2020, due to pandemic-driven restrictions. The proposed offer represents a 25% premium over the last trading price.

site_title: BHG to open new concept at Robinsons' former Raffles City space
summary: BHG Singapore is set to open a new concept store in the former Robinsons space at Raffles City Shopping Centre by the end of January. This marks the retailer's first two-floor operation in the location. The news comes after Robinsons Singapore closed its store last weekend, citing years of losses. The exact details of BHG's new concept and operations are not specified in the article.

site_title: What America has lost
summary: The US has suffered significant damage to its credibility as a world leader under President Trump's four-year term. The Capitol storming and impending violent protests pose a risk of extending extremist violence beyond the inauguration. America's allies and enemies will closely watch its response, and its reputation will be difficult to restore. The country's loss of prestige has made it harder for its adversaries to be swayed by US entreaties, with Beijing potentially gaining an advantage by promoting its model of governance. The US's decline will also impact other nations, including those in the Indo-Pacific, and embolden illiberal leaders and far-right parties.

site_title: Citigroup profit beats, but shares dip on higher costs, weak revenue
summary: Citigroup reported a 7% decline in fourth-quarter profit to $4.63 billion, beating market expectations but falling short of Wall Street approval. The decline was attributed to higher costs and weak revenue across its consumer business. The bank's shares fell 1.6% in premarket trading. Despite this, Citigroup expects to resume share buybacks in the first quarter and has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. New CEO Jane Fraser has vowed to overhaul risk management and internal controls.

site_title: Exxon investigated by SEC over Permian property valuations: WSJ
summary: ExxonMobil is being investigated by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over allegations of overvaluing properties in the Permian Basin. A whistleblower complaint from an employee in 2019 claimed workers were forced to use unrealistic assumptions to reach a higher valuation, leading to at least one employee being fired in 2020. Exxon shares dropped 4% in pre-market trading following the news. The SEC and Exxon declined to comment on the investigation.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil is being investigated by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) after a whistleblower complaint from an employee alleging the overvaluation of property in the Permian Basin, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Lian Beng-led consortium buys BreadTalk building in S$118 million sale and leaseback
summary: Lian Beng Group, led by a consortium, has acquired the BreadTalk IHQ Building in Tai Seng for S$118 million in a sale-and-leaseback deal. BreadTalk Group will rent the property for 10 years before having the option to extend or buy back the building at a mutually-agreed price. The consortium will fund its share through bank borrowings and internal resources.

site_title: Audi RS 6 Avant: A wild, wicked wonder of a wagon
summary: The Audi RS 6 Avant is a high-performance, four-wheel-steer wagon with a twin-turbocharged 4.0-litre V8 engine producing 600 horsepower. It features an aggressive design with oversized flares, a raked tailgate, and RS-specific styling elements. The car boasts a well-appointed cabin with advanced digital displays, a sports steering wheel, and a 48-volt mild-hybrid drivetrain. It accelerates from 0-100km/h in 3.6 seconds and has a top speed of 250km/h. The RS 6 Avant is available in Singapore for S$505,365.

site_title: Sembcorp CFO returns to New Zealand; no replacement named
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced that CFO Graham Cockroft is stepping down on February 28, 2021, to return to New Zealand after two years. Cockroft contributed to the group's strategic development, particularly the demerger of the marine business. The company is working on naming his successor and has stated there are no unresolved issues with shareholders. The announcement led to a slight decrease in Sembcorp shares, dropping 0.55% to S$1.82.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust warns of 60-70% fall in FY2020 DPS on pandemic impact
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) expects a 60-70% decline in FY2020 distribution per stapled security (DPS) due to the pandemic's impact on the global hospitality industry. The projected DPS cut comes with a potential 40-50% drop in distributable income. ART's portfolio value may decline by 6-8%, resulting in unrealised losses of S$325-345 million. Despite the challenges, the trust has a strong financial position with sufficient liquidity.

site_title: Eli Lilly invests US$30m in health-equity focused venture fund
summary: Eli Lilly is investing $30 million in Unseen Capital Health Fund, a venture capital firm focused on minority-owned, early-stage healthcare companies serving marginalized communities. The fund aims to raise $100 million and make 6-8 investments by summer. With Eli Lilly as its anchor investor, the fund will support healthcare solutions for underprivileged communities.

site_title: BlackRock sells HK$1.6b China Telecom stake after US ban
summary: BlackRock has sold nearly all its stake in China Telecom, a company subject to a US ban on investments linked to China's military, after the US government expanded the ban to nine firms. The sale, worth HK$1.6 billion (S$274.1 million), reduced BlackRock's stake from 6.1% to 0.2%. The move follows other US investors scrambling to exit stocks subject to the sanctions, which take effect in November 2021.

images.alt_text: BlackRock has sold almost all its stake in China Telecom, a company subject to a new ban on US investment, a stock market filing on Friday showed.

site_title: UK Supreme Court hands businesses victory in Covid-19 insurance ruling
summary: The UK Supreme Court ruled in favor of businesses that claim insurance coverage for losses caused by COVID-19 lockdowns, rejecting the stance of major insurance companies. The court found that many business interruption policies should cover widespread disruption, which led to thousands of businesses being denied compensation. The Financial Conduct Authority will work with insurers to settle claims and make interim payments, with the aim of providing a "massive boost" to affected businesses.

site_title: Wells Fargo records surprise quarterly profit
summary: Wells Fargo reported a surprise quarterly profit of $2.99 billion, or 64 cents per share, despite low-interest rates and high costs. The bank's credit costs decreased by $823 million, a significant drop from last year. Analysts had expected 60 cents per share. The bank's net income is the first quarterly profit in three years, and it has been in regulators' penalty box since 2016. Rising costs remain a concern, but the profit beat expectations and may signal a turnaround for the bank.

site_title: Malaysian businesses reposition to target local consumers
summary: Malaysian businesses are shifting their focus to local consumers due to the prolonged absence of overseas visitors, largely from Singapore, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Tourism revenue plummeted 81% in 2020, with a total of RM12.6 billion in receipts, compared to RM66.1 billion in 2019. In response, shopping malls and retailers are repositioning their concepts to appeal to domestic tourists and residents, introducing curated concepts, artisanal bazaars, and yoga sessions. The government has also announced a state of emergency, which may last until August, further limiting international travel.

images.alt_text: There is a realisation that the country's rising Covid-19 infections is likely to keep overseas visitors out for a good part of 2021.

site_title: 'Parasite' director to head Venice film festival jury
summary: South Korean film director Bong Joon-ho, who won the Academy Award for Best Picture with his film "Parasite," has been named jury president of the 2021 Venice Film Festival. This marks the first time a South Korean has held the position. Bong expressed his excitement and hope for the festival, praising the "great films" that will be showcased. The 78th edition of the festival is scheduled for September 1-11, 2021, and is considered one of the most prestigious film festivals globally.

site_title: Ocean Tankers fails to strike out PetroChina's writs against vessels
summary: Ocean Tankers' judicial managers failed to strike out PetroChina's admiralty writs against four vessels chartered by the oil shipper. The writs, filed in April 2020, claim failure to deliver cargo and misdelivery of cargo. Justice Ang Cheng Hock dismissed the applications, ruling the writs were against the vessels, not Ocean Tankers. If PetroChina wins, the judgment is limited to the vessels' realized value, and Ocean Tankers remains open to judgment against it. The decision may impact PetroChina's potential security interest in the vessels.

site_title: Philippines senators query government's preference for China vaccine
summary: Philippine senators have questioned the government's preference for the Chinese Covid-19 vaccine, Sinovac Biotech, citing lower efficacy rates. The country has secured 25 million doses from Sinovac, despite concerns from senators about its safety. An opinion poll showed less than a third of Filipinos are willing to get vaccinated due to safety concerns. The Food and Drug Administration has yet to evaluate Sinovac's emergency-use request, while Pfizer and BioNTech's vaccine has been authorized for use. President Rodrigo Duterte's preference for Chinese-made vaccines has raised concerns about the country's ability to boost public confidence in vaccines.

site_title: European nations say Covid vaccines fall short as Pfizer slows supplies
summary: European nations are receiving lower-than-expected Covid-19 vaccine supplies due to Pfizer's slowed shipments and uneven distribution among EU states. About one-third of EU governments cited "insufficient" doses at a health ministers' meeting. This comes as vaccines developed by Pfizer and BioNTech started being delivered in the EU at the end of December, and Moderna's shot began deliveries this week after EU approval. The uneven supply is causing concerns about the bloc's ability to combat the pandemic.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare issues H2 2020 profit warning
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare, a Catalist-listed company, has issued a profit warning for its half-year and full-year results, citing the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The group expects a significant loss due to provisions and impairments on investments, including a planned rights issue by First Reit to avoid a debt default. The unaudited results are scheduled for release on February 23, 2021, and the company's counter closed at S$0.035, up 2.94%, before the guidance was published.

site_title: Philippines extends travel ban, steps up safeguards over Covid-19 variant
summary: The Philippines has extended a travel ban for 30 countries and territories, including China and the US, due to a more transmissible Covid-19 variant. The ban, initially set to expire on January 15, has been extended until January 31. Filipinos returning from these areas are now required to undergo a 14-day quarantine. The variant, first detected in Britain, is nearly 70% more transmissible than the original strain. There is no evidence it's more deadly, but the government is taking precautions to protect public health.

site_title: Equities see US$27b inflows as reflation trade gathers pace: BofA
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden announced a $1.9 trillion stimulus package, exceeding market expectations, sparking a reflation trade. Investors poured $27 billion into financial and energy stocks, with energy stocks attracting $3.6 billion. Inflation expectations dominated market action, with inflation assets outperforming deflation assets in 2021 by the most since 2006. Emerging market equities saw their sixth largest inflow ever, and municipal bonds saw a record inflow of $2.5 billion. Despite vaccine rollout lag, BofA's base case still favors vaccines prevailing over the virus and a reopening over a recession.

site_title: US says Capitol rioters meant to 'capture and assassinate' officials: filing
summary: US federal prosecutors have filed a court document stating that rioters who stormed the US Capitol on January 6, 2021, intended to "capture and assassinate" elected officials. Jacob Chansley, a QAnon conspiracy theorist, is among those charged, with prosecutors citing strong evidence that supports this intent. The filing comes as more serious charges are being brought against individuals involved in the violence, including one man accused of beating a police officer with a pole bearing an American flag.

site_title: Singapore's GIC, three others invest US$720 million in software firm ThoughtWorks
summary: GIC and Abu Dhabi's Mubadala, along with German tech firm Siemens and Fidelity Management and Research LLC, have invested US$720 million in software consultancy ThoughtWorks. The capital injection will be used to buy out other shareholders and supports the company's growth strategy. ThoughtWorks' enterprise value is pegged at US$4.6 billion, following Apax Partners' announcement to sell a minority stake to new investors in Q1 2021. This investment marks a significant boost to ThoughtWorks' growth prospects, with Apax partner Rohan Haldea welcoming the new backers.

site_title: OCBC turns positive on aviation but maintains 'sell' on SIA
summary: OCBC Investment Research has turned positive on the aviation sector due to Covid-19 vaccine progress and easing travel restrictions. Analyst Chu Peng expects a gradual recovery in 2021, particularly in the second half, driven by strong leisure travel demand. The recovery is contingent on successful vaccine rollouts and less strict travel restrictions by mid-2021. OCBC maintains a 'sell' rating on Singapore Airlines (SIA), citing its exposure to the aviation sector.

site_title: China's monetary policy to support 2021 economic recovery
summary: China's monetary policy will continue to support its economic recovery in 2021, with a focus on maintaining policy stability and avoiding sudden shifts. The central bank will keep interest rates and reserve ratios flexible and targeted, with a goal of reducing corporate borrowing costs. China's weighted average corporate lending rate is expected to decrease, and consumer prices are likely to rise moderately. The yuan's value is expected to stabilize at a reasonable level, with two-way fluctuations becoming normal. Policymakers remain cautious due to a resurgence of infections worldwide and in China.

site_title: PIA plane 'held back' by Malaysian authorities over UK court case
summary: A Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) plane was held back by Malaysian authorities over a UK court case related to an arbitration dispute over payments. The Boeing 777 aircraft was seized after a court order, and alternative arrangements were made for passengers. PIA described the situation as "unacceptable" and sought support from Pakistan's government to raise the matter diplomatically. The airline is struggling financially, with over $4 billion in accumulated losses, and has faced several challenges, including a scandal over pilots' licenses and a ban from flying to the European Union.

site_title: Developers seen to continue private housing launch momentum in 2021
summary: Developers in Singapore are expected to continue their private housing launch momentum in 2021, driven by positive market conditions and the rollout of the Covid vaccination program. In 2020, an estimated 10,883 private housing units were launched for sale, surpassing the 9,912 units in 2019 by 1.1%. Experts predict a continued strong performance, with launch volume rivalling that in 2020, and home sales expected to reach 9,500 to 10,500 units this year.

site_title: HK civil servants given four weeks to pledge loyalty to the government
summary: Hong Kong's 180,000 civil servants were given four weeks to sign a document pledging loyalty to the government and dedication to the mini-constitution. Those who refuse may face job loss. The declaration, required since Beijing's national security law was imposed in June, promises to uphold the Basic Law and "bear allegiance" to the city and government. Authorities claim the law is necessary for stability, while Western governments and rights groups are concerned it's being used to crush dissent. Refusal to sign may raise doubts on a civil servant's suitability to remain in the service.

site_title: Swedish court dismisses Huawei appeal over 5G network exclusion
summary: A Swedish court has dismissed Huawei's appeal against its exclusion from the country's 5G network rollout. The decision allows the 5G spectrum auction to proceed as planned. The court stated that a ruling by the Administrative Court of Appeal is final and cannot be appealed. This clears the way for Swedish telecoms regulator PTS to resume 5G spectrum auctions without removing the earlier ban on Huawei. The auction is scheduled to take place next week.

site_title: China bans banks from selling deposit products on third-party internet platforms
summary: China's Banking and Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has banned commercial banks from selling deposit products on third-party internet platforms, citing risks related to information disclosure and product management. The move aims to prevent spillover financial risks brought by the rapid development of the fintech sector. Big tech companies, including Ant Group and JD Digits, have been offering high-yield deposits through their apps, which may be violating regulatory rules and exacerbating a liquidity crunch among lenders. The CBIRC has stopped these services, which were previously allowed.

site_title: Q&M unit to sell off stake in Chinese company; floats possible special dividend from part of S$17m proceeds
summary: Q&M Dental Group is selling off its remaining stake in Chinese dental equipment maker Aidite (Qinhuangdao) Technology Co for S$25.1 million, with expected proceeds of S$17 million. The sale will be used for working capital needs, business expansion, and a potential special dividend. Q&M's effective stake in Aidite will be reduced to 9.19%. The company believes the sale will strengthen its balance sheet and provide resources for future expansion.

site_title: JPMorgan profit jumps 42% on reserve release, investment banking strength
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported a 42% jump in fourth-quarter profit to $12.1 billion, driven by reserve releases and strong performance in trading and investment banking. Revenue rose 3% to $30.2 billion, with investment banking revenue surging 37% to $2.5 billion. The bank's net income was ahead of Wall Street estimates, with CEO Jamie Dimon attributing the release of credit reserves to economic uncertainty, despite positive vaccine and stimulus developments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.70 points to 1,627.01. Volume reached 5.850 billion lots worth RM4.063 billion, with losers narrowly outnumbering gainers 571 to 512.

site_title: Singapore shares up for third straight session, STI gains 0.16%
summary: Singapore shares rose for the third consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.16% to close at 3,004.87 points. The STI's gain was attributed to optimism over the US economic rescue plan, despite the exception of Hong Kong, which ended in negative territory. Key transport-related stocks, including Singapore Airlines, Sats, and ComfortDelGro, also performed well, while the Singapore Exchange and Singtel declined.

site_title: UK economy shrank in November as new lockdown hit
summary: The UK economy shrank 2.6% in November, its first monthly decline since the initial Covid lockdown in April, due to new restrictions. Despite a smaller decline than expected, the economy is now 8.5% smaller than pre-pandemic levels. The Bank of England's bond-buying program was increased to £900 billion in November, and Governor Andrew Bailey expressed uncertainty about further stimulus. The economy faces risk of a double-dip recession.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: BHG Singapore is taking over the first two floors of the space formerly occupied by Robinsons Singapore at Raffles City Shopping Centre. This move marks a significant expansion for the department store operator.

images.alt_text: GL Limited owns hotel operator glh, which has Hard Rock Hotel London in its portfolio of hotels in the UK.

site_title: 30 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 30 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 59,059. Among them, 29 were imported cases and one was in the community. The locally transmitted case, a 32-year-old para-veterinarian, remains unlinked. With 35 cases discharged, 58,742 patients have recovered, and 41 remain in hospital. Globally, over 92.3 million people have been infected, with over 1.97 million deaths.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare gains as health stocks offset US stimulus boost
summary: Australian shares ended steady on Friday, paring early gains, as investors lapped up US President-elect Joe Biden's plans for a massive stimulus package. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% before closing flat, and ended 0.6% lower for the week. Domestic healthcare stocks weighed on the benchmark, while miners rose 0.8% due to concerns over tight supply amid fresh virus curbs in China. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.7% for the session, its worst since March last year.

site_title: Japan to stick to budget surplus goal even as pandemic costs grow: sources
summary: Japan plans to maintain its target of achieving a primary budget surplus by fiscal 2025, despite growing pandemic-related costs, according to sources. The government is expected to present its projections next week, but may need to revise the target if new pandemic measures impact growth. The decision to stick to the target was reportedly made "at this time," indicating a commitment to achieving the goal despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch lower on lockdown worries
summary: European stocks declined on Friday, inching lower due to concerns over tighter lockdowns in Germany and France, as well as new Covid-19 restrictions in China. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.5% as German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged swift action and France strengthened border controls. US President-elect Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus package proposal failed to excite markets, and shares in Siemens Energy and SAP declined. The decline was also attributed to US-EU trade tensions, with tariffs on the agenda.

site_title: Trump plans to live at Mar-a-Lago, employ some current aides
summary: Donald Trump plans to move to Mar-a-Lago in Florida after his presidency, with some current White House staff expected to work for him or his son-in-law, Jared Kushner. Trump intends to live at the resort, despite opposition from some future neighbors. The State Department has offered Blair House to President-elect Joe Biden and his wife for the night before his inauguration on January 20. This move comes as Trump's presidency is set to end, with Biden taking office.

site_title: Tencent-backed Yidu Tech surges 121% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Yidu Tech, a Tencent-backed company offering AI and big data products to the healthcare industry, made its Hong Kong debut with a 121% surge in shares. The company raised HK$4.12 billion (S$704.8 million) in its IPO, which met overwhelming demand from investors. Yidu Tech's shares opened at HK$58.25, outperforming the IPO price of HK$26.30. This is the third-best Hong Kong IPO opening over US$500 million, following e-cigarette maker Smoore International Holdings and Alibaba.com. The company's IPO attracted Tencent and other cornerstone investors, and its shares are expected to continue soaring amid a frenzy of trading around tech IPOs.

site_title: SIIC Environment changes CEO on 're-designation of work' at the top
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has changed its CEO, Yang Jianwei, due to a re-designation of work. Yang, 50, previously served as general manager of SIIC Management (Shanghai) Co since 2018 and will retire by rotation. He can stand for re-election at general meetings and will not be inking a service contract. The decision was made by the board, citing the need for a change in leadership.

site_title: Vallianz tells bourse disclosure delay due to back-and-forth with listing sponsor
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore support vessel company, delayed its disclosure of the sale of a subsidiary for over a week due to correspondence with its listing sponsor. The company sold a wholly-owned unit for $1 on December 31, 2020, but filed the announcement on January 11, 2021, prompting queries from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Hot stock: GL hits 10-month high after Guoco Group's privatisation bid
summary: Shares of GL Limited hit a 10-month high after Guoco Group proposed a voluntary conditional offer to privatize and delist the hotel operator. Guoco Group, which holds a 70.84% stake, aims to buy GL at S$0.70 per share. The counter rose 26.8% to S$0.71, matching the offer price. The move is seen as a response to the challenging operating environment due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Brexit, and low oil and gas prices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap 10th straight weekly gain; Kospi down 2%
summary: South Korean stocks closed down 2.03% on Friday, marking the sharpest fall in over two months, as profit-taking and foreign selling eclipsed optimism over a US stimulus plan. The Kospi index slid 64.03 points to 3,085.90, reversing 10 straight weeks of gains. Major heavyweights like Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor dropped 1.9% and 4.2%, respectively. Foreigners were net sellers of 761.7 billion won worth of shares. The won fell 0.13% to 1,099.4 per dollar.

site_title: iFast responds to SGX query, cites contract bids, news and industry reports
summary: iFast responds to Singapore Exchange's (SGX) query on its share price surge, citing participation in project bids, including those in Hong Kong, which may have a material positive impact on its business. The company also cites news of its assets under administration growth and research reports from Jefferies and CGS-CIMB as possible explanations for the trading activity. iFast confirmed its compliance with listing rules and did not provide further comments due to confidentiality requirements. Its shares surged 5.5% to S$4.59 on Friday.

site_title: Goldman eyes deals to boost consumer banking unit: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is considering acquisitions to boost its consumer banking unit, Marcus, after slowing loan and deposit growth in 2021 due to the pandemic. The bank aims to build businesses with predictable revenues, such as consumer banking and mass-market wealth management. Executives are looking at digital businesses, excluding branch acquisitions, as potential targets. Goldman plans to maintain its deposit target of $125 billion over five years despite regulatory restrictions and a slowdown in market conditions. The bank's efforts to grow its consumer business come as it seeks to reduce reliance on volatile trading and investment banking revenues.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC turns positive on aviation, maintains 'sell' on SIA
summary: OCBC Investment Research has turned more positive on the aviation sector, expecting a gradual recovery in 2021. Analyst Chu Peng attributes this optimism to strong pent-up demand for leisure travel, a successful vaccination rollout, and easing travel restrictions. While passenger numbers are expected to grow 56% year-over-year, international travel is expected to take longer to recover due to border controls. Despite this, OCBC maintains a "sell" call on Singapore Airlines (SIA), citing concerns over share dilution, and sets a fair value estimate of S$3.70.

site_title: Zara billionaire Ortega doubles money on US$460m telecom bet
summary: Amancio Ortega, billionaire and founder of Zara, has more than doubled his money on a US$460 million telecom investment in Telxius Telecom's tower unit, valued at 7.7 billion euros. Ortega's investment firm, Pontegadea Inversiones, bought a 9.99% stake in 2018, resulting in a return of at least 103%. The sale of Telxius' assets to American Tower has boosted Ortega's fortune, helping to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on his Inditex retail empire.

site_title: No need to introduce TraceTogether-only check-ins yet, authorities tell retailers
summary: Singapore authorities have instructed retailers who implemented TraceTogether-only check-ins prematurely to halt the practice. The move comes after over 40 retailers were found to have put up posters requiring the TraceTogether app or token for entry, despite the function not being nationwide. The government has delayed the rollout of TT-only SafeEntry to a later date, citing the need for a reasonable period of national distribution and token collection in constituencies.

site_title: Proxy restrictions at en bloc sales meetings to take effect from Jan 18: MinLaw
summary: Ministry of Law (MinLaw) will implement amendments to the Second Schedule of the Land Titles (Strata) Act on Jan 18, 2021, restricting proxy holders at en bloc sales meetings to 2% of total lots or 2 lots, whichever is higher. The move aims to encourage owners to participate in person and minimize proxy abuse. The new restrictions come as the private residential market is expected to maintain healthy momentum in 2021, with undersupply in the primary market and a growing demand for collective sale sites.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Bitcoin claws back most of losses from this week's swift plunge
summary: Bitcoin has recovered most of its losses from the previous week's plunge, briefly topping $40,000 and trading around $39,230 as of Friday. The cryptocurrency's price surged 7.5% on Thursday, with other peers like Ether and Litecoin also rising. Analysts attribute the recovery to institutional adoption and retail investor involvement, with some predicting a strong rally and potential price target of $50,000 by year-end.

site_title: China's new home prices rise 0.1% m-o-m in December
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.1% month-over-month in December, matching the previous month's pace, according to official data. This marks a slowdown from the 4.0% increase in November. The 3.8% year-over-year rise in December is the smallest since May. The government's efforts to cool the market, prompted by China's quickly recovering property sector, have taken their toll.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after Biden unveils huge stimulus plan
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled a $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, which had little impact on Asian markets due to its inclusion in valuations. Reassurances from the Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell on low interest rates and loose monetary policy also calmed investor anxiety. However, surging virus infections and lockdowns remain major concerns, despite vaccine rollout progress.

site_title: BHG Singapore to take over two floors formerly occupied by Robinsons at Raffles City
summary: BHG Singapore is taking over the first two floors of the space formerly occupied by Robinsons at Raffles City Shopping Centre. The new concept store, "ONE ASSEMBLY", will open by the end of this month, offering a range of beauty, fashion, home, and living products, as well as experiential spa cabins. The store is a collaboration between BHG and Raffles City, and is expected to become a favored destination for shoppers.

site_title: GE sues Siemens Energy over stolen trade secrets
summary: General Electric (GE) has filed a federal lawsuit against Siemens Energy, alleging the German rival exploited US trade secrets to secure a $225-340 million contract with Dominion Energy in 2019. GE claims a Dominion employee shared confidential information with a Siemens employee, who then adjusted their bid. Siemens has denied reviewing the lawsuit but defended its conduct, stating it disclosed the breach to both Dominion and GE after an internal investigation and took disciplinary action against involved employees.

site_title: WEF targets Marina Bay Sands for Singapore's 'Davos' summit: sources
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is planning to host its Singapore summit at Marina Bay Sands in late May, with around 1,000 delegates expected to attend. The event's plans are still fluid due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Negotiations are ongoing, but the WEF and Marina Bay Sands have declined to comment. The summit's date and venue were not confirmed, but it is expected to take place between May 25-28.

site_title: Guoco Group proposes S$0.70 per share offer to take GL private
summary: Guoco Group proposes a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.70 per share to take GL Limited private, representing a 25% premium over its last trading price. The offer is conditional upon acceptances of no less than 90% of shares. GL's core hotel business has been severely impacted by pandemic-driven restrictions, resulting in a net loss of US$19.8 million for the six months to Dec 31, 2020. The offer aims to provide greater management flexibility and allow shareholders to exit their investment due to low trading liquidity.

site_title: Gold rises on US stimulus hopes, dovish Fed stance
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,848.75 per ounce, driven by hopes of a substantial US pandemic relief package and the Federal Reserve's dovish monetary policy stance. US President-elect Joe Biden proposed a $1.9 trillion stimulus package, while Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled no plans to raise interest rates. Analysts expect gold to remain supported by a weaker US dollar, stimulus expectations, and depressed real interest rates, with some predicting prices could break above $2,000 if inflation expectations increase.

images.alt_text: Gold ticked up on Friday as prospects of a substantial US pandemic relief package boosted the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge, while the Federal Reserve's dovish monetary policy stance also supported prices.

site_title: Xiaomi dives 11% in Hong Kong after US blacklisting
summary: Xiaomi shares plummet 11% in Hong Kong after being blacklisted by the US, following a move by the Trump administration to ban Americans from investing in Chinese companies deemed a threat to national security. The blacklisting, part of a broader effort to counter China's military-civil fusion development strategy, also affects other tech firms like Huawei and chip giant SMIC. The company's smartphone sales have surpassed Apple's in the third quarter, according to International Data Corporation.

site_title: 'Anything can happen' with Tokyo Olympics: Japan minister
summary: A Japanese cabinet minister, Taro Kono, admitted that "anything can happen" with the postponed Tokyo Olympics due to the coronavirus surge, deviating from Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's assurance of a "safe and secure" Games. The minister acknowledged the possibility of the Olympics being cancelled and emphasized the need for back-up plans. Public support for the Olympics has plummeted, with over 80% of respondents thinking the Games should be cancelled or postponed again. The country's state of emergency is in place until February 7.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by a positive US economic recovery plan, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.27% to 28,573.86. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also showed slight gains. Traders remain optimistic about long-term recovery prospects.

site_title: Indonesia quake kills at least 35, injures hundreds
summary: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Sulawesi island, killing at least 35 people and injuring hundreds. The quake, which occurred at a shallow depth of 10 km, triggered aftershocks and landslides, damaging homes, bridges, and the provincial governor's office. Authorities warned of possible aftershocks and tsunamis, although no tsunami warning was issued. This is the second major earthquake to hit Sulawesi in recent years, following a devastating 6.2-magnitude quake and tsunami in 2018 that killed thousands.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group to build first overseas fuel cell system plant in China
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has signed an investment pact with China's Guangdong province to build its first overseas fuel cell system production plant, with a planned annual capacity of 6,500 systems. Construction will begin in March 2021 and completion is expected by the second half of 2022. The facility will cater to the growing demand for fuel cell vehicles in the region, despite concerns about the technology's niche status and environmental risks. This move marks Hyundai's entry into the Chinese market and underscores the company's commitment to expanding its electric vehicle capabilities.

site_title: Playtika prices US$1.88 b IPO above target range: sources
summary: Mobile gaming company Playtika Holding Corp raised US$1.88 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), selling shares at US$27 each above its target range of US$22-24. The IPO values Playtika at US$11.1 billion, making it the biggest US listing in 2021 so far. Founded in 2010, Playtika has over 35 million monthly active users and its games include Bingo Blitz and Slotomania.

site_title: Developers in Singapore sell 1,217 private homes in December; full-year tally at 10,024
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 1,217 private homes in December, a 57.2% increase from November. The full-year tally reached 10,024 units, surpassing the 9,912 units sold in 2019 by 1.1%. This marks a significant recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, with Q4 sales being lower than Q3 2020. The URA will release final figures in a week's time.

site_title: Man United face title test in Liverpool showdown
summary: Manchester United, seeking their first Premier League title in eight years, face a crucial test against Liverpool on Sunday. With points likely to be dropped, third-placed Manchester City have a chance to climb back into contention. United, led by Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, have a three-point lead over Liverpool and are on a seven-game winning streak on the road. Meanwhile, Chelsea's title ambitions are put on hold due to a four-game losing streak, with Frank Lampard's team 10 points off the top four.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) declining 0.2% to 2,993.94. The decline follows a record high reached on Thursday. The US economy's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, unveiled by President Joe Biden, has sparked market volatility. In other markets, the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 ended modestly lower, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.1%. European and Asian markets rose, with the Stoxx 600 index hitting new highs, driven by technology stocks and upbeat Chinese export data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.58 points, or 0.10%, to 1,634.13. Volume was 761.99 million lots worth RM423.01 million. Gainers beat losers 292 to 269. The decline follows a global trend, with European stocks also down due to bank and healthcare concerns, and US stocks near records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Trump administration nudges Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac away from government control
summary: The US Treasury Department has agreed to alter its stake in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, allowing the housing finance giants to move away from government control. The plan would enable the companies to retain profits, but they must build a minimum of $283 billion in capital to pay dividends to investors or exit government control. The Treasury will retain nearly 80% of their stock until then, and the companies cannot issue common stock until the Treasury exercises its warrants. This plan, announced by the Trump administration, will now be implemented by President-elect Joe Biden's administration.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.24% and the Topix index rising 0.13%. The gains come as investors await US President Joe Biden's plan for new stimulus. The benchmark indices extended rallies from the previous session, with investors watching for details on US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps winning streak on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed 0.62% lower on Friday, snapping a five-day winning streak, as investors took profits after recent strong gains. The Nikkei 225 index fell 179.08 points to 28,519.18, while the Topix index lost 16.67 points to 1,856.61.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed lower on Friday, snapping a five-day winning streak, as investors locked in profits after strong recent gains.

site_title: Magnitude-6.2 quake hits Indonesia's West Sulawesi
summary: A magnitude-6.2 earthquake struck Indonesia's West Sulawesi on Friday, with the epicentre 36km south of Mamuju, the capital. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The quake had a depth of 18km. Mamuju is home to approximately 110,000 people.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast surges more than 5.5%, prompting SGX query
summary: Shares of iFast Corp surged 5.5% to S$4.59, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on "unusual price movements". This marks the fourth query issued to iFast in six months. The company reported a record assets under administration of S$14.45 billion, a 44.5% year-on-year growth. iFast was also queried in January for "unusual price movements" after announcing its digital bank licence application. The SGX is seeking an explanation for the trading activity and confirmation of compliance with listing rules.

site_title: Google closes Fitbit deal as US, Australia probes continue
summary: Google has closed its $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit despite US and Australian competition regulators continuing to probe the deal. The Justice Department and Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said they have not reached a final decision on whether to pursue enforcement actions. Google complied with the DOJ's 14-month review and met agreed-upon restrictions on using customers' health-related data. The company acquired Fitbit to compete in the fitness market and retains 1,800 employees.

images.alt_text: Search and advertising giant Google closed its deal to buy fitness tracking company Fitbit, the companies said on Thursday, even as US and Australian competition regulators said they were continuing probes of the US$2.1 billion transaction.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Friday's session on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, slipping 0.36% to 28,394.37, as traders largely ignored the US$1.9 trillion stimulus proposal. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index was barely moved, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.25%. The market reaction suggests the proposal's impact had already been factored in.

site_title: Biden to unveil US$1.9t economic plan as US recovery buckles
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is set to unveil a $1.9 trillion economic plan, dubbed the American Rescue Plan, to revive the US economy amid a flagging recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The proposal includes measures to raise the minimum wage, aid struggling state and local governments, reopen schools, and roll out a massive vaccination campaign. Biden aims to pass the plan with a slim majority in Congress, despite Republican opposition, and plans to present a second recovery plan after his inauguration.

site_title: China's 2020 GDP growth slowest in over four decades: AFP poll
summary: China's economy experienced its slowest growth since the 1970s in 2020, with a forecasted 2.0% expansion, according to an AFP poll of economists. The country's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic gained pace in the fourth quarter, with strong exports and consumer spending contributing to a rebound. China is expected to be the only major world economy to post positive 2020 growth, with official GDP figures set to be released on Monday. Analysts predict a further pick-up in Q1 2021 growth, driven by exports and investment, but warn of lingering uncertainty affecting consumer spending.

site_title: Courts Singapore taking up Robinsons' former Heeren space
summary: Courts Singapore plans to open a six-storey flagship store in the former Heeren retail space on Orchard Road, set to open by Q1 2022.
