The 189,000 square foot space will feature new retail concepts and "Japanese standards of customer experience." This marks Courts' first overseas large-format store concept in a central Singapore location, with the company expressing confidence in the retail sector's evolution. The store is expected to be Courts' largest retail space in Singapore.

site_title: Toyota to pay US$180m to settle US emissions violations: government
summary: Toyota has agreed to pay the US Department of Justice $180 million to settle charges that the company failed to report vehicle emissions problems to authorities. The penalty and agreement for injunctive relief aim to prevent future violations. Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey Bossert Clark stated that Toyota's misconduct will not be repeated. The settlement is a result of Toyota's failure to comply with rules requiring auto companies to report emissions issues.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds fire on rates, seen staying put in 2021
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept its policy rate unchanged at 0.5% as expected, maintaining easy monetary policy to support the economy's partial recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The decision is seen as a stable outlook for the economy, with 20 of 23 analysts predicting the bank will hold rates through the end of 2021. The economy is expected to grow 3% this year, with the manufacturing sector recovering from a 1.1% contraction in 2020. Policymakers are cautious due to the ongoing third wave of the coronavirus and weak job market.

site_title: First Reit FY2020 DPU down 51.7% to 4.15 S cents
summary: FIRST Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 4.15 Singapore cents for FY2020, down 51.7% from FY2019. The DPU for Q4 2020 was 0.84 cents, representing a 57% decline from the previous year. Distributable income for FY2020 fell 51.2% to S$33.4 million, largely due to rental reliefs extended to tenants during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says cyberattack resulted in 'significant data breach'
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) confirmed a significant data breach following a cyberattack on its data systems earlier this week. Governor Adrian Orr stated that the investigation is ongoing, but further details are being withheld to avoid affecting the investigation. The bank is taking steps to mitigate the breach, but no additional information is available at this time.

site_title: Oil prices climb on Chinese data, dollar weakness
summary: Oil prices rose 0.6% to $56.42 a barrel for Brent crude and 1.3% to $53.57 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, driven by a weak US dollar and bullish Chinese import data. The US dollar index fell, making dollar-denominated oil cheaper for foreign currency holders. Despite concerns over surging coronavirus cases in Europe and new lockdowns in China, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries maintained its forecast for world demand to rise by 5.9 million barrels per day this year.

site_title: Trump's Florida club warned over maskless New Year party
summary: President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida received a warning from county authorities after a video showed a crowd of partygoers ignoring Covid-19 restrictions, including not wearing masks. The warning, issued on January 12, was due to a "breakdown in enforcement" of mask orders, and the club faces a fine of up to $15,000 for future violations. The New Year's Eve party, where Trump's son Donald Trump Jr. posted a video, was attended by a maskless crowd despite a county rule requiring masks.

site_title: Trump administration takes final swipes at China and its companies
summary: The Trump administration has imposed sanctions on Chinese officials and companies for alleged misdeeds in the South China Sea, increasing tensions with China ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. The sanctions target state-owned enterprises, officials of the Chinese Communist Party, and military personnel for allegedly using coercion against states with rival claims. Nine Chinese firms, including CNOOC and Xiaomi, were added to the Pentagon's list of companies with alleged ties to the Chinese military, subjecting them to a new US investment ban.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend gains for third day, political woes hit Italy
summary: European shares rose for a third consecutive day, driven by technology stocks and hopes of a large US stimulus package under President Joe Biden. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.7%, with mining, auto, and travel stocks leading the gain. China's exports grew more than expected, while Germany's economy shrank by 5.0% in 2020. However, investors remain cautious about the impact of coronavirus lockdowns on the recovery. Meanwhile, Italy's FTSE MIB fell 0.5% due to political uncertainty, and shares in Italian lenders dropped 0.9% due to concerns over funding.

site_title: North Korea shows off submarine-launched missile at parade: KCNA
summary: North Korea showcased a submarine-launched ballistic missile at a military parade in Pyongyang, as part of the ruling Workers' Party's congress. The display, which included rockets with a "powerful striking capability," was seen as a show of strength by the country, aimed at sending a message to the US ahead of President Joe Biden's inauguration. The move is seen as an attempt to extract concessions from Washington, following a tumultuous relationship with former President Donald Trump. The display is also a challenge for North Korea under the new US leadership, with Biden's "strategic patience" approach potentially limiting progress.

images.alt_text: Nuclear-armed North Korea displayed a submarine-launched ballistic missile at a military parade in Pyongyang, state media reported Friday, in a show of strength days before Joe Biden's inauguration as US president.

site_title: Merkel urges tougher shutdown over virus resurgence
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged tougher restrictions to contain the country's worsening coronavirus outbreak, calling for "significant additional measures" to stop the virus. The country recorded over 1,200 Covid-19 deaths and 25,000 new cases, with hospital beds filling up. Merkel plans to bring forward a meeting with state premiers to discuss stricter measures, including border checks and mask requirements. The government has been criticized for having too many exceptions in its current shutdown, and experts say stronger measures are needed to bring down infections.

site_title: Time to revisit headcount test for scheme meetings: observers
summary: Hong Kong's headcount test, a rule requiring a simple majority of votes cast in a scheme meeting to approve a scheme of arrangement, should be reviewed due to its potential to distort the outcome of a vote. The rule, which protects minority shareholders, is still debated in other jurisdictions. The test has been abolished in Hong Kong's new Companies Ordinance, but the court can now dispense with it for certain schemes. Market players suggest harmonizing the test or introducing new safeguards, such as full disclosure of proxy votes, to improve equity.

site_title: Once again, Trump's fate in Senate leader McConnell's hands
summary: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has the power to decide Donald Trump's fate, with a crucial moment approaching after Trump's second impeachment. McConnell, a long-time ally of Trump, has expressed disdain for the president but may be willing to defend him to prevent conviction. If McConnell fails to bring the Senate back into session early, Trump will be tried as a former president, and if 17 Republicans join him in opposing conviction, Trump could become the first president to be banned from public office.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as market awaits Biden stimulus plan
summary: US stocks declined modestly Thursday as investors awaited President-elect Joe Biden's stimulus package. Disappointing labor data showed a surge of 181,000 unemployment benefit applications, nearing the one million level since August. Biden is set to unveil his proposal, following a decade of coronavirus restrictions. The market digested the news amidst a choppy session.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished a choppy session modestly lower Thursday as the market awaited details of President-elect Joe Biden's stimulus package after digesting disappointing labor data.

site_title: China Evergrande may tumble, UBS analysts say in 'sell' call
summary: China Evergrande Group was downgraded to "sell" by UBS analysts, who predict shares may lose more than half their value. The bank slashed its 12-month target price to HK$6 from HK$15.20 and expects contract sales to decline 2% to 707 billion yuan. Evergrande aims to reach 750 billion yuan in contract sales, but the UBS report highlights concerns over the company's debt-cutting efforts and limited growth potential.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang, Medtecs, Sunningdale Tech, First Reit, Lian Beng
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding signed a deal for a liquefied natural gas supply chain joint venture, causing its shares to drop 1.84% to S$1.07. Medtecs International Corp plans to distribute Covid-19 rapid tests in the Philippines, with its shares closing 1.79% lower at S$1.10. Sunningdale Tech shares fell 0.6% to S$1.54 after a takeover proposal was deemed "too low." First Reit's FY2020 DPU halved to 4.15 cents due to lower income. Lian Beng Group's net profit fell 5.2% to S$17.6 million.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has inked a deal to set up a liquefied natural gas supply chain joint venture.

site_title: The 4-day week: how workplaces can successfully establish it
summary: The four-day week has gained relevance as a flexible working arrangement due to the pandemic, with some countries and companies exploring its implementation. Spain is working on a national shift to a 32-hour week, while transnational companies like some have successfully implemented the four-day week with positive results. Proponents argue that it can reduce unemployment and improve work-life balance, but critics worry about productivity losses and increased costs. Despite these concerns, several companies are adopting the four-day week, making it a global trend.

site_title: Trump's impeachment in House could set off bitter Senate fight
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 232-197 to impeach President Donald Trump for inciting the deadly Capitol riot on January 6. The impeachment could lead to a bitter Senate fight, potentially delaying President-elect Joe Biden's term. The Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell, rejected calls for a quick trial, and the impeachment is unlikely to result in Trump's ouster before Biden's inauguration on January 20. A two-thirds majority is needed to convict and remove Trump, and conviction could lead to a vote banning him from running again.

site_title: UK planning labour regulation overhaul in post-Brexit shake-up: FT
summary: The UK's business department is drafting plans to overhaul labour regulations post-Brexit, aiming to end the 48-hour working week, alter rest break rules, and adjust overtime pay for holiday entitlements. The proposed changes have not been agreed by ministers and are subject to Downing Street's approval. The move is seen as a significant shake-up of UK labour markets, potentially impacting worker protections.

site_title: France imposes 6pm nationwide virus curfew
summary: France has imposed a nationwide 6pm curfew starting Saturday to combat a rise in Covid-19 cases, with the measure set to last for at least two weeks. The curfew will restrict all services and shops, except for emergency services, and will be accompanied by other measures, including increased testing and vaccination efforts. Prime Minister Jean Castex warned that the situation remains fragile and a new lockdown could be imposed if the health situation deteriorates badly.

site_title: WHO team arrives in Wuhan for probe into origins of Covid-19
summary: A 13-member team of World Health Organization (WHO) experts arrived in Wuhan, China, on January 14, 2021, to investigate the origins of COVID-19. The team, led by Peter Ben Embarek, will complete a two-week quarantine before starting their work. The WHO aims to establish the pathway of the virus from animals to humans to prevent future outbreaks. The mission comes amid China's efforts to control local clusters of the virus, with over 20 million people under lockdown. The team's findings are expected to shed light on the pandemic's origins, which China has been reluctant to disclose.

site_title: 'Exuberant spending' could follow pandemic: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell suggests the US economy may experience "exuberant spending" after the pandemic, potentially leading to upward pressure on prices. However, he does not predict this will result in significantly higher inflation, citing the central bank's tools to address inflation if needed. The Fed has implemented an inflation targeting policy, keeping interest rates at zero and allowing inflation to rise beyond 2% to promote full employment. Powell's comments come as the world's largest economy struggles with pandemic fallout, including massive government spending and job losses.

site_title: Bank Indonesia's new rules for digital payment not expected to deter foreign investors
summary: Bank Indonesia's new rules requiring online payment firms to have at least 15% Indonesian ownership and 51% voting rights are unlikely to deter foreign investors in Indonesia's digital economy. Industry players expect the regulations to encourage consolidation and mergers among large players, potentially driving dependence on domestic companies. Despite this, investor interest remains strong, driven by the sector's rapid growth, and foreign investors are expected to continue supporting the industry's development. The regulations aim to strengthen the industry and ensure financial system stability, while maintaining access and consumer protection.

site_title: The beauty of Japanese wood
summary: An ongoing exhibition, "Into The Woods," showcases the quality of Japanese cypress and cedar wood in Okuyamato region. The exhibition, now on till Feb 21 at Lumine Singapore, features 16 artisans from Okuyamato and their creations, including wooden items, dried foods, and tea. The unique wood grain and near absence of knots make Japanese cypress and cedar highly valued in sushi counters and other high-end restaurants. The exhibition aims to introduce the wider Okuyamato area through a larger variety of craft and products, and to appreciate the craft unique to the region.

site_title: Online learning still in vogue
summary: Virtual workshops have become the new norm, even after lockdown restrictions have eased. Companies like Bynd Artisan and MPC Events offer virtual workshops, which have seen a significant increase in demand, especially among corporate clients. These virtual workshops allow participants to engage with craftsmen remotely, often through live streaming, and provide tools and materials ahead of time. The trend is also driven by environmental concerns, with companies like Vivant offering live streaming wine experiences with a sustainable focus.

site_title: AirAsia X shows court creditors' support for restructuring plan
summary: AirAsia X has received support from most of its lessors for a restructuring plan, with 15 out of 20 aircraft lessors not in favor of the airline liquidating. Potential new investors have shown interest in fundraising, and the airline has received 10 letters from Malaysian and Singaporean corporations expressing interest. Lessors are seeking more equitable terms and new commercial arrangements. Despite Airbus and Rolls-Royce opposing the plan, AirAsia X believes it can recover 44-66% of lease rental losses under new agreements.

site_title: Stanchart's investment banking head is top internal CEO contender
summary: Standard Chartered's investment banking head Simon Cooper has emerged as the internal contender to replace CEO Bill Winters, who has outperformed the bank during the Covid-19 pandemic. Cooper, currently based in Singapore, may return to London and be considered for deputy CEO. The bank's chairman Jose Vinals is also considering external candidates, and a "market-mapping" exercise is underway to monitor all potential options. Cooper joined Standard Chartered in 2016 and previously worked at HSBC. His promotion would follow Winters' successful tenure from 2015-2018.

site_title: Singapore Airlines raises US$500m in oversubscribed US-dollar debt debut
summary: Singapore Airlines has raised US$500 million through its first US-dollar-denominated bond issue, with the notes due 2026. The oversubscribed issuance was anchored by high-quality institutional investors and will be used for aircraft purchases, payments, and general corporate purposes. The airline expects to issue the notes on January 20, 2021, subject to customary closing conditions. The move strengthens SIA's liquidity position and provides financial flexibility to capture medium to long-term growth beyond the pandemic.

site_title: ByteDance's chief rival wins HKEX nod for US$5b IPO
summary: ByteDance's main rival, Kuaishou Technology, has received approval for a US$5 billion initial public offering (IPO) on the Hong Kong stock exchange. The Tencent Holdings-backed short-video startup plans to gauge demand for its IPO starting next week, aiming for a valuation of US$50 billion, nearly twice its recent estimate. This listing is expected to be one of the city's biggest of the year.

site_title: TSMC to spend up to US$28b to protect lead in advanced tech
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) plans to invest up to $28 billion in 2021 to maintain its lead in advanced technologies. This represents a 64% increase from the previous year's $17.2 billion investment. The company aims to meet growing demand and capitalize on projected revenue growth. TSMC's chief financial officer, Wendell Huang, stated that the increased investment is necessary to safeguard the company's position as the preferred chipmaker for major technology and auto giants.

site_title: Mental health startups and apps on the upswing
summary: Mental health startups and apps are experiencing a surge in demand and funding due to the growing need for mental healthcare services. Corporations are also taking notice, offering mental health services as a work benefit. Experts predict that demand for mental healthcare will outlast the pandemic. The rapidly growing sector is creating innovative solutions, with architecture firms designing buildings that prioritize mental well-being.

site_title: Grab faces tough digital bank fight as tech rivals muscle up
summary: Grab's fintech arm, Grab Financial Group, has raised US$300 million in Series A funds, valuing it at US$3 billion, despite facing a tough fight in South-east Asia. Tech rivals Sea and Gojek have gained direct exposure to Indonesia's banking sector, acquiring stakes in Indonesian banks and expanding into consumer digital financial services. Grab's fintech ambitions are hindered by its lack of a banking licence in Indonesia, requiring it to partner with local banks or consider a merger to compete with Sea and Gojek.

site_title: Nomura, Sparx to form company to invest in unlisted firms
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc and Japanese asset manager Sparx Group Co are forming a company to invest in unlisted firms, aiming to tap into the private market's potential for growth. The new firm, Nomura Sparx Investment Inc, will have 400 million yen in capital, with Nomura holding a 51% stake. It plans to list on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Venture Funds Market within two to three years, with the goal of boosting its size to 100 billion yen or more within 10 years. The move is part of Nomura's efforts to expand into private markets and provide more investment opportunities.

site_title: Australia slams Google for blocking news sites from users
summary: Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg criticized Google for blocking news sites from users after the company ran tests to determine the value of its service to Australian news outlets. Google's experiments, which will affect about 1% of its users, aim to measure the impact of news businesses on its search results. Frydenberg urged Google to "pay for original content, not block it" as the companies resist a government-mandated payment system. If negotiations fail, a government-appointed arbitrator will decide the outcome, further escalating the dispute between the tech giant and the Australian government.

site_title: New life for old stuff
summary: Designers showcase the potential for repair and reuse in a world where "throwaway" culture dominates. The "R for Repair" exhibition in Singapore features 10 design firms that transformed discarded or broken items into functional and attractive pieces. Participants included a watch with a broken strap, a toy bus, and an old sewing machine, which were paired with designers to create new, innovative designs. The exhibition aims to encourage a "value shift" towards sustainability, highlighting the potential for repair and reuse to reduce waste and promote long-term design.

site_title: So much for dry January?
summary: Dry January, a month-long abstinence from alcohol, quickly turned into Damp January for many participants due to the US Capitol assault and subsequent crisis. Many broke their vows to drink after witnessing the tragedy, citing the need for comfort and coping mechanisms. Despite some staying sober, others found it difficult, with some turning to wine or other substances as a way to cope with stress and emotions. Experts warn that the intersection of pandemic stress, economic stress, and social strife can lead to increased substance consumption among those at risk.

site_title: Takeover price for Sunningdale Tech at S$1.55 too low: Quarz
summary: QUARZ Capital Management has expressed concerns over the proposed takeover price of S$1.55 per share for Sunningdale Tech, stating it is "too low" and undervalues the company. The activist investor believes Sunningdale's book value is close to S$2 per share, indicating greater profitability. Quarz is urging Sunningdale chairman Koh Boon Hwee to protect minority shareholders and negotiate a fairer deal.

site_title: Rising yields are raising threat levels for risk asset rally
summary: Rising US Treasury yields, now above 1.1%, are raising concerns about the sustainability of the global risk asset rally. Investors, such as JPMorgan and Union Bancaire Privee, warn that higher yields could lead to market pressure, particularly if they breach levels of 1.3-1.6%. The rise in yields is driven by expectations of stronger growth and inflation, with the 10-year breakeven rate on inflation-protected Treasuries reaching 2% for the first time in over two years.

site_title: London landlords pessimistic on rent as UK housing loses steam: survey
summary: London landlords are becoming increasingly pessimistic about rent prices due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and its impact on the city's housing market. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors found that London is the only part of the UK where rents are expected to fall in the next three months. The shift towards working from home has led to a decrease in demand for housing in the city, with many residents seeking more space outside of London.

site_title: Manhattan bargain hunters drive 94% jump in apartment leases
summary: Manhattan apartment leases surged 94% in January, with 5,459 new deals, the largest annual increase since 2011. The median rent dropped 17% to $2,800, with 54% of leases including move-in incentives. Despite the jump, the vacancy rate remains 5.52%, and the number of available listings increased 172% to 13,718. Experts say the surge in leases may indicate a new-found affordability for renters, but caution against assuming it's a sign of imminent recovery.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Medtecs International Corp, a Catalist-listed medical equipment manufacturer, signed a letter of intent to distribute Covid-19 rapid tests in the Philippines with biologics firm Enimmune Corp. The agreement is expected to have minimal impact on the company's earnings and net tangible assets per share for the year 2021. No further details on the agreement's terms or timeline were provided.

site_title: Despite Trump's promises, China's trade surplus with US widens to US$317b in 2020
summary: China's trade surplus with the US widened to $317 billion in 2020, exceeding President Trump's promise to narrow the gap. Despite the US imposing tariffs on Chinese goods, China's exports surged, driven by electronics and medical equipment demand during the pandemic. The surplus increased 27% from 2019 and reached a record high since 2015, with exports rising 3.6% and imports shrinking 1.1%. China is expected to continue fulfilling its commitments under the phase-one trade deal with the US.

site_title: First Reit's EGM: What unitholders should know
summary: First Reit, a healthcare real estate investment trust, is holding an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on January 19, where two resolutions will be voted on. Two parties, Lippo Karawaci and First Reit, are in financial difficulties, with Lippo Karawaci facing negative cash flow since 2015. Unitholders must familiarize themselves with the resolutions and vote by January 16 to make an informed decision.

site_title: Day of fear and reckoning in Washington, DC
summary: US President Donald Trump was impeached for the second time by the House of Representatives, with 20 Republican lawmakers joining Democrats in voting to impeach him. The impeachment comes amid concerns of an alarming surge in violence ahead of the presidential inauguration and a week after pro-Trump rioters attacked the US Capitol. The move is seen as an attempt by Democrats to hold Trump accountable for inciting an "armed rebellion" and "clear and present danger" to the nation. Trump is expected to leave office on January 20, and his impeachment could mark the beginning of a civil war within the Republican Party.

site_title: Business of looking good glows with work-from-home, mask-wearing
summary: Singapore's aesthetics and wellness industry is experiencing a surge in demand for cosmetic enhancement procedures, driven by pent-up demand from the pandemic and mandatory mask-wearing. Local companies such as MWH Medical and Singapore Medical Group have seen double-digit growth, with many patients opting for treatments instead of traveling abroad. The industry is expected to continue growing, with some experts predicting a significant increase in demand after deferring treatments during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Thanks to work-from-home arrangements, people can now undergo face transformational procedures while avoiding being seen by others, according to SW1 Clinic's Dr Low (left).

site_title: US dollar holds above three-year lows
summary: The US dollar held above three-year lows against major peers, rising due to expectations of President-elect Joe Biden's fiscal stimulus, which is expected to be around $2 trillion. The 10-year Treasury yield rose, supporting the dollar. Investors are cautious, as the spending push may have already been priced in, and the recent recovery of the dollar is threatened by a build-up of bearish positions. The dollar advanced 0.13% to 104.02 yen, while the euro slipped 0.05% to $1.214.

site_title: Borrelli Walsh: 17 interested parties in Hyflux
summary: Seventeen parties have expressed interest in Hyflux, following the appointment of judicial managers Borrelli Walsh, after signing non-disclosure agreements (NDAs). The interested parties include previously known investors such as Strategic Growth Investments and Utico, but some, like Pison and OUE, have pulled out. The 17 parties have until Jan 31 to submit non-binding proposals, and will need to demonstrate sufficient funds to proceed with restructuring. If suitable offers are received, a notice will be issued to shortlisted investors, inviting them to participate in the second stage of the investor process.

site_title: STI rises 0.76% to hit 3,000, first time since March 2020
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.76% to close at 3,000, its first time since March 2020, driven by gains in property developers City Developments and UOL Group. Asia markets were mixed, with key benchmarks in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul higher, while Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta declined. Analysts attribute the positive outlook to US President-elect Joe Biden's stimulus plan and China's strong economic data, potentially leading to a cyclical recovery rotation trade at the end of the month.

site_title: A week of wonders at Singapore Art Week
summary: Singapore Art Week, now in its 9th year, features over 100 events across the island and online from January 22 to 30, 2021. The event showcases over 300 artists and curators, adapting to the COVID-19 restrictions with new physical and virtual formats. Highlights include bus-stop art installations, a Light to Night Festival with visual projections, and a drive-through art exhibition in a carpark. The S.E.A. Focus selling exhibition has gone hybrid, with physical and online displays, and the IMPART Collectors' Show features private collectors' art through videos. The event aims to explore new opportunities in the arts despite the pandemic.

site_title: 17 parties have signed NDAs to explore investing in Hyflux: JMs
summary: Seventeen parties, including Strategic Growth Investments and Utico, have signed non-disclosure agreements to explore investing in embattled water treatment company Hyflux. The move comes after the company was placed under judicial management in November and had only three initial offers. Hyflux's current cash balance is sufficient for nine months of operations, and the judicial managers will review the company's assets and business before deciding on a restructuring or sale of individual projects and assets.

site_title: Singapore player Grabs lion's share of food delivery market
summary: Grab dominated the food delivery market in South-east Asia, accounting for nearly half of the region's food delivery gross merchandise value (GMV) in 2020, with an estimated US$5.9 billion. The market grew 183% year-over-year, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, with Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore being the top three markets. The report predicts a permanent growth trend, but notes that players must balance high growth with low food prices and invest in infrastructure to scale.

images.alt_text: Singapore-headquartered ride-hailing giant Grab has cornered the food delivery market, contributing close to half of South-east Asia's food delivery gross merchandise value (GMV) in a year that saw demand in the region skyrocket.

site_title: US economy growing modestly but virus tempers optimism: Fed
summary: The US economy is growing modestly, with a majority of Federal Reserve districts reporting employment gains, but a growing number also reporting drops in employment levels due to the resurgence of COVID-19 cases. The vaccine rollout has boosted business optimism, but concerns over the virus dampened this optimism. The economy shed 140,000 jobs in December, and while some industries, such as manufacturing and construction, continue to add jobs, others, like leisure and hospitality, reported renewed employment cuts. Analysts expect the economy to rebound in the second half of 2021 with the rollout of vaccines and government aid.

images.alt_text: The US economy shed 140,000 jobs in December as the country faced a surge of Covid-19 infections, the first loss of jobs in eight months and a sign that the economic recovery could be losing momentum.

site_title: US blacklists China's CNOOC, saying it helps China intimidate neighbours
summary: The US Commerce Department added Chinese National Overseas Oil Corporation (CNOOC) to a blacklist, citing its role in helping China intimidate neighbors in the South China Sea. Skyrizon, a Chinese company, was also added to the Military End-User List for developing or producing military items. These actions are part of the administration's efforts to increase tensions with China in its final weeks. The move follows recent tariff announcements and asset seizures against Chinese companies.

site_title: What confidence means
summary: A factory worker, Ron, stood out from his colleagues due to his confidence, evident in his demeanor, interactions, and attire, including distinctive blue trouser braces. Despite being part of a busy and potentially intimidating work environment, Ron exuded a quiet confidence that made him approachable and engaging. His confidence was not flashy, but rather a natural part of his personality that made him a valuable presence in the factory.

site_title: Key long-term trends in 2021
summary: Key trends in 2021 include a shift towards emerging markets, particularly in Asia, as investors rotate out of laggard sectors and geographies. Sustainability and digitalization have gained momentum, with a focus on clean technologies, electric vehicles, and automation. Active management is crucial in generating outperformance, as many investors focus on large index weights and big names. The vaccine rollout has provided a ray of hope for the hospitality industry, but uncertainty remains. Investors should consider exposure to markets and avoid holding a large portion of their portfolio in cash due to possible risks of inflation.

site_title: Maybank KE raises Wilmar target price on potential Q4 surprises
summary: Maybank KE has raised its target price for Wilmar International to S$6.80 from S$5.40, citing potential Q4 2020 surprises, including record-high Chinese soya-bean crush margins and a rise in palm oil prices. Analyst Thilan Wickramasinghe maintained his "buy" call with unchanged earnings per share estimates, indicating a positive outlook for the agri-business group ahead of its Q4 results announcement.

site_title: Yangzijiang inks deal for 30% stake in new Chinese LNG joint venture
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) has inked a deal to set up a liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply chain joint venture, investing 6 million yuan (S$1.23 million) for a 30% stake. The joint venture, Jiangsu Run Yuan Energy Co, will build LNG storage facilities and undertake trade in natural gas. Yangzijiang's partner, which holds 19% interest, is 41%-owned by the company's honorary chairman. The deal is considered an interested-person transaction and is not expected to affect Yangzijiang's earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: US: Dow, Nasdaq hit record highs as focus turns to Biden's stimulus plan
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Thursday as investors await President-elect Joe Biden's stimulus plan, which could exceed $1.5 trillion. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.38%, the S&P 500 gained 0.30%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.62% to new highs. Despite a weaker-than-expected jobless report, investors are optimistic about the economic outlook, with the S&P 500 rising for the seventh time in nine sessions this year.

site_title: GuocoLand MD, Sistic chairman among 9 new NMPs
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob has appointed 9 new Nominated MPs (NMPs) for a 21/2 year term starting January 21. Among the new appointees are SISTIC chairman Janet Ang and GuocoLand group managing director Cheng Hsing Yao. This marks the first time Ang has held public office. The appointments were made to increase representation and diversity in Parliament.

images.alt_text: Mr Cheng Hsing Yao, group managing director of GuocoLand, and Ms Janet Ang, Sistic chairman, will be appointed for a 21/2 year term starting Jan 21.

site_title: Top US banks seen riding trading boom as view for 2021 brightens
summary: US top banks are expected to see their annual profits rebound in 2021, driven by a trading boom and easing pandemic concerns. Analysts predict a combined net income of around $73 billion, down from a record $120 billion in 2020. Trading revenue is forecasted to reach $20 billion in the fourth quarter, with lenders' earnings per share expected to jump nearly 35% this year. The industry's shift towards low-risk assets, such as Treasuries, and reduced lending are also seen as contributing factors to the predicted recovery.

site_title: Hybrid bar food at Sake Labo
summary: Sake Labo, a new sake bar on Stanley Street in Singapore, serves an awkward mix of Japanese-Spanish tapas. The bar's concept blends Spanish tapas, Japanese ingredients, and a Singapore accent, with a focus on drink lots of sake first, and eat second. The sake menu is comprehensive, with options starting from S$70 for 720ml bottles. Food dishes, such as prawns in sake kasu broth, Gardenia sandwich loaf, and crispy fried potatoes, show promise but are inconsistent in quality. The bar has a cosy-casual vibe and functional service, but its weak concept and limited menu options hold it back from being a truly great dining experience, earning a rating of 5.5.

site_title: Twitter chief backs Trump ban, but says it sets 'dangerous' precedent
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey has backed the platform's ban of US President Donald Trump, citing a "dangerous" precedent and a failure to promote healthy conversation. The ban, which has also been implemented by other major social media platforms, was made following the storming of the US Capitol by Trump's supporters. Dorsey expressed concern that the ban sets a precedent for unchecked power by companies over public conversation, but acknowledged that the decision was necessary to prevent further incitement of violence.

site_title: US consumer comfort drops to six-month low on finances concern
summary: US consumer sentiment reached a six-month low, dropping to 43.2 points, due to concerns over personal finances. This is the eighth consecutive decline, with a 6.6-point drop since mid-November. Americans' assessments of their finances fell to 55.9 points, the lowest since late May. Despite a $900 billion coronavirus relief package, the decline is attributed to increased restrictions on economic activity amid a surge in coronavirus infections. The decline was most pronounced among Republicans.

site_title: Doctor who declared Trump 'healthiest' president ever dies
summary: Harold Bornstein, Donald Trump's former personal doctor, has died at 73. Bornstein claimed Trump was the "healthiest" president ever in a 2015 letter, stating he dictated the letter himself. However, he later admitted to "making it up as I went along." Bornstein had hoped to join Trump in the White House but was thwarted after revealing Trump was taking a hair growth medication. No cause of death was given, and the news was reported on January 14, 2021.

site_title: Impeachment is a call for 'moral clarity'
summary: US President Donald Trump has become the first president to be impeached twice, despite 75% of Republican voters approving of his presidency. A columnist argues that impeachment should be a teachable moment to promote "moral clarity" and combat bigotry, conspiracy theories, and violence. The columnist suggests that tackling extremist ideologies, disarming terrorists, and pressuring advertisers to withdraw from extremist platforms are key steps in preventing such incidents. Impeachment may be a step towards reform, but it is a long road ahead, and the columnist warns that threats from within are often the most dangerous.

site_title: Lian Beng H1 net profit falls 5.2% to S$17.6m
summary: Lian Beng Group's net profit fell 5.2% to S$17.6m for the first half-year, impacted by Covid-19 restrictions and construction segment disruptions. Revenue dropped 36.6% to S$197.5m, with property development turnover declining due to construction activity hold-ups. The company recognised development profit and sales at private-home projects, offsetting losses from the British hotel business. No interim dividend was recommended, prioritizing cash conservation, and the construction order book stands at S$1.5 billion.

site_title: The four Ps have just shrunk
summary: The four Ps of marketing - product, price, place, and promotion - have shrunk due to the pandemic, with "place" losing its significance. Retail shopping in physical stores has declined, and many businesses are considering closure. Entertainment and dining have also seen a decline, while online shopping has become the norm. Marketers are left with only three Ps to play with, with product and promotion acquiring larger importance. The shift has led to a focus on minimum value standards, with consumers upgrading quality over price. The pandemic has accelerated the transformation of marketing, with digital advertising becoming a new paradigm.

site_title: Small businesses hit by Covid-19 can renegotiate some contracts
summary: Small businesses significantly affected by the Covid-19 pandemic in Singapore can renegotiate certain contracts with their counterparties starting Friday, Jan 15, under the Re-Align Framework. The framework allows eligible businesses with annual revenue of not more than S$30 million to renegotiate contracts for six weeks. This move aims to support small and micro businesses impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Trump administration shelves planned investment ban on Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu: sources
summary: The Trump administration has scrapped plans to blacklist Chinese tech giants Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu, four people familiar with the matter said. This decision provides a brief reprieve to Beijing's top corporates amid a broader crackdown by Washington. Despite shelving plans for these three companies, the administration plans to add up to nine other Chinese companies to the list, targeting alleged military companies. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's more dovish stance on China is seen as a factor in the decision.

site_title: Samsung launches Galaxy S21 phones with lower prices
summary: Samsung has launched the Galaxy S21 series of smartphones, featuring three devices with lower prices compared to last year's lineup. The Galaxy S21 starts at $799.99, while the S21+ and S21 Ultra cost $999.99 and $1,199.99, respectively. The price drops aim to compete with Apple's iPhone 12 and address rising competition from Xiaomi. The new devices feature improved cameras, 5G connectivity, and IP68 water resistance, with the S21 Ultra offering support for Samsung's S Pen digital stylus.

site_title: Trump finds himself abandoned by the city that made his name
summary: New York City is severing ties with the Trump Organization, ending over $17 million in contracts, following President Donald Trump's call to stop the certification of Joe Biden's election, which led to the US Capitol riot. The city cited "criminal activity" and plans to owe the Trump Organization $30 million if they proceed. Several businesses, including a real estate firm, Deutsche Bank, and a golf group, have also abandoned Trump. The move cuts into the heart of Trump's brand, particularly in New York City, where he has lived and developed iconic properties.

site_title: KrisEnergy creditors vote 'yes' on debt restructuring scheme
summary: KrisEnergy's creditors have approved its debt restructuring scheme, with 80.93% of creditors supporting the move. The company will proceed with the final two stages, involving zero coupon note holders and shareholders. CEO Kelvin Tang described the approval as a "critical step" in reorganizing liabilities and achieving a more sustainable capital structure. Trading in KrisEnergy shares remains suspended, and the company will apply for court sanction of the scheme.

site_title: 12,000 visitors throng Normanton Park showroom despite monsoon deluge
summary: Normanton Park, a 1,862-unit 99-year leasehold project in Singapore, saw a significant turnout of 12,000 visitors during its 13-day preview from January 2 to 14, despite heavy rainfall. The visitors, mostly comprising upgraders, investors, and prospective homebuyers, showed interest in the project's smart-home features and prices ranging from S$1,445 to S$1,672 per square foot. Balloting for bookings will be conducted on January 15, and bookings will begin on January 16.

site_title: Ghosn hid part of Nissan salary, feared being forced out of Renault
summary: Carlos Ghosn hid part of his compensation from Nissan due to fears the French government would force him out of Renault if the amount was disclosed, a former Nissan executive testified in a Tokyo court. Ghosn allegedly concealed $118.6 million in deferred payments through 2018, when new rules required executives to disclose payments above $1 billion. Ghosn denies wrongdoing, claiming he was the victim of a boardroom coup. Kelly, Ghosn's co-defendant, faces up to 10 years in prison if found guilty.

site_title: US jobless claims jump by most since March, close to a million
summary: US jobless claims surged by 181,000 to 965,000 in the week ended Jan 9, the largest jump since late March, indicating persistent labor-market pain due to coronavirus infections. Continuing claims rose to 5.27 million. The US$900 billion pandemic aid package recently approved is expected to provide relief, but a larger federal stimulus package may be needed to address labor market weakness. President-elect Joe Biden is expected to release details of a proposed additional relief package, which could extend unemployment benefits and aid cities and states.

site_title: Norwegian Air to end transatlantic flights, seeks state help
summary: Norwegian Air, a budget airline that once challenged traditional rivals with transatlantic flights, will end these services due to the pandemic, resulting in 2,000 job losses. The airline will focus on Nordic and European routes, cutting its fleet to around 50 aircraft before expanding to 70 in 2022. Norwegian Air will seek government help and is discussing possible state participation in a restructured company. The plan aims to cut debt and liabilities, with the goal of returning to profit before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization later this year.

site_title: Hin Leong Trading's judicial managers given more time to restructure troubled firm
summary: The Singapore High Court granted a three-month extension for Hin Leong Trading's judicial management order, allowing the firm's judicial managers more time to restructure the troubled oil trader. The order was initially set to expire on February 3, 2021. The Lim family, including founder Lim Oon Kuin, also applied to discharge the judicial managers of its sister company Ocean Tankers Pte Ltd. The judicial managers are seeking to recoup $3.5 billion in debt owed to 20 banks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines successfully raised US$500m in its oversubscribed US dollar debt debut, with the final demand tally exceeding US$2.85 billion. The issuance was anchored by high-quality institutional investors, including real money asset managers. This move is seen as a strong indication of the carrier's financial stability and access to capital markets.

site_title: Subaru to cut output at plants in Japan, US due to global chip shortage
summary: Japanese automaker Subaru plans to cut output by "several thousand" vehicles at its Japanese and US plants due to a global semiconductor shortage. Production at Gunma, Japan, and Indiana, US, factories will be reduced without specifying the exact number. This move follows a global scramble for semiconductors as demand rebounds from the coronavirus crisis. Subaru will also examine potential further cuts from February. The shortage affects other carmakers, including Nissan and Honda, which have also announced production reductions.

site_title: WhatsApp faces first legal challenge in India over privacy
summary: WhatsApp faces its first legal challenge in India over its updated privacy policy, which critics say threatens user surveillance and national security. A petition filed in an Indian court alleges the policy, which reserves data sharing with Facebook and its units, verges on user surveillance. The update sparked outrage in India, where WhatsApp has 400 million users. The court hearing is the first major legal challenge to WhatsApp's updated policy in the country.

site_title: MAS appoints new deputy managing director
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) appointed Leong Sing Chiong as deputy managing director (Markets & Development) on February 1, 2021, succeeding Jacqueline Loh. Leong will oversee Markets and Investment Group, Fintech and Innovation Group, and Development and International Group. He began his career in 1993 and held various appointments, including chief representative of MAS' London office. Leong will continue in his current role as assistant managing director for Markets & Investment until a successor is appointed.

images.alt_text: Leong Sing Chiong has been appointed as MAs' deputy managing director (Markets & Development) with effect from Feb 1.

site_title: Affirm's Nasdaq debut values GIC's stake at US$2.1b
summary: Affirm, a Singaporean-backed lender, made its Nasdaq debut, with its shares nearly doubling in value to US$97.24 apiece. The company raised US$1.2 billion and its post-debut market capitalisation reached US$23.6 billion. GIC, the largest shareholder, now values its stake at US$2.1 billion, following a 98.45% increase from its IPO price. Affirm was founded in 2012 and has partnered with over 6,500 merchants.

site_title: Medtecs International exploring Covid-19 test-kit tie-up for Philippine market
summary: Medtecs International Corp, a medical equipment supplier listed on the Catalist, is exploring a partnership with Enimmune Corp to distribute Covid-19 rapid tests in the Philippines. The Taiwanese biologics firm's test kits will be promoted by Medtecs, with definitive agreements to be signed. The company will make further announcements on the tie-up as material developments occur.

site_title: SLB Development H1 net profit stable year on year at S$5.54m
summary: SLB Development, a Catalist-listed company, reported stable net profit of S$5.54 million for the first half of 2021, a 0.9% year-on-year increase. Revenue decreased 4.9% to S$19.0 million due to a slowdown in construction work amid COVID-19 measures. The company's net profit was boosted by share of results from joint ventures and associates, reversing a previous loss of S$592,000.

site_title: New Renault boss plans leaner, electric future
summary: Renault's new CEO, Luca de Meo, plans to slim down the company and focus on technology as it faces management turmoil and the Covid-19 crisis. The company aims to cut costs by 500 million euros, reduce car production to 3.1 million vehicles by 2025, and focus on electrified models, including a revamped classic Renault Super Cinq. De Meo aims to boost operating margins to 5% by 2023 and generate three billion euros in automotive free cash flow by 2023.

site_title: Next Billion Venture appoints SeedPlus' partner to South-east Asia team
summary: NEXT Billion Venture appoints Foo Tiang Lim, a seasoned venture partner with over a decade of experience in South-east Asia, to its team. Lim will focus on identifying high-growth startups in Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Singapore. He joins from SeedPlus, where he managed a portfolio of South-east Asian startups. NBV, a US-based venture capital firm, aims to differentiate by investing in ubiquitous problems across emerging markets while recognizing localisation for success.

site_title: ByteDance's chief rival wins HKEX nod for US$5b IPO
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a short video startup backed by Tencent Holdings, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange for a US$5 billion initial public offering, making it one of the city's biggest listings of the year. Kuaishou plans to gauge demand for its IPO starting next week and aims for a valuation of US$50 billion, surpassing its recent estimate. This move paves the way for Kuaishou to become the third most valuable private company in the world, beating SpaceX.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains, STI up 0.76% to hit 3,000
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,000 points for the first time since March 2020, gaining 0.76% or 22.49 points. The STI surpassed the 3,000-point mark due to a positive market sentiment, with US President-elect Joe Biden's stimulus plan and potential positive preliminary data from Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine trials contributing to the gains. Property developers City Developments and UOL Group were among the best-performing counters, while Wilmar International also saw a 2.4% increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.98 points to 1,635.71. The trading volume was 6.49 billion lots worth RM4.87 billion. Despite a slight edge in volume, there were 584 gainers and 583 losers. The market's performance was not significantly influenced by recent US-EU trade talks and tariff threats, as traders seemed to brush off the news.

site_title: Indonesia may allow private sector to buy and distribute vaccines
summary: Indonesia may allow private companies to buy and distribute COVID-19 vaccines, reducing the burden on the state. Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin proposed this move, citing concerns about prioritizing the rich. The plan, if approved, would enable companies to procure vaccines for their staff and potentially sell them to the public. This move is seen as a potential solution to the country's vaccine shortage, with an estimated cost of US$5.3 billion. However, critics warn that it may disadvantage the poorest and most vulnerable populations.

images.alt_text: Indonesia may allow companies to procure their own Covid-19 vaccines, the country's health minister said on Thursday, as an influential business chamber called for members to be able to inoculate staff or sell vaccines to the public.

site_title: AirAsia X shows court creditors' support for restructuring plan
summary: AirAsia X, a Malaysian budget airline, has received support from most of its aircraft lessors for its restructuring plan, with 15 out of 20 lessors not in favor of liquidation. The airline has also received interest from potential investors, including Tune Group, which owns a 17.83% stake, to participate in its proposed fundraising exercise. AirAsia X plans to raise up to RM200 million by issuing shares to new investors after reorganization and is seeking to restructure RM64.15 billion of debt.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets little changed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained unchanged or edged higher at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.3%. Paris' CAC 40 remained flat. The markets' stability was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also a focus.

site_title: TSMC Q4 profit rises 23% to record high on work-from-home, iPhone boost
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported a record high quarterly profit of T$142.8 billion (S$6.76 billion) in Q4, a 23% increase from the previous year. The surge was driven by demand for high-end chips as the pandemic forces people to work from home and the release of Apple's new iPhone. This surpassed analyst estimates of T$135.39 billion, solidifying TSMC's position as the world's largest contract chipmaker.

site_title: Philippines approves Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for emergency use
summary: The Philippines' Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved the emergency use of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine, with a 95% success rate, amid concerns over the country's high coronavirus cases. The country aims to inoculate 70 million people, or two-thirds of its population, and has secured deals with multiple vaccine manufacturers. The FDA has also received an application from China's Sinovac Biotech for emergency use authorization. The Philippines will receive its first batch of Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines in the first quarter through the Covax facility.

site_title: Nomura, Sparx to form company to invest in unlisted firms
summary: Nomura Holdings is teaming up with Japanese asset manager Sparx Group Co to form a company that will invest in unlisted firms. The move aims to increase business in private markets and provide individuals more opportunities to invest in unlisted companies. This is part of Nomura's efforts to boost return on equity to 10% in five years.

site_title: Hong Kong's biggest ETF resumes buying stocks banned by US
summary: Hong Kong's largest ETF, the Tracker Fund of Hong Kong, has resumed buying stocks of Chinese companies banned by the US, reversing a decision made just two days earlier. The fund, managed by State Street, cited its non-US status as the reason for the reversal. The move boosted shares of China Mobile, which had seen significant volatility due to the US ban. The decision comes after criticism from Hong Kong's former central bank chief and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, which will continue to monitor the situation.

site_title: Takeover price for Sunningdale Tech at S$1.55 is 'too low': Quarz Capital
summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital Management is appealing for Sunningdale Tech's chairman to negotiate a fairer deal after the proposed takeover price of S$1.55 per share is deemed "too low" and "significantly undervalues" the precision plastic components manufacturer. The proposed deal is at a 22% discount to Sunningdale's book value of close to S$2 per share, with Quarz citing the company's consistently profitable track record and increasing net asset value. Quarz argues that minority shareholders should be able to reap the benefits of higher profitability from the company's "heavy and extended investment phase".

site_title: Para-veterinarian is sole Covid-19 community case in Singapore
summary: A 32-year-old Singaporean para-veterinarian is the country's lone locally transmitted Covid-19 case, according to the Ministry of Health. The patient, who developed a fever on Monday, was tested positive on Wednesday and is currently unlinked to any close contacts. His case is being monitored, and all his contacts, including family and co-workers, are isolated and on quarantine. This brings Singapore's total number of imported cases to 59,029, the highest since March 23.

site_title: Bukalapak raises funding from Standard Chartered for expansion
summary: Indonesia's Bukalapak.com has secured funding from Standard Chartered as part of its efforts to raise US$200 million for expansion. The online marketplace, which has about 100 million users and 13.5 million sellers, has already received US$100 million from existing investors. The partnership with Standard Chartered aims to collaborate on digital banking, and Bukalapak's transaction volumes more than doubled in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic. This funding round is part of a flurry of deals among South-east Asia's biggest internet companies, including Sea and Grab Financial Group.

site_title: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing's operating profit beats pre-pandemic level
summary: Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, reported a quarterly operating profit of 113.1 billion yen, beating pre-pandemic levels, driven by China's resurgence and demand for comfortable roomwear. Sales fell short of market expectations at 619.8 billion yen. The company's profit increase surpassed the market's forecast of 104.7 billion yen.

site_title: WHO team arrives in Wuhan to probe Covid-19 origins
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) team, led by Dr. Peter Ben Embarek, has arrived in Wuhan, China, to investigate the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic. The team, consisting of 10 independent experts, will spend two weeks interviewing people and conducting research in Wuhan. China had initially delayed the team's arrival, drawing criticism from the WHO and the US, which has accused China of hiding the extent of its initial outbreak. The team aims to determine whether the virus emerged from bats or had an intermediate animal host.

site_title: Australia: Shares stand pat ahead of US stimulus plan, earnings
summary: Australian shares remained steady, unchanged at 6,686.6 points, ahead of the US stimulus plan and earnings season. Investors were cautious, limiting market movements. Afterpay led a surge in technology stocks, while moves were limited due to market anticipation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.93% on Thursday, closing at 28,496.86, driven by traders awaiting US President Joe Biden's stimulus package proposals. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.91% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 1.39%. The gains were largely unaffected by recent US-EU trade tensions and new tariff threats, which have been brushed off by traders.

site_title: BOJ sticks to upbeat view on regional Japan despite curbs to combat pandemic
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained an upbeat view on regional Japan, raising its assessment for three areas and describing most local economies as picking up despite new measures to combat the pandemic. The BOJ upgraded its assessment on factory output for all nine areas for the first time since 2009, citing robust demand for goods offsetting weak service-related spending. The report suggests the BOJ will hold off expanding stimulus at its next rate review, reinforcing market expectations.

site_title: Chinese drone firm DJI builds team to work on self-driving tech
summary: China's SZ DJI Technology, the world's largest drone maker, is building an engineering team to work on self-driving technologies. The company is hiring engineers for auto electronics, autonomous driving, and in-car software, and plans to sell driver-assist technology such as lidar sensors and packaged solutions for autonomous driving functions. This move comes as several hardware and software tech firms, including Huawei and Baidu, are racing to tap into the auto industry's autonomous future. DJI's entry into the self-driving market is seen as a significant development in the industry.

site_title: Courts Singapore to open new flagship store at The Heeren in place of Robinsons
summary: Courts Singapore is set to open a new flagship store at The Heeren, spanning six storeys, in place of Robinsons, which closed its doors in December 2021. The 189,000 square foot space will be the retailer's largest in Singapore, featuring new retail concepts and "Japanese standards of customer experience". The store is expected to launch by Q1 2022 and marks the first overseas large-format store concept by parent company Nojima Corporation in a central Singapore location.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat as investors await US stimulus details, Powell remarks
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Thursday as investors awaited US stimulus details and Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's remarks. The benchmark Kospi closed up 1.64 points, or 0.05%, at 3,149.93. US President-elect Joe Biden is set to unveil a Covid-19 relief plan costing trillions of dollars later in the day. Foreigners were net buyers of 672.1 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened, but the benchmark bond yield rose. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates steady when it meets on Friday.

site_title: US stands by Taiwan, envoy says after cancelled trip
summary: US Ambassador to the UN Kelly Craft reaffirmed the US stance of supporting Taiwan, despite a cancelled trip to Taipei. Craft spoke with Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen, expressing the US's commitment to democracy and its partnership with Taiwan. The cancellation of Craft's trip was due to a State Department ban on travel ahead of the Biden administration's transition. Craft stated that the US will continue to stand with Taiwan as friends and partners, standing shoulder to shoulder as pillars of democracy.

site_title: Google 'experiment' blocks Australian news from local searches
summary: Google has started blocking Australian news sites from local searches in an experiment amid a push by Canberra to compel tech firms to pay media outlets for their content. The move comes as Australia plans to force Google and Facebook to pay media organisations when their platforms host their content or face millions of dollars in fines. The experiment, affecting around 1% of Google Search users, will test the impact of news businesses and Google Search on each other.

site_title: StanChart's Singapore-based investment banking head is top CEO contender: FT
summary: Standard Chartered's investment banking head Simon Cooper has emerged as the internal contender to replace CEO Bill Winters, citing outperformance of his advisory and trading unit during the Covid-19 pandemic. Cooper, based in Singapore, may return to London as deputy CEO, with chairman Jose Vinals also considering external candidates. The bank's board is conducting a "market-mapping" exercise to monitor all potential options. Cooper joined Standard Chartered in 2016 and previously worked at HSBC. His appointment would follow Winters' eventual departure, which is expected after his first three years at the bank.

site_title: Sumitomo to close Singapore crude, fuel oil trading desk at end-March
summary: Sumitomo, a Japanese trading house, plans to close its crude and fuel oil trading desks in Singapore by end-March and relocate the functions to Tokyo. The company will also exit its bunker fuel blending business in Singapore, citing reduced opportunities due to stricter emissions standards. Employees were informed of the decision on Monday, and the transition will be completed in April. Sumitomo's Singapore unit, Summit Energy & Resources, will continue its oil trading business until the end of March.

site_title: Poshmark prices IPO above marketed range at US$42 a share
summary: Poshmark, an online marketplace for second-hand goods, priced its initial public offering (IPO) above its marketed range at $42 per share, raising $277 million. The company, valued at $3.5 billion, sold 6.6 million shares. This follows successful IPOs of Affirm Holdings and Petco Health and Wellness Co. Poshmark's shares are expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol POSH, led by Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs Group, and Barclays.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on Chinese data, US stimulus hope
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.85% on Thursday, driven by strong Chinese trade data and hopes for US stimulus under the new administration. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 241.67 points to 28,698.26, while the Topix index rose 8.88 points to 1,873.28. The positive sentiment was attributed to the Chinese data and the potential for fresh US stimulus, which lifted shares in the region.

site_title: Buddhist monks snapping up ESG bonds in Japan
summary: Buddhist monks in Japan, specifically the Tokuunin Zen Buddhist temple in central Tokyo, have invested in ESG bonds to generate returns for building repairs and maintenance. The temple bought 40-year social bonds sold by the University of Tokyo, citing the need for inflation coverage. The investment allows the temple to contribute to society while earning a return, making it a unique example of ESG investing in Japan.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's MTN programme limit raised to S$2b from S$500m
summary: Keppel DC Reit's multicurrency medium term note (MTN) programme limit has been raised to S$2 billion from S$500 million. The program, which includes perpetuals, will be used to finance acquisitions, investments, and development works. Net proceeds will also be utilized for refinancing borrowings and general working capital purposes. The Singapore Exchange has given in-principle approval for the listing and quotation of any notes and perps issued under the amended program.

site_title: GIC-backed Affirm sees stock nearly double in Nasdaq debut
summary: Affirm Holdings, a US provider of installment loans to online shoppers, saw its shares nearly double in its Nasdaq debut, valuing the company at over $23 billion. The company raised $1.2 billion in the offering, with its shares ending the first day at $97.24 apiece, a 98% pop from its IPO price of $49. Founded by PayPal co-founder Max Levchin, Affirm's debut marks a significant milestone in the company's journey to becoming a known brand.

site_title: Brexit adds to airline virus woes in Britain
summary: Airlines in the UK face post-Brexit obstacles, with no-frills carriers like Ryanair and EasyJet being notably affected. To continue flying within the EU, airlines with less than 50% EU-based shareholders must demonstrate majority ownership by European persons by the end of 2021. This adds costs and complexity, particularly at a time of huge losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The restrictions are intended to ensure safety and strong competition, but may hinder competitiveness and add administrative burdens.

site_title: E-payments, fund transfers pip card transactions in South-east Asia
summary: E-wallets and fund transfers have surpassed card transactions in South-east Asia, with e-payments growing faster than card transactions in 2020. Non-bank tech firms, such as e-wallet providers, are dominating the fintech scene, especially in Indonesia and the Philippines. However, instant interbank transfers, like PayNow and PromptPay, are gaining popularity in mature economies like Singapore and Thailand, potentially limiting growth prospects for fintechs. Large tech companies, including Grab and Sea Ltd, are expanding into banking services, while non-bank tech firms face competition and potential losses in a crowded market.

site_title: Cargill in talks to exit global sugar trading business
summary: Cargill, a top agricultural commodities firm, is in talks to exit its global sugar trading business, with a potential sale of its 50% stake in Alvean, the world's largest sugar trader, to Brazilian partner Copersucar. The deal, if successful, is expected to be announced in the first quarter. Cargill is shifting focus to food processing and meat production, following a similar move by rival Archer-Daniels-Midland Co Bunge. This exit marks the latest change in Cargill's business strategy, which aims to reduce reliance on trading amid struggling commodity markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares end firmer on tech boost, US stimulus prospects
summary: Australian shares ended 0.43% higher at 6,715.3 points, driven by a tech boost, particularly from Afterpay, which surged 10% after Morgan Stanley raised its price target. Tech stocks rose 4.7% after three straight days of losses, with Afterpay's gains led by the stellar debut of Affirm Holdings. Financials climbed 0.8%, while gold stocks and miners fell 1.5% and 0.8%, respectively.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE raises TP for Wilmar on potential Q4 surprises
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has raised its target price for Wilmar International to S$6.80 from S$5.40, citing potential upside surprises in Q4 2020 results. Analyst Thilan Wickramasinghe expects significant margin surprises due to record-high Chinese soya bean crush margins and a 30% rise in palm oil prices. He also sees potential for Wilmar's food products business to accelerate in China's recovering hotel and restaurant demand. The analyst believes significant upside exists, potentially triggering asset carve outs or privatisation. Wilmar shares rose 1.8% to S$5.14 at midday trading.

site_title: KKR closes first Asia-Pacific real estate fund at US$1.7b
summary: KKR has closed its first Asia-Pacific real estate fund at US$1.7 billion, expanding its presence in the region. The fund focuses on urbanization trends, corporate carve-outs, and take-private opportunities in markets such as Japan, Australia, and Singapore. KKR's real estate efforts are part of the firm's broader expansion into alternative asset management products, following a record US$9 billion raised in 47 Asia-focused real estate funds last year.

site_title: LTA awards S$34.3m civil contract for Hume station on Downtown Line
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded a S$34.3 million civil contract to JSM Construction Group for the construction of Hume station on the Downtown Line. The project includes the installation of a station entrance, ventilation shaft, and fitting-out works. The station is expected to open in 2025 and will provide convenient access to the Rail Corridor and surrounding residential developments. Installation of rail systems and electrical and mechanical services will also be carried out, with testing to follow completion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.61% in opening trade on Thursday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, as investors await US stimulus proposals. The Hang Seng Index gained 172.52 points to 28,402.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.38% to 3,584.93.

site_title: Biden to unveil economic plan as US recovery buckles
summary: President-elect Joe Biden will unveil his economic plan to revive the US economy, which is struggling to recover from the pandemic despite trillions of dollars in government spending. The plan may include stimulus payments, tax hikes on the rich, and an increase in the minimum wage. Biden aims to build on the success of the last massive rescue package, which provided $600 in direct payments. With Democrats controlling Congress, he has a good shot at passing a third rescue package, which could include direct relief for families and small businesses.

site_title: China reports first Covid-19 death in eight months
summary: China reported its first COVID-19 death in eight months, with a fatality in Hebei province. The National Health Commission also reported 138 new infections, the highest single-day tally since March 2021. Authorities have launched mass testing and lockdowns in several cities, including Shijiazhuang and Xingtai. China is preparing for a WHO expert team's arrival to investigate the pandemic's origins. The country's official death toll now stands at 4,635, with no reported deaths since May 2021.

site_title: WHO convenes emergency committee early over coronavirus variants
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is convening an emergency committee two weeks early to discuss the new coronavirus variants from South Africa and Britain, which have rapidly spread to 50 countries. The variants are more infectious than the initial strain and have raised concerns that they may render certain vaccines less effective. The meeting aims to consider issues related to vaccination and testing certificates for international travel. Global infections have surpassed 91 million, and deaths have approached 2 million, prompting governments to reimpose economic lockdowns and social restrictions.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization's (WHO) emergency committee will meet two weeks early on Thursday to discuss the new coronavirus variants from South Africa and Britain that have rapidly spread to at least 50 countries and sparked widespread alarm.

site_title: Petco IPO raises US$864m as retailer returns to market
summary: Petco, a US-based animal supply chain store, raised $864 million in its initial public offering (IPO), returning to the public market 15 years after being taken private. The company sold 48 million shares at $18 each and will continue to be controlled by its current owners. Petco operates 1,500 stores across the US, Puerto Rico, and Mexico, but reported a net loss of $25 million on $3.58 billion in net sales for the 39-week period ended October 31.

site_title: Hong Kong national security police make 11 new arrests
summary: Hong Kong's national security police arrested 11 people, including veteran human rights lawyer Daniel Wong, on suspicion of aiding 12 pro-democracy activists who attempted to flee the city by speedboat to Taiwan. The arrests come a week after over 50 democracy activists were detained for subversion under Beijing's national security law. Those on board the speedboat were charged with crimes linked to 2019 protests, with 10 previously jailed for up to three years. The law mandates life imprisonment for offenses deemed "secession, subversion, collusion with foreign forces and terrorism".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.23 points, or 0.50%, to 1,644.92. Volume was 751.02 million lots worth RM468.57 million. The market saw 364 gainers compared to 287 losers.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise with Biden stimulus plan in focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as investors awaited Joe Biden's stimulus plan, with hopes for a huge spending splurge in the US economy. Despite concerns over surging virus cases, analysts said a new drug developed by Johnson & Johnson could make a difference. The focus is on Biden's proposed $2,000 cash handouts, which could drive inflation higher. Markets also took heart from comments from top Fed officials indicating no plans to wind down monetary easing, and European Central Bank head Christine Lagarde saying a policy tightening would be unwarranted.

images.alt_text: Asian markets mostly enjoyed fresh gains on Thursday as investors await Joe Biden's proposals for a vast new stimulus as well as comments from the head of the Federal Reserve on its policy outlook.

site_title: Singapore Airlines raises US$500m in oversubscribed US dollar debt debut
summary: Singapore Airlines has raised US$500 million through its first US dollar-denominated bond issue, exceeding its initial demand of US$2.85 billion. The 2026 notes, issued at 99.573% of their principal amount with a 3% annual coupon, were oversubscribed by high-quality institutional investors. The airline's S$10 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme allows for the issuance of these notes, with the expected maturity date set for July 20, 2026.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH Reit, HC Surgical, Aspen, GL, GKE Corp, Keppel DC Reit
summary: Stocks to watch: Key developments include SPH Reit's lower Q1 DPU, HC Surgical Specialists' earnings more than doubling, Aspen Holdings' glovemaking venture, GL's net loss, GKE Corporation's earnings tripling, Keppel DC Reit's multicurrency medium term note programme raised to S$2 billion, and Singapore Airlines launching its first US dollar bond.

site_title: Snap says it is permanently terminating Trump's account
summary: Snapchat permanently terminated US President Donald Trump's account following the violent unrest at the Capitol. The decision was made in the interest of public safety and due to Trump's attempts to spread misinformation, hate speech, and incite violence. The indefinite suspension was announced last week.

site_title: China's Dec exports rise 18.1% y-o-y, imports up 6.5%, top forecasts
summary: China's exports rose 18.1% in December from a year earlier, exceeding forecasts, while imports grew 6.5%, beating expectations. The trade surplus widened to US$78.17 billion. The stronger-than-expected exports and imports suggest that global demand for Chinese goods remains solid, supporting the country's economic growth.

site_title: Twitter chief says Trump ban sets 'dangerous' precedent
summary: Twitter chief Jack Dorsey has defended the platform's decision to ban US President Donald Trump, calling it a "dangerous" precedent that sets a failure to promote healthy conversation.
