Twitter shut down Trump's account after a violent mob stormed the Capitol, citing the risk of further incitement of violence. Dorsey believes the ban sets a precedent that could fragment the public conversation, but ultimately promotes healthy conversation. The ban is considered overdue by critics, but some argue it stifles free speech.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 down 0.15% at 28,414.49, and the Topix index down 0.24% at 1,859.95, following recent rallies. The move was attributed to profit-taking.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust obtains S$50m green loan from DBS to finance lyf one-north
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has secured a S$50 million green loan from DBS for five years to finance its lyf one-north Singapore development. The 324-unit co-living property is expected to be completed in Q4 2021, featuring energy-efficient and smart building features. This loan supports ART's commitment to environmental sustainability, with the trust now owning 21 green-certified properties. The stapled group's managers see this loan as a positive step, encouraging other companies to explore green financing solutions.

images.alt_text: lyf one-north is slated for completion in Q4 2021. It will be fitted with energy-efficient and smart building features

site_title: Parler asks US court to order Amazon to restore service to social media app
summary: Parler, a social media platform favored by Donald Trump supporters, is suing Amazon to restore its service after Amazon shut it down following the US Capitol riot on January 6. Parler claims Amazon breached its contract by cutting it off, citing concerns over threatening language on the site. The company removed most problematic posts, but Amazon cited posts with vile language and threats against individuals, including former first lady Michelle Obama. Parler's CEO, John Matze, says the app's future is uncertain, and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton has issued subpoenas to Amazon, Google, and Apple over their handling of the app.

site_title: Gold retreats as US dollar, Treasury yields rebound
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,838.39 per ounce as US Treasury yields and the dollar rebounded, driven by investors awaiting details on President Joe Biden's coronavirus stimulus proposal. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields rose near ten-month highs, lifting the dollar against rival currencies. The stimulus plan is estimated to cost "trillions" of dollars and could impact gold prices, with some analysts predicting a boost in real interest rates and inflation outlook. The US Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook will also be closely watched, with Chairman Jerome Powell set to participate in a virtual event.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Thursday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 11.46 points to 2,988.97. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 25, with local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC leading the gains. Other notable movers included GKE Corporation, which rose 3% after tripling its first-half net profit, and HC Surgical Specialists, which jumped 28.6% after reporting a 12.4% year-on-year revenue increase.

site_title: Japan machinery orders rise, Covid-19 emergency clouds outlook
summary: Japan's core machinery orders unexpectedly rose 1.5% in November, a second straight month, driven by demand for chip-making equipment and computers. The data contradicts economists' median estimate of a 6.2% drop. However, a renewed coronavirus emergency in Tokyo and other areas may dampen business spending. Core orders declined 11.3% compared to the previous year. The government raised its assessment on machinery orders, citing a pick-up move, but analysts warn of a double-dip recession due to dwindling corporate profits and the current third wave of coronavirus infections.

site_title: UK housing market boom starts to fade: survey
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a slowdown, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' survey. New buyer enquiries fell to a seven-month low in December, and house price growth slowed to a 21-year record. The survey attributed the decline to new Covid-19 lockdowns and the expiry of a temporary tax cut for buyers. Despite this, respondents expected an economic recovery to support house prices. Mortgage approvals reached a 14-year high in November, but analysts predict a cooling of activity in 2021 due to rising unemployment and the end of government subsidies.

site_title: Grab raises US$300m for fintech arm from investors including Hanwha
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing giant, raised over $300 million in funding from investors led by Hanwha Asset Management Co for its fintech business. The funding marks the first external investment in Grab's financial services arm, which aims to expand into insurance, lending, wealth management, and payments. Grab's senior managing director Reuben Lai stated that the pandemic has accelerated the need for digital financial services in South-east Asia, positioning the company at an "inflection point."

site_title: US Q1 budget deficit surges to record US$573b amid pandemic
summary: The US budget deficit surged by 61% in Q1 2021, reaching a record $573 billion, driven by high spending amid the pandemic. The deficit for the 2020 fiscal year was a record $3.1 trillion, more than double the prior record. Government expenditures increased due to pandemic programs, but the impact of a $900 billion measure will be seen later. The cost of servicing the public debt dropped by $28 billion to $131 billion amid record low interest rates.

site_title: Disneyland opens mass Covid-19 vaccination centre
summary: Disneyland in California has opened a mass COVID-19 vaccination center, 10 months after the pandemic forced the theme park's closure. The site, which will administer over 7,000 shots per day, is initially targeting over-65s and healthcare workers. California's slow vaccine rollout has been criticized, but the move is seen as a step towards reopening the state. The site's opening is also hoped to boost tourism, with Disneyland aiming to inoculate all residents by July 4 under its "Operation Independence" plan.

site_title: Huawei executive's family granted exemption to enter Canada
summary: Canada granted travel exemptions to Meng Wanzhou's husband, Liu Xiaozong, and their two children, allowing them to join her in Vancouver as she fights extradition to the US. This exemption, made for family reunification, was granted despite Canada's halt on non-essential travel in March 2020. The news emerged during Meng's extradition trial this week, with Liu Xiaozong arriving in October and the children in December.

site_title: Trump impeached for unprecedented second time
summary: Donald Trump became the first US president to be impeached for a second time, with 232 lawmakers voting to charge him with inciting the January 6 US Capitol attack. The impeachment, which occurred just before Trump's departure from office, triggers a trial in the US Senate, but it's expected to take place after Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20. This marks Trump's second impeachment, following a similar charge in 2019.

site_title: Italy plunged into political crisis, government risks collapse
summary: Italy plunged into a political crisis on January 13, 2021, after former Premier Matteo Renzi withdrew his party from the ruling coalition, risking the collapse of the government during the COVID-19 pandemic. Renzi's decision was over the handling of the pandemic and European Union recovery funds, but critics accused him of seeking more power for his party. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte warned that a government crisis would be "unforgivable" and urged Renzi to reconsider, proposing a new pact to regroup under. The crisis has raised concerns about snap elections and the potential for a reshuffled cabinet.

images.alt_text: Italy was plunged into political crisis on Wednesday after former premier Matteo Renzi withdrew his party from the ruling coalition, risking the collapse of the government in the middle of a raging coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Architect of Obama pivot to steer Asia policy for Biden
summary: Kurt Campbell, a key architect of the Obama administration's "pivot" to Asia, will serve as coordinator for Indo-Pacific affairs on the National Security Council for President-elect Joe Biden. Campbell's appointment signals renewed efforts to rally US allies in the face of rising China. He has criticized President Donald Trump's pressure on Japan and South Korea to pay more for US bases, advocating for a more nuanced approach to deter Chinese adventurism. Campbell and China expert Rush Doshi propose a competitive but peaceful region, offering Beijing a place in regional order if it abides by agreed-upon rules.

site_title: US won't bar investments in Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu: report
summary: US officials will not bar American investments in Chinese tech giants Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent, despite national security concerns. The decision comes after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin prevailed over Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. The move contrasts with previous actions taken against other Chinese firms. The decision was made as the Trump administration winds down, with President-elect Joe Biden set to take office.

site_title: UK's Johnson warns against 'unthinking sinophobia' in China ties
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned against "unthinking sinophobia" in China ties, urging a balance in criticism of Beijing's actions and policies. He made the statement during a meeting with parliament's select committee heads. Johnson renewed criticism of China but emphasized the need to avoid knee-jerk reactions. His comments come as the UK continues to navigate its complex relationship with China.

site_title: Saudi crown prince says kingdom offers US$6t investment opportunities over next decade
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced the kingdom's investment opportunities worth US$6 trillion over the next decade, as part of his Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy and reduce dependence on oil. The Public Investment Fund (PIF) will finance 85% of these opportunities, with the remaining 15% coming from global investors. The PIF is behind several mega projects, including NEOM, Qiddiya, and a luxury Red Sea resort, with infrastructure costs estimated at US$100 billion to US$200 billion.

site_title: DuPont's new plant helps boost Singapore as regional chemicals hub
summary: US chemical giant DuPont has built a new enzyme-blending factory in Singapore, boosting the country's push to be Asia-Pacific's speciality chemicals hub. The facility, set to become operational in the second quarter, will produce biotechnology solutions for Asia-Pacific, creating 96 jobs, including 77 for Singaporeans or permanent residents. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said the new facility demonstrates confidence in Singapore's strengths as a leading chemicals hub and highlights opportunities for growth in the energy and chemicals sector.

site_title: Indonesia launches massive Covid vaccination drive
summary: Indonesia launches a massive COVID-19 vaccination campaign, aiming to inoculate 181.5 million people with the Chinese CoronaVac vaccine. President Joko Widodo received the first shot, and the campaign's goal is to achieve herd immunity by vaccinating two-thirds of the 270 million population. The drive, which started on January 13, 2021, follows record increases in cases and deaths, with 24,951 fatalities and 858,043 infections reported. The government expects the cost of the program to be over $7 billion.

site_title: Global banks warn of market chaos if court abolishes Libor
summary: Global banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Credit Suisse, and Deutsche Bank, are warning a US judge against immediately terminating the London interbank offered rate (Libor) after a group of borrowers filed a lawsuit claiming it was a "price-fixing cartel." The banks argue that an injunction would cause market chaos and undermine years of reform efforts. If terminated, hundreds of trillions of dollars of financial assets could be affected, potentially destabilizing the global economy.

site_title: Oil ends lower, retreating from recent gains as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, retreating from recent gains, due to concerns about rising global Covid-19 cases hampering fuel demand. Brent crude prices settled at $56.06 a barrel, down 0.9%, and US West Texas Intermediate at $52.91 a barrel, down 0.6%. Lower crude inventories and rising refinery production provided some support, but analysts warn that the road to higher oil demand and prices will remain bumpy. Governments' continued restrictions on travel will restrain energy demand for months.

site_title: GL posts H1 net loss of US$19.8m on British hotel closures
summary: GL Limited, a Singapore-listed hotel operator, posted a net loss of US$19.8 million for the first half of 2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its British portfolio. Revenue fell 89.9% to US$19.5 million, with most core hospitality properties closed during the period. The company expects its British hotels to face a difficult operating environment this year, with uncertainty over when they will reopen.

site_title: Four emerging technology trends in 2021
summary: Four emerging technology trends in 2021 will shape the new normal, including digitalisation, automation, remote work, and smart cities. As the pandemic recedes, organisations will focus on recovering and adapting to new consumer needs. Key predictions include the development of data-centric solutions to address privacy concerns, automation revolutionising contact tracing, the transformation of the modern office with remote work, and the integration of IoT and data to build more resilient smart cities. These trends will drive innovation, create new opportunities, and pose challenges for businesses and governments to address.

site_title: No chance of 'fair' trial before Trump leaves office: Senate leader
summary: US Senate leader Mitch McConnell says there's no chance of a "fair or serious" trial of impeached President Donald Trump before he leaves office next week due to the short time frame. Trump was impeached on one charge of "incitement of insurrection" for his comments at a rally that led to the US Capitol siege. A trial is likely to begin after President-elect Joe Biden is sworn in, and McConnell's statement suggests it won't conclude before Trump leaves office.

site_title: Canada's Circle K owner in talks to buy France's Carrefour
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc, the owner of Circle K, is in talks to acquire French grocer Carrefour SA in a deal valued at approximately 16.4 billion euros. The proposed transaction would create a trans-Atlantic retail giant, with Couche-Tard initially proposing a 20-euro-per-share deal, representing a 29% premium. The talks come as Carrefour faces challenges in its European market and has been expanding its e-commerce and organic food offerings. A deal would mark a significant expansion for Couche-Tard into Europe, where Carrefour operates over 2,800 supermarkets.

site_title: Aspen says glovemaking unit secured US$100m in sales for 2021
summary: Aspen Holdings announced its glovemaking venture has secured US$100 million in sales for 2021, with the production of one billion medical grade examination gloves to be distributed by a third-party buyer in Europe and the US. The agreement, made for the entire 2021 production of Aspen Glove, is set to run from May 1 to December 31, 2021.

site_title: US vaccinates 10 million against Covid but remains behind target
summary: The US has administered over 10 million doses of the Covid-19 vaccine, with 3.1% of the population receiving the first dose. The country remains behind its immunization targets, with vaccines not yet available to children.

site_title: US asks Tesla to recall 158,000 vehicles for touchscreen failures
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has asked Tesla to recall 158,000 Model S and Model X vehicles due to touchscreen failures that could pose safety risks, including loss of rear-camera image display and reduced rear visibility. The issue affects Autopilot driver assistance system functionality. Tesla was upgraded to a formal safety probe in November after the NHTSA identified the problem. The recall request was made through a formal letter to Tesla.

images.alt_text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) on Wednesday asked Tesla to recall 158,000 Model S and Model X vehicles over media control unit failures that could pose safety risks by leading to touchscreen displays not working.

site_title: Singapore's Sea acquires Indonesian bank to gain foothold in financial tech
summary: Singapore's Sea has acquired Indonesian bank PT Bank Kesejahteraan Ekonomi (Bank BKE) through its subsidiary Turbo Cash Hong Kong, gaining full control of the Jakarta-based lender. This move aims to expand Sea's presence in the financial technology sector in Southeast Asia. The acquisition was made by buying stakes from existing shareholders PT Danadipa Artha Indonesia and PT Koin Investama Nusantara. The deal is considered a strategic move by Sea to strengthen its foothold in the Indonesian market.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up as House impeaches Trump again
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.2% and 0.4% respectively. Despite the House's second impeachment vote of President Trump, investors largely shrugged off the event, focusing on improving economic data and anticipation of US stimulus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down less than 0.1%. Intel surged 7% on an executive shakeup, while Target fell 1.2% on comparable sales growth. Markets remain near all-time highs as investors bet on a 2021 economy boost.

site_title: Europe: British shares fall on virus risks; Persimmon tumbles
summary: European shares fell on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 dropping 0.1% and the FTSE 250 falling 0.5%. Rising coronavirus cases and lockdowns across Europe raised concerns about the economy's near-term effects. Housebuilder Persimmon tumbled 6.2% after reporting a 9% fall in revenue due to Covid-19 risks. Deliveries of Covid-19 vaccines to Britain are on track, but investors remain cautious, with the FTSE 100 having recently lost steam due to new business restrictions.

site_title: Margin squeeze puts F&B players in a spot over food delivery demand
summary: Food and beverage (F&B) firms in Singapore are struggling with margin squeeze due to increasing food delivery demand. While delivery boosts sales, it also adds costs, with some operators passing on these fees to consumers. Others, like Wafuken and Kam's Roast, are hesitant to raise prices, fearing customer backlash. F&B establishments, with thin profit margins, are facing a dilemma, with delivery-related costs eating into profits and manpower costs also rising. To cope, some are introducing family-set menus and investing in cloud kitchens to maintain delivery sales.

site_title: Oil prices rally further after crude stocks fall more than expected
summary: Oil prices surged for the seventh consecutive day, with US crude gaining 34 cents, or 0.6%, to $53.55 a barrel, and Brent crude rising 36 cents, or 0.6%, to $56.94 a barrel. The rally was driven by a larger-than-expected drop in US crude inventories and optimism over economic growth in China, despite rising pandemic cases. The price increase is seen as a positive sign for US drillers, who may be tempted to return to production amid declining Saudi Arabian output.

site_title: US home prices ease in sign pandemic rally may cool this year
summary: US home prices have started to slow, with a 13.8% increase in December compared to the previous year, down from a peak of 16.5% in July. This slowdown may signal the end of the pandemic housing market rally. With interest rates unlikely to fall significantly lower, buyers will be squeezed out of the market due to a shortage of homes. Experts attribute the slowdown to unsustainable growth and a return to normal market conditions.

site_title: SPH Reit Q1 DPU down 13%; gross revenue up 10.8 per cent
summary: SPH Reit reported a 1Q DPU of 1.2 Singapore cents, down 13% from the previous year. The decline was attributed to the "gradual Covid-19 recovery" in Singapore and Australia. Gross revenue rose 10.8% year-over-year, in line with expectations. The lower DPU was expected, considering the recovery pace.

site_title: Companies with better social practices earn higher returns: report
summary: Market returns for companies with better social practices have increased by 17 basis points per month, up from 15 bps in 2018, according to a report by Federated Hermes. This represents a significant increase during the pandemic. Hyper-growth companies with poor social metrics observed lower returns, with monthly returns nearly three basis points lower than better-ranking peers. Federated Hermes recommends investors prioritize companies with high ESG scores to generate alpha in both bull and bear markets.

site_title: Conservation shophouses in Tanjong Pagar and Outram Park up for sale
summary: Several conservation shophouses in Tanjong Pagar and Outram Park have been put on the market, amid strong demand for the property type. A three-storey shophouse at 91 Tanjong Pagar Road has an indicative price of S$10.2 million, while another pair at Teo Hong Road comes with a guide price of S$33 million. The sale of these shophouses is expected to test the market for Singapore's prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: AEM's bid for CEI cements its M&A strategy to extend industry leadership
summary: AEM Holdings has made a S$99.7 million bid for contract manufacturer CEI, its largest acquisition to date. The offer includes a mix of cash and new AEM shares, with CEI shareholders holding a maximum of 2.49% of the enlarged total number of issued shares. The acquisition aims to boost AEM's capabilities and diversify revenue growth, with CEI's capabilities in printed circuit board assembly and box build manufacturing expected to bring in opportunities for better supply-chain integration and wider cross-selling.

site_title: GIC-backed lender Affirm prices IPO above range to raise US$1.2b
summary: Affirm Holdings, a US-based lender providing installment loans to online shoppers, priced its initial public offering (IPO) above its marketed range to raise US$1.2 billion. The company sold 24.6 million shares for US$49 each, giving it a market value of US$11.9 billion. Founded in 2012 by Max Levchin, Affirm had a net loss of US$15 million in the third quarter on revenue of US$174 million. The IPO follows a hot year for IPOs in 2020 and marks Affirm's entry into the market with a valuation of about US$15 billion.

site_title: Biden must adopt multilateral tactics for China policy
summary: The US-China relationship has shifted to a "strategic competition" due to China's rise under President Xi Jinping. The Biden administration is expected to adopt a multilateral approach, working with allies to press China to reform and open up. This may involve increased coordination on tariffs, sanctions, and policies on Chinese investment. While rolling back Trump-era measures may be challenging, the Biden team may still pursue new trade agreements and cooperate with the EU and other countries on investment and WTO reform, restoring normalcy to US economic diplomacy.

site_title: STI reverses 2-day losses to end flat, despite Wall Street gains overnight
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Wednesday, ending a two-day losing streak, despite a rise in US equities. Asian markets were mixed, with the Kospi and Nikkei 225 indexes rising, while Chinese markets declined due to a resurgence of Covid-19 cases in mainland China, with 115 new cases reported. Top performers included Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Singapore Airlines, which received government offers of Covid-19 vaccinations.

site_title: Vietnam e-wallet MoMo raises around US$100m, eyes IPO
summary: Vietnam's e-wallet company MoMo has raised around $100 million from six global investors, including Warburg Pincus, as part of plans to become a "super-app" and go public by 2025. The company aims to double its 50 million users to 100 million in the next two years, leveraging the growth of fintech in Vietnam during the COVID-19 pandemic. MoMo plans to use the funding to expand its services and become a one-stop smartphone application, similar to successful models in China and Indonesia.

site_title: Novo Tellus to take controlling stake in Grand Venture Tech via placement, vendor share sale
summary: Private equity fund Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 is set to take a 29.6% stake in Grand Venture Technology's enlarged share capital through a placement and vendor share sale. Grand Venture will issue 71.5 million new shares at S$0.33 apiece to raise S$23.6 million, with 81% of proceeds going towards expansion via mergers and acquisitions. The transaction is conditional upon shareholders' approval and listing approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: US core consumer price index up marginally in December
summary: The US core consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.1% in December, slightly below expectations, due to slack in the labor market and muted demand. The core CPI increased 1.6% year-over-year, while the broader CPI advanced 0.4% month-over-month and 1.4% year-over-year. Inflation remains below the Federal Reserve's goal, with most economists expecting it to remain relatively tame this year, driven by pent-up consumer demand and potential stimulus.

site_title: WhatsApp with consent: Are you informed?
summary: WhatsApp users in Singapore were not explicitly informed that their data could be requested for criminal investigations, sparking debate. The Singapore Police Force can obtain data under the Criminal Procedure Code, but the issue was whether users were informed of this potential use. WhatsApp updated its Privacy Policy in January 2021, requiring users to agree to new terms and conditions by February 8, 2021, or risk account termination. Elon Musk called on users to switch to Signal after the update, citing concerns about data privacy.

site_title: SGX names ING's Herry Cho new head of sustainability and sustainable finance
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has appointed Herry Cho as the new head of sustainability and sustainable finance, effective February 8. Cho will oversee the company's environmental, social, and governance ambitions, as well as expand its sustainable finance pillars. This newly created role aims to drive SGX's sustainability efforts and strategic direction.

site_title: Australian scientists suggest delaying AstraZeneca vaccine as infections fall
summary: Australian scientists are proposing delaying the mass inoculation of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine due to its lower efficacy compared to Pfizer and Moderna vaccines. The vaccine has 62% efficacy, whereas Pfizer's has over 90%. Experts suggest considering alternative vaccines, such as Moderna, to achieve herd immunity. The Australian government has already ordered 53 million doses of AstraZeneca, but some experts believe it can afford to wait for more effective vaccines, given the country's low case numbers.

site_title: Brexit deal may actually mean less British cod for fish & chips
summary: The UK's post-Brexit fishing deal has been met with disappointment from fishermen, who feel they have given away too much in terms of fishing rights. The deal allows the UK to regain control of 25% of EU fishing rights over five years, but many fishermen, including Peter Bruce, are worried they will end up with less quota, particularly for key catches like cod and haddock. The deal also means quota swapping between individual countries will no longer be possible, and foreign boats will still be able to catch within 19 km of British shores.

site_title: WhatsApp stresses privacy as users flock to rivals
summary: WhatsApp has faced criticism over its new terms, which sparked a surge in users to rival messaging apps Telegram and Signal. The update allows businesses to share data with Facebook, raising concerns about user privacy. WhatsApp has assured users that their messages with friends and family remain private, but the change has led to a significant increase in users switching to Telegram and Signal, with Telegram reporting over 500 million monthly active users and Signal seeing a huge surge in demand, including a recommendation from Elon Musk.

site_title: Washington's Wardman Park hotel driven into bankruptcy by virus
summary: The historic Marriott Wardman Park hotel in Washington filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, listing assets and liabilities of $100-500 million. The hotel, which opened in 1918, has been closed since the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak and faced a legal dispute with Marriott International Inc. over insufficient investments. The bankruptcy filing follows the hotel's struggles amid the pandemic, with workers warned of permanent closure. The hotel's owner, Pacific Life Mutual Holding Co, will continue to operate while working out a recovery plan.

site_title: China auto sales head for recovery this year
summary: China's vehicle sales fell 1.9% to 25.3 million vehicles in 2020, the third consecutive year, but rebounded in December with a 6.4% increase to 2.83 million. Passenger vehicle sales dropped 6% for the year, while commercial vehicle sales surged 19% due to government investment in infrastructure and stricter emissions rules. New energy vehicle sales rose 11% to 1.37 million units, with expectations of 1.8 million units in 2021 driven by supportive government policies and automaker discounts.

site_title: Singapore's HSA to vet Sinovac vaccine before public roll-out
summary: Singapore's Health Sciences Authority (HSA) will vet a Sinovac coronavirus vaccine before its public roll-out, following a 50.4% effectiveness rate in a Brazilian trial that falls short of regulatory approval. This is the latest update after the vaccine's announcement last week. The HSA will scrutinize the vaccine's data before making a decision on its approval.

site_title: Sally Rooney to publish new novel
summary: Sally Rooney, a 27-year-old novelist, is set to publish her new novel, "Beautiful World, Where Are You," in September. The book follows four young characters in Ireland as they navigate relationships, work, and economic uncertainty. Rooney's first two novels, "Conversations With Friends" and "Normal People," were critically acclaimed and commercially successful, selling over 1 million copies in the US. The new novel explores global and entrenched problems, with Rooney asking questions about how people should live together without earnestness but with sincerity.

site_title: Japan extends state of emergency to 7 more prefectures
summary: Japan has extended its state of emergency to 7 more prefectures amid a rise in Covid-19 cases. The move allows local authorities to impose restrictions on residents' movements and businesses. A survey by NHK found most people want to cancel or delay the Summer Olympics. The decision comes after governors of Osaka and other hard-hit prefectures requested the government declare a state of emergency.

site_title: Europe extends and tightens lockdowns
summary: European governments have extended and tightened lockdowns in response to the fast-spreading coronavirus variant first detected in Britain. Italy, Switzerland, and Germany will impose stricter measures, including extended closures of restaurants and cultural sites, and increased testing requirements for travelers. Vaccinations are expected to take several months to have a significant impact, with some countries predicting a slow improvement in the summer. The Dutch government has also extended its lockdown, while Poland's Finance Minister remains optimistic about the impact of the vaccine.

site_title: San Francisco office vacancy rate eclipses 2008 financial-crisis high: Cushman
summary: San Francisco's office vacancy rate reached 16.7% at the end of 2020, surpassing the 2008 financial crisis high of 15.1%. The surge is driven by record sublease space and a halt in new leasing, with tech companies like Pinterest and Oracle relocating from the area. A recovery is expected as vaccination rates rise and employees return to the office, with early signs of a rebound from Cushman & Wakefield clients. Employment in office-based industries has been gaining ground since 2020's low.

site_title: Renault CEO to unveil plan to dig French carmaker out of a rut
summary: Renault CEO Luca de Meo will unveil his "Renaulution" turnaround plan, aimed at stemming record losses at the French automaker. The strategy focuses on cost cuts, shrinking the product range, and shifting to more profitable markets, including SUVs and electric vehicles. The plan also includes eliminating 14,600 jobs and reducing production capacity by a fifth. De Meo aims to rebuild Renault around four pillars: its namesake division, Dacia, Alpine, and new mobility. The plan is expected to balance the company's urgency with concerns from the French government on local jobs.

site_title: New Vietnamese leaders will face twin challenges
summary: Vietnam's new leaders face twin challenges: managing relations with the incoming Biden administration and seeking US support against aggressive Chinese behavior in the South China Sea. The country's communist party congress, starting January 26, will select a new general secretary, prime minister, president, and national assembly chair, with the current prime minister, Nguyen Xuan Phuc, seen as the best candidate for the general secretary position. The new leadership must balance trade relations with the US, which has imposed duties on Vietnamese cars and truck tires, and navigate China's expansionist militarization of the South China Sea, while also seeking to deepen bilateral engagement with the US.

site_title: 'Uncle Roger' comedian ignites China censorship row with deleted video
summary: UK-based comedian Nigel Ng, known for his "Uncle Roger" character, sparked a censorship row in China after apologizing to Chinese fans and removing a video featuring fellow YouTuber Mike Chen, who had criticized Beijing. The video, which had racked up over 20 million views, was deleted due to Mr. Chen's past criticisms of China. The incident highlights China's growing influence over digital content creators, even those on platforms inaccessible in the mainland. Mr. Ng's Weibo account has been relatively small compared to his YouTube following.

site_title: AmBank, CGS-CIMB 'neutral' on glovemaking sector
summary: AmBank and CGS-CIMB have maintained a "neutral" stance on the glove sector, citing that valuations are already reflected in earnings outlooks. AmBank forecasts Top Glove's net profit to be RM2.9 billion for FY21, while CGS-CIMB expects UG Healthcare to report a net profit of S$30 million for Q2 FY21. Despite strong fundamentals, the brokers advise investors to accumulate at lower levels due to limited upside at current share prices.

images.alt_text: AmBank has a fair-value estimate of RM6.50 for Top Glove Corporation. The company's shares closed at RM6.63 on Bursa Malaysia, down RM0.05. Above: A production line in its Selangor factory.

site_title: CCCS reiterates rules to Grab and Gojek after Uber's S$6.58m fine is upheld
summary: The Competition Appeal Board (CAB) has upheld a S$6.58 million fine against Uber for its 2018 merger with Grab, finding that the deal substantially lessened competition in Singapore's ride-hailing sector. The fine was initially imposed by the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) in 2018. The CCCS has also reiterated that it will monitor any potential merger between Grab and Gojek, and will take action if it finds the deal to be anti-competitive. Uber will review the ruling, and Grab did not contest the decision and paid a S$6.42 million penalty.

site_title: YouTube removes Trump content, blocks new uploads for a week
summary: YouTube removed new content from US President Donald Trump's channel due to concerns about potential violence following the US Capitol riot. Trump's channel has its first strike, barring new uploads for at least seven days, and comments are indefinitely disabled. This decision comes after other social media platforms, including Twitter and Facebook, have suspended Trump's account. The move aims to balance free speech with safety considerations following the violent riot.

site_title: Is it time to have a central depository for cash?
summary: A letter to the editor questions the need for a central depository for cash in Singapore, given the country's strong banking sector. Despite the global economy's recovery from the Covid-19 shock, banks have become risk-averse and cut back on lending. The three local banks, however, are making billions in profits, with net interest margins under 2%. The writer suggests that the banks' ability to price loans based on borrower risks, while hedged against government guarantees, allows them to maintain profitability.

site_title: Global investors call for end to crisis involving marooned seafarers
summary: Global investors, representing over $2 trillion in assets, have called for an end to the crisis involving hundreds of thousands of seafarers stuck on ships due to Covid-19. The situation is affecting supply chains and creating bigger risks every day. The UN General Assembly has urged countries to designate seafarers as key workers, and investors are warning that if nothing is done, it could lead to a major supply chain risk for companies. The investor group is also pushing for seafarers to have their rights and interests represented to lower operational risks.

site_title: US companies are aghast at Trump, but for how long?
summary: US companies are distancing themselves from President Donald Trump after the violent attack on the Capitol. Many corporations, including Marriott, Dow, American Express, and Morgan Stanley, have halted donations to lawmakers who opposed the presidential election result. Even Blackstone co-founder Steve Schwarzman has severed ties with Trump, citing the need for a peaceful transition of power. However, the sincerity of these actions is questioned, as some see the move as a convenient timing before the next election cycle.

site_title: Australians head to sea cliffs for rope jumping
summary: A group of friends in eastern New South Wales, Australia, have gathered on a 60-meter cliff to perform rope jumping, a stomach-churning activity that involves free-falling towards the ocean while tied to a rope. The sport, which combines elements of bungee jumping and abseiling, has gained popularity in recent years. Participants, including 24-year-old Daisy Allen, experience an exhilarating rush of adrenaline as they free-fall and are then hauled back up the cliff by their friends. The event showcases the trust and camaraderie among the group, who describe it as an "informal tribe."

site_title: Returning to office with confidence: Siemens turns to technology
summary: Siemens President Ruth Gratzke is leading a "Return with Confidence" campaign to create safe and healthy indoor office environments as companies worldwide return to work post-lockdown. The campaign uses technology to minimize touchpoints, promote social distancing, and improve air quality. Gratzke emphasizes the importance of balancing work and personal life, citing her own experience as a home educator and president. She advises young job seekers to be confident and aggressive in their job search, and recommends the book "The Other Kind of Smart" by Harvey Deutschendorf for its emphasis on EQ and listening skills.

site_title: Amazon starts 89 rupee-a-month mobile video plan to target India's millions
summary: Amazon has launched a 89-rupee-a-month mobile video plan in India, its first standalone Prime Video plan, targeting the country's 85% mobile internet users. The plan offers 6GB of data and comes with a 30-day free trial. This move aims to democratize access to content and reach hundreds of millions of users in India, a key market for Amazon's streaming services.

images.alt_text: In the next few years, India will have as many streaming-service users as TV viewers, and that calls for innovation on the product and distribution fronts, said Amazon's Gaurav Gandhi.

site_title: Wave of regional buyers expected to land on Sentosa Cove
summary: A wave of regional buyers is expected to enter Singapore's Sentosa Cove market, driven by eased travel restrictions and the easing of entry requirements for foreign buyers. Agents anticipate a surge in demand from Southeast Asian and Indian buyers, with some already in Singapore seeking permission to enter for medical treatment or property viewings. Sentosa Cove's waterfront appeal and lower prices compared to its peak in 2010-2012 are key draws for buyers. The area's unique ambiance and tranquil setting are expected to continue attracting buyers, with a modest upside in prices anticipated for 2021.

images.alt_text: Shincee Leonardi, wife of OUE chairman Stephen Riady, is believed to be selling a pair of adjacent bungalows along Ocean Drive on Sentosa for mid-S$40 million.

site_title: Citi's Asia consumer banking head returns to US in leadership shuffle
summary: Citi is appointing Gonzalo Luchetti as the new head of its consumer banking unit for Asia-Pacific and EMEA, effective February 1. Luchetti, a 14-year Citi veteran, returns to the US after successfully running the business since 2018, driving strong performance despite the Covid-19 crisis. He succeeds Anand Selva, who is now global consumer banking head, and Jane Fraser, who will become CEO. Luchetti's leadership will focus on career development and broadening experience, with a thorough search for his replacement to begin immediately.

site_title: China to import more Indonesian products
summary: China plans to import more Indonesian products and increase investment in the country, aiming for a more balanced trade. The decision comes after Indonesia's trade deficit with China decreased to $7 billion in 2020, down from $15.4 billion in 2019. Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi urged China to remove trade barriers for top products such as palm oil and bird's nest to address the trade imbalance. China also agreed to a study on the Lambakan dam project in East Kalimantan and supported Indonesia's plan to become a regional vaccine production hub.

site_title: Sterling hits 7-week high against euro
summary: The British pound reached a 7-week high against the euro, rising 0.4% to 88.97 pence, after Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey expressed concerns over cutting interest rates below zero. This move was seen as a spillover from previous comments and is attributed to investors shifting their expectations of negative rates from May to June. The pound also rose 0.2% against the US dollar to a 9-day high at US$1.3697, with analysts predicting a more pronounced GBP upside for the year.

site_title: Despite pandemic, total 2020 new home sales may match 2019's
summary: Singapore's new home sales in 2020 may match 2019's total, with a preliminary tally of around 10,000 units sold, despite the country's worst recession due to the pandemic. Developers sold 1,217 new homes in December, a 60% increase from November, driven by low interest rates. The market's resilience is attributed to cash-flush buyers, including en-bloc millionaires, who have benefited from "wealth creation" over the past few years.

site_title: Intel CEO Bob Swan replaced by VMWare's Pat Gelsinger
summary: Intel CEO Bob Swan is stepping down on February 15, 2021, and will be replaced by Pat Gelsinger, head of VMWare. The move comes after pressure from activist investor Dan Loeb to explore strategic alternatives for the company, including a possible breakup and sale of assets. Intel shares jumped 13% following the announcement, amid challenges such as delays in chip fabrication and talks with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Samsung Electronics.

site_title: US: Stocks flat amid Trump impeachment debate
summary: US stocks were flat early Wednesday, with Intel rising 10% after naming new CEO Pat Gelsinger. Investors monitored a Capitol Hill debate on impeaching President Donald Trump amid the siege of the US Capitol by Trump supporters. Despite Democratic leaders' plan to hold a vote on impeaching Trump, the market showed little reaction. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down slightly, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index remained unchanged.

site_title: How Vogue's Kamala Harris cover created an uproar
summary: Vogue's cover photo of US Vice President-elect Kamala Harris sparked controversy, with many criticizing the dark, unflattering image. The magazine initially released a more formal portrait, leading to accusations of bad faith. However, sources close to the arrangement revealed that both scenarios had been agreed upon in advance. The magazine claimed the informal image captured Harris' authentic nature, but critics argued it was insensitive given the country's current crisis and Harris' historic status as the first Black female VP. The controversy highlights the complex role of fashion in shaping public perception of female leaders.

site_title: Emotions run high as US House begins debate on impeaching Trump
summary: The US House of Representatives began debating impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump, with at least five Republicans joining Democrats in voting to charge him with inciting an insurrection. The move comes just seven days before Trump's term ends and President-elect Joe Biden is set to take office. If the House approves the impeachment charge, a trial in the Republican-controlled Senate will be held, potentially setting a precedent for Trump's removal from office.

site_title: Hong Kong tracker fund makes U-turn on China investments
summary: Hong Kong's Tracker Fund of Hong Kong (TraHK) has reversed its decision to stop investing in US-listed companies linked to China's military, citing the US ban on American investors in these firms. The fund, with $14 billion in assets, had initially complied with the order but now plans to resume investments in sanctioned entities from January 14. The U-turn highlights the challenges faced by international firms in Hong Kong amid escalating tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Lagarde confident of eurozone's 2021 outlook despite virus surge
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde expressed confidence in the eurozone's 2021 economic recovery despite the resurgence of COVID-19 cases and vaccination challenges. The ECB's forecast of 3.9% economic growth in 2021 remains plausible, according to Lagarde, who noted that lockdown measures until the end of the first quarter are crucial for the forecast. However, she warned that extending shutdowns beyond March would be a concern. Lagarde welcomed the EU's 750 billion euro recovery fund and emphasized the need for continued fiscal policy support.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia committed to free flow of goods
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have reaffirmed their commitment to maintaining a free flow of goods across the Causeway despite the recent movement control order in Malaysia. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated that Singapore's supply chain is resilient and has continued to function without disruptions, with diversification efforts and stockpiles in place. The government is monitoring the situation closely, reviewing supply chain resilience daily, and preparing for potential disruptions globally due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Worker from India with Covid-19 is first dormitory case in Singapore since Dec 15
summary: A worker from India, who arrived in Singapore on December 11, 2020, has tested positive for Covid-19 after a routine test on January 12, marking the first locally transmitted case in a dormitory since December 15, 2020. The individual, a work permit holder, had previously tested negative on December 21 and December 27. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has classified the case as locally transmitted while conducting further epidemiological investigations.

site_title: Port of Singapore container throughput dips 0.9% in 2020
summary: The Port of Singapore's container throughput decreased by 0.9% in 2020, with 36.9 million twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) passing through. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the container throughput remained stable, according to the Maritime and Port Authority (MPA).

site_title: Google to pause all political ads from Jan 14
summary: Google will pause all political ads on its platforms starting Jan 14, following the US Capitol violence, until at least Jan 21. This decision comes ahead of the presidential inauguration. The move, which also includes ads referencing impeachment, protests, or the inauguration, is part of Google's "Sensitive Event" policy. The pause, similar to Facebook's, aims to curb misinformation and prevent hate or violence. Advertisers will not be exempt for news or merchandise ads.

site_title: China parties lead foreign buyers of Sentosa Cove villas
summary: Foreign buyers from China were the largest group of foreign buyers of villas in Sentosa Cove last year, comprising a mix of young professionals and ultra-high net worth individuals. Many of these buyers were not Singapore permanent residents, paying 20% additional buyer's stamp duty. Some have settled in Singapore, invested in local businesses, and set up their own enterprises. The largest transaction was a S$16.5 million villa purchased by the family of Chinese tycoon Zhou Haijiang, which was sold by Oxley Holdings boss Ching Chiat Kwong.

site_title: Driving sustainability, helping needy among top concerns at pre-Budget dialogue
summary: Singaporean youths at a pre-Budget 2021 dialogue emphasized the need for environmental and sustainability initiatives while addressing the vulnerable in society. Minister Indranee Rajah noted that sustainability can be a potential growth area, while Minister Alvin Tan highlighted emerging opportunities in the agri-tech sector. Participants also expressed concerns about the future of work, mental well-being, and welfare dependency, with a desire to have their opinions heard. The dialogue aimed to provide input to the government ahead of the Budget 2021 unveiling on February 16.

site_title: EU clears LSE acquisition of Refinitiv, subject to conditions
summary: The European Union has cleared the London Stock Exchange's (LSE) $27 billion acquisition of Refinitiv, subject to conditions. The LSE must sell its 99.9% stake in Borsa Italiana and provide access to its venue data, FTSE UK Equity Indices, and WM/R FX benchmarks to competitors for 10 years. The European Commission stated that the commitments address competition concerns, concluding that the transaction would no longer raise concerns.

site_title: China to import more Indonesian products to balance trade
summary: China plans to import more Indonesian products and increase investment in the country to balance trade, according to a top Chinese diplomat. The move comes as Indonesia seeks to address its large trade deficit with China, which has shrunk to $7 billion from $15.4 billion in 2019. Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi urged China to remove trade barriers for key products like palm oil and bird's nest. China and Indonesia also agreed to collaborate on infrastructure projects, including a $400 million dam project in East Kalimantan.

site_title: Malaysian PM has one last shot to control worsening Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Malaysia declares a national emergency to curb the worsening Covid-19 pandemic, allowing Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to extend lockdown measures and suspend parliament until August 1. The move aims to control the pandemic and cement Muhyiddin's position, despite his leadership being under threat. The emergency measure, not seen in over half a century, will hold off calls for elections and provide Muhyiddin with a wide window to address the crisis.

site_title: Arty experiences online and offline
summary: Singapore Art Week is set to take place, featuring over 300 artists with their works displayed both online and offline. The event aims to spread creative joy across the island. Meanwhile, the pandemic led to a shift towards online workshops, which continue to be popular, allowing individuals to learn from the comfort of their own homes.

site_title: Singapore Environment Council honours 12 companies for their efforts to go green
summary: The Singapore Environment Council (SEC) has awarded 12 companies with the GreenDNA Certification for their efforts to adopt green practices. The certification aims to recognize companies that have set measurable goals to reduce carbon emissions, water efficiency, and waste management. Recipients include ComfortDelGro, DBS Bank, and City Developments Limited, who have implemented initiatives such as converting taxis to hybrid models and establishing sustainable sourcing principles. The SEC aims to achieve a 36% carbon intensity reduction by 2030 through this certification.

site_title: Ship insurers primed to raise rates after Red Sea attacks
summary: Ship insurers are set to raise rates for merchant ships traveling through the Red Sea due to increased concerns over attacks by militia groups. The US administration's designation of Yemen's Houthi movement as a foreign terrorist organization has heightened the risk. Insurers will increase premiums for vessels entering the Red Sea, particularly those making port calls in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Annual war-risk cover and "breach" premiums will be higher, calculated according to the ship's value. The increased costs will impact vessels traveling through the Red Sea, a key waterway for oil and commodity transportation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore and Malaysia reaffirmed their commitment to maintaining supply chains across the Causeway, with Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stating the country's supply chain is resilient to potential disruptions.

site_title: GL posts H1 net loss of US$19.8m as Covid-19 pandemic closes British hotels
summary: GL, a British hotel operator, reported a net loss of US$19.8 million in the first half of 2021, down from a profit of US$26.9 million in the same period last year, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its British hotels. Revenue fell 89.9% to US$19.5 million, with the group expecting a difficult operating environment for its UK hotels this year.

site_title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with US$1.4b deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm acquires Nuvia, a chip startup founded by Apple veterans, for $1.4 billion. Nuvia's custom CPU core design will be used in smartphones, laptops, and automotive processors. The deal aims to reestablish Qualcomm's leading position in chip performance and reduce its reliance on Arm. Nuvia's technology will also empower Microsoft's customers across the Windows ecosystem, according to Microsoft's chief product officer. The acquisition marks a significant push by Qualcomm to compete with Apple and Intel in the chip market.

site_title: EU watchdog says some banks trying to circumvent rules after Brexit
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has found that some non-EU banks are attempting to circumvent rules on offering investment services to EU customers by using reverse solicitation tactics, where products or services are marketed at the client's initiative. This practice emerged after the UK transition period ended on December 31, 2020.

site_title: GKE Corp H1 net profit more than trebles to S$6.52m
summary: GKE Corp, a logistics provider, reported a 3.6-fold increase in its first-half net profit to S$6.52 million, driven by a production ramp-up in China and higher average selling prices for ready-mixed concrete. Revenue rose 9.2% to S$60.1 million. The company expects a boost from growing urbanization in China, but warned that Covid-19 disruptions to international trade could impact its port logistics and support services. No dividend was recommended.

site_title: Covid-19: More than 6,200 vaccinated in Singapore so far
summary: Singapore's nationwide Covid-19 vaccination drive has administered over 6,200 doses since its launch on December 30. Eight vaccination centers will be operational by the end of February, including two at Changi Airport Terminal 4 and Raffles City Convention Centre. The vaccination program aims to further reopen activities in the community and economy, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong urging Singaporeans to get vaccinated when their turn comes. The program is expected to have enough vaccines to vaccinate everyone by the third quarter of this year.

site_title: Social element of ESG growing in importance, impact on returns
summary: Market returns are stronger for companies with better social practices, according to new research from Federated Hermes. Companies with good or improving social practices can potentially deliver up to 17 basis points more in returns each month, up from 15 bps in 2018. The research highlights the growing importance of the social element of ESG, particularly in how companies treat employees, customers, and suppliers.

site_title: US core consumer-price gauge cooled slightly from previous month
summary: The US core consumer-price gauge cooled slightly in December, increasing 0.1% from the previous month, as labor market slack and muted demand kept inflation pressures tame. The core CPI rose 1.6% from a year earlier, below the Federal Reserve's goal. Demand is gradually picking up, and widespread vaccinations and fiscal stimulus may generate pricing power in the coming months, with most economists expecting relatively tame inflation this year.

site_title: Thailand's opposition, protesters stay out of new reconciliation panel
summary: Thailand's newly formed reconciliation panel, comprising politicians from the ruling coalition and military-appointed senators, has excluded opposition parties and protest groups, despite initial openness to their participation. The 11-member panel will focus on resolving issues raised by anti-government protesters, who demand the government's resignation and a rewriting of the military-backed constitution. The opposition can still join at any time, according to House Speaker Chuan Leekpai, amid ongoing efforts to reduce conflict in the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 24.65 points to 1,636.69 on Wednesday, with 950 gainers outweighing 308 losers. The market saw a volume of 7.123 billion lots worth RM5.105 billion.

site_title: Japan expands state of emergency
summary: Japan expanded its state of emergency to seven more prefectures amid a steady rise in Covid-19 cases, with the total now covering 55% of the population. The move comes as public opinion polls show a majority opposing the Summer Olympics, set for July 23 to August 8. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's approval ratings have fallen, with 40% disapproving, and experts predict the state of emergency will likely not be lifted until March. Japan's coronavirus cases have topped 300,000 and the death toll has reached 4,187.

site_title: RHB Investment Bank CEO set to join billionaire Kuok's group
summary: RHB Investment Bank's CEO, Robert Huray, is set to join billionaire Robert Kuok's Kuok Group in Singapore as regional managing director in March. Huray will leave RHB Investment Bank in February, overseeing the conglomerate's investments in South-east Asia. Kuok Group, a multinational conglomerate with operations across six continents, will benefit from Huray's experience in investment banking. Huray, who previously worked at Credit Suisse Group and Citigroup, will bring his expertise to the role, further expanding Kuok Group's presence in the region.

site_title: US cancels UN envoy's trip to Taiwan, citing Biden transition
summary: The US State Department has cancelled all travel this week, including a planned visit to Taiwan by US Ambassador to the UN Kelly Craft, due to the transition to the incoming Biden administration. China had warned against the trip, citing concerns over US support for Taiwan. The cancellation comes amid strained Sino-US ties, with the Trump administration's support for Taiwan being a point of contention. Taiwan's government expressed "understanding and respect" for the decision, but welcomed Ambassador Craft to visit in the future.

site_title: DHL owner Deutsche Post boosts profit as virus spurs demand
summary: Deutsche Post, the owner of DHL, reported record earnings of 4.84 billion euros in 2020, exceeding analyst forecasts. The surge in home shopping during the coronavirus crisis drove the growth, with record cash flow enabling the company to invest in future growth. CEO Melanie Kreis predicted further gains in profit this year and next, citing the perfect finish to the year. The company's DHL arm benefited significantly from the increased demand.

site_title: Sea acquires Indonesian bank to gain foothold in financial tech
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based tech startup, has acquired Indonesian bank Bank Kesejahteraan Ekonomi (Bank BKE) to gain a foothold in financial technology. The acquisition accelerates Sea's ambition to establish itself as a leader in the region's digital banking arena. Sea raised $3 billion in a stock offering to fund business expansion, including its plans to launch a digital bank in Singapore. This move follows similar investments by rival companies Gojek and Grab Holdings, highlighting the growing competition in the region's digital banking sector.

site_title: High Street Plaza near Singapore River launched for collective sale at S$239m
summary: High Street Plaza, a 11-storey mixed-use tower in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale at a reserve price of S$239 million. The 999-year leasehold building, completed in the 1970s, offers developers the opportunity to redevelop the site, which is currently zoned for commercial use. The site's proximity to key landmarks and the Singapore River is expected to boost its value, with ERA Realty Network noting its potential for rejuvenation and redevelopment. The tender closes on February 24.

site_title: Uber appeal against CCCS decision dismissed, S$6.58m fine upheld
summary: Uber's appeal against the Competition Appeal Board's (CAB) decision to uphold a S$6.58 million fine for its 2018 merger with Grab has been dismissed. The fine was originally imposed by the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) in 2018, finding the merger led to a "substantial lessening of competition" in Singapore's ride-hailing sector. Uber will now pay the fine, as well as CCCS' costs, and the watchdog has reiterated its ability to take action against potential Grab-Gojek merger, which it is "actively monitoring."

site_title: Singapore container throughput dips 0.9% in 2020, with port staying open amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's container throughput decreased 0.9% to 36.9 million Twenty-foot Equivalent Units (TEUs) in 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Vessel arrival tonnage rose 1.7% to a record 2.9 billion gross tonnes. Cargo throughput fell 5.8% to 590.3 million tonnes, primarily due to a decline in oil cargo volumes. The Maritime and Port Authority attributed this to global supply-chain disruptions. The government will continue to support the maritime industry, prioritizing stability, rule of law, and pro-business policies to maintain Singapore as a trusted maritime hub.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hesitant at open
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index at 6,757.08 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 at 13,903.38 points, and Paris' CAC 40 at 5,647.62 points. The hesitation is attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Fewer COEs in Feb-April quota
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority has announced a 12.8% decrease in certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three-month quota period, starting February, with an average of 4,241 COEs per month. This includes a 30.5% drop in commercial vehicle COEs, a 3.2% increase in motorcycle COEs, and 12.2% fewer COEs overall. Fewer COEs typically lead to higher premiums, but the uncertain economic outlook may temper prices in the long term.

site_title: iPhone assembler Foxconn sets up auto arm as Apple car looms
summary: Foxconn Technology Group, Apple's Taiwanese manufacturing partner, is setting up an auto arm to provide production and consulting services to global automotive companies. The move comes as Apple considers making its own electric vehicles, with development work expected to take at least half a decade. Foxconn has already unveiled its first EV chassis and software platform, and plans to deliver its first development kit in April. The company is also expanding a plant to develop automotive metal parts and has signed a manufacturing deal with Chinese electric-vehicle startup Byton.

site_title: STI reverses loss to end 0.01% higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.01% higher at 2,977.51, snapping a two-day losing streak, following overnight US stock gains. The top performers were Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Singapore Airlines, while Thai Beverage was the worst performer. Asian markets were mixed, with China's markets closing lower due to a resurgence of coronavirus cases.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde confident on outlook despite virus surge
summary: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde expressed confidence in the eurozone's 2021 recovery despite a surge in COVID-19 cases and challenges in vaccination programs. The ECB's forecast for 3.9% economic growth in 2021 remains "very clearly plausible," Lagarde said. This forecast follows a 7.3% decline in 2020, and Lagarde has no reasons to believe the forecast is incorrect. The ECB's outlook suggests a strong recovery for the eurozone in 2021.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher on Fed policy support hopes, chip shares
summary: South Korean shares closed higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of continued policy support from the Federal Reserve to the US economy. The Kospi index rose 0.71% to 3,148.29, with chipmakers SK Hynix and Samsung Electro-Mechanics leading the gains. Foreigners bought 193.8 billion won worth of shares, and the won rose against the dollar. The US economy is expected to see a strong rebound in the second half of the year, with monetary policy remaining accommodative despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Amazon starts 89 rupee mobile video plan to target India's millions
summary: Amazon has launched a 89 rupee mobile video plan in India, targeting the country's millions of smartphone users. The single-user plan comes with 6 gigabytes of data and is available to Bharti Airtel's prepaid customers after a 30-day free trial. This move aims to democratize access to content and reach hundreds of millions of users, with Amazon already having customers in over 4,300 cities and towns. The streaming service is part of Amazon's expansion in India, where the online-video market is expected to grow to $4.5 billion over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com is starting its first mobile-only Prime Video plan, targeting the hundreds of millions of entertainment-hungry smartphone users in India as the country's streaming market surges.

site_title: AirAsia's digital platform eyes more airline partnerships
summary: AirAsia Group's digital platform, airasia.com, is in talks with several Middle Eastern and European airlines to sell flights on its online platform. The company's CEO, Karen Chan, stated that airasia.com is now selling any airline's flights, not just AirAsia tickets. Discussions are underway with Middle Eastern airlines to drive traffic to pilgrimage destinations and with European airlines once international borders open. This move aims to capitalize on pent-up demand after the COVID-19 pandemic hit the airline industry.

images.alt_text: Malaysian budget carrier AirAsia Group's travel, e-commerce and fintech unit airasia.com is in partnership talks with several Middle Eastern and European airlines.

site_title: Taiwan central bank seeks 'moral persuasion' to slow currency surge: sources
summary: Taiwan's central bank has asked custodian banks to exercise restraint in foreign exchange trades to slow the country's currency surge, which reached a 23-1/2-year high in January. The Taiwan dollar's 5.6% gain against the US dollar last year has made exports less competitive, and the government is wary of intervening too heavily to avoid being labeled a currency manipulator by the US. The central bank hopes to alleviate pressure on US dollar sales by spreading out foreign exchange transactions, a tactic known as "moral persuasion."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with losses, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.15% to 28,235.60. The declines were driven by profit-takers following a recent rally, while concerns over the virus offset hopes for US stimulus. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with the latter dropping 1.08%. The losses followed a strong rally in the region, with stocks having reached new highs in recent days.

site_title: HSBC grooms top bankers for make-or-break push into China
summary: HSBC is grooming top bankers to lead its expansion in China, a crucial market for the bank's future. David Liao and Mark Yunfeng Wang, heads of Asia Pacific and China operations, are among contenders to succeed Peter Wong, the current top Asia executive. HSBC is seeking a leader to navigate its fraught relationship with Beijing and drive growth in the mainland and Hong Kong markets. The informal search aims to identify a successor for Wong, who will retire in the coming months.

site_title: SPH Reit Q1 DPU down 13% to 1.2 Singapore cents
summary: SPH Reit has reported a 13% decline in its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.2 Singapore cents, down from 1.38 cents in the previous year. Despite a 10.8% year-over-year increase in gross revenue to S$66.6 million, the decline was attributed to rental relief for tenants affected by the Covid-19 pandemic in Singapore. Meanwhile, tenant sales in Australia are recovering steadily to near pre-Covid-19 levels. The Reit's debt stood at S$1.3 billion as of November 2020, with refinancing and revolving credit facilities available.

site_title: Carrefour shares surge 10% after Couche-Tard merger approach
summary: Carrefour shares surged 10% after Canadian convenience-store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard initiated exploratory talks on a potential merger transaction. The move follows consolidation in the European and French supermarket sectors as competition from online rivals intensifies. However, analysts questioned whether the potential deal would lead to synergies between the two groups. Carrefour described the approach as "friendly" and talks are preliminary. The company has reported a robust third-quarter performance and launched a five-year overhaul plan to cut costs and boost e-commerce investment.

site_title: 38 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including a migrant worker
summary: Singapore reported 38 new Covid-19 cases, including one migrant worker, as of noon on Wednesday. The total cases now stand at 58,984. The cases include imported cases who were placed on stay-home notices or isolated on arrival.

site_title: Six injured by leak at LG Display plant in South Korea
summary: Six workers were injured in a chemical leak at LG Display's factory in South Korea on Wednesday. The incident occurred at the company's plant in Paju, 55 km north of Seoul. LG Display is investigating the cause of the accident and has not commented on production or injuries. The company supplies mobile displays to Apple.

site_title: Citi's Asia consumer banking head returns to US in leadership shuffle
summary: Citi appoints Gonzalo Luchetti as its new head of consumer banking for Asia-Pacific and EMEA, effective February 1. Luchetti, a 14-year Citi veteran, returns to the US after successfully leading the region's consumer banking business since 2018, driving strong performance and profitability despite the Covid-19 crisis. He succeeds Anand Selva, who was promoted to global consumer banking head, and will oversee a thorough search for a new regional head. Luchetti's focus on client satisfaction has been credited with driving growth and reducing complaints in the region.

site_title: Asean electronics companies still lag China in climbing global value chain: report
summary: Asean electronics companies remain behind China in the global value chain, according to a report by ANZ. Despite the Asean Quad's presence in niche segments, the region's electronics companies account for only 1% of Asian electronics revenues. Challenges include an uncompetitive business environment in the Philippines, reliance on low-wage workers in Malaysia, and underdeveloped infrastructure in Vietnam. China dominates with 23% of Asian electronics revenues, while Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan contribute 74%. The report suggests that China's focus on cutting-edge technology could create opportunities for other Asian economies to expand in lower-value activities.

site_title: Indonesia president says vaccine will help stop virus spread, support economy
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo emphasized the importance of the country's mass Covid-19 vaccination programme, stating it will help stop the spread of coronavirus and accelerate economic recovery. The immunisation drive using the CoronaVac vaccine from China's Sinovac Biotech will start immediately in regions across the country.

site_title: Britain's Asos raises profit view after strong Christmas sales
summary: British online fashion retailer Asos raised its profit view after strong Christmas sales, surpassing market forecasts. Group retail sales rose 23% over the four months to Dec 31, driven by strong demand during Covid-19 lockdowns. Asos' active customer base increased by 1.1 million to 24.5 million. However, gross margin fell 90 basis points due to changes in product mix and increased freight costs. The company expects a full-year profit at the top end of market forecasts.

site_title: Vietnam mobile wallet MoMo raises about US$100 million, aims for IPO
summary: Vietnam's e-wallet company MoMo has raised approximately US$100 million from six global investors, including Warburg Pincus, to become a "super-app" and go public by 2025. The company, Vietnam's largest e-wallet by users, aims to double its users to 50 million in the next two years. The funding will support the growth of MoMo as an all-in-one smartphone application offering multiple services. The company plans to list on a bourse in the 2021-2025 period, with an initial public offering (IPO) being a key goal.

site_title: How to pick the right travel scheme for business visitors
summary: Singapore's Air Travel Pass (ATP) and Reciprocal Green Lanes (RGL) schemes facilitate business travel from approved countries. Key differences include travel purpose and duration: ATP for any purpose, maximum 90 days, and free application; RGL for business and official reasons, maximum 14 days, and requires a detailed itinerary. Both schemes require health precautions, including PCR tests and isolation periods. Application fees are S$160 for tests and accommodations. ATP applications are due 7-30 days before entry, while RGL applications are due 2-5 weeks before entry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher led by tech shares
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, led by gains in tech shares, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 rising 1.04% to 28,456.59. The Topix index also increased 0.35%. The gains were driven by hopes of sound earnings, with chip-linked and other tech shares rallying.

site_title: SGX names ING's Herry Cho as new head of sustainability and sustainable finance
summary: SGX appoints Herry Cho as managing director and head of sustainability and sustainable finance, effective February 8. Cho, previously head of sustainable finance Asia Pacific at ING, will drive the company's environmental, social, and governance ambitions. She has facilitated over 30 sustainable transactions and spearheaded ING's sustainability strategy in the region. This appointment is part of SGX's efforts to expand its sustainability efforts and develop its SGX First platform, a multi-asset exchange-led sustainability platform.

images.alt_text: Previously the head of sustainable finance Asia Pacific at ING, Ms Cho was responsible for spearheading its sustainability strategy and direction for the region.

site_title: HDB rolls out one-stop portal that lists new flats up for sale
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched a one-stop portal for buying and selling HDB flats, making it easier for homebuyers and sellers to gather information on the purchase or sale of a flat. The portal includes a flat-listing service, financial calculators, and a loan listing service. This is the second phase of the HDB Resale Portal, which has reduced the time needed for resale flat transactions from 16 weeks to around eight weeks. The portal aims to further improve the transaction process for HDB homebuyers and sellers.

site_title: YouTube suspends Trump's channel after violating policy on inciting violence
summary: YouTube has suspended Donald Trump's channel for seven days after it violated policies on inciting violence following the US Capitol assault by his supporters. The incident occurred as Trump's supporters tried to halt the certification of President-elect Joe Biden's election win. The suspension follows similar actions taken by Twitter and Facebook, which removed Trump's accounts and eliminated content supporting the assault. Amazon.com also suspended Parler, a social media platform favored by Trump supporters, from its web hosting service.

site_title: Brokers' take: AmBank maintains 'hold' on glovemakers; CGS-CIMB retains 'add'
summary: AmBank maintains its "hold" stance on glove makers, citing already reflected valuations in earnings outlook. The bank forecasts Top Glove's net profit to be RM2.9 billion for FY21, RM2.7 billion for FY22, and RM1.5 billion for FY23. CGS-CIMB retains "neutral" stance but upgrades Riverstone Holdings to "add" with a target price of S$1.70. The brokerage expects glove ASPs to remain on an uptrend, supporting strong earnings in quarters ahead.

site_title: Lenovo works with CICC on 10b yuan Shanghai listing
summary: Lenovo is working with China International Capital Corp to list in Shanghai through the issuance of Chinese depositary receipts, which could raise approximately 10 billion yuan. Lenovo plans to sell up to 10% of its enlarged share capital and submit a listing application after a shareholders meeting in February. The move aims to attract big technology firms to sell yuan-denominated securities in China, following a trial programme launched by Beijing in 2018. Shares in Lenovo rose 17% in Hong Kong following the announcement.

site_title: Aspen's glovemaking unit secures US$100m in sales for 2021
