summary: Aspen Holdings' subsidiary Aspen Glove has secured a US$100 million sales deal for 2021, agreeing to produce one billion medical grade examination gloves for an unnamed distributor. The distributor has paid a US$2 million cash deposit and will distribute the gloves in the Europe and US markets. This deal is expected to allow Aspen Glove to penetrate new markets and accelerate its expansion plans, with production of additional lines starting from Q3 2021 and Q2 2022.

site_title: Singapore, Kuala Lumpur committed to keep supplies flowing across Causeway
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have reaffirmed their commitment to maintain supply chains across the Causeway, with no disruptions reported despite Kuala Lumpur's state of emergency and movement control order. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing said Singapore has diversified its supply sources, built up stockpiles, and boosted local production to ensure continuity. The resilience of Singapore's supply chains is being reviewed daily, and the country is well-equipped to withstand potential disruptions.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up on stimulus hope but traders still on edge
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for another US virus relief package, despite political uncertainty and surging virus cases. Investors are cautiously optimistic about the prospect of a new stimulus, with top Federal Reserve officials downplaying the likelihood of winding down easy-money policies soon. However, concerns about inflation and potential policy changes weighed on the dollar and US Treasury yields. Most Asian markets were up, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul leading the gains, while Shanghai and Wellington edged down.

site_title: GIC-backed lender Affirm prices IPO above range to raise US$1.2b
summary: Affirm Holdings, a lender that provides installment loans to online shoppers, priced its US$1.2 billion initial public offering (IPO) above its range at US$49 per share, surpassing its marketed range of US$41 to US$44. The San Francisco-based company's fully diluted valuation is about US$15 billion. Founded in 2012 by Max Levchin, Affirm has over 6,500 merchants using its platform, with Peloton Interactive being its largest merchant partner. The IPO marks a significant milestone for the company, which had previously postponed its IPO from December alongside game developer Roblox.

site_title: Indonesia divers search for crashed plane's second black box
summary: Indonesian investigators are hopeful of retrieving the second black box from the wreckage of a Sriwijaya Air Boeing 737-500 that crashed into the Java Sea on Saturday, killing 62 people. The search and rescue operation, which involves over 3,000 personnel, has focused on finding the cockpit voice recorder. The devices contain critical flight data, including speed, altitude, and direction, and are expected to provide clues about the cause of the crash. The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has sent investigators to Jakarta to assist in the investigation.

images.alt_text: Indonesian investigators said on Wednesday they were hopeful of retrieving a crashed passenger jet's second black box, as they seek to explain why the plane with 62 people aboard slammed into the sea minutes after takeoff.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up at open after Wall Street ends higher; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% or 6.47 points to 2,983.64 on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains from Wall Street. Investors took heart over more government stimulus and coronavirus vaccines in 2021, with banking stocks leading the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced less than 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: Walmart, Disney suspend contributions to US lawmakers who opposed Biden certification
summary: Major US companies, including Walmart and Disney, have suspended their donations to lawmakers who opposed President-elect Joe Biden's election certification, citing the recent attack on the US Capitol. Other companies such as AT&T, Amazon, and Mastercard made similar moves. The decision comes after 147 Republicans in the House of Representatives and Senate voted to challenge the election results. The companies' actions aim to reassess their strategy after supporters of outgoing President Donald Trump attacked the Capitol, resulting in five deaths. The impact of this decision remains unclear.

site_title: Australians head to sea cliffs for adrenalin-pumping sport
summary: A group of friends in eastern New South Wales, Australia, have gathered at a cliff to participate in rope jumping, a sport that combines elements of bungee jumping and abseiling. The activity involves free-falling from a 60-meter height while tied to a rope, with the goal of experiencing an exhilarating rush of adrenaline. The rope jumping trend, which originated in the 1990s, has gained popularity in recent years, with some jumpers installing their own ropes on cliffs or skyscrapers. The activity requires trust and faith among participants, who describe it as an "informal tribe."

images.alt_text: Australia's adventure sport enthusiasts are joining the ranks of those heading to the seaside but for a much more stomach-churning activity - rope jumping.

site_title: China sees biggest Covid-19 spike in over five months, four cities in lockdown
summary: China has reported its biggest daily spike in Covid-19 cases in over five months, with 115 new confirmed cases, mostly in Beijing and northeast China's Heilongjiang province. Four cities in lockdown aim to prevent further spread, with over 28 million people under home quarantine. The National Health Commission reported 107 local infections, with Hebei province accounting for 90 cases. China's total confirmed cases now stand at 87,706, and the death toll remains unchanged at 4,634.

site_title: Zoom raises US$1.75b in new stock offering
summary: Zoom Video Communications is raising US$1.75 billion through a stock offering, capitalizing on pandemic demand for its video-conferencing platform. The company is selling 5.15 million shares at US$340 apiece, a 4.7% discount to its last close. The offering is expected to close on or about January 15. JPMorgan Chase & Co is the sole bookrunner for the sale.

site_title: Australia job vacancies recover from pandemic shock to hit record
summary: Australian job vacancies have reached a record high, increasing by 23.4% in the November quarter to 254,400. This surge in vacancies follows a plunge to 129,200 in the May quarter during pandemic lockdowns. The recovery offers hope for the labor market, which saw the jobless rate drop to 6.8% in November. Private sector vacancies rose 24.2%, with the largest gains in arts and recreation, accommodation, and food and retail trade. This uptick in vacancies suggests a continued recovery in the labor market.

site_title: Global investors call for end to seafarers marooned at sea due to coronavirus
summary: A group of leading investors, representing over $2 trillion in assets, has called for an end to the crisis of seafarers being marooned at sea due to the coronavirus pandemic. The situation affects 400,000 merchant sailors, with many at breaking point and exceeding the 11-month limit for working at sea. The investors urge countries to designate seafarers as key workers, enabling their transfer from ships during lockdowns. They warn that the crisis poses a major supply chain risk for companies and could lead to a "humanitarian tragedy" if action is not taken.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.34 points, or 1.08%, to 1,629.38, driven by a higher opening. The market saw 970.75 million lots traded worth RM539.51 million, with 498 gainers surpassing losers 207.

site_title: Gold rises as rally in US dollar, Treasury yields hits brakes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,858.56 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and lower Treasury yields, which made gold cheaper for other unit holders. US President-elect Joe Biden's planned fiscal stimulus also boosted the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields fell to 10-month lows, further supporting gold prices. Silver, platinum, and palladium also saw gains, while silver dipped slightly. The outlook for gold remains constructive, with analysts expecting the metal to continue its upward trend despite potential short-term dips.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Wednesday, influenced by a higher yen and reports of a Japanese government-announced expansion of a virus state of emergency. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.03% and the Topix index slipped 0.21%. The flat opening comes as investors monitor US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: Saudi Aramco seeking US$7.5b loan for oil pipeline investors: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco is seeking a US$7.5 billion loan to fund potential investors in its oil pipelines, according to sources. The company is in talks with lenders to secure favorable terms for the funding package, which could raise about US$10 billion from the sale of a pipeline unit. This is part of Aramco's effort to raise money from leasing rights or stakes in non-core assets, mirroring Abu Dhabi National Oil Co's strategy. The move aims to maintain annual dividend payments of US$75 billion, as the company's gearing has risen to 21.8% due to increased debt.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sunpower, Grand Venture, Tee International, Spackman, Memories
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday include Sunpower, which bought boilers and secured a 25-year steam supply contract, and Grand Venture Technology, which raised S$23.6 million through a conditional placement agreement. Tee International reported a net profit of S$547,000 for the second quarter, reversing a loss in the previous year. Spackman Entertainment Group confirmed its former interim CEO Richard Lee will stay on as a non-executive director. Memories Group is in talks to issue up to US$10 million in convertible loans amid material uncertainty over its going-concern status.

site_title: Bank of Japan to mull cutting this year's growth forecast: Nikkei
summary: The Bank of Japan is considering cutting its economic growth forecast for the current fiscal year due to the impact of state of emergency measures against the coronavirus on consumption. The central bank may revise its forecast for the following year, however, due to robust exports and a government stimulus package. Despite this, many officials are cautious about further stimulus, as it would contradict government efforts to keep citizens home. Japan's economy is at risk of a double-dip recession, with the government considering extending the state of emergency beyond Tokyo.

site_title: Marvel superheroes return... in quirky black-and-white sitcom
summary: Marvel's WandaVision, a quirky black-and-white sitcom, premiered on Disney+ on Friday, marking the start of the Marvel Cinematic Universe's television storyline. The show follows witch Wanda Maximoff and android Vision as they navigate a 1950s suburban life, trading superhero battles for school fundraisers and neighborhood watch meetings. Director Matt Shakman drew inspiration from TV comedies like It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, aiming to create a unique and original series that explores the "why" behind the characters' actions. With a dozen Marvel series in the works for Disney+, WandaVision aims to emulate the success of The Mandalorian, taking bold risks with genre and tone.

site_title: Singapore Airlines launches US dollar debt debut
summary: Singapore Airlines launched its first US dollar bond to fund new aircraft purchases, with a term sheet indicating a minimum of $300 million in funds raised. The five-and-a-half-year deal, priced at the US treasury yield plus 300 basis points, aims to diversify the airline's funding sources. This marks a departure from its traditional issuance of debt in the local currency, as the deal cannot be sold to US investors. The airline expects passenger levels to recover to 25% of pre-Covid levels by the end of March, with a focus on flying to nearly 45% of pre-crisis destinations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly at open on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.12% to 28,309.32. This follows investors monitoring rising virus infections and awaiting news on a new US stimulus bill. In contrast, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose 0.14% and 0.19% respectively. The global market is also watching US-EU trade talks and the impact of US tariff threats on the economy.

site_title: Pence rejects invoking 25th Amendment to oust Trump
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence has rejected invoking the 25th Amendment to remove President Donald Trump from office, effectively setting the stage for an impeachment vote. Pence told House leaders he does not believe invoking the amendment is in the nation's best interest or consistent with the Constitution. This decision comes after Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol, leading to violence and five deaths. Pence had previously certified Joe Biden's election victory, despite intense pressure to invalidate the electoral votes. The House of Representatives is set to vote on a resolution calling for Pence to initiate the 25th Amendment process.

site_title: Reinventing Southeast Asia's retail industry to drive economic recovery
summary: Southeast Asia's retail industry is undergoing a digital transformation to drive economic recovery, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite challenges, many heritage retailers, such as Robinsons, have closed their doors. However, the pandemic has also led to increased investment in digital platforms. The region's largest retailers are shifting focus to e-commerce, with GoTo shares expected to rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off. Experts suggest this shift towards digital retail is a key factor in the industry's recovery.

site_title: UK businesses grapple with Brexit border fallout
summary: UK businesses are struggling with Brexit-related red tape, nearly two weeks after the country's final divorce from the European Union. Increased bureaucracy is slowing the flow of freight, particularly for fresh produce, and causing significant disruption at the border. The trade deal has led to costly and time-consuming paperwork, including customs declarations, regulatory food safety checks, and "rules of origin" levies. The logistics industry is experiencing major headaches, with traffic slowing at the Channel port of Dover, and some companies are shifting freight to eastern English ports or Ireland to bypass the UK.

site_title: Conservation shophouses at Tanjong Pagar, Outram Park up for sale
summary: Several conservation shophouses in Tanjong Pagar and Outram Park have been put on the market, with one three-storey shophouse at 91 Tanjong Pagar Road up for sale via expression of interest for S$10.2 million (S$2,615 per square foot). The shophouse has a land area of 1,292 sq ft and an estimated gross floor area of 3,900 sq ft. This marks the latest in a growing demand for conservation shophouses in the area, with prices expected to continue to rise.

site_title: New Brazil data shows disappointing 50.4% efficacy for China's Sinovac Biotech vaccine
summary: Brazil's Sinovac Biotech vaccine showed a disappointing 50.4% efficacy in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 infections in a trial, falling short of regulatory approval and previous results. Researchers criticized the Brazilian government's handling of the data, which was released in partial form. The vaccine, known as CoronaVac, had previously shown 78% efficacy in a different trial, but the new data included mild cases that did not require clinical assistance. Despite this, public health experts expressed relief that no hospitalizations occurred among vaccinated volunteers, and the vaccine will still help begin the process of overcoming the pandemic.

site_title: Air travellers entering US will need negative Covid test: official
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has announced that all air passengers entering the country will need a negative Covid-19 test within three days of departure, effective January 26. This policy expands on a previous rule targeting Britain, aiming to make travel safer by combining testing with home isolation and precautions like mask-wearing and social distancing.

site_title: Trump's long-favoured banks pull back amid riot fallout
summary: US President Donald Trump's favored banks, Deutsche Bank and Signature Bank, are pulling back from doing business with him amid fallout from the recent Capitol riot. Deutsche Bank will no longer lend to Trump, owing him over $300 million, while Signature Bank has closed two personal accounts holding $5.3 million, citing the need for the president's resignation. Both banks have suspended ties with Trump following his encouragement of rioters at a rally, with Signature Bank stating its decision is in the best interests of the nation and American people.

site_title: Huawei executive asks Canada court to relax bail conditions
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, facing extradition to the US on fraud charges, has asked a Canadian court to relax her bail conditions due to Covid-19 fears. Her husband testified that she is at increased risk from the virus, but government lawyers questioned her sincerity, citing recent public health rule violations. Meng has been in a two-year battle against extradition over charges related to Huawei's relationship with a former Iranian subsidiary.

images.alt_text: On the stand, Huawei chief financial officer Meng Wanzhou's husband Liu Xiaozong testified that Meng is fearful of catching Covid-19 from her security guards, which were ordered by a judge for the duration of her extradition fight.

site_title: WhatsApp stresses privacy as users flock to rivals
summary: WhatsApp has faced backlash over its updated terms, sparking users to flee to rival messaging apps Telegram and Signal. The update, which affects users outside Europe, allows businesses to share data with Facebook for targeted ads. WhatsApp denies that the change affects user privacy, but critics say it compromises data protection. Telegram has seen a surge in new users, with its founder stating that people are seeking a private and secure platform, while Elon Musk has recommended Signal to users.

site_title: Grand Venture Technology inks pact for proposed S$23.6m placement
summary: Grand Venture Technology has entered into a conditional placement agreement to raise S$23.6 million by issuing 71.5 million new shares at S$0.33 each. The placement shares will represent about 23.4% of the firm's enlarged share capital, resulting in a transfer of controlling interest. The agreement was entered into with NT SPV 12, a wholly-owned subsidiary of private equity fund Novo Tellus PE Fund 2.

site_title: Intel's self-driving car unit plans to step up use of its own radar tech by 2025
summary: Intel's self-driving car unit, Mobileye, plans to shift towards using its own radar-based technology by 2025, aiming to lower the cost of autonomous driving. The company will use a single lidar sensor per vehicle, a different approach from competitors. Mobileye's camera-based system is already on the road, gathering data to map roads in new cities. This move is part of the company's strategy to make autonomous driving more affordable.

site_title: Pompeo cancels last foreign trip amid Trump impeachment moves
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo canceled his final foreign trip amid President Donald Trump's second impeachment vote. Pompeo will assist the transition to President-elect Joe Biden, identifying officials to stay temporarily. The trip to Europe was canceled, including a meeting with Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg. The move comes as Democrats push for Vice-President Mike Pence to remove Trump for inciting the US Capitol storming. Pompeo has backed Trump despite condemning the violence.

site_title: Taiwan visit by US's UN ambassador cancelled: official
summary: US UN Ambassador Kelly Craft's trip to Taiwan has been cancelled, following the State Department's decision to cancel international trips ahead of President Joe Biden's inauguration. This move comes after China expressed strong opposition to the trip. The cancellation also mirrors the cancellation of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's final official visit to Europe to ensure a "smooth and orderly" transition.

site_title: US: Stocks gain with oil, airline shares leading
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by gains in petroleum-linked shares, airlines, and retailers, as investors anticipate government stimulus and coronavirus vaccines in 2021. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced less than 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. Petroleum producer Apache surged 11.2%, while United Airlines and Caterpillar also rose. General Motors announced plans to build electric vans, and Walmart gained 1.1% after announcing a fintech startup.

site_title: Renault bets on electric after 2020 sales slump
summary: French auto giant Renault reported a 21.3% drop in 2020 sales to 2.9 million vehicles, amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company unveiled plans to transition to electric- and hydrogen-powered vehicles. Renault aims to recover from a 2020 sales slump and follows Fiat-Chrysler's withdrawal from a potential partnership. The group's roadmap for electric vehicle adoption comes after sales were 14.2% lower overall in the market.

site_title: US Justice Dept expects sedition, conspiracy cases in Capitol attack
summary: US officials expect hundreds of arrests in connection with the January 6 US Capitol storming, with some facing sedition and conspiracy charges. Over 70 cases have already been charged, with the FBI opening 160 case files. The number of cases is expected to grow into the hundreds, according to US Attorney Michael Sherwin.

site_title: 'Global Britain' campaign postponed on Covid-19 resurgence
summary: The UK's "Global Britain" campaign, aimed at showcasing the country's foreign leadership and engagement, has been postponed due to the resurgence of COVID-19 in the UK. Prime Minister Boris Johnson had planned to launch the campaign in January, following the EU-UK trade deal, but now faces challenges in recalibrating its international policy amid a post-Brexit flux in its US and European alliances. Johnson's vision for a "great global trading nation" is uncertain, and his relationship with President-elect Joe Biden has raised concerns about a potential UK-US trade deal.

site_title: Vogue's Wintour defends controversial Kamala Harris cover
summary: Anna Wintour, editor-in-chief of Vogue, has defended a cover photo of Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, which critics say diminishes her achievements and is disrespectful. The photo, taken by Tyler Mitchell, features Harris in casual attire, sparking controversy on social media. Wintour stated that the intention was not to diminish Harris's victory, but rather to showcase her in a joyful and optimistic light, bringing positive change.

site_title: GM takes to skies with flying car concept unveiled at CES
summary: General Motors unveiled a concept for an autonomous air taxi, called the Cadillac brand electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft (eVTOL), at the 2021 Consumer Electronics Show. The single-seat aircraft can travel autonomously up to 90 kmh from rooftop to rooftop, propelled by eight rotors using "next generation battery technology." GM plans to integrate VTOL technology into its vision for a multimodal future. The news comes as GM also unveiled a new BrightDrop brand for electric vans and made other announcements on its plans to ramp up electric-powered vehicles.

site_title: Trial of ex-cop accused of George Floyd killing to begin in March
summary: The trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, charged with murdering George Floyd, will begin on March 8 as scheduled. Chauvin's co-defendants, Alexander Kueng, Thomas Lane, and Tou Thao, will appear separately in late August, despite requests to postpone the trial due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The decision was made by Judge Peter Cahill, citing the impossibility of complying with physical restrictions in a joint trial. The trial is a result of Floyd's death, which sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform.

images.alt_text: The trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin - charged with murdering African American man George Floyd - will begin as scheduled March 8, but his co-defendants will appear separately in late August, a judge ordered in a decision made public on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat despite rise in cyclicals
summary: European stocks closed flat on Tuesday, with cyclicals such as banks, automakers, and oil supporting markets. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.05%, while Germany's DAX and France's CAC showed mixed results. Investors await US earnings season and clarity on fiscal spending plans under President Joe Biden. Cyclicals like oil majors BP and Royal Dutch Shell gained, while defensive sectors like healthcare and utilities checked gains. Companies are expected to report a 26.3% drop in fourth-quarter earnings, but a predicted improvement in earnings for the first two quarters of 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses on Tuesday, STI down 0.23%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.23% on Tuesday, following US stocks' first drop in five sessions, amid investor concerns over valuations and the Covid-19 pandemic. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 6.73 points to 2,977.17. Thai Beverage and CapitaLand were top performers, while Singtel and Singapore Airlines ended lower. DBS Group Research expects some hesitance in the fourth-quarter results season due to resistance towards travel and hospitality stocks.

site_title: Former Trump property aims to be Palm Beach's most expensive ever
summary: A fully furnished spec home in Palm Beach has hit the market for US$140 million, potentially becoming the most expensive real estate transaction in Palm Beach history. The 21,000-square-foot property, built by Trump, has nine bedrooms, 12 baths, and 45.7m of shoreline. The asking price is attributed to the property's newness and ease of moving in, with the record currently held by a 70,000-square-foot home sold in 2019 for US$111 million.

site_title: Sheldon Adelson, founder of Las Vegas Sands, dies at 87
summary: Sheldon Adelson, founder of Las Vegas Sands and one of the world's wealthiest individuals, has died at 87 due to complications from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Adelson built the largest casino company in the world and was a major Republican donor, contributing over $218 million to candidates and groups in 2020. He also used his wealth to support conservative causes and advocate for Israel, including offering to underwrite the cost of relocating the US embassy in Jerusalem. Adelson's net worth was approximately $33 billion, and he controlled more than half of Las Vegas Sands' shares.

site_title: Clients' liquidity, viability top worries for audit committees: poll
summary: Audit committees at Singapore-listed companies are concerned about clients' liquidity and viability, alongside impairment of asset values and internal controls risks, following the COVID-19 pandemic. A poll found that 48% of respondents cited going concern and liquidity as their top worry, as companies shifted focus to short-term survival. The study also highlighted the need for directors to increase skills, knowledge, and experiences when appointing new independent directors, with the introduction of new listing rules aimed at strengthening diversity and independence.

site_title: Half of women put off by macho language in job advertisments in Britain
summary: A study in Britain found that biased language in job advertisements deters nearly half of women from applying. Openreach's study, which involved 2,000 women, showed that changes to language increased interest in an engineering job by over 200%. Women were put off by phrases like "being on the road in your van" and "getting your hands dirty", which were deemed macho. The findings highlight the need to attract more women to male-dominated sectors, with Openreach suggesting a more inclusive approach to job adverts.

site_title: Tilting towards value equities in 2021
summary: A bullish outlook for global equities in 2021 is maintained by Standard Chartered Bank's Chief Investment Officer, citing three key factors: economic growth, inflation expectations, and bond yields. Stronger economic growth and rising inflation expectations would support Value equities, while subdued inflation and bond yields could still lead to outperformance. Value stocks, which underperformed in 2020, are expected to benefit from being unloved and under-owned, and may outperform Growth stocks in 2021.

site_title: Ford to close Brazil manufacturing operations after more than a century
summary: Ford Motor Co. is ceasing manufacturing operations in Brazil after over 100 years, resulting in the elimination of 5,000 jobs and a $4.1 billion charge. The decision will end sales of three locally made models: the Ecosport, Ka, and T4, with two factories closing immediately and a third by the end of the year. The job losses primarily affect Brazilian workers but also include those in Argentina.

site_title: Thailand unveils 210 billion-baht stimulus to counter virus impact
summary: Thailand has unveiled a 210 billion-baht (S$9.25 billion) stimulus package to counter the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with cash handouts of 3,500 baht per month for 30 million people, mostly informal sector workers and farmers. The government aims to distribute the funds starting in February to support individuals and businesses affected by curbs on businesses and mobility. The stimulus package also includes measures to boost domestic spending and tourism, and the government has allocated 209 billion baht to meet additional expenses and draw from a 260 billion baht surplus.

site_title: Biden to tap former derivatives regulator to head SEC: reports
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is expected to nominate Gary Gensler, a former Obama administration derivatives regulator, as the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Gensler has a reputation for toughness and is seen as a progressive choice to roll back Trump administration efforts to ease financial regulations. His nomination is likely to be welcomed by those who favour tighter control over financial markets. Gensler has a long history in government and previously served in senior roles in the Treasury Department and at Goldman Sachs.

images.alt_text: Mr Biden will tap Gary Gensler to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), according to news outlets, a position where he could roll back the efforts of outgoing president Donald Trump's administration to ease regulations imposed in the wake of the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: China plans to let banks sell soured personal loans to ease risks
summary: China plans to allow commercial banks to sell soured personal loans to distressed asset managers as soon as this month. The move aims to alleviate financial risks, with the goal of offloading up to 1 trillion yuan (S$205 billion) of non-performing loans. The policy is expected to benefit retail banks, allowing them to get rid of risks and trim their bad loan burden. The trial program involves six state-owned commercial banks and 12 joint-stock lenders, and is subject to approval by the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission.

site_title: New home sales to hover at 10,000 in 2020: analysts
summary: Singapore's new home sales reached 10,008 units in 2020, a year marked by the country's worst recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic. December sales increased 60% from November, driven by low interest rates and a surge in cash-flush buyers. These buyers, including those who became millionaires through en bloc sales, are driving demand and pushing prices up, with a 2.1% quarterly increase in Q4 2020.

site_title: How advisory boards can raise the bar on ESG advocacy
summary: A dedicated ESG advisory board can play a crucial role in embedding sustainability into a company's operations. These boards provide expertise on specific ESG issues and can bring valuable networks and lobbying prowess to the table. They can also provide unbiased, outside-in feedback during annual board evaluations and mentor other stakeholders to catalyze mindset change. Established boards, such as those at DSM, Daimler, and Mitsubishi, have successfully provided counsel to strengthen their companies' leadership roles in sustainability and ESG.

site_title: Analysts expect Malaysia's MCO to be extended
summary: Malaysia's Movement Control Order (MCO) is expected to be extended due to the worsening COVID-19 outbreak, posing a significant risk to the country's economy. Analysts predict a downside risk to the country's 2021 GDP, with forecasts revised down to 10.0% from 11.5%. The lockdown is expected to hit employment, wages, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with potential losses of RM2.4 billion per day. The government's decision to suspend parliament sessions and plans to form an independent committee to advise the King on the emergency will have limited impact on businesses, while the travel industry is bracing for a big hit.

site_title: Oil settles up, near US$57 on tight supply expectations
summary: Oil prices surged to an 11-month high near US$57 a barrel on Tuesday, driven by Saudi Arabia's plans to limit supply and offset concerns about rising coronavirus cases. Brent crude rose 92 cents, or 1.7%, to US$56.58 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate gained 96 cents, or 1.8%, to US$53.28. Saudi Arabia plans to cut output by 1 million barrels per day in February and March to maintain inventories, and analysts expect a drop in US crude stockpiles, supporting oil prices.

site_title: Singapore F&B sector braces for labour, cost squeeze from MCO
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector anticipates a labor and cost squeeze due to Malaysia's latest Movement Control Order (MCO). Despite previous disruptions, companies have adjusted and expect a rise in costs but minimal disruptions. The MCO will exacerbate existing issues, but firms have been prepared for the past several months. Most anticipate a smooth transition and minimal impact on operations.

site_title: China puts 5 million in Hebei under lockdown to eradicate Covid cluster
summary: China has locked down a city of nearly 5 million people in Hebei province to combat a Covid-19 cluster, with strict travel restrictions imposed on several other cities. The lockdown, which began on Tuesday, aims to eradicate the virus ahead of the Chinese New Year, when millions are expected to travel. The province has reported 560 new cases in recent weeks, with officials rushing to test all residents in two days. The measures come as a steady trickle of new cases has surfaced in China's northern provinces since October.

site_title: Right physical asset balance key to success of grocery delivery players
summary: Singapore's online grocery delivery sector is intensifying with Grab, foodpanda, and Deliveroo investing heavily, fueled by periodic lockdowns and movement restrictions in South-east Asia. This trend is expected to accelerate in Malaysia, where a Movement Control Order has been imposed in five states. Building a physical asset balance is key to success for grocery delivery players, as some are also investing in their own inventory to compete with established players. This intensifying competition may lead to further growth and innovation in the sector.

site_title: Investors have a new default worry in China's debt market
summary: China Fortune Land Development Co's US dollar bonds have fallen to record lows, with some rebounding but still at 53.5 US cents on the dollar, due to concerns over its debt repayment abilities. The mid-sized developer's shares have sunk 48% in the past year, and its onshore bonds have slumped 58% at 43 yuan. Beijing's efforts to cut risk in the real estate sector, including tightening controls and bank lending restrictions, have raised investor concerns. China Fortune Land needs to repay or refinance $4.4 billion of debt this year, and its parent has wired funds to pay early redemptions.

site_title: Wake up the mob . . . at your own risk
summary: A mob broke into the US Capitol, echoing Edmund Burke's warning of the dangers of unchecked anger and revolution. Burke, a conservative philosopher, wrote in 1790 that "anger and madness will destroy us in half an hour." Some members of the elite jumped on the populist wave to advance their interests, despite the Founding Fathers' efforts to create a representative democracy with checks and balances. The Republican Party's populist agenda, led by President Trump, proved to be a mishmash of nationalist clichés and conspiracy theories, ultimately losing control of the Senate. The incident highlights the threat to democracy posed by radicalized politicians who prioritize their own interests over the rule of law.

site_title: Singapore resale condo market robust despite pandemic, with prices up 1.4% in 2020
summary: The Singapore resale condo market remained robust in 2020, with resale transactions for non-landed private homes rising 18.1% from the previous year, reaching 10,712 properties. Resale prices increased by 1.4%, with the price index ending 2020 at its highest level since 2019. The market's resilience was attributed to renewed interest in the resale condo market in the second half of 2020, as well as low mortgage rates and a possible economic recovery. Experts predict moderate sales growth and further price increases in 2021, with resale prices potentially rising by 1-4% for the year.

site_title: GIC retains position as most active state-owned investor: report
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) retained its position as the most active state-owned investor for the second year, with US$17.7 billion deployed in 65 deals in 2020. GIC was followed by Canadian public pension fund CPP, CDPQ, and Mubadala. The report, which studied 438 state-owned investors, noted a significant decline in investment activity due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The technology sector emerged as the industry of the year, with a fifth of investments in tech, media, and telecommunications.

site_title: Labour recovery from Covid-19 needs coordination: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizes the need for high-quality coordination in handling the labour market shock caused by the Covid-19 pandemic in Singapore. The goal is to find a match for people's skills and human capital, rather than just getting them back in jobs quickly. Tharman notes that coordination is key to achieving both speedy matching and good matches, and that every modern economy must have this capability. He also highlights the need for lifelong learning, particularly for blue-collar workers, and for the government to strike a balance between helping firms and individuals to stay competitive.

site_title: Malaysia's latest curbs to have limited impact on Singapore: economists
summary: Singapore is expected to experience limited impact from Malaysia's reintroduction of a Movement Control Order (MCO) amid the COVID-19 pandemic, according to economists. The narrower coverage of the MCO, with more sectors deemed essential, is expected to minimize disruptions to goods flows and manufacturing supply chains. Economists also anticipate minimal impact on bilateral trade and investment, with the focus on containing the domestic pandemic situation.

site_title: Billionaire Republican donor Sheldon Adelson dies
summary: Billionaire casino magnate and Republican donor Sheldon Adelson, 87, has died from complications related to non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Adelson was a supporter of outgoing President Donald Trump and served as the founder and visionary leader of Las Vegas Sands company.

site_title: Four key trends in Asia's banking sector in 2021
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

In 2021, Asia's banking sector will be shaped by four key trends: data privacy and regulation as a priority, the real-time acceleration of a pan-Asia payments network, the turning to automation to handle rising fraud, and economic growth through financial inclusion. With the pandemic driving digital transformation, banks and fintechs must balance data sovereignty and regulatory requirements, while governments accelerate real-time payments and regulators focus on financial inclusion to empower unbanked populations. Key players like Mastercard, Visa, and Swift will also play a role in establishing a strong foothold in real-time payments.

site_title: Oil and gas firms likely to be spared steep impairment that ravaged them in 2020
summary: Oil and gas firms are unlikely to face steep impairment losses in 2021, following a robust start to the year, driven by output cuts and vaccine hopes. Brent crude prices have reached $55 a barrel, a level last seen in February 2020, after Saudi Arabia and Iraq pledged to cut oil output. This marks a significant recovery for the sector, which was severely impacted by the pandemic in 2020, with combined write-downs of $145 billion. Analysts expect the sector to benefit from a rebound in demand, particularly in Asia, but warn of ongoing risks and structural shifts in the energy industry.

site_title: Cash piles, hostile bids set stage for a wild Japan M&A year
summary: Japan's M&A activity is expected to remain active in 2021, driven by pent-up demand, cash piles, and external forces. The country has seen a resurgence in dealmaking in the second half of 2020, with acquisitions totaling around $140 billion, and momentum is likely to continue. Japanese companies are focusing on domestic acquisitions and restructuring, while also pursuing outbound deals. Hostile bids for domestic rivals have become normalized, and private equity firms are eyeing Japan for new transactions. A strong yen and record cash reserves could encourage companies to make acquisitions, particularly in the overseas market.

images.alt_text: Late last year, the ultimate consolidation was realised with NTT Docomo Inc, Japan's largest listed unit, being taken private by its parent Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp.

site_title: SGX RegCo announces enhanced rules for auditors, valuers
summary: SGX RegCo has announced enhanced rules for auditors and valuers in Singapore, requiring primary-listed issuers to appoint auditors registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) for statutory audits. The new rules also expand administrative powers to direct the appointment of a second auditor in exceptional circumstances. Additionally, property valuers must now have at least five years of relevant experience and be independent of issuers. The changes aim to improve market quality, investor protection, and the quality of valuation reports.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan, CEO of SGX RegCo, says the new rules should improve market quality and investor protection, and adds that a maturing marketplace would mean greater scrutiny from investors and higher expectations.

site_title: APAC firms have shown 'remarkable resilience' amid pandemic: Vodafone
summary: APAC firms have shown remarkable resilience amid the pandemic, with 80% of businesses in the region coping well with business continuity plans. According to Vodafone Business's Future Ready Report, the most common characteristics of future-ready businesses include a positive attitude to change, openness to new technology, and adaptability. The report found that businesses in India, China, and Singapore are most optimistic, and are likely to increase their digital transformation efforts and diversify their supply chains. As the pandemic continues to disrupt businesses, future-ready businesses are better equipped to navigate the challenges and seize opportunities in increasingly volatile conditions.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Enviro-Hub Holdings invests US$5 million in a 25% stake in Malaysia's Pastel Glove Sdn Bhd. Manhattan Resources appoints former Sembcorp Industries chief Tang Kin Fei as non-executive, non-independent chairman. Camsing Healthcare extends its deadline to appoint an independent reviewer until Friday. Hong Leong Asia names its chairman's daughter as head of sustainability and corporate affairs. Tee International reports a net profit of S$547,000 for the second quarter, reversing a loss of S$35.9 million in the previous year.

site_title: China make-up ad pulled for victim-blaming
summary: A Chinese company, Purcotton, has pulled an advertisement for make-up wipes after it was criticized for victim-blaming in a scenario where a woman uses the product to scare off a stalker. The ad sparked widespread outrage on Chinese social media, with users accusing the company of making light of a serious issue and insulting the female sex. Purcotton initially defended the ad, but eventually apologized and removed it from circulation, with state media also condemning the ad as "beautifying the criminal and smearing the victim".

site_title: Blackstone to buy Sandcrawler building in Singapore for S$176m
summary: US private equity giant Blackstone Group is planning to buy the Sandcrawler building in Singapore for approximately S$176 million. The sale process is ongoing and subject to regulatory approval from JTC Corporation. CBRE brokered the deal.

site_title: State of emergency suspends KL parliament for first time since 1969; allows Muhyiddin election breather
summary: Malaysia's King declared a nationwide state of emergency for the first time in over 50 years, suspending parliament to allow embattled Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to avoid an election during the pandemic. The emergency decree grants more power to tackle the surge in Covid-19 cases, including private hospitals, and may allow police and military assistance in public health measures. The move comes after a record high in new infections and forecasts of daily cases reaching 8,000 by late March or May. The declaration has been criticized by opposition politicians, who blame Muhyiddin for failing to contain the surge and using the pandemic to stay in power.

site_title: Sunpower inks steam supply deal in China
summary: Sunpower Group, a Singapore-listed company, has signed a deal to buy four sets of boilers from a Chinese textile company for 100 million yuan (S$20.5 million). The move was welcomed by KGI Securities and DBS Group Research, which upgraded their target prices for the stock and maintained "outperform" and "buy" recommendations.

site_title: China's credit growth slows as policy support eases
summary: China's credit growth slowed in December, with aggregate financing at 1.72 trillion yuan, down from 2.13 trillion yuan in November. Shadow banking activities dropped by 737.6 billion yuan, the largest decline in at least four years. Financial institutions offered 1.26 trillion yuan of new loans, lower than in November but higher than December 2019. The stock of outstanding credit grew 13.3% from a year earlier, slower than in November. The central bank may be normalizing policy as it explores exiting emergency stimulus measures, with Governor Yi Gang indicating a need for tightening in credit supply.

site_title: Innovation centre to develop Singapore as base for advanced manufacturers
summary: Singapore's PlanetSpark Innovation Centre was launched on January 12, 2021, to nurture hardware technology startups in the AI and IoT sectors. Developed by Excelpoint Tech and Enterprise Singapore, the centre aims to grow over 30 startups in three years with an initial investment of S$5 million. Startups can access a network of semiconductor partners, mentors, and venture capital firms to accelerate product development and commercialization. The centre complements the government's efforts to grow the electronics industry and develop Singapore as a resilient base for advanced manufacturers.

site_title: US dollar holds firm as Treasury yield jumps
summary: The US dollar maintained its recent gains after a spike in US Treasury yields, lifting demand for the currency. The 10-year yield reached a 10-month high, and markets have brought forward bets on Fed interest rate increases to 2023. Despite concerns about inflation, the US dollar index remained unchanged at 90.438, above lows of 89.206 hit last week. Analysts expect the greenback to resume its decline as stimulus spending and vaccine rollouts brighten the global outlook.

site_title: UBS lowering threshold to charge depositors for negative rates, closing 40 Swiss branches
summary: UBS Group is lowering the threshold for charging depositors for negative interest rates, starting in July for clients with deposits over 250,000 francs (S$373,400) or the same amount in euros. The previous threshold was more than two million francs or 500,000 euros. Clients with mortgages or investments in UBS funds may be exempt from the charge. The move aims to mitigate the impact of low and negative interest rates on the bank's business.

site_title: Bad debt surge threatens India's financial stability: RBI
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) forecasts that non-performing assets in the banking sector will rise to 13.5% of total advances by the end of September, nearly doubling from 7.5% a year ago. This is the worst since 1999 and poses a threat to financial stability. The RBI attributes the surge to soaring markets and a weakened economy, triggered by the coronavirus outbreak. To address the issue, the central bank has taken measures, including a loan repayment moratorium and a two-year debt restructuring program. However, the extent of the problem remains unclear due to the measures.

site_title: Asia-Pacific can lead in race to save the ocean economy
summary: The High Level Panel for a Sustainable Ocean Economy, launched by 14 countries, aims to achieve 100% sustainable ocean management and national waters. Asia-Pacific nations, including Australia, Fiji, Indonesia, Japan, and Palau, are well-represented on the panel, signaling the region's potential to lead in saving the ocean economy.

site_title: Is cruising set to bounce back?
summary: The cruise ship industry is expected to bounce back, according to Inchcape Shipping Services. Grant Holmes, head of the cruise industry, notes that 2019 was a record year and 2020 was projected to be even better, but the pandemic hit in mid-March, paralyzing the sector. Despite high costs, the industry is anticipated to recover, with some cruise programmes resuming operations. However, no specific timeline has been provided for the industry's full recovery.

site_title: Trump calls his speech before Congress storming 'totally appropriate'
summary: US President Donald Trump denied any responsibility for the violence that broke out after his speech to supporters, calling it "totally appropriate." The speech encouraged thousands to march on Congress, where a crowd stormed the building, forcing lawmakers to abandon the certification of Joe Biden's election win. Trump stated that his words and final paragraph were misinterpreted, claiming they were "totally appropriate."

site_title: Indonesia finds black box from Sriwijaya Air's plane crash
summary: Indonesian authorities have retrieved one of the black boxes from the Sriwijaya Air plane crash, which occurred on Saturday, killing 62 people. The black box, a white plastic box, was being transported to Jakarta's port after being recovered from the Java Sea. The device is believed to be either the flight data recorder or cockpit voice recorder. The recovery is part of an investigation led by Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee, which expects to analyze the data in three days. This is the second major air crash in Indonesia since 2018.

site_title: 2021's key trends in healthcare management and delivery
summary: Key trends in healthcare management and delivery in 2021 include record-high investments in digitizing health, with a focus on telehealth, artificial intelligence, and digital health solutions. Mobile electronic medical record systems are also emerging, enabling personalized care and streamlining vaccination processes. Advanced technologies such as AI and natural language processing are being integrated into healthcare IT platforms, automating clinical documentation and medication administration. Additionally, healthcare IT systems are being upgraded to automate and streamline healthcare processes, allowing for more time to focus on patient care and improving patient outcomes.

images.alt_text: While useful in the current social-distancing context, telehealth technologies may further enable patients to consult medical specialists within and beyond national borders.

site_title: Sea can pass on S-E Asian deal frenzy
summary: Singapore-based Sea Ltd is in talks for potential mergers and acquisitions with South-east Asian technology companies, including Gojek and Tokopedia. Sea, valued at $106 billion, has a strong presence in gaming, e-commerce, and payments, and is expanding its user base. However, founder Forrest Li is reportedly hesitant to pursue large acquisitions, instead focusing on strategic partnerships and investments. Sea's shares have risen 13-fold since its 2017 listing, and the company has a significant war chest of cash, making it a potential buyer for smaller companies.

site_title: Simon Rattle to leave London Symphony Orchestra for Munich
summary: Simon Rattle, 65, will leave the London Symphony Orchestra in 2023 to become the chief conductor of the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra in Munich, Germany. Rattle's decision is "entirely personal" and driven by his desire to be closer to his family, who live in Germany. The move comes as Brexit takes effect, which Rattle has long warned would harm Britain's cultural life and touring orchestras. His contract extension with the London Symphony will be just one year, and he will take an emeritus position, allowing him to continue leading projects in London.

site_title: US home prices ease in sign pandemic rally may cool
summary: US home prices are slowing down, signaling the end of the pandemic housing market rally. The asking price for a typical single-family home rose 13.8% from last year, down from a peak of 16.5% growth in July. Analysts attribute the slowdown to unsustainable growth rates and low borrowing costs, which may not decrease further. With a housing shortage, buyers are likely to be squeezed out of the market, leading to a potential cooling of the market.

site_title: The Brexit boon to Europe and the US
summary: US President Joe Biden's economic policies may negatively impact the euro and European economy, as he aims to keep the US dollar low to boost spending on pandemic response, environment, and infrastructure. This could harm European exports, particularly for countries like Germany, which relies heavily on exports. In contrast, Brexit has created an opportunity for Germany to deploy fiscal stimulus, potentially leading to a more effective EU fiscal- and monetary-policy model. This shift could help harmonize US-EU relations and benefit both economies, with the EU's new recovery fund and internalized trade model potentially providing a strong antidote to European populism.

site_title: ESG investments to drive growth for asset managers: IMAS survey
summary: A survey by the Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) found that 86% of respondents believe ESG investments will drive growth for asset managers over the next three years. 67% also expect ESG or impact strategies to grow in popularity in 2021. The survey highlights the increasing trend of sustainable investments globally, with 71% of managers expecting business lines around sustainable finance or ESG to become a point of differentiation.

site_title: GM to sell electric delivery vans to FedEx, other fleet buyers
summary: General Motors is launching a new business unit called BrightDrop, which will supply electric commercial-delivery vehicles to customers including FedEx. BrightDrop plans to sell electric pallet movers and a cargo van in 2021 and 2022, respectively. The company estimates the US market for delivery vehicles could be $850 billion by 2025. GM has also partnered with Skyscanner to lead the business unit, and offers fleet-management services to enable customers to track goods and vehicles.

site_title: From the music hall to ballet royalty: A British tale
summary: The Royal Academy of Dance (RAD) was founded in 1920 by Edouard Espinosa and others, including Adeline Genée and Tamara Karsavina. The academy, which is now one of the world's major ballet training programs, aimed to establish standards for dance instruction and promote professional ballet training in Britain. The organization played a significant role in shaping British ballet and its legacy, with notable figures such as Darcey Bussell and Margot Fonteyn contributing to its growth. The RAD's history is showcased in the exhibition "On Point: Royal Academy of Dance at 100" at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

site_title: How to position your stocks for success in 2021 and beyond
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

As the pandemic subsides, investors are positioning themselves for recovery in 2021 and beyond. Laggard sectors such as Singapore's banks and retail real estate investment trusts (Reits) may see a swift recovery due to improved economic conditions and the promise of Covid-19 vaccines. The digital shift sparked by the pandemic is also expected to persist, with tech giants and businesses adapting to online payments and e-commerce. Investors are advised to diversify their portfolios, hold cash for unexpected market downturns, and focus on strong and resilient companies to capture the eventual recovery.

site_title: Microsoft, Facebook, Google to halt political donations after US riot
summary: Tech giants Microsoft, Facebook, and Google are halting political donations in the US after a deadly pro-Trump riot at the US Capitol. Other companies, including Intel, Goldman Sachs, and Citigroup, are also pausing or planning to pause donations. Microsoft's PAC made significant contributions to lawmakers who voted against President-elect Joe Biden's certification. The moves come amid heightened attention on the tech industry's response to the events and pressure from employees and some lawmakers.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI, DBS raise TPs for Sunpower on M&S divestment
summary: KGI Securities and DBS Group Research have upgraded their target prices for Sunpower Group, raising it to $1.45 and S$0.94, respectively, following the company's plan to divest its manufacturing and services segment. Analysts believe the green investment (GI) segment will be a standout performer due to favourable policy support and growth opportunities. The disposal is expected to result in a one-off gain, but analysts note the company's high debt levels, with no immediate liquidity issues forecasted.

site_title: Markets search for China's 'red line' as yuan starts year with jump
summary: The Chinese yuan surged to a two-and-a-half-year high against the US dollar in the first trading day of 2021, with a one percent jump, amid expectations of the People's Bank of China (PBOC) closely managing the currency. Authorities aim to maintain a stable level, with PBOC governor Yi Gang stating a focus on guiding expectations to keep the yuan stable at reasonable levels. Analysts predict volatility in the currency's movement in 2021, with some considering 6.4 per dollar as a "red line" for the authorities.

images.alt_text: The yuan leapt one per cent against the US dollar on the first trading day of the year to two-and-a-half-year highs, and logged its biggest weekly rise in two months last week.

site_title: US job openings declined by less than forecast in November
summary: US job openings declined to 6.53 million in November, below the forecast of 6.45 million. The decline was less than expected, indicating steady labor demand before the resurgent virus affected employment. This marks a reversal from the previous month's increase. The figure doesn't include recalled workers or internal job openings.

site_title: 83-year-old Singaporean man among new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: An 83-year-old Singaporean man who recently returned from India has been confirmed to have contracted COVID-19, bringing Singapore's total cases to 58,946. The 17 new cases, all imported, are asymptomatic or serving stay-home notices. There were no community cases or infections at workers' dormitories. The number of unlinked community cases remains stable, with 26 cases discharged on Tuesday, leaving 53 patients in hospital.

site_title: Blackstone to buy Star Wars 'Sandcrawler' building in Singapore
summary: US private equity giant Blackstone Group is planning to buy Lucas Real Estate Singapore's iconic facility, The Sandcrawler, in Singapore for an indicative price of nearly S$175.8 million. The futuristic, horseshoe-shaped building, inspired by the Star Wars franchise, houses Industrial Light & Magic and serves as Lucasfilm's regional headquarters. The 22,500 square meter campus has a high occupancy rate and features a unique design with a metallic facade and movie-themed decor. The sale is subject to approval from JTC Corporation and is expected to cement Blackstone's presence in Singapore's digital media hub.

site_title: US: Stocks stable amid Washington anxiety, vaccine optimism
summary: US stocks remained stable early Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index showing minimal changes. Markets weighed concerns over elevated coronavirus cases and US political unrest, particularly following the Capitol attack, against optimism over Covid-19 vaccines. Law enforcement officials warned of potential unrest ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. Despite some selling interest, the market maintained a bullish bias, with individual companies such as Walmart gaining 0.9% on a new fintech startup announcement.

site_title: Tech startup MicroSec raises Series A funding led by MassMutual Ventures
summary: Singapore-based cyber security firm MicroSec has completed a Series A round of funding led by MassMutual Ventures, totaling US$3.2 million. The investment will enable the firm to expand its capabilities, sales, and marketing, as well as product development. MicroSec's clients include the Singapore government and tech players like Honeywell and Infineon. CEO Vishram Mishra plans to double the firm's headcount this year, following key executive appointments. The funding is well-timed to address market demands for Internet-of-Things technology and cyber security in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: Fidelity ups stake in Hong Kong cryptocurrency company
summary: Fidelity has increased its stake in Hong Kong cryptocurrency company BC Technology Group to 6.29% after investing US$6.71 million. BC Group raised HK$697 million in a top-up share placement, with institutional investors participating in the deal. The investment comes amid soaring interest in bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, driven by institutional demand.

site_title: Tee International books Q2 net profit of S$547,000 after divesting loss-making operations
summary: Tee International reported a Q2 net profit of S$547,000, reversing a loss of S$35.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue was halved to S$46.4 million due to the completion of a major project. The company's Q2 results were largely driven by the absence of losses from discontinued business operations.

site_title: Mercedes and BMW's dominance wanes as electric brands ascend
summary: German luxury car brands Mercedes-Benz and BMW saw their dominance wane in 2020 as electric vehicle companies, led by Tesla, gained market share in China. Despite Mercedes topping the premium auto ranks for a fifth consecutive year, BMW's deliveries fell 7.2% to 2.03 million, while Tesla made significant inroads in the world's largest luxury market. The trend is expected to continue, with analysts predicting further losses of market share for BMW, Mercedes, and Audi as electric brands expand their offerings.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz narrowly beat BMW for the title of world's best-selling luxury-car brand in 2020, a year in which cracks started showing in German dominance of the all-important China market.

site_title: Ex-Sembcorp CEO Tang Kin Fei joins Manhattan Resources as chairman
summary: Former Sembcorp Industries CEO Tang Kin Fei has joined Manhattan Resources as chairman, replacing the late Liow Keng Teck. Tang, 70, will also serve on the nominating and remuneration committees. He is the father-in-law of Manhattan's managing director and chief executive, Low Yi Ngo. This board shake-up comes after the previous chairman's death in 2018.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment board okays director's post but will relook board, management after independent review
summary: The board of Catalist-listed Spackman Entertainment Group has approved former interim CEO Richard Lee to remain as a non-executive director, despite evidence suggesting he was a nominee of CEO Charles C. Spackman. The decision comes after a Hong Kong court decision stated Lee was Spackman's nominee. The board will reassess the suitability of directors and management after an independent review, which could take three months, following a Singapore Exchange regulator's order.

site_title: Max Levchin's Affirm aims for over US$10b valuation in IPO
summary: Lending startup Affirm Holdings aims for a valuation of over US$10 billion in its IPO, following an upward revision in price range. Founded by PayPal co-founder Max Levchin in 2012, the company offers financing for online purchases in monthly installments. Affirm plans to sell 24.6 million shares priced between US$41 and US$44 each, raising up to US$1.08 billion. The company's valuation is higher than its last private funding round, which valued it below US$3 billion.

site_title: Memories Group can continue as going concern, says board, despite auditor's uncertainty
summary: Memories Group, a Catalist-listed tourism operator, faces material uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, its board believes a going-concern assumption remains appropriate, citing fund-raising efforts and a shift in business focus to the domestic tourism market. The company has obtained additional borrowings and is in talks to issue up to US$10 million in convertible loans. The board believes the domestic tourism market will generate some cash flow, supporting the going-concern assumption.

site_title: Asset platform Zipmex raises US$6m in new funding round
summary: Zipmex, a Singapore-based digital asset exchange, has closed a US$6 million funding round led by Jump Capital. This latest round follows previous funding rounds in 2019 and 2021, with the funds intended to expand product offerings, including interest-bearing savings product ZipUp and exchange token ZMT.

site_title: GSK, Vir to test antibody for Covid-19 treatment
summary: GSK and Vir Biotechnology are testing a second antibody-based treatment for mild to moderate Covid-19 in a UK trial. The monoclonal antibody has shown potential to clear infected cells and enhance virus-specific T cell function. This is the second treatment from the Vir-GSK collaboration to be investigated as a potential Covid-19 treatment, following a first experimental antibody that is currently being assessed in global late-stage studies. The trial is expected to begin in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: England brings in pre-departure testing for travellers from Jan 15
summary: England will require travellers from abroad to show proof of a negative Covid-19 test taken up to three days before departure starting January 15. Transport operators must verify the test result before boarding flights, trains, or ferries, with fines of £500 starting from non-compliance. Exemptions will include hauliers and international crew. The pre-departure test requirement is in addition to a 10-day self-isolation rule for arrivals from abroad.

site_title: GIC retains position as most active state-owned investor for second year running: report
summary: Singapore's GIC retained its position as the most active state-owned investor for the second year, deploying US$17.7 billion in 65 deals in 2020. Canadian public pension fund CPP was the second most active, followed by CDPQ and Mubadala. The report notes a significant contraction in capital investments by state-owned investors, mainly due to logistical and cautionary measures during the COVID-19 pandemic. Technology investments rose to a fifth of total investments, with Temasek emerging as the top tech investor, and private equity and debt investments expected to continue in the next decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.21 points to 1,612.04. The index saw a trading volume of 8.408 billion lots worth RM5.764 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 732 to 502.

site_title: Singapore may not be hit hard by Malaysia's state of emergency and MCO: economists
summary: Singapore may not be significantly affected by Malaysia's state of emergency and reintroduced Movement Control Order (MCO) amid the Covid-19 pandemic, according to economists. The MCO's impact on Singapore is expected to be limited to manpower movement and possibly some disruptions to businesses. Economists expect flows of goods and investment to remain unaffected, with Singapore-Malaysia manufacturing supply chains and food trade expected to be minimally impacted.

site_title: Saudi Arabia puts financing for Riyadh airport expansion on hold
summary: Saudi Arabia has put on hold financing plans for the expansion of Riyadh's airport, worth potentially billions of dollars, amid the country's re-assessment of strategic priorities following the coronavirus crisis. The Riyadh Airports Company had approached banks with a request for financing proposals last year, but the process has been halted. This decision comes as Saudi Arabia prioritizes budgetary needs and cuts state spending by 7% this year to tame a fiscal deficit, following a sharp contraction in the economy due to lower petroleum revenues and the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's approach to recovering from the Covid-19 shock focuses on matching workers with their skills and human capital. Malaysia's new Movement Control Order will exacerbate a manpower shortage and cost issues in the food and beverage sector. The Singapore Exchange RegCo has introduced enhanced rules on auditors and valuers. Resale condo transactions rose 18.1% in 2020, while Singapore stocks ended in the red, down 0.23% on Tuesday. MicroSec, a Singapore-based cyber security firm, completed its Series A funding round led by MassMutual Ventures.

site_title: Indonesia retrieves 'black box' from crashed Sriwijaya Air plane
summary: Indonesian authorities have retrieved a black box from a crashed Sriwijaya Air plane that plunged into the Java Sea on Saturday, killing 62 people. The black box, which may be a flight data or cockpit voice recorder, was recovered and is being transported to Jakarta's port. The retrieval comes as investigators face a challenging task in determining the cause of the catastrophic loss of control. Once the recorders are analyzed, Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee expects to have an answer within three days, with the jet being nearly 27 years old and a different design from the 2018 Lion Air Boeing 737 MAX crash.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses on Tuesday, STI down 0.23%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day down 0.23% on Tuesday, following a decline on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index dropped 6.73 points to 2,977.17. Thai Beverage was the top performer, rising 3.25%, while CapitaLand gained 2.04%. Singapore Airlines and Singtel were among the laggards, down 1.40% and 2% respectively. Analysts expect some hesitance ahead of Q4 results season, citing concerns over travel and hospitality stocks.

site_title: Japan households' inflation expectations weaken as pandemic clouds outlook: Bank of Japan survey
summary: Japanese households' inflation expectations weakened to 60.0% in December, down from 63.3% in September, according to the Bank of Japan's survey. The coronavirus pandemic is heightening deflationary risks for Japan's economy, suggesting a weakening outlook. The decrease in inflation expectations highlights the challenges faced by the Bank of Japan in achieving its inflation target.

site_title: Thailand approves soft loans and subsidies to mitigate virus impact
summary: Thailand has approved measures to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, including soft loans and subsidies. The new measures aim to boost liquidity for businesses, provide debt relief, and support unemployment. Electric and water expenses will be subsided until March, and higher internet speeds and data will be supported to promote working from home. The government has allocated 638 billion baht for low-interest loans, and Deputy Prime Minister Supattanapong Punmeechaow said new measures are within the government's budget, aiming to manage the outbreak by March.

site_title: Sunpower Group to buy boilers in industrial steam supply deal in China
summary: Sunpower Group has acquired four sets of boilers from Hebei Sanli Group in a 100 million yuan (S$20.5 million) deal. The boilers will be used to provide steam for 25 years under a steam supply right contract. As part of the agreement, Sanli Group has committed to maintaining its production levels in Hebei province's Gaoyang county. The deal is expected to provide Sunpower Group with a stable revenue stream and expand its industrial steam supply capabilities in China.

site_title: Britain introduces new company rules to stop links to China's Xinjiang
summary: Britain introduces new company rules to prevent goods from China's Xinjiang region entering the supply chain, amid allegations of forced labor. Foreign minister Dominic Raab announced tougher measures, including robust guidance for due diligence on sourcing, fines under the Modern Slavery Act, and a ban on non-compliant companies from government contracts. The package aims to prevent British organizations from profiting from human rights violations against Uighurs and other minorities in Xinjiang.

site_title: South Korean firm's smart dog collar tells owners what's in a bark
summary: A South Korean startup, Petpuls Lab, has developed an AI-powered dog collar that can detect five canine emotions through voice recognition technology. The Petpuls collar tracks physical activity and rest, and owners can monitor their dog's emotions through a smartphone app. The device boasts a 90% average accuracy rate, according to Seoul National University, and has been marketed online for $99. The company aims to improve pet-human communication and bonding, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when more people spent time at home with their pets.

site_title: Besieged UK hospitals offer a warning on lagging Covid vaccines
summary: The UK's hospitals are under strain due to a surge in COVID-19 cases from a new, faster-spreading strain, despite the country's rapid vaccine rollout. Over 2.2 million people have received the first vaccine shot, but hospitals are buckling under the pressure, with daily infections at record levels and the death toll the highest in Europe. European countries are concerned about the potential spread of the mutation, which has prompted calls for stricter movement restrictions, as they lag behind in vaccinations and face logistical or supply issues.

site_title: Britain's Hut Group sees stronger 2021 as beauty products lift Q4
summary: Britain's Hut Group raised its 2021 revenue forecast by 10% due to a surge in online demand for beauty products during the UK's coronavirus lockdowns. The company, which acquired Dermstore.com for $350 million, now expects 2021 revenue to be between 30% and 35% higher than 2020 revenue. The Hut Group saw a 51% jump in fourth-quarter 2020 revenue, and has started reinvesting capital raised from its London IPO into mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Malaysia's MCO to put more pressure on manpower and supply costs for F&B firms
summary: Malaysia's latest Movement Control Order (MCO) will exacerbate the manpower shortage and cost issues faced by food and beverage (F&B) firms in Singapore, according to companies in the sector. Despite this, most firms expect a rise in costs but no significant disruptions. Manpower costs have increased since Malaysia's first MCO in March 2020, with poaching common and locals shunning available jobs, resulting in insufficient foreign worker quotas for some companies. Supply chain disruptions are expected to be less of an issue, but prices for some goods, such as fresh produce, may continue to rise.

site_title: Foresight eyes London stock market listing in February
summary: Foresight Group, a UK-based infrastructure and private equity fund firm, plans to list on the London Stock Exchange in February, with around 80% of shares being sold by existing shareholders and 20% by new shares. The company expects 50% of its shares to be in public hands following admission, making it eligible for the FTSE UK index series. This follows similar listings plans by Moonpig and Dr Martens. Admission is currently expected to occur next month.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 6,808.64 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices adding 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and the threat of tariffs.

site_title: UBS lowers threshold to charge depositors for negative rates
summary: UBS Group plans to lower the threshold for charging depositors a fee due to low and negative interest rates. Starting in July, clients with deposits exceeding 250,000 francs (S$373,387) or the same amount in euros will be subject to the charge. Clients with mortgages or investments in UBS funds may be exempt. The fee will only apply to the excess amount above the threshold. UBS also plans to close around 40 branches in Switzerland by March to focus on digital banking, affecting 150 employees.

images.alt_text: UBS Group plans to lower the threshold for customer deposits that will be subject to a charge as the bank deals with the prospect of low and negative interest rates for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Regional bourses more affected by global Covid-19 figures than local cases: Study
summary: A study found that regional bourses, such as Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, were more affected by global Covid-19 developments than local cases. Global pandemic developments, particularly in the US, impacted daily stock market returns, while local virus cases and deaths did not significantly affect returns.
