However, the study also noted that monetary policy, foreign exchange rate movements, and US virus controls had a significant impact on regional stock market volatility. Policymakers are advised to consider these factors when mitigating the pandemic's adverse effects on the economy.

site_title: Seoul: Shares track Wall Street lower on Fed tapering talks
summary: South Korean shares closed down 0.71% on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street losses, as foreign investors sold shares amid concerns of the Federal Reserve pulling back on bond buying and rising interest rates. The benchmark Kospi fell 22.50 points to 3,125.95, while the won weakened and bond yields rose. Foreigners net sold 618.6 billion won worth of shares, and analysts attributed the selling to worries about an equity market overheat and rising interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, driven by hopes for vaccine rollout and new US stimulus. The Hang Seng Index gained 1.32% to 28,276.75, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 2.18% to its highest level since 2015. The gains offset concerns over surging virus infections and lockdowns.

site_title: Disneyland to become mass vaccination site in Orange County, California
summary: Disneyland in Orange County, California, will become the first large site to provide Covid-19 vaccinations, with operations set to begin later this week. The resort, which has remained closed since March, will serve as a Super Point-of-Dispensing (POD) site. This move is part of the county's efforts to combat the pandemic, with additional Super POD sites to be announced as agreements are finalized. The Disneyland Resort is supporting the vaccination effort, with Disney officials expressing gratitude for the opportunity to help.

site_title: India's army chief expects China talks will solve Himalayan border crisis
summary: India's army chief, General Manoj Mukund Naravane, expects talks with China to resolve the Himalayan border crisis, which escalated after a 2020 clash that killed 20 Indian soldiers. The crisis has led to a significant buildup of troops from both countries, with thousands deployed in the Ladakh region. Despite several rounds of talks, tensions remain high, and trust between the two nuclear-armed neighbours has been severely impaired, according to India's Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar. General Naravane stated that India will hold its ground to achieve national goals and interests, but expects another round of talks soon.

site_title: Former Airbus CEO joins electric-flight startup Lilium
summary: Former Airbus CEO Tom Enders has joined the board of electric-flight startup Lilium, citing the company's focus on clean-energy intercity flights and strong partners. Lilium aims to operate an all-electric five-seater flying taxi and has secured deals with airports in Europe and the US. Enders' addition brings industry experience and credibility to the startup, which has valued at over $1 billion. This move highlights the growing trend of aviation executives joining startups to develop sustainable flight options amid the mounting climate crisis.

site_title: Japan says working to isolate, analyse new virus variant
summary: Japan is working to isolate and analyze a new coronavirus variant detected in four people who arrived from Brazil, with officials emphasizing there is no evidence it's more transmissible or dangerous. The variant was found in two adults and two children who arrived on January 2, with one hospitalized with breathing difficulties. The World Health Organization has been notified, warning that new changes to the virus are possible as it spreads. Similarities have been found between the newly detected strain and those in the UK and South Africa, raising concerns about vaccine resistance.

site_title: Malaysia's Pharmaniaga signs Covid vaccine agreement with China's Sinovac
summary: Malaysia's Pharmaniaga has signed an agreement with China's Sinovac to purchase and manufacture Covid-19 vaccines domestically. The deal includes a fill-and-finish process and license to manufacture under Sinovac's technology and know-how. This is part of Malaysia's efforts to secure 23.9 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines from various manufacturers, including Sinovac, CanSino Biologics, and Gamaleya Institute. The agreement aims to support Malaysia's long-term partnerships and grow the vaccine manufacturing sector in the country.

site_title: China plans further Hong Kong crackdown after mass arrest: sources
summary: China is planning further measures to suppress democracy in Hong Kong after the mass arrest of over 50 democrats last week, according to sources. Beijing's involvement in the crackdown is "substantial," and officials are discussing reforms to Hong Kong's electoral system to reduce the opposition's influence. The Chinese government may delay the September elections, and could introduce changes to the electoral system, including curtailing the power of democrats on a key election committee. The move is part of a broader effort to silence activists and maintain control over the territory.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as risk aversion mounts on virus woes
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,679.1 due to concerns over a highly infectious Covid-19 strain, sparking fears of fresh global lockdowns. The S&P/ASX 200 index was limited by heavy buying in financials, which rose 0.7%. The metals and mining sub-index declined 0.9%, while local tech stocks reached a month-low. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.8% due to heightened virus screening for inbound international travellers. The lack of a national plan to control the virus contributed to the uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.09% to 28,164.34. The Topix index gained 0.16% to 1,857.94, despite concerns over rising virus cases in Japan. The gains were limited by sluggish trading.

site_title: Rakuten worker arrested for alleged SoftBank 5G secrets leak
summary: A former SoftBank Corp employee has been arrested in Japan on suspicion of leaking 5G trade secrets to his new employer, Rakuten Mobile Inc. Confidential 4G and 5G networking plans and technology were compromised, but no client data was exposed. Rakuten Mobile confirmed the employee's involvement and is cooperating with the police investigation. The incident highlights the intensifying competition in Japan's lucrative telecom market, where Rakuten has been disrupting the industry with its unlimited mobile data allowances.

site_title: Widening Covid-19 wealth gap will pressure public spending, debt, say reports
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is widening wealth and income inequality in Asia, with virus control and economic downturn expected to pressure public spending and debt. Analysts warn that this could lead to higher bond yields or unconventional monetary policies, potentially clashing with inflation targets. Moody's has a negative outlook on Asia-Pacific sovereign credit-worthiness for the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Democratic drive to impeach Trump speeds ahead after Capitol siege
summary: Democratic leaders plan to vote on formal charges of misconduct against President Donald Trump on Wednesday, unless he resigns or Vice-President Mike Pence invokes the 25th Amendment to remove him. The House is also considering a resolution calling on Pence to take action. Trump's actions following the January 6 Capitol siege have driven a wedge among Republicans, with some lawmakers calling for his resignation or impeachment. The impeachment drive appears unlikely to result in Trump's removal, with a Senate conviction requiring a two-thirds vote, and Democrats are concerned that a trial could hamper President-elect Joe Biden's agenda.

site_title: 17 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 17 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 58,946. The cases include 17 individuals placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival, with no community cases or cases from worker's dormitories. Two additional cases were linked to the NewOcean 6 cluster, bringing the total to 11 confirmed cases. Meanwhile, 32 cases were discharged, leaving 67 patients in hospital, with 165 recovering in community facilities.

site_title: Chinese electric-car maker Xpeng gets S$2.66b line of credit
summary: Chinese electric-car maker Xpeng Inc has secured a 12.8 billion yuan (S$2.66 billion) line of credit from five Chinese banks to support its business expansion. The deal comes as the company continues to grow its manufacturing, sales, and service capabilities, despite the high costs of producing electric cars. Xpeng's shares have surged to US$44.36, driven by its successful initial public offering and follow-on offerings, with investors backing the company including Alibaba Group and Hillhouse Capital Management.

site_title: Drug makers help Nikkei scale fresh 3-decade high
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 Index reached a fresh three-decade high of 28,177.81, driven by a report of an effective Covid-19 treatment, with drug makers Chugai Pharmaceutical, Takeda Pharmaceutical, Eisai, and Shionogi & Co leading the charge. Retail stocks also gained, while automakers Toyota Motor and Honda Motor fell due to semiconductor shortages. Semiconductor shares rose on prospects of stronger chip demand.

site_title: Labour recovery from Covid-19 shock cannot be left to market forces: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for "high-quality and effective coordination" to recover the labour market from the Covid-19 pandemic. He stressed that coordination is crucial to find the best match for workers' skills and human capital, rather than relying solely on market forces. This approach is key to both speedy job-matching and good matches, according to Tharman, who chairs the National Jobs Council.

site_title: Covid-19 and cold has cooking fuel outpacing petrol in India
summary: India's consumption of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) surpassed petrol in 2020, driven by a government buying programme, cold weather, and stay-at-home orders due to Covid-19. LPG consumption rose 4.3% to 27.41 million tons, while petrol demand plunged 9.3% to 27.27 million tons. The shift is attributed to greater residential demand for cooking fuel and the government's free LPG cylinder programme for lower-income people.

site_title: Indonesia says crashed Sriwijaya Air jet had passed airworthiness check
summary: Indonesia's transport ministry stated that the Sriwijaya Air Boeing 737-500, which crashed into the Java Sea on January 9, 2021, had passed an airworthiness inspection on December 14, 2020. The plane was grounded between March and December last year due to the pandemic. The crash killed all 62 people on board. The ministry's announcement came as a search continued to recover the plane's two black box recorders.

site_title: Pandemic's robot 'heroes' highlight their value at tech show
summary: Robots played a significant role in helping people survive and stay safe during the pandemic, with many exhibiting their value at the Consumer Electronics Show. Companion robots, such as Cutii, saw increased demand as people experienced isolation during lockdowns. These robots aim to connect individuals to others, providing emotional support and companionship. Other robots, like Misty Robotics' temperature screening app and LG's disinfecting robots, are being showcased as solutions for improved health and safety. Even after the pandemic, experts expect a continued focus on health and safety in kitchens, with automated food prep systems gaining traction.

site_title: Intel graphics chip will tap new version of TSMC 7-nanometer process: sources
summary: Intel plans to use Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's (TSMC) new 7-nanometer process to make its second-generation discrete graphics chip, DG2, to combat Nvidia's rise in the PC gaming market. The chip is expected to be released late this year or in early 2022 and will be more advanced than Nvidia's 8-nanometer process and AMD's 7-nanometer process. Intel has lost its manufacturing edge and is debating outsourcing its flagship CPU chips, with activist investor Third Point LLC urging the company to consider keeping its design and manufacturing operations under one roof.

site_title: Freezing weather in Asia sends energy prices soaring, catching markets off guard
summary: Freezing temperatures in Asia have sent energy prices soaring, catching markets off guard. China's coldest winter in decades has led to a surge in heating demand, causing record highs in electricity, fuel, and vessel prices. The extreme cold has also disrupted energy supply, with coal shipments frozen and power plants struggling to meet demand. The situation is expected to persist, with temperatures showing no signs of easing in key markets, leading to a bigger restocking need and strong pricing into the second quarter.

site_title: Australia blocks Chinese buyout of builder over security concerns
summary: Australia blocked a Chinese construction company's A$300 million bid for a domestic builder, citing national security concerns. China State Construction Engineering Corp had planned to acquire 88% of Probuild's stake, but the offer was rejected by Australia's foreign takeover regulator. The decision is seen as a sign of heightened tensions between the two trading partners. No further details on the nature of the security concerns were disclosed.

site_title: Twitter suspends 70,000 accounts linked to pro-Trump QAnon conspiracy
summary: Twitter has suspended over 70,000 accounts linked to the QAnon conspiracy theory following the US Capitol attack, with many accounts operated by a single individual. The move comes as Twitter began permanently suspending thousands of QAnon accounts on Friday. The platform aims to reduce the spread of misinformation and minimize the risk of harm following the violent events.

site_title: Gold gains as stocks dip on Washington worries, rising virus cases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,847.96 per ounce, driven by Asian stocks' decline due to US political uncertainty and rising coronavirus cases. The firmer dollar and higher US Treasury yields limited gains. Global coronavirus infections surpassed 90 million, prompting economists to consider gold underpriced and vulnerable to market volatility.

images.alt_text: Gold ticked higher on Tuesday as Asian stocks slipped on political ferment in Washington and a global surge in coronavirus cases, although a firmer dollar and higher US Treasury yields limited gains.

site_title: Alzheimer's drug shows promise in small trial
summary: A small clinical trial of Eli Lilly's Alzheimer's drug, donanemab, showed promising results, slowing the rate of cognitive decline in patients by 32% over two years. The two-year study involved 272 patients with Alzheimer's disease and found that plaques, a hallmark of the disease, were gone and stayed gone after six to 12 months of treatment. The findings, if confirmed, would be the first positive result in a Phase 2 study and offer hope for patients and their families.

site_title: UK retailers call for police help to enforce mask rules
summary: UK retailers are calling on the police to help enforce mask rules in supermarkets amid rising Covid-19 infection numbers. Morrisons and Sainsbury's have announced they will challenge people who refuse to wear masks, with security guards deployed to supermarkets. The British Retail Consortium says incidents of abuse against shop workers have risen sharply, leading to calls for police support. The government has expressed concern about the spread of the virus in supermarkets, and Prime Minister Boris Johnson has urged people to follow the guidance. Retailers argue that supermarkets are a safe environment, but enforcement is needed.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics organisers say cancellation report 'fake news'
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers downplayed a poll showing 45% of respondents favouring cancellation of the 2020 Games, citing "fake news". The poll, which took place just under 200 days before the postponed Games' start in July, was published amid a state of emergency in Tokyo due to a surge in coronavirus cases. The Tokyo 2020 CEO, Toshiro Muto, expressed confidence in the event's success despite the poll results.

site_title: 10,712 condo resale transactions in Singapore for 2020: SRX
summary: In 2020, Singapore's condo resale market showed a 18.1% increase in transactions, with a total of 10,712 properties changing hands, according to SRX Property. Resale prices rose 1.4% and the price index reached its highest level since 2019. The revival in the resale market, particularly in the second half, may have supported the new sale market. Volumes were down 5.1% in December, but prices continued to rise, with the OCR segment seeing the highest median resale price. Experts predict a moderate increase in resale transactions and prices in 2021, with possible gains of 1-4%.

site_title: World's biggest battery race gets new contender in Australia
summary: Australia has entered the world's biggest battery race with Origin Energy Ltd. announcing a 700-megawatt facility near the Eraring coal plant in New South Wales, set to start by the end of 2022. The project aims to support the country's transition to renewables and meet energy policy objectives. Other companies, including Neoen SA and Tesla Inc, have also announced plans for energy storage projects in Australia. The development comes as utilities worldwide rush to install large batteries to back up wind and solar generation, addressing power crunches and the retirement of ageing plants.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, AEM, CEI, Olam, CRCT
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) may consider listing special purpose acquisition companies and plans to launch a consultation this quarter. AEM Holdings launched a S$99.7 million buy-out bid for CEI, while Olam priced S$250 million of perpetual securities at 5.375%. CRCT sold real estate in Wuhan for S$52.6 million, and Leader Environmental Tech acquired a municipal sludge treatment company. Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics sold a stake in a joint venture, and Vallianz Holdings sold a wholly-owned subsidiary.

site_title: Asia: Stocks swing as virus and unrest offset vaccine, stimulus
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday, driven by hopes for vaccine rollout and stimulus, but concerns over surging infections, lockdowns, and US unrest. Germany's BioNTech increased vaccine production, while seven mass vaccination sites were opened in England. The US is set for a historic second impeachment of Donald Trump, which could distract from a planned stimulus bill. Markets remain cautious, with inflation expectations rising, and the Federal Reserve potentially winding down its bond-buying scheme.

site_title: Malaysian PM Muhyiddin says no curfews or military rule under emergency
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has assured the country that there will be no curfews or military rule under the emergency order in place until August 1. The civilian government will continue to function, and the emergency is not intended to suspend Parliament or avoid snap polls. Muhyiddin committed to holding a general election as soon as the Covid-19 crisis is under control. The emergency order allows the king to make necessary decrees to tackle the pandemic, including taking over private healthcare facilities if public hospitals are stretched.

site_title: Singapore gets new innovation centre in boost to advanced manufacturing sector
summary: Singapore launched the PlanetSpark Innovation Centre in Changi Business Park, aiming to boost the country's electronics and advanced manufacturing sector. The centre, developed by Excelpoint Technology and Enterprise Singapore, will nurture AI and IoT startups, with an initial investment of S$5 million to support over 30 startups in the next three years. The centre's goal is to enhance Singapore's competitiveness in these sectors and foster innovation.

site_title: Pilgrim's Pride, Tyson Foods settle some chicken price-fixing litigation
summary: Pilgrim's Pride Corp and Tyson Foods Inc have settled price-fixing litigation with US$75 million and an undisclosed amount, respectively, to resolve claims of conspiring to inflate chicken prices. The settlements do not affect claims by indirect purchasers, such as restaurant and supermarket operators, nor claims against other defendants. This is the largest settlement in over four years of litigation and follows Pilgrim's Pride's agreement to pay a $110.5 million fine to resolve a US Department of Justice criminal price-fixing probe.

site_title: PayPal blocks site that helped raise funds for those who attended Capitol violence
summary: PayPal has blocked a Christian crowdfunding site, GiveSendGo, after it helped raise funds for individuals who attended the US Capitol violence, where supporters of President Donald Trump stormed the building. PayPal also closed an account held by Ali Alexander, one of the event's organizers. Twitter has suspended over 70,000 accounts sharing QAnon content, and several major US companies have cut off campaign contributions to those who challenged President-elect Joe Biden's victory. The moves follow growing corporate distaste for those involved in the violence.

site_title: Samsung bets on bespoke fridges to win millennials
summary: Samsung Electronics Co plans to focus on personalized home appliances, particularly fridges, to win over younger customers in the post-pandemic era. The company's home appliance business is expected to report a 10% increase in sales for 2020, driven by a boom in sales of refrigerators and cleaners during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, demand is expected to weaken in the second half of 2021 as subsidies wane and people return to normal life. Samsung will aggressively introduce new products to maintain market share and provide differentiated offerings to overcome challenges.

site_title: SoftBank sells US$2b of Uber stake after stock recovery
summary: SoftBank sold approximately US$2 billion in Uber stock after the ride-hailing giant's shares increased. The sale was made by an affiliate of SoftBank's Vision Fund, which still holds about 184.2 million shares worth around US$10 billion. This move comes after SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's aggressive investment in Uber, which faced challenges following its 2019 IPO and the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Japan PM says to add Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo to state of emergency: Kyodo
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga plans to declare a state of emergency for Osaka, Kyoto, and Hyogo prefectures to combat the spread of Covid-19, following pressure from Tokyo and neighboring prefectures. This move comes after a state of emergency was already declared for the greater Tokyo metropolitan area. The decision aims to stem the spread of the virus in western Japan.

site_title: Deliveroo to expand into 100 new UK towns and cities in 2021
summary: Deliveroo plans to expand into 100 new UK towns and cities in 2021, increasing its reach to around 4 million more people and bringing its total potential customers to almost two-thirds of the UK population. The company's expansion aims to capitalize on the surge in home delivery demand during the Covid-19 pandemic. Deliveroo also plans to expand in 150 existing areas, taking its total ridership to over 50,000. The move is seen as a strategic step to capitalize on the growing demand for food delivery services in the UK.

site_title: New US tariffs on French, German aircraft parts to start on Tuesday
summary: The US will begin collecting new duties on aircraft parts and other products from France and Germany on Tuesday, as part of the long-running Boeing-Airbus subsidy battle. The tariffs include 15% on aircraft parts and 25% on certain wines. This move follows a US Trade Representative's office announcement, with US Customs and Border Protection set to start collections at 12:01am ET. The tariffs are part of the ongoing dispute over subsidies for the two European aircraft manufacturers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 5.54 points to 1,611.71, with a 0.34% decline. Losers outpaced gainers 244 to 137, and volume reached 110.18 million lots worth RM72.78 million.

site_title: Japan government offers cash payouts to small firms hit hard by coronavirus
summary: Japan's government will offer 400,000 yen (S$5,100) cash payouts to small firms experiencing a 50% or greater sales loss due to the coronavirus pandemic, and 200,000 yen for individuals facing similar losses. The measures aim to ease the health crisis without requiring adjustments to existing state budgets. Finance Minister Taro Aso made the announcement after a cabinet meeting.

images.alt_text: Japan's government will offer 400,000 yen (S$5,100) cash payouts to small firms that suffer sales loss by half or more and 200,000 yen for individuals who face a similar extent of sales loss due to shorter hours over the coronavirus pandemic, Finance Minister Taro Aso said.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a retreat on Wall Street fueled by profit-taking. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.05% to 27,894.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.38% to 3,518.01. Investors kept an eye on surging virus infections.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Tuesday slightly lower following a retreat on Wall Street fuelled by profit-taking, with investors keeping tabs on surging virus infections.

site_title: Malaysia's king declares state of emergency to curb spread of Covid-19
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah declared a state of emergency to curb the spread of Covid-19, giving Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin extraordinary powers to introduce laws without Parliament's approval. The emergency, which will last until August 1 or earlier, comes amid a razor-thin majority in Parliament and opposition calls for Muhyiddin's resignation. The move is seen as a proactive measure to combat the pandemic, but its impact on day-to-day activities remains unclear.

site_title: Ascott cracks record unit growth despite Covid-19
summary: The Ascott Limited, a subsidiary of Capitaland, achieved a four-year streak of record growth in property units in 2020, adding 14,200 units across 71 properties globally. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, this exceeded the 14,100 units added in 2019. The new units are expected to boost annual fee income by over S$27 million. Ascott's CEO Kevin Goh expects over 80 properties with 17,000 units to open in 2021, primarily in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Covid-19, digitalisation challenged Singapore listcos' audit committees in 2020: Review
summary: A review of audit committees at Singapore-listed companies found that the COVID-19 pandemic and digitalization posed significant challenges, increasing workloads and risks. The top concerns for audit committees included managing liquidity, going concerns, and internal controls risks. While some companies took steps to address these challenges, the review noted that audit committees may not have fully considered cyber security risks. The review's findings led to calls for tighter rules governing boards of listed issuers in Singapore, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore urging companies to appoint more diverse and independent directors.

site_title: South Korea regulator to lift ban on share short selling from March 15
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission (FSC) announced it will lift the ban on share short selling of listed shares on the Kospi and Kosdaq starting March 15. The ban, which has been in place since March 13, 2020, aimed to curb speculative trading amid the coronavirus outbreak. The Kospi index has surged nearly 120% since its lows, with investors looking towards a broad recovery in the country's economy.

site_title: Japan bank lending, deposits keep rising in Dec as pandemic strains persist
summary: Japan's bank lending and deposits reached new records in December, with outstanding loans increasing 6.2% to 577.6 trillion yen and total deposits surging 9.3% to 802.9 trillion yen. Companies are holding back on capital expenditure due to the pandemic, leading to increased deposits. The Bank of Japan eased monetary policy to cushion the economic blow, but the government's new state of emergency measures have clouded the outlook for Japan's economy, which is the world's third-largest. Lending by cash-strapped firms has peaked, and the government's actions may further impact the economy.

site_title: Trump, Pence signal common front with Oval Office meeting
summary: US President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence met in the Oval Office, signaling a united front against Democrats' calls for Pence to remove Trump due to his fitness for office. Trump has no intention of resigning before his term ends, and Pence has no plans to invoke the 25th Amendment. They reaffirmed that those who stormed the Capitol last week do not represent the "America first" movement. The House of Representatives will vote on a resolution calling for Pence to invoke the 25th Amendment on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia records handful of new coronavirus cases as national frictions grow
summary: Australia reported a handful of new locally acquired coronavirus cases, with one case in Queensland and five in New South Wales. The cases were linked to the highly infectious UK strain, prompting a three-day lockdown in Queensland. In New South Wales, two mystery cases led to a hospital closure for deep cleaning. The recent surge in cases has heightened tensions between state leaders over the best approach to manage the outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Australia recorded a handful of new locally acquired coronavirus cases on Tuesday, with frictions increasing between state leaders over the best approach to manage and contain the outbreaks.

site_title: Indonesia uses unmanned undersea vehicle in hunt for air crash victims, 'black boxes'
summary: Indonesia has deployed a remotely operated underwater vehicle to search for victims and recover flight recorders from a Sriwijaya Air Boeing 737-500 jet that crashed into the Java Sea on January 9. The plane, carrying 62 people, disappeared four minutes after takeoff from Jakarta. Indonesian police identified the first victim, flight attendant Okky Bisma, and a vehicle is now scouring the seabed for debris. The recovery of the flight recorders is expected to take three days, with investigators relying on the data to determine what caused the catastrophic loss of control after takeoff.

site_title: Olam International prices S$250m perps at 5.375%
summary: Olam International priced S$250 million of perpetual securities at 5.375% following an intraday book-building exercise. The new perps are expected to be issued at par on Jan 18, 2021, under the US$5 billion euro medium-term note programme. The issue was well-subscribed, with the final distribution rate tightened from 5.5%. The perps will bear a 5.375% distribution rate for the first five-and-a-half years, resetting at a rate equivalent to the prevailing swap offer rate plus a step-up margin. The issuance will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Singapore stocks drop following Wall Street decline; STI down 0.3% at open
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.3% at the open on Tuesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 8.70 points to 2,975.20. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 45, with Genting Singapore gaining 1.2% and CEI jumping 15%. The decline was attributed to US equities retreating from records set last week due to investors taking profits and Democrats' efforts to impeach President Donald Trump.

site_title: UK consumer spending slides in December as pandemic flares: Barclaycard
summary: UK consumer spending fell 2.3% in December, the largest drop in six months, due to a surge in coronavirus cases. Spending in pubs and restaurants plummeted 71% and 65%, respectively, while grocery sales soared. The decline was attributed to the late rollout of coronavirus vaccines and subsequent lockdown. Economists predict this will tip Britain back into recession.

site_title: Moderna says Covid-19 vaccine immunity to stay at least a year
summary: Moderna Inc. announced that its Covid-19 vaccine, mRNA-1273, provides immunity that lasts at least a year. The company is confident in its mRNA technology to combat the new coronavirus variant and expects to deliver 600-1 billion doses in 2021, with forecasted sales of $11.7 billion. CEO Stéphane Bancel stated the team feels "very comfortable" with the vaccine's track record, indicating a promising start to vaccine distribution.

site_title: Trump protest outside Twitter HQ over ban flops
summary: A planned protest outside Twitter's San Francisco headquarters against the social media platform's ban of Donald Trump fizzled out, with only a few supporters attending. The protest was called for in response to Twitter's permanent ban on Trump's account, which was imposed due to multiple rule violations and the risk of further violence. Despite police presence and security measures, the turnout was significantly lower than expected. The incident follows the storming of the US Capitol by Trump supporters last week, and the ongoing impeachment process against Trump for "incitement of insurrection."

site_title: Ford to close its factories in Brazil
summary: Ford is closing its three factories in Brazil due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the country's slow sales, resulting in significant losses. The closures will affect approximately 5,000 workers and incur one-off charges of about US$4.1 billion. Ford is shifting to a "lean, asset-light business model" and will continue serving South America with cars sourced from other markets. The company will maintain its product development center and regional headquarters in Brazil.

site_title: SGX RegCo announces enhanced rules on auditors, valuers
summary: SGX RegCo has announced enhanced rules for auditors and valuers in Singapore, effective February 12, 2021. Primary-listed issuers must appoint an auditor registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA), while secondary-listed issuers from certain developed markets may continue to use auditors from their jurisdiction. Property valuers must have at least five years of experience and be independent of issuers. The changes aim to improve market assurance and investor confidence, and will be enforced through enhanced regulatory oversight and deterrence mechanisms.

site_title: Portuguese president tests positive for coronavirus
summary: Portugal's President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa has tested positive for coronavirus, cancelling all public engagements just two weeks before a presidential election he is expected to win. The 72-year-old head of state is asymptomatic and isolating in the presidential palace. Portugal is facing a new lockdown amid a surge in new cases, with nearly 4,000 people in hospital. The presidential election campaign will be suspended due to the lockdown, with polls predicting Rebelo de Sousa's re-election.

images.alt_text: Portugal's President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa has tested positive for coronavirus and cancelled all public engagements, his office announced late Monday just two weeks before a presidential election he is expected to win.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials see strong economic rebound, fanning talk of taper
summary: Federal Reserve officials predict a strong US economic rebound in the second half of 2021, fueled by fiscal support and vaccine distribution. They may discuss tapering of bond buying, potentially as early as late 2021, with some officials open to raising interest rates in 2022 or 2023 if growth exceeds expectations. However, officials emphasize that any tapering will be communicated in advance to avoid market volatility, similar to the 2013 taper tantrum. The Fed aims to see "substantial further progress" on employment and inflation before adjusting its monetary policy.

site_title: Garage's 10 startups to watch in 2021
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Business Times has identified 10 startups to watch in 2021, including Gojek and Tokopedia's potential merger, Grab's battle for dominance in Indonesia, and Medtech firm Mirxes' expansion into six new cities. Insurtech company CXA is burning cash and may face financial woes. Biotech startup Hummingbird Bioscience is developing a Covid-19 antibody treatment. Fashion commerce startup Zilingo has made significant staff cuts and is rebuilding. Prestige Biopharma is pursuing an IPO on the Korea Exchange. Fintech startup M-DAQ is planning an IPO, and coworking operator JustCo is expanding globally.

site_title: Parler sues Amazon over web shutdown
summary: Parler, a conservative-friendly social platform, sued Amazon on Monday after its web division shut down the site for failing to curb violent content. Parler alleged Amazon's actions violated antitrust laws and aimed to help Twitter, which banned President Donald Trump and other accounts promoting violence. The lawsuit seeks a restraining order to block Amazon Web Services from cutting off access to internet servers. Amazon denied the lawsuit, stating that Parler's content incited violence and violating its terms of service.

site_title: US banks cast wary eye at mortgage borrowers as forbearance periods end
summary: US banks are uncertain about the performance of their mortgage portfolios as forbearance periods end, with a growing share of mortgage loans in forbearance and minimal auto loans and credit cards in arrears. The mortgage forbearance program, imposed by US agencies, doesn't require proof of hardship, unlike other credit products. This has lenders bracing for potential losses across most credit products, particularly mortgages, as enhanced jobless benefits and forbearance periods expire. The outcome will be closely watched as lenders struggle to predict borrower behavior.

site_title: Europe: Soaring virus cases knock stocks off 10-month high
summary: Europe's stock markets fell on Monday, retreating from a 10-month high, due to surging coronavirus cases across the continent and mainland China. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 0.7%, with Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 also falling. Optimism over US fiscal stimulus was tempered by concerns about the pandemic's impact on the economy. Meanwhile, some sectors like banks, energy, and mining remained relatively stable, while travel and leisure stocks declined.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.61% and the Topix index down 0.42%. Investors were disheartened by falls on Wall Street and concerns over rising virus cases in Japan. The market decline comes amid US-EU trade talks and tariff threats, which traders are brushing off.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday with investors disheartened by falls on Wall Street and facing concern over continued rises in virus cases in Japan.

site_title: Acting US Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf resigns
summary: US Acting Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf resigned on January 11, 2021, amid concerns of potential violence during President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration. No reason was given for the resignation. Pete Gaynor, the Federal Emergency Management Agency administrator, will take over.

images.alt_text: Chad Wolf, the acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, resigned on Monday amid rising worries over the possibility of more violence during President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration next week, a DHS official said.

site_title: Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care picks banks for US$300m IPO
summary: Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care has selected Credit Suisse, Malayan Banking, and Morgan Stanley as arrangers for a potential US$300 million initial public offering (IPO) in Kuala Lumpur. The IPO, which could take place in the second half of this year, would be the healthcare firm's first listing. The selection follows discussions by Malaysian conglomerate Sime Darby on spinoff plans for the healthcare unit, which it jointly owns with Ramsay Health Care.

site_title: Brent crude falls on renewed lockdowns, stronger dollar
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday after strong gains last week, falling 33 cents to settle at US$55.66 a barrel for Brent crude. Renewed coronavirus lockdowns and a stronger US dollar weighed on prices, while a Saudi pledge to cut 1 million barrels per day also supported oil prices. Despite this, analysts expect Brent to rise to US$65 per barrel by summer 2021. Worldwide coronavirus cases surpassed 90 million, with new outbreaks in China and other countries.

site_title: US: Wall Street retreats from records amid political turmoil
summary: US stocks retreated from records on Monday amid political uncertainty, despite ignoring the violent invasion of the US Capitol by Trump supporters last week. The Dow Jones Industrial Index fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.2%. Investors are concerned about rising Covid-19 cases, vaccine rollout issues, and the impeachment process against President Trump, which could distract from President-elect Joe Biden's economic aid plans. Tech companies affected by Trump's account ban and Parler's platform loss also saw significant declines.

site_title: WHO rules out Covid-19 herd immunity this year
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has ruled out achieving herd immunity to Covid-19 this year due to the rapid spread of the virus and the emergence of new variants. Despite efforts to boost vaccine production, scientists warn that it will take time to produce and administer enough doses to halt the spread of the virus. The WHO's chief scientist, Soumya Swaminathan, stated that maintaining physical distancing, hand-washing, and mask-wearing is crucial to controlling the pandemic. The WHO is also sending a team to China to investigate the origins of the disease.

site_title: Twitter's 'problematic' Trump ban troubles Europe
summary: Twitter's permanent ban on US President Donald Trump's account has sparked controversy in Europe, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel calling it "problematic." The EU has introduced proposals to regulate digital giants, with European Commissioner Thierry Breton seeing the ban as a "9/11 moment of social media." The move has led to a flood of reactions worldwide, with many calling for increased regulation of social media companies, citing concerns over freedom of expression and the power wielded by these companies.

site_title: Government bailouts of national carriers: not all are strategic assets
summary: Ryanair challenges the European Commission's approval of state aid for flag carriers Scandinavian Airlines, TAP Air Portugal, Finnair, Air France, KLM, and Lufthansa, citing concerns over the financial sustainability of these airlines. CEO Michael O'Leary argues that bailouts are not strategic assets and should only be provided to carriers with a symbiotic relationship with the country, such as Singapore Airlines. He advocates for a more judicious use of taxpayer funds, investing in areas with competitive advantages, and mandating airlines to set aside a percentage of profits for a rainy day fund.

site_title: Hedge funds head for cover as dollar rebound gathers pace
summary: The US dollar is experiencing a rebound, with speculative traders covering short positions and adding to dollar demand, according to data from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The dollar surged 0.5% against the euro and 0.3% against the pound, with benchmark Treasury yields surging 20 basis points last week. Investors expect more short-term dollar strength ahead, driven by the Democratic Party's control of Congress and push for fiscal stimulus. A steepening yield curve could also benefit the dollar, but experts warn that yields must rise above pre-pandemic levels for a "proper scare".

site_title: Dutch customs seize sandwiches from UK passengers after Brexit
summary: Dutch customs officials have confiscated sandwiches from UK passengers on a ferry, citing new post-Brexit trade rules. The rules, which came into effect on January 1, prohibit bringing foods containing meat or dairy into the EU for personal use, aiming to prevent disease spread. The confiscations were filmed at the Hook of Holland port, with drivers being told they could not take off the meat to leave the bread. The incident highlights the challenges faced by UK citizens traveling to the EU under the new rules.

site_title: Digital bonds: It all comes down to trust
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) recent "digital bond" issuance has sparked debate on the possibility of digital bonds passing legal scrutiny and earning trust. The pilot, which used digital ledger technology and self-executing smart contracts, cut settlement times in half and eliminated manual processes. However, creating a truly digital bond requires eliminating the physical bond and establishing a robust legal basis. Governments and law reform agencies are working to address trust concerns, with Germany's recent laws granting formal recognition to electronic debt securities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has also extended its regulatory scheme to digital tokens, but the underlying questions remain unanswered.

site_title: Business travel with the ATP
summary: The Air Travel Pass (ATP) is a short-term visa permitting business travel to Singapore for any purpose, potentially easier for China counterparts than the Reciprocal Green Lane. The ATP can be a better option for businesses, particularly those dealing with Chinese partners. Meanwhile, a specialist healthcare center is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, controlled by Sojitz. Additionally, a startup aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: Ten startups to watch in 2021
summary: The tech community is expected to experience an exciting 2021, with numerous potential deals, mergers, and acquisitions. Ten startups to watch in 2021 include GoTo, OpenAI, Manus, Bluebird, and DeepSeek, which are poised for significant growth. GoTo shares are tipped for a rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off, while OpenAI plans to release a web browser to challenge Google Chrome. Chinese AI startup Manus accelerates its move to Singapore amid the intensifying AI race.

site_title: Indonesia approves China's Sinovac vaccine; begins nationwide inoculations
summary: Indonesia has approved China's Sinovac vaccine for emergency use, launching nationwide inoculations amid surging COVID-19 infections and deaths. The approval comes as public health experts raise concerns about varying efficacy rates and lack of data, potentially undermining public trust. This marks Indonesia's first emergency use approval outside of China, making it the world's fourth most populous country to do so.

site_title: KKR raises US$3.9b in biggest Asia-Pacific infrastructure fund
summary: KKR has raised US$3.9 billion for its first Asia-Pacific infrastructure fund, surpassing its initial target. The firm, which has already invested over US$1.8 billion in six infrastructure investments in Asia, plans to focus on brownfield, cash yield investments with downside projections. KKR's expansion in the region is seen as a response to increasing demand from institutional investors seeking a "one-stop shop" with deal-making, operational, and capital market expertise. The firm's global infrastructure team and strategy were established in 2008, and it now has a 14-member team in Asia with plans to add more.

site_title: SGX looking into listing of special purpose acquisition companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering listing special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs) and may launch a consultation as early as this quarter. The move comes amid the popularity of Spacs listings in other markets, with the US seeing $78 billion raised in 2020. SGX sees Spacs as a way to provide faster time to market and more certainty in terms of price and execution, benefiting the Singapore capital markets ecosystem and increasing the vibrancy of mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: China to push tech giants to share consumer credit data, say sources
summary: China plans to require tech giants including Ant Group, Tencent, and JD.com to share consumer loan data to prevent excess borrowing and fraud. This move aims to tighten scrutiny on the industry and rein in technology champions. The plan, if implemented, would effectively end the government's laissez-faire approach to the sector, which has seen large Internet platforms resist handing over their data. This marks another step in China's efforts to regulate its booming tech industry and address concerns about financial stability.

site_title: Ship orders slump to 20-year low with owners unsure which green fuel to use
summary: Ship owners are delaying new vessel orders due to uncertainty over which alternative fuels to use, resulting in a 20-year low in ship orders. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) aims to cut shipping's greenhouse-gas emissions in half by 2050, prompting ship owners to wait for scalable solutions. Currently, only 12.3% of vessels on order have alternative-fuel propulsion, compared to 0.6% of the global fleet. The industry is exploring options like ammonia, hydrogen, and biofuels, but a clear choice is needed to meet the IMO's targets and avoid a potential shortage of vessels and spike in freight rates.

site_title: Singapore, other regional bourses end session lower; STI down 0.31%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.31% lower on Monday, ending at 2,983.90. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top performer, gaining 5.87%, while City Developments was the worst performer, falling 2.18%. Asia markets also ended in the red, with China's producer price index falling 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index closing 1.08% lower. The STI's decline was attributed to a high base of comparison for the consumer price index, which rose 0.2% in December.

site_title: Business opportunities aplenty in Africa: SBF
summary: Singapore-based companies are increasingly expanding into Africa, with over 60 firms operating in more than 40 markets. The continent offers vast opportunities, despite common misconceptions of high-risk ventures. The African Continental Free Trade Area, launched in January, is expected to become the world's largest free-trade zone by 2030. With six of the world's 10 fastest-growing economies in Africa, Singapore's direct investment in the continent reached $19 billion in 2017. Businesses are advised to thoroughly study opportunities and have reliable local partners to succeed in Africa.

images.alt_text: Ranveer Chauhan, chairman of Singapore Business Federation's African Business Group, during a visit to Gabon. "Africa is not only for the big (companies), and it doesn't offer only high-risk opportunities. It is a big market, with a multitude of opportunities."

site_title: New York City's High Line park to get US$60m link to brand-new train station
summary: New York City's High Line park is set to receive a $60 million link to the newly opened Moynihan Train Hall, a project aimed at improving mass transportation in the city. The expansion will provide an alternative way to access the train hall and is part of a broader package seeking to boost the local economy. The project, which will include a 366-meter elevated walkway, is expected to connect the existing High Line at 30th Street to a pedestrian path at Manhattan West. The expansion has raised concerns about spending during a financial crisis, but Governor Andrew Cuomo believes it is crucial for the city's future.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng warns of FY2020 loss due to adverse Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore-based property developer Chip Eng Seng expects to report a FY2020 net loss of S$25.7 million, wider than the H1 2020 loss of S$25.7 million, due to the impact of Covid-19 on its businesses. The group's property segment was affected by construction site closures, slow construction demand, and increased project costs. Additionally, Chip Eng Seng's hospitality businesses and property investment segment are expected to incur significant impairment losses and doubtful debts, respectively. The company will announce the full year net loss in mid-February 2021.

site_title: AGC reviewing training for prosecutors
summary: The Attorney-General of Singapore, Lucien Wong, announced the review of training for prosecutors to strengthen the administration of justice. This comes after "imperfections" in the past year led to intense scrutiny and criticism. Internal guidance has been drawn up and division-wide briefings held to ensure prosecutors disclose documents to the defence. The review aims to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the prosecution process.

site_title: Renovation boom in pandemic augurs well for profits, says building materials supplier
summary: SIG, a building materials supplier, expects losses for 2020 to be at the "better end" of its expectations, with a possible return to profitability in the second half of 2021. The company attributes this to solid demand for renovation and maintenance during the pandemic, particularly in the UK and France. Despite a 13% decline in revenue for 2020, SIG reported a 4% increase in like-for-like revenue in the fourth quarter. The company's new CEO is focusing on sales and margin revival, and its operations remain open despite a third national lockdown in England.

site_title: China's Baidu to create a smart EV company with automaker Geely
summary: China's search engine giant Baidu Inc is setting up a company to partner with carmaker Zhejiang Geely Holding Group to make smart electric vehicles. The new EV company will utilize Baidu's intelligent driving capabilities and Geely's car manufacturing expertise. Geely will be a strategic investor and hold a minority stake. This move comes as tech companies worldwide are racing to develop smart cars, following Tesla's success in commercializing EVs.

site_title: What next for the 'Make America great again' insurrection?
summary: US President Donald Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol on January 6, 2021, with the goal of overturning the presidential election results. Trump had told his audience that the election was "stolen" and urged them to "stop the steal" and "take back our country." The violence resulted in vandalism, destruction of memorials, and a break-in of the Senate chamber. Despite Trump's claims of a "landslide" victory, the election was won by Democratic candidates, and Vice President Kamala Harris will cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate. The Capitol storming led to the halving of Republican senators who objected to the certification of the election, and the failure of Trump's calls to action.

site_title: New hongbao notes generate 330 tons of emissions - MAS pushing for e-gifting
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is pushing for e-gifting of new hongbao notes during the Lunar New Year celebrations to reduce emissions. The production of new notes generates 330 tons of carbon emissions annually, equivalent to charging 5.7 million smartphones for five days. The MAS encourages online reservations for physical notes at participating banks, aiming to reduce queues and waste. China has already adopted e-gifting, with 823 million packets sent or received via WeChat in 2019.

site_title: Building a safe, secure, sustainable agriculture sector in Asian countries
summary: Asia's food consumption is rapidly changing due to population growth and urbanization, but the region faces capacity constraints in meeting demand, with arable land and water per capita declining. To address this, businesses should tap into innovative agritech solutions to modernize operations and boost supply chain resilience. Key areas include ramping up local food supply, driving food production and productivity, taking food safety to a higher level, and making the agriculture sector more sustainable. Financial institutions can also support sustainable financing to help businesses access sustainable loans.

site_title: Continued global cooperation key to recovery: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of global cooperation in the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. He stated that if vaccine rollout is successful and policy stimulus continues, the global economy may start to recover in the second half of 2021. Heng highlighted three key areas for cooperation: public health, climate change, and digital governance. This cooperation can help the world rebuild and emerge stronger from the crisis.

site_title: Can immersive art remain afloat when money is the object?
summary: For-profit immersive art centers are investing heavily in a struggling industry, despite the pandemic's impact on tourism. Companies like Fotografiska and Meow Wolf are expanding to new cities and wooing investors, with Fotografiska announcing plans for a fourth location in Berlin and Meow Wolf investing $158 million in new locations. Despite a lack of audience in the US due to the pandemic, industry leaders remain confident, citing growing demand for immersive experiences and the potential for long-term growth. However, critics question the motivations of for-profit art centers, arguing that they prioritize investor returns over community investment.

site_title: NZ central bank says it was not specific target of cyberattack
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), said a cyberattack that breached its data systems also affected a third-party application, not specifically targeting the bank. The file-sharing service, provided by California-based Accellion, was taken offline during investigations. RBNZ governor Adrian Orr stated that the bank's core functions and financial system remain sound, with no indication of a state-backed attack. The incident is part of an escalation in cyberattacks, and experts suggest the possibility of state-backed involvement, prompting further investigation with domestic and international cybersecurity experts.

site_title: Calls for Malaysia to have stronger Covid strategy
summary: Malaysia's Movement Control Order (MCO) needs additional initiatives to recover its economy and healthcare system. Malaysian senator Liew Chin Tong suggests increasing testing capacity, hiring temporary contact tracers, and medical practitioners to roll out the vaccine. This would help mitigate the impact of the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian raises target price for Singapore Medical Group on potential offer
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price for Singapore Medical Group (SMG) to S$0.46, up from S$0.37, following the company's Dec 20 disclosure of a possible transaction. Analyst Lucas Teng expects SMG to recover its patient load to 80-85% of pre-Covid levels in 2021, boosting earnings. With a forward P/E of 17, SMG is trading at a discount to recent offer premiums and peers' average. The stock has risen 12% since the announcement, closing 4.6% higher at 34.5 cents.

site_title: New Senior Counsel appointed from public, private and academic sectors
summary: Three Senior Counsel have been appointed for the new legal year in Singapore, including Abraham Vergis, managing director of Providence Law Asia; Kristy Tan, senior director of the Attorney-General's Chambers; and Goh Yihan, dean of the Singapore Management University's School of Law. The appointments, announced by Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon, bring the total number of Senior Counsel to 91. The three newly-minted Senior Counsel expressed their interest in mentoring young legal practitioners and inspiring aspiring lawyers, with Vergis highlighting the need for creative approaches to law and Tan aiming to demonstrate different possibilities in the practise of law.

site_title: Fortress Minerals soars 19.6% on earnings jump, proposed acquisition
summary: Fortress Minerals shares surged 19.6% in late morning trading after posting a 5.5-cent gain, reaching an intra-day high of 33.5 Singapore cents. The company reported a net profit of US$4.3 million for the third quarter, more than five times that of the previous year. Revenue more than doubled to US$10.3 million, driven by higher volume and pricing for iron ore concentrates. The company also proposed a US$30 million acquisition of a Malaysian miner, Monument Mengapur.

site_title: WHO to probe virus origins in China as infections rise globally
summary: A 10-member World Health Organization (WHO) team is set to arrive in China this week to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, amid global surges in infections and deaths. The team will conduct joint research with Chinese scientists, following accusations that Beijing tried to block the investigation. The pandemic has infected over 90 million people worldwide, killing nearly 2 million, with Europe facing its "hardest" days ahead and Britain racing to vaccinate its population. The investigation comes after international criticism of China's lack of transparency during the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong's Hang Seng overhaul could offer investors more opportunities
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index is set to undergo changes, increasing the number of constituents from 52 to 65-80, and lowering the weighting cap to 8%. The overhaul aims to broaden industry coverage and dilute the influence of large financial companies. While it may not significantly impact market trading volume, it could provide more opportunities for investors to access blue-chip companies that have been overlooked. The changes are expected to benefit healthcare, consumer staples, and infrastructure companies, and could lead to higher valuations and greater volatility.

site_title: Top global oil exporter Saudi Arabia launches car-free city
summary: Saudi Arabia's US$500 billion Neom project, dubbed The Line, has been launched as an eco-city with zero cars, zero streets, and zero carbon emissions. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman unveiled the plans, which include a city of a million residents, 95% nature preservation, and high-speed public transportation. Construction will begin in the first quarter of this year, creating 380,000 jobs and contributing 180 billion riyals to the kingdom's GDP by 2030, powered by 100% clean energy and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Euro slips to two-week low as US yields rise
summary: The euro fell to a two-week low against the US dollar, reaching US$1.2167, due to rising US Treasury yields and expectations of more fiscal stimulus under President-elect Joe Biden. This has lifted the US dollar, which rose to a one-month high against the Japanese yen. Investors are trimming their bearish bets on the US dollar, and the currency index has lost 12% since its three-year peak in March, now above its almost three-year low.

site_title: US Capitol violence obscures serious foreign cyber-hacks
summary: A recent major cyber-hack by Russia has compromised up to 10 US government bodies, including the US Treasury, and dozens of Treasury e-mail accounts. The breach, which was undiscovered for months, is attributed to SVR, Russia's foreign intelligence agency, and is considered a significant threat to US financial and national security interests. US President-elect Joe Biden is expected to take meaningful steps to respond to the breach, including financial penalties and retaliatory hacks on Russian infrastructure. The incident has overshadowed the US Capitol violence, which has dominated media headlines since.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. In the Singapore stock market, NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks edged down from records, with concerns over tariff threats. Companies like Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected revenue and operating losses. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Industrial Reits set to continue bullish run in 2021: analysts
summary: Analysts predict industrial Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) in Singapore will continue their bullish run in 2021, driven by low interest rates, high demand for logistics warehouses and data centers, and growth in e-commerce. Experts cite the zero interest rate environment and liquidity conditions in Asian markets as factors contributing to the outperformance of industrial Reits. They expect these Reits to deliver strong earnings and growth, with some analysts picking winners such as Ascendas Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The High Court will hear winding-up applications against two Ezion Holdings' subsidiaries on January 28. New Silkroutes Group appointed Lim Eng Seng as an independent director. Vallianz Holdings sold a subsidiary for US$1, while Leader Environmental Technologies bought a municipal sludge treatment company for S$281,700. Capitaland Retail China Trust sold a stake in a mall for S$53 million and Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics sold a joint venture stake for S$3.7 million.

site_title: Half of Swiss hotels, restaurants risk bankruptcy
summary: Nearly half of Switzerland's restaurants and hotels risk bankruptcy within months due to failing financial support. Industry group GastroSuisse warns that 98% of businesses in the restauration and hospitality sector need urgent financial assistance, with around 50% at risk of going bankrupt by the end of March. The sector's financial struggles come amid stubbornly high coronavirus case and death numbers, with the Swiss government expected to extend closures until the end of February without providing significant financial support.

site_title: China consumer prices rise in December ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: China's consumer prices rose 0.2% year-on-year in December, driven by food price increases ahead of the Chinese New Year festival, with fresh produce and meats experiencing price hikes. Pork prices dropped 1.3% year-on-year, while vegetable costs are expected to decrease after winter. The rebound follows the first negative reading in over a decade the previous month. Economists predict steady consumer prices moving forward, with pork prices stabilizing and vegetable costs dropping, as vaccinations progress and demand for consumer goods increases.

site_title: Worst Bitcoin plunge since March shakes faith in crypto boom
summary: Bitcoin experienced its worst two-day plunge since March, with a 21% drop to $32,389, fueling concerns that the cryptocurrency boom may be unsustainable. The price has more than quadrupled in the past year, evoking memories of the 2017 mania. Analysts are divided, with some, like Scott Minerd, predicting a correction, while others, like Howard Wang, believe it's in a bubble. The cryptocurrency's rally is seen as untethered from reason by some, while others argue it's matured with institutional investors.

site_title: KKR bets US$200m on OneRepublic frontman Ryan Tedder's catalogue
summary: Private equity firm KKR has agreed to buy a majority stake in Ryan Tedder's music catalogue, valued at nearly US$200 million, for US$200m. The catalogue includes hits like "Counting Stars" and "Apologize" and features co-written songs with artists such as Beyonce, Lady Gaga, and U2. Tedder's management and artist development companies will also participate in the equity transaction. Record label Interscope Records retains ownership of OneRepublic's master recordings. KKR aims to expand Tedder's music reach through its experience in digital, media, and music businesses.

site_title: China's biggest daily Covid-19 case jump in 5 months
summary: Mainland China reported its largest daily increase in Covid-19 cases in over five months, with 103 new infections on January 10. The majority of cases were in Hebei province surrounding Beijing, with 82 new local infections reported. The country also saw 18 new imported infections from overseas, bringing the total number of new cases to 103, the highest since July 30. Authorities are taking aggressive measures to curb the spread of the virus, including lockdowns and travel restrictions, ahead of a visit from a World Health Organization team investigating the pandemic's origins.

site_title: Bitcoin eyes gold's role and cryptos are here to stay
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's arrival has raised concerns among bitcoin investors that regulators and central banks may become hostile towards cryptocurrencies. Despite this, digital currencies are expected to remain popular as investment vehicles and stores of value. Bitcoin's market value has roughly doubled since Yellen's dismissive remarks in 2017, and its price continues to rise despite high transaction costs and limited use for payments. The technology behind cryptocurrencies, particularly blockchain, is improving, and private competitors denominated in new currencies like bitcoin may be heavily regulated or discouraged.

site_title: RBI squeezes money markets to spur sell-off in shorter bonds
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has taken its first step towards unwinding emergency pandemic measures by increasing key money market rates and yields on short-term debt. The weighted interbank call rate rose to 3.44% and the yield on a five-year bond surged 13 basis points. The RBI plans to drain liquidity via a reverse repo operation, which is expected to nudge short-term interest rates to converge to the reverse repo rate. This move is seen as a signal to slowly exit from extraordinary accommodation measures, which have caused liquidity to surge.

site_title: North Korea in show of force after lambasting US
summary: North Korea staged a military parade as part of its grand party congress, showcasing its military capabilities and nuclear ambitions under leader Kim Jong Un. The event came after Kim lambasted the US, declaring it his "biggest main enemy" and predicting that Washington's "hostile policy" toward Pyongyang would remain under the Biden administration. North Korea's nuclear plans include developing smaller and lighter nuclear weapons, ICBMs, and nuclear-powered submarines, posing a significant challenge to the US and its allies. The event signals a contentious approach toward the new administration, with analysts warning that North Korea will continue to test and advance its nuclear capabilities if its demands are not met.

site_title: Black Wednesday at the Capitol: What Trump and Trumpism have wrought
summary: US President Donald Trump's actions on January 6, 2021, led to a violent mob storming the Capitol Building, forcing a lockdown and curfew in Washington, DC. The event was incited by Trump's baseless claims of a rigged election and his calls to his supporters to "take back our country." The violent attack on American democracy was a dark day in the nation's history, orchestrated by a vengeful president who refused to concede his loss. The incident has had lasting consequences and will be remembered as one of the darkest days in American history.

site_title: Samsung surges after Intel is said to consider chip outsourcing
summary: Intel is reportedly considering outsourcing chip production to Samsung and TSMC, a major departure for the Silicon Valley pioneer. The move comes after successive delays in Intel's chip fabrication processes, which have put it behind competitors that design their own chips and contract TSMC to do the manufacturing. TSMC, the largest maker of semiconductors, is preparing to offer Intel chips manufactured using a 4-nanometre process, with initial testing using an older 5-nanometer process. Intel's CEO, Bob Swan, has promised investors that he will set out his plans for outsourcing and get Intel's production technology back on track when the company reports earnings on January 21.

site_title: US: Political jitters push stocks lower at open
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, retreating from last week's record gains due to ongoing political turmoil and COVID-19 concerns. The Dow Jones fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 lost 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.0%. Traders are monitoring the intensifying debate over President Trump's impeachment and the potential distraction from President-elect Biden's economic aid plans. The market is also wary of the slow rollout of vaccines and rising cases.

site_title: Staples seeks US$2.1b deal for parent of Office Depot
summary: Staples, a retail company, has offered to buy the parent company of Office Depot for $2.1 billion, valuing the company at $40 per share. This is an 8.2% premium above Friday's close and represents a 61% increase over ODP's average closing price over the last 90 days. The deal aims to consolidate the office-products space and compete against online retailers. Staples had previously attempted to acquire Office Depot in 2016 but was blocked due to antitrust concerns. If the deal is not accepted, Staples plans to commence a tender offer in March.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccination centres to be up soon, jabs can be given at polyclinics, GP clinics
summary: Singapore's chief health scientist Tan Chorh Chuan announced that Covid-19 vaccine centers will be set up soon, allowing vaccinations to be given at polyclinics and general practitioner clinics. The first vaccinations were administered on January 11, including healthcare workers and eldercare staff. Tan assured the public that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine requires two injections, given 21 days apart, and that full protection only takes place with two doses. The authorities plan to run clinical trials to study the immune response to vaccination and have an active outreach program to address concerns and educate the public.

site_title: DBS upgrades Riverstone to 'buy', lowers target price
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Riverstone Holdings to "buy" from "hold" and lowered its target price to S$1.85 from S$2.03, citing an attractive fiscal 2021 price-to-earnings ratio of 7.3 times. The upgrade comes after the share price corrected by 50% following vaccine news. Analysts expect strong demand for healthcare gloves, with a firm average selling price and extended order visibility until December 2021. Despite Covid-19 vaccine availability, demand is expected to remain due to hygiene concerns and potential logistical delays.

site_title: Biden taps career diplomat William Burns as CIA chief
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden announced William Burns as his pick to lead the Central Intelligence Agency, citing Burns' decades of experience as a diplomat. Burns, a retired veteran diplomat, previously served as ambassador to Russia and Jordan, and was involved in secret talks with Iran that led to the 2015 nuclear deal. Burns' appointment was seen as a likely candidate to lead the State Department, given his experience with Iran.

site_title: Aptiv unveils new self-driving platform with wireless upgrades
summary: Aptiv unveiled its new self-driving platform, which can be used across various vehicles and updated wirelessly, reducing system validation costs for carmakers by up to 20-30%. The platform, designed by Aptiv's chief technology officer Glen De Vos, allows for real-time updates and tracking of vehicle problems, enabling carmakers to fix issues or upgrade features without waiting for the next vehicle model. This technology aims to make autonomous driving more affordable and accessible, despite fully self-driving vehicles being years away.

site_title: Pfizer, BioNTech boost vaccine goal more than 50% to 2 billion
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech have increased their Covid-19 vaccine production target to 2 billion shots for 2021, a 50% boost from the previous 1.3 billion doses. The move comes as countries seek more doses due to the global rush. A new production site in Germany will produce up to 750 million doses annually, and the companies are seeking to add suppliers and improve production processes. This increase aims to address the growing demand for vaccines, particularly as the European Union secures more doses to combat a new, faster-spreading virus variant.

images.alt_text: Pfizer and BioNTech raised their Covid-19 vaccine production target for this year to 2 billion shots, as the partners respond to a global rush of countries seeking to order more doses.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic speeds up Barcelona's urban-greening plan
summary: Barcelona's urban-greening plan, worth 38 million euros, aims to turn one in three streets in the central Eixample district into green zones to combat pollution and cramped living conditions. The 10-year plan, announced in November, will transform crossroads into public spaces with urban forests, parks, and green areas, prioritizing groups traditionally excluded from city planning, such as children, women, and the elderly. The plan responds to the Covid-19 pandemic's increased awareness of the importance of nature in urban living.

images.alt_text: The new urban design aims to put at its centre groups that have traditionally been excluded, such as children, women and the elderly, said Barcelona's deputy mayor Janet Sanz.

site_title: Heathrow passenger numbers plunged 73% in 2020
summary: Heathrow Airport reported a 73% decline in passenger numbers in 2020 due to COVID-19 restrictions, with December seeing an 83% drop. Annual cargo volumes also fell 28% as fewer passenger planes left space for goods. The airport lost its title as Europe's busiest airport to Paris-Charles de Gaulle in October.

images.alt_text: Heathrow Airport, the busiest in Britain, said that passenger numbers slumped 73 per cent during 2020 as Covid-19 restrictions wiped out travel.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust sells Wuhan mall, other premises for 258 million yuan
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has sold Wuhan mall and other premises for 258 million yuan (S$52.6 million) in cash. The sale, due to operational challenges, will unlock value from a non-core asset and allow the trust to focus on its core portfolio. The divestment is expected to generate estimated net proceeds of S$46.8 million, which will be used for debt repayment, capital expenditure, and other corporate needs. The deal is not expected to impact the trust's net asset value and distribution per unit.

site_title: Malaysia imposes virus curbs, warns hospitals at 'breaking point'
summary: Malaysia imposes a two-week partial lockdown in over half the country due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with 138,000 infections and 555 deaths reported. The lockdown, starting Wednesday, will affect the capital Kuala Lumpur and five states, with non-essential businesses closed and only essential workers allowed outside. Travel between states is prohibited, and only two people per household will be allowed outside for essential purposes. The move comes as the country's healthcare system is at "breaking point," with two Cabinet ministers testing positive for the virus.
