site_title: Timberland owner VF Corp sets up new supply chain, business centres in Singapore, Kuala Lumpur
summary: VF Corp, the owner of outdoor brands Vans and Timberland, is setting up new business centres in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur as part of a shift in regional operations from Hong Kong to Shanghai. The new supply chain hub in Hong Kong will relocate to Singapore, while a services centre in Kuala Lumpur will support business functions. The moves aim to boost integration across VF's global supply chain network and strengthen relationships with consumers in China. The company expects the relocation to be completed by mid-2022, with a focus on becoming a more consumer-minded, retail-centric, and hyper-digital enterprise.

site_title: House Democrats set in motion bid to remove Trump from office
summary: House Democrats launched a bid to remove President Donald Trump from office by urging Vice President Mike Pence to use the 25th Amendment to declare him unfit. A resolution to fast-track this process was blocked by Republicans, setting up a roll call vote on Tuesday. If Pence doesn't respond in 24 hours, the House will move toward a vote on an impeachment resolution, which could come as soon as Wednesday. Over 200 House members have signed on to the impeachment resolution, charging Trump with inciting the January 6 insurrection.

site_title: AEM launches bid to take CEI private
summary: AEM Holdings launched a S$99.7 million bid to take CEI Ltd. private, offering S$1.15 in cash or a mix of cash and new AEM shares for each CEI share. The offer price is a 26.1% premium to CEI's volume-weighted average price. CEI shareholders can choose between three payment options, with the cash consideration offering a "clean cash exit opportunity" and the mixed option allowing them to share in AEM's future prospects. The deal is conditional on at least 50% valid acceptances and requires in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Taiwan's new passport hopes to banish confusion with China
summary: Taiwan introduced a redesigned passport with increased prominence of the island's name, "Taiwan", in English to avoid confusion with China. The change aims to prevent citizens from being mistakenly identified as Chinese nationals while traveling abroad. The new passport design removes the phrase "Republic of China" from the top, replacing it with larger "Taiwan" text. The move follows concerns about Taiwanese citizens being unfairly subject to entry bans during the pandemic. The new passport has already received over 700 applications, with the goal of increasing visibility and sovereignty recognition.

site_title: Engie and Neoen plan US$1.2b solar, storage project in France
summary: Engie and Neoen plan a US$1.2 billion solar farm in southeastern France, one of the largest in the world, near Bordeaux. The 1 gigawatt solar farm will meet the annual power needs of approximately 600,000 inhabitants. The project, known as Horizeo, aims to demonstrate the maturity of solar power production without public aid, with electricity sold via corporate power purchase agreements. Construction is expected to begin in the next three years, highlighting the increasing competitiveness of solar power in Europe.

site_title: Thai royal defamation cases ramp up as protests pause
summary: Thai authorities have charged 41 people, including four democracy activists, with royal defamation, with the threat of a 15-year jail sentence. The charges have halted protests demanding political reform and the resignation of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha, as Thailand grapples with a surge in coronavirus cases. The move marks the biggest use of royal defamation laws since 2017, with analysts warning of an "unprecedented escalation of legal persecution" and a temporary reprieve for authorities.

site_title: Beijing's virus clampdown spurs food price surge and shortages
summary: Beijing's efforts to curb Covid-19 infections have led to a surge in food prices, with shortages reported in meat and vegetables. Truck drivers delivering supplies are being tested for the virus, causing delays and supply chain disruptions. The restrictions have resulted in reduced vegetable supplies, with prices doubling for some items, including Chinese scallions. Chilly weather and record corn prices have also contributed to inflation, further exacerbating the issue. The shortages are affecting Beijing's food supply, particularly from southern regions like Hainan and Yunnan.

site_title: Former Gatwick owner outbids Blackstone for Signature Aviation
summary: Global Infrastructure Partners has agreed to buy private jet services firm Signature Aviation for $4.63 billion, outbidding private equity giants Blackstone and Carlyle. The deal offers Signature shareholders $5.50 per share in cash, surpassing the $5.17 proposed by Blackstone and Cascade Investment. Despite the COVID-19 travel curbs, private jet operators have fared better, with wealthy passengers opting for a safer way to fly. The deal is set to take Signature Aviation off the London Stock Exchange, owned by Global Infrastructure Partners, which previously managed a 49.99% stake in Gatwick Airport.

site_title: Singapore and other regional stocks end the day lower; STI down 0.31%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 0.31% at 2,983.90, reversing its gains from last week. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top performer, gaining 5.87%, while City Developments declined 2.18%. Other regional markets, including China's Shanghai Composite Index, also ended the day in the red. China's producer price index fell 0.4% and the consumer price index rose 0.2% in December. The STI's decline was attributed to a high base of comparison before rebounding in the second half of the year.

site_title: Redefining Data Security for SMEs in the Digital Economy
summary: Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly vulnerable to data risks due to the shift to remote work and cyber threats. Nearly two-thirds of SMEs experienced a cyber incident in 2019, with sophisticated attackers using artificial intelligence to analyze behavioral patterns. SMEs should prioritize cybersecurity, educate employees, and establish protocols for data classification to mitigate risks. Effective data protection requires a holistic approach, complementing cybersecurity and data management. By taking a proactive stance, SMEs can balance flexibility with risk awareness and thrive in the digitalized business environment.

site_title: AEM Holdings plans to take CEI Ltd private in S$99.7 million buy-out offer
summary: AEM Holdings has launched a S$99.7 million buy-out bid for contract manufacturer CEI Ltd, offering S$1.15 in cash or a mix of cash and new AEM shares for each CEI share. The offer marks a 26.1% premium and is conditional on a 50% acceptance rate by the close of the offer. AEM plans to delist and privatise CEI, citing business synergy and opportunities for better supply-chain integration and manufacturing processes.

site_title: Year-old baby girl among new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: A 1-year-old baby girl and a 2-year-old toddler, both arriving from India, are among 22 new COVID-19 cases confirmed in Singapore on January 11. The cases, including 8 work permit holders, were all imported and asymptomatic. Two additional cases linked to the NewOcean 6 cluster were also reported, bringing the total cluster cases to 11. With 32 cases discharged, 58,653 patients have recovered, and 67 remain in hospital, including one in the ICU.

site_title: Chinese regulators to push tech giants to share consumer credit data: sources
summary: Chinese regulators plan to instruct tech giants Ant Group, Tencent, and JD.com to share consumer loan data with nationwide credit agencies to prevent excess borrowing and fraud. The move, part of Beijing's tightening scrutiny of the industry, would effectively end the government's laissez-faire approach and require large internet platforms to feed their vast loan data to credit agencies. The goal is to allow lenders to adequately evaluate risks and prevent over-borrowing, but the plan may dampen the scale and profitability of tech majors' credit businesses.

images.alt_text: China plans to push tech giants including Ant Group, Tencent and JD.com to share consumer loan data to prevent excess borrowing and fraud.

site_title: Thai minister proposes 'golf quarantine' to boost tourism
summary: Thailand's Tourism Minister proposes a "golf quarantine" plan to boost the ailing tourism sector during the coronavirus pandemic. The plan, subject to Cabinet approval, allows foreigners to quarantine in golf resorts for two weeks, moving around in hotel areas and playing golf, rather than isolating in rooms. This comes as Thailand grapples with a second wave of coronavirus infections, having reported 10,547 cases and 67 deaths. The plan aims to attract foreign tourists, with a special visa scheme already attracting 1,000 visitors.

site_title: Ramsay Sime Darby picks banks for US$300m IPO
summary: Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care has selected Credit Suisse Group, Malayan Banking, and Morgan Stanley as arrangers for a planned initial public offering (IPO) in Malaysia, valued at approximately US$300 million. The IPO could occur in the second half of 2021, with the hospital operator potentially joining other companies in listing in Malaysia this year, following a trend of companies raising US$487 million through first-time share sales in 2020.

site_title: Vallianz sells off loss-making crew management subsidiary for nominal US$1
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore support vessel operator, sold its loss-making crew management subsidiary Offshore Engineering Resources for $1 on December 31, 2020, without a valuation exercise. The subsidiary had a nine-month net loss of $324,000 and unaudited net tangible liabilities of $20,000. The disposal is not expected to affect Vallianz's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2021 financial year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed Monday with a slight gain, driven by optimism over a potential US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.11% to 27,908.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.08%. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the region, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Royal Mail names former Ocado exec Thompson as CEO of UK business
summary: Royal Mail has appointed Simon Thompson, a former executive at Ocado and WM Morrison, as CEO of its UK business, aiming to steer the company through a surge in online parcel deliveries. Thompson replaces interim CEO Stuart Simpson, who will leave by the end of the month. The appointment comes after Royal Mail reached a deal with its largest union over pay and operational changes, allowing the company to focus on its parcels segment. Martin Seidenberg, chief executive of its international parcels business, will join the Board on April 1.

site_title: Entain CEO resigns days after Ladbrokes owner rejected MGM approach
summary: Entain CEO Shay Segev resigned seven months after taking the role, following the company's rejection of a $11 billion approach from MGM Resorts International. Segev plans to join DAZN as co-CEO, citing no impact from MGM's offer. The company's board remains unanimous in its view that MGM's proposal undervalues Entain, with Segev's departure described as a "sorry circumstance" due to the company's inability to match his promised rewards.

site_title: Singapore Airlines readies first US dollar bond: term sheet
summary: Singapore Airlines is preparing its first US dollar bond, with a term sheet circulated by bookrunners and calls with prospective investors underway. The airline's sole global coordinator is Citigroup, with BofA Securities and HSBC as joint bookrunners. The deal size will be determined on Tuesday, following briefings with investors in Asia and Europe. This marks a departure from Singapore Airlines' past debt deals in Singaporean dollars. The airline expects passenger levels to reach 25% of pre-Covid levels by the end of March, with plans to fly to nearly 45% of pre-crisis destinations.

site_title: Sanofi to buy antibody maker Kymab in US$1.45b deal
summary: Sanofi has agreed to purchase UK monoclonal antibody developer Kymab in a deal worth up to $1.45 billion. The French drugmaker will gain global rights to KY1005, a potential treatment for inflammation diseases and cancer, and access to new antibody technologies and research capabilities. Sanofi plans to finance the transaction with cash and has been hunting for acquisitions to bolster its pipeline. The deal continues the company's pivot toward treatments targeting the immune system, following its previous acquisition of Principia Biopharma Inc for $3.4 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 15.94 points lower on Monday at 1,617.25, with 650 losers outnumbering 490 gainers. The index saw a trading volume of 6.625 billion lots worth RM5.561 billion.

site_title: Chevron says repairs underway at Australia's Gorgon LNG Train 1 after weld quality issues
summary: Chevron is conducting repairs to propane heat exchangers on Train 1 at its Gorgon LNG plant in Western Australia due to weld quality issues discovered during inspections. The plant's Train 2 was shut in May for maintenance after cracks were found, and Train 3 will undergo a similar process after Train 1's repairs are completed. The repairs are ongoing, with no timeline provided for their completion, and the company will continue to deliver LNG to customers and gas to the Western Australian domestic market.

site_title: Asean-4 to lag regional rebound; more easing on the cards in Indonesia: reports
summary: Asean-4 economies, including Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Thailand, are expected to underperform regional growth this year due to local Covid-19 outbreaks. Analysts cite vaccination challenges and limited fiscal support as hurdles. Singapore is seen as a regional winner, driven by its tech sector and vaccination boost, while South Korea benefits from an export-driven upcycle. Thailand's recovery may be hampered by political uncertainty and rising virus transmission. Indonesia is forecast to require more fiscal support and monetary easing, while the Philippines faces uncertain vaccine procurement plans.

site_title: SGX RegCo considers consultation on Spacs
summary: SGX RegCo is considering a consultation on special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs) as early as this quarter. The exchange has seen increased interest in Spacs listings in other markets and has previously consulted on this structure in 2010. CEO Tan Boon Gin stated that there have been enquiries and expressions of interest from companies to explore this listing structure.

site_title: First Qatar to Saudi flight to take off after thaw
summary: Qatar and Saudi Arabia have resumed air travel between the two countries after a landmark agreement to normalize ties. The blockade, imposed in 2017, had restricted Qatar's airspace. The resumption marks a significant step forward for the two nations, ending a long-standing rift. The agreement is seen as a major development in the region, with Qatar's former rivals, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt, also participating in the normalization process.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of continued global cooperation in the post-Covid world. The AGC is reviewing training for prosecutors to improve administration of justice. Three new Senior Counsel were appointed for the new legal year. A four-storey building in District 8 is up for sale with a S$23.5m guide price, while OCBC launched Singapore's first solar panel consumer loan for landed property homeowners. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed in negative territory, slipping 0.31% to 2,983.90.

site_title: Thousands gather for Japan coming-of-age day despite virus surge
summary: Thousands of young adults in Japan gathered to celebrate coming-of-age day despite a surge in COVID-19 cases. The traditional ceremony, where they can legally drink, smoke, and get married without parental approval, was cancelled or postponed at many venues due to the virus. However, some events were held with limited capacity and social distancing measures in place, with participants wearing masks and keeping a safe distance. Despite concerns, many young people attended the ceremonies to mark a significant milestone in their lives.

site_title: Massive tech show will go on, in virtual format
summary: The 2021 Consumer Electronics Show (CES) will proceed in a virtual format due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 1,800 exhibitors participating online. The event aims to showcase the latest trends and innovations in artificial intelligence, 5G, digital health, and more. CES will feature over 300 speakers, including sessions on privacy and 5G internet, and will be available for replay on demand until mid-February. Despite some analysts predicting a diminished experience, organizers hope to deliver a new and unique digital experience to its expected online audience of 100,000 or more.

site_title: Seoul: Shares retreat from record high on heavy foreign sell-off
summary: South Korean shares retreated from a record high on Monday, closing 0.12% lower at 3,148.45 after a heavy sell-off by foreign and institutional investors outweighed a record buying spree by retail investors. Foreign and institutional investors sold 3.7 trillion won worth of shares, while retail investors bought a record 4.48 trillion won. The won weakened and the benchmark bond yield fell, with the won losing 1% against the dollar so far this year.

site_title: Goldman, JPMorgan, Citi suspend political donations
summary: Several major banks, including Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Citigroup, have suspended or plan to suspend political donations, citing the violent events at the US Capitol and the baseless claims of election fraud by President Donald Trump. The decision aims to show respect for the rule of law and to distance themselves from lawmakers who opposed the election certification. Marriott International and Morgan Stanley have also announced similar moves, with some other companies reviewing their policies on political giving.

site_title: Freehold commercial building in District 8 up for sale with S$23.5m guide price
summary: A freehold commercial building in District 8, Singapore, is up for sale with a guide price of S$23.5 million, equivalent to S$1,760 per square foot. The four-storey building has a total gross floor area of 13,370 sq ft and is zoned for commercial use, making it eligible for foreign buyers. The property is located near three MRT stations and has a single tenant on the ground floor, with vacant upper floors. The sale is seen as a "timely opportunity" for investors to acquire a medium-sized commercial building, with recent trends showing rising freehold prices despite uncertain economic conditions.

site_title: Global coronavirus cases surpass 90 million in battle on new variant
summary: Global coronavirus cases surpassed 90 million, according to a Reuters tally, as new variants continue to spread globally. Europe remains the worst-affected region, with 31% of global deaths, followed by North and Latin Americas. Countries are extending or reinstating lockdowns to control the spread, with Germany and France imposing new restrictions. The US reported its highest death toll on Wednesday, with over 4,000 fatalities, and India crossed 150,000 deaths, becoming the third nation to reach this milestone. Vaccination efforts are underway, with the UK aiming to immunize its most vulnerable people by mid-February.

site_title: China says WHO team to probe Covid-19 origins will arrive Jan 14
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) team of international experts is set to arrive in China on January 14 to investigate the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic. The team's arrival was delayed due to a "misunderstanding" with Chinese authorities, who had initially denied the team's request for authorization. The investigation comes amid criticism of China's initial response to the pandemic, with the US calling for a "transparent" investigation. China has sought to shape the narrative on the pandemic's origins, with some studies suggesting it may have emerged in multiple regions.

site_title: Nio may launch mass market vehicles under another marque
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, may launch mass market vehicles under another marque as EV technologies advance and battery costs decrease. CEO William Li stated that Nio will not use its brand for mass market products, but the company is expanding its offerings with the launch of its first sedan model. Nio delivered 43,728 vehicles last year, surpassing conventional automakers Daimler and General Motors in terms of market capitalization.

images.alt_text: China's electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio, which competes with conventional premium automakers including Daimler and BMW, may make mass market products under another marque, its chief executive said.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says it was not specific target of cyber attack
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, reported a cyber attack that breached its data systems, but stated it was not a targeted attack. The breach also affected other users of a third-party file-sharing application. The incident was contained, but the full impact is still being assessed. Governor Adrian Orr confirmed that the attack was not specific to the Reserve Bank, and other users of the file-sharing application were also compromised.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.3% to 6,855.29 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 index fell 0.5% to 13,974.36 points, while the Paris CAC 40 lost 0.2% to 5,695.41 points. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: China's Baidu to create an intelligent EV company with automaker Geely
summary: China's search engine giant Baidu Inc has announced plans to create an intelligent electric vehicle company with automaker Geely, leveraging Baidu's autonomous driving technology and Geely's car manufacturing expertise. The new company will be an independent subsidiary of Baidu, with Geely holding a minority stake. This move follows similar partnerships by tech companies such as Alibaba and Didi Chuxing in the EV sector, as they race to develop smart cars. The partnership aims to strengthen the concept of "software-defined vehicles" and capitalize on the growing demand for intelligent connectivity in the automotive industry.

site_title: Malaysia buys additional 12.2 million doses of Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Malaysia has signed a deal to purchase an additional 12.2 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine, bringing the total to 25 million doses and covering 39% of its population. The purchase brings the country closer to meeting its vaccination target.

site_title: Australia: Gold miners drag down shares; NZ falls 2%
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 6,697.2, led by a 4.3% drop in gold stocks as bullion prices slumped to a near six-week low. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 2% to 13,290.09, its worst session since July 9. The decline was attributed to concerns over the spread of highly transmissible Covid-19 variants, which dimmed hopes for a quick economic recovery.

site_title: JLL names Singapore, Thailand country heads as it eyes regional growth
summary: JLL has appointed Chris Archibold as its new Singapore country head, replacing Chris Fossick. Meanwhile, Michael Glancy will take over as Thailand country head, succeeding Suphin Mechuchep, who has been named chairperson for Thailand. These moves are part of JLL's efforts to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Ship orders slump 50% with owners unsure which green fuel to use
summary: Ship owners are canceling new orders due to uncertainty over which alternative fuel to use, resulting in a 50% decline in orders over the past two years. The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2018 target to cut shipping emissions in half by 2050 has led to a delay, with many owners opting to wait for scalable solutions. Alternative fuels such as ammonia, hydrogen, biofuels, and electrification are being considered, but their scalability is still unclear, potentially leading to a shortage of vessels and increased freight rates in the future.

images.alt_text: Ship owners facing looming deadlines to use less-polluting fuels have slashed the number of new vessels on order because they don't know which alternative technology to switch to.

site_title: China approves high-speed railway project worth US$8.82b
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved a US$8.82 billion high-speed railway project connecting Xiongan New Area with Hebei and Shanxi provinces, expected to take four-and-a-half years to complete.

site_title: Israeli magnate faces corruption charges in Geneva over Guinea deals
summary: French-Israeli diamond magnate Beny Steinmetz faces corruption charges in Geneva over alleged multi-million-dollar bribes paid to Guinean officials to win lucrative mining rights in the Simandou region. The trial, which began Monday, accuses Steinmetz of corrupting public officials and forging documents. Steinmetz denies wrongdoing and claims the allegations are baseless and an attempt to smear him. If convicted, he could face up to 10 years in jail.

site_title: Asia: Most markets, dollar rise as Biden pledges huge stimulus
summary: Asian markets rose, driven by a strong US dollar following President-elect Joe Biden's pledge of a massive stimulus package. The dollar hit a three-week peak against the yen, while stocks in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets climbed. Investors welcomed the prospect of increased spending, coupled with Federal Reserve support and low rates, but remain cautious due to COVID concerns and ongoing China-US tensions. Oil prices remained at 10-month highs, supported by hopes for more stimulus.

site_title: OCBC launches solar panel consumer loan for landed property homeowners
summary: OCBC has launched Singapore's first consumer loan for landed property homeowners to install solar panels, providing a term-financing option for up to S$30,000 over 1-5 years. The loan is offered in partnership with Sembcorp Industries' electricity retail arm, with initial consultation costs covered by Sembcorp Power. This move aims to increase accessibility to clean energy for homeowners, with OCBC's head of consumer financial services stating it's a key step towards a more sustainable energy source. The loan is expected to help homeowners defray upfront costs and accelerate clean energy adoption.

site_title: 'Big thing': Taiwan praises US move to lift restrictions on ties
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced the lifting of restrictions on interactions with Taiwanese officials, a move praised by Taiwan's Foreign Minister Joseph Wu as a "big thing" for relations with the island's most important global backer. The move is seen as a major boost for Taiwan-US relations, despite China's likely increased tensions. US Ambassador to the UN Kelly Craft will visit Taiwan this week to discuss promoting Taiwan's international participation, a highly symbolic move given Taiwan's limited UN representation. The move is set to elevate Taiwan-US relations to a global partnership.

site_title: Becoming a bank would shrink but not squash Ant
summary: China's Ant Group, a financial company led by Jack Ma, will likely shrink but not be completely eliminated after regulators require it to create a holding company, monitored by the central bank. The company's US$300 billion valuation is expected to decrease due to reduced growth prospects. Ant's fast-growing credit unit will be impacted by new rules requiring online companies to fund 30% of consumer loans, potentially limiting its ability to transfer financial risk. The company's capital ratio will still meet regulatory requirements, but its valuation will be significantly reduced.

site_title: EV startup Faraday in SPAC merger talks to go public: sources
summary: Faraday & Future, an electric vehicle startup, is in talks with Property Solutions Acquisition Corp, a blank-cheque firm, to go public through a merger valued at around $3 billion. The deal, which could raise over $400 million in equity, aims to support Faraday's development of its flagship vehicle, the FF 91. This follows a trend of Chinese startups competing in the electric vehicle market, with companies like Nio and Xpeng recently going public. The merger would be the latest in a series of electric vehicle companies merging with blank-cheque firms, including Nikola and Fisker.

site_title: Three new Senior Counsel take silk
summary: Three new Senior Counsel were appointed in Singapore, including Abraham Vergis, managing director of Providence Law Asia, Kristy Tan, senior director of the Attorney-General's Chambers, and Goh Yihan, dean of the Singapore Management University's School of Law. The appointments bring the total number of Senior Counsel to 91. The trio aims to mentor young legal practitioners and inspire aspiring lawyers, emphasizing that there are alternative paths to achieving the elite appointment.

site_title: Bitcoin hits one-week low as rising US yields dent rally
summary: Bitcoin dropped over 12% to a one-week low of $33,447 due to rising US yields, which lifted the dollar and hurt non-income paying assets. Ethereum fell 20% to a one-week low of $1,007.51. The decline comes amid rising US yields and a stronger dollar, which negatively impacted cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Half of Swiss hotels, restaurants risk bankruptcy: employer group
summary: Nearly half of Switzerland's restaurants and hotels are at risk of bankruptcy within months due to the devastating effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. Industry federation GastroSuisse warned that around 50% of businesses could fail without significant financial support. The group polled 4,000 owners and found 98% are in urgent need of support. The Swiss government is expected to extend the closure of bars and restaurants until the end of February, but GastroSuisse urged the government to provide immediate and uncomplicated financial support to avoid disaster.

site_title: AGC reviewing training for prosecutors to improve administration of justice
summary: The Attorney-General of Singapore, Lucien Wong, announced the review of training for prosecutors to improve the administration of justice. The review comes after the acquittal of Parti Liyani, a foreign domestic worker who was accused of stealing over $34,000, sparking public outcry and criticism of the prosecution's handling of the case. Wong emphasized that acquittals demonstrate a healthy legal system, and that the prosecution pursues cases where they truly believe an offense has been committed. He also stressed the importance of prosecutors taking pride in doing right and fulfilling their obligations to disclose documents to the defense.

site_title: Gold hits near six-week low on firmer dollar, higher Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices fell to a near six-week low at US$1,816.53 per ounce, as a stronger dollar and higher US Treasury yields pressured the non-yielding bullion. The US 10-year Treasury yield held above 1 per cent, making gold expensive. Higher bond yields increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, and investors took note of Federal Reserve comments and US President-elect Joe Biden's hints at direct pandemic relief.

site_title: Year on from first Covid-19 death, Wuhan basks in recovery
summary: China marks the one-year anniversary of the first Covid-19 death in Wuhan, where the virus has been largely extinguished. The city, once considered the "coronavirus ground zero," has bounced back with a low infection rate, with residents proudly showcasing their recovery. China's official Covid-19 death toll stands at 4,634, a fraction of the 1.9 million global deaths. Wuhan's residents, including 66-year-old Xiong Liansheng, attribute their city's success to high awareness of epidemic prevention and control.

site_title: Wheat exporters in Australia look beyond China to North Africa
summary: Australia is on track for its second-largest wheat crop ever, with over 30 million tonnes expected. Mounting tensions with China have led to a decrease in Chinese imports, while weather woes in other parts of the world have increased export supplies from Australia. This has created a demand for wheat in North Africa and the Middle East, traditionally supplied by Russia and Europe. As freight costs are lower, Australia is poised to become a major supplier to these markets, potentially offsetting the impact of tensions with China.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Monday
summary: Financial markets in Tokyo closed on Monday for a public holiday. Trading resumed on Tuesday, January 12. Meanwhile, global stock markets saw a downturn, with European stocks dragged down by bank and healthcare sectors, while US stocks edged down from records amid US-EU tariff threats. Asian markets also experienced volatility, with Singapore stocks rising in a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: North Korea's Kim assumes late father's mantle
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has taken on his late father's mantle, with his official party title changed to general secretary, according to state media. The move is seen as a bid to bolster his authority amid the country's struggling economy and self-imposed coronavirus isolation. Analysts say the change is largely symbolic, but it comes as Kim strengthens his military capabilities and calls the US his "foremost principal enemy." The change follows a congress where Kim was unanimously elected as general secretary, with his sister Kim Yo Jong missing from the party central committee.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH raises TP for Singapore Medical Group on potential offer
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price for Singapore Medical Group (SMG) to S$0.46, maintaining a "buy" call, following the group's possible transaction disclosure. The stock has risen 12% to S$0.33 since the announcement, driven by expansion in high-growth markets and organic growth initiatives. Analysts believe SMG should be valued at a slight premium or similar to peers, given its growth prospects.

site_title: China's Dec PPI -0.4% y-o-y, CPI +0.2% y-o-y
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) fell 0.4% in December, less than expected, indicating a steady recovery in the manufacturing sector. The consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.2% in December, also below forecast. The data suggests China's economy continues to recover from the COVID-19 shock, but the slight miss may raise pressure on policymakers to implement policies to sustain growth.

site_title: Quick takes: OCBC in transition
summary: OCBC has appointed Helen Wong, former chief executive of HSBC in Greater China, as its new group chief executive officer from April 15. She will be the bank's first female CEO and the first woman to head a Singapore bank. Wong rejoined OCBC last year and has extensive experience in Greater China, which is expected to enhance the bank's franchise in the region. Analysts predict a positive impact on OCBC's share price under her management, with a focus on leveraging regional connectivity for growth. The appointment signals OCBC's continued focus on Greater China, a strategic pivot made in 2014.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% at the open on Monday, extending last week's rally, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street and anticipation of US stimulus plans under Joe Biden. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,003.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased marginally.

site_title: Hot stock: Fortress Minerals surges 14.3% after Q3 profit jump, proposed acquisition
summary: Fortress Minerals' shares surged 14.3% to a record high after posting a net profit of US$4.3 million in Q3, more than five times the previous year's profit. The company also proposed a US$30 million acquisition of Malaysia's Monument Mengapur. Revenue more than doubled to US$10.3 million, with earnings per share increasing to 0.87 US cents.

site_title: KKR raises US$3.9b in biggest infrastructure fund for Asia
summary: KKR & Co raised US$3.9 billion for its first Asia-Pacific infrastructure fund, surpassing its initial target of US$3 billion. The firm, which has already invested over US$1.8 billion in six infrastructure investments in Asia, plans to expand its presence in the region. KKR's global infrastructure team and strategy were established in 2008, and the firm has a 14-member team in Asia with plans to add more. The fund-raisings come as global private equity firms shift towards becoming investment houses with broad offerings in alternative assets.

images.alt_text: KKR & Co raised US$3.9 billion for its first Asia-Pacific infrastructure fund, amassing the largest pool of cash in the region for investments in everything from waste management and renewable energy to communication towers.

site_title: How Aussie doctor's at-home Covid test won US approval
summary: An Australian doctor, Sean Parsons, has led his company Ellume to US FDA approval for its at-home Covid-19 test. The test, which delivers results in 15 minutes, will soon be available over the counter in US pharmacies. Ellume aims to manufacture 100,000 units per day by this month and one million by mid-year, with the goal of diagnosing millions of people with coronavirus to reduce transmission. The test is seen as a complement to traditional methods and is expected to be needed for "many years" to come.

site_title: Continued global cooperation key in post-Covid world: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of global cooperation in the post-Covid-19 world, highlighting areas of public health, climate change, and digital governance. He noted that the US-China relationship will shape global cooperation, but also urged Asia's leaders to work together, citing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership. Heng stressed the need for Asean to maintain its centrality and play a proactive role in engaging external partners, while Singapore's openness is key to its economic success.

site_title: Oil prices fall on renewed coronavirus concerns as China cases mount
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday due to renewed coronavirus concerns, with Brent crude oil futures dropping 42 cents to $55.57 a barrel. Strict lockdowns in Europe and new movement restrictions in China, where cases have surged, led to the price decline. Despite this, US President-elect Joe Biden's plan to announce trillions of dollars in new coronavirus relief bills this week is expected to support crude prices. Saudi Arabia's pledge for a voluntary oil output cut is also seen as a factor in maintaining prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.73 points, or 0.53%, to 1,624.46. Losers beat gainers 294 to 160. The decline follows global market trends, with stocks in Europe and the US also experiencing downward pressure due to concerns over US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Australia's Nov retail sales jump 7.1%
summary: Australian retail sales surged 7.1% in November, driven by pre-Christmas sales in the state of Victoria, which emerged from a lengthy lockdown. In Victoria, retail sales rose 22.4% from October, while excluding Victoria, turnover increased 2.6%. The strong sales data suggests a rebound in consumer spending as the country recovers from the pandemic.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng warns of FY2020 loss on Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore property developer Chip Eng Seng expects to report a FY2020 net loss of S$25.7 million, wider than the S$32.6 million net profit in FY2019, due to the impact of Covid-19 on its businesses. The company's property segment was affected by construction site closures, while its hospitality businesses saw no significant recovery in occupancy rates and revenue. The group also expects significant impairment losses in its property investment segment and a provision for doubtful debts in its education business.

site_title: Fortress Minerals Q3 profit jumps to US$4.3m; proposes acquisition of Monument Mengapur
summary: Fortress Minerals reported a net profit of US$4.3 million for Q3 2020, more than five times that of the previous year, driven by revenue growth to US$10.3 million. The company also proposed a US$30 million acquisition of Monument Mengapur, a Malaysian copper and minerals exploration company. Fortress Minerals aims to further elevate production capacity and efficiency while maintaining demand for its high-grade iron ore concentrate.

site_title: Pelosi says ready to start second impeachment of Trump
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced plans to push forward with efforts to remove President Donald Trump from office, citing his role in the Capitol attack. She stated that a resolution calling for Trump's removal under the 25th Amendment would be introduced in the House of Representatives, and if Vice-President Mike Pence does not agree, impeachment legislation would be brought to the floor. This comes after Trump's previous impeachment in 2019 was acquitted by the Senate.

site_title: Apple, Hyundai set to agree electric car tie-up: Korea IT News
summary: Hyundai Motor and Apple Inc plan to sign a partnership deal on autonomous electric cars by March, with production expected to start in the US around 2024. The deal aims to launch a self-driving electric car in 2027. Hyundai shares rose nearly 20% after reports of the potential partnership. The companies plan to release a "beta version" of the Apple car next year. This partnership follows reports of Apple moving forward with autonomous car technology and aiming to produce a passenger vehicle with its own battery technology as early as 2024.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Riverstone to 'buy' as valuation turns attractive
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Riverstone Holdings to "buy" from "hold" and lowered its target price to S$1.85, citing an attractive valuation and a firm average selling price due to strong demand and tight supply. The company's fiscal 2021 price-to-earnings ratio is 7.3 times, near its five-year average. A bumper dividend for FY2020 and extended order visibility to December 2021 also support the upgrade.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Keppel, China Everbright, Chip Eng Seng, First Reit
summary: OCBC announced the appointment of Helen Wong as its new group CEO, effective April 15, marking the first time a woman will head a Singapore bank. Keppel Corporation reached an agreement with lenders to discharge security over Floatel's assets, boosting shares by 1.8%. China Everbright Water won a public bid for a 65% equity stake in Tianjin Binhai New Area Huantang Sewage Treatment for S$136.4 million. Chip Eng Seng reported a net loss for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, while First Reit responded to concerns about family conflicts.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley to delist some products in Hong Kong
summary: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and JPMorgan Chase will delist approximately 500 Hong Kong-listed structured products due to US sanctions. The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) stated that the delisting won't harm the market, as there will be sufficient investment choices. HKEX remains competitive, citing its pipeline for initial stock offerings, and will monitor the developments.

site_title: South Korea's Jan 1-10 exports drop 15.4% y-o-y
summary: South Korea's exports declined 15.4% in the first 10 days of January compared to the same period last year, with shipments to China and the US decreasing. Meanwhile, imports dropped 22.9% and average exports per working day rose 5.8%. The data will be released in full on February 1, 2021.

site_title: UAE's SHUAA Capital buys out Stanford Marine's debt as part of restructuring
summary: A consortium led by SHUAA Capital has bought out 1.13 billion dirhams (S$408 million) of debt held by Stanford Marine Group as part of its restructuring. The move aims to strengthen the marine services firm's liquidity position and support over 1,800 jobs. The debt buyout also helped banks recover cash, addressing a distressed debt situation. The deal was made possible by a 2015 Islamic loan of US$325 million, which was provided by several banks, including Dubai Islamic Bank and First Abu Dhabi Bank.

site_title: 'Sex and the City' revival coming on HBO
summary: HBO Max announces a revival of 'Sex and the City' titled 'And Just Like That...', featuring original leads Sarah Jessica Parker, Cynthia Nixon, and Kristin Davis, excluding Kim Cattrall. The 10-episode series will follow the three women navigating love and friendship in their 50s, with production set to start in New York City in late spring. The show's premiere date has not been specified, but Parker has posted a teaser trailer on Instagram. The revival will explore the evolution of the characters, with Parker set to produce alongside her co-stars.

site_title: Indonesia sets new rules on payments systems
summary: Indonesia's central bank has introduced new regulations on payment systems, effective July 1, requiring non-bank payment services to have at least 15% Indonesian ownership and 51% voting rights owned by locals. Non-bank payment infrastructure companies must be at least 80% Indonesian-owned. The regulations aim to mitigate potential risks in the financial system and promote good governance. Payment service providers will be classified based on transaction size, interconnectivity, and complexity, determining their capital and risk management requirements. The new rules are expected to impact firms like Gopay, OVO, and DANA.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Monday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% at the Monday open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 10.77 points to 2,982.42. Advancers outnumbered decliners 96 to 44, with notable movers including Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Singtel. Local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB also declined. Meanwhile, Singapore Medical Group rose 4.6% and China Everbright Water increased 4.4%. US stocks ended at record highs last Friday, driven by anticipation of fiscal support.

site_title: Indonesian air crash investigator says crashed jet possibly ruptured when hitting waters
summary: An Indonesian air crash investigator believes the Sriwijaya Air jet that crashed into the Java Sea with 62 people on board possibly ruptured when hitting waters. The investigator, Nurcahyo Utomo, notes that the scattered debris found so far is not widely distributed, suggesting a possible in-water rupture rather than a mid-air explosion. The cause of the crash is still unknown, but the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Marriott, BlueCross suspend donations to US lawmakers who voted against Biden certification
summary: Marriott International and the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association have suspended donations to US lawmakers who voted against certifying President-elect Joe Biden's victory. The move comes after the violent assault on the US Capitol, with companies citing the need to support democracy. Citigroup has also paused contributions to lawmakers who challenged the Electoral College results. Other companies, including Ford Motor, have not made any decisions about changes to giving. This decision aims to demonstrate respect for the rule of law and unity in the country.

images.alt_text: Marriott International Inc, the world's largest hotel company, and the Blue Cross Blue Shield Association (BCBSA) said on Sunday they will suspend donations to US lawmakers who voted against certifying President-elect Joe Biden's victory last week.

site_title: Greeks ignore virus lockdown as temperatures soar
summary: Greeks defied coronavirus lockdowns to enjoy warm weather, with temperatures reaching 28°C (82°F) in some areas. The heatwave, fueled by African dust, prompted people to flock to beaches and parks, with police monitoring the situation to avoid overcrowding. Authorities extended lockdown restrictions for another week, with nurseries, kindergartens, and primary schools set to reopen on Monday. The country has reported over 4,000 pandemic deaths in the past two months, with 36 new deaths announced on Sunday.

site_title: Japan finds new coronavirus variant in travellers from Brazil
summary: Japan has detected a new coronavirus variant in four travellers from Brazil's Amazonas state, with 12 mutations identified. Studies are underway to assess the variant's efficacy against vaccines. While there's no proof of high infectiousness, Brazil's Health Ministry notes the variant's potential for higher virus infectiousness, having been identified in UK and South African variants. The travellers are in quarantine at Tokyo's airport, amid a state of emergency in Tokyo and surrounding prefectures due to a surge in cases.

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit sets up S$1b debt issuance programme
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit has announced a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with RBC Investor Services Trust Singapore serving as trustee. The program will allow for the issuance of unsubordinated notes and unsecured perps, with net proceeds used for refinancing existing borrowings, acquisitions, and general corporate purposes. DBS and OCBC have been appointed as joint arrangers and dealers of the program, with LReit units closing flat at 77.5 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: ISDN keeps focus on China and diversification strategy amid pandemic
summary: ISDN Holdings, a Singaporean company, reported "good growth" despite the Covid-19 pandemic, with its president Teo Cher Koon attributing the success to a focus on China and diversification strategy. The company sells systems and provides hardware and software solutions to clients, with opportunities for growth in disinfectant products and solutions. ISDN's financial performance suggests resilience in the face of economic challenges, but its H2 revenue may still fall short of targets.

site_title: Silence, division between old allies Trump and Pence
summary: Vice-President Mike Pence and former President Donald Trump have severed ties following the violent Capitol storming on January 6, 2021. Pence led the session confirming Trump's election loss, but the two have not spoken since. Pence plans to attend Joe Biden's inauguration, contradicting Trump's decision to skip it. This stark rupture marks a significant rift between the two former allies, with Pence being Trump's most devoted supporter for the past four years.

site_title: US Republican senator says Trump should quit, as momentum for impeachment grows in House
summary: US Republican Senator Pat Toomey has called for President Donald Trump to resign amid growing momentum for impeachment in the House of Representatives. Toomey cited potential criminal liability for Trump following the deadly Capitol storming. Meanwhile, Democrats in the House are preparing to move forward with impeachment proceedings, with 200 co-sponsors for the legislation. The Justice Department has charged two more people in connection with the attack, and the US Army has opened at least 25 terrorism cases.

site_title: A rebound for gold amid jitters
summary: Gold prices have rebounded from a low of $1,820 per ounce to recent highs of $1,937, driven by investor optimism amid Covid-19 cases and economic stimulus measures. Despite increasing cases and lockdowns in the UK, Japan, and Germany, gold has been trading in an uptrend channel, forming a bullish flag pattern with potential price objectives of $1,970 and $1,993. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets, and technical analysis suggests gold may continue to rise amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Top global oil exporter Saudi Arabia launches car-free city
summary: Saudi Arabia has launched a car-free city, "THE LINE", as part of its $500 billion NEOM mega development. The city, set to be built along the Red Sea coast, aims to preserve 95% of nature and have zero cars, streets, and carbon emissions. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman unveiled the plans, which include a 170-kilometer city for 1 million residents with high-speed public transportation and 100% clean energy. Construction will begin in the first quarter of this year, creating 380,000 jobs and contributing $63.6 billion to the kingdom's GDP by 2030.

site_title: A selection of sustainable funds
summary: Sustainable fund launches have increased in recent months, with firms integrating ESG factors into their investment processes. Thematic funds, focusing on specific impact areas, are also available. However, "greenwashing" is a concern, with some managers using ESG labels without substantial underlying impact. Recent sustainable fund launches include Manulife's Sustainable Asia Bond fund, UOB's United Sustainable Credit Income Fund, Ninety One's Global Environment Fund, and Schroder's Sustainable Multi Asset Income Fund, which aim to generate income from sustainable sources while minimizing environmental and social risks.

site_title: A civic duty to help stem the spread
summary: A CEO from Lunch Actually, Violet Lim, emphasizes the importance of getting vaccinated against Covid-19, stating she would encourage staff to get vaccinated and take time off for the jab. She believes business leaders have a responsibility to lead by example and achieve herd immunity.

site_title: US theatres kick off 2021 with hopes of erasing worst year on record
summary: US cinemas kick off 2021 with hopes of a better year, despite a pandemic-driven downturn in 2020. Many theatres remain closed, and only highly anticipated movies are expected to attract audiences. Analysts predict a slow start, with older releases like Wonder Woman 1984 and The Croods: A New Age dominating the box office. However, a backlog of big-budget films, including James Bond and Black Widow, is expected to boost ticket sales later in the year, potentially undoing the damage of 2020's 80% box-office decline.

site_title: Prince Charles urges business to put planet and people first
summary: Prince Charles is launching the "Terra Carta," a new charter of sustainability backed by major companies like Bank of America, AstraZeneca, and BP. The nearly 100 actions aim to bring prosperity into harmony with nature, people, and the planet over the next decade. Charles, an environmental advocate, urges businesses to prioritize the planet and its people, citing climate change as the greatest threat to humanity. The Terra Carta is designed by Jony Ive and LoveFrom, and its signatory companies must take practical steps to transform the global economy.

site_title: Digital health in spotlight as pandemic shifts tech show focus
summary: Digital health care is in the spotlight at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) amid the ongoing pandemic. Remote patient visits, biosensors, and other gadgets are being showcased, with demand for telehealth services projected to rise 64% in the US. Companies are developing tools to monitor the elderly, detect diseases early, and provide accurate diagnostic results. However, regulatory approval is needed for these devices to be deemed highly accurate. The pandemic has highlighted the need for better communication platforms, home monitoring devices, and accessible internet for remote care, with companies working to address these gaps.

site_title: Keppel-linked Floatel reaches agreement with lenders for full discharge of some assets
summary: Keppel-linked Floatel has reached an agreement with lenders to discharge security over assets owned by some group entities, expected to occur in February. The deal involves a US$46 million settlement payment and full release of cash in blocked accounts. Floatel Endurance will remain with the group, and lenders' claims of US$115 million will be fully released. The agreement was approved by Floatel shareholders and bondholders, and is part of a proposed restructuring of the company, which aims to create a new entity acquiring Floatel's vessel subsidiaries.

site_title: Tesla hunts for design chief to create cars for China: sources
summary: Tesla is searching for a design director in China to create electric cars tailored to Chinese consumer tastes, amid efforts to open a "full-function" studio in Shanghai or Beijing. The US carmaker is looking for a "bi-cultural" candidate with 20 or more years of experience familiar with Chinese tastes and able to bridge gaps between China and the US. The move is part of Tesla's broader push to boost global sales volume and follows comments from CEO Elon Musk on creating a China design and engineering center. A China-specific model, such as a $25,000 electric car, is also reportedly in the works.

site_title: Yield-starved investors likely to snap up Europe's debt sales
summary: Europe's governments, including France and Belgium, are set to tap the market for another 30 billion euros this week, driven by the insatiable hunt for yield among investors. The European Central Bank's bond-buying backstop and liquidity injections have encouraged investors to pile on sovereign debt holdings, despite governments borrowing and spending more to shield their economies. The ECB's emergency bond-buying program is more than sufficient to buy up the expected one trillion euros of debt this year, and negative-yielding debt is pushing investors further out the yield curve.

site_title: Aircraft leasing rates unlikely to take off this year
summary: Aircraft leasing rates are unlikely to rise in 2021, having dropped by 10-40% in 2020. The industry faces pressure, with lease rates expected to remain low due to a surplus of used aircraft and reduced demand. Leasing companies are becoming more selective in granting rental deferments, and some have agreed to defer lease payments. Sale-and-leasebacks have increased, with around 500 aircraft sold and leased in 2020. The industry is expected to remain cautious, with values and lease rates potentially "bumping along the bottom" for some time.

site_title: Renaissance United issues Q3 result warning due to gas shortages
summary: Renaissance United has issued a Q3 earnings warning due to increased costs from using liquefied natural gas (LNG) during China's winter gas shortages. LNG prices surged to three-year highs in December 2020, but the company was unable to pass these costs to end-users, who are regulated by local governments. This will impact the company's third-quarter earnings.

site_title: Home-turned-museum retains 'soul' of south Iraq
summary: An 80-year-old family home in Samawah, Iraq, has been restored as a museum, retaining its traditional architecture and "soul." The house, once occupied by three generations, was on the verge of disrepair before owner Abdellatif al-Jablawi purchased it and spent $171,000 to renovate it. The project was met with resistance from some family members, but al-Jablawi's commitment to preserving the building's heritage ultimately prevailed. The museum now hosts cultural events and is a symbol of the city, open to everyone.

site_title: Vietnam to exceed 6% growth target for 2021, say analysts
summary: Vietnam is expected to exceed its 6.0% growth target for 2021, with forecasts ranging from 7.1% to 9.3%, driven by new trade agreements, global economic recovery, and successful Covid-19 containment. The country's GDP growth accelerated to 4.48% in Q4 2020, and Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc has hinted at raising the official growth target to 6.5%. New trade agreements, including the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement, and the government's efforts in digitalisation and e-commerce are also expected to boost growth.

site_title: Apple, Amazon suspend Parler social network from App Store and Web hosting service
summary: Apple and Amazon have suspended Parler, a social networking service popular among right-leaning users, from the App Store and Web hosting service due to its failure to prevent posts inciting violence. The move follows a similar action by Google, citing participants' using Parler to coordinate the US Capitol siege. Parler's CEO, John Matze, has criticized the tech giants, calling it a "coordinated attack" to kill competition and free speech. The suspension is expected to take Parler offline unless it finds a new hosting service.

site_title: Top Glove's independent directors suffer ire of institutional investors
summary: Top Glove's board of directors suffered a rebuke from institutional investor BlackRock, which voted against the re-election of six independent directors due to the company's failure to address labor and human rights issues in its supply chain. The move highlighted the growing influence of small shareholders in corporate governance, with BlackRock citing concerns over worker safety and Covid-19 mitigation. Despite the criticism, Top Glove's share price rose 11% on the news, and the company plans to expand its workers' accommodation facilities. The incident may force independent directors to become more accountable to minority investors, potentially enhancing corporate governance standards in the local market.

site_title: The future of AGMs: physical or virtual?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift towards virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) in 2020, with significant increases in virtual meetings in Asia and Canada. As the pandemic recedes, regulatory authorities in Singapore are open to allowing hybrid or fully virtual shareholder meetings, citing the need for effective engagement, proper verification, and secure voting processes. While physical meetings offer a higher degree of interaction, virtual meetings provide unprecedented access and increased shareholder participation. The future of AGMs may lie in hybrid meetings, which combine core physical meetings with remote access, offering the benefits of both formats while minimizing shortcomings.

site_title: Green shoots into 2021
summary: S-REITs began 2021 with a 2.0% price gain, outperforming the Straits Times Index and major global Reit markets. Top gainers included ARA US Hospitality Trust (20.6%), First Reit (8.5%), and Ascendas India Trust (7.2%). The iEdge S-Reit Index averaged 10.0% gains in its first five trading days.

site_title: Wilmar and Yangzijiang continue buybacks
summary: Share buybacks continued in the Singapore stock market, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Wilmar International leading the way. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bought back 4 million shares at 97.62 Singapore cents per share, while Wilmar International bought back 252,000 shares at S$4.85. This follows a trend of share buybacks by STI stocks, with 100 stocks conducting buybacks in 2020 totaling S$1.03 billion. Additionally, there were significant director and substantial shareholder transactions, including Ho Bee Land's acquisition of Ho Bee Land shares and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' chairman's acquisition of shares.

site_title: M'sia hypermarts see long queues amid talk of fresh Covid-19 curbs
summary: Malaysia is bracing for new Covid-19 curbs, with long queues seen at hypermarkets and restaurants ahead of a possible announcement by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. The country's daily cases reached an all-time high of 3,027, with 95% of bed capacity in public hospitals taken up by active cases. Cabinet ministers have urged shoppers not to panic buy, but rumors of an impending lockdown have fueled concerns, with some making last-minute trips or dining out.

site_title: NZ central bank reports data system breach
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) reported a data system breach, which has been contained but is still being investigated. The breach occurred through a third-party file-sharing service used by the central bank to store sensitive information. The nature and extent of the information accessed are still being determined, but it may include commercially and personally sensitive information. This incident comes as the bank warned of rising cybersecurity incidents in New Zealand, with the expected cost of cyber incidents estimated between NZ$80 million and NZ$140 million per year.

site_title: Japanese pray for end to pandemic in annual ice bath ritual
summary: Japanese participants in an annual Shinto ritual at a Tokyo shrine prayed for the end of the COVID-19 pandemic by taking an ice bath. The event, scaled down due to the health crisis, saw only 12 people participate, resulting in extremely cold water. The ritual, now in its 66th year, aimed to purify the soul and ward off epidemics. Japan has been struggling with a recent surge in coronavirus infections, prompting the government to declare a limited state of emergency in Tokyo and its surrounding areas.

site_title: MOM clarifies differences between ICT, other EP holders
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has clarified the differences between intra-corporate transferees (ICTs) and other employment pass (EP) holders. ICTs, who must have worked for their company for at least a year, can no longer bring family members to Singapore via dependant's passes or long-term visit passes. However, those from countries with a free trade agreement (FTA) with Singapore, such as India and Australia, are exempt. This move aims to build a Singapore core among employers, potentially leading them to advertise for EPs on MyCareersFuture.sg instead of using the ICT route.

site_title: Performance of STI, private home resale market took different paths during pandemic
summary: The Singapore private residential market recovered faster than the Straits Times Index (STI) in 2020, with home prices rebounding to pre-pandemic levels in the months following the circuit breaker. The Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) fell 2.6% in the first half of 2020, compared to a 22.1% decline in the STI. The market's resilience was attributed to investment demand from Singaporeans and foreign buyers, as well as demand from HDB upgraders. Experts expect the market to continue recovering, with both the STI and SRPI moving in tandem as the economy improves.

site_title: Democrats push for second Trump impeachment
summary: Democrats in the House of Representatives are pushing to impeach US President Donald Trump for a second time, with 190 co-sponsors for the articles of impeachment. Despite no Republican support, some lawmakers, including Senator Pat Toomey and Senator Ben Sasse, have called for Trump's removal. The effort comes after Trump encouraged his supporters to storm the US Capitol, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has asked members to draft legislation to invoke the 25th Amendment. A Senate trial, if triggered, would require a two-thirds majority, making conviction unlikely.

site_title: Indonesia locates crash site, plane's black boxes
summary: Indonesia has located the crash site of a Boeing 737-500 jet that went down just minutes after takeoff on Saturday, killing 62 people. Divers, warships, and vessels with sonar have been deployed in the search. Debris suspected to be from Flight SJ182 has been found, along with emergency signals transmitted by two devices. The search team has already located the aircraft's black boxes, and authorities expect to retrieve them soon.

site_title: Bank stocks back in vogue on stimulus, interest rate outlook
summary: US bank stocks have rebounded, jumping 8.4% in January, outperforming the S&P 500 Index. The rebound is attributed to anticipation of federal spending in 2021, rising interest rates, and optimism about economic growth. Large banks such as JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo are set to release quarterly earnings this week. Analysts predict a continued strong performance, driven by fiscal stimulus, infrastructure spending, and capital returns, with Goldman Sachs closing at a record high.

site_title: Aircraft lessors face bumpy year ahead
summary: Aircraft lessors in the Asia-Pacific region face pressure on leasing income, cash flow, and asset value, but may see a modest improvement from 2020. Analysts expect lessors to continue facing challenges due to airline customers' defaults and restructuring. S&P Global Ratings predicts negotiations and disputes between airlines and lessors, leading to potential lease restructurings, aircraft repossessions, and impairment charges. Some lessors, like BOC Aviation, have issued profit warnings and cut capital expenditure to shore up liquidity.

site_title: Medical students earn their spurs in packed Czech hospitals
summary: Hundreds of medical students in the Czech Republic are volunteering to help in hospitals packed with Covid-19 patients, with some working up to 12-hour shifts a month. The students, who are studying at Prague's Charles University, are performing various medical tasks, such as blood sugar tests and feeding patients, to help alleviate the burden on staff. The move is seen as a crucial step in coping with the country's high infection rate, which has led to one of the highest per capita Covid-19 daily death rates in Europe.

site_title: Singapore's China index adds to 2020 gains in early 2021
summary: Singapore's FTSE ST China Index gained 6.4% in the first four trading sessions of 2021, adding to its 7.4% total return in 2020. The index, comprising 17 stocks with significant China operations, saw notable gains from Wilmar International (8.4%), Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (3.7%), and Nanofilm Technologies International (13%). The index's newest entrant, Nanofilm, boosted its gains since listing to 92%. China's economy is expected to grow 8% in 2021, driven by a consumption-driven, services-orientated economy.

site_title: Vietnam to limit inbound flights ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: Vietnam will limit inbound flights until mid-February to reduce coronavirus risks ahead of the Chinese New Year. Only necessary flights approved by health and transport ministries are allowed, with all arrivals required to spend 14 days in quarantine. The country has suspended all inbound international commercial flights since March and has been operating repatriation flights to bring home Vietnamese citizens. Vietnam's strict quarantine and tracking measures have helped it fare better than many nations, with only 1,513 infections and 35 deaths. International flights may resume after the Lunar New Year.

site_title: UK commercial real estate looking to cut debt
summary: UK commercial property companies are looking to reduce debt and adapt to the post-pandemic economic landscape. The pandemic has led to a shift in consumer habits, with many businesses struggling to stay afloat. Companies like Hammerson are implementing strategies to reduce debt, including selling assets and introducing new leasing approaches. Despite a 56% decline in UK office investment in 2020, a rebound is expected later in the year, driven by sovereign wealth funds and overseas institutions. The UK real estate market is expected to take up to two years to recover.

site_title: Al Khalij, Masraf Al Rayan merger deal to create Qatar's second-largest lender
summary: Qatar's Al Khalij Commercial Bank and Masraf Al Rayan have agreed on a share-swap deal to create the country's second-largest lender, valued at $3 billion. The merger will give Al Rayan $47 billion in assets, surpassing its next two largest competitors. Al Rayan will become the new entity's chairman, while Al Khalij's Hamad Bin Faisal Bin Thani Al-Thani will be vice-chairman. The deal aims to create a stronger financial institution to support Qatar's economic growth, following a wave of bank consolidations in the Gulf's financial industry.

site_title: CEO Biyani sees quick OK of Future's US$3.4b deal despite Amazon dispute
summary: India's Future Group expects swift regulatory approval of its $3.4 billion deal to sell its retail assets, despite Amazon's efforts to block the deal. CEO Kishore Biyani believes the court's decision not to delay the transaction with regulators will lead to quick approval. The deal is crucial for Future Retail's survival, with over 1,700 outlets impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. Amazon has alleged the deal breaches pre-existing contracts, but Biyani is unsure of Amazon's intentions, saying it would be "confusing" to block the deal and harm employees and businesses.

site_title: Dollar recovers from brief dip after weak US payrolls report
summary: The US dollar recovered from a brief dip after a weak December payrolls report, with nonfarm jobs decreasing by 140,000 and the unemployment rate at 6.7%. The dollar index rose 0.35% to 90.117, driven by expectations for further stimulus measures to boost the economy. US President-elect Joe Biden said Americans needed immediate relief, and the dollar index has found some footing after hitting its lowest level since March 2018, climbing 1.2% over two sessions.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly shipping market report reveals a surge in tanker and dry bulk prices, with Capesize rates reaching $21,131, surpassing November and December 2020 levels. Activity increased due to a heated Brazilian market, while demand remained strong in the Atlantic and Pacific regions. In contrast, the Handysize market remained slow, with most Atlantic routes in the negative zone. VLCC rates fell 17% on the new 2021 Worldscale schedule, while Suezmax and Aframax rates plateaued. The market is expected to continue its upward trend, with brokers anticipating increased demand and fresh cargoes entering the market.

site_title: Apple, Amazon suspend Parler from App Store and web hosting service
summary: Apple and Amazon have suspended Parler, a social networking service popular with right-leaning users, from their App Store and web hosting service. The move comes after Parler failed to adequately moderate posts inciting violence, following a similar action by Google. The suspension is effective until Parler resolves the issues, with Amazon's move potentially taking the site offline unless it finds a new hosting service. Parler's CEO, John Matze, claims the suspension is a coordinated attack to kill competition and free speech, and the site may be unavailable for up to a week.

site_title: Consumer Electronics Show turns to tech for virtual salvation
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is hosting its first virtual event, moving away from its traditional in-person format due to the pandemic. The online event, built with Microsoft, will feature over 100 hours of programming, including keynote presentations, press conferences, and interactive sessions. Exhibitors have created video presentations, digital press kits, and chat forums to engage with attendees, while artificial intelligence will match interests and recommend connections. The event aims to replicate the "magic" of CES in Las Vegas, but organizers acknowledge that it won't be the same as an in-person experience.

site_title: Banking through the crisis: A test of speed, personalisation and purpose
summary: McKinsey analysts say Singapore banks must adapt to the post-pandemic banking landscape, focusing on productivity, capital management, and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations. Emerging Asian countries, particularly Singapore, are expected to buck the trend of low interest rates and economic challenges, presenting a "big opportunity" for growth. Experts recommend agility, new business models, and prioritizing ESG considerations to thrive in the long term, with up to a quarter of banking profits potentially influenced by ESG issues.

site_title: China Everbright unit wins 666.3m yuan bid for 65% stake in Tianjin enterprise
summary: China Everbright's indirect wholly owned subsidiary has won a 666.3 million yuan (S$136.4 million) bid for a 65% stake in Tianjin Binhai New Area Huantang Sewage Treatment, a state-owned enterprise with a daily water treatment capacity of 220,000 tonnes. The transaction is expected to expand China Everbright's presence in Tianjin and provide a foundation for further wastewater treatment projects. The acquisition will be carried out through a transfer agreement with the company's sole shareholder, Tianjin Binhai Environmental Protection Asset Development.

site_title: Singapore equity market in a 'sweet spot': Phillip Securities
summary: Singapore's equity market is poised for better returns in 2021, according to Phillip Securities' head of research Paul Chew. The market is in a "sweet spot" with potential economic rebound and low interest rates, supported by the success in containing the virus. Phillip Securities has set a target for the Straits Times Index (STI) to reach 3,200, based on a 14 times price-to-earnings ratio and a 25% earnings rebound. The research house has identified high dividend-yielding equities in less-volatile sectors, such as Ascott Residence Trust, Asian Pay Television Trust, and Manulife US Reit, as key picks for the year.

site_title: China Everbright unit buys stake in Tianjin firm
summary: China Everbright's indirect wholly owned subsidiary has acquired a 65% stake in Tianjin Binhai New Area Huantang Sewage Treatment for 666.3 million yuan (S$136.4 million). The firm, a wholly state-owned enterprise, owns projects with a daily water treatment capacity of 220,000 tonnes. This purchase marks China Everbright's entry into the water treatment sector, expanding its presence in the industry.

site_title: 42 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 42 new COVID-19 cases, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 58,638. The cases were confirmed as of noon on Sunday and included 29 new cases announced on Saturday night. The Ministry of Health confirmed that there were no community cases or cases in worker's dormitories. The total number of recovered patients stands at 58,596, with 67 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: Sea change in commitment to sustainability among funds
summary: The asset management industry is shifting towards sustainability, with momentum building towards environmental stewardship. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued guidelines on environmental risk management, which firms must implement to ensure the resilience of customers' assets. Large fund managers, such as Amundi and BlackRock, have set clear sustainability targets, including ESG analyses and proxy voting. Smaller firms, like Lion Global Investors and UOB Asset Management, are also integrating ESG into their investment processes. Industry leaders are calling for greater adoption of sustainable business practices and responsible investment, with some firms setting ambitious targets to reduce carbon emissions and promote long-term value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Young American adults top US$10t in assets for first time
summary: US young adults have reached a record $10 trillion in assets for the first time, doubling their wealth over the past four years despite the 2020 recession.
