However, this generation also has a massive debt burden. The Federal Reserve report notes that younger generations have been disproportionately affected, while older generations have benefited. Experts, including Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid and Luke Templeman, have called for policies to help younger generations save capital and prevent a wealth gap.

site_title: Nio launches first electric sedan model as Tesla delivers China-built SUV
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio launched its first sedan model, the ET7, at an event in Chengdu, China, targeting the country's largest car market with a drive range of over 1,000 km and starting price of 378,000 yuan. The launch comes as rival Tesla starts selling its China-made Model Y SUV. Nio's CEO, William Li, said the ET7's battery technology and features, such as lidar sensors, will compete with premium sedans like BMW's 5-series.

site_title: China to counter 'unjustified' foreign trade and business laws
summary: China has published new rules to counter "unjustified" foreign trade and business laws, particularly those imposed by the US. The rules, which took effect on Saturday, allow Chinese companies and citizens to report restrictions to the Ministry of Commerce within 30 days. The department will assess cases for potential violation of international law and provide support to those suffering significant losses. This move comes amid an ongoing backlash against Chinese companies, including Huawei and ByteDance, and a growing list of US-imposed restrictions on Chinese firms.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says its data system was breached
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) reported a breach of one of its data systems, where a third-party file-sharing service was illegally accessed. The breach, which has been contained, may have compromised sensitive information, including commercially and personally sensitive data. This incident comes after a series of cybersecurity incidents in New Zealand, with the bank warning of a rise in frequency and severity of such incidents. The full implications of the breach are still being determined, but the RBNZ is responding with urgency.

site_title: Pompeo lifts restrictions on US-Taiwan relationship
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has lifted restrictions on contacts between US officials and Taiwanese counterparts, likely to increase tensions with China. The move, made in the final days of President Donald Trump's presidency, reverses a policy that limited US engagement with Taiwan. The US has no official relations with Taiwan but has increased backing for the island, including arms sales and laws to counter China's pressure. China claims Taiwan as its territory, describing it as the most sensitive issue in US-China relations. The decision is expected to anger China and heighten US-China tensions.

site_title: China to provide Covid-19 vaccines free of charge: government official
summary: China will provide Covid-19 vaccines free of charge once available to the general public, according to a government official. Manufacturing and transport costs are factored into the government's plan. China has already administered over 9 million vaccine doses, with 7 million given since mid-December.

site_title: Pelosi tells lawmakers to prepare for action next week on Trump
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has urged lawmakers to prepare for action next week on President Donald Trump, amid the violent storming of the Capitol. She stopped short of saying whether she intends to move forward with impeachment, but insisted that Trump be held responsible for the attack. Pelosi has called for Trump to resign and raised the prospect of impeachment unless he leaves office immediately. A group of House Democrats plans to unveil an Article of Impeachment on Monday, accusing Trump of inciting insurrection. The House would have just days to act before President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, which could lead to a Senate impeachment trial.

site_title: Louvre museum visitor numbers plunge due to Covid restrictions
summary: The Louvre museum in Paris reported a significant drop in visitor numbers last year, with a decline of over 70% due to Covid-19 restrictions. The museum's receipts fell by 90 million euros compared to 2019, resulting in 2.7 million visitors in 2020, down from 9.6 million in 2019 and a record 10.2 million in 2018. The museum closed for six months during French lockdowns, contributing to the drastic decline in visitor numbers.

site_title: Chinese state-owned companies tap into Canada's wage subsidy despite diplomatic dispute
summary: Chinese state-owned companies, including Sinopec, CNOOC, and PetroChina, have accessed Canada's wage subsidy program despite a diplomatic dispute between the two governments. The program, launched in spring 2020, has paid out C$57 billion in claims, including multi-million dollar benefits. The Canadian government acknowledged that some state-owned enterprises have accessed the program to support jobs in Canada, but emphasized that the program applies to businesses of all sizes. The move has raised tensions between the two countries, which have been strained since Canada's 2018 arrest of a Huawei executive.

site_title: Pence will break with Trump and attend Biden-Harris inauguration
summary: Vice-President Mike Pence will attend President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20, breaking with President Donald Trump's decision not to attend. Pence had defied Trump's call to overturn the election and instead fulfilled his ceremonial duty to preside over Congress's acceptance of the Electoral College results. Trump had said he wouldn't attend, but Biden welcomed Pence's attendance, saying he'd be honored if the vice-president were to come. This move marks a significant break between Pence and Trump.

site_title: Indonesia finds body parts, debris, detects emergency signal of crashed jet
summary: Indonesia has detected signals that could be from a flight recorder of a Sriwijaya Air jet that crashed into the sea after taking off from Jakarta on Saturday. The Boeing 737-500 with 62 passengers and crew was headed to Pontianak when it disappeared from radar screens four minutes after takeoff. Human body parts, suspected plane debris, and a section of an emergency chute have been retrieved. The Indonesian Navy and search teams are focusing on the outer ring of the Laki and Lancang islands off the Jakarta coast, with a diver using an underwater metal detector to pick up signals for the plane's two black boxes.

site_title: Brisbane locks down as new strains put Australia on high alert
summary: Brisbane, Australia entered a three-day lockdown on January 8, 2021, amid concerns over the emergence of more contagious strains of Covid-19. The lockdown was triggered after a UK strain of the virus was detected in a cleaner at a quarantine hotel, marking Australia's first local case. Authorities are on high alert, with Queensland's chief health officer warning of a low risk but taking precautions. The move comes as parts of Sydney prepare to end a week-long lockdown due to an outbreak of new Covid-19 variants.

CEO Manfred Knof is preparing a radical restructuring to turn the bank profitable in the long term, with details expected to be announced in the first quarter. The move comes as the bank struggles to recover from the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Honda says domestic output could be affected by chip shortage
summary: Honda Motor has warned that its domestic output in Japan could be affected by a global semiconductor shortage, with the company beginning to see impact in parts supply. Honda will initially reduce production by 4,000 units this month, mainly affecting the Fit subcompact, and is taking measures to minimize the effect. The company's semiconductor inventory is secured until February, but it is under examination for supplies from then on. This is the latest example of automakers hit by a chip crunch as demand rebounds from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Indonesian clerics declare Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine halal
summary: Indonesian clerics have declared Sinovac's Covid-19 vaccine, CoronaVac, halal, or permissible under Islam. This decision was made by the Indonesian Ulema Council, days before Indonesia is set to start its vaccination program using the Chinese vaccine. The vaccine has been found to be 78% effective in a Brazilian trial and is awaiting emergency use approval from Indonesia's food and drug agency. The declaration aims to alleviate concerns among Indonesia's large Muslim population, which is struggling with the country's worst Covid-19 epidemic.

site_title: 23 new Covid-19 cases; 21 imported and two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 23 new Covid-19 cases on January 8, bringing the total to 58,836. The cases include 21 imported cases and two community cases. Crowne Plaza Changi Airport was closed for two weeks after a second unlinked case was confirmed, and staff will be tested for Covid-19. The number of new community cases has increased, with 161 patients recovering in community facilities and 61 remaining in hospital.

site_title: Britain approves Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine for use
summary: Britain's medical regulator approved Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine for use, adding it to the three vaccines already approved. The country has ordered 17 million doses of the vaccine, with supplies to begin in spring. This approval brings the total number of approved vaccines to three, including Pfizer/BioNTech's and Oxford University and AstraZeneca's vaccines.

site_title: British retail giant M&S logs sliding sales on virus
summary: British retail giant Marks and Spencer reported a 8.4% decline in total sales to £2.8 billion in its third quarter due to virus restrictions, despite solid online food sales. Clothing and household goods sales fell by a quarter, while food sales rose 2.2% due to a tie-up with Ocado. CEO Steve Rowe warned that the outlook remains challenging due to new COVID-19 restrictions and Brexit trade deal impacts, particularly in Ireland, the Czech Republic, and France.

site_title: Venture capital hits record high in US in 2020 despite pandemic
summary: US venture capital reached a record high in 2020, with nearly $130 billion invested in companies despite the COVID-19 pandemic. This represents a 14% increase from 2019, but a 9% decrease in the number of deals to 6,022. Mega-rounds, worth $100 million or more, also hit a record, with $63 billion raised in 318 deals. Successful tech companies are "vacuuming up" most financing, with "insatiable investor demand" for early-stage investments. Experts expect this trend to continue in 2021, driven by capital chasing investments in trending categories.

site_title: London declares 'major incident' with hospitals at risk of Covid deluge
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan declared a major incident due to a surge in coronavirus infections linked to a new strain, warning hospitals in the city could be overwhelmed in the next couple of weeks. The number of patients in London's hospitals has grown by 27% and those on ventilators by 42% over the last week. Khan urged the central UK government to take immediate action to combat the spread, including greater financial support, daily vaccination data, and measures to slow the virus's spread. The situation is described as "critical" with the spread of the virus "out of control".

site_title: Total to keep up renewables energy investments in 2021: CEO
summary: Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne stated the company will maintain its 2021 renewable energy investment efforts, aiming for 35 GW of gross renewable energy generation capacity by 2025. The investment budget for electricity and renewables will surpass $2 billion in 2021. Total is seeking to reduce its dependence on oil and shift towards electricity and renewable energy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 30.24 points to 1,633.19. Volume reached 10.034 billion lots worth RM7.165 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,040 to 353.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate eased to 3.3% in November, with resident and citizen unemployment rates improving from 4.6% and 4.7% respectively. OCBC appointed Helen Wong as its new group CEO, the first female CEO of a Singapore bank. Singapore also started its nationwide COVID-19 vaccination drive, with Prime Minister Lee receiving the vaccine. The country's economy also saw significant developments, including a new solar power project in India and successful capital securities pricing by UOB referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average Overnight Indexed Swap (Sora-OIS) rate.

site_title: SoftBank clashes again with Moody's over credit rating
summary: SoftBank Group criticized Moody's credit-rating practices, escalating a conflict between the Japanese company and the leading authority on corporate debt. SoftBank stated that Moody's report is based on subjective assumptions with no reasonable basis for support, instead pointing investors to rival firms. This clash dates back to March 2020, when Moody's downgraded SoftBank two notches amid the COVID-19 pandemic. SoftBank's share price has surged 150% since then, and the company is set to sell hybrid bonds worth 100 billion yen this month.

site_title: Singapore unemployment eases to 3.3% in November
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate eased to 3.3% in November, the lowest since July, according to the Manpower Ministry. The resident unemployment rate improved to 4.6% and the citizen unemployment rate to 4.7%, but Minister Josephine Teo cautioned against reading too much into a single data point. The NTUC welcomed the news, but acknowledged enduring challenges in sectors such as aviation and tourism. The labour movement pledged continued support for firms and workers. Updated employment figures will be released at the end of January.

site_title: Sembcorp unit bags new solar power project in India
summary: Sembcorp Energy India Ltd (SEIL), a unit of Singapore's Sembcorp Industries, won a 400 megawatt (MW) solar power project through its renewables subsidiary, Sembcorp Green Infra, in a closely-contested auction by the Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI). The project is a significant win for SEIL, which will likely contribute to the company's growth in the Indian renewable energy sector. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the project's size and SEIL's victory are seen as a positive sign for the company's expansion plans.

site_title: Indian sari pioneer Satya Paul dies at 78
summary: Indian fashion designer Satya Paul, known for modernizing the traditional sari with funky prints, has died at 78, according to his family. Born on February 2, 1942, Paul launched L'Affaire, India's first sari boutique, in 1980 and established his own label five years later. His designs combined Indian handloom techniques with modern palettes, producing saris with polka dots, zebra prints, and abstract motifs. Paul's pioneering work breathed life into the traditional sari, leaving a lasting impact on Indian fashion.

site_title: South Korea's IPO market poised for record year on booming retail demand
summary: South Korea's IPO market is expected to reach a record $24.2 billion this year, driven by robust retail demand and companies offering products in high demand during the pandemic, such as digital banking and electric car batteries. The market is poised to raise up to 20 trillion won, four times the amount raised in 2020. Analysts attribute the growth to the technology sector, including companies with significant online presence, and the government's plan to increase IPO shares allocation to retail customers to 30%. Several deals, including KakaoBank and LG Chem's electric car battery unit, are in the pipeline.

site_title: Credit Suisse expects higher costs from US case to push it to Q4 loss
summary: Credit Suisse expects to book a net loss for its fourth quarter due to increased provisions of US$850 million for a long-running US dispute over a residential mortgage-backed security. The bank had initially set aside US$300 million, but this amount is now expected to rise. This increase in provisions will push the bank into a loss for the fourth quarter.

site_title: STI joins Asia rally, nears 3,000-level again
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 86.22 points or 2.97% to 2,993.19, nearing the 3,000-level, following Wall Street optimism after Joe Biden's confirmation as US president. The rally also reflects expectations of stimulus spending to aid the US economy. Other Asian indices, such as Japan's Nikkei 225 and Malaysia's KLCI, also gained, while the Shanghai Composite Index retreated. The STI's gains were driven by a steepening yield curve, benefiting financial stocks.

site_title: Democrats inch toward second Trump impeachment after Capitol siege
summary: Congressional Democrats are considering impeaching President Donald Trump for a second time, following the US Capitol siege. The impeachment comes after Trump's false claims of election fraud and his alleged role in inciting the violence. Democratic leaders, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, have called for immediate impeachment proceedings if Trump's Cabinet refuses to remove him from power. Trump has released a video denouncing the violence, but his actions remain under scrutiny.

site_title: South Korea unveils inflatable isolation ward for Covid-19 patients
summary: South Korea's researchers have designed an inflatable "negative pressure" ward for isolating and treating Covid-19 patients. The mobile clinic modules, developed by the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), use a ventilation system to prevent the spread of airborne pathogens. The large, greenhouse-like tents can be installed and equipped in under a day and cost a fifth of building a conventional hospital ward. The units are ready for mass production, but no customers have been announced yet, addressing a global shortage of such beds during the pandemic.

site_title: TSMC's quarterly revenue hits record on strong iPhone demand
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported record quarterly revenue of NT$361.5 billion, driven by strong demand for Apple's new 5G iPhones. This marks a slight deviation from estimates, but the company's shares have rallied over 70% in the past 12 months. Revenue for the year reached NT$1.34 trillion, a 25% increase from 2019. The strong demand has also boosted other Apple suppliers, with assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry Co and chipmaker Dialog Semiconductor Plc reporting increased sales forecasts.

site_title: New member of Council of Presidential Advisers sworn in
summary: Singapore's Council of Presidential Advisers welcomed a new member, Peter Seah Lim Huat, who was sworn in on January 8, 2021. Seah, a 33-year banking veteran, replaces Po'ad Shaik Abu Bakar Mattar after 14 years of service. Seah holds key positions at DBS Group Holdings, GIC, Fullerton Financial Holdings, and STT Communications, and previously served as Vice Chairman and CEO of Overseas Union Bank.

site_title: UOB prices capital securities referencing Sora
summary: UOB successfully priced capital securities referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average Overnight Indexed Swap (Sora-OIS) rate, marking the first in Singapore. The reset coupon rate will reference the five-year Sora-OIS rate, promoting the adoption of Sora-based pricing benchmarks in the Singdollar bond market. The move is part of Singapore's transition to Sora as the new interest rate benchmark, expected to replace the Singapore Overnight Rate (SOR) by end-April 2021. The issuance was subscribed by high-net-worth and institutional investors, and UOB aims to expand Sora use across more financial products.

site_title: Australia: Shares notch best week in 2 months on broader global rally
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,757.9 points, their best week since November 13, 2020, driven by a global rally on expectations of US stimulus and economic recovery under a Democrat-controlled Senate. However, gains were tempered on Friday due to a lockdown in Brisbane after a case of the more contagious Covid-19 variant was discovered. The tech sub-index and energy stocks also posted gains, with buy-now-pay-later firms and energy stocks benefiting from rising oil prices.

site_title: 'It's impossible': Tokyo residents concerned about hosting Olympic Games
summary: Tokyo residents are concerned about hosting the Olympic Games due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. A December poll showed that 31% of Japanese residents favor delaying or canceling the Games, citing fears of an influx of foreign arrivals and potential further spikes in cases. Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga reiterated his intention to hold the Games, but many residents believe it's impossible or difficult to host them safely within the 200-day timeframe. Over 15,000 athletes are expected to attend, raising concerns about the spread of new virus mutations.

site_title: OUE closes Crowne Plaza Changi Airport hotel after two staff contract Covid-19
summary: The Crowne Plaza Changi Airport hotel, owned by OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit), has closed temporarily for two weeks after two staff members tested positive for COVID-19. The hotel is undergoing deep-cleaning and disinfecting under the guidance of the Ministry of Health (MOH) and the National Environment Agency. This is the second time a hotel owned by OUE C-Reit has been closed due to COVID-19 cases, following the 14-day closure of Mandarin Orchard Singapore in November.

site_title: Gold slips as rising yields, stronger dollar weigh
summary: Spot gold fell 0.3% to $1,907.66 per ounce, weighed down by rising yields and a stronger dollar. Despite hopes of large US stimulus measures boosting inflation expectations, the lack of a catalyst drove prices lower. The benchmark 10-year bond yield reached a fresh high above 1%, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. Investors await US non-farm payrolls data, while gold remains near its $2,000 handle, with a risk of a pullback if the Federal Reserve unwinds its asset purchasing program.

site_title: 7 things to watch for in Singapore's 2021 economic growth story
summary: Singapore's 2021 economic growth story is expected to be shaped by several key factors. The country's strong labor market and high productivity are expected to drive growth. However, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on global trade and supply chains remains a concern. Other factors to watch include the government's efforts to diversify the economy, the rise of digital technologies, and the potential for inflation. Overall, Singapore's economy is expected to continue its growth trajectory, with some sectors potentially outperforming others. The government's budget and policies will also play a crucial role in shaping the economy's outlook.

site_title: Rising food prices a boon for rural incomes, may trigger food security interventions in Asean: Maybank KE
summary: Rising food prices in Asean countries, particularly in major commodity exporters such as Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia, may boost rural incomes and employment, potentially triggering food security interventions. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's Food Price Index reached its highest level in six years in December 2020, driven by factors like adverse weather, supply chain disruptions, and stockpiling due to lockdowns. This could lead to increased domestic production and subsidies, as Asean governments aim to enhance food security and offset the impact of the pandemic on lower-income households.

site_title: MSCI, FTSE Russell drop Chinese telcos, shares lose US$10b in value
summary: Global index providers MSCI and FTSE Russell have removed three Chinese telecom companies, China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom Hong Kong, from their benchmarks due to a US investment ban. The deletions, effective January 8 and 11, respectively, have resulted in a nearly $10 billion loss in share value. The move is in response to President Donald Trump's November order banning Americans from investing in companies linked to China's military. The deletions are expected to lead to passive investors, such as index tracking funds, selling the stocks, and some analysts predict a short-term market impact.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end at 30-year peak as global reflation trade ignites rally
summary: Japanese stocks surged to a 30-year high, closing at 28,139.03 on the Nikkei 225 Index, driven by expectations of US fiscal stimulus and rising bond yields, which are expected to fuel global inflation. The Topix index rose 1.57% to its highest since February 2018. The tech sector led the gains, with semiconductor makers forecasting robust profits. The rally was fueled by a weak dollar and higher commodity prices, with stocks such as Murata Manufacturing Co Ltd and Daikin Industries Ltd gaining 5.04% and 3.81%, respectively.

site_title: Bitcoin slides more than 5% after topping US$40,000 for first time
summary: Bitcoin fell more than 5% on Friday, dropping to US$36,618.36 after reaching an all-time high of US$40,402.46 the previous day. This decline came after market participants had warned of a correction following the US$40,000 milestone. Bitcoin has surged over 700% since March, driven by increased demand from institutional, corporate, and retail investors, and could potentially reach US$146,000 if it becomes a safe-haven asset, according to JPMorgan strategists.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post sharpest weekly gain since 2008
summary: South Korean shares surged 4% to a record high on Friday, posting the sharpest weekly gain in over 12 years, driven by a surge in Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor. The Kospi index jumped 9.7% for the week, with chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix rising 7.1% and 2.6%, respectively. Hyundai Motor jumped 19.4% after discussing electric car and battery cooperation with Apple. Foreign buying added 1.64 trillion won to the market, with the won weakening and the benchmark bond yield rising.

site_title: US education secretary quits in second Trump cabinet resignation
summary: US Education Secretary Betsy DeVos resigned on January 8, 2021, becoming the second Trump cabinet member to quit over the US Capitol mob attack. DeVos stated her decision was influenced by President Trump's rhetoric, calling it "unconscionable for our country." DeVos' resignation comes amid Trump's own departure from the White House.

site_title: Japan's wages drop at double the pace expected by economists
summary: Japan's wages fell 2.2% in November, exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.9% decline, as employers continued to be cautious about the profit outlook amid the global coronavirus resurgence. This marks the eighth straight month of wage decline, adding to headwinds for households and businesses. Falling wages also darken the outlook for consumer spending, which accounts for over half of Japan's economy, and are expected to worsen in December due to reduced year-end bonuses.

images.alt_text: Japanese wages fell in November for an eighth straight month, dropping at more than double the pace expected by economists, as employers continued to be cautious about the profit outlook amid a global resurgence of the coronavirus.

site_title: The ex-cop behind China's largest gay dating app
summary: A former Chinese police officer, Ma Baoli, now leads Blued, a popular gay dating app that has over 58 million users worldwide. The app was launched in 2012 after Ma left the police force due to the stigma surrounding his own homosexuality. Despite China's classification of homosexuality as a mental illness until 2001, Blued has avoided conflict with authorities and instead focuses on raising awareness and tolerance of the LGBTQ community. The app has also made efforts to tackle HIV stigma and provide resources for users.

site_title: Samsung surges to new high on strong memory market outlook
summary: Samsung Electronics shares rose 7.1% to a record high on Friday amid a rebound in the memory-chip market. The company posted a 26% increase in operating income to 9 trillion won (US$10.94 billion) for the three months ended December. Micron Technology issued a bullish forecast, predicting a shortage of dynamic random access memory (DRAM) this quarter, driving up prices. Samsung's Galaxy smartphone sales were weaker due to competition from Apple and Chinese rivals, but the company plans to unveil its next flagship series, the Galaxy S21, on January 14.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics shares rose 7.1 per cent to a record high in Seoul on Friday amid signs of a rebound in the memory-chip market and off the back of a surge in earnings.

site_title: Asia: Equities track US records as stimulus bets roll in
summary: Asian markets continued to rise on Friday, following the US stock market's record-breaking performance, as investors anticipate a potential massive US stimulus package. Despite concerns over rising Covid-19 cases, investors are optimistic about the economy, citing the Federal Reserve's promise of low interest rates and the Biden administration's plans to revive spending. Markets in Tokyo, Taipei, Singapore, and Shanghai rose, while Hong Kong and Wellington edged down, as traders await the release of US jobs data for December.

site_title: Temasek-backed biotech firm Abbisko raises US$123m from Carlyle, Warburg
summary: Abbisko Therapeutics Co, a biotech firm backed by Temasek, has raised US$123 million in a funding round led by Carlyle Group and Warburg Pincus. The company, based in Shanghai, focuses on cancer research and therapy development. Proceeds from the funding will be used to accelerate clinical programs and expand its preclinical pipeline. Existing shareholders, including Lilly Asia Ventures and Temasek Holdings, also participated in the round.

site_title: Australia to require negative Covid-19 results for international travellers
summary: Australia will require all international travellers to test negative for Covid-19 before boarding flights to the country, tightening travel rules to stop the UK Covid-19 variant. The country also plans to reduce the cap on international arrivals to some states to half until February 15.

site_title: Chinese bargain hunters pile into stocks blacklisted by Trump
summary: Chinese investors are taking advantage of US President Donald Trump's executive order banning US securities investment in Chinese companies allegedly owned or controlled by the Chinese military. As US investors dump shares in sanctioned companies, Chinese investors are buying up shares in Hong Kong-listed companies such as CRCC, CNOOC, and Tencent, with holdings tripling in some cases. Experts predict that a Joe Biden presidency will reverse the investment ban, and Chinese investors are betting on a turnaround, seeing the companies as globally competitive and "China's name cards."

site_title: Top Glove defends board after BlackRock criticism
summary: Top Glove defended its board after BlackRock criticized its handling of a coronavirus outbreak, citing workers' accounts of poor conditions and the firing of a whistleblower. BlackRock, the world's biggest asset manager, voted against the re-election of six independent directors, citing concerns over governance. Top Glove's board said its independent directors have served an average of six years and meet regularly to discuss pandemic matters. The company holds over 5,000 infected foreign workers and one died in the outbreak last year.

site_title: PM Lee receives Covid-19 vaccine as Singapore starts nationwide vaccination drive
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong received the Covid-19 vaccine on January 8, 2021, at the start of a nationwide vaccination drive in Singapore. Alongside 88 healthcare workers, he was administered the vaccine at the Singapore General Hospital. Lee emphasized the vaccine's effectiveness and encouraged Singaporeans to take it up, stating it will make them and their loved ones safer. The vaccine is free for all Singaporeans and long-term residents, with more shipments expected in the coming months.

site_title: Hyundai Motor says in early talks with Apple, shares surge 20%
summary: Hyundai Motor said it is in early-stage discussions with Apple Inc. to cooperate on electric cars and batteries. The talks come after Reuters reported that Apple is moving forward with self-driving car technology and plans to produce a passenger vehicle with its own battery technology as early as 2024. Hyundai's shares surged 20% following the announcement. Apple declined to comment on the discussions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Friday, following a record lead from Wall Street, as investors await further US stimulus measures after Democrats took control of Capitol Hill. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.30% to 27,630.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange gained 0.13%. The gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and Trump's threat to extend a stock rally.

site_title: China orders local media to censor Alibaba coverage: FT
summary: China has ordered domestic media to censor reports about an antitrust probe into Alibaba Group Holding, signaling the issue's national political sensitivity. The directive, issued by the government's propaganda arm, restricts news outlets from engaging in extended analysis without permission. The move targets Alibaba, led by billionaire Jack Ma, whose empire has been impacted by the investigation and restricted access to global sites. Authorities have previously exerted control over domestic news coverage of politically sensitive topics, including the Covid-19 outbreak and Hong Kong protests.

site_title: Big tech show, now virtual, aims for digital connections
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) has shifted to a digital-only format due to the pandemic, aiming to provide digital connections for the technology industry. The January 11-14 event will feature new innovations in healthcare, artificial intelligence, robotics, and smart homes, with some companies unveiling products virtually, such as Audi's electric sports car and LG's large bendable display. Analysts predict that large multinational firms will generate buzz, but small companies may struggle in the digital format, with some expecting a decline in participation. The show's organizers plan to return to a physical format in Las Vegas for 2022.

site_title: Pfizer, BioNTech vaccine appears effective against mutation in new coronavirus variants: study
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech's COVID-19 vaccine appears effective against a key mutation in new coronavirus variants, according to a laboratory study. The vaccine neutralized the virus with the N501Y mutation, which could increase transmissibility and evade antibody neutralization. The study, not yet peer-reviewed, suggests the vaccine's effectiveness against this mutation, providing a potential solution to emerging variants.

site_title: Indonesia frees cleric linked to Bali bombing
summary: Indonesia has released radical cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, 82, from prison after completing an unrelated jail term. Bashir, a key figure in the Islamist terror network Jemaah Islamiyah, was linked to the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed over 200 people. His release has sparked grief and anger among victims' families, with some calling for him to be kept under close surveillance to prevent him from spreading his extremist views. Bashir had been previously jailed for his involvement in the bombings, but his conviction was quashed on appeal.

images.alt_text: A radical cleric linked to the Bali nightclub bombings was freed from prison on Friday, stirring grief and anger among victims nearly two decades after more than 200 people, mostly foreign tourists, were killed in Indonesia's worst terror attack.

site_title: Evergrande's aggressive share buybacks fail to impress investors
summary: China Evergrande Group's latest share buyback effort has failed to impress investors, with its shares closing at HK$14.28 in Hong Kong, down 12% since the last buyback on Dec 2. Despite spending HK$1.3 billion to buy shares at a premium, the move has done little to shore up the stock. Evergrande faces new sector restrictions on borrowings and a debt pile of US$120 billion, prompting analysts to question the company's ability to prioritize debt reduction over earnings.

site_title: Intel woes provide timely lesson for Samsung
summary: Samsung ends 2020 on a strong note, driven by its dominance in memory chips, with expected operating profit for the three months to December at $8.2 billion. Despite disappointing smartphone sales, the company's shares have reached a record high due to a recovery in memory chip prices. In contrast, Intel faces a leadership vacuum and is under pressure from activist investors to break up, following decades of losing market share to competitors like Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Prices for memory chips, Samsung's main profit driver, are showing signs of a recovery, helped by industry-wide supply cuts and improving server demand.

site_title: Biden names final economic team picks
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has announced his final economic team picks, including Rhode Island Governor Gina Raimondo as commerce secretary, Boston Mayor Martin Walsh as labour secretary, and former Obama official Isabel Guzman as small business administrator. This diverse team, which includes former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen as treasury secretary, aims to support small businesses, increase union density, and rebuild the middle class. The new officials will prioritize addressing the worst jobs crisis in nearly a century, triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Joe Biden on Thursday unveiled his picks for commerce secretary, labour secretary and small business administrator to fill his incoming economics team.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands CEO takes leave for cancer treatment
summary: Las Vegas Sands CEO Sheldon Adelson, 87, is taking a leave of absence for cancer treatment, resuming treatment after retaining his role in 2019. President Robert Goldstein will take over as acting chairman and CEO. The move is unlikely to impact the company's strategic direction or operations, particularly at its Sands China arm. Adelson's absence may have implications for the company's relations with Macau and Beijing, but the analyst DS Kim sees no negative impact on its market positioning.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.72 points to 1,597.23. The decline was largely due to regional market trends, with stocks in Europe and the US experiencing downward pressure. Despite this, the number of gainers outpaced losers 171 to 137. The market's performance was influenced by ongoing US-EU trade talks and concerns about new Trump threats to extend a stocks rally.

site_title: Surrounded by shrinking circle of aides, a brooding Trump lays into Pence
summary: US President Donald Trump has isolated himself in the White House, surrounding himself with a small group of loyalists and lashing out at Vice-President Mike Pence and others who refused to try to prevent the certification of President-elect Joe Biden's 2020 election victory. Trump has berated Pence and his chief of staff, Marc Short, for their actions, and has been criticized for his role in the unprecedented breach of the Capitol building on January 6, which resulted in four deaths. The rift between Trump and Pence is deep, with some advisors saying they may never speak to each other again.

site_title: WhatsApp updates terms as Facebook moves to monetise app
summary: WhatsApp has updated its terms to allow Facebook to share more information with its parent company, share contacts and profile data with other Facebook apps, and roll out advertising and e-commerce. Users must accept the changes by February 8 or risk losing access to the service. The update has sparked criticism from user advocates, who claim the changes are not legal and force users to accept. Facebook aims to monetize WhatsApp by enabling businesses to contact clients and sell products directly on the platform.

site_title: US sets new record with nearly 4,000 Covid-19 deaths in one day: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded a record 3,998 Covid-19 deaths on January 7, 2021, according to Johns Hopkins University. This surpassed previous daily death records. The 265,246 new infections reported during the same period also set a new record. The surge in cases and deaths is attributed to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: China's internet regulator weighs tighter curbs on payment, shopping platforms
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has proposed updating its rules to widen oversight of online services, including payment, shopping, and livestreaming platforms, for the first time. The plan aims to protect citizens' rights, safeguard national security, and promote the healthy development of internet services. The regulator is seeking public feedback until February 7 and marks a shift towards stricter regulation of the country's vast internet space. This move comes after China has ramped up scrutiny of its technology giants, reversing a once laissez-faire approach.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1% at open on Friday, tracking Wall Street's gains after the democratic victory in Georgia, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,935.30. Gainers outnumbered losers 118 to 31, and shares of Sembcorp Marine and Singtel rose 1.2% and 0.4%, respectively. The rally follows Wall Street's overnight surge to record highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 0.7% and the S&P 500 gaining 1.5%.

site_title: Japan household spending posts surprise gain in Nov, rises for second month
summary: Japan's household spending unexpectedly rose 1.1% in November, marking the second consecutive month of growth, beating forecasts for a 1.5% decline. This recovery is attributed to improving consumer sentiment despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. However, a recent one-month state of emergency in Tokyo and sluggish wages may hinder the recovery, with some analysts predicting an economic contraction in the first quarter. The government's growth targets remain uncertain due to these factors.

site_title: Grayscale holds over 3% of Bitcoin, sees pension interest
summary: Grayscale Investments' new CEO, Michael Sonnenshein, expects increased interest from institutional investors, such as pension funds and endowments, to fuel growth. The company has seen over 3% of Bitcoin's total supply held in its Bitcoin Trust, with the majority of inflows amid a rally that pushed Bitcoin to $40,000. Grayscale plans to double its staff and introduce new products, but Sonnenshein notes that the company's success may impact Bitcoin's supply, potentially increasing its scarcity.

site_title: Samsung Electronics forecasts 25.7% jump in Q4 operating profit
summary: Samsung Electronics forecasts a 25.7% jump in Q4 operating profit to 9 trillion won, driven by demand for devices powered by its chips due to the coronavirus pandemic. The prediction slightly misses analyst forecasts, but the company's sales forecasts remain lower than its third-quarter figures. Samsung is crucial to South Korea's economic health, with its overall turnover equivalent to a fifth of the national gross domestic product. The company's operating profits and sales forecasts were affected by the pandemic and the burial of late chairman Lee Kun Hee.

site_title: ESG backed S$17.4b in Covid-19 business loans in March-Dec 2020: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's government agency Enterprise Singapore (ESG) provided S$17.4 billion in Covid-19 business loans to over 20,000 companies between March and December 2020, exceeding last year's S$1.3 billion. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized that while credit support is crucial, it must be paired with broader business transformation and digitalization to boost growth. The government will evolve its schemes as the economy recovers, and some may wind down to release resources for other sectors in need.

site_title: Boeing to pay US$2.5b fine over 737 MAX: DOJ
summary: The US Department of Justice (DOJ) has fined Boeing $2.5 billion for allegedly defrauding regulators over the 737 MAX, a plane grounded for 20 months after two deadly crashes. Prosecutors accused Boeing of prioritizing profit over candor, engaging in "half-truths" and a "cover-up." The company concealed information about the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), an anti-stall system linked to the crashes. The fine reflects Boeing's conduct, including its initial reluctance to cooperate with the investigation. The agreement settles charges related to Boeing's statements to regulators about the issues with the MAX.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Bullard expects ongoing economic recovery as vaccines take hold
summary: St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard expects the US economic recovery to continue this year, driven by vaccines taking hold and massive monetary and fiscal support. Despite some downside risk, Bullard notes high aggregate resources available to fund consumption, suggesting continued recovery in the first half of 2021. This aligns with Fed policymakers' expectations to keep monetary policy accommodative for years to come.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, ISDN, Soilbuild Construction, Secura
summary: Sembcorp Industries won a 400 megawatt solar power project in Rajasthan, India, under a 25-year power purchase agreement. ISDN Holdings' shares jumped 23.3% after CGS-CIMB raised its target price to 72 Singapore cents due to better revenue prospects. Soilbuild Construction Group appointed Tan Hee Wee as CEO of its construction business, while Secura Group clinched a S$13.5 million contract for unarmed security services.

site_title: UK virus strain triggers lockdown in Australia's Brisbane
summary: A three-day lockdown has been imposed in Brisbane, Australia's third-largest city, after a worker at a quarantine hotel contracted the highly infectious UK strain of Covid-19. Over two million residents are required to stay at home, with restrictions including mask-wearing for essential reasons only. The lockdown is aimed at stopping the spread of the UK strain, which appears to be more infectious than previously detected strains in Australia. The move follows recent outbreaks in Sydney and Melbourne, and comes ahead of planned vaccine rollouts in February.

site_title: Optimism sweeps UK boardrooms but slow recovery ahead: Deloitte
summary: UK business leaders show optimism, with a surge in confidence in profit margins, ahead of tighter Covid-19 restrictions. A Deloitte survey found the biggest improvement in optimism since 2007, despite half expecting revenues to take until end 2021 to return to pre-pandemic levels. Expectations for hiring and investment recovered, but remain in negative territory. Economists believe Britain has slipped back into recession, with the Bank of England estimating a 1% contraction in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Australia: Stimulus hopes put shares on track for best week in two months
summary: Australia shares are on track for their best week in two months, driven by vaccine roll-out prospects and US stimulus. The S&P/ASX 200 index edged up 0.1% to 6,712 points, set to close the week 2.4% higher. However, a three-day lockdown in Brisbane curbed gains on Friday after a case of the more contagious Covid-19 variant was discovered.

site_title: Trump acknowledges Biden victory a day after Capitol chaos
summary: President Donald Trump conceded to Joe Biden's presidency on January 7, 2021, a day after supporters stormed the US Capitol, defiling American democracy. Trump condemned the violence and stated his focus would be on a smooth transition to a Biden administration. His concession marked a significant shift from his previous claims of a stolen election. The incident highlighted a stunning assault on American democracy, as Congress certified Biden's victory.

site_title: UK job market strengthened in Dec for first time in three months: REC
summary: Britain's job market strengthened for the first time in three months in December, according to a recruiters' survey, driven by increased business activity and market confidence partly due to vaccine news. Growth in permanent hiring remained modest, reflecting ongoing headwinds from the Covid-19 pandemic and Brexit. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation attributed the upturn to improved market confidence, but warned that the UK economy faces a fresh blow with its economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Baidu plans smart electric vehicle company, to make cars at Geely plant: sources
summary: China's Baidu plans to form a smart electric vehicle company with a majority stake at Geely's plants, utilizing in-car software from Baidu and engineering expertise from Geely. The venture aims to revamp existing manufacturing facilities to produce smart electric vehicles, marking a significant foray into the automotive sector by the leading search engine company.

site_title: Audi A4 Avant review: Real estate investment
summary: The Audi A4 Avant is a practical and versatile car ideal for those who value space and flexibility. With a larger boot and improved loading capabilities, it outshines the sedan version. The car offers a well-appointed interior, advanced tech, and a comfortable drive, making it a worthwhile consideration for those who appreciate the benefits of a wagon. Although it may not be a popular choice in Singapore, the A4 Avant is a smart and capable vehicle that deserves more attention.

site_title: Oil hits 11-month highs on Saudi cuts, shrugs off US turmoil
summary: Oil prices reached 11-month highs, with Brent crude settling at $54.38 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) at $50.83 a barrel, after Saudi Arabia announced deeper oil cuts. Market focus shifted away from US political turmoil, as investors reacted positively to the Saudi pledge. The price increases were driven by firmer equities and reduced market uncertainty.

site_title: Pelosi says removing Trump 'emergency of highest magnitude'
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi urged President Donald Trump's removal from power, calling it an "emergency of the highest magnitude." She blamed Trump for the pro-Trump mob storming the Capitol and encouraged Vice-President Mike Pence and Trump's cabinet to invoke the 25th amendment. If not invoked, Pelosi said Congress is prepared to move forward with impeachment. Pelosi criticized Trump, saying he "incited an armed insurrection against America" and praised some "courageous" Republicans for speaking out against him.

site_title: Bitcoin soars past US$40,000 for the first time
summary: Bitcoin surpassed US$40,000 for the first time, rising US$10,000 in five days. The price surge is attributed to increased investor interest, particularly with the US economy poised to deliver more stimulus under President Biden. However, experts warn of a potential correction, with some predicting a new bubble, while others see it as a legitimate alternative to gold. Central banks are also testing digital applications in response to the rise of cryptocurrencies.

site_title: US Vice-President Pence opposes using 25th amendment to remove Trump
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence opposes using the 25th amendment to remove President Donald Trump from power, according to reports. Democrats and some Republicans have called for Trump administration officials to invoke the 25th amendment or for impeachment proceedings to remove Trump after his supporters stormed the US Capitol. Pence's opposition may hinder efforts to relieve Trump of his powers before he leaves office on January 20.

site_title: Trump, Republican malcontents will add to obstacles for Biden
summary: A mob scene at the US Capitol building on January 6, 2021, marked the final act of Donald Trump's presidency, with the president himself seemingly embracing the violence. Trump's support among Republican congressional party members began to peel away, with several lawmakers condemning the protesters. The incident is seen as a final blow to Trump's influence, with the president eventually signaling a peaceful transfer of power to President-elect Joe Biden. The event has also raised concerns about the state of American democracy, with Trump's actions and rhetoric seen as a threat to the country's institutions.

images.alt_text: The storming of the US Capitol was not a coup or even an attempt at one, but it was the latest in a series of stab wounds to the American body politic inflicted by Mr Trump and his administration.

site_title: Fed officials all backed bond-buying pace: Fed's December minutes
summary: Federal Reserve officials have unanimously agreed to maintain the pace of asset purchases at $120 billion per month, with nearly all favoring the current composition. The committee strengthened its commitment to bond buying until "substantial further progress" is made toward employment and inflation goals. Officials noted that adjustments to asset purchases could be considered if progress is made, but no specific triggers have been agreed upon. Chair Jerome Powell described the new guidance as "powerful," with some officials predicting a potential tapering of purchases in 2022 or later.

site_title: Pompeo angers China with Hong Kong threat, plan to send envoy to Taiwan
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced plans to sanction individuals involved in the arrest of 53 Hong Kong democracy activists and send a US ambassador to Taiwan, drawing China's anger and threat of retaliation. Pompeo also expressed outrage over the arrest of an American citizen, stating the US will not tolerate arbitrary detention or harassment of its citizens. The moves come amid a significant crackdown on dissent in Hong Kong since China's imposition of a security law last year.

images.alt_text: Washington may sanction those involved in the arrest of over 50 people in Hong Kong and will send the US ambassador to the United Nations to visit Taiwan, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Thursday, drawing anger and the threat of retaliation from Beijing.

site_title: Indonesia's biggest lender said to be mulling US$1b rights issue
summary: Bank Rakyat Indonesia, Indonesia's largest lender by assets, is exploring a potential US$1 billion rights issue to strengthen its capital base. The fundraising plan could take place in the first half of this year, with the proceeds intended to prepare for potential acquisitions. The bank's state-owned status and significant assets, valued at 1,448 trillion rupiah, make it a key player in the country's national economy recovery program. Deliberations are ongoing, and the bank's focus remains on maintaining and improving performance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending rallies on Wall Street, as risk-on investor sentiment persisted despite a state of emergency due to a surge in new virus cases. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.72% or 198.98 points to 27,689.11, while the Topix index gained 0.27% or 5.02 points to 1,831.32. The rally is attributed to investors' willingness to overlook the emergency, citing the potential for economic recovery and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: France plans mass duck slaughter as bird flu hits foie gras
summary: France is considering a mass preventive cull of ducks to halt the spread of a severe strain of bird flu, with over 350,000 ducks already slaughtered since December 24. The highly pathogenic H5N8 virus has been detected in 124 outbreaks, with Belgium also reporting cases and culled contaminated flocks. The French government is weighing a wider cull, amid concerns over the impact on the foie gras industry, which could lead to a two-month production freeze. The bird flu outbreak has already led to a suspension of French poultry imports to China, further threatening the industry.

site_title: US suspends tariffs on French goods in digital tax dispute
summary: The US has suspended planned tariffs on $1.3 billion in French goods, citing ongoing investigations of similar measures in 10 other jurisdictions. The tariffs, imposed in July 2020, targeted French handbags and cosmetics in retaliation for France's digital services tax on tech firms. The US Trade Representative cited concerns over fairness, while the EU expressed willingness to work with the US on finding a global solution. France warned it would respond firmly if the US reverses its decision, amid ongoing talks to address the digital tax policy dilemma.

site_title: Biden confirms Merrick Garland as pick for attorney general
summary: President-elect Joe Biden has confirmed Merrick Garland as his pick for US attorney general. A centrist judge with a record as a moderate liberal, Garland was previously blocked by Republicans from serving on the Supreme Court in 2016. If confirmed, he will lead a Justice Department that must decide whether to investigate President Donald Trump and his associates for various actions over the past four years. Garland emphasized the importance of independence from political pressure and vowed to approach his new role with "humility."

site_title: Sembcorp unit bags new solar power project in India
summary: Sembcorp Energy India Limited (SEIL), a unit of Sembcorp Industries, has won a 400 MW solar power project in Rajasthan, India through a closely-contested auction by the Solar Energy Corporation of India (SECI). The project is expected to be ready for commercial operation by mid-2022 and will be funded through a mix of internal funds and debt. This win brings SEIL's renewables portfolio to over 3,000 MW in operation and under development across Singapore, China, and India.

site_title: US: Dow Jones, S&P, Nasdaq end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks surged to fresh records, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index reaching new highs. The Dow Jones jumped 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 1.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 2.6%. The rally followed the certification of President-elect Biden's election victory and the Democrats' slim majority in Congress. Investors are optimistic about a stronger recovery as vaccines roll out and stimulus is pushed through. However, economic damage remains, with layoffs continuing and jobless benefits applications at high levels.

site_title: Trump insurrection undermines US international interests
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's foreign agenda is being undermined by the chaotic transition period following President Donald Trump's insurrection on January 6, 2021. The international implications are significant, with allies expressing concern and foes potentially taking advantage of the US' democratic turmoil. The US' democracy promotion agenda, which prioritizes restoring a commitment to democracy, may be less effective in the short term, and critics argue that focusing on economic reform and material prosperity could be a more effective approach in attracting developing countries to emulate the US.

site_title: Bank lending to plastics industry faces scrutiny
summary: Banks have provided over $1.7 trillion in finance to 40 plastics companies without requiring measures to reduce plastic pollution. A report by Portfolio.earth found that Bank of America, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase were the top three financiers of plastics between 2015 and 2019. Campaigners are calling on lenders to make loans conditional on recycling measures, similar to their approach to fossil fuel projects. The financial sector is seen as crucial in addressing plastic pollution, with Vivid Economics' director Robin Smale stating that banks need to take a proactive role in addressing the issue.

site_title: US considering adding Alibaba, Tencent to China investment ban
summary: The US is considering adding tech giants Alibaba and Tencent to a blacklist of firms allegedly owned or controlled by the Chinese military, in a move that would target Asia's two most valuable companies worth a combined $1.3 trillion. The decision is part of President Trump's hardline policy against China, following an executive order in November that banned US investors from buying shares of Chinese firms. The move has sparked skepticism among investors, who argue that it would have significant reputational and financial impacts on the US stock market.

site_title: Saudis raise Asia, US oil prices after shock output cut
summary: Saudi Arabia has raised oil prices for Asia and the US, increasing prices by 70 cents for Asian shipments and 20 cents for US grades. This move comes after the kingdom cut its output by 1 million barrels per day, sparking a 7% increase in Brent crude prices. The decision, made after a meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+), is the second monthly price hike for Saudi Arabia's main market. The production cuts will last until April, with Saudi Arabia pumping around 8.12 million barrels per day in February and March.

site_title: Oxley gets S$106.4m investment from Hong Kong private equity firm
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, received an investment of S$106.4 million from Hong Kong private equity firm Dignari Capital Partners. The investment was made through a convertible note issuance, with a maturity of 24 months and an option to extend by 12 months. Oxley plans to use the funds for working capital and general corporate purposes. The investment is expected to strengthen the company's financing capabilities and position it for future growth.

site_title: Curtain falls on CoAssets crowdfund platform, but no systemic risk seen in P2P lending
summary: Singapore-based crowdfunding platform CA Funding, a subsidiary of CoAssets Group, is winding down after transferring US$30 million of receivables to a debt recovery firm. The move is likely to bring to the fore issues of transparency and investor education, which could impact the future of crowdfunding in the country. Industry watchers say there is no systemic risk seen in peer-to-peer lending, but investors may lose their investments. Regulatory safeguards are in place, but investor education may need to be stepped up, with some relying on licensing as a form of endorsement without conducting due diligence.

images.alt_text: Former CoAssets COO Lawrence Lim (left) departed the company in 2019 due to irreconcilable differences with founders Getty Goh (right) and Seh Huan Kiat.

site_title: HK stock traders dash for HSBC as China giants sink
summary: Hong Kong investors are seeking refuge in bank shares amid uncertainty for growth stocks, with HSBC and Standard Chartered rising as much as 5.5% and 7.7% respectively. The bank's recent gain is attributed to a steepening yield curve, creating a favorable environment for lending. HSBC's net interest margin is expected to improve as investors anticipate share buybacks, with the bank potentially spending up to $3.5 billion between this year and next. This rebound follows months of uncertainty for the lender, driven by regulatory, economic, and geopolitical pressures.

site_title: Share buybacks hit S$1.03b in 2020, up 75% from prior year: SGX
summary: Singapore's share buyback transactions in 2020 reached S$1.03 billion, a 75% increase from 2019, with 100 primary-listed stocks participating. DBS, Wilmar International, OCBC, and Singapore Technologies Engineering led the buybacks. Wilmar bought back 11.3 million shares in December 2020, marking its return to share buybacks after a 4-year hiatus. The buybacks were largely driven by employee compensation plans and long-term capital management, with a valuation gap between Wilmar and its Shenzhen-listed subsidiary Yihai Kerry Arawana.

site_title: The future of virtual AGMs
summary: Virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) have become increasingly popular, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic. A study by the Asian Corporate Governance Association found significant growth in virtual meetings across Asia, with over 160 Canadian listed issuers and 111 Japanese companies adopting virtual technology in 2020. Regulatory authorities in Singapore fast-tracked legislation to allow virtual AGMs, while others across the region discouraged physical meetings. The shift to virtual AGMs is expected to continue, with many jurisdictions now allowing remote meeting formats. This trend is seen as a response to the pandemic and a growing demand for digital business practices.

site_title: Bitter wait for CoAssets noteholders as investments turn sour
summary: CoAssets' promissory noteholders face a long-drawn process to claw back their investments as hundreds of retail investors stand to lose their investments due to the group's disposal of $30 million in irrecoverable bad debt to Hong Kong-based debt recovery company Sunfits. Industry watchers predict a prolonged legal process before the outcome is clear. Promissory notes, which are essentially promises to pay investors, are considered legally binding, but their validity depends on enforceable guarantees and transparency in fund usage. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is involved in the investigation, and CoAssets' co-founders and staff are being questioned.

site_title: Biden calls Capitol protests one of 'darkest days' in US history
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden described the January 6th Capitol protests as one of the "darkest days" in US history, blaming President Donald Trump for inciting the violence. Biden criticized Trump for encouraging his supporters to reject the election results, leading to deadly chaos at the Capitol. Biden's comments come as he prepares to take office and mark a stark contrast with Trump's presidency, which Biden described as having "unleashed an all-out assault on the institutions of our democracy."

site_title: US dollar edges higher but hovers above 2018 lows
summary: The US dollar edged higher, hovering above 2018 lows, after Democrats took control of the Senate, potentially leading to larger fiscal stimulus under President-elect Joe Biden. Analysts expect higher inflation and widening budget and trade deficits, which could negatively impact the dollar. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 89.567, while the Australian dollar slipped 0.3% and the euro dropped 0.2%. The US dollar gained 0.3% to 103.385 yen, but the British pound traded flat.

site_title: 82 HDB resale flats sold for at least S$1m in 2020: SRX
summary: In 2020, 82 HDB resale flats sold for at least S$1 million, a 28% increase from 64 units in 2019. These transactions accounted for 0.35% of total HDB resale flats sold, with December adding 10 more high-value transactions. HDB resale prices rose 6.4% for the year, surpassing the 0.3% increase in 2019. Experts attribute the market's resilience to the pandemic to record-low mortgage rates, fiscal stimulus, and policy changes, with resale volume expected to rise by 3-5% in 2021.

site_title: Last days: Chaos, armed insurrection and a vengeful loser
summary: US President Donald Trump's term ended with chaotic and divisive events, with his administration being criticized for its response to COVID-19. Despite this, Trump's administration achieved notable policy successes, including corporate tax reform and improved relations between Arabs and Israelis. The administration also played a role in the development of COVID-19 vaccines, which have saved lives. However, Trump's final weeks in office were marked by confusion in the markets and a lack of celebration for his policy wins, suggesting a tumultuous end to his presidency.

site_title: A centuries-old play sheds light on the pandemic
summary: A centuries-old play, Oedipus Rex, is being revived by Nine Years Theatre, with its first live production in almost a year. The play, first performed in 429 BC, tells the story of King Oedipus who uncovers the truth that he is the murderer of his father and stabs his own eyes in exile. The production's director, Cherilyn Woo, believes the play offers comfort and catharsis in the pandemic, highlighting themes of fate, free will, and the consequences of human actions.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise for second day as commodity, construction stocks gain
summary: European stocks rose for a second day, with the Stoxx 600 index advancing 0.5% to near February 2020 highs. Construction and commodity-linked stocks led gains, driven by Saint Gobain's upbeat sales forecast and hopes of larger US stimulus. London's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX index also rose, with the latter advancing 0.6%.

site_title: A nod to Bangkok's past
summary: Central: The Original Store in Bangkok is a 50s-era tribute to the city's largest retail group, paying homage to its history while being relevant to the present. The five-level shophouse, designed by Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen and Tokyo-based interior designers Tripster, features a traditional Thai restaurant by acclaimed chef David Thompson, a jazz bar, and an exhibition space showcasing the history of Central. The store retains original structures from the 1950s building and incorporates traditional hand-crafted terracotta and bespoke iron vitrines.

site_title: US Congress certifies Biden win hours after Capitol Hill assault
summary: The US Congress formally certified Joe Biden's election victory hours after hundreds of President Donald Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol, causing chaos and violence. Despite Trump's encouragement to protest, Congress ultimately certified the Electoral College vote with Biden receiving 306 votes and Trump 232. Four people died and 52 were arrested in the assault, with several Republican aides resigning in protest. The violent event was the culmination of months of divisive rhetoric, and some prominent Republicans blamed Trump for inciting the mob. The certification marked the end of Trump's presidency, with Vice President-elect Kamala Harris set to take office alongside Biden on January 20.

site_title: Amazon pledges US$2b for affordable homes in three US regions
summary: Amazon has pledged $2 billion to support affordable housing projects in three US regions, including its Seattle headquarters and northern Virginia. The fund will back efforts to preserve and create over 20,000 affordable housing units by 2025. The move comes as the housing market faces a surge in home values and rents, with many areas experiencing a decline in affordability. This is part of a larger trend among tech giants, including Google, Apple, and Microsoft, which have also committed to affordable housing initiatives.

site_title: Japan declares state of emergency for Tokyo area as Covid cases surge
summary: Japan has declared a one-month state of emergency in the Tokyo area and three neighboring prefectures due to a surge in COVID-19 cases, with over 7,000 new cases reported. The emergency, from Jan 8 to Feb 7, includes restrictions on bars and restaurants, and aims to limit the spread of the virus before the postponed Tokyo Olympics in June. The government also plans to start a vaccination campaign by the end of February, and has raised the maximum compensation for the restaurant business to 60,000 yen per day.

site_title: Hashida charts a new course
summary: Sushi chef 'Hatch' Hashida has launched his fourth restaurant in Singapore, 'HATCH', in Amoy Street. The three-in-one space features a stylised torii gate, a temple of omakase, and a room emulating old sushiyas. The restaurant showcases Hashida's culinary journey, with a focus on traditional Edomae-style sushi elevated in an innovative way. The menu, which includes signature dishes like otoro carving, will be priced from S$150 to S$350 for lunch and dinner. Hashida aims to blend traditional and modern elements, reflecting his global influences and Singaporean roots.

site_title: Covid-19: How we can do better
summary: CNN host Fareed Zakaria's book "Ten Lessons For A Post-Pandemic World" offers 10 lessons to prevent another global health disaster. Zakaria, an international relations expert, argues for a fundamental change in government and society to mitigate the risk of pandemics. He emphasizes the importance of transparent governance, trusting scientific data, and addressing wealth inequality. Zakaria also calls for radical changes, including strengthening global health organizations and implementing redistribution policies, to equip people with skills and security in an age of change. The book's lessons are relevant for countries beyond the US, and Zakaria hopes to prevent future global health disasters.

site_title: BlackRock raps Top Glove board over worker safety
summary: BlackRock criticized Top Glove's board for failing to prioritize worker safety, despite some improvements in Covid-19 mitigation and labor practices. The asset manager voted against seven out of 12 resolutions at Top Glove's annual general meeting, citing concerns over the company's handling of worker health and safety issues. This criticism comes amid over 5,000 worker infections and a whistleblower's dismissal. BlackRock remains concerned about Top Glove's approach, which has led to the company's continued presence on the United Nations Global Compact watch list.

site_title: CGS-CIMB makes 'buy' call on GKE Corp with S$0.18 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on GKE Corp with an "add" rating and S$0.18 target price, citing potential benefits from Singapore and China's logistics and infrastructure developments. Analysts forecast 93% growth in FY5/21 net operating profit after tax, driven by strong demand for warehouse space in Singapore and GKE's expansion in China. The analysts also expect higher rental yields and robust margin expansion for GKE.

site_title: Mumbai home market to get boost from lower development levies
summary: Mumbai's home market is expected to see a price drop due to a 50% reduction in development-related levies until December 2021. The move, suggested by a government-appointed committee, aims to lower development costs and subsequently home prices. The state government has also cut local tax on home purchases by 60%, leading to an 80% surge in Mumbai home sales in the previous quarter. This reduction in levies is expected to make homes cheaper for buyers.

site_title: Bayer partners CureVac on Covid vaccine effort
summary: Bayer is partnering with CureVac to seek international approval for CureVac's coronavirus vaccine, using messenger-RNA technology. The vaccine is currently in an advanced clinical trial and aims to produce several hundred million doses. CureVac CEO Franz-Werner Haas stated that the partnership will help get the vaccine to those who need it upon receipt of regulatory approvals. The companies are preparing to seek clearance in Europe and worldwide, following the success of similar vaccines from Moderna and BioNTech SE-Pfizer.

site_title: Trump's dangerous narcissism may have changed leadership forever
summary: US President Donald Trump's narcissistic leadership style is likely to leave a lasting impact on the US political system and beyond. His behavior, characterized by a grandiose sense of self-importance, has caused chaos and damaged relationships. Research has shown that narcissistic leaders often emerge during times of crisis, but their weaknesses eventually surface, leading to negative consequences for organizations and employees. As Trump vacates the political stage, his legacy serves as a warning to future leaders about the dangers of unchecked narcissism and the importance of diplomacy, empathy, and service.

site_title: Malaysia to shoot for post-crisis growth; polls may be called
summary: Malaysia aims to recover from the COVID-19 crisis and achieve post-crisis growth by 2021. The country's Vision 2020, introduced by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, envisioned a self-sufficient, industrialized, and prosperous nation by 2020. With polls potentially being called, Malaysia seeks to capitalize on its economic growth. Meanwhile, other ASEAN nations face economic challenges, including a potential slowdown in China's GDP growth and the impact of higher US tariffs on the Asian garment industry.

site_title: DBS starts coverage on ARA H-Trust with 'buy' call on vaccine, earnings optimism
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) with a "buy" call, citing a potential upside of over 50% due to its strong growth prospects in the select-service hotel subsector. The research team sets a target price of US$0.69, implying a significant increase from current prices. They believe the worst is over for the group due to the progressive rollout of Covid-19 vaccines, and expect the trust to double its earnings over the next two years as travel normalizes.

site_title: Elon Musk overtakes Amazon's Bezos to become world's richest person
summary: Elon Musk surpassed Amazon's Jeff Bezos to become the world's richest person, with a net worth of over $188.5 billion, according to Bloomberg News. Musk's wealth jumped after Tesla's gains on Thursday.

site_title: The 9 most important cars for Singapore this year
summary: Singapore's electric car market may gain momentum in 2021, driven by incentives of up to S$45,000 for zero-emission cars. The year ahead will see the introduction of various notable cars, including the Mercedes-Benz S-Class, Volkswagen Golf, Honda Civic, Ferrari SF90 Spider, BMW M3 and M4, Lexus LC500 Convertible, Audi e-tron GT, MG HS PHEV, and BMW iX3. While traditional high-performance cars will still be available, the shift towards electrification is expected to continue, with luxury brands like Mercedes and Lexus launching electric models.

site_title: Mall of America gets modified terms on US$1.4b mortgage
summary: The Mall of America has reached a modified terms agreement with its US$1.4 billion lenders, allowing it to pay only interest on the debt after missing mortgage payments during the pandemic. The 5.6 million square foot mall will continue to meet reporting requirements and send net cash to lenders on a monthly basis. The agreement, made in December, follows a forbearance and cash management agreement in place from April to November 2020. The loan matures in 2025 and CWCapital will monitor rent collection efforts.

site_title: The rise and rise of livestreaming retail
summary: A new phenomenon in the retail world has taken Singapore by storm - live-streaming e-commerce. Larger-than-life personalities, including TV titan Jack Neo, have commandeered screens, reeling in consumers and locking down sales. Retail players are moving in, seeing the rich potential of live-streaming. The trend is attributed to its ability to build strong relationships between sellers and buyers, creating a sense of community and trust. As a result, sales have skyrocketed, with Revolut, a fintech firm, also experiencing significant growth through its online platform.

site_title: UK home sales expected to rise in Q1
