The companies will continue to collaborate informally to design programs tailored to their employee populations. The move comes as the US struggles with high healthcare costs, with 17.7% of GDP spent on healthcare in 2019, and the lack of universal medical coverage remains a priority for policymakers.

site_title: Football: Pochettino starts at PSG with no time to waste
summary: Mauricio Pochettino begins his reign as coach of Paris Saint-Germain, tasked with getting the best out of Neymar and Kylian Mbappe. Pochettino's relationship with Neymar is seen as crucial to his success, following a brief stint with Diego Maradona and Ronaldinho. The Argentine replaces Thomas Tuchel, who was sacked with six months left on his contract. Despite leading PSG to the Champions League final, Tuchel's departure is unlikely to be missed by supporters. Pochettino aims to go one step further than Tuchel, who led the team to the final for the first time in history.

site_title: 'Breakthrough' achieved in ending Gulf rift with Qatar: US official
summary: The US has announced a breakthrough in ending the three-year blockade on Qatar, with Saudi Arabia set to reopen its airspace and borders to the Gulf nation. Jared Kushner, US President Donald Trump's son-in-law, will attend the signing ceremony following his shuttle diplomacy. The agreement, facilitated by the Gulf Cooperation Council and Egypt, aims to put an end to the blockade and Qatari lawsuits. This marks a significant development in the Gulf Cooperation Council rift, with Kushner having previously brokered recognition of Israel by four Arab states.

site_title: Biden promises 'new day', Trump heads to Georgia on eve of pivotal Senate runoffs
summary: President-elect Joe Biden urged Georgia voters to send two Democrats to Washington in Tuesday's Senate runoff elections, while President Donald Trump prepared to campaign for Republican incumbents Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue. The runoff elections will decide control of the US Senate, with Biden's party needing twin victories to enact his legislative agenda. Trump has claimed widespread voter fraud despite reviews rejecting his claims, and his efforts are seen as potentially breaking the law. The outcome hinges on Republican voter participation, with strong Democratic early voting turnout.

images.alt_text: President-elect Joe Biden urged Georgia voters on Monday to send two Democrats to Washington in Tuesday runoffs that will decide control of the US Senate, while President Donald Trump prepared his own pitch to keep the chamber in Republican hands.

site_title: EY's wish list for Budget 2021 includes boosting funding for training, hiring
summary: EY has proposed measures for Budget 2021, focusing on boosting funding for training, hiring, and staff issues amid the Covid-19 economic downturn. Recommendations include expanding Budget 2020's training credit to cover employers' capability development expenses, a one-off SkillsFuture Credit top-up for lower-income citizens, and higher support for job redesign in sectors hit hard by the pandemic. The firm also suggested preferential tax rates for financial technology innovation and tax breaks for pandemic-related allowances or benefits.

site_title: 5G airwave bids surge past US$76b to set auction record
summary: The US 5G airwaves auction has surpassed $76.5 billion in bids, setting a record, with the sale of midband frequencies expected to drive profits in emerging 5G technology. The auction, which started last month, has seen frenzied demand from carriers such as Verizon and AT&T, with T-Mobile potentially gaining a significant advantage. The sale is crucial for companies seeking global leadership in 5G technology, with the frequencies expected to be used for next-generation mobile devices, autonomous vehicles, and manufacturing facilities.

site_title: Third CDL director resigns; firm sets up group to focus on contentious Sincere investment
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has appointed a new working group to focus on improving Sincere Property Group's liquidity and profitability. The move comes after the resignation of Tan Yee Peng, the third CDL director to step down in recent months due to disagreements over the investment in Sincere. Options for the group include reviewing potential divestments of assets and restructuring existing liabilities. CDL's shares closed at S$7.80 on Monday, down 2.1%.

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off 2021 with rally on Brexit and vaccine optimism
summary: European shares rallied on the first trading day of 2021, driven by a landmark Brexit trade deal and optimism over coronavirus vaccine campaigns. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.7% to reach fresh February 2020 highs, with mining and healthcare sectors leading the rally. Global stocks hit record highs, and Britain began vaccinating its population with the AstraZeneca-Oxford University Covid-19 vaccine. The positive sentiment was also fueled by a survey showing German factories producing more goods despite a stricter lockdown.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Mester says monetary policy will remain accommodative for 'quite some time'
summary: US Federal Reserve President Loretta Mester stated that monetary policy will remain accommodative for a "quite some time" due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Despite potential economic growth later this year, the Fed's goals for inflation and full employment may not be achieved, and uneven recovery is expected. Some workers may struggle to find new jobs, and inflation is unlikely to exceed the Fed's 2% target. The Fed has agreed to keep interest rates near zero and continue purchasing $120 billion in government bonds monthly, with potential policy adjustments if the economy improves more rapidly than expected.

site_title: Top US executives demand Congress certify Biden victory
summary: Top US business executives, including over 170 prominent executives, have signed a joint letter urging Congress to certify Joe Biden as the new US president, condemning attempts to thwart the certification process as "counter to the essential tenets of our democracy." The letter, released by Partnership for New York City, calls for certification on January 6, despite over 100 Republican members planning to raise objections. The certification process is generally a formality, with a vote doomed to fail in the Democratic-controlled House and Republican-majority Senate.

site_title: Tesla poised for global expansion after just missing 2020 target
summary: Tesla delivered 180,570 vehicles in Q4 2020, falling 450 vehicles short of its 500,000-yearly goal set by CEO Elon Musk. The company's quarterly delivery figure is a record, with 36% growth from the prior year. Despite missing the target, Tesla is poised for global expansion, with plans to open new factories in Texas and Germany. The company's shares rallied 743% in 2020, reaching a market capitalization of $668.9 billion. Tesla's success sets the stage for a new year of growth, with the company expected to continue ramping up production and meeting growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Singapore PMI still rising, but factory growth momentum expected to ease in 2021
summary: Singapore's factory sector continued its expansion in December, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.5 points, up 0.1 point from November. The electronics cluster saw its fifth consecutive month of growth, with new orders and export orders showing encouraging signs. However, employment and electronics supplier deliveries shrank for the 11th straight month. Experts expect manufacturing growth to ease to 3.2% in 2021, with some warning of potential disruptions from foreign labor shortages and US sanctions on Huawei.

site_title: 'A slap in the face': The pandemic disrupts young oil careers
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted young oil and gas careers, forcing many to reconsider their future in the industry. With over 100,000 layoffs and a decline in demand, the industry's future is uncertain. Many students and recent graduates, including those who were drawn to the industry's promise of secure careers, are now seeking alternative paths, such as environmental science or consulting firms specializing in energy conservation. Despite some optimism that the industry will rebound, growing concerns about climate change and the shift towards renewable energy may ultimately lead to a decline in oil and gas employment.

site_title: Grab expects to break even in food delivery by end-2021
summary: Grab expects its food delivery business to break even by the end of 2021, driven by positive earnings and nearly tripling of food delivery net revenues year-on-year in Q3 2020. The company nearly doubled its merchants in South-east Asia and has broken even in ride-hailing in all operating markets. Group revenues have returned to over 100% of pre-Covid levels, growing 70% year-on-year in 2020. Grab will continue to focus on small and medium enterprises, aiming to accelerate its economic recovery in the region.

site_title: STI up 0.53% as GDP contraction slows in Q4
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.53% to 2,858.90 in the first trading day of 2021, driven by data showing a slowdown in the country's economic contraction in Q4 2020. The Singapore Exchange was the top performer, gaining 4.53% to S$9.70. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong also rose 0.89%, while Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 0.68%. The slowdown in Singapore's economy was seen as a positive sign, with investors locking in profits after a strong rally in Malaysia in 2020.

site_title: Beijing seeks to wrong-foot Biden with Brussels deal
summary: The European Union and China have agreed to a Comprehensive Agreement on Investment (CAI), a deal that will give European and Chinese firms better access to each other's markets. The agreement was reached in late December, just before the US presidential inauguration, as China seeks to capitalize on a potential window of opportunity before new US President Joe Biden takes office. The deal is seen as a positive step in EU-China relations, but experts warn that underlying issues, such as human rights concerns and the US's growing scrutiny of China's economic practices, may limit the deal's long-term impact.

site_title: Oil slides with US stocks as Opec+ delays output decision
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.4% and 1.9% for Brent and US West Texas Intermediate, respectively, after Opec+ failed to agree on increasing output in February. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies will resume talks on Tuesday. The decision was delayed due to disagreements over production levels, with Saudi Arabia opposing increased output and Russia calling for higher production. The S&P 500 and Dow also fell, influenced by President Trump's visit to Georgia to try to keep the US Senate in Republican hands.

site_title: Peugeot, Fiat merger set to be sealed by shareholders
summary: Shareholders of PSA and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) are expected to approve a merger, creating the world's fourth-largest automaker, Stellantis. The vote comes after the European Commission gave conditional approval to the 2019 merger. The outcome is seen as a foregone conclusion, with the mega-merger expected to be finalized.

site_title: Construction, process and marine workers among priority groups for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong announced that construction, marine, and process sector workers, as well as migrant workers, will be among the priority groups for Covid-19 vaccination. Vaccination has begun with healthcare workers and essential personnel. The programme will be progressively broadened, with elderly and those at greater risk of severe disease targeted from February. A vaccine injury financial assistance programme will also be introduced to provide peace of mind. The Ministry of Health has secured enough vaccines for all Singaporeans and long-term residents.

images.alt_text: Workers "in jobs or settings where risk of a super-spreading event is high", including migrant workers, will be among the priority groups for Covid-19 vaccination, said Mr Gan.

site_title: Wonder Woman's global box office total tops US$118m
summary: Wonder Woman 1984 has reached a global box office total of US$118.5 million, with US$5.5 million earned in North America and US$10.1 million from overseas markets over the New Year's holiday. The film's US performance represents a 67% drop from pre-pandemic levels, but its global total is considered a moderate success given the coronavirus's impact on the movie business. The film's success has led to plans for a third installment, with lead actress Gal Gadot and director Patty Jenkins set to reunite for the project.

site_title: Top Glove commits to 20% special dividend on 'good profit performance'
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysia-listed glove maker, has committed to a 20% special dividend for the remaining quarters of its financial year ending August 31, 2021, due to "good profit performance and strong cash flow". This 70% dividend payout ratio will reward shareholders and follows a record-breaking net profit of RM2.38 billion in the first quarter of 2021. The company's shares closed at S$1.87, down 6.5% from its intraday low of S$1.75.

site_title: Bitcoin holds near record, Ether surges amid crypto rally
summary: Bitcoin reached near-record levels at $33,060, while Ether surged 22% to $1,163, amid a crypto rally. The surge follows Bitcoin's breach of $34,000 and is attributed to investors rotating profits from Bitcoin to other digital coins. Proponents see Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation and dollar weakness, while skeptics view the 300% surge as a bubble fueled by momentum. Volatility remains a concern, with experts citing low interest rates, political uncertainty, and government stimulus as drivers of the rally.

site_title: Singapore banks to benefit from pickup in credit growth this year: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore banks are expected to benefit from a pickup in credit growth this year, driven by easing of social distancing measures and the COVID-19 vaccination program. Analysts at CGS-CIMB maintain an "overweight" call on the sector, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB targeted at S$28.35, S$12.52, and S$27.72, respectively. UOB is seen as the top pick, with analysts expecting its net interest margin to sustain or trend upwards. Credit growth is forecast to alleviate concerns about lower earnings for banks.

site_title: China telco shares hit by NYSE delisting announcement
summary: China's three biggest telecoms companies, China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom, saw their shares fall as much as 5% in Hong Kong after the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) announced its decision to delist the firms. The US government's move to block investment in 31 firms it says are owned or controlled by China's military led to the NYSE's decision. China's foreign ministry called the move "unwise" and "oppressive," while analysts believe the delisting will not significantly impact the firms' operations.

site_title: Asean equity markets to post solid recovery, led by Singapore and Thailand: Credit Suisse
summary: ASEAN equity markets are expected to post a solid recovery in 2021, led by Singapore and Thailand, according to Credit Suisse. The region's markets are seen as undervalued, with low foreign ownership and cheap relative valuations. Singapore is forecast to grow 6% in 2021, driven by government support and re-opening of borders, while Thailand is expected to bounce back after a tough 2020, with a SET index target of 1,660. Malaysia and Indonesia are also expected to see growth, with Malaysia's market projected for a 59% net profit recovery and Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index target at 6,600.

site_title: Kori Holdings unit bags S$81.2m in six contracts
summary: Kori Holdings' subsidiary, Kori Construction, has secured six contracts worth S$81.2 million in three projects between September 2020 and January 2021. The contracts include strutting works and sheet piling works for the North-South Corridor Tunnel in Singapore, with the largest contract valued at S$30 million. The projects are expected to positively impact the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2021.

site_title: Singapore seeks to enable digitalisation of key documents
summary: Singapore aims to be a leading maritime and trade hub by enabling the digitalisation of key trade documents via the adoption of the Model Law on Electronic Transferable Records (MLETR). The country has introduced an amendment to the Electronic Transactions Act, following a move by Vietnam to seek a lower US tariff rate. Meanwhile, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: Border measures still apply for vaccinated travellers: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore will maintain its cautious approach to vaccinated travelers, subjecting them to prevailing border measures and stay-home notice requirements. Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a more cautious approach, citing ongoing studies on the effectiveness of vaccinations in reducing Covid-19 transmission risks. The government will fine-tune its approach over time if evidence shows significant reduction in transmission risks. Safe management measures, widespread testing, and contact tracing capabilities remain essential to the country's defense against the virus.

site_title: Congress likely to apply banking rules to antiquities market
summary: Congress has passed legislation that will subject the antiquities market to greater oversight, aiming to curb money laundering and illicit activities. The National Defense Authorization Act, overridden by the House and Senate, broadens the 1970 Bank Secrecy Act to include the trade of ancient artifacts. Regulators will design measures to remove secrecy from transactions, and the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network will study the role of art in money laundering and terror financing. The law also seeks to end the use of shell companies to conceal buyer and seller identities.

site_title: Hedge funds optimistic about speedy recovery in 2021
summary: Global hedge funds are optimistic about a speedy recovery in 2021, expecting many previously undesirable sectors such as energy and retail to rebound. Despite the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, hedge funds showed resilience, with many outperforming the market. Investors forecast an explosion of pent-up demand for travel and leisure, leading to "super growth" in 2021. Key sectors expected to benefit include technology, finance, and energy, with macroeconomic trends and inflation also expected to play a role.

site_title: Opec+ warns of risk to oil recovery as group plots next move
summary: OPEC+ warned of risks to oil recovery due to the resurgent pandemic, with OPEC Secretary-General Mohammad Barkindo stating that the outlook for the first half of 2021 is "very mixed" and includes "many downside risks." The group is set to meet to consider increasing production, amid concerns from investors about market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Philippine bourse to aim for more Reits and IPOs this year on hopes of post-Covid recovery
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange aims to boost capital market activity in 2021 with seven planned initial public offerings and four real estate investment trusts (Reits) from local firms, despite the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. This represents a significant increase in activity, with only seven IPOs in the past three years. The exchange plans to relax listing rules and introduce new features to attract more companies and restore investor confidence. Funds raised through the bourse rose 2.9% in 2020, mainly through IPOs and follow-on share sales.

site_title: A new chessboard beckons for Singapore's politics
summary: Singapore's 4th-generation (4G) leadership took center stage in 2020, with ministers Gan Kim Yong and Lawrence Wong co-chairing a multi-ministry task force to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic. The opposition gained ground, with the Workers' Party (WP) securing two group representation constituencies and holding on to a single seat. WP chief Pritam Singh was designated Leader of the Opposition, marking a shift towards a two-party dominant Westminster system. The government faces challenges in containing Covid-19, deploying vaccines, and economic recovery, while also addressing voter concerns over political diversity and livelihood issues.

site_title: Covid-19 offers no lessons for the world, you say? Here are my takeaways
summary: A letter to the editor criticizes Janan Ganesh's article "Covid-19 has no grand lesson for the world" for its perceived flaws in logic and reasoning. The writer argues that the pandemic has taught the world the importance of virtuous leadership, collectivity, and following science. They argue that countries like New Zealand and China have achieved better outcomes through collective efforts and strong governance, while countries like the US have struggled due to demagogic leadership and individualistic policies. The writer also criticizes Ganesh for downplaying the significance of mask-wearing and social distancing measures.

site_title: Australian home prices rise for third straight month to finish 2020 strong
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.9% in December, marking the third consecutive month of growth, and finished the year with a 2% gain. Low interest rates and the shift to remote work fueled demand, particularly in regional areas where home prices surged 6.9% in 2020. Experts attribute the strong housing market to record-low interest rates and increased consumer confidence. However, new Covid outbreaks in major cities and closed international borders pose risks to the economic recovery and home prices.

site_title: Kirin to invest US$30m in maker of Indian craft beer Bira
summary: Kirin Holdings, a Japanese beer maker, will invest $30 million in B9 Beverages, the maker of India's popular craft beer Bira. The investment will give Kirin a stake of under 10% in the company. The deal aims to help Bira break even in the 2022 fiscal year, which has been hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. The investment will also allow Bira to accelerate plans to launch its products in Japan later this year, with the deal expected to be closed in the next few days.

site_title: Georgia on my mind
summary: In a surprise upset, Joe Biden won the state of Georgia in the 2020 presidential election, marking a significant shift in the traditionally Republican stronghold. The Asian American vote played a crucial role in Biden's victory, with nearly 70% of Asian American voters supporting him. Now, Georgia is set to decide the Senate in two runoff elections, where Democrats Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff face off against Republicans Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue. The outcome could give the Democrats a crucial governing majority, with Vice President-elect Kamala Harris holding the tie-breaker vote.

site_title: Singapore private home prices may rise in 2021 amid reviving economy
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to rise in 2021 due to a recovering economy and improving market sentiment. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate shows a 2.2% gain in 2020, with prices increasing 2.1% quarter-on-quarter in Q4 2020. Analysts attribute the turnaround to low mortgage rates, fiscal support, and wage subsidies. Regions such as the Rest of Central Region and Core Central Region saw significant price increases, with non-landed properties rising 3.2% and 3.3% respectively. Experts predict a 1-5% rise in private home prices, with some forecasting a 5% increase overall.

images.alt_text: Given ample liquidity, a low interest rate environment and improving buyer sentiment, there is room for private home prices to head upwards in 2021, say analysts.

site_title: Biden plans minimalist trip from Capitol to White House on inauguration day
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's Inauguration Day plans will be largely virtual due to the coronavirus pandemic. He will conduct a traditional review of military troops on the east side of the US Capitol, followed by a speech to the nation. Biden will also receive an official escort and a "virtual parade" across the country featuring local bands, poets, and dance troupes. The event aims to minimize the risk of virus transmission, with Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris having been vaccinated.

site_title: Using their arts education to help the greater community
summary: Two IB graduates from the School of the Arts in Sota, Izad Hamzah and his peers, believe that talent knows no social or economic boundaries. Izad plans to establish a record company in Singapore to provide opportunities to those passionate about music who lack the chance to express themselves. He aims to recruit students from various schools and help them find a career in music. This endeavor showcases the potential of arts education to positively impact the community.

site_title: Will the world act this year on climate change and biodiversity loss?
summary: The world is awaiting crucial UN environmental meetings in 2021 to address climate change and biodiversity loss. The Convention on Biological Diversity meeting in Kunming, China, and the UN Climate Change Conference in Glasgow will set targets for the decade ahead. While optimism is present, the COVID-19 pandemic and politics may hinder progress. The Leaders' Pledge for Nature, signed by 92 countries, is a promising sign, but major biodiversity hotspots like Australia and the US remain uncommitted. Environmentalists hope these meetings will elevate discourse on biodiversity and drive global action to combat climate change.

site_title: Removal of HSR assets company 'could not be accepted'
summary: Singapore's Minister for Transport Ong Ye Kung stated that Malaysia's proposal to remove the assets company for the High Speed Rail (HSR) project was unacceptable. The project was terminated on January 1 after Singapore incurred costs of over $270 million. Singapore will discuss new proposals from Malaysia, but starting from a clean slate. Malaysia agreed to compensate Singapore for costs incurred, with the compensation amount and payment schedule specified in the legal agreements. The termination does not affect plans for the Jurong Lake District, but some details may need to be adjusted.

site_title: Ringgit leads regional charge against USD on vaccine optimism and canned HSR
summary: The Malaysian ringgit rose against the US dollar in 2021 due to optimism over Covid-19 vaccines and the cancellation of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail project. The ringgit crossed the 4-level mark, trading around 3.9 to the dollar, while the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2% to 1,593.12. This movement was seen as a regional currency trend, with other ASEAN currencies also rising against the US dollar.

site_title: Things will get better. Seriously...
summary: The US economy is expected to experience a significant improvement in the coming months, driven by the rapid development of COVID-19 vaccines and technological advancements. Despite potential economic sabotage by Republicans, the economy is expected to bounce back, with a potential boom that could last for a long time. The author attributes this optimism to the fact that the private sector was not overextended before the pandemic, and Americans have been saving, which will lead to stronger balance sheets. Additionally, the author expects technological innovations such as biotechnology and renewable energy to drive growth.

site_title: First Reit's problematic rent structure with master lessee brought to fore
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), is facing significant challenges due to its problematic rent structure with its master lessee, Lippo Karawaci (LK). LK, which pays about four-fifths of First Reit's total rental income, has been experiencing financial difficulties, including weak operating cash flows and an inability to divest assets. The pandemic has further impacted LK's revenues, leading to a drastic decline in patient volumes and resulting in significant rental subsidies for First Reit. To address these issues, First Reit's manager has proposed a lease restructuring, which includes a 37% cut in base rents and a 50% discount on a proposed S$158 million rights issue.

site_title: Important not to let HSR termination hobble further cooperation
summary: The High Speed Rail (HSR) agreement between Singapore and Malaysia has been terminated, dealing a significant blow to potential bilateral cooperation and economic ties. The HSR was expected to be a major catalyst for collaboration, promoting interdependence and "prosper thy neighbour" principles. Despite the setback, strong people-to-people ties can help temper political histrionics and moderate negative impacts on relations. Both countries must now focus on long-term cooperation, with leadership being crucial for sustainable and beneficial relations.

site_title: US dollar softens against most majors
summary: The US dollar softened against most major currencies, holding near mid-2018 lows, as global risk sentiment remained buoyant. The dollar index posted its first annual loss since 2017, falling 13% from its peak in March. The Chinese yuan rose 0.9% to a 30-month high, while the euro and sterling gained 0.4% each. The softening US dollar boosted commodity prices and pushed Bitcoin to milestone highs. Investors' bullish sentiment was driven by low US interest rates, massive budget and trade deficits, and a rebounding world trade.

site_title: Markets to sustain rally in 2021 amid vaccine-led recovery: analysts
summary: Analysts predict a sustained market rally in 2021 driven by the global Covid-19 vaccine roll-out, with cyclical and value stocks expected to lead the recovery. Economic growth is expected to be gradual and uneven across sectors, with some sectors recovering more quickly than others. A balanced portfolio with growth and defensive names is recommended, with investments in technology, value stocks, and industrial real estate investment trusts (Reits) being highlighted as opportunities. The market is expected to extend its rally into 2021, with some analysts predicting a return to pre-Covid levels in early-2022.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 2.9% in Q4 2020 - the biggest quarterly rise in 9 years
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.9% in Q4 2020, the biggest quarterly increase in nearly 10 years, marking the third consecutive quarter of growth despite a surge in supply and the Covid-19 pandemic. For 2020, resale prices increased 4.8%, surpassing the 0.1% growth in 2019 and the 0.9% decline in 2018. Policy changes, including the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant, are attributed to the market's recovery, with a record 72 HDB flats sold for over S$1 million in 2020.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% due to investor uncertainty about market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US fell, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Higher food costs stalk Britons as Brexit reality hits home
summary: The UK's departure from the European Union has avoided a no-deal Brexit, but British shoppers may still face higher food costs due to increased border checks and red tape. The UK Food and Drink Federation estimates that these costs could add £3 billion to the industry, potentially leading to an 8% increase in food prices. Despite this, some supermarkets argue that prices won't be significantly affected, and retailers plan to absorb the costs to avoid passing them on to consumers.

site_title: Workers at Google parent Alphabet form union
summary: Google's parent company Alphabet has formed a union, the Alphabet Workers Union, affiliated with the Communications Workers of America. The union, which has over 200 members, aims to represent well-compensated tech workers, temporary workers, and contractors, focusing on pay, benefits, and ethical decisions. The union was formed in response to recent firings and controversies, including the firing of Timnit Gebru, a Black AI ethics researcher. The union seeks to promote social, economic, and environmental justice and end unfair disparities between full-time and temporary workers.

site_title: Making trade facilitation pacts easy to use is vital for companies
summary: Singapore's trade facilitation measures, such as free trade agreements and single-window connectivity, have helped reduce supply chain costs and uncertainty, making the country an attractive trading hub. However, many companies struggle to utilize these measures due to complexity and unpredictability. To address this, the Singapore government should focus on simplifying the process, reducing operational challenges, and providing better support to SMEs. This could include developing a reliable technology tool for FTA compliance, offering more flexible grants for internationalization, and enhancing single windows for reporting and compliance.

site_title: Economists maintain outlook despite better-than-expected 2020 GDP data
summary: Singapore's 2020 GDP contraction of 5.8% year-on-year is slightly better than expected, but economists maintain a cautious outlook for 2021, projecting a long and uneven recovery. Vaccine rollout and border reopening will be key factors in determining the pace of recovery, with some economists predicting 5% growth and others 4-6%. The manufacturing sector is expected to continue leading the recovery, while the construction sector is seen as a positive outlier. However, the services sector is expected to be uneven, with some segments recovering faster than others.

site_title: LHN to launch Keppel Road mixed-use development by mid-Feb
summary: LHN is set to launch its mixed-use development at 1557 Keppel Road by mid-February 2021. The 96,299.05 sq ft space will feature commercial and residential areas, including a three-storey office block and 47 serviced apartment units. The development aims to cater to changing market demands for co-living and working spaces, with in-house dining options and a gym. It is expected to attract commercial tenants and is near major MRT stations, including the upcoming Cantonment station.

site_title: Insurer Centene to buy Magellan in US$2.2b mental health push
summary: Centene Corp is acquiring Magellan Health in a US$2.2 billion deal, aiming to expand its mental health services amid the ongoing pandemic. The deal includes 2 million pharmacy benefit members, 16 million medical pharmacy members, and 18 million specialty health service customers. Centene expects to complete the transaction in the second half of 2021. The acquisition is part of the healthcare industry's trend of consolidation to lower medical costs, following deals such as CVS Health's US$69 billion acquisition of Aetna.

site_title: Applied Materials lifts bid for Kokusai to US$3.5b
summary: Applied Materials has raised its bid for Kokusai Electric to $3.5 billion, a 59% increase from the original $2.2 billion, citing growing demand for semiconductor equipment and improved earnings prospects for the combined entity. The new closing deadline has been extended to March 19 to secure regulatory approval from China. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the growing trend in the semiconductor industry, with Applied Materials expecting substantial value for its shareholders.

site_title: Iran resumes 20% enrichment at Fordow amid growing tensions with US
summary: Iran has resumed 20% uranium enrichment at Fordow, a breach of the 2015 nuclear pact, amid growing tensions with the US. The move, aimed at developing nuclear weapons, coincides with increasing tensions between Iran and the US in the last days of President Trump's administration. The decision, announced by Iran's government, could hinder efforts by the incoming Biden administration to re-enter the agreement. The International Atomic Energy Agency is set to inform members about developments in Iran, and the EU Commission has expressed concerns about the move.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing sentiment leans toward growth in December as PMI inches up by 0.1 point to 50.5
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed signs of growth in December, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.5 points, up 0.1 point from November. The sector's expansion was attributed to increased new orders, factory output, and inventory. However, employment and electronics supplier deliveries contracted for the 11th straight month. Experts predict a continued expansion in manufacturing, but with a moderate pace, and attribute the improvement to potential progress in reopening borders later this year.

site_title: Australian Open quarantine plan may face legal challenge
summary: Australian Open organisers plan to use a luxury Melbourne hotel to quarantine hundreds of international players ahead of the tournament in February. However, apartment owners at the hotel are threatening legal action, citing concerns for their health and accusing the hotel's management of "ambushing" them with the plan. The owners claim they were not consulted and have expressed shock over the sudden decision. The hotel's management says their "Covid-safe" plan will keep residents isolated and separate from staff and guests. A potential lawsuit could face legal challenges due to public health and legal issues.

site_title: Jack Ma's disappearing act fuels speculation about billionaire's whereabouts
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has not appeared in public since a speech in Shanghai in October, fueling speculation about his whereabouts amid a Chinese regulatory clampdown on his business empire. Ma's absence sparked social media speculation, with some suggesting he has been "told to lay low" by Chinese regulators. The Chinese government has launched an antitrust probe into Alibaba and ordered Ant to separate its lending business. Ma's absence comes as Alibaba's Hong Kong-listed shares fell 2.15% on Monday, and his business empire faces increased scrutiny over financial regulation.

site_title: Nurture Education Group grows its preschool family
summary: Nurture Education Group, a Singapore-based preschool operator, has acquired G8 Education Singapore for approximately S$8.7 million, expanding its portfolio to 54 centers. The acquisition aims to establish the group as one of the largest private preschool operators in Singapore, enabling it to have a voice in the early childhood sector and collaborate with the Early Childhood Development Agency. The move follows the Singapore government's plan to increase government-supported preschool places to 80% by 2025, reducing private operators' share of the market. The group's CEO, Julie Koh, plans to continue growing through acquisitions, with a focus on demographics and locations.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow begin 2021 at all-time highs on economic rebound bets
summary: US stocks began 2021 at record levels, with the S&P 500, Dow, and Nasdaq rising due to hopes of a vaccine-driven global economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 21 points to 30,627.47, the S&P 500 rose 8.5 points to 3,764.61, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 70.2 points to 12,958.522. This follows a rally in 2020 driven by vaccine optimism, with investors betting on a swift economic rebound.

site_title: New measures to guard against money laundering, terrorist financing
summary: Singapore has approved new measures to counter money laundering and terrorist financing in the cryptocurrency sector, strengthening laws governing digital payment tokens. The Payment Services (Amendment) Bill, passed by Parliament, introduces enhanced standards for virtual asset service providers dealing in cryptocurrencies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will regulate cryptocurrency service providers facilitating cryptocurrency transactions, custodial services, and exchange activities. The new laws will also require segregating customer assets from provider assets and impose measures to safeguard consumer protection and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Danske Bank becomes Nordic ESG debt leader after US$4.3b in deals
summary: Danske Bank has become the Nordic ESG debt leader after arranging $4.3 billion in sustainable bond sales for Nordic borrowers in 2020. The bank expects a 25% expansion in the primary market over the next 12 months, driven by increased social and sustainability bonds from Nordic countries. New clean debt types, such as sustainability-linked bonds, are also expected to contribute to growth, with Danske Bank anticipating increased demand from financial institutions in areas like green covered bonds.

site_title: South Korean-flagged tanker seized by Iran, media reports
summary: Iran's Revolutionary Guards Corps seized a South Korean-flagged tanker, the Hankuk Chemi, in Gulf waters for allegedly polluting the Gulf with chemicals. The tanker, carrying 7,200 tonnes of ethanol, was being held at Iran's Bandar Abbas port city. The incident comes amid tension between Iran and South Korea over frozen Iranian funds due to US sanctions. Several crew members, including nationals of South Korea, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Myanmar, were detained. The seizure occurred ahead of an expected visit by South Korea's deputy foreign minister to Tehran.

site_title: Tiny apartment sales soar in world's priciest home market
summary: In Hong Kong's highly unaffordable housing market, a record 13% of apartments sold in 2019 were nano apartments, defined as homes under 260 square feet, with 85% lacking a separate bedroom and 70% without a window in the toilet. Despite selling for over HK$5 million, these tiny units barely fit basic necessities. The trend reflects the city's struggle to provide affordable housing, with low-income earners often resorting to coffin homes or living in industrial buildings.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's property affordability is the worst in the world, topping other housing hotspots such as Vancouver, Sydney, and Los Angeles.

site_title: With virus still a problem, Thailand's hopes for economic recovery remain grim
summary: Thailand's economic recovery remains uncertain due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which devastated the tourism-reliant economy in 2020. The country's GDP is forecast to contract 6.6-7.7% in 2020, with estimates for 2021 ranging from 2.6-4.5%. The government is considering tougher measures to restrict businesses and limit people's movement to curb the spread of the virus, which could shave off at least 1% from annual GDP growth. Thailand's exports are also expected to recover slowly, with a forecast of 4% growth in 2021.

site_title: Singapore-Johor RTS Link project progressing well, says Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung says the RTS Link project is progressing well, with the Johor side having broken ground and Singapore's side to follow soon. The 4km rail link, set to connect Johor and Singapore, is expected to commence in 2026 as scheduled and carry up to 10,000 passengers per hour. The project aims to ease congestion on the Causeway and make the border more accessible, with a trip time of just five minutes between stations.

site_title: Bitcoin slumps 14% after weekend surge
summary: Bitcoin experienced a 14% slump to $27,805 on Monday, following a weekend surge that saw it reach a record high of $34,800. The cryptocurrency had surged over $30,000 for the first time on Saturday, as investors anticipated its potential as a mainstream asset. The decline marks a reversal from the previous weekend's gains, and analysts are likely to be watching the market's performance closely in the coming days.

site_title: Natixis to sell H2O stake to investment firm's management
summary: Natixis agrees to sell its majority stake in investment firm H2O Asset Management back to the firm's management team, ending a decade-long partnership marred by controversy. The sale is part of a "progressive and orderly unwinding" of the partnership, which could impact H2O's distribution network and client base. Regulatory approval is required for the sale, which will allow H2O to continue operating independently.

site_title: Kori Holdings unit bags six contracts worth S$81.2m
summary: Kori Holdings, a construction services firm, announced that its subsidiary Kori Construction secured six contracts worth S$81.2 million between September 2020 and January 2021. The projects include strutting works and sheet piling works for the North South Corridor Tunnel and Mandai Lake Road. The contracts are expected to positively impact the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2021, according to Executive Chairman and CEO Hooi Yu Koh.

site_title: Construction spending increases strongly in November
summary: US construction spending rose 0.9% in November, driven by a robust housing market and historically low mortgage rates. Spending on private construction projects increased 1.2%, fueled by homebuilding investments, while spending on residential projects rose 2.7%. Non-residential construction spending fell 0.8% due to depressed prices from the pandemic. Public construction projects eased 0.2% in November, marking the fourth consecutive quarterly drop in spending on non-residential structures.

site_title: Grab's Ebitda unlikely to breakeven before 2023: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service has assigned a first-time B3 corporate family rating to Grab Holdings, citing the company's leading position in key regional markets and substantial cash holdings. However, the rating also reflects uncertainties around Grab's ability to achieve sustained profitability due to low switching costs, higher competitive intensity, and investment risks associated with its digital financial services business. Moody's expects Grab's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) to breakeven on a consolidated basis before 2023, with cash needed to fund new businesses and potential acquisitions.

site_title: Teledyne to buy sensor maker Flir Systems for US$7.36b
summary: Teledyne Technologies agreed to buy sensor maker Flir Systems for about $7.36 billion, its largest acquisition in three decades. The deal, valued at $8 billion, includes $56 per share in cash and stock, representing a 28% premium to Flir's last closing price. The acquisition will immediately add to earnings, with Flir's products used in defense, heavy industry, and government. The deal follows Teledyne's strategy of targeting acquisitions to build cash flow and follows a pause in its acquisition of France's Photonis in September.

site_title: Hong Kong extends face-to-face school closures until mid-Feb
summary: Hong Kong has extended the suspension of face-to-face school classes until mid-February due to the critical spread of the coronavirus. The Lunar Year Holiday will end on February 15, allowing some primary and secondary students to return to take exams under strict conditions. The city has recorded around 9,000 coronavirus cases and 150 deaths.

site_title: Trump, Biden to rally in Georgia ahead of high-stakes Senate races
summary: President-elect Joe Biden and President Donald Trump are set to rally in Georgia ahead of the high-stakes Senate runoff elections on Tuesday. The outcome of the elections, which will determine control of the Senate, could give Biden's party a majority, allowing him to enact his agenda. Trump has refused to acknowledge his loss in Georgia and has pressured election officials to overturn the results, sparking concerns about election integrity. The outcome of the runoff elections will be decided by Republican senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue and Democratic challengers Raphael Warnock and Jon Ossoff.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 24.64 points to 1,602.57. The market saw 7.400 billion lots traded worth RM5.876 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 934 to 360.

site_title: PSA shareholders approve merger with Fiat Chrysler
summary: PSA shareholders have approved a merger with Fiat Chrysler, creating the world's fourth-largest carmaker, Stellantis. The merger, announced in 2021, was nearly unanimous, with PSA Chief Carlos Tavares stating the new company will be formed. The deal marks a significant consolidation in the automotive industry, combining the resources and expertise of both groups. The new Stellantis company will oversee a global presence, with operations in multiple countries and a diverse range of vehicles.

site_title: Economists maintain 2021 outlook despite better-than-expected growth numbers in 2020
summary: Singapore's economy contracted 5.8% in 2020, slightly better than the forecasted 6-6.5% contraction. Despite this, economists maintain their 2021 outlook, predicting a long and uneven recovery that will depend on the vaccine rollout. Most economists expect a 4-6% growth rate, with the manufacturing sector leading the recovery and the construction sector showing a positive outlook. However, the services sector is expected to be uneven, with some segments recovering faster than others.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Sorrell's S4 Capital snatches up two businesses to underpin 'new era' strategy
summary: S4 Capital, owned by Martin Sorrell, has acquired two businesses: US-based Decoded Advertising and Metric Theory, as part of its 'new era' advertising strategy post-Brexit. The combined entity, S4 Capital, will also include MediaMonks and MightyHive. The acquisition aims to bolster the company's digital content offerings on platforms like Facebook and Google.

site_title: Vaccinated travellers to remain subject to border restrictions and SHN requirements
summary: Singapore will maintain its cautious approach to vaccinated travelers, keeping them subject to border restrictions and stay-home notice (SHN) requirements. The government plans to study the effectiveness of vaccinations in reducing transmission risk and may relax restrictions if evidence shows significant risk reduction. Vaccinations for seniors are set to begin in February, with wider population vaccinations to follow. The government is monitoring ongoing studies on vaccine effectiveness and will review its approach based on data.

site_title: Surrey Point in Newton up for collective sale with S$55m guide price
summary: Surrey Point, a freehold residential development in Newton, Singapore, is up for collective sale via public tender with a guide price of S$55 million. The site has a gross plot ratio of 2.8 and an 11,977 square foot area, translating to a land rate of about S$1,661 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot benchmark in the Singapore market.

site_title: 6-year-old girl from India among 24 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: A 6-year-old girl from India is among 24 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all of whom are imported. The cases include 18 work permit holders, a dependant's pass holder, and a short-term permit pass holder. The girl and 21 others are asymptomatic and tested positive while serving stay-home notices or in isolation. Singapore's total cases now stand at 58,721, with 58,482 patients fully recovered and 67 patients in hospital.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher on first day of trade in 2021
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.9% on the first day of 2021, tracking gains in other Asian markets, with the Hang Seng index reaching its highest since February 2020. The gains were driven by expectations of a global economic recovery and China's stimulus measures, but were capped by Sino-US tensions, particularly over China's opposition to US attempts to politicize trade issues.

site_title: OCBC makes fourth round of rate revisions on 360 account
summary: OCBC has made its fourth round of interest rate revisions on its flagship savings account, the OCBC 360, effective February 1. The bank will cut rates for balances up to $25,000 to 0.3% from 0.4%, down for balances between $25,000 and $50,000 to 0.6% from 0.8%, and maintain 1.2% for balances above $75,000. This follows recent rate cuts by banking peers DBS and Standard Chartered, amid a prolonged low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Prices of private homes seen to increase in 2021 as sentiment improves
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to rise in 2021, driven by a recovering economy and improving sentiment. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate shows a 2.1% quarter-on-quarter increase in Q4 2020, the highest quarterly gain since 2018. Analysts attribute the surge to low mortgage rates, fiscal support, and wage subsidies, with some predicting prices to rise 1-4% in 2021, driven by new project launches and a decrease in unsold units.

site_title: South Korea's population falls for first time during pandemic
summary: South Korea's population declined by 21,000 in 2020, marking the first time on record, due to a 11% drop in births to a historic low. The country's low fertility rate and ageing population are attributed to the pandemic's impact on jobs and incomes, with young people delaying marriage and pregnancies. The population now averages 2.24 people per household, with nearly 40% living alone. The government faces pressure from increasing senior population and declining working-age population, which may strain finances.

site_title: Thailand to receive first 200,000 Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines in Feb
summary: Thailand is set to receive its first 200,000 doses of Sinovac Covid-19 vaccines in February, with a total of 2 million doses ordered from China. The country aims to inoculate at least half of its 70 million population and plans to produce 200 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine locally annually. Thailand's medical professionals are expected to receive the first doses within 1-2 months, with additional shipments arriving in March and April.

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off 2021 with rally on Brexit and vaccine optimism
summary: European shares rallied in the first trading session of 2021, driven by a landmark Brexit trade deal and optimism over coronavirus vaccines. The STOXX 600 index gained 1.2% to reach fresh February 2020 highs, with mining and travel & leisure stocks leading the gain. London's blue-chip index rose 1.6%, while Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 also increased. The Brexit deal set rules for industries like fishing and agriculture, but left automatic access to the EU's financial markets for the UK's finance sector, resulting in lower UK bank shares.

site_title: STI starts 2021 on a positive note, up 0.53% as regional indices finish mixed
summary: Singapore shares started 2021 on a positive note, with the Straits Times Index gaining 15.09 points or 0.53% to 2,858.9. The Singapore Exchange was the top performer, gaining S$0.42 or 4.53% to S$9.70. The index's gain followed macrodata showing Singapore's economic contraction slowed in the fourth quarter of 2020.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP shrank 5.8% in 2020, but the contraction slowed to 3.8% in Q4, an improvement from the 5.6% contraction in the previous quarter. This marks a slight recovery in the country's economic performance.

site_title: Fatal incident halts Hyundai's South Korean factory after retooling for new EV
summary: Production at Hyundai's Ulsan, South Korea factory was halted after a worker died in an accident at the facility, which was recently refitted to manufacture the Ioniq 5 electric vehicle. The incident occurred at a pressing facility, and the Ministry of Employment and Labor is investigating. Hyundai Motor Group Chairman Euisun Chung expressed condolences and vowed to create a safe environment. Operations may resume soon, but a timeline is unclear. The incident halted production at the plant, which had been closed for two weeks to prepare for the Ioniq 5's production.

site_title: Top Glove commits to 20% special dividend on 'good profit performance'
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysia-based glove maker, has committed to a 20% special dividend, in addition to its existing 50% dividend payout ratio on profit after tax and minority interests. The move is attributed to the company's "good profit performance and strong cash flow." The special dividend will be applicable for the second quarter to the fourth quarter of FY2021, and shares rebounded after the announcement, closing at S$1.88.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: New digital banking opportunities for consumers and SMEs (Ep 87)
summary: The Business Times podcast "BT Money Hacks" discusses digital banking opportunities for consumers and small- and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore. Digital banking allows for lower and transparent costs, more choices, and cash withdrawals from shops instead of ATMs. Consumers can benefit by taking steps to use digital banking services, while SMEs can prepare by taking steps to benefit from and prepare for digital banking. The conversation highlights the potential of fintech, such as SOCASH, to improve financial services in Singapore.

site_title: Grab expects to break even in food delivery by end-2021
summary: Grab expects to break even in its food delivery business by the end of 2021, driven by strong earnings in Q2 2020 and a significant increase in food delivery net revenues year-over-year. The company nearly tripled food delivery net revenues in Q3 2020 and brought nearly 600,000 new merchants onto its platform in 2020. Grab has also broken even in ride-hailing in all its operating markets, including Indonesia. Group revenues have returned to over 100% of pre-Covid levels, with total group net revenue growing 70% year-over-year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares start 2021 at record high on chip, EV boost
summary: South Korean shares began 2021 at a record high, with the Kospi index closing 2.47% higher to 2,944.45, marking the sharpest daily gain in over six months. The rally was driven by robust chip demand and improved global demand, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix surging to record highs. Foreigners invested $82.47 million in the main board, extending the index's gains to a sixth straight session, and the index ended 2020 up 30.8%.

site_title: Australia: Shares post solid start to year as miners shine
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.5% to a 7-week high, driven by mining stocks' 2.7% gain, led by iron ore prices jumping 3% and gold stocks rising 5%. Heavyweights Evolution Mining, Newcrest Mining, and Northern Star Resources gained between 2% to 4%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,684.20 points, its best day since November 24. The gains were aided by a decline in Covid-19 cases in Australia's largest state.

site_title: Singapore's construction, marine and process workers among priority groups for vaccine
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong has announced that construction, marine, and process workers, as well as migrant workers, will be among the priority groups for COVID-19 vaccination due to their high risk of super-spreading events. Vaccination efforts have begun with healthcare workers and essential personnel, with plans to vaccinate the elderly and those at greater risk from February. The program will be progressively broadened to include other Singaporeans and long-term residents who are medically eligible, with prior bookings required due to cold-chain requirements and limited vaccine supply.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: UK rolls out AstraZeneca vaccine, touts first starter status
summary: The UK begins vaccinating its population with the Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 shot, becoming the first Western country to roll out an inoculation programme. The country has secured 100 million doses of the vaccine and has already administered over 1 million doses, more than the rest of Europe. The UK aims to deliver tens of millions of doses within months, with the programme initially targeting six hospitals in England before expanding to hundreds of other sites.

site_title: Asia manufacturing picks up pace as China starts to moderate recovery
summary: Asia's manufacturing sector continues to show signs of recovery, with key indicators such as Japan's PMI and Taiwan's PMI reaching their highest levels in years. China's factory growth, however, has started to moderate, with its official manufacturing gauge falling to 51.9 in December. South and Southeast Asia's economies also saw mostly marginal improvement, with India and Indonesia advancing into expansion territory. The data suggests a continued robust healing from the pandemic in the region, driven by strong demand for exports.

site_title: England school returns in doubt as Johnson warns on lockdown
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that England's schools may need to stay closed longer due to rising COVID-19 cases. Virus cases are surpassing 50,000 a day, putting pressure on the government to intensify action. Johnson rejected criticism of his government's response, stating that additional measures may be needed in the coming weeks. Health Secretary Matt Hancock suggested areas in tier 3 restrictions face tighter rules, and unions called for paid time off for parents. The UK is set to administer its first Covid-19 vaccine shots this week.

images.alt_text: Boris Johnson said England's schools may need to stay closed for longer than currently planned and warned tougher restrictions are probably on the way to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Hotel staff in contact with SHN individuals to be rostered for routine Covid-19 testing
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Lawrence Wong announced that hotel staff in contact with individuals serving Stay-Home Notice (SHN) hotels will be placed on a 14-day rostered routine testing (RRT) regime to prevent Covid-19 transmission. The measure applies to workers in high-risk sectors, including construction, marine, and process industries. Following an outbreak at the Mandarin Orchard Singapore hotel, 571 employees underwent PCR tests, with some positive serological tests indicating past infections. The hotel was allowed to reopen after disinfestation, with improved protocols and crowd regulation implemented.

site_title: Stock markets to sustain rally in 2021 amid vaccine-led recovery: analysts
summary: Market analysts predict a sustained rally in 2021 due to the global COVID-19 vaccine rollout, with cyclical and value stocks experiencing a strong rebound. Economies will recover gradually and unevenly across sectors, benefiting Singapore due to its tourism and domestic consumption sectors. Experts expect a gradual and broadening market rally, with DBS's chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook citing this trend.

site_title: CDL forms working group to improve Sincere's liquidity
summary: CDL establishes a working group to improve Sincere Property Group's liquidity and profitability by reviewing potential divestments and restructuring liabilities. The group's investments in Sincere total $1.9 billion, including a 51% joint-venture equity stake. Deloitte's review identified projects for divestment, debt restructuring, and further operational review. Despite liquidity challenges, Sincere remains a growth platform in the Chinese market, according to CDL's executive chairman.

site_title: Covid-19 'vaccine injury financial assistance programme' to be introduced: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore to introduce a Covid-19 vaccine injury financial assistance programme to provide support for those who suffer serious adverse events related to Covid-19 vaccines. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong assured the safety and efficacy of the vaccine, noting a stringent approval process and similar side effects to established vaccines. Vaccination recipients will be observed on-site for 30 minutes post-vaccination, and a programme will provide financial assistance to those affected. The programme aims to give peace of mind to those taking the vaccination.

site_title: China gas price surge likely shortlived as winter supply measures kick in
summary: China's liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices surged in December due to a cold snap and robust manufacturing activity, peaking at 9,000 yuan (S$1,812) per tonne. However, traders and analysts expect the price surge to be shortlived as state-run producers build up supplies to cope with winter demand, exceeding 9 million tonnes of LNG imports in December. This winter, China has prepared ample supplies of piped gas and LNG, and a new national company, PipeChina, will take over the ownership and operation of oil and gas pipelines, helping to stabilize prices.

images.alt_text: A recent surge in liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices in China is likely to be shortlived, traders and analysts said, as state-run producers build up supplies to cope with winter chills and prevent a repeat of the 2017 crunch.

site_title: China's GEM seeks to double stake, take control of Indonesia nickel project
summary: China's GEM Co Ltd aims to double its stake in an Indonesian nickel project, increasing its holding to 72% from 36%, in a move to strengthen "strategic control" of the resources amid a nickel shortage. The plan, outlined in a framework MoU, will see GEM's Jingmen unit partner with existing investors Tsingshan Group, CATL, and Indonesia's Morowali Industrial Park to boost production capacity to 50,000 tonnes. The deal, which has yet to be finalized, will see GEM's stake in units of Tsingshan and CATL also increase.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks start year in red as capital braces for state of emergency
summary: Japanese shares began 2021 in the red, with the Nikkei 225 Index declining 0.68% to 27,258.38, its largest daily drop in two weeks. The move was attributed to concerns over a potential state of emergency in Tokyo and surrounding prefectures due to a surge in local coronavirus infections. Shares in airlines, transport companies, real estate firms, and retailers fell as fears of travel restrictions and reduced consumer spending impacted the services sector.

site_title: China oil majors may face US delisting after telcos cut
summary: US may delist China's largest oil producers, Cnooc Ltd, PetroChina Co, and China Petroleum and Chemical Corp (Sinopec), following the removal of three Chinese telecom companies from the New York Stock Exchange. The oil majors are considered high-risk due to China's military ties, potentially leading to institutional investors selling their shares in Hong Kong. However, analysts believe the impact on US investors will be limited, as most institutional investors already hold shares in Hong Kong. The delisting could also lead to a loss of transparency for investors.

images.alt_text: Chinese oil majors may be next in line for delisting in the U.S. after the New York Stock Exchange said last week it would remove the Asian nation's three biggest telecom companies.

site_title: Petronas raises December Malaysian crude official selling price to US$50.66 a barrel
summary: Petronas has raised the official selling price of Malaysian crude oil for December to US$50.66 a barrel, a US$8 increase from November's price of US$42.66. This marks the third consecutive price hike since January 2021. The price increase is based on the spot differentials to dated Brent for four grades of Malaysian crude oil, including Labuan, Miri, Kikeh, and Kimanis.

site_title: As end to pandemic mask-wearing nears, South Koreans scramble to arrange cosmetic surgery
summary: In South Korea, the end of pandemic mask-wearing is expected to boost demand for cosmetic surgery, particularly for procedures that can be easily hidden under masks. As of 2020, the industry was valued at $10.7 billion, with a 9.2% year-over-year increase. Surgeons report an increase in inquiries about the face, including nose, lips, and forehead procedures, as people seek to enhance their appearance during the pandemic. The industry is expected to continue growing, with estimated revenues of $11.8 billion in 2021.

site_title: China's three big telcos slide on NYSE's move to delist ADRs
summary: China's three major state-owned telecommunications companies - China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom - declined in Hong Kong after the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) announced it will delist their American depositary receipts (ADRs) to comply with a US executive order sanctioning companies affiliated with the Chinese military. The move affects shares of China Mobile, which fell as much as 4.5%, and China Telecom and China Unicom, which dropped 5.6% and 3.6% respectively. The delisting process is expected to take place between January 7 and January 11, with the companies stating they regret the decision and are reviewing ways to protect their rights.

site_title: Pinduoduo worker's death renews scrutiny of 996 work culture
summary: A Pinduoduo employee's death sparked widespread criticism of the company's 996 work culture, where employees work 9am-9pm, six days a week, with overtime. The practice has been endorsed by tech billionaires despite previous deaths and worker complaints. The incident adds to the challenges for China's largest tech companies, which face regulatory scrutiny and anti-competitive practices. Pinduoduo's stock rose 370% in 2021, making its founder China's second-richest man, but the company's reputation has been damaged by the worker's death.

site_title: China makes rating firm pay for corporate fraud for first time
summary: A Chinese court has ruled that a local ratings firm, Dagong Global Credit Rating Co, must help compensate creditors for Wuyang Construction Group Co's 1.4 billion yuan bond defaults, a first in the country. The court ordered Dagong Global to repay up to 10% of 494 million yuan in debt claims to over 400 individual bondholders. The ruling sets a precedent for financial responsibility of bond underwriters, accounting, and law firms for bondholder losses, and may lead to more prudent behavior from financial intermediaries.

site_title: 'Just stay home' - Thai PM urges compliance as virus cases hit record
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has urged the public to stay home to contain the country's record 745 new coronavirus infections, avoiding a strict lockdown. The government has declared 28 provinces, including Bangkok, as high-risk zones, asking people to work from home and avoid travel. Authorities aim to prevent economic damage from strong containment measures. The move comes after the outbreak was first detected at a seafood market near the capital last month.

site_title: Danske becomes Nordic ESG debt leader after US$4b in deals
summary: Danske Bank has become the Nordic ESG debt leader after arranging $4.3 billion of sustainable bond sales in 2020, surpassing other banks. The bank expects a 25% expansion in the primary market for green debt over the next 12 months. Sustainability-linked bonds, which link debt proceeds to broader environmental, social, or governance goals, are expected to drive growth. The introduction of new European Union Green Bond Standards is also expected to boost supply, with companies set to see a price benefit from issuing under the EU standards.

site_title: Beijing vaccinates thousands in Covid-19 jab drive
summary: Thousands of people in Beijing received their first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine, with over 73,000 receiving the jab in the past couple of days. China has granted "conditional" approval to Sinopharm's vaccine with a 79% efficacy rate, aiming to vaccinate millions before the Lunar New Year mass travel season in February. Beijing has already administered around 4.5 million doses of emergency vaccines, and the country plans a gradual rollout for key groups with high risk of exposure to the virus.

site_title: Higher food costs stalk Britons as the new year brings Brexit
summary: The UK's new year brings concerns over higher food costs due to Brexit-related border checks, which could add 3 billion pounds to costs for food importers, approximately an 8% increase. The UK imports half its food from abroad, primarily from the EU, and food insecurity was already a rising issue before Brexit. Experts warn that these costs will likely be passed on to consumers, despite the UK avoiding a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Tiny apartment sales soar in world's priciest home market
summary: In Hong Kong's world's least affordable housing market, a record 13% of apartments sold in 2019 were nano apartments, defined as less than 260 square feet. These tiny units, which can cost over HK$5 million, account for just 0.2% of total sales since 2010. Despite the city's high property prices, developers offer smaller homes to buyers, with 85% lacking a separate bedroom and 70% without a window in the toilet. The trend highlights the difficulties faced by the younger generation in affording housing in the city.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.53% to 27,087.13, following a healthy run-up last week. Investors monitored the rollout of vaccines and rising virus infections. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat, while the US markets edged down despite reaching fresh records.

site_title: Surrey Point in Newton up for collective sale with S$55m guide price
summary: Surrey Point, a freehold residential development in Newton, Singapore, is up for collective sale via public tender with a guide price of S$55 million. The site has a land rate of about S$1,661 per square foot per plot ratio, and is zoned for residential use with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 35,882 sq ft. The collective sale offers a potential opportunity for investors to capitalize on the site's value, which could be influenced by market demand and the ongoing trend of prime property prices exceeding S$3,000 per square foot.

site_title: Peugeot, Fiat merger to be sealed by shareholders
summary: The shareholders of PSA and Fiat Chrysler are expected to approve their 50/50 merger, creating Stellantis, the world's fourth-largest automaker by volume. The deal, delayed by the Covid-19 pandemic, aims to transition both companies to clean car technology. The merger is seen as crucial for their survival, allowing them to strengthen their presence in Europe and the US. The new company will have a workforce of over 400,000 and is expected to achieve billions of euros in synergies each year, with PSA chief Carlos Tavares set to take the helm.

site_title: Foxconn in talks with Chinese EV startup Byton for funding
summary: Foxconn Technology Group is in talks to invest around $200 million in Chinese electric vehicle startup Byton, aiming to start mass production of the Byton M-Byte by Q1 2022. The deal would provide a lifeline for Byton, which has struggled to produce its first vehicle since unveiling the concept car several years ago. This investment represents a significant bet by Foxconn on the car-making business, as the company seeks to diversify its revenue streams and expand its presence in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 3.62 points (0.22%) to 1,623.59. The index saw 226.36 million lots traded worth RM84.20 million. Gainers outpaced losers 235-191.

site_title: Australia home prices end rocky 2020 on recovery track
summary: Australia's home prices rose 1.0% in December, ending 2020 on a strong note, with a third consecutive month of gains. This recovery is attributed to buyers outnumbering sellers, boosting consumer wealth and confidence. The country's housing stock valued at A$7.2 trillion is expected to continue growing, driven by the turnaround from the Covid-19-led crunch.

site_title: Indonesia inflation picks up further in Dec, but stays below central bank target
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate accelerated to 1.68% in December, its fourth straight month of increase, but remained below the central bank's target range of 2-4%. The core inflation rate, excluding volatile food and government-controlled prices, was 1.6%, below expectations. Prices rose 0.45% on a monthly basis, as inflation continues to stay within the central bank's target. This marks a slight improvement from the previous month's 1.61% inflation rate.

site_title: Singapore stocks start the new year slightly positive; STI up 0.1% at open
summary: Singapore stocks started the new year slightly positive, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% at 2,846.90. The full-year contraction came in at 5.8%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Gainers outnumbered losers 102 to 59, with notable movers including Sunpower Group, which rose 4.4%, and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, which advanced 1%. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS up 0.3% and UOB flat.

site_title: Oil prices slip after Opec warns of downside risks to demand in first-half 2021
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday, January 4, 2021, as Opec warned of downside risks to demand in the first half of 2021 due to the lingering coronavirus pandemic. Brent crude fell 4 cents to $51.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude declined 9 cents to $48.43 a barrel. Opec Secretary General Mohammad Barkindo expressed concerns about the risk of reduced demand, despite expected crude demand growth of 5.9 million barrels per day this year.

site_title: Carl Icahn sells over half his Herbalife stake for US$600m: WSJ
summary: Carl Icahn, a billionaire investor, has sold over half his stake in Herbalife Nutrition for approximately US$600 million. He initially held a 16% stake and has reduced it to about 6%, worth US$400 million, after selling about 10% of his shares back to the company. Icahn is also planning to give up his five seats on the Herbalife board.

site_title: Asia: Hopes for recovery help markets start new year with a pop
summary: Asian markets started the new year on a positive note, driven by optimism about economic recovery and the rollout of coronavirus vaccines. Despite concerns over Brexit and a new US stimulus, analysts expect a strong rebound in 2021, with the Federal Reserve's loose monetary policies supporting the rally. However, the first quarter is expected to be tough as vaccinations are administered but the virus continues to spread. Key gains were seen in Seoul, Sydney, and Shanghai, while Tokyo fell due to concerns over a regional state of emergency in Japan.

site_title: Training, hiring incentives could be beefed up in Singapore Budget 2021: EY
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 may include policy tweaks to boost funding for training, hiring, and staff issues. The proposal aims to support businesses in strengthening and transforming for the future, while helping impacted individuals and households rebuild their lives.
