Ernst & Young Solutions recommends prioritizing the Covid-19 economic downturn, business productivity, and innovation. The move is seen as a response to the economic downturn and efforts to rebuild the workforce.

site_title: Bitcoin trades at US$33,176 following 800% surge
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$34,800 on Sunday, trading at US$33,176 in Asia on Monday, marking an 800% surge since mid-March. The digital currency's limited supply and potential as a safe-haven play during the pandemic have fueled its upward moves. Investors, including larger US investors and traders, are attracted to bitcoin's potential for quick gains. Coinbase, the largest US cryptocurrency exchange, is set to go public, further increasing demand for the digital currency.

site_title: Four trends that will shape your data strategy this year
summary: Four key trends shaping data strategy in Asean in 2021 include the rise of 5G, making machine learning accessible to everyone, data governance in a hybrid cloud world, and the increasing focus on AI ethics. As 5G brings massive connectivity for IoT, organisations must navigate data storms created by connected devices. Machine learning will become more accessible, enabling business users to leverage insights without IT and data science teams. Data governance will take centre stage in hybrid cloud environments, with a focus on security, governance, and compliance. AI will also require data ethics, with a focus on anonymisation, transparency, and data ownership.

site_title: India's manufacturing sector ends 2020 on brighter note
summary: India's manufacturing sector ended 2020 on a stronger note, with the Nikkei Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 56.4 in December from 56.3 in November, indicating growth for a fifth month. Production and new orders grew, but new export orders slowed due to dampened overseas demand. Despite rising demand, employment continued to decline as firms cut jobs. Input prices surged, threatening to squeeze profit margins and keep inflation above the Reserve Bank of India's target range. Optimism for the next 12 months declined to a four-month low amid concerns over price pressures and the pandemic.

site_title: UK's Brexit plans to be tested as festive period ends
summary: Britain faced its first major test of Brexit preparations as thousands of lorries were expected to make the Channel crossing on Monday, the first time since the UK left the EU's single market and customs union. The government anticipated disruptions at key ports such as Dover, but so far, the light holiday season traffic has allowed for minimal work for border officials. The test will assess the UK's ability to keep traffic flowing and implement customs checks smoothly.

site_title: China's wintry cold lifts diesel use as factories buy generators
summary: China's winter cold wave has led to power shortages, prompting factories to buy generators and diesel to ensure production. Wholesale diesel prices rose to the highest level since April, while inventories fell 5.26% in December. The Chinese meteorological authority issued an orange alert, prioritizing energy supply to homes and communities over industrial users. As a result, factories are snapping up portable generators and diesel, with some selling over 20 generators per day, more than triple the normal level.

site_title: Japan's Kirin to invest US$30m in maker of Indian craft beer Bira
summary: Japan's Kirin Holdings is investing US$30 million in B9 Beverages, the maker of Indian craft beer Bira, to secure a spot in India's growing craft beer market. The investment will allow Bira to break even in the 2022 fiscal year and accelerate plans to launch its products in Japan. Bira has posted losses in recent years and has been hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. The deal, expected to be closed soon, will see Kirin acquire a stake of under 10% in Bira.

images.alt_text: Japan's beer maker Kirin Holdings will invest US$30 million in New Delhi-based B9 Beverages, the companies said on Monday, as it seeks to secure a spot in India's growing craft beer market amid falling sales at home.

site_title: Australia: Shares start year on a high as commodities shine
summary: Australian shares started 2021 on a high note, driven by mining stocks and upbeat commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.94% to 6,648.9 points, with miners and gold stocks leading the gain. Financials also climbed, while the biggest loser was superannuation administrator Link Administration Holdings, which fell 13.2%. Investors remain optimistic about the global economy's revival, with central banks expected to keep money cheap and the rollout of coronavirus vaccines providing a boost.

site_title: Opec sees oil outlook for first half of 2021 full of downside risks
summary: Opec's Secretary General Mohammad Barkindo stated that the oil outlook for the first half of 2021 is "very mixed" and poses "downside risks." Despite hopeful signs, the global economy is expected to grow by 4.4% in 2021, with oil demand led by developing countries. However, sectors like travel, tourism, and hospitality may take years to recover to pre-pandemic levels, and Opec is considering holding output steady due to weakening fundamentals.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 2.9% in Q4; biggest quarterly rise in nine years: Flash data
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.9% in Q4 2020, the largest quarterly increase in nine years, driven by policy changes and strong demand. For the year, resale prices rose 4.8%, higher than 2019 and 2018. The HDB resale market's recovery can be attributed to the introduction of the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant and increased flexibility in using CPF funds. Experts expect prices to rise another 2-5% in 2021 as the economy recovers.

site_title: Moscow metro hires first women train drivers
summary: The Moscow metro has hired its first female train drivers, marking a significant change in the Russian capital's transport system. The move comes after recent changes to legislation prohibiting women from many professions, which were criticized for being discriminatory. The Moscow transport department cited automation and reduced physical exertion as reasons for the shift, while the justification for excluding women from jobs like bus driving and metalworking was deemed outdated. This change is part of a broader effort to open up more jobs to women in Russia.

site_title: Iraq says Chinese company wins US$2 billion oil prepayment deal
summary: Iraq has agreed to a $2 billion oil prepayment deal with Chinese company ZhenHua Oil Co, according to the country's petroleum export agency. The deal, which was awarded after intense competition with European and Chinese companies, will supply 130,000 barrels of crude per day for five years. The upfront payment, which would bring in over $2 billion at current prices, is the first of its kind for Baghdad. The deal is part of China's efforts to lend to struggling oil producers via state-controlled trading companies and banks.

site_title: Gold hits two-month high as greenback, real yields face pressure
summary: Gold prices surged to a two-month high, reaching $1,917.05 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and a 25% annual gain in 2020. Silver and platinum also saw significant increases, with spot gold climbing 1% and platinum reaching its highest price since 2016. The rally comes despite US stocks being at all-time highs, as investors seek safe-haven assets amid expectations of economic growth and central bank support.

site_title: Singapore private home prices up 2.1% q-o-q in Q4; rise 2.2% for 2020: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 2.1% in Q4 2020, with a 2.2% increase for the full year, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash estimate. Non-landed properties in prime areas saw a 3.2% increase, while landed properties fell 2.1% in Q4. The URA notes that past data have shown significant differences between flash estimates and actual price changes, advising caution when interpreting the data.

site_title: US dollar slips in to 2021 as investors ride downtrend
summary: The US dollar slipped in 2021 as investors anticipated low US interest rates and a worldwide recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, making it a laggard against other major currencies. The euro rose 0.2% to $1.2244, while the yen and Australian dollars also gained. The Chinese yuan climbed 0.2 to 6.4927 per dollar, and the Singapore dollar reached a 32-month high. The dollar's largest annual loss since 2017 occurred in 2020, and investors are watching Tuesday's runoff vote in Georgia for its potential impact on the dollar's value.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB expects Singapore banks to benefit from pick-up in credit growth this year
summary: CGS-CIMB has reaffirmed its "overweight" call on Singapore's banking sector, anticipating a pickup in credit growth in 2021 due to eased social distancing measures and the COVID-19 vaccination program. Analysts expect DBS, OCBC, and UOB to benefit, with UOB as their top pick, driven by sustained or increasing net interest margins. Credit growth is seen as a reversal of an eight-month decline in bank lending and encouraging growth in Singapore's industrial production index.

site_title: Japan PM says to consider state of emergency for Tokyo area
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga considers declaring a state of emergency for the Greater Tokyo metropolitan area due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with over half of Japan's cases reported in the region. The move comes after a record 4,520 new cases on Dec 31, straining the country's medical system. As an interim measure, the government has already asked restaurants and karaoke parlours to close earlier, and Suga noted that shortening business hours helped stem infections in other regions. A state of emergency would be the second time parts of Japan have entered one due to the pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Keppel, StarHub, Metro, ABR, LHN, Sunpower
summary: Key developments include: City Developments' (CDL) independent director Tan Yee Peng's resignation, Keppel Corporation's plans to adopt an asset-light approach and tap third-party co-investments, StarHub's S$200 million note issuance, and Sunpower Group's management buyout of its manufacturing and services business for 2.3 billion yuan. Other notable announcements include Metro Holdings' acquisition of a 26% stake in industrial properties, ABR Holdings' award of a S$23.6 million tender, and LHN Limited's launch of a mixed-use development.

site_title: Singapore GDP shrinks 5.8% in 2020; contraction slowed in Q4
summary: Singapore's GDP contracted 5.8% in 2020, slowing down in the fourth quarter with a 3.8% decline compared to the previous quarter. The economy showed a 2.1% quarter-on-quarter growth, better than expected. This marks an improvement from the 5.6% contraction in Q3. The better-than-expected Q4 growth is attributed to a slowdown in the contraction, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Third CDL director resigns over Sincere investment
summary: Third director of City Developments Limited (CDL) Tan Yee Peng has resigned due to disagreements with the board and management over the company's investment in China-based real estate developer Sincere Property Group. Her departure follows that of independent non-executive director Koh Thiam Hock, who resigned in December, and former director Kwek Leng Peck, who quit in October. CDL has appointed Philip Lee Jee Cheng to replace Tan, who has 35 years of experience in accounting and finance. The company's investments in Sincere total about S$1.9 billion, and a review conducted by Deloitte & Touche Financial Advisory Services found good assets that the group can extract further value from.

site_title: Philippine bourse eyes more IPOs in 2021 amid 'fragile' recovery
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange aims for at least three companies and four real estate investment trusts to hold initial public offerings in 2021 amidst a "fragile" economic recovery. The exchange's CEO, Ramon Monzon, targets more companies to go public despite the country's forecasted slow growth in the second quarter. Last year's IPOs raised 104 billion pesos, with the exchange planning to introduce new indices and implement short selling to boost growth. The government's mass vaccination plan is expected to prompt a strong rebound in corporate earnings.

site_title: China securities regulator says NYSE delistings 'political', impact 'limited'
summary: China's securities regulator stated that NYSE plans to delist three Chinese telecom firms due to US investment restrictions, calling the move "political" with limited impact. The NYSE had announced the delistings following President Donald Trump's November ban on US investment in 31 firms linked to the Chinese military. The regulator's stance suggests the decision is driven by politics rather than economic concerns, with potential implications for China-US relations and the global financial markets.

site_title: Japan snaps 19-month decline in factory activity in Dec: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity ended a 19-month decline in December, with the private-sector PMI index rising to 50.0, signaling stabilization in output and employment conditions. This marks the first time since April 2019 that the index crossed the 50.0 threshold, separating contraction from expansion. New orders declined at the softest pace since December 2018, but growth expectations for the year ahead rose due to hopes of a fading Covid-19-induced downturn. Export orders fell at a faster rate due to restrictions in major markets, but businesses reported a sustained increase in optimism.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares see strong start to 2021
summary: Tokyo stocks opened the year with a strong start, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.53% and the Topix index firming 0.15%. Investors are betting on a global economy recovery, with the benchmark indices continuing recent momentum.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks began the new year on a strong footing on Monday, keeping up momentum seen in recent weeks with investors betting on the global economy regaining a sense of normalcy.

site_title: Democrat Pelosi narrowly re-elected as US House speaker
summary: Nancy Pelosi, the 80-year-old Democrat from California, has been narrowly re-elected as US House speaker with a vote of 216 to 209, securing her fourth non-consecutive term. Despite a scare when some Democrats defected and voted "present," Pelosi outmaneuvered Republican leader Kevin McCarthy. The outcome marks a significant moment for the highest-ranking woman in US politics, as the new Congress convenes in the final weeks of Donald Trump's presidency.

site_title: LHN to launch Keppel Road mixed-use development by mid-February
summary: LHN to launch a mixed-use development at 1557 Keppel Road in Singapore by mid-February 2021. The integrated space, spanning 96,299.05 sq ft, will feature commercial and residential areas, including office spaces, serviced apartments, and in-house dining options. The development, located near Outram Park and Tanjong Pagar MRT stations, is LHN's second mixed-use project, following 10 Raeburn Park. The project aims to cater to modern working professionals and their lifestyles, with a focus on co-living and working spaces.

site_title: Why emptier US streets meant an especially deadly year for traffic deaths
summary: In 2020, New York City recorded 243 traffic deaths, the highest on record since 2014, defying historical trends of decreased fatal crashes during economic downturns. The surge in traffic fatalities, a 76% increase from 2019, can be attributed to drivers taking to wide-open streets during the pandemic, speeding recklessly, and increased alcohol and drug use. This trend was not isolated, with a nationwide spike in traffic fatalities, highlighting the challenges posed by the pandemic to safety initiatives like Mayor Bill de Blasio's Vision Zero programme.

site_title: Canada surges from 500,000 to 600,000 Covid-19 cases in two weeks
summary: Canada surpassed 600,000 Covid-19 cases, with 15,860 deaths, in two weeks, marking the persistence of the pandemic. Ontario recorded a new daily record of 2,964 cases and Quebec 2,869, with the country's death toll rising to 4,650 in Ontario and 8,347 in Quebec. The government has advised against non-essential travel abroad to stem the spread, following criticism of politicians who took holiday trips despite the guidance.

site_title: US may cut some Moderna vaccine doses in half to speed rollout: official
summary: The US government is considering cutting some Moderna Covid-19 vaccine doses in half to speed up vaccinations. According to Moncef Slaoui, head of Operation Warp Speed, this approach could immunize double the number of people with the available doses. The vaccine requires two injections, and officials believe giving half the dose to people between 18 and 55 would induce an identical immune response. This plan aims to accelerate vaccinations, which have fallen short of early targets, and it is expected to be discussed with Moderna and the FDA.

site_title: China December new home prices slow, private survey shows
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.25% in December, slowing for the second month, according to a private survey. Despite the slower pace, annual price growth still outpaced the previous year, reaching 3.46%. The market continues to be influenced by government-cooling measures, with price drops in some smaller cities. The property market has recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic, but policymakers are now focusing on containing financial risks in the highly leveraged sector.

site_title: 10 stocks to watch in 2021
summary:

Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, while stocks in Europe and the US declined due to bank and healthcare issues, as well as US-EU tariffs. The article also mentions US President Trump's fresh tariff threats on Canada, contributing to Wall Street's opening lower. These events highlight market volatility and the need for investors to monitor these key stocks and market trends.

site_title: Trump heard on tape urging state official to 'find' votes for him
summary: President Donald Trump pressured Georgia's top election official, Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, to "find" enough votes to overturn Joe Biden's victory in the state, according to a recording obtained by The Washington Post. Trump warned Raffensperger that he and his general counsel could face a "big risk" if they failed to pursue his request. The phone conversation occurred on Saturday, January 2, 2021.

site_title: A monster wind turbine is upending an industry
summary: General Electric's (GE) test model for giant offshore wind turbines, the Haliade-X, is significantly more powerful than existing commercial turbines, with a generating capacity of 13 megawatts. This prototype, which can produce as much thrust as a Boeing 747 jet, is changing business calculations in the industry. The machine's size and advance sales have "shaken the industry," with top executives calling it a "leapfrog" over the latest technology. GE aims to deploy the turbines at sea, where stronger and more reliable breezes can be harnessed, and has secured deals with major customers, including Orsted, to supply hundreds of turbines.

site_title: SS&C Technology withdraws from race for Australia's Link Group
summary: US-based SS&C Technology Holdings has withdrawn its A$3.02 billion offer to acquire Australia's Link Administration Holdings, following the company's rejection of the proposal. Link had asked SS&C to better its offer, which was nearly 5% higher than a rival bid from Carlyle Group and Pacific Equity Partners. The Link Group Board will continue to consider alternative options, including the sale of its interest in Torrens Group Holdings and its core asset PEXA, starting from January 18.

site_title: Discovery+ streaming service to launch on Roku, Amazon Fire TV and others
summary: Discovery+, a new streaming service from Discovery, launches on Monday in the US on Roku, Amazon Fire TV, and other platforms, bypassing rivals Peacock and HBO Max. The service will also be available in 12 European markets through Vodafone TV and mobile promotions. This move comes after HBO Max's launch in May, which was initially unavailable on Roku and Amazon.

site_title: Gerry and the Pacemakers star Gerry Marsden dies at 78
summary: Gerry Marsden, lead singer of Gerry and the Pacemakers, has died at 78 after a short illness due to an infection in his heart. Marsden formed the band in 1959 and achieved chart success, including their 1963 version of "You'll Never Walk Alone," which became the anthem for Liverpool Football Club. Marsden's voice was a key part of the band's success, and his song helped create a sense of unity among fans, players, and staff worldwide.

site_title: Tesla says it hit goal of producing half a million cars in 2020
summary: Tesla reported producing over half a million cars in 2020, exceeding its goal. The company delivered 180,570 cars in the fourth quarter, bringing its total to 499,550. This represents a 36% increase from 2019 and a 40% increase in production. Despite challenges, Tesla's CEO Elon Musk remains optimistic, citing the company's buoyant stock and profitable quarters. However, the company faces increased competition in 2021 and still needs to address issues such as low sales of its most profitable vehicles and suspension failures.

site_title: Bitcoin breaches US$34,000 as rally extends into new year
summary: Bitcoin reached a new milestone, breaching US$34,000 in value, after advancing nearly 50% in December and surpassing US$20,000 for the first time. The currency's rally is attributed to increased adoption by institutional investors, who are expanding their investment portfolios to include Bitcoin. Experts predict further price growth, with some forecasting a potential rise to US$400,000, while cautioning that the market remains thinly traded and due for a correction.

site_title: One Canadian's 'buy local' effort fights Amazon on its own turf
summary: A 27-year-old Canadian, Ali Haberstroh, created the website Not-Amazon.ca to support local businesses during the pandemic. The site, which now has over 4,000 businesses listed, offers nationwide shipping, curbside pickup, or delivery, and has garnered over half a million page views. The initiative aims to counter Amazon's dominance and help small businesses stay alive. While some businesses have seen significant increases in sales, others have reported struggles, and the Canadian Federation of Independent Business estimates that 1 in 7 Canadian businesses will close due to the pandemic.

site_title: Deutsche Bank can play leading role in bank consolidation: CEO
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing stated that the bank is gaining financial strength, positioning it to play a leading role in European banking consolidation. With a stock market value of 18 billion euros, Deutsche would be an affordable target for a more valuable potential acquirer. Sewing's restructuring drive is bearing fruit, with earnings and costs in its private and corporate business on track. This development could lead to Deutsche Bank participating in a possible consolidation of European banks.

site_title: The science to keeping New Year's resolutions
summary: Research by psychologist John Norcross shows that people who make New Year's resolutions are more than 10 times as successful in changing their behavior compared to those who don't make formal resolutions. To increase success, experts recommend focusing on one resolution, making small goals, framing resolutions as positive actions, setting time limits, and aiming for progress rather than perfection. By following these tips, individuals can improve their chances of achieving their New Year's resolutions and making lasting behavioral changes.

site_title: India approves vaccines; other nations fighting virus resurgence
summary: India has approved emergency use of two COVID-19 vaccines, developed by AstraZeneca/Oxford University and Bharat Biotech, as part of its massive inoculation drive. The country aims to vaccinate 300 million people by mid-2021. However, the approval of Bharat Biotech's Covaxin was questioned due to lack of published efficacy data. India joins a small list of countries to have approved its own coronavirus shot. The vaccine roll-out is part of a global effort to combat the pandemic, with countries around the world experiencing a resurgence of cases.

site_title: A grim start to EU independence but hopes high for UK economic recovery: economists
summary: The UK economy has retreated into a double-dip lockdown recession, forecast to last until the end of the first quarter of 2021. Despite this, economists remain hopeful for a sunny spring recovery. The EU's independence from the UK commences amidst the recession. Economists predict a growth rebound, with Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Far East Orchard looks to student accommodation to build safe haven
summary: Far East Orchard is shifting its focus to building a portfolio of purpose-built student accommodations (PBSA) in the UK, with a goal of 5,000 beds by 2025. The company's CEO, Alan Tang, aims to generate sustainable, recurring income by diversifying from property development, which has historically produced "lumpy" earnings. FEOR's PBSA portfolio currently has 3,500 beds across six cities in the UK and has an occupancy rate of over 80%. The company is on the hunt for similar properties with good demand and supply fundamentals, and has a "healthy cash balance" to pursue acquisitions and development opportunities.

site_title: A stretch of pristine land in Florida sees real estate boom amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: A real estate boom is underway in Walton County, Florida, as St Joe Co. secures entitlements to build over 170,000 residential units near the Gulf Coast. The company's stock has more than doubled since the end of September, fueled by the Covid-19 pandemic's migration to Florida. Developer Bruce Berkowitz's Fairholme Fund has seen significant gains, with the US$1.6 billion fund up 25% and Berkowitz's personal portfolio up 61%. The area's pristine land and low taxes make it an attractive destination for those looking to relocate, with St Joe's projects including a Jimmy Buffett-themed community and a unique elevation that provides a barrier against hurricane surges.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Broadway Industrial Group has agreed to sell its manufacturing business for US$50 million to Chinese firm Suzhou Gefan Hardware And Plastic Industrial Co. The proposed deal requires shareholder approval and will result in Broadway becoming a cash company. The board believes the price is "fair and reasonable" and presents an opportunity to unlock value for shareholders. Meanwhile, Sabana Reit appointed Yeo Wee Kiong and Willy Shee Ping Yah as independent directors, with Yeo also becoming chairman of the nominating and remuneration committee.

site_title: Tough 2021 for residential landlords as rent budgets, foreign workforce shrink
summary: Singapore's residential landlords face a tough 2021 due to rising vacancy rates and reduced rental budgets. The vacancy rate is estimated to reach 7% for 2020 and 8-9% for 2021, with posh homes potentially seeing rent falls of 2-3% in 2020. Foreign workers, particularly non-residents, have been hit hard, with employment declines of 158,700 from January to September. While Chinese tech companies' expansion in Singapore may provide some relief, their impact on the rental market is uncertain.

site_title: French media group Lagardere gets 465 million euro state guaranteed loan
summary: French media group Lagardere has received a 465 million euro state-guaranteed loan to cope with the economic fallout of the pandemic. The company reported a 38% drop in third-quarter sales due to the pandemic's impact on its airport shops. The loan is part of efforts to support the company amid the economic crisis.

site_title: Fiat and PSA's against-all-odds merger nears the finish line
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and PSA Group are set to complete a merger forming Stellantis, the world's fourth-largest automaker, after two years of negotiations. The deal, which will combine Fiat's Ram and Jeep divisions with PSA's Peugeot and Citroen brands, aims to boost returns through scale and greater resources. However, challenges await, including a lack of presence in the luxury-car business and China's vast auto market. CEO Carlos Tavares will lead the combined company, which will boast an impressive presence in North America's lucrative truck and SUV segments, but faces weaknesses in Europe and reliance on regional markets.

site_title: China oil majors may face US delisting after NYSE drops telcos
summary: China's largest oil producers, CNOOC, PetroChina, and Sinopec, may face US delisting due to their involvement in China's military, according to analyst Henik Fung. The New York Stock Exchange's decision to remove China's three biggest telecom companies has set a precedent for energy sector companies, potentially putting these oil majors at risk. The US has identified CNOOC as a company owned or controlled by the Chinese military, increasing the likelihood of delisting.

site_title: Robinsons' last outlet at Raffles City to close by Jan 10
summary: Robinsons, a Singaporean department store, will close its last outlet at Raffles City by January 10, marking the end of 162 years of history. The liquidator, KordaMentha, has stated that discounts will continue to be updated daily to sell remaining stock down to zero. The store has been experiencing declining sales due to changing consumer tastes and cost pressures, including rent. Staff will remain employed for a short period to assist with account closures and other matters.

site_title: Thailand's economic conditions tipped to worsen as virus spreads
summary: Thailand's economic conditions are expected to worsen in 2021 due to the ongoing coronavirus resurgence, with 52.2% of respondents predicting a decline in economic conditions compared to last year. A national survey by the National Institute of Development Administration found that only 14.6% anticipate an improvement. The country's economic struggles come amidst other regional economic concerns, including China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy.

site_title: New US law closes money-laundering, tax evasion channel
summary: The US has passed a new law requiring the disclosure of owners of US shell companies used to hide billions of dollars, closing a major avenue for global money laundering and tax evasion. The Corporate Transparency Act, included in the defence appropriations bill, forces "beneficial owners" to report their identities to the US Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The law aims to combat kleptocrats, organised crime, and rich tax evaders, and sets penalties of up to two years in jail and a $10,000 fine for non-compliance. Transparency advocates see it as a significant step in protecting the US financial system.

site_title: 35 imported cases of Covid-19, highest number since March
summary: Singapore reported 35 new cases of Covid-19, the highest daily figure since September 14, with all cases being imported. The total confirmed infections now stand at 58,697. The Ministry of Health (MOH) identified two clusters of linked cases, and all infected individuals were on stay-home notices or in isolation when tested. Hospitalized patients remain at 64, while 117 are recovering in community facilities, with one patient in critical condition.

site_title: Aleta Planet pledges S$200,000 annually to charities
summary: Aleta Planet, a Singapore-based fintech company, has pledged S$200,000 annually to charities through its Aleta Planet Foundation. The company's founder, Ryan Gwee, aims to donate a portion of the transaction fees made through its virtual card platform to the foundation's fund, with the goal of supporting charities reviewed by the Community Foundation of Singapore. The initiative was launched in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw some companies roll back their donations, and Gwee wants to ensure that his company continues to support charities even during uncertain times.

site_title: Global opportunities drive S-Reits growth in 2020
summary: Singapore's Reits (Real Estate Investment Trusts) sector experienced significant growth in 2020, driven by global opportunities, with 20 S-Reits included in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index Series. Despite a 20% decline in S-Reits and a 40% decline in global Reits due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the sector has rebounded, generating -3.1% total returns in 2020. The diversified nature of S-Reits and new regulatory measures have contributed to its resilience.

site_title: Time for investors to increase and widen their exposure to stocks as vaccines tame Covid-19
summary: Investors are expected to increase and broaden their exposure to stocks as COVID-19 vaccines become more available, potentially leading to a synchronous global economic recovery. Technology stocks, which were hammered last year, could bounce strongly, with Amazon and Apple rising over 74% and 83% respectively in 2020. However, investors should not completely abandon these stocks and instead seek diversified exposure to stocks with good fundamentals. The risk of high stock valuations and inflation is also a concern, with some analysts predicting a "disruptive shift" in inflation expectations and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: GSH gets loan facilities of up to S$150m, with condition that Sam Goi remains controlling shareholder
summary: GSH Corp, a mainboard-listed property developer, has secured loan facilities of up to S$150 million with a condition that Sam Goi Seng Hui and his family maintain control of at least 35% of the company. The agreement also prohibits them from reducing their stakes below 35% or losing control of voting decisions. If the conditions are breached, the lender may demand repayment of the loan.

site_title: As understanding of Russian hacking grows, so do concerns over US cyber defences
summary: US officials are investigating a massive Russian hacking operation that compromised up to 250 federal agencies and businesses, targeting the US government and major corporations. The breach, which began in October 2019, was detected by a private cybersecurity company, FireEye. US officials are still trying to determine the full extent of the attack, which may have involved "backdoor" access to government agencies and corporations. The breach has raised concerns about the vulnerability of US networks and the effectiveness of its cyber defenses. The US government has confirmed that multiple agencies, including the Treasury and Energy Departments, were infiltrated, and large corporations like Amazon and Microsoft were also affected.

site_title: South Korea expands ban on small gatherings to blunt coronavirus surge
summary: South Korea expands its ban on private gatherings of more than four people nationwide, extending social distancing rules until January 17, amid a prolonged surge in coronavirus cases. The country reported 824 new cases, down from 1,029, with 40% linked to small gatherings. Restrictions on churches, restaurants, and other venues remain in place. The health minister cited the need to reduce deaths and expressed gratitude for citizens' cooperation. The measures are part of the country's efforts to prepare for vaccinations set to begin in February, which are seen as a key hurdle in controlling the surge.

site_title: Broadway to sell entire manufacturing business for US$50m
summary: Broadway Industrial Group has agreed to sell its manufacturing business to Suzhou Gefan Hardware And Plastic Industrial Co for US$50 million. The deal, valued at about US$33 million, will result in Broadway becoming a cash company and is expected to yield net proceeds of US$43.9 million. The proposed disposal requires shareholder approval and is conditional on Gefan's board approval. Broadway's board believes the price is "fair and reasonable" and will allow the company to explore new options.

site_title: US closes key money-laundering, tax evasion channel
summary: The US has passed the Corporate Transparency Act, a law requiring disclosure of owners of US shell companies used for money laundering and tax evasion. The law, included in the defence appropriations bill, forces beneficial owners to report their identities to the US Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. This move is seen as a major step against kleptocrats, organised crime, and rich tax evaders, and could result in a sharp drop in all-cash business transactions. The law grants protection to owners from public knowledge, but transparency advocates say it is a crucial step in protecting the US financial system.

site_title: The Place Holdings to jointly develop a residential-commercial project in Tanah Merah
summary: THE Place Holdings has entered a shareholders' agreement with MCC Land and Ekovest Development to jointly develop a 99-year lease site in Tanah Merah into a mixed residential development. The project will yield 265 condominium units and 2,000 square meters of commercial space. The joint venture company has an issued and paid-up share capital of S$4 million, with The Place Holdings holding a 20% stake. The development aims to cater to the local community's under-served retail needs and establishes a long-term relationship with MCC Group. The investment will be funded by internal resources.

site_title: Break above resistance needed to see upside for EURUSD
summary: EURUSD is targeting 1.3000 in the long run, according to Chartpoint. The currency has broken above a falling wedge pattern and tested resistance zones 1 and 2, with the latter potentially being invalidated. If EURUSD breaks above resistance zone 2, it may move to test 1.4043, indicating potential further upside. The move would also suggest a potential wave III of the super cycle phase, indicating further upside for the euro.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager appoints two directors
summary: Sabana Reit manager appoints Yeo Wee Kiong and Willy Shee Ping Yah as independent and non-executive directors, effective January 1. The appointments require endorsement from independent unitholders at the annual general meeting. Yeo will also chair the nominating and remuneration committee, while Shee will be a member. The move comes after independent director Ng Shin Ein's resignation following the failed merger with ESR-Reit. The Reit rose 1.4% to S$0.355 following the announcement.

site_title: Tesla says it hit goal of delivering 500,000 cars
summary: Tesla reported delivering 180,570 cars in the fourth quarter of 2020, exceeding its goal, and reached a total of 499,550 cars for the year, a 36% increase from 2019. The company's production of 509,737 cars in 2020 was up 40% from 2019, marking a significant milestone for the electric carmaker. Despite challenges, Tesla's stock price ended 2020 at over $700, up from less than $100 in 2019, and the company reported profits in the last four quarters.

site_title: The Great British Booze cruise to France ends with Brexit
summary: The Great British Booze cruise to France, a decades-long tradition, has come to an end due to Brexit. The UK's break with the EU has led to a decrease in British buying power, travel restrictions, and a reduction in the bottle allowance, making it unprofitable for retailers like Calais Wine Superstore and Majestic Wine to continue the practice. The pandemic has also contributed to the decline, with many businesses experiencing significant revenue losses. The loss of the booze cruise is expected to have a ripple effect on the local French economy, with visitors from the UK accounting for a significant portion of spending in Calais.

site_title: Connells agrees to buy realtor Countrywide after bidding war
summary: Connells Ltd has agreed to acquire UK realtor Countrywide Plc in a cash deal valued at about £134 million (S$242 million) after prevailing in a bidding war with private equity firm Alchemy Partners. The deal, worth 395 pence per share, represents a premium of 172% over Countrywide's share price before the offer period. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2021 and will see Connells invest in Countrywide's technology and branch network, repaying all of its lenders in full.

site_title: Experts warn of IPO bubble in US
summary: US initial public offerings (IPOs) have reached a manic level, with stocks doubling in two years and volatility remaining high, prompting experts to warn of a potential bubble. Record-breaking IPOs, including those by Snowflake, Airbnb, and DoorDash, have raised $180 billion, with first-day pops in share price being the biggest in two decades. Experts point to increased share issuance, heightened volatility, and sector growth as warning signs, with a Harvard study suggesting that such conditions often precede a market correction.

site_title: China's electric vehicle industry taking off, but bubble could burst
summary: China's electric vehicle industry is growing rapidly, with the market expanding 8% last year and expected to soar 40% in 2021. Strong government support and decreasing prices have contributed to higher acceptance rates, with half of new car buyers favoring electric models. Start-ups like NIO, Xpeng, and Li Auto are leading the charge, while traditional carmakers are teaming up with tech giants to offer more affordable options. However, analysts question the sustainability of the industry's economic model, citing high valuations and government subsidies, and expect consolidations and mergers in the coming years.

site_title: Afghan journalist shot dead in car ambush
summary: Afghan journalist Bismellah Adel Aimaq, 28, was shot dead in a car ambush in Ghor province, the fifth media professional killed in the country in two months. No group claimed responsibility, and Afghan President Ashraf Ghani condemned the killing, vowing to support and promote freedom of expression. The Taliban denied involvement in the killing, which comes as violence surges in Afghanistan despite ongoing peace talks.

site_title: Bitcoin breaches US$34,000 as rally extends into new year
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high of US$34,182.75, marking a 7.8% gain, and extending its rally into the new year. The cryptocurrency has advanced nearly 50% in December, breaching US$20,000 for the first time. This comes after a severe crash in March that saw it lose 25% amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: UK PM Johnson could lose his seat and majority at next election: poll
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is likely to lose his seat and majority in the next general election, according to a new poll. The survey found the Conservatives would lose 81 seats, wiping out their 80-seat majority, while the Labour Party would win 282 seats. The Scottish National Party is predicted to win 57 of the 59 seats in Scotland, potentially playing a key role in forming the next government. Johnson is also at risk of losing his own seat in Uxbridge, west of London.

site_title: Singapore tightens rules for maritime sector after Covid cases
summary: Singapore has tightened regulations for the maritime sector amid a recent surge in Covid-19 cases. Starting January 8, shore-based personnel will need to take a pre-departure Covid-19 test before boarding ships, and routine testing will be conducted every 7 days instead of every 14. This applies to over 20,000 workers, with those not following the rules facing restrictions on boarding ships for work. The new measures aim to enhance safety and prevent the spread of the virus in the industry.

images.alt_text: Singapore strengthened regulations for workers in the maritime industry after two more Covid-19 cases were found in the last two days of December.

site_title: Vietnam reports first case of new coronavirus variant
summary: Vietnam reported its first case of the new coronavirus variant, known as "VOC 202012/01," in a 44-year-old woman returning from Britain. The variant is 40-70% more transmissible than the original virus, prompting countries to cut off travel links to Britain. Vietnam, known for its swift containment of outbreaks, has recorded 1,474 infections and 35 deaths. The country continues to operate repatriation flights to bring citizens stuck in the UK home amid the pandemic.

site_title: Deutsche Bank should play leading role in banking consolidation: CEO
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing stated the bank is gaining financial strength, positioning it to play a leading role in European banking consolidation. With a turnaround strategy in place, Sewing said the bank meets the criteria to participate in a possible consolidation, despite being an affordable target for a more valuable acquirer. Deutsche's restructuring drive is bearing fruit, with earnings and costs in its private and corporate business on track, and its investment bank outperforming expectations.

site_title: Aviation deaths rise worldwide in 2020 even as fatal incidents, flights fall
summary: Aviation deaths worldwide rose to 299 in 2020, despite a 50% decline in crashes. The majority of fatalities (176) occurred in a Ukrainian plane shot down in Iranian airspace in January 2020. The US has not had a fatal US passenger airline crash since 2009. Aviation deaths have been falling dramatically over the last two decades, with a record-low 13 fatalities in 2017.

site_title: Dizzying valuations, IPO craze tick boxes on bubble checklist
summary: The IPO market is experiencing a manic phase, with stocks valuing over $2 trillion, a level not seen since the dot-com era. The Nasdaq 100 has doubled in two years, leading to concerns about a bubble. Experts warn that current market conditions, including low interest rates and high volatility, meet criteria for a bubble. The market's recent performance defies easy explanation, with investors sitting on fat returns from 2020. Historically, similar conditions have led to market corrections, raising concerns about a potential bubble bursting.

site_title: Indonesia starts nationwide Sinovac vaccine distribution: Kompas
summary: Indonesia begins nationwide distribution of the Sinovac vaccine, developed by China's Sinovac Biotech, to its 34 provinces. The country aims to start inoculations as soon as the vaccine is approved and an emergency use authorization is issued. With over 758,000 virus cases and a 30% positivity rate, Indonesia prioritizes its 1.3 million health workers for initial vaccinations. The country has also signed deals with AstraZeneca and Novavax and developed its own Merah Putih vaccines to ensure sufficient shots for its 268 million population.

site_title: Tokyo to request new emergency declaration as Covid-19 cases climb
summary: Tokyo's governor, Yuriko Koike, will request a new emergency declaration from the central government due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. The city has seen record-high infections, with 1,337 new cases on Dec 31 and 783 on Friday. The request follows similar calls from Saitama Prefecture. Despite Tokyo's raised alert level and voluntary business closures, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has resisted reinstating a national state of emergency, opting for voluntary measures instead.

site_title: Russian annual oil output falls for the first time since 2008 on Opec+ deal, pandemic
summary: Russia's annual oil output declined to 10.3 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2020, the lowest level since 2011, due to a global deal to cut output and sluggish demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The decline was in line with expectations and followed Russia's voluntary cut of over two million bpd in April. Opec+ is expected to release an extra 500,000 bpd into the market in January, and Russia plans to support a gradual increase in Opec+ output by 500,000 bpd starting in February.

site_title: Top stock pickers crush S&P while failing to stem outflows
summary: Top-performing stock mutual fund managers, such as Bill Danoff's Fidelity Contrafund, have beaten the S&P 500 in 2020, but still saw significant outflows of $23.4 billion. This trend is expected to continue, with the industry facing its worst year of outflows, around $500 billion. Meanwhile, passive investing in equity exchange-traded funds (ETFs) has seen over $200 billion in inflows, driven by their lower fees and tax-efficient structure. The shift towards indexing is seen as a permanent threat to actively managed funds.

site_title: India gives final urgent-use approval to AstraZeneca and local Covid vaccines
summary: India's Drugs Controller General VG Somani has given final approval for the emergency-use of two COVID-19 vaccines: the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine with a 70.42% efficacy rate and Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, deemed "safe" with a robust immune response. The AstraZeneca vaccine is being manufactured locally by the Serum Institute of India, while Bharat Biotech is partnering with the Indian Council of Medical Research. This move aims to boost India's vaccination efforts amidst the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Fiat and PSA's against-all-odds merger nears the finish line
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and PSA Group are set to finalize their merger, forming Stellantis, the world's fourth-largest automaker. After two years of negotiations, the deal is expected to receive shareholders' approval at separate meetings on Monday. The merger aims to boost returns through increased scale, comparable to Volkswagen and Toyota Motor, and enhanced resources to compete in the electric vehicle market and against tech industry players. The deal has endured extraordinary drama, including a short-lived attempt to join forces with Renault.

site_title: UK government tells London's primary schools to stay closed
summary: The UK government has ordered all primary schools in London to remain closed for the start of the new term due to a surge in hospitalisations from the mutant strain of the coronavirus. From Monday, most pupils will have to attend remote learning, except for vulnerable children and key worker children. Pre-schools will continue to operate normally. The decision comes after the city's high Covid-19 infection rate, with 807 cases per 100,000 people, prompting the government to take action to protect the public and reduce the spread of the disease.

site_title: 940,000 HDB households to receive final GST rebate payout in January
summary: About 940,000 eligible Singapore Housing Board (HDB) households will receive a final goods and services tax (GST) rebate payout in January, totaling S$630 million. Larger families with five or more members will receive 2.5 times the regular rebate. The value of the vouchers varies based on the type of HDB home, with one- and two-room flats receiving S$100 and five-room and executive flats receiving S$60. This is the final round of distribution for the financial year, following earlier payouts in April, July, and October.

site_title: 'Cheap trick': China rebuffs latest Taiwan offer of talks
summary: China has rebuffed Taiwan's latest offer of talks, calling it a "cheap trick" and provocation. China views Taiwan as its own territory and cut off formal talks in 2016 after President Tsai Ing-wen was elected, citing her as a separatist. Taiwan's President Tsai offered talks as equals, but China sees this as a sign of provocation. The two sides have been escalating tensions, with China increasing military activities near Taiwan and the US supporting the island. China urges Taiwan to stop seeking independence and "dialogue" with Beijing.

site_title: The Gulf Cooperation Council: a bloc in crisis
summary: The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), a bloc of conservative Sunni monarchies, is in crisis. The group, comprising Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, UAE, and Qatar, has been plagued since 2017 when Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Bahrain severed diplomatic ties with Qatar. The crisis has hindered regional cooperation and economic stability, with the bloc sitting on a third of the world's oil reserves. The GCC's future remains uncertain as it prepares to meet in Saudi Arabia, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: Washington has been lucrative for some on Biden's team
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's Treasury secretary choice, Janet Yellen, collected over $7 million in speaking fees from major corporations and Wall Street banks. Yellen's payments included $992,000 from Citi. Biden's choices for secretary of state, Antony Blinken, and director of national intelligence, Avril Haines, also received significant payments from corporate interests. The disclosures have raised concerns among progressive activists about the influence of special interests on the incoming administration. The officials have pledged to abide by conflict of interest rules, but critics argue that the payments create an "unfortunate circumstance."

site_title: Metro Holdings unit acquires 26% stake in portfolio of 14 industrial, logistics properties for up to S$76.6m
summary: Metro Holdings has acquired a 26% stake in a portfolio of 14 industrial, logistics properties in Singapore for up to S$76.6 million. The portfolio includes six industrial properties, one business park, and nine logistics properties. The properties are strategically located near transportation nodes and are expected to enhance Metro Holdings' presence in the market. The acquisition is part of the company's efforts to expand its Singapore footprint.

site_title: A dozen US senators plan to oppose Biden certification
summary: A group of 11 US Republican senators, led by Ted Cruz, plan to challenge Joe Biden's election win in a joint session of Congress on Wednesday. They will demand a special commission to audit the election results and potentially revise vote totals, despite courts and officials finding no widespread voting problems. The effort is likely to fail, with most Democrats and several Republicans expected to oppose it. The move is seen as a last-ditch attempt by former President Donald Trump to undermine the election result.

site_title: Can fund managers spot winners in the digital age?
summary: The CFA Society Singapore questions whether fund managers can identify winners in the digital age. As traditional markets are disrupted by startups, businesses must adapt to technology to thrive. The Internet of Things (IoT), 5G, and Artificial Intelligence (AI) enable customer preferences to be satisfied at a granular level, driving loyalty to those who can consistently deliver. Fund managers must consider how to capitalize on this shift to remain competitive in the market.

site_title: The rise of working out while working from home
summary: The rise of working out while working from home has gained mainstream appeal, driven by millennials' obsession with self-improvement and productivity. A survey found 71% of millennials' work demands interfere with their personal lives, leading to the adoption of desk-bike hybrids and ellipticals for workstations. Experts believe this trend is beneficial for steady state cardio but may lack sunlight and fresh air, and some people struggle with working out at home due to the lack of camaraderie and uncertainty. The trend is attributed to anxiety and the drive for self-worth, with some seeing it as a way to validate themselves during the pandemic.

site_title: Man United close in on Liverpool with 2-1 Villa win
summary: Manchester United secured a 2-1 home win over Aston Villa, moving level with leaders Liverpool on points and games played. The victory extended United's unbeaten league run to 10 games, with Bruno Fernandes scoring the winning penalty after Bertrand Traore's equalizer for Villa. United trail Liverpool on goal difference but will look to close the gap when they face their rivals at Anfield on January 17.

site_title: AstraZeneca expects to supply two million doses of Covid-19 vaccine every week in the UK
summary: AstraZeneca expects to supply 2 million doses of its Covid-19 vaccine to the UK every week by mid-January, according to a report. The company aims to reach a total of 2 million doses by the end of January, with plans to increase supply rapidly. The vaccine, developed by Oxford University, has been approved for use in the UK. The increased supply is seen as a positive development for the country's efforts to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Dow, S&P 500 end 2020 at record highs despite economy ravaged by Covid-19
summary: US stocks ended 2020 at record highs despite an economy ravaged by the Covid-19 pandemic, with the S&P 500 gaining 16.3% and the Dow 7.2%. The gains were fueled by massive fiscal and monetary stimulus, progress on a vaccine, and a shift in investor sentiment towards a post-pandemic world. Despite an uneven recovery, tech and consumer discretionary sectors led the year's gains, while energy was the weakest. Mega-cap companies like Amazon and Apple drove the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to record highs.

site_title: Alarm in France after 2,500 mass for illegal rave
summary: In France, 2,500 partygoers attended an illegal New Year's rave in Lieuron, sparking concern over coronavirus spread and violent clashes with police. The event, which included people from across France and abroad, was set up despite a nationwide 8pm curfew and mass gatherings ban. Police failed to stop the event, and many attendees showed little social distancing. Authorities have launched an investigation and deployed 132,000 police nationwide to ensure security.

site_title: New Year arrives with US hitting 20m Covid cases
summary: The US marked the New Year with 20 million Covid-19 cases, surpassing the global milestone. The country has struggled to contain the virus, with over 346,000 deaths and a vaccination program hindered by logistical issues. Despite nearly 2.8 million people receiving their first doses, the pace of inoculation is behind President Trump's promise of 20 million by year-end. The World Health Organization granted emergency validation to the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, but experts predict a sharp rise in cases and deaths after holiday gatherings.

site_title: A missed opportunity to bolster KL-Singapore connectivity
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have officially canceled their planned high-speed rail (HSR) project, which aimed to connect the two neighboring cities in just 90 minutes. The project, stuck in limbo for over two years, was expected to bolster connectivity between the two nations. The joint statement released on January 1, 2021, confirmed the project's demise, marking a missed opportunity for improved transportation between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore.

site_title: Australia's NSW makes masks mandatory as virus cluster expands
summary: Australia's New South Wales (NSW) made masks mandatory and imposed new restrictions as its COVID-19 cluster expanded to 7 cases, with neighboring Victoria reporting 10 new cases. NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian reduced gym classes, banned dancing and singing at nightclubs, and restricted numbers at weddings and funerals. Despite the measures, the 5-day Cricket test match will proceed with 50% capacity. Victoria also made masks mandatory and shut its border to NSW, citing genomic sequencing showing a direct link between the two outbreaks.

site_title: Volatile commodity markets end 2020 strong with vaccines, stimulus in sight
summary: Global commodity markets ended 2020 on a strong note, driven by recovering demand and widespread stimulus packages following the COVID-19 pandemic. Vaccine rollouts and trillions of dollars in fiscal support are expected to boost investment and spending in 2021, spurring demand for raw materials. Commodity futures such as iron ore, silver, and copper saw significant gains, with iron ore futures up around 50% and silver up 47.9%. Energy prices also rose, with Asian LNG prices gaining over 140% in 2020, and global oil futures notching an annual decline of over 20%.

site_title: Lakers take down Spurs for second time in three days
summary: The Los Angeles Lakers defeated the San Antonio Spurs 109-103 on Friday, their second win in three days. Anthony Davis had 34 points and 11 rebounds, while LeBron James added 26 points, 11 rebounds, and 10 assists. The Lakers took the lead with 28.6 seconds remaining, with Davis sealing the win with two free throws. The Spurs were led by Keldon Johnson with 26 points, and the game was closely contested throughout, with neither team leading by more than seven points.

site_title: Sunpower Group divests non-core business for 2.3b yuan in management buyout
summary: Sunpower Group is divesting its manufacturing and services (M&S) business for 2.3 billion yuan in a management buyout, with 1.3 billion yuan allocated for a proposed special dividend. The company will fully sell its indirect wholly owned subsidiary Sunpower Technology (Jiangsu) Co as part of the deal. The special dividend will amount to 1.1627 yuan per share on a fully-diluted basis.

images.alt_text: The purchaser of the M&S business is a special purpose vehicle (SPV) called Nanjing Sunpower Holdings Co, incorporated in China. The SPV is equally owned by Sunpower Group's executive chairman Guo Hong Xin and Ma Ming, the group's executive director.

site_title: Seven wishes for golf in 2021
summary: Golf in 2021 is expected to be better despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the sport. The HSBC Women's World Championship is set to take place in February-March at Sentosa's New Tanjong course, and the Asian Tour is planning to return to its calendar. A Singaporean golfer is hoped to feature prominently in the SMBC Singapore Open, with the refurbished Serapong course ready for the event. Tiger Woods' son Charlie, 11, is expected to make a breakthrough, while the Singapore Island Country Club is set to host major events. Sponsorship is also expected to increase, with local benefactors like James Loh and Kelvin Chng contributing to local golf events.

site_title: Leaving on a jet plane, but when will we arrive?
summary: Ultra-long-range flights, currently the longest in operation, have been made possible by advancements in technology. Singapore Airlines' inaugural 18-hour flight from New York to Singapore, completed in 17 hours and 40 minutes, showcases the potential of these flights. However, critics argue that the experience is marred by cramped seating, limited entertainment options, and the psychological effects of prolonged isolation. The question remains whether travelers are ready to brave the challenges of ultra-long-haul flights.

site_title: Impress.ai uses artificial intelligence to automate recruitment process
summary: Impress.ai, a Singapore-based start-up, uses artificial intelligence to automate the recruitment process, reducing the time and effort required to find suitable candidates. Founded in 2017, the company aims to expand into regional markets. Its AI technology helps recruiters sift through CVs and conduct fairer interviews, increasing efficiency and accuracy. Impress.ai's innovative approach is poised to make a significant impact in the recruitment industry, particularly in the region.

site_title: UAE opens citizenship to select foreigners to boost economy
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has announced plans to offer citizenship to a select group of foreigners, the first Gulf Arab nation to formalize such a process. The move aims to boost the economy by attracting talent and increasing the population's economic value added. Eligible individuals, including investors, professionals, and their families, will need to meet specific criteria, such as owning a property, obtaining patents, or having creative talents. The citizenship will be granted through a nomination process by the UAE cabinet, local courts, and executive councils, with the right to keep their existing citizenship.

site_title: With little ado, a divided UK casts off into the Brexit unknown
summary: The UK officially left the European Union at midnight on January 1, 2021, marking a significant geopolitical shift for the country. After 48 years of EU membership, the UK entered a post-Brexit future, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson promising to build a "global Britain" and remain a "quintessential European civilisation". However, the country's economic future remains uncertain, with concerns about trade disruption and the potential weakening of Western economic and political stability.

site_title: Rebuking Trump, Republican-led Senate overrides defence bill veto
summary: The US Senate, led by Republicans, has overridden President Donald Trump's veto of the $740 billion National Defense Authorization Act for the first time in his nearly four-year presidency. The override, which received bipartisan support, was 81-13 and marked a rare instance of Republican lawmakers standing up to Trump. The vote came as Trump lashed out at his fellow Republicans and Democrats over his vetoes, and amid pressure from his allies to object to the election results. The override is seen as a rebuke to Trump's attempts to influence the outcome of two US Senate runoff elections in Georgia.

site_title: Can 4 seconds of exercise make a difference?
summary: A new study found that brief, intense exercise intervals of just 4 seconds can significantly improve health and fitness in sedentary adults aged 50-68. Participants, who completed a 3-6 minute workout 3 times a week, showed substantial gains in fitness, muscle mass, and strength. The study suggests that even short bursts of high-intensity exercise can produce outsize benefits, making it a feasible option for those with limited time. The researchers believe that similar workouts, such as sprinting or vigorous jumping, can be done in shorter intervals, making intense exercise accessible to more people.

site_title: Malaysia to lose billions of ringgit in revenue after HSR termination: Najib
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak claims the KL-Singapore high-speed rail project's termination will cost Malaysia billions of ringgit in lost revenue, with potential losses of RM625 billion over 50 years. The project's rerouting to Johor Bahru is expected to result in Malaysia losing trillions of ringgit in the next 20 years. Najib cited the potential increase in tourism from Singapore, which could have brought in RM125 billion annually. Malaysia must now compensate Singapore for the costs incurred for allowing the bilateral agreement to lapse, with the exact amount yet to be determined.

site_title: HSR termination could slow increase in Jurong property prices
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project has been terminated, potentially slowing the increase in property prices in the Jurong area. However, experts focus on the broader plans to decentralize the CBD and longer-term outlook for the area. While the HSR's cancellation may ease pressure on prices, other factors such as the rejuvenation of Jurong as a second CBD and the development of the Jurong Lake District could still deliver benefits. Some experts predict a slower pace of price increases, but others worry about the impact on the tourism sector and potential corrections in property prices.

site_title: CIC aims to revolutionise commodities trading
summary: Commodities Intelligence Centre (CIC) aims to revolutionize commodities trading by facilitating online business-to-business (B2B) trades, reducing transaction costs for buyers and sellers. Launched in 2018, the platform has over 5,200 registered users across 64 countries, offering a range of commodities. CIC's blockchain solution, Trade Pro, provides transparency, traceability, and data security. Companies like BlackGold Natural Resources see benefits in online trading, but others, such as Geo Energy Resources, are cautious due to concerns over access to end-consumer credit profiles.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: StarHub priced S$200 million worth of notes at 2.48% due 2031. Jumbo Seafood opened its 19th location in Fuzhou, China, while ABR Holdings' joint venture Baywind Properties won a tender for three freehold properties in Singapore. Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may be below target, and the US stock market edged down amid tariff threats.

site_title: To beat Covid, politicians need to think like philosophers
summary: Politicians are struggling to effectively distribute COVID-19 vaccines, despite having months to prepare. The issue highlights the need for policymakers to think critically and make difficult decisions, rather than simply following emotions or short-term gains. Philosophical approaches, such as those of Immanuel Kant and John Stuart Mill, can inform these decisions, weighing the moral and utilitarian implications of actions. The author argues that a more thoughtful and balanced approach is necessary to address the pandemic effectively and restore trust in government leadership.

site_title: New train hall opens at New York's Penn Station, echoing building's former glory
summary: New York's Penn Station has unveiled a $1.6 billion, 255,000-square-foot train hall, dubbed the Moynihan Train Hall, designed to alleviate overcrowding. The facility features over an acre of glass skylights, art installations, and 92-foot-high ceilings, likened to the iconic Grand Central Terminal by Governor Andrew Cuomo. The hall serves primarily Amtrak passengers, with Long Island Rail Road commuters using the existing Penn Station. Critics argue the project doesn't address the station's capacity issues, but the new hall is expected to reinvigorate the surrounding neighborhood and potentially attract more commuters to public transit.

site_title: China caps bank loans to real estate to curb systematic risk
summary: China's regulators have introduced new caps on bank lending to the real estate sector, aiming to curb systematic risks. Effective January 1, state-owned banks are limited to lending 40% to developers, while mortgage lending should not exceed 32.5% of their total credit. This move follows a series of property curbs, which failed to dampen buyer enthusiasm, and is part of the government's efforts to stabilize the real estate market. The new mechanism aims to prevent excessive borrowing and mitigate potential risks.

site_title: US jobless claims dip but show recovery has long way to go
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 787,000 in the week ended Dec 26, a modest decrease from 806,000 the previous week. Despite this, economists remain concerned that the US job market and wider economy face an arduous recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The elevated level of claims aligns with weak economic reports, including declining consumer confidence and spending. Economists predict further downside for retail sales and employment, but expect the negative momentum to reverse with more fiscal stimulus in January.

site_title: Ryanair forecasts biggest ever loss on virus hit
summary: Ryanair forecasts a record annual loss of 1.0 billion euros due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has ravaged demand for air travel. The airline expects a net loss of 850-950 million euros in the current year to March, with revenues plummeting 82% to 340 million euros in the third quarter. Passenger numbers have also dropped sharply, from 35.9 million to 8.1 million, and annual traffic is predicted to be between 26-30 million. Despite the challenges, Ryanair sees growth opportunities in the coming years and expects to benefit from new aircraft deliveries.

site_title: HSR termination a setback for economic co-operation
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project has been terminated due to disagreements between Singapore and Malaysia over changes to the project in light of the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite the setback, observers believe the termination is unlikely to significantly impact bilateral ties between the two countries, given their deep interdependency and historical relationship. The project's cancellation may lead to economic losses, particularly for companies that relied on the project, but it may also create opportunities for other forms of cooperation and development, such as the continued development of the RTS Link.

site_title: Sunpower Group divests non-core business for 2.3b yuan in management buyout
summary: Sunpower Group is divesting its manufacturing and services (M&S) business for 2.3 billion yuan (S$463.3 million) in a management buyout. The sale, valued at 73.1% of the group's market capitalization, will be used for a proposed special dividend and general working capital. The M&S segment, which includes high-end environmental protection products and solutions, will focus on core green investment business and pursue opportunities in China's anti-smog sector.

site_title: Reits (Jan 2-3, 2021)
summary: Reits saw a significant increase in US mortgage rates after five consecutive weeks of declines, potentially affecting the demand for Singapore prime projects. Manhattan rents reached a new record, with further increases expected. The UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at its Singapore location post-bankruptcy. These trends indicate a shift in the real estate market, with rising interest rates and increased demand for luxury properties.

site_title: Businessman Mark Wee owns 51.4% of Blumont shares after close of offer
summary: Businessman Mark Wee Liang Yee acquired a 51.4% stake in Blumont Group after a mandatory unconditional cash offer at S$0.0004 per share. He triggered the offer after buying a 50.8% stake from Malaysian businessman Siaw Lu Howe. The offer price was a 80% discount to Blumont's share price. Wee plans to review the company's business and consider disposal or cessation of underperforming businesses. He intends to keep the company listed and redeploy employees.

site_title: Keppel 'cautiously optimistic' about 2021; looks to asset-light approach, third party co-investments
summary: Keppel Corporation CEO Loh Chin Hua expressed "cautiously optimistic" views for 2021, citing the pandemic's acceleration of trends such as digitalisation and e-commerce. The company aims to monetize assets worth S$17.5 billion and achieve S$3-5 billion in asset sales over the next three years. Keppel will adopt an asset-light approach, leveraging third-party co-investments to drive growth. The company is also focusing on digital transformation, with plans to deploy proptech solutions and digitalise operations to improve productivity.

site_title: Jumbo opens second outlet in Fuzhou, China
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its second franchised restaurant in Fuzhou, China, bringing the total number of Jumbo Seafood restaurants in Asia to 19. The new outlet, located at Rong Qiao The Bund, offers a panoramic view of the Minjiang River and has a capacity for 118 seats. This marks the group's seventh restaurant in China, and CEO Ang Kiam Meng expressed excitement over the new location, citing the popularity of Singaporean dishes such as Chilli Crab and Black Pepper Crab among locals.

site_title: Duterte tightens anti-money laundering rules to avoid 'grey list'
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed a law to strengthen anti-money laundering and terrorist financing regulations, meeting a Feb 1 deadline set by the Financial Action Task Force. The move aims to avoid being placed on a 'grey list', which could delay foreign investment and subject remittances from millions of overseas Filipinos to stricter scrutiny. The law strengthens regulations ahead of a global financial watchdog's review of the country's anti-money laundering efforts.

site_title: It's all in the jeans
summary: Levi's, the iconic denim brand, is revamping its strategy to stay ahead in the market. After ending its 55-year-old distribution deal with Jay Gee Group in 2019, the company has taken a more direct approach to retail, with a focus on owned and operated stores. The move aims to give the brand a stronger presence and better control over its products and marketing. The company plans to build its NextGen store in Singapore, which will feature a Tailor Shop and digitally focused design. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Levi's has seen strong e-commerce growth, with global digital revenues growing 50% in the last year. The company is also focusing on the youth market, collaborating with iconic brands like Disney and Lego to appeal to younger consumers.

site_title: If your new year's resolution is to 'do better,' start here
summary: Luxury brands are prioritizing social and environmental responsibility, donating a significant portion of their profits to charity and supporting marginalized groups. Brands such as Bombas, Olivela, and Aether are making a positive impact through donations to homeless shelters, refugee camps, and environmental organizations. Others, like LemLem and Ubuntu Life, are empowering traditional weavers and artisans in Africa. Some brands, like DIFF Eyewear and Unlocked, are also focusing on accessibility and inclusivity through affordable products and fair labor practices. These luxury brands are redefining the concept of "doing good" in the fashion industry.

images.alt_text: LemLem (left) offers high-end, boho-style clothing for women and children, as well as gifts that use a signature woven cotton and are all handmade in Africa. For every pair of socks purchased, Bombas (right) donate another to a homeless shelter.

(Left) Sales from Bottletop's range of bags and accessories fund a foundation to help young people across the world; (Right) Nannacay provides life-changing opportunities to artisans across South America.
Elvis & Kresse repurposes leather offcuts into purses and bags, and donates 50 per cent of profits to charity.
Sneaker brand Enda aims to design and manufacture its products wholly in East Africa.

site_title: Gold prices kept buoyant by US fiscal stimulus bets and a weak dollar
summary: Gold prices ended the year on a positive note, driven by US fiscal stimulus bets and a weak dollar. The US$900 billion pandemic package and the US$1.4 trillion omnibus spending bill boosted gold prices, which rose to US$1,904 an ounce. The dollar's weakness, driven by a trade deal with the European Union, also supported gold prices. The market expects a bullish trend in 2021, with the US Senate runoff elections in Georgia and central banks' potential for additional fiscal and monetary stimulus.

site_title: StarHub prices S$200m 10-year notes at 2.48%
summary: StarHub priced S$200 million 10-year notes at 2.48% interest, with the notes set to mature on Jan 8, 2031. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate funding and investments. Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited has been appointed as the lead manager and bookrunner. The note issuance is part of StarHub's S$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme.

site_title: HSR termination could slow increase in Jurong property prices, but longer-term prospects intact: experts
summary: The termination of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project may slow the increase in property prices in Jurong, but experts believe the area's long-term prospects remain intact. The Jurong district was set to be developed for the HSR terminus, but its land will now be used for other projects.
