Savills Singapore executive director Alan Cheong predicts a slower pace of price increases, but commercial and residential properties in the area will continue to rise in the long run. The decentralization of the central business district and broader plans for the area will also contribute to its growth.

site_title: HC Surgical to acquire remaining 30% stake in subsidiary Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery
summary: HC Surgical Specialists has agreed to acquire the remaining 30% stake in its subsidiary Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery (JOES), subject to certain conditions. The acquisition is contingent upon the outcome of a Singapore Medical Council investigation into a complaint against Dr. Ong. If Dr. Ong is allowed to continue his medical practice, HC Surgical will buy the remaining shares after one year. If suspended, the shares will be purchased after one year from the end of the suspension.

site_title: Singapore in talks with India about resuming commercial passenger flights: CAAS
summary: Singapore and India are in talks to resume scheduled commercial passenger flights between the two countries, with discussions focusing on a gradual resumption. However, air travel bubbles, which grant special exemption from quarantine rules, are not being discussed. The resumption of commercial flights would not automatically come with exemptions unless agreed upon by countries.

site_title: Canadian dollar strengthens 0.4% against the greenback
summary: The Canadian dollar strengthened 0.4% against the US dollar, driven by faster-than-expected growth in Canada's economy, which grew 0.7% in November. This offset volatility on Wall Street, where investors reacted to slower-than-expected growth data. The loonie traded at 1.2780 to the greenback, up from its range of 1.2738 to 1.2874. Despite a decline in the loonie for the week, speculators have increased their bullish bets on the Canadian dollar, with net long positions rising to 13,770 contracts.

site_title: Heeton Holdings appoints new CEO
summary: Heeton Holdings appoints Ivan Hoh Chin Hiep as its new CEO, effective January 1, 2021. Hoh previously held the position of chief operating officer since October 2019. He has extensive experience in the real estate industry, having held various leadership positions at PropNex International and PropNex Investment from 2007 to 2019.

site_title: One year after lockdown, Wuhan clubbers hit the dance floor
summary: One year after Wuhan's lockdown, the city's nightlife is back with a vengeance, with young people enjoying their freedom and dancing to techno beats at clubs like Super Monkey. Masks are obligatory at the door, but inside, many clubbers remove them to socialize and dance. Authorities praise the Communist Party for eliminating the epidemic, but acknowledge the virus has changed the industry, with fewer attendees and a sense of unease.

site_title: HSR termination a setback for economic cooperation, but bilateral ties likely to remain strong
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project has been terminated due to disagreements between Singapore and Malaysia over the project's changes. Despite this, bilateral ties are expected to remain strong due to the two countries' deep interdependency. The termination is a setback for economic cooperation and potential growth in sectors like tourism and supply chains. However, the development of the RTS Link between Johor Bahru and Singapore is expected to continue, and both countries have shown a willingness to cooperate in other areas, including facilitating the movement of workers and supplies during the pandemic.

site_title: Beyond the vaccine race
summary: Robert Langer, co-founder of Moderna, is a pioneer in innovative medical solutions. He has developed an mRNA vaccine against Covid-19, which is 94.1% effective in preventing the disease. Langer believes in persistence and innovation, citing the success of mRNA technology as a key step towards ending the pandemic. He has founded over 40 biotech firms and holds over 1,400 patents, including the Millennium Technology Prize in 2008. Langer is driving innovation in areas such as diagnostics, drug delivery, and cancer treatment, and is optimistic about the future of medical progress, despite challenges such as funding and regulatory issues.

site_title: Game face
summary: Singaporean model Kaigin Yong rose to fame after winning The New Paper New Face 2017 contest, but her breakthrough came when she was spotted by Ford Models in 2018. Represented by the prestigious agency, Yong's catwalk career gained momentum, thanks to the growth of China's luxury market and broader social movements towards diversity and inclusion. Now, at 26, Yong is arguably Singapore's most successful model, having walked for top designers such as Dries Van Noten and Christian Lacroix, and representing her country on international catwalks.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend losses
summary: South Korean shares closed down 17.75 points, or 0.57%, at 3,122.56, as heavyweight names slid amid cautious investor sentiment. Investors await the Federal Reserve meeting and corporate results from US tech giants like Apple and Tesla. Foreigners were net sellers of $563.95 million worth of shares. The decline follows a 2.1% drop in the previous session.

site_title: A study of East & West
summary: Architect Woon Chung Yen, 42, incorporates Chinese aesthetics and principles into his designs, despite lacking mastery in the traditional game of Go. Born in a Mandarin-speaking household and studying Chinese as a first language, Yen brings a unique perspective to his work at Metre, his three-year-old architecture practice. He finds connections between Chinese culture and his designs, such as a curved bench in a renovation project inspired by Chinese calligraphy. Yen emphasizes the importance of finding commonality in geometry and encourages designers to "walk their own path" rather than imitating others.

site_title: The race to convert mid-careers into tech jobs
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Singapore's tech sector has seen strong hiring demand, with over 12,000 job openings available, mostly for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs). However, concerns remain about the skills and capability gap, with automation making production more efficient and potentially leading to a deficit of higher-paying jobs. To address this, the government has launched various skilling programs, including the Tech Skills Accelerator (TeSA) and partnerships with big tech companies like Google, IBM, and Microsoft. These programs aim to upskill and reskill mid-career PMETs, with some offering financial support and job matching.

site_title: Southwest Airlines makes new voluntary leave offer to cut costs
summary: Southwest Airlines is offering voluntary leave to its employees to cut costs due to high staffing levels and the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The airline plans to provide additional opportunities for employees to take Extended Time Off starting in March 2021. This comes as the US Treasury Department distributes $15 billion in payroll assistance to airlines to help workers return to jobs by March 31. Southwest had previously warned 6,828 employees that they could be furloughed. The move aims to reduce costs as the airline continues to operate with high staffing levels.

site_title: Step out in style
summary: Lunar New Year fashion and luxury watch releases are highlighted. Bottega Veneta showcases its seasonal pieces, including the Triangle bag, Yellow Tote bag, and Shell bag. Meanwhile, luxury watch brands like Patek Philippe, A Lange & Sohne, Vacheron Constantin, and Chanel unveil new novelties to celebrate Watches and Wonders 2025, including limited-edition timepieces and collaborations. Jay Chou attends Tudor's event during the watch fair, marking the brand's return to the spotlight.

site_title: A taste of home
summary: For Lunar New Year, Cold Storage offers a special dining experience with luxury ingredients and elegant side dishes. A homemade steamboat with ingredients like shabu shabu pork, grouper, and slipper lobster can be easily prepared with simple recipes from chef David Yip. Additional dishes include a refreshing abalone salad, deep-fried prawn wontons, and braised fish maw with mushroom. To complete the meal, festive oranges and exclusive drinks like Dragon Water and Jinro soju can be purchased at Cold Storage supermarkets.

site_title: A Spring awakening
summary: Cartier showcases its Lunar New Year collection, featuring iconic pieces such as the LOVE bracelet and Ballon Bleu de Cartier watch. The brand's designs evoke a sense of renewal and everlasting memories. In contrast, the luxury watch industry is abuzz with the unveiling of new novelties from Patek Philippe, A Lange & Sohne, Vacheron Constantin, and others at Watches and Wonders 2025, highlighting exceptional timepieces and limited editions to celebrate milestones and anniversaries.

site_title: The house of Hui
summary: Award-winning architect Tan Kay Ngee has designed a modern interpretation of traditional Chinese Hui-style architecture for a Singaporean client. The bungalow, located off Holland Road, features subtle Oriental influences, including a timber lattice screen and Ahlat stone, with a minimalist aesthetic. The design incorporates elements of Chinese calligraphy and aesthetics, such as the use of horizontal and vertical brush strokes, while maintaining a modern and livable space. The project showcases Tan's ability to balance traditional influences with contemporary design, reflecting the client's personality and values.

site_title: Connecting through food and relationships
summary: Chef Darren Teoh of Kuala Lumpur's Dewakan restaurant emphasizes the importance of connections and relationships in his life, particularly during Chinese New Year. Growing up in a loving Chinese-Indian home, he cherishes family reunions and traditional dishes. Teoh's restaurant focuses on locavore-centric cuisine, with a goal of authenticity and sincerity. He credits his partnership with luxury kitchen specialist Sub-Zero and Wolf for sharing his values, resulting in a long-term and meaningful relationship. Teoh's restaurant, Dewakan, now features top-of-the-line appliances from Sub-Zero and Wolf, designed to create an intimate and inviting atmosphere.

site_title: Forging a new era in Chinese cuisine
summary: Chef Edward Chong, head of Peach Blossoms in Singapore, aims to elevate Chinese cuisine to haute cuisine status by challenging traditional cooking methods and presentation. With a background in Cantonese cooking and experience in Western-leaning kitchens, Chong has transformed his restaurant into a modern, progressive space. He seeks to redefine Chinese cuisine, moving away from fusion and Western influences, and instead emphasizing classic techniques and values. Through his efforts, Chong aims to break down cultural barriers and showcase the skill and training that goes into cooking Chinese food, ultimately making a name for himself as a major player in the culinary world.

site_title: Two men extradited from Australia face US charges for US$50m text messaging fraud
summary: Two Australian and Chinese nationals, Michael Pearse and Liu Yongchao, have been extradited to the US to face charges for a $50m text messaging fraud scheme. They allegedly used "auto-subscribing" to charge hundreds of thousands of mobile phone users for unwanted messages, resulting in $9.99 monthly fees. Pearse, 52, and Liu, 33, were charged with wire fraud, conspiracy, and aggravated identity theft, and are being held in Manhattan federal court. A bail package for Pearse will be proposed on February 9.

site_title: A watch for all time
summary: IWC's Portugieser Perpetual Calendar 42 watch is set to run perfectly for nearly 500 years, until 2499, with virtually no corrections. The mechanical watch displays date, day of the week, month, moon phase, and year in four digits, and its displays can be adjusted simply via the crown. The perpetual calendar, developed by IWC's chief watchmaker Kurt Klaus, is the first to integrate the complication with an in-house movement, making it a milestone in watchmaking. The watch is available in both stainless steel and 5N gold cases, priced at S$47,800 for the boutique edition and S$32,700 for the standard model.

site_title: Bull run in China
summary: Singaporean actor and entrepreneur Lawrence Wong shares his experience of reconnecting with his cultural heritage in China. Wong, who rose to fame after starring in the 70-episode historical drama "Story Of Yanxi Palace," credits his success to hard work and adapting to the competitive Chinese market. However, he also faces challenges such as stalkers and mobs in China, and long working hours. Wong has since launched his own skincare brand, Grail, and envisions expanding into other lifestyle categories. Despite his success, Wong regrets missing Chinese New Year with his family due to the pandemic and Malaysia's quarantine rules.

site_title: Spick and span
summary: LG introduces various home cleaning and air purification products ahead of Lunar New Year, including the LG HOM-BOT robotic vacuum cleaner, LG Puri-Care 360° Double Air Purifier, and LG DUAL INVERTER HEAT PUMP DRYER. The company's ThinQ App allows users to easily manage and activate these appliances. The products aim to make cleaning and laundry easier, while also promoting good fortune and warding off bad luck during the Lunar New Year celebrations.

site_title: Pioneering spirit
summary: Longines has launched its new Spirit collection, a line of pilot watches that combines the brand's rich heritage with modern technology. The collection features two versions: a three-hand time-and-date watch and a chronograph with three sub-dials. The watches pay homage to pioneers of aviation, such as Amelia Earhart and Howard Hughes, and are powered by silicon balance springs for high precision and resistance to magnetic fields. With prices starting at under S$5,000, the Spirit collection is seen as a key to growing Longines' lead in the US$1,000 to US$4,000 segment of the global watch market.

site_title: Citicode, Artivision shareholders approve backdoor listings
summary: Citicode and Artivision shareholders approved reverse takeovers, transferring Livingstone Health to the Catalist board and Artivision Technologies to a new entity. Citicode's shareholders approved a reverse takeover of Livingstone Health, transferring its listing status to the Catalist board, and a name change to Livingstone Health Holdings. Artivision shareholders voted in support of a reverse takeover of Mobile Credit Payment. The transactions are expected to complete on February 5, with Citicode's shares to be suspended from trading on February 2.

site_title: Bullish on the ox
summary: The year of the Metal Ox, according to Chinese horoscope, is predicted to be favorable for economic recovery and long-term investments. Jaquet Droz has released four zodiac watches featuring the ox, including models in red and white gold with off-centered hours, miniature paintings, and diamond embellishments. The watches symbolize harmony between humans and nature and values such as bravery and victory. With no explosive events predicted, watch collectors may see strong returns on their investments in these timepieces.

site_title: A joyous Raffles reunion
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore celebrates Lunar New Year with special gifts, feasts, and takeaways at its iconic Grand Dame. The hotel's yì by Jereme Leung restaurant offers a range of traditional dishes, including yusheng, sautéed king prawns, and dried scallops. Guests can also enjoy a luxurious stay in the Residence Suite, complete with a full suite facility for a supplementary rate. Takeaway options include a range of dishes and set menus, as well as auspicious decorations and gifts, such as floral arrangements and custom-made wooden hampers.

site_title: Texas coast uses Christmas trees to rebuild storm-ravaged dunes
summary: The town of Surfside Beach in Texas is rebuilding its storm-ravaged dunes using recycled Christmas trees. The dunes, which were destroyed by powerful storms last year, are being rebuilt by volunteers and will be protected by the branches and needles of the trees. The technique has proven successful, as the trees will eventually deteriorate and fertilize the surrounding vegetation. The efforts aim to combat coastal erosion, which is a major problem in the area, and protect the sensitive ecosystem that includes sea turtles, birds, and alligators.

site_title: Thailand's trade ends 2020 on strong note with exports, imports returning to growth
summary: Thailand's trade ended 2020 on a strong note, with exports and imports returning to year-on-year growth for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic. In December, exports rose 4.7% and imports 3.6%. Economists attribute this to improving global demand and domestic recovery. This positive trend is expected to extend Thailand's recovery in 2021, according to Barclays economists.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers at a port in Bangkok.

site_title: Trump signs order to restrict foreign use of cloud companies
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order on his last full day in office to restrict foreign use of US cloud companies in response to a recent hacking campaign that infected software from SolarWinds and targeted government agencies. The order gives the Commerce Department authority to impose record-keeping obligations on foreign transactions and block US firms from operating in countries where products are used for malicious cyber activity. The move aims to prevent foreign malicious cyber actors from using US online infrastructure, following a breach that infected 18,000 customers.

site_title: Apple's hardware chief leaves post for unnamed new project
summary: Dan Riccio, Apple's senior vice president of hardware engineering since 2012, is leaving his post to lead a new project at the company. John Ternus, one of Riccio's top lieutenants, will replace him. Riccio will remain at Apple as a vice president of engineering and focus on the new project, which is reportedly related to Apple's hardware initiatives, including a self-driving car and headsets for augmented reality and virtual reality. Riccio has joined Apple in 1998 and oversaw the development of various products, including the iPhone and Mac computers.

site_title: DBS sees 'pre-emptive' policy response to curb higher property prices
summary: DBS Group Research suggests Singapore authorities may act pre-emptively to curb higher property prices, with possible policy changes including cutting mortgage tenures and tweaking additional buyer's stamp duty. The analysts believe an acceleration in property prices exceeding 5% will tip the market into "bubble territory," putting pressure on household affordability ratios. A further tweak to the additional buyer's stamp duty, particularly for investors and foreigners, and shortening of mortgage tenures could be effective in countering the impact of ample liquidity and a low interest environment.

site_title: Riverstone acquires more land to ramp up production for cleanroom gloves
summary: Riverstone Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary, Riverstone Resources, acquired 6,741 square meters of industrial land in Malaysia for RM5 million (S$1.6 million) to expand production capacity for cleanroom gloves and other operations. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on the group's consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. The land is located in the Bukit Beruntung industrial area in Selangor, Malaysia, and will be funded by internal resources.

site_title: Support green finance, cash-strapped businesses; greater food security: KPMG
summary: KPMG has proposed a Budget 2021 plan for Singapore, focusing on supporting green finance, cash-strapped businesses, and food security. The plan includes a special grant of up to S$250,000 for sustainable finance deals, grants to co-fund sustainability team salaries, and property tax rebates for green buildings. To address food security concerns, KPMG suggests tax incentives for agri-tech and aqua-tech companies, as well as enhancements to the R&D Tax Incentive Scheme. The plan aims to help Singapore emerge from the pandemic crisis stronger and more resilient.

images.alt_text: Ajay Kumar Sanganeria, partner and head of tax at KPMG in Singapore, said Singapore can become a green finance hub by facilitating sustainable finance deals in line with international standards and regulations.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 task force mulling new restrictions ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 task force is considering new restrictions ahead of Chinese New Year, citing potential for increased intermingling and interactions. Education Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the task force is weighing additional measures to control the spread of the virus. This comes after a new cluster has formed, the first in months. The task force, led by Health Minister Gan Kim Yong, will assess the need for new restrictions.

site_title: The law's middleman
summary: David Grief, CEO of Essex Court Chambers Duxton, sheds light on the profession of a barristers' clerk, often referred to as "middlemen" who manage lawyers' work, business, and personal lives. With over 50 years of experience, Grief identifies more with "senior barrister's clerk" due to the term's negative connotations in Singapore. He oversees the chambers model, where lawyers operate independently, and clerks handle business development, client management, and fee negotiations. Grief's role is multifaceted, involving empathy, business acumen, and conflict resolution. He has expanded the chambers' reach through mooting competitions and public international law initiatives, aiming to establish Singaporean lawyers as experts in the International Court of Justice.

site_title: China defends early actions on Covid-19 after panel report
summary: China has defended its early actions against the Covid-19 outbreak, stating it immediately notified the World Health Organization and took strict prevention measures. China's National Health Commission said the WHO panel's interim report criticizing the country's response was "inconsistent with the facts." The report, led by former New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark and former Liberian President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, suggested Chinese officials could have applied public health measures more forcefully in January 2020 to curb cases. China's defense comes amid concerns its early actions may have contributed to the global spread of the virus.

site_title: China clocks 2.3% growth in Q4, expected to expand further this year
summary: China's economy showed resilience in the fourth quarter, with GDP growth beating expectations at 2.3% in 2020, making it the only major economy to avoid contraction. The economy is expected to expand at 8.4% this year, the fastest pace in a decade. The country's strict virus curbs and government-led policy stimulus helped contain the Covid-19 outbreak and boost momentum. Despite a weak consumption sector, China's manufacturing sector continued to gain momentum, with industrial output rising 7.3% in December. The economy remains poised to power ahead of peers, but faces challenges such as rising labour costs and a recent spike in credit defaults.

site_title: Boeing MAX buyer Air Lease mulls reinstating cancelled orders
summary: Air Lease Corp, one of the world's largest aircraft leasing firms, is considering reinstating some cancelled Boeing 737 MAX orders, with chairman Steven Udvar-Hazy saying the move would likely be made once regulators clear the jet's return. Air Lease had 107 unfilled MAX orders, but the COVID-19 pandemic and grounding led to over 1,000 orders being cancelled. Udvar-Hazy expects to firm up its fleet plans by summer, with a focus on the -8 and -9 versions of the MAX, and notes that Airbus may eventually capture 65% of the global narrow-body market due to its superior economics.

site_title: Asean fintechs may list in US market on dual-listing track
summary: Asean fintech companies, particularly those in Indonesia and Singapore, may list in the US market, taking advantage of the surge in demand for regional growth stocks. Citi's Asean head of corporate and investment banking, David Biller, predicts dual-listing in both the US and home markets for some fintech companies. The strong performance of Nanofilm, listed in Singapore last year, has pointed to growing demand for growth stocks in the region, with Singapore-based investors showing interest in companies without direct comparables.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.99 points, or 0.55%, to 1,618.02. The market saw a higher volume of 1.09 billion lots worth RM447.52 million, but more losers than gainers, with a ratio of 435 to 248. The decline follows a global trend, with stocks in Europe and the US also experiencing downward movement.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'high degree of uncertainty' in global outlook
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva expressed concerns about a "high degree of uncertainty" in the global economic outlook, citing the need for more resources to support heavily indebted countries. The IMF is seeking to expand its liquidity, but the US, the largest shareholder, has blocked a new allocation of Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) since it would benefit richer countries. Georgieva plans to consult with member countries on options for expanding liquidity, and a possible sale of IMF gold reserves is being discussed. The IMF expects the Group of 20 to extend the moratorium on debt payments for the poorest countries.

site_title: CDP account holders will soon be able to access their portfolios via SingPass
summary: Singapore's securities depository system is moving towards a unified national one-step financial planning service, SGFinDex. Starting February 1, eligible Singaporeans and permanent residents with CDP accounts can access their portfolios via SingPass, allowing online viewing of account statements and portfolio information. Work pass holders will have access by mid-2022. This service expands on SGFinDex's existing capabilities, which allow users to retrieve personal financial information from participating banks and government agencies.

site_title: India proposes stricter regulations for large shadow banks
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has proposed stricter regulations for large shadow banks, aiming to prevent financial instability. The proposal, which includes a four-tiered structure and higher risk appetite limits, targets 25-30 non-banking financial companies (NBFCs) with significant size and interconnectedness. The regulations will bring these entities closer to state-owned and private commercial banks. The move is in response to the 2018 collapse of an infrastructure financing firm and subsequent defaults by other NBFCs.

images.alt_text: The RBI has proposed introducing a four-tiered structure for better regulation of non-banking financial companies, with about 25-30 of the nine thousand plus firms falling under the upper or second layer of the strictest regulations.

site_title: Mattress, McDonald's, moaning: tennis tactics for Aussie isolation
summary: Australia's top tennis players, confined to hotels for 14-day quarantine, are finding creative ways to cope with isolation. Some, like Belinda Bencic and Pablo Cuevas, are using unconventional training surfaces, such as hotel windows and mattresses. Others, like Benoit Paire and Damis Dzumhur, are ordering fast food, including McDonald's. Meanwhile, some players are criticizing the hotel food and quarantine rules, with one, Sorana Cirstea, saying she wouldn't have traveled to Australia if there was a chance of hard quarantine. Former tennis coach Roger Rasheed advises players to focus on their conditioning and be grateful for the opportunity to compete during the pandemic.

site_title: STI retreats to under 3,000, even as non-oil domestic exports rise
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped to 2,990.40 points, down 0.48% from the previous day, despite a 6.8% year-over-year gain in non-oil domestic exports. The STI's worst performer was Singapore Airlines, shedding 2.51%. Fu Yu Corp halted trading after experiencing unusual price and volume movements. Despite the decline, the STI remains near its upside cap of 3,050, according to DBS Group Research.

site_title: Calls for masks outside in UK as London market imposes rule
summary: London's historic Borough Market has become the first UK outdoor public place to make face coverings mandatory, with customers and stall holders required to wear masks to prevent the spread of a new virus strain. The market's decision comes as the UK struggles to combat a surge in infections, with scientists divided on the effectiveness of wearing masks in public spaces. Despite the government's reluctance to tighten mask-wearing rules, police are threatening tougher penalties and supermarkets are introducing security guards to enforce compliance.

site_title: Greening architecture
summary: Atelier Ten, a London-headquartered architectural and engineering firm, has been a prominent player in Singapore's iconic landmarks, including the Esplanade, Gardens by the Bay, and Jewel Changi Airport. Founded by Patrick Bellew in 1990, the firm has grown to over 320 employees across Asia, Australia, and the US. Bellew attributes the firm's success to its "game-changer" approach to problem-solving and its focus on sustainability. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, Atelier Ten has continued to secure projects, including Google's HQ in London and a hotel inside a mountain in Saudi Arabia. The firm's emphasis on sustainability and its ability to work on a broad range of building types have positioned it well for future growth.

site_title: Hin Leong Trading's judicial managers given more time to restructure firm
summary: The Singapore High Court granted a three-month extension to Hin Leong Trading's judicial managers to restructure the firm, subject to certain conditions, until February 3, 2021. This follows an application by the managers to extend the original judicial management order, which is set to expire on February 3. The extension allows time for the managers to complete the restructuring process, which includes the sale of assets and the recoupment of $4 billion in debt owed to 20 banks.

site_title: Avarga leads buybacks; director filings decline ahead of earnings
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 3.2% over five trading sessions, reaching a 5.5% total return for the 2021 year to Jan 14. Avarga led share buybacks with 10 million shares purchased for S$2.96 million. Director and substantial shareholder transactions were also reported, including a 7.43% stake in ParkwayLife Reit and increased stakes in Yinda Infocomm and SingHaiyi Group. The STI's top-performing stocks included DBS Group Holdings, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank.

site_title: HDB rolls out one-stop portal that lists new flats up for sale
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched a new one-stop portal to make it easier to buy and sell HDB flats. The portal, called the HDB Flat Portal, will provide a single integrated platform for homebuyers and sellers to gather information on flat listings, financial calculators, and loan listings. The launch comes after a series of engagement sessions with industry players, and is part of the HDB Resale Portal, which has halved the time needed for resale flat transactions from 16 weeks to around eight weeks.

site_title: HC Surgical Specialists reports H1 net profit of S$5m, buoyed by fair-value gain
summary: HC Surgical Specialists reported a net profit of S$5 million for the first half of 2021, more than doubling its earnings from the previous year. The company's revenue rose 12.4% year-over-year to S$10.99 million, driven by a fair-value gain of S$1.54 million. The gain was attributed to increased share prices of Medinex and Singapore Paincare Holdings. Despite foreign patient volumes falling during the pandemic, the company has seen strong demand from the local population. An interim dividend of 1.7 Singapore cents per share was recommended.

site_title: Singapore Airlines readies debut US-dollar bond; bookrunners circulate term sheet
summary: Singapore Airlines is set to issue its first US-dollar bond, with Citigroup as sole global coordinator and BofA Securities and HSBC as joint bookrunners. The airline aims to diversify funding, following successful past fund raisings. The deal's size will be determined on Tuesday after briefings with investors in Asia and Europe. The airline expects passenger levels to be around 25% of pre-Covid levels by March, with plans to fly to nearly 45% of pre-crisis destinations.

site_title: Mimecast says hackers hijacked its products to spy on customers
summary: Mimecast, an email security provider, reported that hackers hijacked its products to spy on customers, affecting around 10% of its 36,000 customers. The attack, linked to a sophisticated threat actor, exploited a compromised certificate to access connections between Mimecast's products and Microsoft's cloud services. Three cybersecurity investigators suspect the hackers are the same group that breached US software maker SolarWinds and sensitive US government agencies, with Russia being blamed by US intelligence agencies. Mimecast's investigation is ongoing, with the company declining further comment.

site_title: China's industrial output rises 7.3% y-o-y in December; retail sales miss forecast
summary: China's industrial output rose 7.3% year-over-year in December, exceeding expectations, marking the ninth consecutive month of expansion. Retail sales, however, missed forecasts, growing 4.6% year-over-year, down from November's 5.0%. Fixed asset investment increased 2.9% in 2020, slightly below forecast. The data suggests China's post-Covid recovery is ongoing, but raises concerns about policymakers facing pressure to slow growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise ahead of US stimulus plan, New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,715.3 points, driven by anticipation of a US$1.9 trillion stimulus package from President-elect Joe Biden. Tech stocks led gains, with Afterpay and Altium rising 3.9% and 2.1%, respectively. Mining stocks also advanced, with Champion Iron and Orocobre gaining 4.2% and 2.6%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index remained flat at 13,107.29 points, poised to lose more than 3% for the week.

site_title: Facebook executive says 'no plans' to end Trump ban
summary: Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg stated that the platform has no plans to lift the indefinite suspension of outgoing President Donald Trump's accounts. The suspension was imposed after the violent US Capitol invasion by Trump supporters. Facebook has also taken steps to combat disinformation and remove content that could incite violence, including suspending accounts and groups related to the phrase "stop the steal." The platform aims to ensure its service is not used for malicious purposes and is open to working with the Biden administration to promote regulation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 16.08 points, or 1.01%, to 1,575.89. Volume was 535.71 million lots worth RM248.67 million. Losers beat gainers 474 to 126. The decline follows a broader market trend, with US stocks also edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Retail goes live(stream)
summary: Livestream e-commerce has become a growing trend in the retail world, with South-east Asia leading the way. The technology has attracted major brands and sellers, generating significant sales and attention. In China, the market for livestream e-commerce is expected to hit $2 trillion in 2021, with a penetration rate of 14.3%. In South-east Asia, consumers frequently shop via livestream sales, with a median of about three days between purchases. Retailers are finding the technology attractive due to its ability to inject trust and authenticity into the online shopping experience, with lower marketing costs and increased reach. However, challenges such as finding talent and logistics remain, with some firms innovating solutions to overcome these hurdles. Industry players are confident that livestream e-commerce is here to stay, with growth expected to continue even as Covid-19 restrictions ease.

site_title: US: Dow Jones ends at record as stocks shrug off Capitol Hill unrest
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a fresh record, ending at 30,829.40, despite unrest in Washington after President Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol. The S&P 500 gained 0.6% to close at 3,748.14, while the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.6%. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to the expectation of a transition to President-elect Joe Biden's administration and a removal of domestic unrest.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Wall Street loss, virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on January 5, 2021, due to falls on Wall Street and concerns over the pandemic spread. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.34% and the Topix index fell 0.26%. The lower opening was attributed to ongoing jitters over the pandemic and upcoming US Senate runoff elections.

site_title: Dr Martens considers London IPO
summary: Dr. Martens is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in London, with private equity owners Permira and existing shareholders planning to sell down their stakes. The IPO would give the company a free float of at least 25% and would not involve selling new shares. Permira acquired Dr. Martens in 2014 for $463.26 million, increasing the firm's global presence and reporting average 2-30% revenue growth. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are joint global co-ordinators for the offering, with Barclays, HSBC, and others serving as joint bookrunners.

images.alt_text: Dr Martens had revenues of 672 million pounds in the year ended March 31, 2020.

site_title: Hedge funds bet on recovery in 2021
summary: Global hedge funds are optimistic about a speedy recovery in 2021, driven by pent-up demand for travel and leisure. Despite the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, hedge funds showed resilience, with many outperforming the market. Investors expect sectors such as energy, retail, and financials to rebound in 2021, with some predicting a "super growth" period. Experts forecast a decrease in uncertainty and an increase in certainty in the new year, with macroeconomic trends and currencies expected to perform well.

site_title: Local and loving it
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singaporeans can discover local heritage and support small businesses through various initiatives. JalanJalan.me, a community project, highlights hidden shops, artisans, and eateries in neighborhoods like Ang Mo Kio and Clementi. Urban farms like Sprout Hub in Choa Chu Kang offer space for urban farmers to grow various crops. Meanwhile, homegrown events company Cocomo Events offers glamping experiences at home, and Sunday Bedding sells quality bedlinen and lounge wear. Atlas Handcrafted and Ye Traditions also support local artisans by selling their heritage foods and traditional products, promoting the value of Singapore's culinary culture.

site_title: Major firms urge Japan to bolster 2030 renewables goal
summary: Major Japanese firms, including Sony, Panasonic, and Nissan, have urged the government to double its 2030 renewable energy target to 40-50% of power generation, citing the need to meet global climate change responsibilities. Currently, Japan aims for 22-24% of power from renewables. The 92-member Japan Climate Initiative petitioned ministers to increase the goal, citing the need for ambitious renewable energy deployment to stimulate growth and play a greater role in the global business environment.

images.alt_text: Major firms including Sony, Panasonic and Nissan on Monday urged the Japanese government to make its 2030 renewable energy target twice as ambitious.

site_title: Singapore incurred S$270m in HSR costs; removal of assets company was 'main concern'
summary: Singapore has incurred over S$270 million in costs for the terminated Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project due to Malaysia's failure to reach an agreement by the Dec 31 deadline. The main concern was the proposed removal of the assets company, which Singapore considered essential to protect its interests. The project was terminated on Jan 1, with Singapore receiving some S$15 million from Malaysia as compensation. The exact terms of compensation remain confidential due to confidentiality obligations.

site_title: Woman shot dead in US Capitol was veteran, Trump supporter: reports
summary: Ashli Babbitt, a 14-year US Air Force veteran and strong Trump supporter, was fatally shot while storming the US Capitol on January 6, 2021. Babbitt, from San Diego, was among hundreds of protesters attempting to overturn President Trump's election loss. The circumstances of her death are under investigation, with police confirming a death but not releasing details. Babbitt's husband owns a business in San Diego, and she had recently retweeted messages in support of Trump before the incident.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB maintains 'add' on Dairy Farm, raises TP to US$5.50
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" recommendation on Dairy Farm International with a higher target price of US$5.50, citing the supermarket chain operator's attractive long-term valuation and potential recovery play. Analysts believe investors should be willing to ride out volatility linked to Hong Kong's economy and Covid-19 uncertainties. The counter's valuation is seen as below the long-term average, with near-term uncertainties already priced in.

site_title: MGM seeks to buy Ladbrokes owner Entain: WSJ
summary: MGM Resorts International is seeking to buy British gaming company Entain Plc, the owner of the popular Ladbrokes brand, in a move to expand its online-gambling business. MGM made an offer to buy Entain, but exact details and value of the bid remain undisclosed. The company's move comes as casino operators look to double down on the online-gambling market. MGM and Entain did not immediately comment on the matter.

site_title: Opec crude output cuts should help US shale profits in 2021
summary: Opec's decision to cut crude production through March has boosted US shale firms' profits in 2021, with US crude oil production falling by 2 million barrels per day in the last year. Higher prices, now above $52 per barrel, will increase US producers' bottom lines despite recent cost cuts and flat production commitments. Analysts expect US shale companies to see a 32% increase in cash from operations this year, with prices needing to reach $60-$65 per barrel to restore US output by one million bpd.

images.alt_text: A decision by Opec and allied countries to cut crude production through March delivered a late Christmas present for US shale firms that have slashed costs, but any rise in prices spurred by the unexpected move may be just a modest stocking stuffer.

site_title: CGS-CIMB raises target price for Boustead Projects
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Boustead Projects to S$1.33 from S$0.95 following the establishment of its private business trust, Boustead Industrial Fund (BIF). Analyst Ong Khang Chuen sees the move as positive, enabling the company to unlock the value of its leasehold portfolio and strengthen its balance sheet. He also flags a possibility of special dividends in the near term, with dividend per share potentially reaching S$0.22 or a 26.6% dividend yield.

site_title: Joint venture between ABR unit and LWH wins tender for 3 properties worth S$23.6m
summary: ABR Holdings' joint venture company, Baywind Properties, has won a tender for three freehold properties in Lorong N Telok Kurau worth S$23.6 million. The properties, consisting of a pair of semi-detached houses and one bungalow, will be developed into apartments upon obtaining necessary approvals. The purchase price will be financed by internal resources and bank borrowings, with no expected material impact on ABR's earnings and net tangible assets.

site_title: Bitcoin shoots past US$35,000 as wild swings resume
summary: Bitcoin surged to a new all-time high of $35,842, surpassing its previous record of $35,000, after a 17% drop on Monday. The digital coin's rapid recovery suggests institutional investors are not abandoning the space, with many allocating funds to Bitcoin. Analysts point to a "clear bull market" and a "range of factors" contributing to the price swings, including a long-term price forecast of $146,000 from JPMorgan Chase. The market's maturity and increased institutional investment are seen as key drivers of the recent price surge.

site_title: Count the costs: Which comes first, wages or rents?
summary: Singapore companies are more resistant to paying higher wages, with some viewing it as an external force, whereas they are more willing to accept higher rents due to market forces. Experts attribute this to the relative scarcity of high-quality office space compared to labor, and the abundance of lower-wage foreign labor, which discourages employers from investing in employees' upskilling. The government has been hesitant to implement a minimum wage policy, instead opting for a progressive wage model, and some policymakers suggest a similar approach for rents, targeting specific segments of tenants to help.

images.alt_text: Count the costs: Which comes first, wages or rents?
Count the costs: Which comes first, wages or rents?

Grade A office space refers to those top-notch commercial premises typically located in the Central Business District and close to a train station, with characteristics such as two to three lift lobbies and smart building features.

"The problem is most of the malls are held by the main operators, monopolising the whole markets... Over the last five years, increases have been killing us softly, bleeding slowly." - Alan Goh (above), chief executive of Katrina Group.

"Employers 'cannot afford' to pay higher wages where the labour is not very productive, which is due to the fact that employers themselves do not invest in increasing productivity from domestic labour because they have the alternative of hiring cheaper foreign labour instead." - Linda Lim (above), professor emerita at University of Michigan's Stephen M Ross School of Business.

In not setting a ceiling to rental or a floor to salary - except in the three sectors where wages are low - the government is being consistent in allowing market forces to determine the prices for leasing and hiring workers, says professor of finance, economics and real estate at NUS Business School Sumit Agarwal.

"Many employers themselves have experience with deciding whether to adjust prices because there is high demand for their services or products, so while they might not like it, they can see why a landlord is justified in doing so," says Walter Theseira, associate professor of economics at the Singapore University of Social Sciences.

Tay Huey Ying, JLL Singapore's head of research and consultancy, points out that in Singapore where there are many competing uses for scarce land, the limited supply of office space relative to demand often places pressure on companies to give in to rental hikes in an upmarket.

site_title: Retail sector to see slow, steady growth in 2021
summary: Singapore's retail sector is expected to experience slow but steady growth in 2021, driven by cautious reopening of borders and containment of COVID-19 risks. Retail sales recovery has moderated, with a 0.2% month-on-month improvement in October but still down 11.2% year-on-year. Consultants predict incremental growth, with those transforming their businesses and improving e-commerce strategies more likely to survive and thrive. Key trends include social commerce, influencer marketing, and live-streaming, as well as omnichannel strategies and personalized customer experiences.

images.alt_text: As the e-commerce landscape has become more crowded, social media will play a bigger role in capturing consumers' attention.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$130m to settle criminal and civil charges
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $130 million to settle criminal and civil charges related to bribery and market manipulation. The bank will pay $80 million in criminal penalties and $43 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission for bribery conduct. In exchange, the bank won't be prosecuted for three years and wasn't required to plead guilty. The settlement follows a similar case involving JPMorgan Chase, which paid $920 million for spoofing charges. This marks another settlement by a major bank before a potential change in US administration.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's legal troubles come on top of a long downward spiral of declining revenue, stubborn fixed expenses, lowered credit ratings and rising funding costs.

site_title: PSA International joins global efforts to solve crew-change crisis, support vaccine distribution
summary: PSA International joins the Neptune Declaration and Covax programme to combat the crew-change crisis and support vaccine distribution. As a key player in global trade, PSA recognizes seafarers as frontline workers eligible for priority vaccine access. The company has also committed to enabling vaccine distribution through the World Economic Forum and Unicef Charter. This move aims to ensure seafarers' well-being and support the global supply chain during the pandemic.

site_title: Ladies in red
summary: Luxury watchmakers Piaget, Harry Winston, and Richard Mille have released limited-edition watches to celebrate the Lunar New Year, specifically the Year of the Ox. The Piaget Altiplano The Year of the Ox features an ox on a grand-feu cloisonne enamel dial, while the Harry Winston Premier Chinese New Year Ox Automatic showcases the animal in a muscular form with diamonds and an emerald-cut diamond. The Richard Mille Caliber Extra Flat Automatic RM 033 features a skeletonised automatic movement with a curved case back. Prices vary, with the Piaget Altiplano priced at S$103,000 and the Harry Winston watch available upon request.

site_title: UBS Singapore takes flight with sustainable installation
summary: UBS Singapore has launched an immersive sustainable installation, "Taking Flight," at its new office in Park Mall building to commemorate its 50th anniversary in Singapore. The installation features 3,600 butterflies and birds made from repurposed bottles, designed in collaboration with UBS staff and community partners. The bank aims to make the installation a record holder for the "Largest Display of Butterflies Made from Recycled Plastic Bottles." UBS also plans to support local community partners through its annual internal fundraising campaign.

images.alt_text: The UBS installation titled Taking Flight is located at its new office in Park Mall building. The installation commemorates UBS's 50th anniversary in Singapore in 2020, and its ongoing commitment to sustainability and community engagement.
